Faster than Curious George can get into trouble, a primate patrol captures the new arrival. After being sold into slavery, he befriends a left-leaning, pro-human chimpanzee played by Helena Bonham Carter. Along with a group of fugitive homosapiens, Wahlberg's band must elude the tyrannical military leader, Thade (Tim Roth) and flee to safety.Burton's Apes has a quirky tone. The movie isn't as substantial as the earlier incarnation - but, it is entertaining. Take a cameo by Heston. As Roth's dying father, he playfully re-visits dialogue from the first film. Given Heston's political convictions, his anti-gun rant is deliciously ironic. Remember, he's the guy  who  defiantly announces before  National Rifle Association meetings: `You can have my gun, when you pry it from my cold, dead paws.' Calm down, Moses.Make-up specialist, Rick Baker, supplies the latex for the simian characters. This guy has more Oscars than NSYNC has bad songs for good reason. Baker gives each ape its own incredibly detailed look. In a distinguished career, this film is his best work.Still, even more impressive are the actors within the monkey suits. The way Bonham Carter, Roth and their fellow contemporaries totally transform themselves with body movements, ticks and facial expressions  is outstanding.Burton gleefully turns his primates loose - letting them bound across the screen, arms flailing and voices screeching. These factors give Planet of the Apes a manic energy.Although, the movie suffers when the action shifts to the human contingent. Wahlberg is acceptable as the lead. He is distant. Still, his spaceman realizes the absurdity of his situation and just wants out. Wahlberg's detachment is an interesting counterpoint to the ape's dynamism. However, the emerging star's dour delivery does overstay its welcome by the third act.The remaining humans are sadly underdeveloped. They are bland and boring. I've seen more exciting people at Republican nominating conventions.Burton ends the film with an obligatory surprise finale. The closer is hysterical. It is more abstract than the original's final scene. But, if you take the time to piece it together, the conclusion makes perfect sense.What else could Burton do? Audience expectations are high for a shocking last act. At least he answers the call with good-natured playfulness.The new Planet of the Apes is a mixed bag. It's inventive and exciting -humorous, not campy. No, it's not the 1968 version. Who cares? Burton's movie stands on its own merits.  Still, Apes is lacking in just enough areas to hold it back.  Oh, well - better luck in the sequel.This film is a six out of ten.

title: no logic
text: Planet of Apes Score: 7 First, I haven't watched the 1968 version, so I can't make comparisons. There's no logic at all.  There are two things that are out of logic: the human sensations, and fictious stories.  I thought the only logical explanation for this story is that it's a dream.  Another explanation is that the astronaut is travelling through space-time.  But the first unlogical thing is that the Apes are speaking English(well, this is the only language they can say to show to American audiences). Well, the ending(I'm addicted to talk about endings of movies), is quite unexpected.  And it quite supports the explanation of the astronaut travelling through space-time. Okay, don't talk about the logic thing, I think this is rather a fable, to put human into an inferior position how they often treat animals.  Well, anyway, I don't think this fable thing, is quite relevant to the current world, so to speak.

title: Impressive makeup, lousy movie
text: Aside from the impressive makeup jobs, Planet of the Apes doesn't have much to offer. The plot is bland and predictable, with a heavy-handed message and an unnecessarily confusing ending. The acting is over-the-top and uneven, as well. This doesn't feel like a Tim Burton movie, which could be a good thing, because Burton should distance himself from this mess as much as possible.

title: Mark Wahlberg a bit wooden - watch the original first
text: In this version the ending is not the same as the original.  However I would strongly recommend watching the original first as it develops the idea of the human/animal relationship being turned upside down.  The original has same corny lines but that was 1968, filmakers nowadays should have no excuse.

title: I want my money back!!!
text: I have NEVER ever been do disgusted/disappointed with a movie. (Well, there was that Artificial Intelligence movie that made me laugh SO hard @ the end I had to plug my nose from laughing so hard so the REST of the people in the audience wouldn't hate me, since most of them were INTO it.!!)Please don't see this movie. It's stupid. There's nothing good about it except the makeup/costume bit. The ending was ridiculous. The acting made me vomit. There was *no* character development, and the character you DID get developed to was that stupid Chimp, who by the time made his second appearance, you wanted to leave.Come on. Really? I want my money back.

title: Just telling the truth
text: The movie although very eye entertaining was not very interesting but as the movie wore on, 2 hours doesn't seem like long enough and the twisted ending only makes it seem more ridiculous. I find it very hard to believe that throughout the whole movie,all he seemed concerned about was getting home even, though there were 2 women throwing themselves at him. Next to other noticeable errors in the movie I found it exceptional but wouldnt make an effort to see this one on video.

title: Burton's worse film!
text: I count myself very fortunate I did not see this on the big screen. I had watched snippets before and was very unimpressed. I'm one of the many that loved the original. So when Burton attempted yet another remake (and I still can't get into Alice in Wonderland as my family can), I treaded very carefully. This movie came on TV, non letterbox, not that it would matter for the piece of junk it is. Bland story, uninteresting characters....oh what a waste of time. I got about 50% of the way through, then realized I had much better things to do and wasn't going to waste my time. So I did jump to the last 10-15 minutes to catch the infamous ending. The worst Burton film of all time. He doesn't have anything close to the wretchedness of this film. Thank goodness! He's one of my all time favorites. Can't believe the total current rating is 5.5.

title: Super Monkeys!!!
text:
I see that a good film of Tim Burton (Sleepy Hollow) is very excellent his work with his beautiful equips!!! I find that the film in 1967 to 1973 is much difference with today. I want to tell you my comments of culture, costume and decoration and actor and actress.
For costumes and decoration, I find it's very beautiful decorations that he are like a real future if possible. They are very odd culture of the monkeys. They are good a color!!! I see the costumes are beautiful too!!! It's gone in film! For the actors and the actresses, Mark is cool. to play the perfect role of Leo. He is a good actor. For Tim Roth, it is played a good role of malicious!!! It's excel!!! For Helena, it is actress a little as in the film Club Fight. For Michael Clarke Duncan, it is the role of large gorilla!! It gives me fear. The others of the monkeys are differences the characters in the village. They are special culture.
I believe that Burton is a good spirit! Congratulated!!!Finally, I'm talking about my comments of costumes and decoration and actors and actresses. I hope which the film is still a sequel film of planet of the apes in Washington D.C. with the director Tim Burton and the actor Mark.

title: Apes Make Great Actors
text: What do you get when you put good actors in ape suits opposite mediocre actors in ripped clothes? The apes steal the show. That's what happened here. Whalberg and his human costars drag the movie along at an almost dead pace. Their only purpose seems to be solely to dismantle a poorly thought out story line into complete unrecognition. Carter, Roth, and Duncan however, are excellent. They're good outside of the ape suits but within them, they are transformed into sci-fi Gods. If not for them, the movie would be a B flick. The ending is completely ridiculous and practically ruins any positives you might have found within the actual film. Next time they make a movie about those apes, pick better actors to portray the humans (Heston is still king) and develop a story that actualy makes sense.

title: Slow and illogical
text:
Okay, the first Planet of the Apes (PotA) was unique and interesting in its time. But, it surely was not worthy of a remake, revisioning, or regurgitation.What is most disturbing about this movie is how slow and illogical it is. It plods along through scenes with very little energy. I kept thinking about how hot everybody must have been in those monkey outfits. There are points where Mark Walburg does the most illogical and pointless things. For example - why doesn't he ever talk! I mean if strange animals were locking me up AND they happened to also speak my language, I would make every effort to reason with them. But Mark just stands there .... duhhhh. When he finally gets a gun - which could flatten the apes does he protect it with his life - heck no. Another ape grabs it from him and breaks it.And the woman with the overly red pouty lips. What the hell was she doing there other than looking pretty? Her role has no purpose whatsoever other than somebody who can receive the animalistic affections of Mark.
This is a pathetically bad movie. Worse than I even expected. I had real high hopes for this before it came out. I was really looking forward to seeing it. All I can say is I am happy I waited until it came out on video. I would have been really p***ed to have spent $10.00 to see this piece of crap.

title: A decent spectacle
text: Tim Burton is one of the most original and appealing directors of all cinema history, but this time, he seems not to be believing in what he is doing. What is more, you can easily realize, that this is not an own fiction. It is perfectly truth that make-up, special effects, costumes design, mourning atmosphere and its production design are brilliant, but the screenplay as well as the some of the performances are uneven. The movie easily bleeds because of its narrative weakness and its forced final twist. It has also a great rhythm and spectacular action moments, by far the best, however it sinks rapidly not only because the relations between characters are a kind of childish, but also because of its sense of humor. In spite of that, it is a decent and interesting motion picture.

title: the worst ape remake since King Kong
text: I read somewhere that Hollywood should concentrate on remaking bad movies and leave the classics alone. We can only hope. While this remake wasn't a total waste, I still wish I had the six bucks back to go toward a DVD of the original. Lots of violence and one of the worst endings I've ever seen. This version doesn't add anything new. It only reiterates why Hollywood should leave the good stuff alone.

title: Burton slips slightly, but still very entertaining
text: This new version (I can't quite call it a remake) of a sci fi classic doesn't seem determined to light up brain cells, question our place in nature, or examine our society and our attitude toward "lesser beasts". It's just a good, exciting science fiction adventure film, and on that level, it succeeds quite well with only a few small stumbles.Tim Burton remains the only director I can name who has never made a film I don't like.  You might call me biased, but I do go into every new Burton film afraid that this will be the one.  Fortunately, I'm still waiting.So why is this not a remake?  Well, there are no characters from the original story (either the novel OR the film), and the situation is significantly altered.  While still being the story of an astronaut who lands in a strange new ape-dominated world, very little else is the same. Only a few lines of dialogue intended to evoke the 1968 film remind us.What's good?  First, of course, is Rick Baker's absolutely astounding makeup.  The original appliances still stand up quite well, so this was a nightmare assignment for any makeup artist.  Baker is one of the very few who could handle it, and handle it he does.  There has never been such amazingly detailed, expressive work in the history of film; the actors are able to come right through the latex and hair.  Too much praise cannot be heaped upon his work.  Then there's the patented Tim Burton visual approach; this is easily his best-looking film since "Edward Scissorhands", and really helps to lend the proceedings an otherworldly appearance.  The acting from the performers in the roles of apes is uniformly excellent, particularly Tim Roth in one of the most frightening villain roles I've seen in years.  He truly gives the impression of being dangerously unpredictable; a genuinely great movie psycho.  Mention must also be made of Danny Elfman's score, his most dynamic and interesting in years.  It recalls Goldsmith's work just enough to remind us of what we're watching, while also moving into new territory.What doesn't work?  Well, the humans.  They talk, but have nothing of consequence to say.  Why is Estella Warren so much cleaner than everyone else, and where did she get that lipstick?  And if she's intended to be a love interest for Wahlberg, shouldn't they have a conversation or two?  And sadly, we're given only the barest peek at the ape society before our heroes escape and return to the wilderness.  I really would like to have seen more of their culture.Now, the ending has already become much-debated and argued over across the Internet and elsewhere.  First off, I like the ending.  While it may not have quite the punch of the original's, I think it's a good twist for those going in expecting a twist (and weren't we all?).  Without revealing too much, let's just say that the screenwriters have obviously read the novel.In conclusion, this is an entertaining and exciting sci-fi adventure.  It won't open up your mind much, and it may not be among Burton's best works, but it's a lot of fun, and has a great deal to admire.  7 out of 10.

title: People, this is a BAD movie...
text: ...it's not as terrible as "Sleepy Hollow", but it's pretty darn bad. The only "saving" grace is pretty design and excellent ape make-up. But there is nothing else - not a damn thing else - to applaud about it. I like action and sci-fi movies as much as anyone - and I don't expect them to be "Citizen Kane." I do expect to care a *little* bit about the characters - this is really just the minimum for buying into a film's world. Unfortunately, this movie only has one performance that even qualifies (Helena, naturally) - and it can't make up for a blank "hero" and a toilet-paper-ready "script." The "surprise ending shocker" is stupid because there is no explanation for it at all to be found anywhere on this planet or another. Twists are great, but they should at least appeal to logic a little bit - and not be just completely inexplicable. If you think this movie is a ten, really, you should see more movies.

title: Burton's Monkey Mishmash
text: Tim Burton is one of Hollywood's darkest, most imaginative filmmakers, so one must wonder what went wrong with his latest venture, a reworking of the 1968 sci-fi classic, Planet of the Apes.  This is Tim Burton-lite, and as easily distinguishable as his prior films are, it's disheartening to see that he clearly gave in to Hollywood blockbuster mentality, as Planet bears no sign of his signature dark style.Planet of  The Apes is loosely based on its predecessor.  Mark Whalberg (here a cardboard cut-out action hero) stars as an astronaut who gets sucked into a time warp (?) and finds himself crash landing on a planet and captured by talking apes who have created a society where humans are their servants.  He finds a friend in female ape Helen Bonham Carter. The rest of the movie follows our hero Whalberg as he attempts to escape from his captors, in particular a nasty General played by an unrecognizable Tim Roth.The story is hardly noteworthy.  It's merely a clothesline on which to hang a few charged action sequences, grandiose sets, and the human actors eluding their captors.  What made the classic so striking was its scenes of the apes treating the humans as livestock.  Here, director Tim Burton has instead chosen to eschew characters and rely on the quality of the first film to garner any sort of sympathy for his characters.  The only likeable characters are, again, Helen Bonham Carter as an ape who sympathizes with and wants to help the humans, and Paul Giamatti, as a wise-cracking ape who by the end becomes very grating with his one-liners.The only true innovation in this updated version is the makeup; it's light years ahead of the 1968 version, and the actors disappear behind it, as well as the militarized costumes.  The apes look more ferocious, but this is a very poor substitute for an actual story.  Even the action sequences are dumbed down, with bullets and spears flying, there is no blood onscreen whatsoever.  Was it the studios who persisted in Burton to not show blood? Sleepy Hollow was a gorefest, but I imagine since this is a huge studio summer blockbuster, all controversial images and language were censored in order to have a more family oriented (money-making) movie.With all its flaws, Planet of the Apes is made watchable thanks to the amazing makeup and the performances from Roth and Bonham-Carter.  Perhaps Tim Burton will push the envelope with his next film, as here his influence seems nonexistent, except for the dark ending bound to leave audiences looking for a total mindless summer film confused.6 out of 10

title: Tim Burton ruins yet another good story
text: I can't express how much I cannot stand Tim Burton's style. In fact the only film that I enjoy of his is when he actually deviates from his usual style(Ed Wood). The irony lies in the fact that the film is about arguably the worst director of all time. He totally crapped up what could have been a great Batman movie and did the same thing with Planet of the Apes. The plot was such a snorer as it trudges along in a uneven pace. It leaves me to wonder,did he ended it so crappy as to not want to make a sequel? I anticipated the release of this film for so long and when I threw away my eight dollars and fifty cents to see it on opening night i wanted to send my bill to Burton. GOD!! WHAT A STINKER THIS MOVIE WAS!!! Roth was good though, as always. Wahlberg, not so impressive. Will somebody retire Tim Burton? please?! I once read an interview with Kevin Smith, an independent film maker, and the interviewer commented that Tim Burton stated that he had never read a comic book to which Smith replied, "Well, that explains Batman."

title: The best movie of the summer is finally here!!!
text: A lot of folks have expessed their disappointment in the final twist of the movie, but let me just say Tim Burton is one funny guy.  The end was a great twist and lent a smile to my face.  You people that hate the end, too bad. There's nothing you can do to change it, so live with it and take it for what it is, Tim Burton's sense of humor shining through. The screen play by William J. Broyles and others was fabulous, and who can say more than "The Oscar goes too...Rick Baker for Planet Of The Apes"?  Burton delivers his usual chuzpah in his own dark and twisted way, and his long time friend, Danny Elfman delivers one of his best scores ever.  If you are looking for true summer escapist fun, Planet of the Apes rules.  So, grab some popcorn and a banana and be prepared to have fun.

title: Ed Wood could have done worse.
text: The original Planet of the Apes is a deserving classic with basis in creative spins on theories of evolution and de-evolution.It was a perfect blend of science and fiction that captivated the imagination of audiences, who left the theater with a feeling of awe and wonder that few films manage to inspire.Millions of minds were seeded with a lifetime of ideas and questions of our existence, just as well as they were served pure entertainment in an exciting space-adventure with talking monkeys.33 years and several sequels later the world is still fascinated enough to give Tim Burton a chance at diluting the original concept, and what a job he did.Words fail when trying to describe the shallowness suffered when two hours of a viewers life are lost to this stupidity.The deepest thought presented is that apes playing cards would have four sleeves to cheat with instead of two.If going by the assumption that the true level of a director can be judged by their worst efforts, it can only be determined that Tim Burton is a huge hack.How fitting that it was he who made the movie about Ed Wood.

title: this is weak
text: What the hell ? This is one of the poorest films I have ever seen. At first it seemed quite average, but then, I decided to think about the ending in the context of the rest of the film. It made so little sense that I threw the DVD into space, hoping that it would travel through time a few times, and give me an idea of what happened in the film.Unfortunately I doubt there is any logical reason as to why the earth became controlled by Apes.I was never quite sure what year he was in, or what planet he was on, so I assumed -at first- that the ending made sense. Of course this later obviously became disproven. All in all there was no need for:Most of the ApesMost of the HumansThe ending

title: Why are sequels rarely as good as the original?
text: I was contemplating that question after watching remakes of The Time Machine and Planet of the Apes.  The answer of course is that people always do remakes of good movies. They really should be doing remakes of bad movies, they are ones that need it.And there is no better example of the above then The Planet of the Apes, a movie that is such a pale imitation of the original that I was angry at myself for paying $4 to see it.Tim Burton is a very good director, I'm usually a fan of his work.  But, with this movie he seems to have gotten so caught up with turning actors into monkeys that he lost sight everything else.  The movie has great makeup, but no soul.  It just reeks of being a directors vanity project. This movie far surpasses the original in it presentation of the monkey planet, i.e. make-up, effects, acting, yet is less believeable.Burton also seems to have been so consumed with his monkey cast, he forgot his humans.  It can not go unmentioned how insipid Mark Wahlberg is movie. A potted plant would have held my attention as much as he did.And finally, nothing illustrates the futility of trying to remake this movie then the "surprise ending".  Obviously, he couldn't do the same ending as the original, it wouldn't be a surprise.  So it became necessary to come up with something totally different, but would still have the power and impact of the original.  Well, I guess they couldn't think anything so they decided to go with nonsensical instead.  Yes folks, the big surprise is that the movie's ending MAKE NO SENSE!!! None, zero, zippo.

title: Good special effects and costumes; weak writing.
text: Everything about this remake was better than the original except for the screenplay and acting. The ending was inexplicable and may have set the stage for another movie. I thought the acting in both movies was about the same. Not great, not bad.

title: Not so good
text: Maybe it is because I grew up with the old Planet of The Apes, but this movie just didn't do it for me. The acting was poor and the story line was poor.  You can't make a great movie with an kick butt set, killer make-up and cool costumes alone. Was I the only one (on this planet) that noticed that the only living things on this planet were humans, apes and horses?  Hello!  Where did the horses come from?  Why no fish in the swamp where the shuttle crashed?  Why no bugs?  Why no birds?  Did I miss something?  Do I need to see this movie again?  I have also always wondered what would happen if you set an ape on fire and blasted him a hundred feet in the air.  Now I know that "nothing" happens. ------------ W H A T E V E R!  I think this movie must have had a different ending that was never put on film, because the script did not add up.  What was good about this movie again?

title: Tastes great, less filling.
text: Tim Burton does a great job on the new Planet of the Apes. He manages to make a film that will not offend the traditionalists who enjoyed the original (like me), while at the same time creating something new that audiences of today will appreciate.First and foremost, this movie looks great. Even if all other components of the movie were weak (and some are), I would still be partial to this picture. The costumes, makeup, and sets are rich and extremely authentic-appearing, and really bring to life the apes and their culture. In a movie about a different culture, this is important. (There is by no means a comprehensive vision of a simian society, but enough is touched on to give us a good taste.) Without giving away the finer details, the plot is equal to the original, and the same interesting philosophical qualities of the 1968 version are here, with the social commentary on animal treatment, tensions in communities over diversity, the place of religion within the state, etc. There is enough action to make things interesting on a primal level (the initial capture scene is much more intense in the new Apes, the apes themselves being much more intimidating), and some personal relationships also add an element to the story.Even though many of the actors are covered in convincing makeup (with the possible exception of Carter, who looks a little too cosmetic), their personalities come through, and you can buy the idea of a speaking simian. Roth is especially good--his character plays a constant game of testosterone repression that he doesn't win often. His rage is palpable. Mark Wahlberg does a much better job as protaganist than Charleton Heston could ever have done. Overall, a good job by the cast.It's still not a perfect movie, not by a long shot. The comic relief, as with all action/serious(?) movies, gets a little distracting (although, by comic relief standards, Giamatti does a pretty good job). The humans seem a little too articulate to be so "primitive", and the entire explanation as to how/when/where Wahlberg's character gets where he is is never really reasonably explained. The final scenes of the movie are downright confusing, maybe close to ridiculous (if they mean what I think they're supposed to mean), and the film would have been better had it stopped five minutes sooner.I give the movie a 7.

title: Yawn
text:
Yet another Hollywood attempt at cashing in on a proven franchise, Tim Burton's supposed "re-imagining" of the 1968 sci-fi classic Planet of the Apes is a dreadfully dull, meandering affair, which consistently fails to engage the viewer on any meaningful level. Sure, it tries to live up to the lofty social-political commentary of the original, but here there's nothing to back it up-- the plot is shallow, the dialogue lame and the characters are so underdeveloped we can hardly recall their names.
For example, near the end of the film, a human boy stands up to his ape oppressors in what I assume was meant to be a moving moment. But it has little impact because the character has never been properly introduced; the scene is the first in which he figures prominently. Similarly, two Ape generals square off at one point in what is clearly intended as a battle between two giants. But the set-up for their feud is so scant (the bland line of dialogue inserted earlier in the film) that the pay-off is virtually non-existent. They fight, one wins...whoopee.Characters like these appear throughout the film. The lead female human seems to exist solely for her cleavage; Kris Kirstofferson appears as a human male who does almost nothing and who, like his counterparts mentioned above, engages in a Big Moment that fails to have any impact. It's hard to feel bad for human slaves who are this dull. As for the apes, they're so one-dimensional they're better described as types than as actual characters. Most notably, there's the evil general (played with wonderful vitriol by Tim Roth), who seems to simply hate all humans, period. His behavior is entirely one-note: he stomps about, growls and acts viciously at every opportunity, and almost always without sufficient motivation. As a villain he's about as interesting as Skeletor was in the old He-Man cartoon. Likewise, Helena Bonham Carter's character, an ape with a soft spot for humans, is little more than a caricature of good will.Finally, the lead character, played by Mark Wahlberg, walks through the film in an apparent daze. Never does he seem amazed by this monkey planet he's landed on, nor does he appear distraught by the predicament in which he's found himself. Charlton Heston's lead character in the original POTA film may have been over-the-top in places, but he at least struck the right notes of paranoia, amazement and outrage. By comparison, Wahlberg seems drugged; and this is a problem because we're supposed to be seeing this world, at least in part, through his eyes. Recall the introductory portions of the original POTA, in which the team of wayward astronauts slowly makes their way into Ape territory. Their journey becomes stranger and stranger as they encounter human skins, a tribe of primitive humanoids, and finally the fully-clothed warrior apes. Never does this new film approach this level of horror and amazement. Instead, its protagonist runs through its world like a blip in a video game. And that's a shame.On the good side, Rick Baker's makeup is, on the whole, extraordinary; Danny Elfman's score is rich and bombastic; and the physicality of the ape characters' performances are fun in that they are much more simian in nature than those featured in the 1968 original. But even fans of Tim Burton will have a hard time finding his personal stamp on this film.
And what of the surprise ending? It's there, and it's fun. But it feels tacked on and most viewers will probably figure it out a minute or so before it actually happens.If you really want to enjoy this movie, go buy the action figures. That's the point, right?

title: Amazing
text: One of the best films ive seen.  Not just the plot but the beauty of the scenery.  Once again he created a beautiful spectacle like in Sleepy Hollow and Edward Scissorhands.  The apes looked so real, and they moved so perfectly.  An amazing film.  7-1/2 out of 10!

title: okay fun
text: The movie has some of the most elaborate makeups that somehow feel life like. All the apes walk with an "apey" wobble and the expressions they all make  give an underlying realism only Tim Burton could have brought about. However his magic was lacking from the movie. The movie seemed to have a not so convincing or involving story twists I would have attributed to a re-creation(not remake) of a classic like this.  It fails to make any lasting impression. Helena Bonham Carter does her bit well, so does the rest of the crew. Appearance by Charlton Heston (although barely recognizable) is memorable.As for the sound, it is very good. The LFEs are quite convincing and less distracting. The set of the planet matches with the score perfectly well.

title: Disappointing and confusing
text: I have seen and liked the original film, and expected more from a remake than this.GOOD: Effects and makeup are good.  No complaints about the score and visuals, they are adequate, and the performances were okay (Tim Roth was excellent, the other principals were fine, and a handful of the "supporting supporting actors" did very well with extremely limited roles).  The action scenes were exciting and fun.BAD: The escape from the ape city was terrible.  The characters are going in circles, then suddenly someplace in the middle of town there are tunnels to escape.  Plus, what escape route leads through everybody's bedroom?The story was pared down to include as much action as possible.  I like action scenes but the original film had more meat to it and deserved more respect.Finally, the ending was completely nonsensical as presented.  Without seeing the inevitable sequel, there is no justification for it.

title: Cool Movie, dumb ending
text: I enjoyed" Planet of the Apes" very much but the ending brings the rest of the film down. Tim Burton has a great eye for gothic visuals and he doesn't dissapoint here. Most of the movie is very dark and moody. The performances are good also, Mark Wahlberg does a good job playing an air force Pilot who crash lands on a different planet in time, Michael Clarke Duncan, Helena Bonham Carter, and Tim Roth also are convincing as apes from another world, the majority of this film is good, but like I said the ending brings it down, it's not totally bad but you're left saying, "oh, sure, Whatever". Other than that, I reccommend seeing this film.

title: Not a pure Burton movie but a really good entertainment !
text: I remember having seen original 'planet of the apes' when I was young. The apes at this moment didn't impressed me at all, and now I can't even remember them. In Tim Burton's you are really looking at apes. They are, I was going to say 'human', they're true. And this is a very good point for Burton, having done an impressive movie. Burton's universe is there, but not too much, I mean it's not Sleepy Hollow! Even Danny Elfman has made an effort on not doing his kind of music :) You spend a really good time, it's funny and smart, and well, Mark Wahlberg is nice!

title: Did apes make this movie
text: With some pretty amazing Makeup Effects, Visionary Director Tim Burton, and extremely talented actors like Mark Whalberg, Paul Giamatti, and Helen Bonham Carter. You'd think this would be a pretty great remake. However the story falls extremely flat and some of the acting feels like everyone is trying too hard or too little. The film is a pale comparison to the original (and the remakes that came after it), however the makeup is astonishing.

title: Okay, but no replacement for the original.
text: I saw this movie when it was first out, five years ago. I am often skeptical about remakes. This one was Okay, and worth seeing. But since that time, I have several times noted that "Planet of the Apes" was playing on one of the cable/satellite channels, and then been disappointed to find that it is the remake rather than the original. I might have watched it if it were the original. I have not yet felt inclined to re-watch the remake.Sometimes a remake is better than the original. I have never seen the original "Maltese Falcon" with Ricardo Cortez, but the remake with Humphrey Bogart is probably better. Everybody remembers the remake, many not even aware that it is a remake. I hope that, when we remember "Planet of the Apes," we will remember the original and not this lesser remake.

title: Save Your Money
text: Ok, I know this is supposed to be cheese.But will someone please entertain me! I can't imagine that Tim Burton was proud when he presented this turd to his executives for their first screening.But I did notice a few things:Marky Mark and Denise Richards must've went to the same drama club.A few under-nourished humans can put off battalions worth of Apes.Marky Mark is "special" - special because he had different clothes!An obligitory kiss with blondie - WHERE THERE NEVER WAS A RELATIONSHIP WITH THIS PERSONALITY_LESS ENHANCED-LIPPED BIMBO.There was no tension ever in this movie. I remember the original keeping me on the edge of my seat and hating the bad guys - Here there weren't any real characters - EVERY ONE WAS A CLICHE!Some of the long range scenes looked like the actors re-used the cheesy ape suit from Octopussy (or Trading Places)!I could go on - but why waste time on this. I am looking for the next American Beauty. Will I find it in Ghost World?Save your money on this beastie - 1/10.

title: A remake is a remake is a remake when the original is a standout.
text: This one isn't just a remake, it's a spinoff, a miniature update with a celluloid umbilical chord still attached to the mother film released in 1968.  This Ape movie doesn't stand on its own but lopes along in the shadows of its predecessor.  It beats the original only in the amount of violence portrayed and at the box office (which probably results from curiousity about about how they could redo the thing).Not without some clever touches but, overall, it's a massive huh?

title: Mark Wahlberg is a disaster
text:
I knew this was going to be a bad movie. I loved the original so any attempt to top it was, in my perspective, bound to fail. And surely, it did.
This is one misconceived film, and has nothing in the form of pace, believability or lovable characters. The ending (here we go again) is glued on for no apparent reason, other than trying to be true to the novel on which the film is based. The plot is more or less non-existent. And why is it that these "wild" humans, are running around with nicely combed and washed hair, and look like a million? A film such as this, has got to be more dirty. We're talking about a planet ruled by monkeys damn it! And when humans can talk and communicate with the apes the analogy to our own world is lost, along with any reason as to why Mark Wahlberg would make a difference.Speaking of; one of the main reason for the failure is Mark Wahlberg. I havent seen an actor do such a bad job in....well, ever actually. He has got the face of a robot, and less talent than one. And why does he make such a big difference in this world? He has got no charisma, he displays no leadership, he has trouble raising his voice, he delivers all of his lines with the same tone of voice and is generally as inspiring as a taxaccountant. Why are we led to believe that he could lead a rebellion against monkey-tyrrany?Without a doubt Tim Burtons worst film. Avoid!4/10 for good makeup and nice FX's.

title: Everything A Movie Should Be
text: I saw this movie tonight and I actually was crying at one point because this movie is everything a movie should be.  Everything worked so well together. The actors were great, the make up was outstanding (I hope the Academy doesn't overlook this movie when Oscar time rolls around) and the background/setting was spectacular.  I HIGHLY recommend this movie, but when you go to see it, just remember, it's a readaptation of the original Planet of the Apes, NOT a remake, so don't go in thinking that the only thing that has changed is the cast.

title: Not as bad as I thought it was going to be....
text: I was very surprised by this film. I thought I would dislike it intensely, because that is how I feel about just about everything else that Tim Burton does (Beetlegeuse, Frankenweinie, Legend of Sleepy Hollow). However, it really wasn't that bad. That said, here is what I found lacking:The plot. Pretty ho-hum. Man gets lost, man tries to get found.The hero. Mark Wahlberg just doesn't cut it for me. He is fine as a supporting character, say, as a crewmember. But he doesn't carry this film. I never really cared about him as a person, and he never really did anything that could be called virtuous or admirable (except for the predictable scene where he saves the teenager as the apes attack). His character is shallow and wooden.The make-up & costumes. Sometimes great, as in the gorilla generals and Gen. Thade. The female ape make-up was silly, and the pants suit that Helena Bonham Carter wore through the entire movie made her look like Carol Channing. Estella Warren looked like she had just robbed her costume from Raquel Welch on the set of One Million Years B.C. (although at least Raquel's role had some substance to it). The stunts. More of that silly flying around stuff that seemed to get popular after Hidden Crouching Tiger or whatever it was called came out. Since when do gorillas fly through the air?The ending. My 13-year-old daughter predicted it. And it doesn't even make sense.The sets. Stolen from the Ewok Adventure, apparently.What did I like? The pacing. It moved the movie right along and made it seem shorter than it really was.

title: very disappointing
text: First off, I am a very big Tim Burton fan.  I could go on forever about how much I love his films, but this is about PLANET OF THE APES and not Burton's career.  The original PLANET OF THE APES movie is a favorite of mine.  I have loved it since I first saw it as a child.  And I could never realize why so many of my friends would laugh at me.  No one ever understood the film.  Well, none of my childhood friends.  When I first read that Tim Burton was selected to direct the new APES film I was a little confused. He is a brilliant director, but an APES film?  A number of months later I saw the theatrical trailer and was very impressed.  Well, not entirely.  I have a very strong hatred for Mark Wahlberg.  Other than his casting, the film looked good.  When I saw the film summer of 2001, I was utterly disappointed. If any of you have seen the movie, you know what I am talking about.  I think the main problem with the movie was the script.  And that brings my attention to a possible problem with Tim Burton.  Visually, he is amazing but his taste in scripts or screenplays is lacking.  Hell, maybe he decided to do the movie before reading the script. That would probably explain a lot. This was the first Tim Burton movie that I not only did not like, but rather hated.  The movie is incredibly slow, boring, and very expensive.  However, visually (if you were to watch the movie with no volume) the film is great. With the exception of a few action sequences. For some reason every other action sequence or so by Burton is terribly filmed.  I thought he did a wonderful job with the action in his previous film SLEEPY HOLLOW, but the climatic battle in PLANET OF THE APES has some horrible shots.  On the other hand of course it had some beautiful and provocative scenes too.  One in particular is of the chimp Tim Roth running on all fours towards a fleeing Mark Wahlberg into the old space ship. And also the shots of the Ape infantry charging on the frontline on all fours was incredibly brilliant and scary.  As I stated earlier, great film visually and Burton is amazing but the dialogue and script for this movie are horrible. In conclusion, I'd give this film a D.

title: Good film, awful remake
text: "Planet of the apes" was good film, it was not a great film like the 1968 classic and in fact it was horbble remake. Most of you  have probbly seen the original "Planet of the Apes" so i wont bother explaining the plot. But while I was watching this remake I was wandering, why did Tim Burton direct this? As I said this was a good film but, Tim Burton has directed some great films like "Edward Scissor Hands" and "Sleepy Hollow" It should have been directed by somebody else since this was a remake the whole movie was laid out, so Tim Burtons brains were wasted. But still it is a good popcorn movie witch can be viewed by the entire family.

title: Waste of time
text: I was looking forward to seeing this movie.  After finally watching it I felt disappointed and confused.  Too many questions left unanswered.  Very poor job of making it seem realistic.  The special effects are mildly entertaining but don't make up for the poor story.  This was the most over-hyped movie of the past 5 years.  I wouldn't see it again for free.

title: B Movie Story Unconvicing Story
text: To be fair I watched this movie before I watched the original story. This movie is convincing mostly because of the story line. It sounds like tall tales. In other words, not convincing as the original Planet of the Apes which do deserve an 8. This one is one of those movie I won't recommend my friends to watch except for the beginning ape chase scenes. The story falls on a couple of things that makes it difficult to accept. Time traveling through the future in an electrical storm in space seems too far fetched compared to the original movie, which traveled near light speed. The fact that the space station had a couple of "space pod" and Standard Operating Procedures, it's unlikely that any space station would be traveling around chasing space pods lost in electrical storms. Space stations' aren't built for chasing or rescue missions. They could have sent a couple of space pods, with a chimp is more plausible. The fact that humans became a slave, and yet they can speak English and talk, makes it unconvincing compared to the original movie which they aren't able to talk as the Apes are convinced that humans are unintelligent. The original movie the Apes assume humans to be stupid since they can't communicate is a more convincing story. The ending of the movie, I believe spoiled the movie completely and this is where the scoring is bad. In any good movie there are three things that's is key to scoring. The plausibility of the story, the beginning movie to pull us into the story, the ending that wraps up the entire move is the most important. The story fails on plausibility as mentioned here. Why are humans too passive is unconvincing. The fact that humans in this movie has no capacity to use weapons and being unorganized is very unconvincing. Humans are well known to be organized in times like these. The ending is really hard to rationalized into the story and no plausibility at all. It creates a Pandora's box. So if I were a movie producer and I was to do something different, time traveling through a wormhole, a black hole is more convincing, if we want to add to the old original story. The fact that a small space pod to travel long distance is unconvincing also even with all the technology in this movie. A human slavery is only possible through greater limitations of freedom as in concentration camps conditions is more convincing I believe, or the fact that the humans brains were "neutered" into stupidity, as in the removal of frontal lobe is another possibility. The fact that human slave they became a butler and a maid is an unintentional comedy and too unbelievable. The fact that they put humans in wood cage and to assume humans are too stupid to find a way to break those bamboo wood sounds unrealistic. Humans intelligence couldn't be that stupid given a slight 2000 years or more of evolution. I can continue to criticized this movie because of it's many mistake. In my opinion the movie compares slightly better than Snakes on the Plane movie. You can make another Planet of the Apes...if the story line is a plausible one, I believe and make some of the fixes mentioned here. As you noticed directors in general ignore good story writing but in animations where changes are very difficult and costly, a good story is much more possible. This is why Pixar Studios and Disney have such an impressive list of classic movies in spite of the fat that its a cartoon. While story writing can be written on the fly, it is this reason why Xanadu flopped, or in more recent one Disaster Movie was a complete flopped. The movie was made before the story and they had no idea as to the title of the movie.

title: Pointless Remake.
text: Director Tim Burton was behind this big-budget, but ultimately pointless, and unsatisfying "re-imagining" of the classic 1968 original. Here, Mark Wahlberg takes over the lead astronaut role, as he finds himself(through a muddled set of circumstances) thrust into a future earth where(no surprise) apes now rule over men, and he must find a way to survive this ordeal, and get back to his own time, assuming he ever can...Good makeup F/X and supporting cast(including Charlton Heston, in a knowing cameo) cannot redeem such an otherwise uninspired and purposeless film, which really has nothing new to offer, and provokes no new insight.Final twist at the end is so arbitrary and crass, that it may make you scream, or at least say "Huh? What the Heck..." A sixth film in the original series would have served more purpose than this mess!

title: This movie is not The Original!
text: First off, as a fan of the original POTA i found this movie to be EXCELLENT!!!  I grow tired of hearing all the comparisons to the original. The worst complaint is that the film was not Satirical enough. This is a new movie.  A satirical version of this movie already exists.  Why would Tim Burton want to do another satirical version???  He wouldn't, that would be redoing a movie.  This is a re-imagining! Perhaps this is why tim burton decided to create a more literal interpretation of the subject matter.  And in so doing takes nothing away from the original and actually amplifies the sentiment of the original while actually maintaining a social message!  It may have be in a different area and more straight forward but it still echoes the sentiment of the original.  As for the complaints that the film makes no sense, it makes perfect sense.  One gets the sense that much of what happened will be explained later, in a sequel.  I could think of several explanations of various plot "holes" and inconsistencies.  It just depends on what they have in mind.  Just remember how much was left out of the original POTA.  To watch that film alone without all the sequels prompts many questions.   Also, I thought the small homages to the original were brilliant and fun.  And, The Special effects were astounding.  The makeup alone is completely worth seeing.  It really saddens me to see such a backlash against this film.  I left the theater actually feeling like this film stands right in line with the rest of the Apes films.

title: Seeing it for the first time
text: Unlike most people, I did not see the original Planet of the Apes before I went to this movie.  So, I did not get a lot of the jokes that pertained to the previous movie(s).  Based on that, I have to say that this movie is not as good as I thought it would be.  The action is great, and the costumes phenomenal (Rick Baker is awesome).  But the dialogue lacked depth.  Go see the movie for the action and laughs, but don't go if you don't like cheesy lines delivered badly.

title: Unneeded and uninteresting.
text: Not even Tim Burton's unique and great style can save this movie.There are several bad things about "Planet of the Apes". (One of them is the fact that this movie should never have been made at all but let's put that aside.) It might sound strange but the thing that troubled and disappointed me the most was that the humans in the movie could all speak normal English and all acted like almost normal humans and some even seemed to have make up and hairdressers! Another troubling thing was Mark Wahlberg. Now, I'm not one of those people who have something against Mark Wahlberg, not at all but he was simply totally miscast. He is too much of an hero, which is not the right type of guy for this movie. And let's not even get started about Estella Warren or Tim Roth's overacting and some of the unneeded and weak characters in a disappointing story with an ending so weird that not even the smartest person will understand it.Now, I must say that the movie has some nice sets, costumes and make up that are typically trademark Tim Burton, the special effects are also quite good. It's also good that there still is plenty of humor to enjoy but it's not enough to make the movie interesting.There are some nice scene's but there also are some extremely disappointing scene's. The hunt is pretty cool (although still not as cool as the '68 hunt version) but the end battle is extremely weak and disappointing and ends too abrupt. Especially the Colonel Attar vs. Krull battle is laughable and a disgrace for the two characters that were about the most interesting two in the movie.I do not hate this movie I simply did not enjoy it. Only watchable for the Tim Burton fans and for the nice Charlton Heston cameo.4/10http://bobafett1138.blogspot.com/

title: Even farther from the original concept than the first movie
text: Spoiler Alert I read "Planet of the Apes" by the French novelist Pierre Boulle as a young teenager in the early sixties, having no idea that a film based on the book with Charlton Heston (whom I have never liked as an actor) would be released a few years later. I bought if off a drugstore book rack because the title was interesting and I was crazy about science fiction. I was somewhat disappointed when the book turned out to be more an allegory on the human condition than hard sci-fi.In the book, two space travelers, one male, one female, discover a canister drifting in space. Inside it is a manuscript which, conveniently enough, they can read. The unnamed author of the manuscript tells his story: He is an extreme misanthrope, so disillusioned with the human race and man's inhumanity to man that he builds a spaceship and, along with two or three other men (no women), he travels at relativistic speeds (hence there is time dilation amounting to centuries or millennia) to another solar system, where they find an earthlike planet. It is, you guessed it, the Planet of the Apes. The apes have an advanced civilization and the humans are the oppressed animals. The humans are mute and naked and really do live like animals. The ape civilization consists of the three ape races: The chimpanzees are the scientists and the engineers, the gorillas are the military and laborers, and the orangutans are the philosophers and statesmen. He is separated from his companions, captured and paired for mating with a woman, whom he names Nova. The senior member of his crew, a scientist, is eventually rediscovered, but the scientist has regressed to a subintelligent level by having to live as a human. (His degeneration was not the result of brain surgery, as in the 1968 film, which was a big goof anyway, because the man's operation was on the right, whereas in the normal human brain, language function is in the left hemisphere.) The protagonist learns the language of the apes and becomes a celebrity among them. With this new life comes disturbing revelations: The apes behave much more like 'animals' than they would like to believe of themselves, and he discovers old documents that reveal that on this world, as on his own, the humans were originally the superior race. Their downfall came when they began to perform experiments in intelligence amplification on apes. The enhanced apes overthrew and subjugated the humans. The protagonist is appalled by the discovery that the apes can be as degenerate, corrupt and "inhumane" as humans. At the same time, his position is increasingly jeopardized as the apes' distrust of him grows, along with their fear of him as a potential leader of a resurgent human race. I don't recall whether he escapes and finds his old ship, or manages to build a new one, but he leaves the Planet of the Apes with Nova, who is now pregnant with his child and learning to speak, and travels back to Earth (more time dilation), or what he thinks is Earth, only to discover that it is now also a Planet of the Apes. Here the manuscript breaks off, and the two space travelers ponder its meaning, whereupon it is revealed that they are---surprise!---apes as well.You can see how far the original film departed from the novel, and threw in a lot of hokey nonsense as well. Yet it retained some of the flavor, essential ideas and philosophy of the book. The new Planet of the Apes has not even done that much. It is a tame (no pun intended), essentially mindless exercise in special effects. Why did they even bother?

title: Not bad taken by itself
text:
If this had been the FIRST Planet of the Apes, I think reviews would be quite different of this movie.  But, unfortunatly, because of the cult following that the original series has (me included), it is compared with the classic.  I myself can see why it doesn't compare with the original, and I agree, it is NOT as good as the first Planet of the Apes.All that being said, I must say that taken by itself, this version of Planet of the Apes is actually quite good.  The make-up effects were GREAT as were the other special effects.  As for the story, I didn't it was bad.  The dialogue could have been better, but what do you really want from Burton? As for the acting, so Wahlberg needs some acting lessons?  Tim Roth was very good, as was Michael Clarke Duncan.  And even though she had all that make-up on, Helena Bonham Carter was STILL sexy as hell. 
Although not exactly up to the original classic, this version is a fun movie.  I also, hope that there is a second one.  This time maybe get somebody other than Burton to direct it.

title: Not the real Burton
text: I have watched every Burton's film but this seems to be a job which was taken by accident. The movie is average and there's little of 'the Burton' influence. I hope the next project will be more independent. Danny Elfman's music has a bit change of style. But it remains mysterious and attractive.

title: Slow-moving, dull, and without logical plot
text: I don't think this inept script could have ever been produced withoutthe name of Tim Burton behind it. Science fiction aficionadosshould take note that, unlike the original PLANET OF THE APES,this non-remake makes no effort to lay any kind of logicalconnection between the different time frames alluded to in the plot.If you have ever seen any time travel films before, even mediocreones, you will have come to expect some logical inconsistencies(reflecting that time travel is theoretically impossible in the firstplace), but Burton seems intent on simply giving the finger to anysemblance of logic here. If you haven't seen the film yet, you haveprobably been told to expect a surprise ending; I would tell you toexpect a surprisingly stupid ending that is surprisingly insulting tothe audience's intelligence.Burton's fondness for dark sets is apparent here,  but instead ofthe decadent, wildly overgrown urban landscape of his GothamCity,  all you get here is sensory deprivation and an urge to nod offduring one of the film's frequent and lengthy periods of inactivity.The ape makeup, which was groundbreaking at the time of theoriginal film, has not really improved much. Some of it is quitegood (Tim Roth as Thade), but it is otherwise uneven, as is theacting.Burton makes much of the difference in strength and agilitybetween apes and humans, but the way he shows this is not byendowing the apes with natural animal-like grace, but by loadingthem onto hidden catapults and launching them into the scene. It'slaughable.The DVD has a few extras, including commentary by Tim Burtonand Danny Elfman, but I got the best laugh from the cast biosection, which gives page after page of gushing plaudits forBurton's untalented girlfriend, Lisa Marie, who is alleged to haveappeared in the film. Darned if I could find her though. Jeez, what_won't_ Burton stoop to to keep his bed warm!Rating: 3/10.

title: not Burton´s best, but not bad
text: I must say that I was very dissapointed when I saw this film. The "re-imagine" concept just does not work in the movies (just ask Gus Van Sant). But I thought Burton might make it work. Well, I was wrong. I adore Burtons work and in my personal opinion he is Hollywood´s greatest director, but that does not mean that I love every piece of celluloid that he comes in contact with. POTA has some potentials but somehow they just fizz out. You can never stop asking yourself "Why?" Why make a remake of a near perfect film? If POTA 2001 would have been the first ape film, this might have been hailed as a great film. The fact simply is that we have seen this before. And what what is Burton doing with a comic relief?! Limbo is doing the same for this movie as Jar Jar did for Episode one! He is to much, to "haha funny" and should have been killed when the humans escaped. But no, we have to endure him throughout the whole film! The movie does have some good points though. First of all it has Tim Roth. He is without a doubt the best actor in this film and his ape impression is at times very frightening. The sets, costumes and everything in that department was impeccable, in a Burtonian way. There have been some who say that the make up in this film is no better than in the original. That is pure nonsense. I am inclined to think that these people are only blinded by some hate of Burton and his POTA and for fouling the memory of the original that they can´t give credit where credit is due! The makeup in this movie is sheer brilliance. The movement of the actors lips are now visible and so are other discreet features. This is better make up and saying otherwise just underlines that some people can´t judge films without letting feelings cloud there judgement. Last words. See the film at least two times. The initial shock wears off an you like it better the next time.

title: Monkey See, Monkey Do
text: Almost everyone involved in the making of this movie is to be lauded for their individual creative efforts; this much is certain... great costumes, props, makeup, etc.My only problem with the end result of POTA is its emphasis on action, and very little attention to the human vs. ape and mankind philosophies so aptly and dramatically demonstrated in the original 1968 film on which the "reimagined" 2001 Tim Burton movie was partly based (The screenwriters who worked on this one also pulled information from Pierre Boulle's short sci-fi novel "Monkey Planet.").True, everything made nowadays must have one sense-throttling, action packed sequence strung almost imperceptibly to the next, never stopping to look at the wondrous 'flower' that made the 1968 film so unique.  The original film was nature vs man, evolution alongside devolution, and an overall downward spiral towards mankind's oblivion (or pretty much the next worst thing, anyway, since people aren't totally extinct by the time the main character crash lands on either eponymous planet).The best things in the 2001 remake are the handful of pop references made first in the original movie, the references to modern (some 21st Century) attitudes ("I'm having a bad hair day," says one female chimp in Burton's version), and the overall upgraded feel and tone of the movie now that more than thirty-three years have elapsed in the world of cinema.Its a given to say that special-effects are a boon to this new, improved version.  Yet, I miss hearing all that (somewhat) great dialog heard in POTA 1968.Everyone I know who's seen the Burton version has mentioned something about its ending, and the questions it poses.  Let us all hope Simos (the name of the simian deity in this film) answers our inquisitive, and slightly confused, prayers in a rational manner... ...and will there be an even more confusing sequel to this reimagination?

title: The worst movie since Waterworld, and the worst remake ever!
text: This movie is so bad that the only thing that could adequately describe it would be a particularly-foul-smelling, one-hundred-minute fart. The producer, director, and screen-writer should all win 'Chumpies' (or should that be 'Chimpies'?) at the Anti-Oscar Awards.The acting is so bad that, no doubt, Kris Kristofferson pleaded to be killed early in order to escape the locale. Most of the other actors were mainly trained to say, "Grrr!" and leap about like demented chimps.The attempts at humor are pathetic, being mostly banal take-offs on modern stand-up one-liners. The hero is a blockhead space pilot who can't fly as well as a trained chimp, and whose face is far less expressive.If you're going to rent this movie, be sure to rustle up a biiig bag of popcorn, 'cuz you're going to want something to put over your head to escape the worst remake, ever!

title: A brilliant, whimsical spectacle
text: I must thoroughly disagree with others who didn't like this one. Except about the fantastic overall look and special effects, far above the original -- after all, special effects and make-up have come a long way since 1968.It is not a copy of the original. It gives a nod to the original in several places, rather obviously, and with a bit of whimsical tongue-in-cheek; apparently Charlton Heston agreed, and I trust I need not elaborate.I actually rate this one as a 9.5, and would have gone to ten, but for the unclear ending; they were obviously looking for something that would have the impact of the Statue of Liberty showing up, half buried, as we saw in the first film; this one falls a bit short in that regard, and while I could "figure it out," it should have been more simple and obvious. It wasn't.Helena Bonham Carter pretty much walks away with this one, as she makes about the cutest chimp anyone can imagine. Again, I trust I need not elaborate; just why Our Hero would leave this world, I dunno. The two finest babes on the planet both wanted him. Guess humans aren't really all that smart, after all.

title: Great...but I should have left before the last minute of the movie!!
text: I was impressed by the majority of the movie.  I especially like Thades' (Tim Roth) walking motion as i have been imitating it all day.  Apart from some of the cliche comic relief remarks (you know what i mean), and the very end (last minute or so), i thought the movie was GREAT!!  But that ending .. .

title: Tim Burton should be ashamed of himself
text: I LOVE Tim Burton.  He's original, he's smart, and his movies are usually visually inventive.  I guess you can't win 'em all.The story in this waste of time is close to non-existant and doesn't give the talented cast any chance at all of projecting any kind of character. There is one mildly entertaining action sequence, and there is the odd in-joke that works (most notably Charleton Heston's cameo), but that's about it as a MOVIE.As a technical exercise, this film displays little of Burton's usual brilliance, but Rick Baker's makeup definitely deserves special mention. The ape characters are incredible, and show remarkably subtle facial expressions.  Had the characters themselves be better written, there's some chance this wouldn't have been a total waste.3/10 for outstanding makeup and a few cool in-jokes.

title: Worst movie of 2001
text: I happened to catch "Planet of the Apes" on PPV last night. I was quite excited because I had missed my chance at the box office. Boy am I glad I didn't waste my money buying a ticket. This is one of the worst movies I have ever seen. There is no plot, no character motivation, no life, no story thru-line to carry the picture and the ending is so bad, it reeks of a low-budget, straight-to-video, sci-fi flick. I am a HUGE fan of Tim Burton and I think he is one of the most brilliant directors Hollywood has to offer. In fact, "Sleepy Hollow", in my opinion, is his best film to date. But POTA is a film that could best be described as never-should've-happened. Why does Hollywood see the need to remake classic, highly rated films and turn them into pure trash? This is one film that should NOT have been remade or reimagined or whatever you wish to call it. Why can't Hollywood remake films that were terrible when they were FIRST released instead of doing things the other way around??? The screenplay for this film is drenched with cheesy dialogue. (In one scene, David Warner tells his daughter, Helena Bohnam Carter to wash her hands before dinner after she has been touching humans!!!) The writers saw fit to throw every kind of silly convention of humor that one could relate to humans and apes at the screen and expected us to eat it up. This is one viewer who wishes he could make the writers eat their own words!!! Save you money and rent something else.

title: This movie is great...until you compare it to the original
text: This movie redefines the basic principle on which the original movie was made.  The first time, I saw this movie, I thought it was awesome. I would've given it at least an 8/10...Great makeup, awesome effects, well thought-out plot, better than average acting.  However, then...I saw the original.  I changed my rating. You see?? I saw this version first and then the original.  I felt I'd made a mistake.  I don't think I could watch this one again as attentively as I did at first.  But, in any case, the ending made more sense in the 1968 version than it did in this one.  I'd be surprised if they come up with a sequel.  After careful consideration of all aspects of the film, and then comparing it with something that was monumentally better, I give this film a final rating of 6/10 (max).

title: Intriguing and strange with a twist at the end.
text: I found the movie to be quite exciting and strange.  I had to give great credit to the make-up artists for the movie.  The make-up was so terrifyingly real.  I was kind of lost at the end, but that was just because I had seen the original and was expecting something different.  But it was all in all a wonderful film.

title: Walberg stick to comedies
text: Mark Walberg should only do comedies. He has one facial expression: extremely confused.

title: Comments from a dissapointed viewer
text: Well, a typical burton movie some would say. I agree to a certain extent. Burton means a good looking movie with a pretty bad script, but he most often get away with it. Sleepy Hollows is excellent for example.This movie however, has a really really bad script. There are plotholes all over and the ending is terrible. One would think that since he based it on a idea very well covered before that the script would be easy to make into something marvelous. But instead it was predictable and full of plotholes. I will not mention them here since a few of you might not have seen to movie, but trust me on this one.The actors taking the shapes of apes are excellent, and they do a good enough job. Mark Wahlberg is stiff and doesn't really feel like he is in a perilous situation, but that is mostly because of his lack of lines, he says very little, asks almost nothing it doesn't really fit in what a person would do in his situation. You don't really get to know any of the characters.So, pretty good effects, lousy script, a typical burton movie, but in this case, the script is so bad and the effects not good enough to make watching it worthwhile.

title: Disappointing
text: Tim Burton has shown many things in his life as a filmmaker: a knack for gloomy atmosphere; a real sense of empathy for the lonely and different ones; a wicked sense of humor; he's even shown that he can play by the rules of the studios, delivering not only once but twice, even making a sequel and pulling it off.Sadly, none of that shows in "Planet...". The problem does not lie in the fact that they tamper with the story from the first film. As they've made clear, the producers and director are not trying to remake a classic, but use it (and the book it originated from) as a stepping stone to build the new movie, so their deviations from the original would not be a problem... if they were good.Burton doesn't have a good starting point: the script is very, very bad, your usual Hollywood-esque pastiche of old lines with (supposedly) new parallelisms and not-very-bright pop culture references. All that would be interesting if something happened, along the story, to the characters. Sadly, it is not so: the astronaut, the good apes and the pretty girl remain the same (that is, totally uninteresting) throughout the movie. Even the bad apes are not really changed, as the ending goes. And let's not even start with the inconsistencies...This is by far Burton worse movie ever, light years away from his classics. His trademarks barely show: we don't care about what happens with the characters at all, the sets lack the grandeur that we've learn to love and expect ("Sleepy Hollow" and "Batman" come to mind) and his "wicked sense of humor" is limited to changing classic lines from being spoken by humans to simian mouths.The acting is really bland, too. Mark Wahlberg has proven that he can act. But he wanders through "Planet..." with his best "Keanu-I-don't-know-what-the-heck-is-going-on-Reeves" look on. And Stella Warren... well, she IS pretty. Helena Bonham-Carter is as boring as usual and Tim Roth has lots of fun but is well below some of his best movies.The summing up of all of this is in one word: disappointment. Not from what it is (even at this point the movie can be seen if one has enough popcorn and soda) but from what it could had been with the talent implied. And yes, the make-up is awesome and Heston's cameo is really cool, but somehow they are not sufficient to save a picture from being just another fancy way of wasting your time and your money.

title: Completely missing the point...
text: OK...maybe Hollywood doesn't produce movies with deeper meanings any more. *sigh*The original "Planet of the Apes" tried to incorporate some social criticism in the story. Things like 'beware of the bomb' and 'where is this technological World coming to?'. At the time, space-faring people were very much on everyones mind and PotA was part of what people were interested in.Nowadays things are a little different. The cold war and the nuclear threat are all but forgotten and people travelling into space are only of interest to some people at NASA and a group of Trekkies. When this movie was announced I was very interested in the way this remake would re-actualize this movie.Let's be short about this: They didn't.Not only didn't they translate the original into something current audiences would relate to, they also used some lines without giving it any relevance to the rest of the new story. At some point General Thade is warned about the dangers of humans...about their inherent violent nature and such. In the original this was caused by the key-event responsible for apes-taking-over, namely the nuclear war. In this new remake this warning has NO basis in the story at all! The opposite is true.The 2 endings to the story are even more unlikely and illogical. I'll not spoil things any further by describing them, but I was appalled at the complete senselessness of it all.My final feelings were: "No way!" and "Who cares?"

title: Lives up to the Hype....
text: I went to see this film with great expectation. I loved the original series of films, and I expecting this to be just as good if not better, and it was! It's hard to say if it was better, I'd say, they are almost on different grounds, due to the Special FX we had in the 60's and the stuff we got now. So that changes a lot, but it's not just the FX, the story is great, it keeps you guessing, and near the end, you just..don't know what to expect, I didn't and I read about the ending on the net anyway. This was defiantly a "Re-Imagining" not a "Re-make" This is so different than the first. In fact, I don't even know what the heck the ending was about, was it earth, was it another planet...I swear, you think about the ending to this movie for more than 5 minutes, your head will explode. But all I can say is, this movie rocks, great acting, awesome story, sweet plot, I'm just stoked for the sequel!

title: This film missed a couple of evolutionary steps...
text: What was wrong with this film?  Let me count the ways.  "Planet ofthe Monkeys" was somewhat entertaining.  However, it was alsoan extremely safe film, and I would have expected more chancesto be taken from a filmmaker such as Tim Burton.  There werequite a few plot holes that I was willing to forgive for the sake ofmoving the film along.  But when the ending comes and it is not somuch shocking (me and a friend each predicted it) as completelymind boggling.  Even in a world such as this, the question thatbegs to be asked: How is that ending even possible?  Throughoutthe whole movie, through all the bland human characters and theinteresting but tried and predictable ape characters, I was able tosuspend my disbelief; then the ending comes and the disbelief isunsuspended.  The ending simply is not possible. What makes a movie memorable is always a strong ending, onethat gets talked about (read: The Sixth Sense).  Just because thisending will be talked about do not make the mistake of assumingthat it is a memorable ending.  The original ending in the 1968'Apes' was in there for shock value and I never did like it but atleast it could be explained!  Anyway, go see the movie foryourselves if you must, and if there are any physicists or scientistsout there who feel they can adequately explain the plausibility ofthat ending please feel free to tell me.  This film is just the latestbig budget disappointment in a summer saturated with moviesthat do not live up to the hype.  My advice, save your money on thisfilm and go see a worthwhile film like Made, The Princess and theWarrior, Sexy Beast or even Kiss of the Dragon, which makes nopretenses about the kind of movie it is (not to mention that you getto watch a teaser for Black Hawk Down before the movie!).

title: A waste of a good movie
text:
Why do they bother to remake good movies?I had hoped that because the technology is so much better than it was in the 60s, that we would see the FX simply enhance an already great movie. Nope.Instead, we saw mediocre special effects and make-up trying to hold together a mere shadow of the original story.The entire beauty of the Original POTA can be summed up like this:  Taylor is a human on a planet that for some reason is run by apes and humans are slaves.  He longs to leave the planet and get back HOME to Earth.  The shocker at the end of the movie is that he already IS home.The new Apes could not hope to compete with that and, given that so many people already know the ending, tried very hard to end with an equal, if different, shock.  It didn't work.One thing about the ending (no spoiler here): you either loved it, or you hated it.  I hated it.  There has been so much discussion about whether or not it made sense...all I can say is that if you have to argue about it, then it wasn't clear enough.  I think the movie would have been much more entertaining if the story line brought you to the ending, (like the original did), instead of throwing it at you from out of nowhere.
I'm glad I saw it.  Once.  I'm also glad I rented it on DVD instead of paying theater prices to see it.And I'm thinking of buying the originals...

title: bad, damn, dirty bad
text: Just a really bad movie.  The only thing from keeping this a 1* is the decent soundtrack and how the apes ran.  Bad acting, bad directing, bad (or no) story, okay sfx.  Bad, bad, bad.  Did anybody really care about anything in this movie other than how the apes ran?

title: Very Disapointing
text: If this movie was not directed by Tim Burton I would concluded as just plain stupid.  I mean the original did not cost no 100 million dollars to make and was very original.  This time it is the same story with just a few twist which I will not give away.  Basically it's about a man who crashes onto a planet which is totally flipped in the ecosystem where the apes are the rulers and the humans are the savages. Sounds Familiar right.  Like I said Tim Burton is a great director he does do a good job of trying to make his mark in visuality ,but it's the same old story. Now the only real good thing was Paul Geomanti(Sorry if I miss prenounced his name)he brought a little bit of humor to the story.  If your a big fan see it for yourself don't let me stop you if you aren'tthen go see something worth your money beacuse this isn't.6/10 grade

title: bewilderingly bad film
text: Myself and my girlfriend left the cinema bewildered and disappointed by this terrible film.
