We are both Tim Burton fans and were willing to overlook the mixed advance press.Suffice it to say that this film is a mess, doesn't make any sense, and has severe acting problems.  The male lead is a man who used to advertise underpants and is a complete emotional blank.  Even worse, his love interest is that curse of Hollywood films, a model woman who has no acting ability whatsoever.  Just think: they spent tens of millions of pounds on this, could have had anyone in the world write a script and work on it and this is what was produced.

title: I Don't Much Care For This!
text: I see why people hate this film. In fact, the first time I saw this, I hated this film and I rarely hate films. I couldn't even watch the whole thing. I'm reviewing this movie after viewing it for a second time. I thought it was OK. Tim Burton certainly made much better movies.Leo Davidson lands on a planet with the humans the minority race. The majority race is none other than evil gorillas. Now, Leo needs to help the humans and escape while he can.The acting is so so. Mark Wahlberg is a decent actor. Tim Roth played a great villain. Estella Warren needs to quit acting(maybe she did). Her character is awful.The special effects were pretty good even though there are lots of movies with better effects. The makeup is solid, nothing extraordinary. The ending- well, I didn't like the ending too much. I really hope the prequel is better than this. I rate this film 6/10.

title: Ouch!
text: Not having seen the original, I was forced to judge this movie on its basic credibility alone.  I get the feeling that being attached to the star of its namesake is why it saw theatrical release at all.  This thing was mind-numbing.  The characters made no sense, the plot was inane, and the science was terrible.  You can only watch so many scenes of monkeys jumping on each other and pounding.  That's basically the whole film, briefly interrupted by scenes of Mark Wahlberg trying to look heroic.  The special effects are pretty good, but that's like wrapping up feces in a pretty gift box.  What happened to you, Tim Burton?

title: Far, far better than most would have you believe
text: I'm going to catch some heat for this, but I've found Tim Burton's Planet Of The Apes to be a far better film than any of the three recent versions. I can't explain it, but there's something so otherworldly and exotic about the production design, makeup and effects, a true storyteller's touch used, resulting in a piece with elements of fantasy and world building brought lushly to the forefront, whereas the newer films just felt somewhat clinical and sterile, going through minimalist motions without any real sense of wonder applied. Oh and another thing: real, tactile makeup on actual human actors, which will win against motion capture/cgi any day. There's also an old world, medieval feel to this planet, as the 'humans being subservient to apes' dynamic has already been in full swing for generations, as opposed to a lengthy origin story that takes up most of the newer trilogy. No build up here, just Marky Mark getting marooned on a distant world dominated by simians, fighting his way through their ranks, sort of falling in love with one (Helena Bonham Carter as a monkey=kinky) and attempting to find a way back to earth. There's various apes of all shapes and sizes at war, the most memorable of which is a sleek, snarling Tim Roth as Thade, a volatile warlord who despises humans. Michael Clarke Duncan towers over everyone as Attar, his cohort and fellow soldier, and seeing already be-jowelled Paul Giamatti as a cumbersome orangutan is priceless. The human faction is led by weathered Kris Kristofferson and his daughter (Estella Warren, quite possibly the most beautiful girl on the planet), leading the dregs of humanity as they exist in hiding and fight for their lives. No expense was spared in filling every frame of this planet with lived-in splendour and atmospheric decoration, from suits of armour and architecture to the overgrown thickets of mountainous vegetation that grow on this world. As for the apes themselves, it's terrific how real they feel. It's the same thing that happened with Lord Of The Rings vs. The Hobbit, and the switch from practical Orc effects to the overblown cgi madness of the goblins in the later films. The human eye is inherently adept at deciphering what is real and what is not, and the effects of the later Ape films with Andy Serkis just felt lifeless and orchestrated, whereas here the makeup prosthetics are organic, authentic and wonderful to look at. Don't even get me started on the ending either, it's completely brilliant and will leaving you in cold isolation as the credits roll, a perfect gut punch to a film that could have easily turned sappy in the eleventh hour. So that's my two cents. Bring on the backlash.

title: Uneven, but by no means horrible
text:
I have never seen the original Planet of the Apes nor its numerous sequels. So, I wasn't going into this movie expecting to not have any "cult-classic" expectations dashed upon the rocks.  I was hoping that 1) This film earned its "Directed by Tim Burton" tag, 2) I wanted a half-way intelligent story, and 3) I wanted to marvel at the monkey (excuse, me, *ape*) makeup.Let me take those points in reverse.  You've probably heard that the makeup is incredible.  Well, it is.  Different species of simians are represented, from baboon to monkey to chimpanzee, and the "evolved" forms represented in the movie are pulled off well.  But it would be for naught if the actors themselves couldn't "get into character."  Let me tell you, the ape cast did superb jobs.  Mr. Roth, playing the villain general Thade, should get an award; his imitations of simian mannerisms (pawing of his comrades, wild vine-climbing screeching fits of anger) were spot-on.  Helena Botham-Carter kept up with her costar in her role of human beneficiary; she would toggle back and forth between heated intelligent arguments on the worth of humans and "ooh ooh ooh ah! ah! aaahh!"-ing when she'd panic.  Ok, that's exaggerating, but you get the idea.Story-wise?  Ehh... I think I would have liked it better if we were focused on the monkeys rather than the "spaceman".  Mark Wahlberg (sp?) was decent, but he was a bit rough in some parts, and when the movie trailed behind him and his rag-tag bunch as they fled the city, it dragged.  When the focus switched back to the apes (especially Thade), you had interesting dialog exchanges, wonderful acting, and a generally more interesting movie.
Are you going to this movie to see a Tim Burton movie?  ... Well, you *may* be disappointed somewhat.  I didn't get the Tim Burton feel like I did watching "Sleepy Hollow".  But if you go in simply expecting to see a well-directed movie, you'll probably like it better.  Burton fans need to draw their own conclusions, but it felt like the movie was being directed by someone else, though someone equal to the task.Bottom line: It's not the best film.  But it's a good film.  I didn't feel like I wasted $7.00 seeing it in the theater.  I hope you don't, either.
Rating: 7/10

title: I'm Up a Tree
text: The technology, the make up, the scenery, just marvelous. A good cast, although the male lead was about as dull as dry toast sitting in a toaster for a day and a half (I hope the apes do whatever they want to him in the sequel). It isn't even the obtuse ending that bothered me. It's that there was something so lacking. With the gifts of computer animations and the advancements in the craft of movie-making, why couldn't one care less what happens to these characters. I don't like Charlton Heston, but when he told off those apes in the first movie, I cheered him. As with the original, why are the humans so docile and disorganized. They have evolved to the upright state, fully clothed, communicative--but they aren't more than silly critters to the apes. How would you feel if your dog started making sweaters, got married, and lived in a cave? Would you be interested in whether he had become a sentient creature, capable of more advance thinking.Another question is why those apes were able to bounce in the air so much. I've never seen a monkey bounce; I've seen them swing, not bounce. The bad guy (excuse me, bad simian) can come flying like an oversexed kangaroo at any point. I have to admit, I liked the battlefield scenes. They reminded me of a kickoff at an NFL football game. Apparently they planned to take over the planet by running into each other.I really did like the physical appearance of the apes--there was great expression. I got a kick out of the humans being sold as pets in stores. As usual, of course, the gorillas are the dumb ones (It's because they are big--right--big people are supposed to be dumb). Oh, wait! They may have been the script writers and got exactly what they had coming to them!Once again, a disappointing summer--two blockbusters in the science fiction field, this thing and Jurassic Park III. Maybe I need to take up golf!

title: Bad remake of a great movie
text: This was bad.Director Tim Burton has not managed to capture the spirit of the original.Acting is good,especially by evil monkey Tim Roth(always good),but Mark Wahlberg is way too boring to watch.He`s got that serious look on his face in the whole movie.Not any sense of humour! Just dark and creepy atmosphere with no light characters.It could have helped with some funny dialogues,but that`s not Burton`s point.It`s more unintentionally funny with those stupid costumes... Maybe some says it`s entertaining;I say it`s boring.2/10

title: Nice Saturday afternoon movie
text: At first, I thought this was a parody movie- Mark Wahlberg, Helena Bonham Carter, Paul Giamatti and Michael Clarke Duncan- I was wrong. This turned out to be a loose remake of the 1968 original. It was nice to see Charlton Heston (uncredited) as the iconic Dr. Zaius. Mark Wahlberg did a fine job, as did Helena Bonham Carter. Paul Giamatti's character felt like comic relief to me, slightly out of place, but not unwelcome. It was well made, the acting was good and it kept me interested throughout the movie, but no spectacular 'whoa!' moments. I consider this a fine movie and I would watch it again but I wouldn't purposefully go out of my way to find it. All-in-all, a nice movie for a Saturday afternoon.

title: For once a summer movie that thinks its audience is SMART!
text: To sum up the monumental movie Planet Of The Apes in one word would be a discredit to Tim Burton and his wonderful remake of the groundbreaking movie.  A deep movie that managed to keep my attention for about 2 hours, spark questions and for once, NOT EXPLAIN EVERY LITTLE ACTION THE CHARACTERS TAKE.  My pet peeve today is that movies have to take so much time in explaining every tiny detail about the plot.  In essence they are preaching to the lowest common denominator. In a movie that contains so many sub-plots, Tim Burton does a great job of presenting the foundation though dialogue, and then the rest of the plot though visual aids.  If you want to understand the movie you have to look for the details and then come to your own conclusions, which isn't that hard if you were actually watching the movie, and have some reasonable level of intelligence (which of course is rare into days movie viewing demo graph, and no I'm not an old cranky manI'm only 16).  If your tired of the same mush that infests out cinema today and want to see a movie that is smart, funny, and makes you think see this movie.  If you don't you can always go for the special effects, make-up (Wonderful job), and of course Supermodel Estella Warren! ;-)10/10!!!

title: Boy those chimps are ugly . . . . .
text: Well, what can one really say about the Planet of the Apes except that it's relatively well-made. I must admit though, special effects are becoming the norm - however, I must give credit to the directors in that the apes look rather realistic, and significantly ugly. Generally the plot was sound, the character of General Thade being sufficiently menacing - I mean, snarling at the camera every five seconds was enough to send a shiver down my spine. Well, maybe a exaggerate just a touch but his characterisation was definitely superb. The other characters are less certain, in fact did the girl really say anything? Of course, she was there for aesthetic purposes .. . . . need I say more?

title: Didn't age very well
text: Some movies are able to go years on end without aging. See 1957 "12 angry men": even watching it in 2024 the story holds your attention, the characters are fleshed out, and the cinematography is beautiful.Here at home we're on a marathon of sorts, presenting classic movies to my 16 year old daughter, and some movies - like this "Apes" remake - haven't aged well for some reason or other.Sometimes is the pace, sometimes are stylistic choices from their time period, sometimes is the cheesy music (and let's be honest: 80s movies were basically just excuses for cheesy soundtrack), and - like this remake - it lacks a soul.Tim Burton was a gun for hire, the production and effects were more than adequate for the time, probably anyone with an ounce of brass with 20th Century Fox dip their fingers in this pie, making it essentially a committee-directed film.And when we watch a movie like it after many years, the end product is unforgiving.

title: Welcome to the Monkey Jungle!
text: Hey there chimp! I mean chump! Yes you! You are the ones who went bananas when you heard that the famous classic neanderthal film `Planet of the Apes' was being remade by noveau director Tim Burton. However, after you saw its `mongoloid' ending- you probably went apes and wanted your money back. What planet are you from anyways? Don't worry! I `peel' your pain! The same thing happened to me. However, I was fascinated by the incredible `mono' a `mono' makeup created by the great Rick Baker. I was also `going ape' by the realistic set design. The story was not too bad either; that was until Burton `cheetah' us all with a horrific ending. *** Average

title: Nonsensical mess of a movie
text: Yes, it was visually stunning, and the costume work was spectacular.  Still, this movie not only violated real-world logic, it violated its own created logic, thus making it one of the messiest, frustrating movies I have seen, ever.  Mark Wahlberg was brilliant in Boogies Nights and Three Kings, but here he is unspectacular.  There is never any reason given why he stands out among all other humans as being special, though the story depends on Ms. Carter's interest in him.  He wears a white shirt, that is all.  Otherwise he is quiet, and does nothing out of the ordinary until later in the movie. Roth's Thade also takes an interest in Wahlberg's character, but again, without reason or logic.I believe Thade was the worst villian, ever.  He had no logical reason for wanting to wipe out the humans.  And this is where the story really breaks down.  The motivation is gone.  The apes have achieved supremacy, but yet there is still a need to kill all humans, who live like wild animals, and are thus harmless to the much more powerful and advanced apes.  Apes who ride horses (which the movie refuses to explain why they are on this planet, though it explains the origin of the Apes and Humans).  The logic comes to a complete break down when Thade's general turns on him, for no reason.  He has not seen anything to warrant his turn-around, and this unexpected and unlikely twist further diminishes the story.I thought I was going to vomit and retch, I desperately tried to plead with this movie to make more sense, that if you set up a fantasy world, you must abide by the rules of that world.  But it did not, and it caused my head to explode in complete pain.I give it a 3 out of 10, for costumes alone.  Those Apes looked realistic (save their body-size), and the Roman-theme was a nice touch, albeit Gladitor-esque.

title: Not exactly a remake...but worth your time regardless.
text: "Planet of the Apes" (2001), despite its title, is not exactly a remake or sequel to the old ape movies from the 1960s-70s. So much of the plot is different, I see it more as a reimagining of the story.As far as this film goes, it isn't rated all that well. Additionally, the star, Mark Wahlberg, made public statements about how the studio ruined this film...mostly by giving the director Tim Burton impossible to meet deadlines...resulting in a rushed movie. You might want to know that I am a big fan of the original series...so impressing me won't be easy.Speaking of impressing....the ape costumes and makeup are insanely good. I thought they were CGI but when I read Rick Baker actually used practical effects to make the apes, I was shocked. It is really amazing...and it makes we wonder how the newer ape movies could be better...that is, for the male apes. The female apes look creepy and almost like an entirely different species. They could have used some work.The story is very different. It begins in 2029 on a space station. Captain Davidson (Wahlberg) goes out in a space craft during some weird space storm to retrieve a chimp astronaut (a 'normal' Earth-type chimp...not a scary one like you'll later see in the film). His ship goes out of control...flying through space and crashing on some planet controlled by apes.These apes manage to be even crueler and meaner than those in the original films...as well as acting more ape-like. Among them, the most ardently anti-human and evil is Thade...and after the Captain an some other humans escape from their incarceration, he's excited about how to use this not only to kill humans but gain power.So is this any good? Well, it's a heck of a lot better than the paltry 5.7 score it now has. It would have you think the film is very poor...and it certainly isn't. While I hate remakes and reimaginations, this one kept my interest and I enjoyed it very much. And, since the newer reboot is supposed to be better, the film has me wanting to see more.By the way, the very end scene is neat...and makes no sense whatsoever...one of the weakest parts of the story, actually.

title: Monkey madness
text: Quiet a few people say that the remake of Planet of the Apes is not quiet up to the standards of the original and I would agree. Even though the story has been dramatically changed it has a similar essence.The acting is not quiet as good as the original but it is good. The characters do not seem to be that strong but they are reasonable.The soundtrack is virtually non existent. I have watched the film a few times on TV and on the DVD I got about a year ago and I can say it is far from outstanding.My main complaint about this film is the ending. It is not what I call satisfying enough to warrant a round of applause.Overall an average film that has its merits.

title: What have you done, Mr. Burton?
text: One of my friends I went to see the movie with, asked me, at the very beginning of this new version, if it had any resemblance to the original. He hadn't seen it. It was right at the time the starship of the movie's hero landed in the strange land. And I told him that yes, more or less, at this point, the movies were pretty much the same. Right there and then, similarities just vanished. The starship of this new version landed, and then the new version began to orbit around the old one, as tough admiring its excellency, but never getting into its atmosphere. The thing is that this new movie remind me of the old one over and over again, not because the latter is revived, but because its essence completely absent, and I missed it. Where the original gave us a science fiction story with RATIONAL twists of imagination, the new one develops as a succession of events that happen just because somebody said so. And when things happen just because they have to, the wonder of science fiction disappears, and we are left with a boring movie. And I heard about the `surprise' ending before I saw the movie. It is surprising, all right, but for the wrong reasons. Just when you think that nothing could be worse, well, it does. At this point, the new version just decides to give up the orbiting and finally heads for the space of oblivion. This ending leaves interrogations, not about the argument, but more like `What was Tim Burton trying to accomplish with that?'. I admire the fact that Tim Burton wanted to do something different, not just copying the original version. I mean, he dared to go against the odds and try and build something new inspired by a true classic. But as expected, he has only shown, once again, that you better don't mess with classics of that caliber.

title: A bad remake of a good movie
text: Well, here we have Tim Burton's latest opus.  No, not a short fat penguin, but I'm sure he has a unsettlingly dark and creepy film adaptation of Bloom County up his sleeve somewhere.  After all, you saw what he did to poor Batman, once a proud superhero who often found himself in goofy contrived plots fighting pastel colored villains, he now is a dark, scary, menacing type inhabiting the now perpetually nocturnal Gotham City.On the other hand, Tim Burton actually isn't that bad of a director when he's working with original material.  I rather liked Ed Wood and I thought that Edward Scissorhands had some good moments.  But when it comes to doing remakes of older movies, or film adaptations of television shows, he just plain sucks.  Case in point, Planet of the Apes.  What once was a fascinating film with a biting, socially relevant anti-war message has become a "Taco-Bell commemorative cup free with purchase of a large soda" kind of movie. Imagine if this kind of thing catches on, someday we may see a remake of Dr. Strangelove with Gary Oldman playing the base commander, Bill Pullman as the president, Tom Arnold as the Joint Chief of Staff, and Will Smith riding the bomb to his death in blazing color, followed by a hip-hop remix of "We'll Meet Again" playing over the closing credits.Anyhow, getting back to the movie.  There is one particular scene in this movie I find particularly troubling.  Toward the beginning, when the whistle/spaceship thing the hero was flying crashed on the planet, it came in at an acute angle through the trees and crashed in a swampy, wooded area. The ship then subsequently sank.  This is a BLATENT rip off of Star Wars. When I saw this scene, I forgot what movie I was watching and was temporarily disoriented when I didn't see Yoda shortly afterward.  Now, I know that ideas are sometimes borrowed from other movies, and that's okay. But I would appreciate it if they could at least TRY to change it around a little, or give it a new twist.  But no, they didn't.  They could have saved some money if they had just reused the scene from Star Wars (which probably cost one-tenth as much to film).Well, it happened, they remade Planet of the Apes, leaving a nasty stain on the rich tapestry of western culture.

title: Smooth plot, Impressive apes, and Great overall aura
text:
The look and feel of this film is great!  It's a different, yet consistent aura, which makes the film very interesting and feasible.  Danny Elfman's score fits in seamlessly with the film, and the casting is very good.
The plot is very smooth and the film carries along well, which is to be somewhat expected, as it's a re-make, but that shouldn't be taken for granted, because even with little changes, re-makes can be screwed up.The actors and makeup artists did an amazing job creating believable apes. The movements of the actors are astounding - the walking especially.  The makeup is incredible - becoming more rare as cinema progresses because directors and producers want to do things computer generated, because it's quicker and easier, even though makeup is more realistic.  Tim Burton's decision to go with makeup was very shrewd.Planet of The Apes is a fascinating film and provokes much thought, if you are open to it.  I liked it very much.

title: didn't need ending
text: Tim Burton's "re-imagining" of Planet of the Apes is pretty good except for that ending (no spoilers) that I really didn't like.  Burton really didn't nee that ending to make it good.  it was great by itself. USAF space station Oberon is doing experments on geniticly altered monkeys in space.  One day a chimpanzee named Periclese  gose to investigate an elctric magnetic storm and disaperes.  The film's hero, Leo Davison (Mark Wahlberg), who has become freinds with Periclese, gose out to find him and is swept up in the storm.  He eventualy crashes on a planet that is contrloed by apes, and is captured.  He then mets Ari (Helana Banham Carter) and escapes "Ape City".  The group is being hunted by the comander of the ape army, Thade (Tim Roth).  They reach the sacred ruins of CALIMA, and have a hugh battle with the ape army. The film had incredible scenery and make-up.  I loved "Ape City" (probubly so did everyone else), and all the scenes were the veiwer gets a look at ape civilization.  The action sequences are also outstanding with a whole lot of apes flying through the air.  I also liked that the actors actualy moved and looked liked apes.  Mark Wahlberg's preformance could have been better, but was berible.  The stand-out preformances are realy Tim Roth and Helana Bonham Carter.  Both did exelently in their roles.  Roth is no where. It's all Thade.  This is undoutibly one of Burton's most imaginitive films, but not his best.  I give Planet of the Apes 8/10.

title: Ome of the better summer movies
text: Planet of the Apes was a real delight after a summer of disappointing movies.  This summer has been one disappointment after another.  First there was Tomb Raider, which was full of dumb cliches.  Then there was A.I, which had too much hype behind it and was too long to keep your interest.  After all the disappointments it's a real relief that the studios can still come up with a good movie. 	Tim Burton brings us another blockbuster hit.  This is Burton's best work since Sleepy Hollow.  Burton uses his unique techniques to bring the apes alive for the film.  His artistic expertise that Burton displayed in the making of Planet of the Apes has probably made him one of the most well known directors today.  The mere talent that Burton brings to a film makes him one of the most unique directors of our time. 	Mark Wahlberg is wonderful in this film.  He plays Leo Davidson, a United States captain who crash lands on the planet and discovers that the apes rule the planet.  This is a step up for Wahlberg from 1994's Renaissance Man, where he plays Private Tommy Lee Haywood.  This is probably Wahlberg's best film since Boogie Nights. 	Tim Roth plays the evil General Thade, general to the ape army.  He despises the human race.  Charlton Heston makes a small cameo appearance as General Thade's Father, the only ape with a gun.  Overall I gave Planet of the Apes a 6.  If you liked this I would suggest renting Sleepy Hollow, Batman, and Edward Scissorhands.

title: The biggest diappointment of the millenium.
text: It all sounded so good, a "reimagining" of Planet of the Apes. Richard Zanuck returned to helm production and Tim Burton was brought on board to direct. We were so optimistic. The original was a landmark film, could they do it justice? The sequels were so juvenile and simplistic surely they had learned, alas it was not to be. This movie is a train wreck. Poorly concieved, poorly written, poorly acted, preposterous in logic and impossible to follow it defies our hopes and dreams. Even without comparison to the original it fails miserably. But we can't view it without remembering. The fundamental mistake I think is that this is more than just a story about Apes. Its about one mans odyssey, his journey through time and space searching for .... well shall we say the perfect world, only to arrive in a nightmare. The remake conveys none of that. Its a chase movie aimed at the 12 to 18 yearolds who dominate the market. All the critics gush about the wonderfull makeup and effects, really? They are all in denial. They assume that because of the technical advances in the last 30 years it must be better. Well its not. The gorillas are pretty good, but we are forced to watch closeups of Helen Bonham Carter who looks ... well looks like she has a mask on. The sets look like ...sets and the Ape village in the original is 10 times more realistic than the graphic in this version. The ending? it defies any and all explanations. I remember after watching the 68 version staggering out of the dark theater with the rest of my stunned human companions, well I staggered out of the theatre again......in disbelief.

title: Yawn
text: Excellent make-up, some convincing acting, good sets and a few eye-candy scenes don't make up for the dead flat screenplay, the sloppy storyboard and the overall sloppy direction.I found myself yawning, slightly irritated, mildly bemused, waiting for something really interesting to happen... just like with some cheap TV-series, just with more pulley systems, more effects, more musical manipulation, and more money.Did I mention that the make-up was great?Well it's not such a bad movie, rather average than bad. Worth seeing for the make-up (in case you didn't get it..;-)), and Helena Bonham Carter's nice performance as Ari.Just don't expect too much of an involving story, and definitely not a movie to remember.

title: Unbelivebly underrated
text: Good actors, great director, great story and brilliant plot twist. I dont know why you hate this movie so much and I can't see any reasons. Its good remake and it isn't bad just because original was better.

title: Really really bad remake
text: This Tim Burton remake of the original "Planet of the Apes" from 1968 (and starring Charleton Heston) is a far, far cry from the quality and plot of the original.Certainly special effects have improved since 1968, but writing has not. The characters were boring and the dialog was awful.  I sat through the entire film with a friend (who thankfully only rented it) and completely understood why, before Christmas, all of the "Planet of the Apes" toys at Target were in the clearance bin.My advice to Tim Burton: don't put this on your resume.My advice to everyone else:  watch the original 1968 "Planet of the Apes" movie.

title: CRAP!
text: Nothing in this movie works, even the Rick Baker makeup is a huge disappointment.  If you want to experience this material as it was meant -- for adults! -- read Pierre Boulle's novel.  The only good thing about this bastardization of Boulle's book is that it makes the 1968 version with Charlton Heston look like the Citizen Kane of science fiction movies.

title: Could of been much better
text: It was not a bad movie, but like 'Sleepy Hollow' it could of been much better.  Burton's directing and Elfman's music have the ability to make a decent movie out of a poor script.  Props for Marky Mark... he really is a much better actor than music performer.  I hope to see him in more leading roles.

title: Well... the makeup was impressive.
text: Tim Burton's new remake of Planet of the Apes is pretty disappointing... visually interesting but shallow.  It really doesn't explore the issues of the day as did the original.  In fact, it's best moments were based on contrived references to the original with familiar dialogue. Interestingly, the only people in the theatre laughing when those references were made were my friends and I (proving my contention that we were among the oldest attendees).  Sadly though, most of these high school students will never see the original and won't know what they're missing.  This film is predictable at just about every turn...  lacking any of the punch that allowed the original to hit audiences with its stunning visual revelation at the end. This movie should have been be more than an opportunity for the makeup artists to remind us that it's 2001 and not 1968.  Shame on Tim Burton for not engaging the challenge!

title: The Remake utterly failed to set the tone of the Original Cinematic Masterpiece
text:
How to describe what's so disappointing in this movie? Others have described many of those points so ill not go into them here, but for me, what ruined the remake was the crash landing.In the remake, the main character, astronaut Leo Davidson (Wahlberg) crash lands on an unknown planet into a jungle!
Compare this to the original where astronaut Taylor (Charlton Heston) and his crew crash land into a bleak desert, its awe and desolation so well portrayed that it firmly set the tone for the movie going forward, add to that the brilliant sound effects during the various desert scenes, and the tone stayed with you until the very last scene of this cinematic masterpiece!In the remake, the jungle landing instantly deflated expectations, and drowned the tone in the swampy shallow waters of the cramped confines of the dense jungle foliage. While the tone was artfully and carefully developed in the original, where the astronauts spent some days traversing this vast eerie desert, cleverly building up expectation and and a certain level of suspense, the remake assumed the audience has no attention span, and immediately sends astronaut Leo to the ape city just a short walk away from his crash site.From there, one scene runs to another, as the plot and setting is further dumbed down.
One final note: The Forbidden zone in the remake is hiding what is more or less a single object, but in the original, the Forbidden Zone conceals an entire ancient civilization. The original far outdoes the remake in scope, vision and refinement. The remake, while it made good effort in ape makeup, cannot hold a candle to the original motion picture, which far excels the remake in practically every category.

title: Again cool premise, with a little spoon of social criticism unfortunately to the detriment of the characters
text: I didn't dare watch the original, so all the remake stuff has to be left out here.Pros: The ending was unexpected and blew me away, the social criticism was very surprising and made me think. The costumes look very good because they are still classically hand-made and no CGI mess.Cons: The film got me from the beginning, the first third of the film is still very mysterious and almost a little horror-like. However, this whole atmosphere is somewhat spoiled by the fact that the Monkeys somehow quickly mutate into joke characters instead of serious opponents. The story is pretty flat and the character development is barely there for the main character. The plot twist was pretty predictable.Conclusion: I fluctuate between 7/10 and 6/10 stars because I don't know what to think of this film.

title: Taking out all the substances of a film.
text: This is planet of the apes for the dummy's. All the questions of society, religion, the horrors of the Cold War and the threat of men's extinction exchanged for explosions and a love story between humans and a monkey.

title: Visual study of ape behavior
text: If you go for the story, you're making a mistake.  Planet of the Apes will always be just campy enough to evoke less than serious empathy for the protagonist plunged into such a freakish society.  In the 2001 version, makeup, special effects, and marvelous acting on the part of the ape actors is the reason to participate.  Tim Roth is captivating.  He is no longer human when the lights go down in the theater.  Helena Bonham Carter is equally intriguing though a bit overzealous in her ape portrayal.  Mark Wahlberg does a nice job but could have used some meaty script material to engage the audience more.  What was the purpose of the human love interest? She ought to have been cut completely.  I see no reason for her in this plot.  Tim Burton's planet is eerie and real enough to let your mind ponder the potential of an ape world.  But then the apes speak and their dialogue is predictable, goofy, and finally disappointing.  With such great talent on board, a great script should not have been too hard to find.  The action was written with plenty of thought and maturity, but when it comes to verbal communication, let's just say a real ape could have written better.

title: Even worse than I thought it would be...
text: I had VERY low expectations for this alleged  "re-imagining" of the original -- and they weren't even met!  What were they thinking? (Answer: They weren't.) Please don't waste your time on this Hollywood trash fest. Clip your nails, balance your checkbook, do anything besides watch this. Remember: If you rent stuff like this, it will only ensure they make more.

title: Awesome
text: This movie has had a lot of bad reviews through time. Well, people complain that this isn't a good replacment to the original planet of the apes. This is not the case, for this is a prequel of the movie escape from the planet of the apes. The movie was to imply that the apes came from human activity, and the ending was a possibility for a new movie. The sequence of the movies are, planet of the apes (2001), escape from the planet of the apes, conquest of the planet of the apes, battle for the planet of the apes, planet of the apes (1968), and beneath the planet of the apes. The new movie rise of the planet of the apes is just a new way of showing how the world resulted to the scene of the planet of the apes (1968). So, don't bag on it, for it is good for what it is.

title: Lack luster and un-engaging
text: Tim Burton's take on this franchise is really appallingly bad. The characters are uninteresting and the dialogue is virtually non existent.I especially hated the scenes where Wahlberg leads his merry men through the jungle. Now, this guy has just fallen from the sky unto an unknown planet. You would think that he would take it slowly as he is not familiar with his surroundings, but no. He instead walk as if it's his daily road to work and not once do you get a sense that they are being chased. There's a scene where all the soldiers are ready to march and at the last minute the general played by Tim Roth, gets called away because his father is dying. Yes it was perhaps a pivotal scene (which isn't saying much as there aren't any pivotal scenes) but why place it just before marching off? The movie is just not worth watching. Really watch the original if for nothing else than the famous lines by Heston.And for those of you who think the makeup is good...well...maybe I've gotten accustomed to better things because I was not impressed. I mean...The Lord of the Rings had way better makeup than this one, and they premiered at roughly the same time. No, watch the original or if you want the more modern take on the franchise go watch Rise of the Planet of the Apes - now THAT'S an epic movie largely because of an excellent Andy Serkis.

title: Remake versus the Original.
text: For all the special effects and souped up ape costumes the remake isn't as good as the original. I wasn't much struck on the acting or the story line for that matter either.  The Charlton Heston as Taylor version still stands the test of time despite being made way back in 1968.

title: In all Honesty, this is extensively more of a movie than the original. No offense Heston!!!
text: In all honesty, I can say that Tim Burtons version of this film made the original in all honesty look like (as that saying goes) look like ape sh**! But that is just my opinion. The graphics, the story, the whole thing seemed to grab more of my attention than the others did... Now there is no doubt that Charleton Heston did an extrodanary job acting in the others, but Mar Wahlberg isn't bad at all in this one! Mark Wahlberg is honestly a good actor, and just because he is not viewed in the same way that Heston is, doesn't mean that he can't give a good performance! Anyways, the whole film was extrodanary in the aspect of anyone who enjoys good plots and imaginative views! PS, I loved the intro for some reason... So Tim Burton, keep up the good work!

title: Good film. Bad ending.
text: Okay, if you don't know... the original Planet of the Apes movie was hailed as a classic. Despite being basically a B-movie with a load of men in rubber masks, it had a unique ending which will be remembered throughout cinema history (if you don't know what it is, then I won't spoil it by telling you). Therefore, now we have the remake (or 're-envisioning' as the film-makers like to call it), it had two choices: either copy the original ending and leave everyone saying they ripped off the first, or try to match it for shock value.I don't think they would have won doing either. They tried 'shock value' and failed.However, if you ignore that, Planet of the Apes (the remake) isn't actually a bad movie. If you like sci-fi (and can forgive the blasphemy of remaking such a classic) you should at least enjoy the make-up - which is awesome for creating new and varied races of apes.Not counting the ending, there are other negatives, too. There are more human characters, most of which don't get the screen time they deserve to be fully developed (and any fans of Kris Kristophen will feel short-changes as his addition is basically an extended cameo). Plus the action isn't that action-packed (but then Tim Burton is hardly an 'action director').However, despite the negatives, it's still not a bad movie. It'll never be the classic that the original was and it was a disappointment at the box office (meaning the ending will never get the explanation it deserved). Don't expect too much and enjoy the grisly performance of Tim Roth as the evil ape leader and not being able to recognise Helena Bonham Carter in her make-up.http://thewrongtreemoviereviews.blogspot.co.uk/

title: This movie was terrible
text: No offense to you Planet of the Apes fans, but I expected a little more out of this one. If your going to remake a movie, then you need to attempt to make it even better then the original. Mark Wahlberg is a very talented actor, but was not the best to play the character he played in the movie. I thought this one along with Ishtar was probably one of the most un-necessary movies in film history. I mean c'mon, that's like making a Problem Child 3!

title: A Good Bad Movie
text: The Movie Is Not Bad And Also It Is Not A Great One Either. The Plot Is Engaging And Entertaining But Some Of The Things Didnt Make Sense. The Production Design Is Great. The CGI Was Good. The Acting Was Mediocre. The Characters Are Poorly Written And Underdeveloped. The Ending Is Dissapointing. Except Leo, Most Of The Characters Are Forgettable. I Liked The Pacing And Cinematography. The Editing is Good. The Sound Track is Easily Forgatable.

title: Not an epic.
text: Went to see this last week, and decided before going not to compare it to the old classic. I have to say the make-up effects were pretty good.-Except Helena who really does look like Michael Jackson. I have to say the feeling of physically powerful apes came over very well. Acting was so-so. But I really missed a good battle scene. I thought the included scene was pretty short and pathetic. And then, like a lot before me have said...The ending....What ??? How ??? Huh ????

title: Loved it!
text: Having never seen the original, I watched this movie many years later and the plot on its own is very entertaining.The story flows well, and everything seems to make sense as the story keeps on going. I'm not good at judging effects, but I found everything quite believable. On top of it, I loved the atmospheres created (mostly because it is a Tim Burton movie but with less of his usual style).The actors were incredible and sincerely, it was an awesome movie. I liked the plot, the actors, the directing and I think this movie is way underrated since it's being compared to the original which I heard is not even close to this plot. All in all, definitely worth watching!

title: Passable
text: Lush settings and advanced makeup artistry are the highlights of Tim Burton's quasi-remake of the 1968 Franklin Shaffner film (itself based on Pierre Boulez' novel) but there isn't as much of interest going on here as there was in the first film. It's an action film, pure and simple. Whatever political comment Shaffner's film had is bleached out of the screenplay (by William Broyles, Jr. who penned `Cast Away', Lawrence Konner and Mark D. Rosenthal); about the only stance the film takes is on the humane treatment of animals and the topic isn't nearly provocative enough in this context. There's a large cast, including Mark Wahlberg (not yet enough of a presence to carry an action lead), Helena Bonham Carter (as stuffy as usual, even in full ape costume), Estella Warren, Paul Giamatti and, as the villain, Tim Roth. Everyone seems to be enjoying themselves but their performances are definitely in a minor key. Burton himself seems to have a curious disinterest in the project and none of the passion that infuses `Sleepy Hollow', `Beetlejuice' and even the misbegotten `Mars Attacks!' is evident here. Still, it's a passable, entertaining diversion with a flair for big screen excitement.

title: Planet of the Bad
text: This movie was terrible.  I went into it with high expectations, only to get a sneaking suspicion that something had gone terribly awry after the opening credits.  These are some of the elements which made viewing this excruciating:1) The set: it looked like a cross between the Wizard of Oz's flying monkeys, the Ewok Adventure and Willow.  I know we're dealing with Tim Burton here, but I just couldn't take it seriously.  And, it always looked like a SET.2)  The cast:  Mark Wahlberg, whom I normally like, just seemed too flat and not commanding enough of a character to lead any insurrection.  Estella Warren, who plays the 2001 equivalent to the original film's Nova, is so bad it's comic.  Check out the first scene in which she's introduced side by side with the Kris Kristofferson character.  The look on her face is so vacuous, you wonder how she's supposedly survived this long on the run. And speaking of Kris Kristofferson: why is he in this movie at all?  His character is completely wasted.3) Danny Elfman's swollen, distracting score:  I felt like I was watching Batman all over again.4) The character development:  The human characters are not developed at all.  We're supposed to buy that there's chemistry between the Mark Wahlberg character and Daena (Estella)?  One doesn't even really know the human characters' names by the end of the film.  I had to look them up on IMDB. I didn't care about any of the characters, and hoped they were all killed by the time the movie ended.5) The tacked-on, twist ending:  Send this ending back for a rewrite! Let's make some sense here, people.In addition to the points listed above, the dialogue was corny.  There were also numerous plots holes and distractions.  One of the distractions was how Daena got lip gloss and managed to shave her armpits while living such a primitive lifestyle.  It's also a wonder that the enslaved and nomadic humans spoke English so well.Helena Bonham-Carter does what she can with the terrible script.  The make-up effects were mixed.  The look of the female primates was not to be believed.  I assume this was done for Burton's lame satiric elements in the film.  The make-up effect on Tim Roth's Thade was more believable.  Tim Roth's scenes fare better than others, although he goes way over the top at points.Don't waste your time with this movie.  Do yourself a favor and rent the original 1968 classic instead.

title: Rubbish
text: Why Tim Burton ever thought the idea of re-making a classic movie like Planet of the Apes is beyond me....like his Batman series (which l didn`t like either...)Planet...is dark, bad lighting, bad acting, bad story, and a finish that is so contrived that is is laughable.The one thing about this film is that it made me put on the Original and l enjoyed it again for the 200th time at least....

title: Ape-raham Lincoln?~?~?? ~!
text: This film was certainly set up for the sequel, that's all I can say. Wahlberg was wonderful, Heston was excellent, and Helena Bonham Carter's humanity, wit, energy and charm shone through her ape makeup clear as a bell.  The film, though hardly satisfying or cathartic, was interesting as a metaphor at least, and I will of course rush to the sequel, if only to experience a more satisfying ending.

title: Disappointing
text: I´m a huge Tim Burton fan and anticipated this movie eagerly. The disappointment was severe! Tim Burton has this time made a movie with characters out of an Arnold Schwarzenegger movie (and a bad one at that) and a story that is sketchy at best.  The only reasons to see this movie is for the makeup -which is fantastic- and for Tim Roth as general Thade- a truly menacing S.O.A.B., awesome performance! That can however wait for video-release (preferably an evening when somebody else is paying), don`t pay full fee for this one. 6 out of 10.

title: Chimply Awful!
text: Having just returned home from viewing this film, I remain stunned.  I expected much better from such a fine director and cast, complete with what seems to have been an unlimited budget.Main beef - where's the plot?  This movie was so predictable and lifeless, I don't know where to begin.  The so-called "plot", was rife with absolutely fantastic leaps of logic (ie. an accidental one-button location of a space/time warp - puhleeeeze!).  Such a pity.The film offered no surprises, other than the guffaws of disbelief from many in the crowded theater.  I'm still trying to understand why somebody felt the original movie, deserving of much praise, had to be remade.The primate characters looked like actors wearing rubber masks.  Nearly every set looked like... well, a set.  Several characters (ie. young warboy), invisible during the development of the story, somehow become important near the end of the film.  But without character background, I felt nothing for them.  The requisite buxom blonde was easy to look at, but left me wondering why she was even there.  Any romance angle between man/blonde or man/girl-illa was undeveloped and anemic, and shouldn't have even been attempted.This was one lame waste of a Friday night, and my hard-earned money.

title: Apes excellent...ending not!
text: In this version of "The Planet of the Apes" the apes get all the attention and deservedly so.  Mr.Wahlberg does a walk-through, which is all that is required of him.  The rest of the humans are negligible; it is the apes which dominate the screen and the story and all are excellent.  The ending chosen was unnecessary; the shock and surprise value was nonexistent. Much better to have gone for something completely original rather than a re-interpretation of Heston's famous last scene which WAS a shock and a surprise.

title: Where do they make the batteries?
text: Ok... I love POTA. All of it. I even have a soft spot for (some of) this one. The story and acting are fine. The effects are good. The ape makeup is amazingly good. So what's wrong? Well... I extrapolate from a single shot in the film: we see a little ape jamming on a Walkman and headphones. Ok... it's a funny little shot, but... consider all of the implications there! So... that Walkman had to be manufactured someplace. The music being played on it had to be recorded someplace. Performed. Batteries are needed for that Walkman too. Where are the batteries made? Is there a grocery store or something to get those batteries? The whole society is in caves. So... are we to believe that in those caves are the manufacturing facilities for the batteries and the Walkman? Are the recording facilities back there? Clothing factories? Gun shops? The mall? That simple shot of an ape boy listening to a Walkman just kills this movie for me. Again... the makeups are great!!!

title: This Apes more than scrapes by as an entertaining and provocative film-going experience.
text: While retaining some of the source novel's and original picture's themes, Tim Burton's version of Planet of the Apes is a very different movie. The subtext, however, remains largely intact. Religious, social and political themes abound, as a distorted funhouse mirror is held up to our own culture.There are plenty of good performances, notably by actors portraying apes--Tim Roth, Michael Clarke Duncan, Paul Giamatti, Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa and David Warner. Helena Bonham Carter manages to be oddly appealing and even winsome through the chimp makeup.While my initial reaction was highly favorable, I'm not sure this new film will posit the longevity of the first one. It breaks no new ground to become a classic.It does feature more simian-like behavior. The apes exhibit physical characteristics of their respective species as they move about and react emotionally. The makeup is extraordinary. The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences should polish up another Oscar award for the brilliant Rick Baker.The movie also seems to be missing a few scenes of motivation or development. I know it was supposed to have been re-edited at the last minute. It would be interesting to view some of the deleted scenes. Here is to hoping for a wealth of bonus material on the DVD.Viewing the 1968 film is not necessary but beneficial to pick up all the intentional references, both in dialogue and situation. Some of them are rather humorous.

title: "Dumb mov(i)e, space cadet!"
text: Eek! When I imagined someone may judge all SF by this movie, I thought about burning my SF collection. The scenario was written without giving much consideration to probability or common sense, not to mention complete disregard of most basic rules of science. OK then, it's action movie dressed in space suit. But action movie needs to make sense too! This one doesn't. I can't believe such steaming pile of bullpoo comes from director of Edward Scissorhands, Mars Attacks! and Batman(s).

title: Good, but did anyone understand the ending?
text: To sum it all up the movie was alright, I wasn't expecting to be as good as the originals, but I just wanted to go see a film to see some good action...and excellent makeup.  I gave it a 6/10, it would've been rated possibly a 7 or a 8, but the ending was confusing...and I still don't get it....

title: A really terribly horrid film
text: A terribly horrid film.  Predictable, with a poor script, and worse dialogue.  Sadly, the ending was, as expected, just horrible.  It's a shame because the original film is just excellent, and I don't understand how Tim Burton got involved with this.

title: Sucks
text: This movie could have been a lot better. In fact, it was fairly decent until the end. However, as others have posted here, I was able to figure out the basic plot of the film after the first ten minutes.The ending was awful. Burton and his people probably thought it would be a killer ending, and, I suppose, it was--it killed the film. The ending did not at all fit with the rest of the story, and now begs the question, "how could that have happened?" I tried to give this movie some seriousness--I tried to think of ways to explain the ending, but they all have Saturn-sized holes in them. Oh, well. My sister warned me that this movie was bad; I should have listened to her.This movie could have been great--but it wasn't. Don't waste your money even renting it.

title: Many new items
text: Very good indeed, more actions and better theme song. I am about to give a 9 rating for this one but the ending is simply disappointed. Also, that is not a good idea to change America's national heritage to something ridiculous. Although i am not American, i think this is not acceptable.Anyway, about the story, well, at first very impressive opening theme and story. It goes well until almost the end of the movie, the last five minutes of the scene which might some audiences confused. But, a totally enjoyable movie to be seen. Well done.

title: Good, if you expect a standard action-science fiction tale, but not nearly up to the original
text: For those who haven't seen the original, this is a 'reimagining', which means that it shares some elements of the classic version but not others. Basically the stories involve a spaceman who lands on a planet where the barbaric humans are controlled by intelligent apes. This version is a good film, entertaining and with a surprising ending, but it lacks the punch and depth of the first edition.Tim Burton is my favourite director. 'Bettlejuice', 'Edward Scissorhands', the first two Batman films, 'Sleepy Hollow' - all excellent: macabre, gothic and filled with black humour. 'Apes' also looks great - the sets are spectacular and the makeup is amazing: the apes truly look real. What the film lacks is some of Burton's darker, slightly disturbing touches. It plays too much like a straight action/sci-fi flick, whereas the original was a powerful allegory for racism and animal rights as well as great entertainment.One of the reasons why the latter film doesn't match up to the original's power is because all the human characters talk. In the original the human's mysterious silence added to the theme of 'men as beasts'. Here that impact is gone, but they might as well not have bothered - the humans still have nothing interesting to say. It's the apes that have all the good lines and characterisation.Also, the ending of the original 'Apes' is one of the greatest in movie history, resonating with meaning, whereas this version's finale feels like a tacked-on surprise designed to set up sequels.The other main reason why the orginal is superior is that Mark Wahlberg lacks Charlton Heston's macho charisma in the role of the heroic spaceman. Heston was cynical, angry, confused. Wahlberg is bland.Nevertheless 'Planet of the Apes' is is a good movie, a cut above the average Hollywood science fiction film. However if I was given a choice of renting the original or the new version in a few years, I know which one I'd chose.6 1/2/10

title: The Worst Movie of the Year Winner!!
text: Quite possibly the most unrealistic movie ever created. They abandoned the original story which is ok, if you have a replacement story. There are no 'shocks', like "the human spoke!". All the humans speak. They speak better than the apes! Yet, they are 'not intelligent'? Mark Wahlberg crashes on this planet and never once shows shock. Apes are are in control? Ok, go with the flow. The original had a nuclear war throw the apes into control. What put them in control here? Beats me. All those scientists on a science station couldn't keep control? They couldn't keep the education level up? Their computer seemed to work still. They couldn't use that? Where did the horses come from? They were on a science space station? For what purpose?These are the types of questions I kept asking myself. The answer to these questions? A script writer who lacks imagination. That's what "re-imaging" means.

title: An entertaining but inconsistant film
text: After watching this film, you appreciate the films of the past that so many have tried to redo. There really not a lot of action in this film except for some fight scenes toward the latter half of the movie. Looking back at the original Planet of the Apes, you could see where there was a definate plot and goal. This remake doesn't have that cohesion. It does work well with the relationship between Whalberg and Carter. But the relationship between Warren and Whalberg develops too quick after the demise of Kristofferson. In that type of primitive society, Kristofferson could be father or husband but we don't know because Warren just says "my family". It's too obvious that the writers used her as competition for Carter. In fact you really see no reason for Kristofferson to even be in the movie. Whalberg's involvement with the primitive humans comes too quickly also. It's like they cut out a part where Whalberg should find out what this planet is for the sake of the length of the movie. The fight scenes seem inconsistant. One minute an ape kills a human with one blow but our hero (Whalberg) takes several blows and falls. But somehow,again, Whalberg maintains the common sense he has in many of his movies. Somehow through all his movies, writers give him lines that make him act (or react) realisticly. While the others have lines and actions that don't seem be what it would be if it was real, Whalberg comes in and acts like the only one sensible or realisitic being. (as though he walked from the seats into the film) So much so that when we see him in the end....an ending that makes absolutely no sense or connection with what we just saw in the rest of the movie, the look on his face is as though he thinking, "what kind of stupid ending is this to a movie" right on the screen.*see more in goofs for inconsistant content

title: Okay, seriously now, why bother?
text: Remaking the original Planet of the Apes was always going to be a big challenge for any director. The 1968 classic was a fantastic sci-fi vision with a bubbling undercurrent packed with issues at the forefront of the era like race-relations and the ever-gnawing fear of nuclear devastation. On top of that, it had a gripping and involving storyline and quite rightly ensured its place in cinema history. However, with Tim Burton attached to this new version you could be easily forgiven for imagining it would be a taut, character-driven new film with much to commend it. After all, it's not like Paul W. Anderson was handed the reigns was it? So it comes as a massive disappointment to say that the 2001 Planet of the Apes is a disaster on every level. The normally reliable Mark Wahlberg is terrible but considering what he was given to work with it'd be unfair to place all the blame on his shoulders. As Captain Leo Davidson he takes on the equivalent to Charlton Heston's lead from the 1968 version but has none of the gritty determination that his predecessor had and spends most of the movie looking utterly bemused, possibly because he's found himself running around a world ruled by apes, possibly because he's been given such a terrible script to work with.The rest of the cast are no revelation either. Tim Roth is an unrestrained monster, but rather than being a credible villain is simply yet another cardboard cut-out Hollywood bad guy whose only separation from cinema's other dastardly Brits is the fact he's done up in a chimpanzee outfit. Burton's squeeze Helena Bonham Carter meanwhile turns in an especially cringe-worthy and highly irritating performance as the daughter of a lead ape senator who helps the humans escape. Funny how it's always family members of incredibly extreme politicians who believe in what's right isn't it? And as she spends most of the film running around talking about how unfair her kind treat the humans, fawning over Mark Wahlberg or screeching wildly, it's very hard to give her any kind of sympathy. Looks like the attempt at making an ape sexy back-fired spectacularly there fellas.It also suffers from Hollywood's tendency to move things along as quickly as possible in case the audience gets bored, for no sooner has Marky-Mark set off on his trek to find a human spacecraft than he's arrived at his destination and is ready to lead a resistance movement. The climax is a huge let down as the ruck between the apes and humans is over within minutes and before you know it, Wahlberg's jetting off into space and returning to Earth for the much talked about ending.Elsewhere, the clichés and general sense of corporate film making abound. Ape suppression of humans means they hit them with sticks and talk like the Uruk Hai from out of Lord of the Rings an awful lot and the script is packed with cringe-worthy tributes to the original ("Get your filthy paws off me you dirty stinking human," urrgh). The finished product is nowhere near the film you could imagine Burton making unless you'd seen it and the whole thing feels like an extended episode of a fourth rate science fiction show that takes itself too seriously. Poor, very poor.

title: good enough without that ending
text: Tim Burton's "re-imagining" of Planet of the Apes was actually pretty good. I think it's just the ending that brought it down.Astronaut Leo Davison (Mark Wahlberg) goes to find a chimpanzee named Peracliese who was lost investigating an electro magnetic storm.  Leo is swept up in the storm and sent to a world where apes rule over humans with an iron fist.  He is captured and brought to Ape City.  A human rights activist named Ari (Helana Bonham Carter) frees Leo and Daena (Estella Warren).  They all escape with others and soon become  hunted by General Thade (Tim Roth).  The group reaches the sacred ruins of CALIMA, and have a huge all-out battle between the ape army and the humans.This movie has intense action sequences, amazing make-up, a good score, fair visual effects, and great directing.  The best performances are Roth's (who I think needs a nomination for best supporting actor) and Carter's.  Burton again does a superb directing job.  The movie itself is good.  I just hated that ending.I give Planet of the Apes 8/10.

title: I am depressed at the last scene.
text: I was so depressed at the last scene while I was so excited to see what kind of movie it would be.   Ok, I like Mark Wahlberg.  He is one of my favorite actors.  I admit it. Besides I still impressed by CG in this movie.  CG is totally impressive.     This movie, however, does not have the satisfactory climax and the unexpected last scene.  It's just depressing.  I almost shouted "What's that!?"   There's nothing worse than the last scene of this movie.

title: A double edged sword.
text: If this wasn't called planet of the apes people would like this movie much more. What's not to like? Well told story that's exciting and entertaining. But since people were looking for it to remake the original? Outdo? I'm not exactly sure. But they weren't happy. The original is a true sci-fi movie. This one is action/adventure. It does keep the main themes but it doesn't explore them like the original.Also what's disappointing (to some) is that you get a Planet of the Apes that isn't really and a Tim Burton movie that isn't really. It's got tremendous visuals, style and atmosphere but they aren't typical Tim Burton. These are also the movies strengths. Burton branches out to do something that doesn't scream his name. And we get a remake that more takes the idea and does a new story with it. I seem to remember this being the first "reimagining" remake. Then after this this seemed to be the approach to remakes. I could be remembering it wrong though.Tim Roth is very good in this. He's a very cool bad guy. And we have never seen him in anything like this before. I was surprised to learn that it was him when I grew up. All of the designs and costumes are really good. That era when CGI was heading into high gear and each big movie did things we hadn't seen before. This is when they really tried with the CG and it wasn't common place enough to say, "That looks good enough."I also remember this dvd being big. It came out just in time for my birthday on the prime of dvds. And it was packed full of extras..I really wish people would give this another shot. It's a very well done and exciting movie. And no, the ending doesn't make any sense.

title: Entertaining, but doesn't live up to its potential
text: Tim Burton's remake of "Planet of the Apes" may well be a disappointment to fans of the original and perhaps even an abomination. However, it is an entertaining film which is not one of Burton's finest, but is decent blockbuster fare.The plot clicks along at a cracking rate, so it is never dull, although a bit more time dwelling on the central character and the world of the film would not have gone amiss and would have injected a bit more interest into the film. Burton cannot make up for this lack of development, but he does provide the film with his excellent breed of design which does make this, at times, an interesting visual spectacle.The characters are also fairly thinly sketched, although there are some good lines in this film, particularly those that reference the original. However, some of the performances, most of which are done through extraordinary make-up, are very good. Tim Roth chews the scenery and most of his prosthetics as he delights in the part of the villain, Thade. Helena Bonham Carter is pretty good, and Mark Wahlberg is fine, although this performance gave no hint of what he would achieve later in his career.However, the wayward climax and somewhat bewildering conclusion let the film's solid base slip and this reviewer was left satisfied, but felt that this could have been so much more. This is a bit of a blip by Burton's standards, but, as blockbusters go, this is pretty good entertainment.3 stars out of 5

title: Fun to watch but a bit silly at times
text: I originally watched this movie as a kid and now many year later I watched it again. This movie has a great vibe to it and the story is fairly decent. However, the main protagonist is miscasted in my opinion and some events are also quite lacking. Like how easily an order from a superior officer is disregarded for silly selfish reasons putting himself at great risk. The same thing at the ending because there couldn't possibly be evenough fuel and oxygen left in that small vessel for the 'final trip'. The main battle was also a dissapointment because 'the plan' didn't make much sense, it didn't work, and choppy editing at times. As a child I felt it had more 'magic' to it but I can't blame this movie for me growing up. Still, because of the great vibe that it has and the excitement at times I still enjoyed watching it again.

title: Good-good movie showing reality in strange ways
text: The movie grasped me from the beginning. Everything I saw on screen took my interesting point of views to the limit. The time-limiting exposed from the start faded into a more complicated, abstract way of cinema. The monkeys were exciting but didn't show reality, unfortunately. I could see a good movie from the start, but then interest started to fade. My reality checking didn't match up to that of the movie. I could see further ways that it could have ended but never understood why they didn't involve the guys in the beginning. You know those guys with the shirts? Why didn't the director make us follow those guys instead of the monkeys? I can't understand the way the formated the movie to make us disoriented from reality-view, really annoying. The way I see it, people has made good movies, and THIS was not one of them mates.

title: so,how do you review an 800 pound gorilla?
text: Ah! Planet of the Apes. I remember seeing the now classic 1968 science fiction film as a boy growing up in Indianapolis,Indiana on late night television with my younger brother and my dad. It was some of the more pleasant moments of my childhood,but that's a tale for another time.Ok,fast forward to 2001. My wife and I took in this flick on a nice friday afternoon(matinee) and I must say this: Rick Baker is a GOD! His make-up is fantastic!Breath takingly real. He is going to get his seventh oscar for this or at least,nominated. Danny Elfman's score was magnificent! That man is a genius. Tim Burton did a good directing this although,it was a very weak script. Mark Wahlberg does ok. I mean,it's no oscar performance.He just acts like a man who just is determined to get off where the apes can talk.Helena Bonham Carter,I tell you,no matter how much make up they put on her,she still has presence and beauty that cannot be denied.(Even though there is one scene that sent a chill through my bones.eeeewww.)Tim Roth and Michael Duncan Clark both make worthy bad guys for this film..but i wanted a little more from the script to make them MORE menacing..alas that was not to be. Now, don't go to this film to expect a masterpiece. Just go and enjoy yourself.Ignore(if you can) the bad dialouge and plot holes.Sit back and relax.It's a little bit of escapism that is worth the matinee price.(Key word:Matinee) The ending leaves a kind of twilight zone feel and perhaps a hint of a sequel,but hopefully they will have a better script with the next one.

title: Stop it Tim Burton
text: This film was a monstrosity, a complete and utter failure. Mark Wahlberg is definitely wrong to play the lead and the plot is a million times worse than the original, the ending makes zero sense and is hilariously bad. The script is far inferior to most other Burton films and it takes itself too seriously as a big budget blockbuster, despite being ridiculous.There are however a few positives, the costumes are quite good and the sets are brilliant in parts and Tim Roth is suitably villainous but that's not enough to make a good film.3/10: One of Tim Burton's worst

title: Please don't waste your time with this movie
text: After suffering through the abysmal plot development, I then had to suffer through the even worse execution of the plot! It would have been nice if the actors, who have potential, would've had a script to work with...But unfortunately, that was not the case, there was poor dialogue and the screenplay was even poorer. I was especially disappointed in the lack of any type of sequence among the events that took place. Not to mention, I'm not too thrilled with monkey romances. It was a very hairy experience, no more monkey business for me or Soe. Democracy to Burma.

title: HOLLYWOOD NEEDS NEW SCRIPT WRITERS!
text: I'm gutted, one of my all time favourite movies Planet of the Apes' is to be remade by one of my favourite directors Tim Burton' at last a film to really look forward to. Oh dear! What's with these filmmakers, why do they seem to pay no attention to the story and script? Planet of the Apes (2001) is a stunning piece of film work with great make-up, effects (a few actors aside) an excellent cast.The first half of the movie is entertaining and builds well though it doesn't take a genius to work out where the story going. The second half comes across as though they ran out of time and were not sure which way to take the movie. Because this it becomes farcical! It looks like they panicked, the problem is the original movie is a classic and easily stands the test of time, the end, still a very powerful image. They concentrate of trying to replicate (in a different way) this but it's desperate. If you're going to see this film try to forget about the original and just enjoy it as a different film. This is difficult because they insist on repeating the classic lines from the first movie. I suppose they were trying to be funny, it was funny but for the wrong reasons. Planet of the Apes is an entertaining movie that does not carry much impact Michael Clark Duncan is big, Mark Wahlberg is good, and Tim Roth is great, though given the costume, setting and make-up not a difficult task! People will not be watching this film in thirty years. Yet another disappointment.

title: Great remake!
text: This movie was a great remake with a different twist......Tim Burton did a great job.....much better that the newer ones with all the unnecessary prequel back story....less is more in my opinion!

title: Tim Burton has made a fun, if not great, remake
text: Tim Burton is one of the most visually inventive directors of our time. "Batman" showcased a vividly realized Gotham City; "Ed Wood" had the authentic look for the story of the worst director ever; and "Sleepy Hollow" showed guts by prominently displaying twisted trees and full moons for a great Halloween treat.  That's just to name a few.  And Burton's "Planet of the Apes" is no different.  Deserts, jungles, extravagant makeup and costumes are all stunning in this film.Mark Wahlberg plays the role made famous by Charlton Heston (who has a short cameo that is terrific fun to see).  He is an astronaut who gets more or less stranded on a strange planet where the apes rule and humans are slaves. Wahlberg leads the people to rebellion, rather reluctantly.Unlike the original "Apes," Burton seems content to throw in more action scenes than dialogue to tell the story.  There is very little social commentary really and the main story seems centered on how Helena Bonham Carter, as a loving ape who cares for the humans, helps Wahlberg in his attempts to save the other people from the evil Thade (a terrific Tim Roth). General Thade doesn't want the humans to rise up, because he'll lose his power as a ruler.But this is nothing new, however entertaining.  While the original pushed a few envelopes by raising social issues, some of them relevant today, and providing real characters, this "Apes" is mostly for show.  I liked the movie on its own terms, however.  It's enjoyable, looks great and has a twist ending that shows the trademark Burton imagination that we've come to expect.  In short, expect a few sequels.My Rating:  * * * (out of four)

title: Another tragic summer action film
text: What a travesty.Whilst simply copying the originals brilliant storyline was out of the question, was it really too much to expect something at least vaguely comprehensible and uncontrived?For no adequately explained reason, the apes in this film appear far more aggressive than in the original, and the deafening roar of ape shrieking becomes rather tiresome - the sound mix rarely gives you a moments peace.The action seems to be mostly shot in close and extreme close ups, and that combined with the psychotic cutting style makes you want to close your eyes.Aside from the action there are regular 'emotional' interludes which fall flat on their face in attempting to make you care. These combined with action that not only fails to excite, but instead annoys, make for yet another bastardisation of a classic film.

title: Revisionist Ape
text: Tim Burton's "Planet of the Apes" is dark, macabre, and visually stunning. William Broyles's screenplay is interesting, but the dialogue has it's moments. A dear friend pointed out for me the low point in writing occurs when Leo (Mark Wahlberg) in an attempt to inspire the humans to battle the attacking apes he says "Come on guys! We can take them..." Whoa! Much of "Planet of the Apes" is like that. It has the trademark Burton brooding, dark settings-- great attention to detail. Though the story is in-cohesive and uneven. And there is some killer over-acting, particularly by Tim Roth as General Thade. Mark Wahlberg is okay as stranded astronaut, Leo, who wants to go home. Human activist, Helena Bonham Carter as ape Ari, is convincing in a strange "romantic" role. Liked Cary-Hiroyki Tagawa as Ari's protector, Krull-- the one really heroic character. All the other characters are forgettable. Even with these weaknesses in writing and acting, "Planet of the Apes" is definitely entertaining. It's pretty much an action picture with a slight social context-- very slight. You have great visuals, chases, explosions, and cool looking apes. Burton's reworked surprise ending is also worth staying for.

title: Flawed Film
text: I went into this movie not expecting very much, and came out with the same attitude. This movie was predictable and boring. Three major flaws stood out for me. #1. How did horses, exactly the same kind as we have here on Earth, evolve on this planet, when no other animals seemed to? What did the horses eat, is their food from the jungle or the desert? #2. How did Leo grow no facial hair in this entire movie, which I am assuming spanned a larger amount of time then a day. #3. Was it just me, or did nobody else miss the character development of Estella's character? At the end of the movie, when she kissed Leo, I realized I had yet to learn what her name was. My rating: 2 stars

title: Just Awful
