text: This movie is pathetic.  There are no moments at all when you feel any connection to the characters.  Mark Walhburg was the worst of the cast.  He just stood around with a stupified look on his face.  The action scenes were contrived and trivial.  There was never a sense of danger.  The ape makeup was one of the good things of the movie, but it was probably best on Tim Roth.  Helena Bonahm Carter's makeup was the worst.  There were so many plot holes, illogical plot elements, and incosistencies with the apes that it ruins all the enjoyment of the movie.  Not one actor gave a half-decent performance.  The only thing to see this movie for is Estella Warren. 2/10.

title: Looks great, great attention to detail, loses it's plot half way through
text: Great looking film. Great acting, particulalry Tom Roth and Helena Bonham-Carter. Ape movements and portraying them as a culture used to moving in all three dimensions is excellent, well thought out. Great use of cameos and dialogue from first films. But...Estelle Warren has a pointless role and is completly wooden. The plot peters out into cliches on top of cliches as soon as they arrive at the final destination. Brave but idiot child doing something idiotic, so hero has to rescue him - even has the old weekly serial device of the danger being right on top of him them shifting to not being nearly so close once the situation is resolved. Gimmick to resolve the major conflict is unconvincing, no explanation of why secondary protagonist should drop all his objections and want to live in harmony with species he has despised all his life. Hero doesn't even make a case to him as to why he should do so. Doing for mere appearance of an apparent saviour is incredible. Using small pod to traverse god knows how many universes and our solar system to get home requires too much suspension of disbelief. Ending is just silly.

title: Tim Roth is great...Not worth the fierce hatred it's gotten, but still just average
text:
I'll state right off that this is a prime example of the burning backlash that resonated after this film's release: The Oscar for Best Makeup went to A Beautiful Mind. Apes wasn't even nominated!!! A SPECIAL Oscar was created for the original!!!And that's a problem. The costuming and, especially makeup, in the 2001 Apes is absolutely marvelous. But people nowadays just seem to despise the film, and Burton himself for having directed it. But this is not deserved, although I'll express my problems with it.The story in a nutshell resembles the original: A lone astronaut crashes on a planet ruled by talking apes, and must survive their prejudice against him. But whereas the original had a deeply philisophical plot and dialogue to provoke thought, the 2001 remake is little more than a glamorized chase scene, running too long.I believe Mark Whalberg is a fine actor, evidenced in films like Boogie Nights and the Yards. But here as main character Leo Davidson, he has little to do besides look awed and run away. Literally. There are some lines here and there suggesting what could have been deeper thoughts, but for the most part it's just plot city: React to the apes, run from them, find shelter, rally to defeat said apes. And the worst part is that the rest of the human characters are a mixed bag of nobodies, equivalent to what I call the "Shirts" of Star Trek lore. You know them, they're the extras who get killed defending the heroes whose names we actually know. Giving the humans the ability to speak does nothing more than hand them the chance to rebel more vocally. There's no explanation for why they can speak, and it doesn't really matter that they can. And worse, the fact that the apes are used to human speech takes away from one of the most powerful moments and subsequent scenes of the superior original, which of course is where Chuck Heston speaks for the first time.That does remind me of the fact that although there are a few too many silly puns (as with the original as well, to be fair), the opportunity to reference the original is met successfully too. Heston's famous line is mirrored by an ape this time, as is his famous last line from the first film. In fact Heston himself appears in a role built in irony: Not only does he play an ape this time around, but he also condemns the evil capacity of a gun, which must have made some of his NRA pals a little miffed.Aside from some fun moments like that, the movie's redeemable aspect is, of course, the apes themselves. Using the aforementioned excellent makeup, the actors in ape costume can now emote with the best of them. They snarl, sneer, smile, and speak mostly clearly. No more muffled sounds coming from the almost duck bill appliances that the 60's actors had to work with. The apes MOVE like apes too, loping about, running on all fours, using their feet to hold things. If the movie focused more on them and far, far less on the throwaway humans, the movie would have been much more enjoyable.
What I did like, or rather love about the film, was Tim Roth. I saw the film in the theater multiple times, directly due to Roth's portrayal of the cruel main ape, General Thade. This character absolutely lit up the screen when he was on, delivering lines with the cruel ferocity and impatience of a madman just brimming over with contempt. He has passionate, naziesque hatred of the human race, and makes it no secret that he longs to exterminate them in any way possible. Roth chews the scenery and loves every minute of it, and it surely makes for the most entertaining part of the film. He swaggers, swings, and essentially becomes the most believable portrayal of a primate that I've ever seen. My favorite scene in the film is when he grabs Whalberg's leg from under him, tripping him onto the floor with a crash without even looking at the human. He then jerks Whalberg up and bends him over his lap, to pry open his mouth and look inside to see if a soul exists. Satisfied that he sees nothing, he pitches Whalberg back onto the floor without looking, as one would do to a piece of wadded paper being tossed aside. It's good, energetic stuff, and gives the film a very dark edge that the original didn't quite have.I've established that the film consisted mainly of scenes with Whalberg and other humans running, escaping, and otherwise walking away from the ape city and any other real interest. Now for the ending..I won't spoil it, but I must say this. The original film had one of the best shock twist ending in history, and was a very tough act to follow. This time around, there are two main twists, none very adequately explained or built up to, and at the end the viewer isn't left with awe but rather a shrug, as he ostensibly thinks "some of that was cool, but the ending was pretty lame and / or confusing." And since Tim Burton said he'd rather jump out of a window than direct another Apes movie, we'll probably never have a follow up.
That's sad, considering that this movie WAS entertaining, but not really done right. The apes were very interesting, but at the sake of the expendable human characters. I left feeling as though the raw power and fierceness of the apes was represented, but not enough. And if the movie focused more on them, as I'd said, it would've been more entertaining. But I admit there would've been less story and conflict as well, so what can you do? Now if only General Thade was in it way more....Ahh, yeah.In closing, I found it a fun but disposable film. The original is still better and a way more engaging, thought-provoking film. The 2001 remake is kind of a more short-attention span flash-fest, with some fun stuff here and there but not much more to sustain your interest after a couple viewings. The makeup, costumes and scenery were great, and Tim Roth's General Thade was a blast. But past that, not too much to sustain interest. But I do maintain that it wasn't the horrifying, joke-and-cringe inducing wreck of flames that pop culture might be saying it is. Decide for yourself, but whatever you do don't blame Burton entirely. The man's done some great work, and he honestly tried. Besides, he didn't write the much-rewritten finished script.

title: What in God's name is this?
text: I'm not going to sugarcoat this - this movie royally sucked.  Tim Burton, I'm afraid is losing his Midas Touch; his last film, Sleepy Hollow was amazing, but this, this is a pile of human waste.  Blame it on the screenwriters who obviously didn't discuss this film with one another during the production process.  First of all it was too slow, and ... well, the ending?  What's with the ending???  How could something that happened 300+ years into the future, on ANOTHER planet, change the entire evolutionary process on Earth, resulting in Abraham Lincoln becoming Ape-raham Lincoln??? This movie nailed it's own coffin shut, and stunk worse than the theatre loungechairs.  Aside from paying to see the opening credits, which may have possibly been the only intense moment in the film, and the wonderful make-up jobs, don't waste your time on it -

title: A different film than the original. Appropriately.
text:
I'm tired of hearing all the complaints about this film. Burton's Planet Of The Apes reprise is ambitious, and ambitious undertakings are always subject to harsh criticisms by the unenlightened masses.Credit must be given to Tim Burton even if alone for coaxing out the single decent performance of Marky Mark's overabundant career.Superior performance by Helena Bonham Carter. Worth seeing again and again. The characters of Ari and her loyal companion the former general remain with you long after the film ends. As do many of the ancillary characters.
Rough transitions between model shots and CGI can be excused due to the studios refusal to grant director Tim Burton further time.
5 endings were shot and until postproduction concluded last week, just three days before release, no one was sure which Burton was electing to use. This DVD should be good. Burton is a masterful director. Here is a prayer for sequels.

title: A high-class action movie, but...
text: I had high expectations from Tim Burton's new film, hoping his unique genius would improve upon the dated preachiness of the 1968 original, but, alas, I was greatly disappointed. Of course, this is a high-class action movie and the apes' looks and movement are quite stunning, but the plot is so corny and juvenile. As for the ending, I don't see any difficulty in understanding it (although I'm not going to spoil it to anyone), it is just a pointless twist on the 1968 ending. And Back to the Future I-II handled time-traveling paradoxes so much better. Acting is quite horrible, with Helena Bonham-Carter as her usual pathetic self, underneath all the make up. 6/10.

title: *sigh* I think I want to cry
text:
This was a BIG disappointment.  I want to cry because I am a huge Tim Burton fan and I have never been disappointed until now.  As everyone will agree, the visual effects and the makeup are amazing.  Rick Baker and crew deserve yet another Oscar.  However, this is where the compliments end.  Let's go down the list of things that I have a problem with:(1) The first 10-15 minutes on the space station looked too much like Buck Rogers for my taste.  Everything was too sanitized and too white. The acting made matters worse especially when it comes accompanied by lines like "Never send a monkey to do a man's job."(2) There was a long period after this where I was happy.  Once he landed on the planet things got better until they reached Calima and it turned for the worse.  Does anyone actually buy the idea that a 3,000 year old piece of equipment that crashed from space would work?  Oh yeah, that's right!  It's NUCLEAR powered.  I guess that the equipment itself would never corrode or rust.(3) Okay... the rest of the humans show up because they heard about the amazing human that will save them.  Uh?  Did I miss something?  Did he do something amazing that I'm not aware of?  At least in the original, Charlton Heston was the only human that could speak.  This ability made him stand out from the rest.  In this version, all humans could speak.  What's so great about Marky Mark?  That's right, he "came from the stars" to save them all.(4) Does anyone else find it extremely cheesy that a chimpanzee lands in a spaceship and saves the day?  Ridiculous.(5) The ending reminded me too much of "Conquest of..." and "Battle for.."
I hope there is no sequel, but I'm sure there will be.  I just pray that Tim Burton does not shame himself again by directing the follow-up.

title: I have seen monkey fights at the Zoo that are more entertaining!
text: This movie is BAD. The actors, the sets, the costumes, the everything is terrific, except the lack of a story. Spelled C-l-i-c-h-e can you not grasp the concept? I really wanted to reserve judgement on what I THOUGHT would be a better movie than what I was presented with. The problem is the Apes. Word to the Production, the Apes become TOO HUMAN and that is only ONE of MANY flaws. Damn Boring ridiculous plot! exceptionally boring! if you want that level of reality than for goodness sake have a F****** Story to tell!Tom:)

title: Well done!
text: I have to admit that I had been looking forward to this movie since I first heard that it was being made.  That usually results in disappointment (e.g. Star Wars, Episode 1).  Despite the hype, I very much enjoyed this movie.Aside from the superlative effects and make-up, the script was tight, the story worked well and the acting was very, very good.  Surprisingly, the actors who portrayed some of the apes really stood out.  I find it interesting when watching animated films, I can almost always tell who is voicing the characters right away.  Had it not been for some help from the opening credits, I don't think I would have guessed any of the "ape actors". Tim Roth deserves an Oscar!

title: Good movie but the ending destroyed the movie
text: If you haven't seen it yet...DONT READ THIS!ok..now i can start.The movie is a great action adventure. The story is good..how evolution might do to apes that crashlands on a planet in another solar system. It was a cool movie...but then it happened. The ending...extremely stupid and not thought through by the makers. How could he return to earth..going back in time to his own time. How can earth then be ruled by Apes?And we do know that the ape planet was another planet, not earth. Cause of the 2 moons, and that the crashed spaceships computers logg says so. We know that the general ape, Thade wanted to kill every human on that planet. And maybe it was so he did when our hero goes back in time again, back to earth. But why was it a statue of Thade on earth saying he killed every human. Why was apes ruling earth, cause we know it was eart he came back to cause of his own spaceships computer, and we saw him traveling back.So people you see...the ending destroyed the whole story of the movie..it was just stupid!

title: What were they thinking?
text: This movie must be a practical joke. It was predictable, silly, and stupid. The make-up for the gorillas was great, but most of chimpanzees looked like pigmen. I hope they don't plan on making any more of these but I'm sure they will. The "big surprise" at the end was obvious once Mark Walberg got in his ship. The only thing this had in common with Pierre Boulle's book was talking apes, and the only thing it had in common with the original film was talking apes. Other than that, everything that makes the book and the original film great (even though they are also very different from each other) is gone. This movie should come with an apology at the end.

title: Not as good as the original of course, but...
text: In comparison to the original this remake suffers but because the source material is so strong, I found it to still be a more than worthwhile viewing experience. The makeup, props, special effects, settings, choreography, and sheer attention to detail are all first class as befitting a film of this scale and budget. However, while the entire supporting cast, especially Tim Roth, is very convincing and in fact is superlative in its performance, the star Mark Wahlberg never convinced me he was in this fantastic situation that almost defied description. He almost seemed 'ho hum' about it! Also in this version the underlying themes of ethics and philosophy and even the sheer sense of adventure and discovery seem to have been overshadowed by a more a conventional 'action movie' approach. Still the movie is marvelously entertaining, 7/10.

title: Two hours of your life you wish you could get back.
text: Tim Burton can deny it all he wants, but Planet of the Apes (2001) really is a re-make... and a poor one at that.But even without comparing it to the original (which is far superior in too many ways to even begin listing here), I can honestly say that this movie left a bad taste in my mouth, and dreams in my head of how I would better spend the 6 dollars I wasted if I ever run into the studio exec who gave this film the green light and demanded that he pay me back.The movie drags on and on, and quickly overstays its welcome.  What few special effects are in the movie (make-up, set design, and stunts are totally separate categories, and should never be included under the heading of "visual effects") could have been much better.  The ape makeup is Oscar-quality good, and is perhaps the only thing in the movie worth noting.The story seems like someone accidently dropped the screenplay into a wood chipper, randomly taped pieces of it back together, and then tried to shoot the movie from that: The story leaves us wondering too many things that are not explained, and most of what is explained is downright laughable.  This movie is funny when it tries to be serious, and never funny when it tries to be humorous.  I was so bored watching this, I tried counting (and lost track of) all the plot holes, but the big one at the end completely made me lose faith in this movie as anything but a 99-cent corner store rental to watch with your friends during a night of serious drinking games.Excellent talent like Tim Roth, Paul Giamatti, Michael Clark Duncan, and Charlton Heston (and even the far less-tolerable, media flavors-of-the-month "Marky Mark" Wahlberg and Helena Bonham Carter, whose names we probably won't even remember in two years) are wasted in this contrived piece of junk.  I never once felt anything for any of the characters in the film... except maybe sympathy for being trapped in such a lousy movie.This film is extremely unrealistic (even assuming that you accept the idea that evolved apes have formed a civilization, which itself is an excellent premise for a film, but a premise that could have - SHOULD have - been handled much better than this movie does it).In a summer boxoffice where intelligent dinosaurs roam, a misunderstood ogar finds love, and deceased Egyptians seek vengence, Planet of the Apes (2001) brings nothing of interest or quality to the table.  I usually come out of a big-budgeted, heavily-marketed, action/effects movie ready to get right back in line and see it again.  But this movie made me wish I'd never gotten in line to see it in the first place.

title: Ending??
text: I would have given this movie a 8 / 10 rating had it not been for the ending.  I don't want to spoil anything for those that haven't seen the movie and want to, but the ending blew me out of the water.  I bought the movie at Sam's Club after they lowered the price $10.  I'm glad I waited. Rent it, it's really good except for the ending.

title: What have you done!?!?!?
text: Oh god no! why!? Planet of the apes is such a classic ground breaking film. It's a true masterpiece because it said more about ourselves & society then any other movie, so when you try and remake it your really asking for trouble. The expectations would be so high that such a film would be doomed for failure, which is kinda what happened.I don't care what anyone says, it's always a bad idea to remake a classic like Planet of the apes, hell look what happened to Psycho! it's just better off not to be remade. Heres why this movie ultimately failed: For one thing this really doesn't fit directors Tim Burton's resume. Tim Burton has done masterpieces like Edward Scissor Hands, Sleepy Hollow, Nightmare Before Christmas, Big Fish, etc. So how does a Sci-Fi Action movie fit his bill? I give him credit for having the balls to try but come on! The Lead character (Mark Whalberg) was stupid, Shallow, Arrogant, and bone headed. Whalberg could never fill in the shoes of the late great Charlton Heston. Heston was Larger than Life, Whalberg is kinda annoying in this film. Besides him most of the acting is shallow & over the top. Seriously the dialogue is ridiculous, were the screen writers monkeys or something. The best performances by far were Tim Roth & Michael Clarke Duncan, they were the only bright spots in the film. I thought the Make up was fantastic and worthy of Oscar consideration but that's it for the positive's of this film.I've heard from many people who like this movie and say don't compare it with the original. Of course were gonna compare it to the freaking original! They both have the same titles and similar story what do you guys expect!? My problem is that there are many references to the original, but this film lacks any soul or message that the original had. The original made a serious political statement on society and where were going in the future. This remake is basically a way to cash in. It lacks any of the magic of the original, It doesn't take itself seriously, there are way too many moments of comic relief, The ending made no F*****g sense, and it's just totally forgettable.Planet of the apes probably should have never been remade. Perhaps with a different director, and definitely different writers, a Remake could have been meaningful. Unfortunately this film is a major disappointment, and is totally forgettable. 10 years from now we will still be talking about the original, and the remake will be largely forgotten.

title: stunning makeup 'makes up' for weakness elsewhere
text: i gave this a high rating partially as a razzberry to the higher marks the current cgi films are getting, but mainly because a great deal of what i loved about the 70's movies was the makeup. it made even the last films of that series watchable (and paul williams as an orangutan!). so, in spite of a typical Hollywood snoozefest type plot/script and, worse yet, miscasting mark wahlberg in the lead (more digression, his human 'love interest' should have taken a page from the original and kept her mouth shut) , the wonderful makeup is just so fun to watch! i can't describe my disappointment at knowing we'll never see this again. i cannot abide the cgi cartoonish current apes versions with, if it were possible, even worse plots/scripts...in fact i'm on my way over to them to give them '1's right now, ciao!

title: Plot does matter
text: As usual, Burton is brilliant at production design, but the characters suffer ... and suffer ... until in the end no one is doing anything for any reason but that Burton thought it would be neat if they did.  The ending in particular is laugh-out-loud preposterous.  Oh, what a shame.  He should really stick to producing.

title: PoTA - Never send a monkey to do a man's job
text: I wanted PoTA to be my favourite film of the year, which on reflection it probably ended up being. Lacking the originals social comment, and released at a time when the World's social ills and insurgency are less than in Charlton's '68 original, the film nevertheless provided good action sci-fi and a clever (if not a bit confusing) ending.HBC gave a good performance, and Roth probably outshone Wahlberg as the mean and devious Thade. A great looking film, well delivered by Tim Burton, who was the ideal director to carry the primate adventures into 2000.Burton brought subtle humour to the film (which I had anticipated being a lot darker than it turned out). The orang-utan love pastiche, the little girl as a pet, and the two card playing apes - one calling the other a "Cheater" (Cheetah).A lot of acknowledgements were given to it's father film. Several quotes and a cameo Heston. I preferred the fact that the apes on Burton's planet were unarmed, other than with clubs, the original (especially the TV series had them kitted out with all sorts of weaponry). It was a shame one of the original underlying mantra of "ape shall never kill ape" was dropped, but by and large it stayed relatively true to it's original.Overall: A good re-working. 8/10

title: Superfluous
text: I've read somewhere that this is the worst movie Tim Burton has ever made. Well, for that, its pretty cool !On the other hand, there is nothing in it to get in any way excited about it. Just a very average science fiction story. Well the surrounding are made very nice. The apes really look and behave like intelligent apes. But the story itself lacked any noticeable inspiration, except maybe some nice jokes - such as apes fearing water. On the other hand, there where story holes, and unexplained parts. Especially the end was really bad.For men, there is Estella Warren with her supersweet kissme-mouth. But she appeared quite seldom in the scenes, and had not really much more personality and charisma than the boring Marky Mark, the main actor. Helena Bonham Carter was however very good, as was Tim Roth.I can't really recommend this one.

title: Boy, this was bad.
text: Once again Hollywood has spent an astronomical amount of cash on a movie and forgot to put aside some money for the writng. The characters are among the most shallow I have ever seen, the dialogue is week and the plot...WHAT PLOT? Tim Burtons visual style could not salvage even a hint of entertainment value from this heaping piece of garbage. And to the argument that "it was just a sci-fi fantasy movie what do you expect?" Aliens, Starwars, Terminator/T2, and the Matrix are as well but they are great movies because they started with great stories then added affects to tell them. Not the other way around. If this movie is the last one on the shelf to rent at your local video store then go read a book.

title: A Big Jumbled Mess
text: Like many I had my hopes up when I went to see this film.  Like most, I love the original film because it had a great story along with fabulous camera work, music, makeup and costumes.  The remake is nothing like the original and I knew that going into it.  Burton's Planet of the Apes has great things (set design, matte' paintings, special effects and makeup) in it, but the story and pacing are disappointing.  The mood is too claustrophobic.  There are no interesting characters (Markey Mark the underwear model can't fill Heston's loin cloth). Cliche's are abundant.  Tim Roth's character is a little too evil and over the top.  The humans talk and have nothing to say. It would have been preferable to keep them mute like the original.  Maybe my point of view has been warped by the excellent 1968 version.  Burton's work ended up being one big jumbled mess.  I even took a short nap in the middle. My 12 year old son woke me up by grabbing my shoulder and when he saw I was dozing said "oh my god."  I guess he liked it (he actually called it "OK" as we departed the theater).

title: "Get your hands off of the classics you damn dirty Burton!"
text: I thought it would be a good idea to watch this film with my nephews having just finished watching 'Rise Of, Dawn Of and War For The Planet Of The Apes'. I thought it would give them some perspective and that it would be more accessible for there age group than 'Charlton Heston's' original. I was very disappointed as a result to find that this version changes the storyline so much that it doesn't fit with the newer films at all. Why can't you just leave things alone Mr Burton?In general though, it's not the worst film I've ever seen, but it put one of my nephews to sleep and the other barely looked up from his phone. I think if you take it as it was meant to be, which is a complete re-invention of the story, then you can watch it without any problems. I was just aggravated that I had to explain the original version to the boys so that they could understand how it fits in with the films that they already know. I also then had to explain this one too, based on my IMDB Trivia findings as I had no clue what was going on.Tim Roth probably gives the best performance, whereas the others all play themselves.I don't hate it and I would watch it again in the distant future, but I would hope that I remember that it doesn't fit with the other films.

title: Another great film done by Tim Burton
text: I must say I too thought it wasn't going to be all that great a few months ago but when I saw more previews of it and tv spots I began to think it might be good after all. So I finally see it and when I came out of the theater I was very surprised about the ending it made me wonder like most people, but I won't say any more don't want to spoil it. Tim burton has done again just like with all of his other movies he has made in the past this one i think tops them all in my opinion his movies are in a eyecandy way oh and don't let me forget about the great Danny Elfman his music it so great I bought the soundtrack the next day, but I must say it's better then the original I mean Rick Baker did such a fantastic job on the make-up you would sometimes forget that those are actors up their with all this make-up on. I know that some people wouldn't agree but i hope that there is another Planet of The Apes so to speak sequel I would only see it only if Tim Burton direct's it. Well I must give this movie a 10/10 it's by far the best movie I've seen all summer long.

title: Planet of the Apes
text: This is much more of a straight remake of the original 1968 version that certainly benefits from superior visual effects and animatronics, but otherwise is really quite stodgy and sterile. Mark Wahlberg is the astronaut "Leo" who finds himself stranded on a planet that is dominated by apes that can speak. Just like their human relatives, the Simian community is facing a war. The more benign, cleverer, chimpanzees are facing a conflict with their more aggressive gorilla cousins led by "Thade" (Tim Roth). Luckily, "Leo" can count on the feisty assistance of "Ari" (Helena Bonham Carter) as they race their antagonists to a secret facility deep in the forbidden zone that could offer them a solution and reveal the nature of their past. Wahlberg is good in these action roles. He manages to keep the pace moving along despite a rather weak story that takes quite a while to establish itself, and then is all too procedural as it bumbles along to an admittedly lively and fitting denouement. It's not a great film, indeed was there really any need to remake it at all, save for it being a vehicle for the easy-on-the-eye star? Still, it's an above average production that passes two hours without effort. If you're really eagle-eyed you might spot "Planet" original Linda Harrison (in a cart) but that might be all this has to make it memorable.

title: Good acting, make-up and special effects but terrible story
text: I like the special effects and make-up. The acting is good. TimBurton sent every actor to ape school. So the actors really had apelike behavior. The ape masks and make-up are so good that theactors can act right through them. But this all can not hide the terrible story. It's full of holes. I really like Tim Burton films but I was disappointed with this one. Hope the next Tim Burton film will be a real Tim Burton film again.(Voted 4)

title: Junk Movie of the Year - 2001
text: What a piece of crap!. This is (one of) the most boring remakes ever done. I love the old ones - low-tech, original, ingenuous and totally entertaining. This remake with its millions-of-billions-of-bucks make-up, and costumes, and toys, and tricks, and whole armies of extras, couldn't give me a single emotion - boring, senseless, cold, with a disconnected plot and no acting at all. It's a long dèja-vu, with ideas taken from nearly any sci-fi movies of the last 30 years - Mad Max lost tribes in the desert, Space Odyssey mother-ship, trip-through-the-unknown and white uniforms, Empire Strikes Back ship-through-the-jungle-into-the-swamp etc. etc. - not to mention the J.Lo-video-meets-Tarzan jungle settings, Raquel Welch 'One Million Years B.C.' lookalike Estella Warren, Gladiator style military camp and battle scenes. Wahlberg is wasted, Bonham Carter dreadful and everyone else insignificant. And the ending - can anyone try to explain me what is that supposed to mean? United Apes of America ??? Charlton Heston where are you ?

title: Mediocre movie, terrible music
text: It's just not very good, and the music score it totally irritating. Wahlberg must have gone to the Charlene Tilton School of Acting. He picks one expression and sticks with it. The film adds nothing new to the dialogue on tolerance as "AI" did with its hypothesis on how we will treat increasingly human computers. I think you should see the other goods films that are out before spending your money on this Apes.

title: Get yer stinkin hands off me
text: Greetings again from the darkness.  Somewhat unstable director Tim Burton offers us a very dark, bleak and action-packed re-make.  Yes, it is a re-make despite all attempts to categorize as something other than.  Some wonderful characters here, including the best non-human villain in film history.  Tim Roth creates a truly evil being in Thade.  His walk and talk had me believing!  The sound, make-up and costumes are outstanding, and really had to be in order to pull this off.  Burton provides a few nice nods to the original, but none better than including Chuck Heston in a real flip of roles.  The usually outstanding Danny Elfman (yes, Jenna's bro) has some fine score moments, but overall a bit of let down.  Marky Mark is OK in the lead, but Estella Warren (from "Driven") is downright awful.  No other human has highlights in their hair!  Michael Clark Duncan ("The Green Mile") is chilling as the sargeant of the ape army.  Again the sound comes into play everytime he speaks or roars.  Not really sure of the purpose of the ending. It is not a surprise ending, but I cannot tell if this is a tip of the cap to the original remakes, or if Burton thought he was providing a shocker. The ending kind of flops on both accounts.  But that should not prevent you from seeing the movie.  Just make sure you go to a big screen, with great sound!

title: A planet where screenplays are written by apes?!
text: Tim Burton is not a director. He is one of Hollywood's top production designers, but he is not a director. His direction is all style, and no substance."Planet of the Apes" is too self-consciously jokey, and has a mean-spirited quality that is becoming too common in Burton's films. He seems to resent his own audience.The film is worth seeing because of the ape makeup, and the performance of Helena Bonham Carter, but it is, overall, one of the biggest disappointments of a weak summer.

title: So hard to watch this...
text: Having grown up with the original movies, tv series, toys, etc... it is SO hard to watch these remakes. I don't blame the actors, I basically blame make up... though the gorillas were spot on. Why did they make HBC look like Michael Jackson? And the orangutans were pretty awful as well. Why can't they find crappy movies to remake? Or better yet, come up with ORIGINAL ideas!! Sigh..

title: Only thing worse is Burton's explanation
text: My first viewing of this film was on DVD...after not understanding the ending, I decided to watch the final chapter a second time, but this time with Tim Burton's commentary track turned on.  This must be heard to be believed!  He goes on for the whole chapter and also half the final credits trying to defend the ending, but he is stammering and interrupting himself and making no sense at all.  It seems he rarely finishes a sentence during this explanation and for all the noise he makes, he doesn't say a single thing.  His basic message is apparantly, "This ending does not make any sense, I only put it in because I thought it was a neat visual," but it takes him forever to say that because he's trying to validate it at the same time even though he himself has no explanation.  Wow...I don't know how the rest of the commentary track goes, but the commentary in the final chapter is the worst commentary I've ever heard on a DVD.  I felt embarrassed for Burton just listening to it.

title: Reasonable re-imagining of a classic tale
text: I liked this film... it was not a great film, but it was a good film.  I felt that it entertained me for the 2 hours or so that it was on and I didnot feel screwed out of 6 bucks... however, this film did not MOVEme the way the original film did... it danced with certain issueswithout ever really delving into them... it used the image of slaverwithout addressing the substance (and so had to rely on deus exmachina resolution rather than the more cerebral ending of theoriginal...)Overall, I think that the ending of this film would have been better atthe end of the original movie, reminding us that WE were the apesand bringing home the point of the film a clear way.  However,since this film only used racism a slavery as a plot device theending simply seemed to say 'boo' rather than to make one thinkor reflect.This is not to say that I disliked Tim Burton's version in any way,but simply to point out that it does not have the same resonanceas the original... worth seeing, but make sure you give the 1968one a read as well.

title: PHENOMENAL visual and technical achievement.
text:
I remember seeing this movie in theaters, almost 20 years ago.
And the more time passes by, one thing becomes ever clearer - this should've been a landmark, an industry defining movie. Its mask work is absolutely brilliant triumph of practical effects, that is STILL absolutely unrivaled and superior to any CGI.
Sadly, the revolution did not happen.
Instead of recognizing what can be done with classical "make up" techniques, the movie industry collectively indulged into artificial image manipulation, to its utter detriment.

title: Good but not great
text: I saw Planet of the Apes last Friday and I got a say that although it's not a bad film, it could have been much better. The film s biggest flaw is that some characters are just plain useless. Especially the boy who always wants to help Leo and Leo's love interest ( he talks to her like 3 times in the whole movie!).On the plus side the acting is pretty good, the special effects are A+ and the ending, while it doesn t have the same impact the original had, wont disappoint you. Tim Burton is known for his great visual style(Sleepy Hollow, Batman) and he does a great job here too.7/10

title: What do you want from a summer movie?
text: Wow!  Lots of comments here, and most of them negative!It wasn't that bad.  Tim Roth was terrific (villain of the year?), great special effects, great action, great humour, even some satire.  What else would you want from a summer movie?  Not the best or most logical script in the world, and not a patch on the original movie, but this is not unknown in a remake.  If you believe what you read Hollywood has been trying to make a new "Planet Of The Apes" movie for years, and Tim Burton was the man who actually managed it.  For that at least he should be applauded.The ending didn't really make any sense.  Many people have already commented on the ending, and I will not add to the comments here.  What I would say is that I wonder if Tim Burton, who has said that he will not be involved in a sequel, chose this ending as a challenge to whoever will be doing the sequel - and surely there will be a sequel.  You know "explain that, if you can?".  Just an idea.

title: A terrible film
text: Im a fan of the original movies, and series. Tim Burton is a personal favorite but this is by far the worst movie he was involved with. First of all, the acting was so bad that they seemed to have rushed the shooting of the film. The makeup? not all that. I thought the female apes didnt even look like apes. Helena Bonham Carter was supposed to look attractive, but The art Director should have done a better job. I enjoyed one thing about this movie, and that was the performance of Tim Roth as General Thade. I give this movie 1 star because of his role and Charlton Heston playing the dying father of Thade was a nice touch, but overall this movie stunk. Dont purchase it, instead buy the original movie if your not a planet of the apes fan.

title: Tim Burton does 'oddballs in outfits' better than most, not this time
text: Believe it or not this tale of a time-traveling astronaut faced with a civilisation ruled by super-evolved apes in an alternate universe is director Tim Burton's most straightforward film yet.Leo Davidson's (Mark Wahlberg) love for his monkey impels him to pursue it through a space anomaly that propels him forward thousands of years. Leo finds himself on a new planet inhabited by various types of monkeys, all highly evolved and English speaking, which is a plus But they aren't alone on the planet. The jungles and remote areas around the monkey settlements are rife with humans, some more opinionated monkeys say 'infested'. Almost immediately upon landing on this new planet Leo is captured and bundled in with various other newly nabbed humans to be taken to Monktropolis (not really but it should've been) to be onsold to others.This is where Leo learns of the basic role reversal that this particular 'planet of the apes' experiences. The undisputed rulers of the land are all hairy and like bananas. Depending on their background or upbringing they all deem the humans as potential equals (best case scenario), slaves and house help (middling) or vermin to be exterminated (worst case).The obvious parallels between the current human / animal relationship is constantly and often clumsily highlighted, leading to 127 too many 'tee-hee, they're just like us' moments.After introducing the few main monkey characters including ruthless army leader Colonel Thade (Tim Roth), a slave trading orang-utan played by Paul Giamatti and his human friendly daughter Ari (Helena Bonham Carter), Davidson and a few humans escape from captivity and with Ari in tow head to the badlands, hoping to find answers to questions that needn't be asked.The last hour or so in this uneven two hour monkey-fest descends into a straight up actioner, and not necessarily a good one, the 'twist' ending straight up sucks and is likely the reason that a sequel wasn't even considered, and Burton shows that as a story-teller he does great visuals. Speaking of visuals, the sets are all immaculate and lush, the monkey makeup is for the most part excellent – especially Tim Roth – and the costumes are all well made, the CGI was wisely limited given the limitations of the time and doesn't stand out too much for the wrong reasons.But all the above merely makes Planet of the Apes an immaculately presented, well acted confusing and frustrating effort. After taking so long to ensure that Thade is the bad guy he is never called upon to do much with all his pent up rage and evil, and just why a monkey driven civilisation is such a bad thing is never addressed.After all, lying around scratching yourself and eating is hardly the worst way to go is it? Final Rating – 6.5 / 10. A couple of decent scenes and some creative visuals can't overcome a bland and often lost plot. Tim Burton does 'oddballs in outfits' better than most, not this time

title: cool movie
text: Throughout this movie there were things that i enjoyed and things that made me annoyed.  I enjoyed the musical score to the movie; my props to danny elfman there.  The plot was pretty sweet too...you'll love the ending.  But what really started to get on my nervous was the lead monkey's voice...it was too monkey like, i really don't know how to explain it, but it got on my nerves.  I highly recommend this movie, i gave it an 8.

title: Disappointing
text: I have to say that I was disappointed. It didnt have the same shock values as the original... For example, the humans here could talk! And when Marky Mark 1st saw them, it was like "oh, hey, these monkeys can talk... isn't that something?" The visuals were impressive but thats it... The extras are cool... I tried not to compare with the original, but you cant help it. When in the original, Heston 1st noticed the apes running around in horses, it was like WOW!! Then when he speaks, it was like Oh oh... Here is like nothing. When Marky Mark asked some of the other humans stuff like "Hey whats going on here?" The humans where like "Oh, well you see it's like this...". The dvd has one of the things I hate the most... If you miss a line and cant understand what was said, you cant just pop the subtitles... You have to go to the main menu... Same for the sound... The end was neat but I wont give it away... Not to buy, just rent and you'll survive...

title: Typically Burton - huge on style, light on substance
text: First up, I'd like to say that I liked POTA.  It is absolutely gorgeous to look at.  The make-up, effects, cinematography, costumes and sets are all pretty hard to fault.  On the acting front, Tim Roth is utterly fantastic as General Thade and he just about makes up for the price of admission on his own.So what's the problem?  Well as much as I want Mark Wahlberg star to continue to rise, I just don't think he has the charisma to carry Charlton Heston's role.  Not that he was bad or anything, his acting is fine and he is certainly a lot better looking than Chuck ever was.  But is he really the brave and indignant leader of the human race who defies the apes and their dirty paws?  Maybe he would have been better as the plucky young male that defiantly chases after the hero (read George Clooney) after being told to stay behind with the others?But in Mark's defence, I don't think replacing him would have necessarily made the film any more satisfying.  This was a difficult film (conceptually) to make when you consider how highly the original is regarded.  Do you just remake it with the same emphasis of script and story, or if you are going to do something different, what do you change?So Burton does what he does best and creates a film that emphasises style over story, and action over acting (or actors).  It worked for Batman and I think it does for POTA.  Time will tell after the franchise has come and gone whether people criticise "POTA Forever" as not holding a candle to Burton's original!Enjoyable: 7/10

title: Tim Burton's reimagining of Planet of the Apes shows clear signs of a muddled and often generic vision lacking any distinguished identity after a decade of development hell
text: On the far reaches of the solar system in orbit around Saturn, the research station Oberon is performing experiments with genetically enhanced apes involving interstellar travel. When an electro magnetic storm emerges in the vicinity, one of the exploration pods is sent with an ape pilot to investigate and soon loses contact upon entering the field. The ape's handler Captain Leo Davidson (Mark Wahlberg) against orders takes a pod and pursues and eventually crashes on an unfamiliar planet soon after. Leo finds himself on a strange world where Apes are the dominant species and humanity is enslaved. With the help of a sympathetic senator's daughter Ari (Helena Bonham Carter) and several human fugitives Leo traverses this unfamiliar world as the human hating General Thade (Tim Roth) pursues.In the mid-70s following five theatrical films, a live-action TV series, and animated series, the Planet of the Apes franchise entered into hibernation with only the occasional spin-off media such as comics or an unreleased Atari game being the only new entries. In the late 80s Adam Rifkin had earned enough clout with 20th Century Fox executives that he pitched a continuation of Planet of the Apes that would've featured the apes in a setting similar to Ancient Rome. This incarnation known as Return to the Planet of the Apes came very close to happening but changes in studio management caused creative schisms with Rifkin and the project was effectively dead but this began a cycle of various creative teams being attached to a new Planet of the Apes film for over a decade. In the intervening years between the original pitch and the ultimate release, several scripts and directors found themselves attached at one point or another including Peter Jackson, Oliver Stone, Sam Raimi, Chris Columbus, and James Cameron to name but a few, and routinely creative differences were the cited reason with creatives wanting to treat the premise as a serious science-fiction film while executives at Fox often made demands for outright farce or camp. Eventually at the end of the 90s, Tim Burton in a departure from his usual work was hired to direct and opted for a "reimagining" rather than a straight remake. Burton often clashed with Fox due to studio mandates and an accelerated production schedule to meet the July 2001 deadline, and Burton had such a terrible experience making the film when questioned about a sequel he was quoted as saying "I'd rather jump out a window". The film became a respectable success earning $360 million against a $100 million budget but critical reception tended to be mixed with praise going to the make-up and effects work while criticizing the story, characters, and ending. The 2001 Planet of the Apes film is great looking, but underneath it's a pretty empty and soulless experience.If there's anything to be said in defense of the 2001 version of Planet of the Apes, it's that it's a very handsomely mounted production with a unique take on the ape city and make-up work that allows for more distinguished character designs that helps stop them from blending together as had been an issue in the original Apes films. The movie's antagonist in Tim Roth's General Thade is also quite engaging (even if he goes very over the top at points) and he creates a memorable villain if nothing else. Unfortunately the actual meat of this movie in the story and characters is very sloppily assembled and has all the hallmarks of something that's been in development so long that they've crudely crammed what they have into a "chosen one" type hero narrative in order to give something just barely viable for the Summer movie season. Unlike the original where Humans were mute and feral, the humans in this incarnation are slaves and with the Apes' crude methods of securing and controlling the humans that seem really insultingly easy, it makes this world feel less tangible than the one minimally crafted over 30 years prior. We also have a very blank set of characters who aren't all that interesting and fall into vaguely defined archetypes (some of whom have names that aren't spoken aloud and I was reliant upon the credits to identify). Mark Wahlberg is an absolute charisma vacuum in the role of Leo and is one of the most bored looking and detached protagonists I've ever seen in a movie like this. Some of the work by the likes of Paul Giamatti, Michael Clarke Duncan, or Helena Bonham Carter is engaging, but the story is such weak and unengaging slog that it feels less like Planet of the Apes and more like a half-assed take on Stargate.Planet of the Apes certainly has the effects and budget to make something engaging, but it's fundamentally lacking in having a script or characters worth caring about. With spotty worldbuilding, an unengaging blank slate as a protagonist, and a story whose credibility is strained to a headscratcher of an ending (which according to Burton wasn't supposed to make sense and was just there as a sequel hook) Planet of the Apes is a movie where all the resources are on the surface and are in service of disguising hollow innards.

title: Haven't seen the original, but this is one cool movie
text: Not haven't seen the original "Planet of the Apes," I've never been part of the fan club.  I wasn't heavily anticipating this remake, like about ninety-percent of the viewing public.  In fact, I predicted it would suck. For some reason, I'm not a sucker for all these big-budget Hollywood summer blockbusters.  I thought I'd feel the same way about this movie as I did with that borefest "The Mummy Returns."  Even action movies can put me to sleep, if flashy special f/x is the only fuel to keep them going.  But as it turns out fifty-percent of the time, the movies I least anticipate are the ones I end up liking quite a bit.  First of all, it's directed by Tim Burton.  I've always been fond of his work (minus "Mars Attacks").  Just like most of his movies, he creates a creepy atmosphere that deeply engages you--sometimes on a conscious level, sometimes on a subconscious level.  And also like most of his movies, he adds a nice touch of humor.  Some of the humor's pretty silly and obvious and some it's pretty subtle.  Whatever route he took, it often worked.  The ape costumes are amazingly realistic and the set designs are very impressive.  Also we have the great Danny Elfman who composed a great score to help intensify the creepy atmosphere.The premise is quite nifty.  A planet run by apes, where the apes rule and the humans are enslaved and put to work and even treated as pets.  That I found very interesting.  The premise is handled nicely, and it was amusing--sometimes hilarious--to see apes take on a human persona.  Playing card games, running shops, etc.In the comic relief department, we have Paul Giamatti who takes on the bumbling henchman role.  Just like his enormously impressive debut as Pig Vomit in Howard Stern's "Private Parts" he is absolutely hilarious.  Now, my mother saw this movie before me, so she pointed out that Charlton Heston had a cameo appearance.  Watching the film and seeing his name absent in the closing credits, I wasn't sure who he played.  I had a hunch he played Thade's father, and I was right.  The hint that sorta gave it away was when he quotes his famous "Damn you all to hell" speech on his deathbed.  I wonder if others caught on that it was Heston in that cameo, because I don't hear much buzz about it.  The story's not topnotch.  This is overall shallow, predictable entertainment, but it works.  I enjoyed it a lot more than expected, though it dragged at points (especially in the third act) and went on a little long.  Tim Roth is great as the villain.  If I didn't check the credits, I wouldn't have known it was him.  He didn't even use his British accent (something he's amazingly good at covering up).  And behind all that makeup, he's almost completely unrecognizable.  Though I haven't seen the original, I'm pretty sure Heston played a much better hero than Mark Wahlberg.  I don't think Wahlberg's a bad actor.  It's just, he's one of those actors who doesn't seem to go the whole nine yards for his craft.  He speaks in a moderately monotone voice, and never seems to have much substance behind his performances (even in his acclaimed role as Dirk Diggler in "Boogie Nights").  He's good in this movie, but they could've cast a better lead. Someone with a more commanding presence.  Please keep in mind I didn't see the 1968 version, so I might be a little sweet on this remake.  After seeing this version, I'm more anxious to check out the old version.  I heard a lot of buzz about this movie's ending. Though I didn't think it was a bad way to end things, it was...weird.  A little enigmatic.  Something you might have to ponder for a while.  Though it's nothing as subtle as M. Night Shamalyan's ending for "The Sixth Sense." Tim Burton really did an impressive job, this is another score for him. It's good, fun entertainment that doesn't take itself too seriously and leaves sufficient room for comic relief.  So I will recommend this movie, but if you're a die-hard fan of the original--please don't get on my case!My score:  7 (out of 10)

title: A grand opportunity missed.
text: This is without a doubt, Tim Burton's worst film to date. I've read other reviews of the film and agree with the general consensus that the score (Elfman) and the makeup/special effects (Baker, etc.) were spectacular. Of course they were! Why shouldn't they be? With the current level of sophistication we enjoy in special effects and advanced makeup/prosthetic applications there is no excuse whatsoever for shabby makeup and crappy effects. What are we left with after the glitz? Stuntmen jumping 20, 30 and 50 feet into the air again and again and again. That particular effect was so overdone throughout the film as to render it completely flaccid by the end of this piece of garbage. Plot? There was none, really. This was purely an action film with a "screenplay" that was written by and for idiots.

title: What a farce
text: First what was good about the movie and it wasn't much, the makeup was great. That's it    Does not compare with the orginial, not in the least.  The ending was laughable and  a disgrace. Lincoln (My favorite President as an Ape !!!) Give me a break.

title: Tim Burton in Hollywood mode
text: I have never been a great fan of Tim Burton, despite his great talent, his skills in terms of story telling and directing too. It is simply not my stuff, not my world, my atmosphere. He definitely has his own trademark. So, I was surprised to have seen this movie because I am a big fan of the seventies films series - which actually began in 1968 - and I absolutely wanted to watch the remake. But I did not notice any typical Burton's trademark in this good film. Nothing in common with his previous stuff. Unlike for instance MARS ATTACKS which is closer to the rest of his filmography. I like this film but it won't let me forget the terrific Franklyn Schaffner's film, starring Chuck Heston.

title: Who directed this film and what have you done with Tim Burton?
text: I am a huge fan of all of Tim Burton's previous films. They contain fantastical fairytale worlds inhabited by beautiful and strange beings. They have a degree of warmth regarding the beauty of the outsider. His almost baroque and gothic imagery are sublime within their own right, and the ultimate message of understanding and appreciating those who are different completes this magical composition. His wonderfully facetious dark and light humor dominate and charm audiences. None of these qualities were present in Planet of the Apes. Mark Wahlburg was an unsypathetic hero with very little character development or history. The same can be said for the rest of the cast sans the comic relief character of the slave trader. No magic here, except for the disappearance of Burton's usual artistic and unique vision. I honestly could not believe that he directed it. Tim, please, come back to us!

title: Nothing compared to original but worth seeing. Kept me entertained.
text: The film was nothing compared to the original BUT you have to understand that going in.  Otherwise, it kept me interested and entertained even though it left alot to be desired.  I rated it a solid 6 - its worth seeing.

title: completely uncalled for
text: I'm not sure, but I think it would take a million monkeys on a million typewriters a million years to come up with a dumber movie.   This film was an absolute mess and should never have been made in the first place being a remake of a movie that didn't need one!Mark Wahlberg essentially plays the same character he played in THE BIG HIT (a blandly "nice" guy in some sort of trance), except this time he's landed on an ape planet in a small spacecraft which can miraculously keep track of what year it is when he goes through wormholes.  Of course he stumbles onto an advanced tribe of apes slightly better made-up than in the original, but at a technology level further back (these ones don't even have guns).  It isn't long before he's walking in Charleton Heston's footsteps in befriending an ape woman and, (sort-of) falling in love with a human woman, and leading a small revolt against the although this time around there isn't even a legitimate reason for him to be doing so.  The entire premise is completely ruined by changing it so that all the humans on the planet can talk and think at pretty much a 20th century level. The original PLANET was based around Charleton Heston trying to prove to the apes that humans were just as smart as they are, but politics and religion alike suppressed the historical truth.  This film has none of this. It's just a dumb action sci-fi movie with little action (most of the violence is off-screen, a la BATTLEFIELD EARTH - an eerily similar sci-fi disaster) and no plot! What semblance of a plot there is is completely ruined by the multitudes of red herrings, plot holes, and a general lack of depth in any area.  Never is the ape society really explored or revealed, nor are any of the characters fleshed out.  We never learn who the other servants are or why they bother tagging along with Wahlberg in the first place.  We never learn how many apes there are or why they have superior technology to humans.  For some unknown reason there are several different species of apes (Gorillas, Orangutans, Chimpanzees) on the planet, yet the ship they all originated from carried ONLY CHIMPANZEES!!   More uncalled for changes: They made the monkey women way too "pretty" in this one, not looking any different from normal women except for their hairy hands and big noses (most of them could actually probably pass for humans) and the human women are all in full make-up with manicures and perfect teeth... when the humans are supposedly living in the stone age!  I know it's just a movie, but COME ON!  How dumb do they expect us audience-members to be.This all wouldn't be so bad if the film hadn't resorted to so much useless parody, such as an ape saying "Get your paws off me you damn dirty HUMAN" or later when Charleton Heston's ape character says about humans "Damn them all to hell!"...  my jaw just about literally hit the theater floor for that one.  What were the scriptwriters thinking?  Do they imagine the few of us who remember those lines from the original will be amused at all by this mutilation of the franchise.  I think even BATTLE FOR... was better... at least the ending of that movie made sense!  I'm not going to ruin it for you but the ending really surprised my by how awful it really was... not that I couldn't see it coming miles away but I honestly never imagined the writers would be THAT tacky.I'm usually very forgiving watching bad sci-fi movies, but this one was WAAAY below lowest common denominator...insulting to my intelligence, confusing, AND boring.  It hasn't been since I watched BATTLEFIELD EARTH or STAR WARS EPISODE 1 that I have sat in the theater completely appalled at what I was watching.  Let's pray that this disaster acts as a career killer for director Tim Burton.  He's made a few very good movies but the magic is over.

title: Not true Tim Burton
text: The film was decent for a summer movie, but this is not vintage Tim Burton. Too commercial like Mars Attacks.  What is true Tim Burton?  Edward Scissorhands, Batman and Sleepy Hollow.  When I heard that 20th Cent. Fox rushed this movie for a summer release I started to get worried.  Out of all the summer movies this year (which has been a horrible year for movies) this ranks up there with The Score.  THe make-up is some of the best you will ever see and the one of the fun things to do is to guess who is playing the ape.  I would recommend it, but remember it is a true summer movie (bad script, good special effects and some bad acting).

title: Of you love makeup in movies watch this movie
text: t is the year 2029: Astronaut Leo Davidson boards a pod cruiser on a Space Station for a "routine" reconnaissance mission. But an abrupt detour through a space time wormhole lands him on a strange planet where talking apes rule over the human race. With the help of a sympathetic chimpanzee activist named Ari and a small band of human rebels, Leo leads the effort to evade the advancing Gorilla Army led by General Thade and his most trusted warrior Attar. Now the race is on to reach a sacred temple within the planet's Forbidden Zone to discover the shocking secrets of mankind's past - and the key to its futureDear all, Forget all non nonsense about the ratings and bad reviews if you are a true Hollywood remake lover and wanted to see best makeup of the year and of its era just rent this DVD or buy it, if you can

title: Monkeybusiness!!
text: I went on the movie, Planets of the apes, with "semi" expectations. For some reason I didn´t expect much from talking monkeys. In some way I was surprised with how fantastic the make up was in the movie and how well the monkey, sorry, "ape" caracters were well performed. The physical expression off them was believable and worked quite well but thats about it. I hoped that the movie would get better in the second "half" but on the contrary it got twice as bad.I heard that Tim Burton had made 5 endings to the movie and this one was chosen rather than the others. Anyone who has seen the movie must be thinking, how bad could the other four endings be so that this one was chosen. The ending is so bad that it effects the whole plot of the movie and made me give this movie 4/10.If the ending would have been different, would have made a little bit of sense, then it would possibly get a higher score.Please write me if you think this writing is out of the blue, or even smack down in the middle of the blueÁgúst Kr, IcelandP.S. pardon my spelling

title: 2001 POTA in-depth Review!
text: Many people think that the original 1967 Planet of the Apes is a classic and a master piece. Sure its one heck of a film especially back in the day when it was made. It had great costumes and makeup with great music by Jerry Goldsmith and a tremendous shocking end. This Planet of the Apes has awesome costumes and very realistic makeup and/or masks. The music is outstanding by Danny Elfman and the 2001 version has even a more shocking end. It seems to Me many people are against or hate this POTA. I really don't know why, it has such an interesting cast and they play their parts very well and sure it may not be director Tim Burton's darkest film but in My opinion it is one heck of movie! The way I see the film it has a lot of emotion and all of the characters are so likable. I'll try to explain this as best as I can about Helena Bonham Carter is a very good looking woman and her character Ari is beautiful. I know she is under tons of makeup and looks very realistic as an ape but whenever she is on screen I can't help but think how neat she is with her voice and personality. Tim Roth's Thade is an awesome character and his character deserves a lot more credit. Roth's performance is truly menacing. Charlton Heston put on another solid performance as Thade's father. Another thing that gets into this movie so much is the music. Each scene is so great with the fantastic score! Below is in My opinions an in-depth look at most of the characters that is in the 2001 Planet of the Apes!-------------Mark Wahlberg as Captain Leo Davidson - Leo Davidson, after the incident of going after Pericles he is stranded on another world thanks to a magnetic storm. The planet he lands on has unbelievable talking apes. He is prisoner but after Ari frees him he gets to know her and her mentor, Krull and some other humans. He joins these two different factions of intelligent species and travels to the forbidden area Calima! Leo is out for himself and to go back home as soon as he can!Tim Roth as General Thade - The great General Thade, a mighty warrior who is afraid of nothing. His mean voice sends shivers down his soldiers back and he hates humans to death!Thade and Ari were once in a relationship but now Ari has other things to do. He loves his father Zaius very much and he is very saddened about his father's illness. Helena Bonham Carter as Ari - She is a beautiful ape and very intelligent as well. She helps Leo escape. She is through with Thade and even though she has feelings for Leo even though he is human. She loves Krull as he is her mentor and in fact he is with Ari all the way with her,Leo,and other escapees from the city.Michael Clarke Duncan as Colonel Attar - The huge Attar is a force to reckon with! He is General Thade's great warrior and best friend. He is a very religious and serious ape.Paul Giamatti as Limbo - The always funny Limbo loves to smell and look good. The human keeper if you will takes his job seriously but when he is forced to follow the escapees his life turns around. Estella Warren as Daena - One of the many prisoners in Ape City,Daena wants out just as much as everyone else but when she meets up with Leo and escapes with the group she has feelings for him but much like he does for Ari he doesn't think much of it. She loves her father Karubi very much and she is shocked and very sad about his death.Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa as Krull - The massive Krull was one of the greatest warriors and a brave leader. He is the mentor of Ari and he is one of the apes who is in the escaped group. His favorite weapons are swords and handles them excellently!David Warner as Senator Sandar - Ari's father, Senator Sandar let Thade have control. He is an ape that believes in manners such as washing hands. He tries not to get on Thade's case and he loves his daughter Ari.Kris Kristofferson as Karubi - The father of Daena,Karubi loves his daughter very much. He is a brave human man but his death in a fight against Attar didn't last long and he never knew what hit him from behind which it was General Thade.Thade's sword decapitated him.Erick Avari as Tival - The male house human is one of the escapees in the group with humans and apes.Luke Eberl as Birn - A stubborn teenager, Birn is a brave young man.Evan Dexter Parke as Gunnar - Another escaped male human. He too is brave.Glenn Shadix as Senator Nado - The great senator Nado. He loves his job and his mate!Freda Foh Shen as Bon - The female house human is one of the escapees in the group with humans and apes.Chris Ellis as Lt. General Karl Vasich - Leader of the Oberon.When the magnetic storm caused malfuctions in the ship a video image played on the monitor. Little does he know that what he just saw was himself in the future!Anne Ramsay as Lt. Col. Grace Alexander - She really cared for the modern day apes in the Oberon.Lisa Marie as Nova - Senator Nado's mate. She is very attractive for an ape and she is always worried about her looks.Linda Harrison as Woman in Cart - Could it be possible that this woman was on another planet at another time or in another lifetime? Could it be that she is reincarnated?Charlton Heston as Zaius,Thade's Father - Thade's father is very ill. Before he passes he wants to make sure to tell and show his son the shocking truth about humans.---------------I just like how everything is in the film. The ending may have been rushed and not make sense to others because it really had several endings but Burton could only pick one. In fact you can also tell as great as the music is if you listen closely some of the tracks are alternatives than the released music on the CD. Also a short time before the final release of the film the producers wanted the movie to be more epic than it was and they wanted it to be like or more like Gladiator and back to the music they wanted the composer Danny Elfman to change the music. I thought it was silly for the movie makers to do that and I am glad it came out the way it did even if the ending is sad and is a mistake or an error. I hope you have enjoyed this in-depth look at Tim Burton's Planet of the Apes. Like I said I love the 2001 version!

title: Liked it but didn't love it
text: My main beef with this flick was the lack of dialogue between Mark Wahlberg's character and the apes where he tries to convince them he is smart.  That is what I remember mostly about the original; Charlton Heston was desperate to prove he was intelligent.  I remember just feeling helpless concerning his plight, and aching for him to succeed.  I would have felt the exact same way had that angle been explored more in this remake.  Helena Bonham Carter's character doesn't go through that discovery, she believes in the intelligence of humans right away it seems.  That fact alone made this version of "Planet of the Apes" far inferior to the original.  Instead of just making it look more sleek, Tim Burton should have been more concerned with this thematic element, an element that in my opinion made the original so compelling.

title: What a waste.
text: This movie was disappointing in so many ways. As my wife put it, they had so much to work with, and they completely blew it. I don't even know where to begin with how disappointing this movie was.The action sequences were non-existent. Times when there should have been a good scene (like the horse-ride through the camp, which could have been really great) were very detached from the action, and consequently quite boring. Both the cinematography and the editing in such scenes were really, well, bad.The acting was stiff. I guess Burton was trying to do this whole thing where people actually moved like apes. But that was annoying. And they seem to have spent two or three times as much time and effort on that as they did on more typical (and effective) elements of acting--you know, emotions, character development, little things like that.The CGI was pretty transparent. When Marky Mark first lands and is standing in the forest looking around, for example, it's SO clear that he's in front of a bluescreen. Ugh. The makeup, on the other hand, was really well done.The score was stifled, I thought. But maybe it was just because it had nothing decent to accompany/illuminate.I expected more cool references to other movies. 2001 was a completely obvious allusion, for example, and they only made one (probably accidental) allusion to it--when Pericles is about to take off in the pod. They could really have done a lot of cool stuff with that--both on the planet and in space. So, what was good about the movie? The makeup, as I already mentioned. That's it, as far as I can recall. Enjoy.

title: OH MY GOD! what a bad, bad movie.
text: I cant believe what I just walked out of. That HAD to be one of the worst movies I have ever seen! I mean, it had potential at some times, and when the crash all comes together near the end, you start the think the plot is pretty good. But then you're shown a surprise- the ending- the bad, bad ending. I wont give it away, but its just really bad. I dont even know why I saw it, I wouldve seen American Pie 2, but it was sold out. I shouldve seen The others. Dont waste your money, but DO rent it, so you can see what I was talking about with the ending thing.

title: not too good
text: When I heard that Tim Burton was making a new version of the sci-fi legend Planet of the apes,I was really excited.I'm a huge Tim Burton fan, and the combination seemed too good to be true.Unfortunately,the movie was one of the biggest disappointments of the year and Burton's worst movie since Mars Attacks! Don't get me wrong!The new version of Planet of the Apes is not a bad movie and in it's own genre actually quite satisfying.The ape-masks are great(even though they make almost impossible to tell which actor is which) and the sets are pretty impressive.The biggest problem with the movie is that it doesn't have the unique visual look and oddness of Tim Burton.The second problem is Mark Wahlberg.He has the same one impression on his face throughout the movie and is one of the most unintresting hero of all times. All in all,not a bad film,but when compared to massive hype,a huge disappointment

title: You can't go home again
text: I grew up on the original Planet of the Apes movies. They were movies that were unique to their time. The 1970's were the only decade where a franchise like the Planet of the Apes could thrive. Fast-forward 25 or 30 years and Tim Burton's "Planet of the Apes" is a much harder sell. Burton's "Planet of the Apes" is a mixed bag. The action parts of the movie work quite well. The comedic parts of the movie fall flat. Most of the "laughs" are found in the first third of the movie. That also happens to be the weakest part of the film. It's Paul Giamatti's job to deliver those laughs but he ends up being annoying and not funny. If director Tim Burton and company had played it straight, "Planet of the Apes" would have been much better. Honorable mention: the wildly dreamy Estella Warren.

title: Is this really a Tim Burton film?
text: Very boring, very long, very confusing, and an awful ending that I just totally hated.Not the worst thing I've ever seen by a long shot, but definitely not one for me.

title: An incredible waste of effort
text: Tim Burton's latest bears his signature: it looks great. Most of the sets are original and the actors' stint in "ape school" has paid off. The ape characters walk, move, and even fidget like apes, chimps, and orangutans, and the actors blend their movements seamlessly into their performances and the scenes. No one seems to be saying "Look at me! Look at me!" (with the exception of Charlton Heston). Helena Bonham Carter and especially Tim Roth give standout performances.Unfortunately, most of the effort that went into making the film is wasted: very little seems to happen and there isn't much suspense. The humans escape from confinement too easily and then have a pretty clear path to their final destination. The explanation for the evolution of a planet of apes is a good one, both surprising and plausible. But then this explanation is quickly followed by a brutal yet lame battle sequence. The film's ending is a shocker, but more of the head-scratching than the jaw-dropping kind. Ultimately, this movie underlines the greatness of the 1968 version.

title: Tim Burtons worst film so far!
text: I am a big fan of both Tim Burton and the original Apes films.. So it's easy to understand I was both anxious to see this new version as well as sceptical.I was expecting to be disappointed, but nothing prepared me for what happened. The first hour of the movie was ok, the last was embarresing.The humans could speak. The Gorillas were silly. Helena Bonham Carter behaved and looked like a human.. The only really cool things were the tributes to the original movie... "God damn! Damn them all to hell!" and so forth!Where the hell did those horses come from?

title: Craptastic ending, decent otherwise
text: The ending just made me want to barf.  It was so tacked-on and disconnected that I just couldn't take it... it was worse than the end of the remake of "Mighty Joe Young"... I wonder if the DVD version will have the option to roll credits 3 minutes earlier.On another note, I think it's amazingly hilarious the way some have misinterpreted Charlton Heston's "support" for gun control.  Let's see, he's an old-guard member of a genocidal regime that wants to eliminate humans or at best enslave them, and warns his son to beware of the human power of invention, symbolized by firearms.  DUH!  Of course tyrants want gun control -- it keeps them safe from their victims!  Charlton Heston made EXACTLY the point about guns that he wanted to make, some people apparently just missed it!On the whole, the movie isn't as bad as some have made it out to be, nor is it as good as others have said.  It was a good action movie, but not much else.  I give it a 6.

title: THE 2001 Planet of the Apes does not compare!
