text: The Planet of the Apes that came out in the late sixties was an incredible film that deals with many social, religious, and political issues. The new remake of this film is awful. The new Planet of the Apes does not have a metaphorical level and it is sheer action just for actions sake. Furthermore, the new film is not exciting or entertaining. I am not sure why the film industry would invest so much money in a film that has already been made. I think that if the original was good, there is not need for a remake! It seems that in this modern era, many film makers have either run out of ideas or sold out. They have begun to remake old films instead of creating new ones. This seems like a waste of talent, money, and technology to me.

title: Good action sci-fi if not compared to original
text: This refers to the TV version in a 2.5 hr slot, so I may have missed some scenes.If you want a faithful updating of the original you'll be disappointed. On its own, however, this is a pretty good sci-fi action film complete with a little character development (for those who need that).In my opinion this movie did parallel the original in terms of certain basic plot points (sorry, no spoilers), but I think the parallels can get lost in the translation/interpretation.What I didn't like was that I had to be prepared for the ending by those who had the DVD commentary; we're supposed to leave the movie in a state of "Huh?", and we're supposed to assume a certain event took place which is just barely eluded to at the very end.Besides being rude, this may or may not set things up for a sequel. The original movies managed to create a final "setting-up" for a perfect cycling in time. Maybe we didn't get a perfect happy ending, but we left satisfied about the reasons behind the first movie's social setting.I believe that a sequel has to be made to explain *clearly* why the movie ended as it did. I think there's too much arrogance behind the current ending; someone is ignoring the population of viewers who aren't well versed in sci-fi versions of warps, portals, etc.Hint: When Thade finds himself in what looks like a control room pay attention to what he sees. And remember that he's no idiot. That may help at the end.And enjoy the movie for itself; try not to compare it to the original

title: Monkeydom
text: I was captured for a moment, perhaps two.  The plotline was marginal.  In a nutshell, I nodded off a few times.  You think Burton would have researched apes a little more behaviorly...one would think jumping around was the primary emotional response of apes.  Get real...and please no sequel...much rather see the intelligent dolphin and apes of the Uplift War saga made into film.

title: A Real Disappointment
text: Tim Burton, known for his visual style, delivers yet again with Planet Of The Apes (POTA), but the film is lacking in virtually every other aspect, from the thinly drawn characters, the barely-there script, to the shockingly bad/incomphensible ending. I'll start first with the character development. There is none. Leo Davidson (Mark Wahlberg)is so one dimensional that at no point did i care if he ever got off the planet and back to, well, whatever and whomever. His entire time is spent throwing out cliched lines instead of being awed, inspired, terrified, or confused of his surroundings. Any emotion would have worked. As for the humans who live on the planet, I'm not sure what their problem was, they werent savages, they outnumbered the apes supposedly, they could communicate at the same level as the apes (unlike the original movie), so why exactly were they living in the hills scared for their lives. Ari (Helena Bonham Carter) and General Thade (Tim Roth) are by far the most interesting, and well acted, characters.  Miss Carter brings a sensual aspect to her character that is very appealing (yes, i know shes playing a simian, but it doesnt seem to matter). While Mr Roth plays Thade deliciously evil and cunning, and his ape-like movements are a sight to see.I was especially disappointed with the relationship between Leo, Ari and Daena (played by model Estella Warren, who is way to beautiful here to pull off a role as a jungle woman). There are obvious hints of attraction between Ari and Leo, yet these scenes go absolutely nowhere in developing the awkwardness of it all. The script doesnt go beyond yearning glances, which is a shame. The last half hour of the movie was basically the standard action plot. The movie builds up to an inevitable war between the humans and the apes, with Leo devising this absurd plan to stun the first ranks (out of thousands of CGI created apes) with the remnants of his old ships ignited fuel tanks. Never mind the fact this would only eliminate maybe 5 percent of the total forces they are up against. The final conflict is never exciting, but then how could it be when we have no emotional investment in the characters.I will not discuss the "surprise" ending, except to say not only is it not surprising, it doesnt make sense, and i defy anyone to explain it.In fact, i read an interview with the higher-ups involved in this fiasco, and they revealed that the ending isnt supposed to make sense, its supposed to leave the viewer confused and guessing. Well, thats just what i want after watching this for two hours, and ending that insults the viewers intelligence by admitting "we didnt even care enough ourselves to give you a plausible ending." Thank you Hollywood. And thank you Tim Burton, for reminding us once more that classics should be left alone and time honored. If you're going to remake a movie, remake a bad movie. In fact, remake this remake.

title: Excellent masks, but a major disappointment
text: I entered the theater enthusiastically after waiting to see this film for a long time. And after 60 minutes I was equally enthusiastic to see the end credits and to be able to walk away from the theater.The ape masks were excellent, and the music was quite ok, though a bit ordinary to my taste, but I think that nothing else delivered. I continuously had the feeling the Burton had wanted to say something, but he was in so much haste, that before he was able to say the punch line the next scene had already started.Since this was a fantasy flick I did my best to out any reality checks away, but I still think that extremely beautiful make-up should not be expected from a lady living in wilderness.

title: 117 minutes of entertainment and 2 minutes of disbelief, horror and shock!
text: This could have been a really good film, one almost equal to it's original, but not yet being a copy. It could have been a modern reflection of the 1968 version. It could have been a re-imaging' and a good one as well, but it was screwed up at the end. I enjoyed this film up to the 117th minute, when everything was is perfect order, but the ending ruined it all. It is preposterous, ridiculous and confusing (only not to say plain stupid). But I guess part 2 will explain it all (oh I can't wait with what they'll come up with).6 out of 10 (disregarding the ending anything between 7 to 7,5 out of 10 can be given)

title: OK remake.
text: Tim Burton's remake of the 1968 film PLANET OF THE APES was OK. It wasn't anything special. The make ups were excellent and the acting was decent. But the story line was rather weak. Tim Roth steals the film as General Thade. However, the original is a lot better.

title: What the Hell???
text: ENDING ALERT!!! DON'T READ THIS IF YOU DON'T WANT TO KNOW!!! What the hell was with that ending? Even if apes took control I don't think they would develop Ford Taurus police cars or white ambulances or even red fire trucks. Or the Washington monument or any of the rest of Washington D.C. Somebody please explain that one to me!

title: Weak second half of the film capped by nonsensical ending
text: * WARNING - THIS COMMENT CONTAINS SOME SPOILERS *I haven't seen the original movie, so I watched this with a completely open mind, without any expectations (except for the fact that I expect Tim Burton films to be top notch!)... ...anyway, the movie starts off in great enough fashion with some nice special fx. Burton does well to convey the Wahlberg character's sense of desolation after crashing on the planet and an interesting subplot ensues, involving Helena Bonham Carter's ape character and the attempt to escape from their masters. Tim Roth is absolutely outstanding as the general - you won't see a more expressive pair of eyes! The love triangle element with Estella Warren's character (what a beauty!) is also fairly well handled.The film simmers along nicely for the first half and then completely degenerates towards the end. The first absurdity is when (*SPOILERS AHEAD*)Wahlberg's monkey jets in and stops the battle - the scene just looked silly, it did not look like it could turn the tide of the battle...then later the henchmen (sorry henchapes!) of the general capitulate too quickly without really being convinced.And the "twist" ending was just well...incomprehensible I thought...another writer here said he found it easy to understand because it was a take on the original film's ending....but for someone like me who hasn't seen the original, I just thought - huh? Was it meant to be a "what-if?" scenario, or was it a direct consequence of what had happened before? I couldn't get my head around it...maybe I'm thick...need to think about it a bit more, but I suspect that I still won't get it...Overall - a good first half to the movie....great performance from Roth and Wahlberg was good too...Burton got the visual style of the film spot on and the costumes and ape make up were just awesome and any special fx used looked good...unfortunately, plot holes and inconsistencies in the second half of the movie undid all the good work and effort put into the rest of the film.

title: Great movie!!!
text: Good movie, actors, and plot...what more would you need? Nothing in this movie is lacking definition or explanation....it's all right there! The only part that needs description is the ending, but it's just a great leading into the sequel, which obviously there will be. I don't think anyone should criticize this movie unless this is the kind of movie they like. Also, all you old POTA fans, you can't compare this one to the original. The only thing in common is the basic plot....it's not the same movie!!! So I think anyone who likes this type of genre of movies really will like this movie, but only see it if it interests you, not because you like the old POTA because it's just not the same.

title: Not enough kristoferson...
text: No, no.  Please, No!  After seeing the previews for this movie I was actually looking forward to seeing it.  How should I have known that Hollywood would crank out another blockbuster with the high quality of "Blown Away" this summer?  This movie could easily be described as Superman 2 and 4 rolled into one, with the camp of Mr. Belvedere mixed in.  What was going on at the end there?  How did general Thade get to be on the lincoln memorial 500 years before he lived.  If you want to see a really good ape movie watch Congo.  Or better yet, watch an episode of Maude.

title: I liked "Apes"
text: Sure, the movie has its flaws (the biggest one being that it could have done much more considering the material and talent available), but I still, for the most part, enjoyed it.  Mark Wahlberg could have done better, but I enjoy watching him still.  The people behind the ape makeup gave the best performances, especially Tim Roth, Helena Bonham Carter, and Paul Giamatti. Estella Warren is a definite hottie.  Tim Burton's direction, the sets, the fx, and the makeup were all great.  There are some really cool action scenes, especially at the final battle.  And although the ending isn't fully explained, it was a cool little twist reminiscent of the original's ending (though not as good) and it was something that audience members both heavily thought and argued about.  You can't say that for every movie last summer. Overall, a satisfying and rousing sci-fi actioner.*** out of ****

title: Not bad at all.
text: I had read mixed reviews on this movie and having not seen the orignal I didnt know what to expect, so I cannot compare it to the first one. I was very impressed at the makeup on the characters in this movie. The apes looked so real its obvious alot of time and money was put into the makeup alone. I liked Helena Bonham's character-she was the one friendly likeable ape that didnt hate humans like her counterparts did. Interesting contrast in the movie on how on this planet apes control the humans and on earth its vise versa. Ending was kind of cool and made you think a little. Good movie overall. 7/10.

title: Apes that rules a planet, has to be Tim Burton
text: When i heard that they were going to make a new version of the old planet of the apes movie, featuring a bunch of apes that rule an entire planet, I just knew that Tim Burton somehow was involved, the only thing logical about the whole thing is that he's behind it. they movie it self was not what i hoped it would be. one of the big things this movie lacks is that it cant really follow the footsteps of the original movie, if the original was none existent then this movie would probably have rose a bit in my book.But after all its a Tim Burton Movie and its at least worth to rent

title: Not all that bad.
text: I'm going to be one of the few to say that this movie is not as bad as everyone makes out. I often feel that people just jump on the bandwagon when they slate it, especially the hardcore Burton fans. It's certainly not a great movie, nor is it a bad one.Visually it's amazing, as with any Burton film. The sets are spectacular, the CGI is convincing and not burdensome and the ape make-up/costumes look truly realistic and in some cases, menacing, particularly the character of Thade. Danny Elfman's musical score is suitably brooding and savage and I think the slew of weird percussion sounds is inspired. The acting is good, with stand-out performances from Tim Roth, who is the perfectly grotesque Burton villain, and Paul Giamatti, providing light relief.The story and script seem to be the main culprits for all the controversy. I actually like the fact that there is little dialogue. Sometimes movies suffer when there is too much dialogue, as it just becomes convoluted. Although Planet of the Apes is nowhere near as profound as Kubrick's 2001, this is the perfect example of 'pure cinema'. There is not one word of dialogue until 40 minutes into the film. Not everything needs to be explained with dialogue, a picture paints a thousand words, as the saying goes. As for the ending, it's more true to the novel. I will say that the Ape Lincoln memorial makes a mockery of the film, which is a fabrication and NOT in the novel. Although there is humour throughout the film, the ending loses its impact as a result of Burton's outlandish joke.

title: Made for the marketing department
text: This is the kind of big, dumb movie Hollywood can make in it's sleep, and in this case, someone did.  The producers knew what they could sell; good visuals and the Planet of the Apes name, and that is all they deliver. This movie is only about how it looks.  If you care about story or characters (the makers obviously did not) you should look elsewhere.The half thought out plot has holes you could push a planet through.  Tim Burton tries to paper some of the holes with action cliches, most of which are embarrassingly bad.As to the cast, Mark Wahlberg is not bad in the lead, but the rest of the cast saved their good work for another film.  Tim Roth badly overplays the villain, General Thade.  Helena Bonham Carter is just there as the pro-human chimp Ari.  The rest of the cast has so little to work with, that they must have collectively said to themselves, "why bother?"Then there is the surprise ending.  It is a total waste of film.  While the ending of the original (and far better) Planet of the Apes was integral to the story, the surprise in this new version has that unmistakeable "tacked on" feel.  It comes out of nowhere, goes nowhere, and does not make sense at all.  It is as if the film makers wanted a visual surprise ending for no other reason than that the original had one, but that they didn't want to put very much thought into creating it.That is the overriding problem with this movie.  It goes for the easy sell visual, without putting any thought behind it.  As a result, it is only good for shutting off your brain for two hours.  If that's all you want from a movie, go for it.

title: Worth seeing, but not an all-time fave.
text: I sat through the movie and thought it was awesome. Later: I have a real problem with the storyline. There was not hardly any character interaction.  The "love" between Wahlberg and the two girls was never even examined.  There were looks, but absolutely nothing to believe that he cared even a little about them.  It was a little mind boggling with the crazy ending.  After I left the theatre everything got to me, and I decided I was trying to hard to interpret it. Now: I can only say it is worth seeing and try not to be too critical.

title: Another Burton flop
text: Well, at least after Sleepy Hollow and the incredible waste of celluloid that is Planet of the Apes it should be clear to everybody that Tim Burton is one of the two most overrated directors of our time (the other one is called David Lynch). Apart from some mildly scary effects there is nothing interesting at all in this film. The actors walk around like zombies, and who can blame them for not being terribly interested in what's going on. The original Planet of the Apes was certainly no masterpiece, but then again: compared to this, maybe it was. Avoid by all means.

title: Do not think of it as a remake!
text:
While all of the people that write bad reviews trying to compare this to the original, I sit and watch and enjoy, rather than whine like little monkeys.
This is not a remake, this is a completely new take on "What If", that's what makes this movie great, Is it original concept? No, Is it still entertaining? Absolutely.! I don't belong in the realm of people that think "this is an actual History" (some do actually) thus this is a pure entertainment. So, relax...

title: Nothing Special......1968 Apes were better period.
text: Honestly, my expectations for this movie diminished right after I watched 2001 version of the "Apes." I thought that Tim Burton would bring something fantastic but it was a total failure.....Not as much passion inputed as an old "Planet of the apes." I wasn't fully disappointed with the special effects but I was well disappointed with the story lines and the visual content of the film. Apes didn't look as real as the 1968 Ape.I would just like to say that this movie is for an entertainment, not for an enlightenment of the hidden meanings and themes behind the film. If you just want to relax and watch the film off the curiosity then this film is a perfect feature. However, if you are a person who wants to be in awe of unexpected glimpse and extraordinary story lines, then either read the novel or watch the 1968 version of "The planet of the Apes." I personally didn't enjoy 2001 version of "The planet of the Apes." 6.3/10 I would give.

title: what a waste...
text: I'm glad the local store rents DVD's for $1.49 a night, otherwise I never would have gotten to see this.  What gets me is all these "industry" types, who know the film is a total disgrace, but since they really don't give a whit about anything in life but padding the bottom line, are like- "who cares if the acting is miserable and there's no depth to the story, no complexity, no nothing - I thought it was pretty entertaining,  and the costumes and special effects were great!"  Or "we'll recap on the foreign market and dvd special features"  Gag.These people are ruining the medium of film.You put so much money and time and effort into a work like this, but you completely ignore the few things that could turn it from TV-quality crap (with GREAT SPECIAL EFFECTS!!!!) into a real, honest to god movie.  To bad they could collectively care less.  They're not movie-makers, they're just businessmen.Well, I'm glad to say you got all of about 5 cents from my viewing...cheers.

title: Sub-par, no soul
text: Tim Burton can usually make us feel.  He gives us foreshadowing, atmosphere, and a sense of reality.He did none of those with this movie.I wanted to like this film; I really did.  In fact, most of the movie was enjoyable.  I found that the apes moved realistically, or at least as one would expect, Tim Roth was a good villain - if more than a bit flat - and that the religious element was delicate but not underdeveloped.However, at about thirty-forty minutes from the end of the film, things fell apart.Characters show up for no reason; we are spoon-fed that which the viewer can already deduce; romance is conjured out of nowhere.  Tim Burton could have made this a satire, but instead he made it an action movie that pales in comparison with even a Steven Seagal vehicle.There is no atmosphere, soul, or logic to the film.  If you liked Burton's other movies, by all means do not see this one.And wow, the ending.  I overheard someone mention Rod Serling's name on the way out.  I can tell you, if I had known who said that, I would have looked at him and told him that Twilight Zone endings were foreshadowed, consistent, and above all else, MADE SENSE.  The movie doesn't even play properly within the logic it sets up for itself.I went into this with higher expectations than I should have.  If you see it, don't make the same mistake I did.

title: 2 on a scale of 10
text: THIS MOVIE SUCKED!!!Ok, now I got that out of the way. No, I didn't. THIS MOVIE SUCKED!!!! There, I added an extra exclamation mark! When I came out of the theater, I was so embarrassed for having seen it, I was praying that no one I knew would be there to recognize me. The last time I remember having that feeling was when I came out of Caligula back in the early 80's.I really can't hardly figure out where to begin because the number of insanely, ludicrously, mindless flaws in logic (or is it ludicrously, mindlessly, insane) were so overwhelming that I truly thought anyone with an IQ of over 60 would NEVER admit to liking this movie. Incredibly, there are actually humans that know how to type (unless some ape is doing it for them) on this web site who liked this pile of garbage.I'm serious. I don't even want to waste time on the number of impossible coincidences and ridiculous plot holes and staggeringly insipid assumptions that were made. It was cheesy, predictable, boring, stupid, insulting and, did I say MINDLESS?The ape costumes were decent, but decent special effects nowadays are assumed. The rest of it was pure, unadulterated junk. IF you have even half a brain, you will be terribly disappointed. If not, have fun and bring your banana. You'll fit in just fine.

title: The only thing I didn't like about this movie was what the adolescent character was asked to do.
text: I recently saw this movie and was surprised to find a line.  This was the first time I had ever waited in a line to see a movie.  It was especially noteworthy because I live in a moderate size town. The stuntmen in this movie seem to be trying out for "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon".  At the same time they made it look very simian.  I thought this movie was well done.  It is a little too dark most of the time but I'm pretty sure this is on purpose.  There is one problem with this movie that I noticed.  Actually I've been noticing it for years.  That problem is the adolescent actor (in this case Luke Eberle).  For the past years both televison and Hollywood have written two main types of characters for adolescent actors.  In the first type the adolescent character is told to: go in the house, go over there, etc.  Why is it that the "adult" actors are afraid for the adolescent characters to be an integral part of the defense of the home or whatever the movie entails.  The second type is where the adolescent character either is allowed to help or just does.  However, the "adult" character either has to fix what the adolescent character did or save the adolescent character from death etc.  This movie is no different.  In it the Luke Eberle character is basically told to go hide by Mark Wahlberg.   The Luke character then refuses and decides to try and help.  Then in typical fashion the Mark Wahlberg character has to save the Luke character from certain death.  When is the establishment and the "adult" actors going to realize that adolescent characters actually can  help in defense situations and many other situations as well?  I realize that many of these adolescent actors have not "paid their dues" yet but to me that is a terrible reason to perpetuate a stereotype.  For that is indeed what it is.  So even though this movie perpetuates both of these stereotypes I think it is still a rather good movie.  However, it could have been better had the writers filled the stereotype spot with something important.

title: Awful... almost as bad (and the same) as Battlefield Earth
text: What a terrible, terrible movie! I had a high expectation for it too. It's a shame. I'll give the make-up artists (e.g., Rick Baker) credit. Bravo. And Danny Elfman's opening score was interesting. But otherwise, this movie was utter crap. (small spoilers follow) First we get this DS9-like space station shot with the wonderful title card that informs us that it's the year 2029!!! Hello! I knew right then that this was going to suck. Science fiction needs to be smart. Then he finds himself on the Ape Planet and the next 90% of the movie is just simple "escape and chase". Yawn... But to try and make it interesting they throw in some cliché and ever-not-so-subtle comments on racism and religion. The script was lousy, let's face it. Then the end of the movie improves slightly (this doesn't say much) until we get the "surprise" ending. Whatever. Tim Burton has the imagery skills but except from Edward Scissorhands and Pee-Wee's Big Adventure, I'd say he's a failure as far as making good stories. The similarities between Planet of the Apes and Battlefield Earth are remarkable. And considering how lousy that movie was, why would anybody allow this script to pass? Certainly a better movie could have been made from the same idea. Oh well, it already has.

title: Monkey mish-mash
text: Tim Burton can usually be relied upon for visionary, provocative entertainment, but this time all we get is "Braveheart" with baboons. This remake is consistently uninvolving and uninteresting, all the way up to the zinger surprise ending which flat out doesn't work.Stick with Chuck Heston and the original "Planet."

title: With all of the bungling, protracted, witless summer movie sequels invading theatres, you've gotta wonder when Hollywood's going to stop monkeying around.
text:
Ah, Planet of the Apes. Sniff it all you want; it smells enough like a case of the remake to fall in line with this summer's sequel monotony, but upon closer inspection, it's clear that this is a chimp of a decidedly different breed.Director Tim Burton reinvents the aesthetic and tonal gestalt of the 1968 classic without ditching the original's thematic underpinnings, creating a world that is both visually fascinating and painstakingly complete.
When Air Force pilot Leo Davidson, (Mark Walberg), leaves his space station in search of a test chimp deployed to survey a magnetic storm, things go awry, leading to a crash-landing on a planet where humans are enslaved by a breed of apes that are uniquely advanced, cognizant and cultured. But their refinement is little more than a thin veneer hiding their aggressive animal drives, which can lead them to the brutal treatment of their captured humans. Leo, who isn't acclimated to the Apes' tyranny, revolts against them and becomes a heroic figure and leader to the enslaved humans who know little else than the servitude and submission they have faced since birth. Helena Bonham Carter (you know, from Fight Club) plays Ari, an ape with compassion towards humans, while Tim Roth brilliantly portrays Thade, a snarling, aggressive (really pretty damn scary) ape general, who wishes to see his planet cured of humans, and his fellow apes cured of their human-derivative tendencies.Under the façade of a fast-paced sci-fi/action blockbuster lays an entirely different animal. On the most primitive level, Apes is gargantuan, pounding its fists with energy and a capacity to amaze that makes this film monumentally entertaining. But like the skillfully crafted latex ape masks through which the actors' subtle, universal, seasoned human facial expressions are transmitted, Apes breathes life of its own beneath the glaze of action. Burton paints a textured portrayal of man's struggle against subjugation, with settings and characters that are unearthly, yet dually dark, gritty and present. The director ditched the early-proposed ideas of digitally animated apes or live apes with computer-generated mouths, enlisting A-list actors instead to give each ape a uniquely human core.Perhaps the real feat here is that Burton was able to make these apes so utterly creepy and animalistic (much more so than their original counterparts) yet still found a way to maintain their human characteristics. Roth and Bonham Carter learned an entire behavioral language for their roles, complete with loping, off-kilter strides and dexterous, long-armed gesticulations. It takes a while to get a grasp of the full complexity of their movements, but once the language is understood, you quickly see how the ape dispositions intensify the actors' capacity for human emotional expression.Other apes include Limbo, a pandering human-slave dealer played by Paul Giamatti, and Attar, Thade's loyal silverback, played by Michael Clarke Duncan (who incidentally, is perhaps the only Ape actor that sounds as though he's using his normal voice). Charleton Heston makes a cameo, donning full ape regalia to play Thade's dying father, and Lisa Marie Pressley appears briefly as a snooty socialite chimp.On the human side, two words: Estella Warren. She says close to nothing (perhaps a throwback to the mute humans in the original, perhaps not). With a character that grows envious of the affection formed between Walberg and Bonham Carter (yes, a man and a chimp) Warren is left to primarily convey her dissatisfaction through looks and body language. And looks plus body are a definite can-do on Warren's checklist. Things seems a little exploitative at times; her garb is close to non-existent, and the camera, perhaps a bit too kind, but Warren certainly helps heighten the degree to which this film is visually fascinating. Unfortunately, it isn't all bananas and cream pie. The Apes script incorporates a few narrative devices that are just too convenient, such as the illogically timed event that causes the wrap-up to the climatic battle scene. Although the majority of dialogue in the film runs smoothly, certain characters (take for instance, the shifty-eyed comic relief, Limbo) are developed in a stagnant and predictable way. Walberg's pre-battle scene speech, despite its relative brevity, is still a little laughable. The re-vamped surprise ending is creatively done, carrying certain light-heartedness to it, but the film leaves things too easily opened ended. However, with a sequel planned 'open-ended' is something that was planned.
Ultimately, Burton's overall design is so meticulous and aesthetically comprehensive and his ape characters, so believable and culturally complete that you can't help but be lured into his stunning visual world, which seems (if not only momentarily) to take precedence over other concerns. You haven't seen anything quite like this. The film may have aped the original, but it stands on its own two feet.

title: Great make up but emotionless and uninspiring
text: In the year 3002 an astronaut crash lands on an alien planet. This world is ruled by talking apes who treat human beings as slaves and the astronaut must find a way to escape the monkey madness and mayhem.Remake, re-imagination whatever you'd like to label it as, Planet of the Apes (2001) is inferior to the original 1968 film and as a standalone piece of entertainment in almost every way.That said, the make up is excellent, Tim Roth as Thade is fantastic, Colleen Atwood costumes are notable and Danny Elfman's thumping score is an achievement. The spaceship sets and on the location night scenes have a unique atmosphere and edge about them. Even Mark Wahlberg tries his best to handle the half-baked script and there are a few welcomed cameos from some of the original cast. On the flip side there's some choppy editing, an uneven story, the ape city and the sandy finale are emotionless and uninspiring. Slipped in is some unnecessary humour, usually supplied by Paul Giamatti (aptly named Limbo) and you never feel any danger or threat from the apes apart from Thade. Also, there's no likable characters to really root for. Nothing can save nominated director and visionary Tim Burton's incarnation of Apes.The fist ten minutes and the last two are probably the most attention-grabbing of this version but with an estimated budget $100,000,000 there's no excuse for the travesty in between.

title: That was a "shocking" ending?
text: Okay, I generally like the first version of a film and tend to skip the sequels, remakes, and anything else designed to remind me of the first film. Being a child of the 80s, I recognize that some sequels are inherently superior to others (i.e. Star Wars films, Indiana Jones, but not _Temple of Doom_, and others), so I tend to be suckered into repeats.So I purchased my $5 IMAX ticket (thank you, Canada) and was eager to see the newest addition to the _Apes_ saga.  From the first scene the sound and special effects are great.  You get wrapped into this film quickly and intensely.  You are, in fact, held throughout the entire film.Burton, as usual, has created a very, very dark film that seems to offer no hope for salvation.  Characters become aware of their "sins" and misconceptions of reality.  The battle seen of ape vs. man shows the reduction of man to his survivalist instinct, and a hope, albeit distant, for reconciliation.Most films would have stopped there.  Kudos to Burton for going further, but where did he think he was going to take us?  A great film was RUINED by the ending.  Too predicable, too "I need an ending, let's go with this one." You lost me, sir.  As we left the theater, my friends and I all echoed the same disappointment.  Tsk-tsk for going the easy way out.

title: A fine technical achievement that falls flat because of its lack of a good story.
text: Tim Burtons interpretation of The Planet Of The Apes isn't the complete disaster it was labelled.It is by no means a great film either.The good things about the film are all in the technical arena.The makeup and costume design are inspired,some of the best i have ever seen.The visual effects are top drawer but the film is let down by a wafer thin plot with a head scratching ending that seems to be more of a homage to the classic original film than a conclusion in itself.Tim Burtons visual talents are on display here but he doesn't seem to have much direction with his film.Its almost as if he decided to make a Planet Of The Apes film before an idea had been decided on.A so so experience.

title: I hope it doesn't turn into a Star Trek
text: I saw this film the day it came out with high hopes.  My friends told me how great the original was and i could only think of how awesome a writer must be to create such an original story.  Oh, i was a fool.Burton has had a successful streak, hasn't he?  Batman, Batman Returns, Sleepy Hollow, and the cult favorite Nightmare Before Christmas.  Yes it is an awesome life.  But every career has a hitch.  This is his.  Mark Wahlberg's career has also been rising.  From the innovative Boogy Nights, to the highly rated Three Kings and The Perfect Storm with another blockbuster (Rock Star) on the way.  Maybe this can be an oversight.No matter the director or the stars, our hero, Leo Davidson cannot see that his ape costars are real actors.  Whenever speaking to them, he inserts a short pause, as if trying to prove to himself that these are real people. His eyes are blank and emotionless.  He plays a hero just as well as Steven Seagal, take that as you will.The apes are frighteningly lifelike, but you can't base a movie on its makeup.  The film is dark, very dark (visually) for the first 3/4.  As if these future apes couldn't figure out lightbulbs, or even gas lights.  The film also uses the rope and pulley system made popular by the Matrix.  While it looked new and exciting in Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, and even Romeo Must Die, seeing apes jumping vertically eight feet (from a sit down) is just silly.None of the "human" characters, beside Leo, play an important role.  It makes you wonder why he's trying to save them.  Apes have evolved into intelligent, thought processing individuals over thousands of years... but what happened to the humans?  Did we just stop at a certain point in time, and someone said, "This is enough for you"?  The ending is so confusing it's physically impossible.  Burton rearranges time so much i think HE get's lost.  Overall, it's a 4/10- saved by the makeup and the ape's acting.

title: If you haven't seen the original pretty good..
text: .. except ofcourse from that last scene that IMHO was not Tim Burtons but from the studio that wanted to have an excuse for a sequel.This movie has good makeup ( except Carter). I was most impressed with the way the apes move. Really good stuff. The different kind of apes are also good in this film.One thing that I didn't like though is that the conversations seemed "empty". I mean when the big gorilla brakes his gun ( the only gun on the planet , wich I suppose had unlimited ammo) the guy just said " Hey,what did you do that for?" . I would have flipped out! The only way for you to survive has been destroyed and you say hey? And other occasions also..Worth to rent.Havent seen the original

title: Don´t forget it is a FANTASY movie
text: WARNING! Don´t read if you didn´t see the movie yet!At first I have to say that I didn´t see the original movie yet (shame on me!) but I don´t consider this to be important for this review. As I´m a Tim Burton-Fan, I had to watch the new "Planet of the Apes" - and I liked it.It is a great movie, full of fantastic pictures - the great comic-style, which I love Tim Burton for. The soundtrack is perfect, the special effects are great and , what is the most important: the story is very entertaining and full of suspense.Of course, as many of you did, you could ask many logical questions as: - Why are there horses on the planet? - Why are there different races? - How is it possible for a few humans and two apes to ride through a complete camp of aggressive apes? - Why does the chimp land exactly at the moment when Leo is about to lose his fight? - How is it possible for a small spaceship, to fly from the planet of the apes back to the earth? And why does it only take three minutes? - Why does Estella Warren wear lipstick? - Why is the earth full of apes at the end?I read many questions like this, and of course there are many more you could ask! But please don´t forget, it is a fantasy movie! A fantasy movie doesn´t need to be realistic, and it also doesn´t want to be!Nobody asks why it is possible to hear noises, when space ships in Star Wars shoot at something - although it is impossible to hear noises in space! A fantasy movie lives of exaggerations! Why do you always bother about realism in fantasy films? If you want to watch a realistic movie, then you should watch a drama or something, but no fantasy or science-fiction movie! - Or at least, don´t wonder about exaggerations!Of course it was not a perfect movie. Mark Whalberg really didn´t act very well, and I often asked myself why Estella Warren is in this movie. She is always in the middle of the plot, looking beautiful but speaking only five sentences over the whole movie.But altogether it was a very nice movie. I will have to buy the DVD as soon as it is available!Therefore 8 out of 10.Well, I think I will watch the original movie soon, but I´m not looking forward to compare the movies!

title: A Deception
text: This movie is a deception, in the real sense of the word. When I heard about this flick, I though that this "re-imagining" would be at least visually better than the original film. Well, it's not. The new makeup is more complex than the appliances used in the firs film, but the apes are grotesque. Ari, for instance, has hilarious ape features, and so David Warner's character. The problem, I think, is the "realistic" sculpture of the masks, made by Rick Baker. I don't know if "realism" is a good choice in a movie called "Planet of the Apes". The general concept is quite bizarre, and realism can make things even worse.In the original, the characters looked like apes, but had a more sophisticated appeal, a noble aspect. It's very difficult to achieve this balance, and perhaps it explains why the makeup of the new "Planet" wasn't nominated for an Oscar. Add to that a bunch of apes running like rabbits, "primitive" humans that think and talk like evolved humans and poor sets, and you have a natural looser. But what really upset me about this film is the title: it should be "THE VISITOR", as Burton had originally envisioned. "THE VISITOR" is more accurate in the sense that the movie is a "re-imagining", not a remake.

title: Tim Burton's vision is a marvel: exciting, thrilling and explosive.
text:
Wow, how good can a film be? Well, when Tim Burton (the genius behind the secrets of the masterpiece THE NIGHTMARE BEFORE CHRISTMAS) signs on to do a project like PLANET OF THE APES, you just know it's going to be good. The actors are very well cast and everyone fit into their parts perfectally. But, for some very odd reason, most people found this wonderful version to PLANET OF THE APES to be a disappointment. I can't see why, because I enjoyed the film to no end. In my opinion, it couldn't have been made better. This really doesn't seem to me like a project that Tim Burton would sign on to direct, but hey, he did it. And did it well.
Mark Wahlberg is tremendous here, and so are remaining cast members: Tim Roth, Michael Clarke Duncan, Helena Bonham Carter, David Warner, Kris Krisstoferson, Chris Ellis and lots more. If you haven't figured it out already, I was entranced by this film.The usual action-adventure will place you in an environment with a highly intelligent creature that will then procede to roam around and kill you off one by one. But, here, Mr. Tim Burton has given us something better. He throws our typical cast of "survivors" into an environment where they are being hunted by a species just about as intelligent as they are. It actually almost resembles the apartheid of the 1930s in a way, only it is in reverse. Instead of the whites in control of the blacks, it is the apes (black people) in control of the whites (but in this case, it would be all humans).The story is well-told and is actually more of another sequel than it is a remake, but either way, Tim Burton's visual gem will be a fun to stun people for generations to come.PLANET OF THE APES: 5/5.

title: Deserves golden banana
text: Apeing the classics.Even the few special effects and the tolerable makeup (unless you're wearing it) aren't up to snuff. The acting is barely sufficient to carry the undemanding plot: all that was required was to update the 1968 original with the current state of the art: and I mean ART. The only good idea in the film is the casting of Charlton Heston, who starred in the original.The remake's finale is worrisome with its latent opening for a sequel: let's hope it never does come about -- but as the saying goes, monkey see, monkey do.If someone from the film industry actually reads these comments, I would love to hear an explanation of how a scene with four-handed apes outrunning four-hoofed horses makes it through the final editing. Maybe this will become clearer in "Planet of the Horses," where the noble steeds take over the world mounted on very fast apes that run on all fours. Director Tim Burton demonstrated his genius with "Big Fish": one movie per species should suffice.

title: Appalling....
text: well what to say. I was eagerly awaiting the release of this movie,  i was so excited about seeing it and i went to the 1st screening this morning. what a waste of money, dont get me wrong the special effects were amazing rick baker deserves an oscar for his outstanding work. the plot was a total joke, very poorly written and the acting wasnt up to scratch either apart from one person. Tim Roth was amazing, absolutely brilliant as the most evil looking ape i have ever seen. the guy deserves an award , should give him the most evil looking thing on screen award (lol).. wark walhberg does his best bless him but overacts a badly written script. helena bonham carter was fairly impressive as human lover ari but lacked a certain something.. and the ending,  oh my god, what an absolute pile of crap, i came out of the movie laughing at its sheer pathetic attempt at bringing an exciting twist, but people give me a break,  now the ending to the original was brilliant finding the statue of liberty but this was dire. as brilliant as tim burton is i am not attacking his vision in any way, but this is possibly the worst movie he has ever made. i was hugely disappointed by it and would say this, go and see it for the effects which at times can be quite scary, but i guarantee 2 things,  you will come out laughing and you will never want to see it again.

title: Well worth my time.
text: "Planet of the Apes" reminds me of one of those times when I had no idea what to expect of myself.Was I going to like the movie?Was I going to hate the movie?I waited anxiously for the release of the film,knowing that it was not going to be the best film ever made.Basicly,when I go to see these types of films,I don't worry about the quality of the acting and the directing or it's script.Some people on this website like to watch films with a story and quality performances.That's sensible.I am different.I look at "Planet of the Apes" this way.One,it's a science fiction film.The genre of science fiction takes you anywere your mind takes you.Finally,two.The only purpose these films have is to entertain the audience.I was very much entertained by the way this film turned out."Planet of the Apes" was to me seven dollars that was well spent.Leaving the theatre,even though I knew there were better ones,I appreciated the film for the fact that it led me on a trip through the entertainment world.Mark Wahlberg is pretty good as Leo Davison and so is Tim Roth is General Thade.What else impressed me about this film is Rick Baker's impressive makeup which I believe is a dead lock for an academy award."Planet of the Apes" is a fun filled journey that thought was never a waste of my time.Every minute was worth it.

title: Entertaining but with some weak points
text: I believe that if it was even less related to the original it would be better. In addition there would be less comparisons with a movie considered a classic.The effects and make up were simply outstanding, the apes the most interesting and complex than the humans. It is worth to watch it just for that.On the other hand the script was weak and the surprise ending does nothing to the story other than an obvious nod to a sequel.Regardless I had a pleasant evening. Gave it a 6

title: Disappointing
text: This was a disappointment.  The effects were state of the art but the screenplay was riddled with cliches.  I've seen better stories on "Lost in Space".  Helena Bonham Carter and Tim Roth were good in their roles given the poor script.  I expected a lot more.  Estella Warren was convincing as a wooden extra with cleavage.

title: Tim Burton does not disappoint
text: After reading some of the early reviews of this film, I was beginning to worry that Tim Burton had finally become just another cog in the mind-numbing machinery of the SFX-laden film industry.  It was a huge relief to discover that Burton's *Apes* -- easily the most entertaining film so far this summer -- is perhaps his most visually and dramatically gripping film ever.  This is despite Mark Wahlberg's woodenly resolute performance, which displays about as much screen charisma as an orangutan's hairbrush.  The apes, however, in their far more pliant makeup, steal the show. Paul Giamatti absolutely steals the film as the conniving human-trader "Limbo," and Tim Roth's General Thade is robustly animalistic.  The apes' habit of leaping in the air in displays of anger owes something to Jane Goodall and something to Hong Kong action flicks -- but wherever it comes from, it adds an extra zest to the simian world. While it doesn't reach the darkly sublime heights of Batman or Edward Scissorhands, *Apes* is Burton's best in some time, and easily steals the show from the series of  stumbling (and expensive) zombies the studios have vomited forth so far this summer.

title: Nothing compared to the original!
text: They clearly had a good idea to work with.  It was also called Planet of the Apes.  Why they chose to take a perfectly good idea and change into a bad idea is beyond me.  This movie was designed to please thirteen year olds. Lots of monkeys jumping around and some cool special effects.  Those of us who have seen the original and know that it was an intellectually effective movie, should generally be disappointed with this sad re-make.  Don't get me wrong, the apes were cool looking and the special effects were decent.  In fact, take the monkeys of today and put them in the Charleton Heston film 34 years ago and you'd really have something.  I don't want to spoil the film for anyone so I won't, but what is the deal with the end?  Those of you who have seen it know what I'm talking about.  This is a perfect example of poor story telling, from completely undeveloped characters who suddenly play a somewhat surprisingly important role in the protagonists actions, to scenes which have even the most intelligent of critics at a loss (in reference to the end).I gave this movie 6 out of 10 because as I said, the monkeys are cool.  I love Tim Roth and they obviously spent a great deal of time teaching the actors to act as apes.  However, this is never enough to make up for a bad story (those apes evolved awfully fast).  See it if you wish, but if you wish to see an updated Charleton Heston picture, don't bother.  Just watch the original.

title: A Quite Uninteresting One
text: The original movie with Charlton Heston is an epic and fantastic movie but all those remakes made after 2k are inferior in every aspect, I even do like the costumes of the old movies more than the new special effects. The one question for me, why Tim Burton agreed to make this mediocre and uninteresting piece. Stick with the old movies (1968-1973) they are all better than the new ones.

title: "Apes" gone Hollywood
text: I remember the original quite well, it having made a great impact on me as a 10 year-old boy.  I remember awaiting each sequel as it arrived in theaters in the 70s.  Tim Burton's film comes as totally different take on POTA, and this time with mind-blowing makeup and outrageous action sequences.Movie-goers who cannot appreciate the joys of "Planet of the Apes" have become too mired down in investigating plot-points and errors in logic -- all of which could be explained away by any talented sci-fi writer.  Tim Burton (surely one of today's greatest film makers) isn't concerned with exposition and plot contrivances -- only in entertaining his audience like a great showman would.  And that he does in a big way with this epic-scale adventure, which hardly resembles the original 1968 movie in character or theme, so pre-conceptions best be left at the door.Burton's "Planet of the Apes" supplies more black comedy than the first, often jumping over-the-top in its ability to constantly amaze and amuse the viewer.  The scene of a "mixed" ape dinner party has to have the most outrageous and amazing makeup effects ever created.  Tim Roth as bad-to-the-bone chimpanzee General Thade is terrifying, evil and ugly and probably gives the best performance among excellent company.  Mark Wahlberg makes for a perfect leading man, understated in manners and voice as a contrast to the bizarre and outlandish apes.  And Paul Giamatti as Limbo (a stand-in for old orange Dr Zais?) gives one of the best comic performances ever seen.This is "popcorn" style cinema, and it really bends over backwards to amaze and amuse the viewer.  Credit must be given to Burton and his art department for the campy sets, costumes and obviously the convincing makeup jobs which trumped any similar ones ever on film.  Rick Baker (the great makeup up artist) has taken his art to a higher plane in this monumental effort, and really should be acknowledged for giving audiences such thrilling creatures to view.  They're like no others ever seen on the screen, and to watch the expressive faces of these apes is a remarkable experience in viewing. The faces appear so life-like that you begin to believe you're watching actual apes.Kids should love this outing, with the violence all being decidedly PG and usually occurring off-screen.  Parents can also sit back and enjoy the trip to this wild planet since its loaded with symbolism and cultural references all cleverly packaged in Hollywood's best style.

title: Nice Try
text: The new Planet of the Apes is a nice try.  The Apes are more ape like but the story is a little hard to swallow. The action was ongoing and you never got bored.  The surprise ending left me feeling hopeless, as all resources and option were completely eliminated.Despite Planet of the Ape's violence and destruction, it's definitely worth seeing.

title: Spartacus meets Tim Burton
text: An unnecessary reboot which did not move anything along or do anything interesting with the characters, the ending also made no sense at all. Mark Wahlberg is no Charlton Heston but the real flaws in this story lie in it's script and direction. This film swings between being too dull and too outright silly. The film seems to have more in common with Spartacus than it does with the original film and it's philosophical questions. Tim Burton obviously had his own take on this material but I just don't think it quite works. Some of the production design is well done but the story lacks a lot of the meaning from the original.

title: Mediocre but visually interesting
text:
The movie begins as a classic sci-fi suspense flick, then turns to action, quickly followed by fantasy. It slips in some comedy, throws in a lame moralistic tale, provides a bit more action, and finally descends to farce. It was crying out for an emotional interlude by way of a romantic connection between the "hero", Mark Wahlberg and supermodel Estella Warren, but this was denied.I guess the movie must have been made by committee, because Tim Burton failed to develop any consistent threads. Instead we have a disjointed collection of Burton trademarks - dark austere sets, amazing visual detail, slightly warped humor, all competing with tired block-buster themes of choreographed fighting sequences, large explosions and poor scripts.
The best thing about the movie is the make-up and visuals. But even that is not enough to carry the mediocrity of it all. And the ending? - plain silly.

title: As good as one would expect
text: Initial while watching the movie I liked it, however the more I think back on it the more I think it was only average.    It was however a very well done remake.   Very tough to improve on the classic Planet of the Apes movie.

title: Much Better Than The Original!
text: I liked it right up until the ending, which made no sense to me.  I do understand that the director (Tim Burton) had to keep the options open for a sequel, but whoever does that sequel (if they do it) will have a difficult time basing it on what I saw!  Good Luck!

title: Remake of "Fistful of dollars" using Klingons?
text: Tim Roth's "original" villian seems to stem from the touchy-feely evil Ramon/Indio villain in "Fistful of dollars/Few dollars more" spaghetti westerns (titles which sum up what this remake is all about). The bonanza of great effects make for great entertainment but the lack of a visionary story make this a one-dimensional kid's movie which won't stick in the brain for adults. There is no "discussion" on the moral/philosphical place of man in the universe: in the original book/movie, our hero is clearly divided since he neither fits in with the future's primitive humans nor the apes. This version is just another uncompelling "Us vs. Them," and the war-like gorillas sound and look like Klingons in "Star Trek." Speaking of gorillas, whom did they evolve from since there were originally only chimps? Where do they live, since there are too many for that hilltown? Where did the modern-speaking humans come from if the caucasian astronauts all died? Why does the blonde babe keep ducking out of scenes - does she have a bladder like a thimble? And are we on earth in the far future or far past? Or another dimension? This last plot problem ruins the great visual ending (try as it might to be like the book's end). The soundtrack also doesn't credit it's inspiration to the better original. For those who absurdly claim we need remakes because kids won't watch the originals, it was we kids who loved the original enough to generate 4 sequels, a live-action and animated TV series, lunch boxes, etc. and inspire Tim Burton.

title: Mediocre film, but succeeds in doing what it was made to.
text: I say.  This movie, while poorly written, acted, and for the most part, executed, was entertaining and though provoking.Many of the reviewers don't realize that the movie is NOT a remake by any means, and obviously doesnt pretend to be judging by the fact that the plot is almost entirely different, and any messege the film tries to get across to the viewer is also quite different.The purpose of the film is to confuse and disorient the viewer and make them sit through the credits with a perplexed look on his or her face.  The ending is much too bizzare to make any conceivable sense, and not even the director could clearly explain it.Though it falls short when it comes to the script and acting, the pace of the film is sporadic, and its clear that Tim Burton didnt give it his all, this is not a bad movie.  Its an entertaining film that succeeds in doing what it was meant to.  I give it a 7 out of 10.

title: It's a one star disappointment. Hopefully the sequel will be an improvement.
text: I have to admit, I never read the book.  Maybe this thing was true to the letter.  If that's the case, the creators of the original movie were even smarter than I thought.  Regardless, this time around was an abysmal disaster.  I gave it a "4" because Charlton Heston was awesome in his cameo. Nothing else impressed.

title: Human-like apes rule the world.
text: After digesting the hype and then taking in Tim Burton's remake of "The Planet of the Apes", I felt cheated or let us say disappointed. It was by no means any better than the original. An astronaut(Mark Wahlberg) lands on a planet where apes rule over humans, ok. He then tries to lead a revolution, ok. The twisted ending is the only captivating part of the movie. The set designs were awesome, cinematography out of sight and the special effects very good. This is a very interesting movie, but lacks the impact of the original. Danny Elfman proves again to be a wizard when it comes to scoring a movie.Supporting cast features Tim Roth, Helena Bonham Clark, Kris Kristofferson, Michael Clarke Duncan and Estella Warren. There is no reason to not think this movie can last over thirty years like the original and still be worth viewing. Hang on to the youngsters and your popcorn. A fun flick.

title: preposterous
text: Some movies are bad because of low budget. Some movies are bad because of a bad plot. Some movies are bad by design, i.e. quickie, cheesy exploitation movies. And some movies are bad because a director goes hopelessly out of control... pounding home his vision with the force of a gorilla's fist in an iron glove. Joining the ranks of "Water World", "The Wild, Wild West" and "Battlefield Earth", "Planet Of The  Apes" comes yelping and screaming to the screen as a comic book come to life. The trouble is, it doesn't know what it is. A science fiction thriller? A horror story? A comedy? High Camp? Unintentionally funny. Stilted. Stupefying. Kris Kristofferson is left hung out to dry as a sort of latter-day Tumak from "One Million Years B.C.;" loincloth-clad Estella Warren appears baffled throughout and although a love interest, has surprisingly little to do . Various human characters are introduced only to later stand around and gawk. Some great ape makeup is wasted on some of the sorriest, most hapless ape villains in movie history. Apes snarl. They grunt. They scream and jump on a planet that seems to have the gravitational pull of our moon...one blow will send an ape or human flying 20 feet into the air on obviously ill-concealed wire harnesses. We have comic(?) relief in the form of a Gilbert Gottfried patterned ape slave trader who is one moment sadistically brutal, the next moment a wise-cracking borscht-belt comedian who may be the most annoying movie character this side of Jar-Jar Binks.  Hero Mark Wahlberg makes one yearn for a real hero in the mold of a Charlton Heston or a Harrison Ford...his heroics consist of simply unfastening a few poorly locked chains and walking free. Couple all this with a some outlandish spacecraft wreckage that functions perfectly after 3,000 years and an army of 10,000 apes that inflicts absolutely no damage to its enemies and you have a turkey that defies description. Tim Burton slips on a Kong-Sized banana peel. A  stupendous, colossal, preposterous yawn.

title: Excellent and no CGI
text: I don't care what other people are saying, this movie was terrific.The story line was believable, the actors did an exceptional job and the best thing about this movie was NO CGI. All the apes are actual actors wearing costumes and masks.The biggest problem with the other (3) new Planet of the Apes movies; Dawn of, Rise of and War of, they used far too much CGI. However, I really liked how they tied those (3) movies into the original Planet of the Apes movie group from 1968.The Mark Wahlberg movie was a stand-alone story and excellent, in my opinion. I think it is grossly "under-rated" and worth the watch.

title: DO NOT GIVE AWAY THE ENDING!
text: DO NOT GIVE AWAY THE ENDING! Tim Burton...what can you say about this guy. He just keeps coming up with spectacular, off-kilter films that no-one else could. Batman, Edward Scissorhands, The Nightmare Before Christmas, and now this stunning re-vision of a sci-fi classic. To be honest, today's youngsters aren't likely to watch a film from the 60's anyway, so it was quite acceptable, and logical, to update it. And what an update! This and Jurassic Park III and going a long way to making up for the lame-ness we've had so far this summer. DO NOT GIVE AWAY THE ENDING!

title: A travesty of a sham! A sham of a travesty!
text: Is there anybody left that actually remembers the original 'Planet of the Apes'?  If so, do remember the point?  Man, given enough time, will destroy himself with technology.  Simple ebough.  Flash forward to the present, and the film is remade.  And what does Tim Burton do?  He gives the moral a 180 and suddenly man is the utmost being and technology is his savior.  It just goes to show how self centered and over confident we have all become.For the record, even if there was no original Planet of the Apes, this would still be a worthless movie.  It becomes more campy by the second, there are far to many innconsistancies to mention here, and the ending was quite possibly the most ridiculous thing I have ever seen.  What, did they have a whole bunch of left of monkey suits to use?  Not only am I about to give up on Tim Burton (that's two, Mr. Burton, remember Sleepy Hollow?) but I am completely fed up with the bastardization of old movies.  Has hollywood run out of new ideas?

title: Underrated gem
text: I saw this in theaters opening weekend when I was in middle school. I loved it so much and was awe struck at the whole storyline and effects. I miss the way films used makeup and puppets as opposed to CGI-ing everything as they do now. This was probably one of the last great make up heavy films they made since computers really took over. All I know is the story had me hooked, and the ending had me leaving the theatre with a punch in the gut, I was begging for more. I awaited the sequel for so long and it's such a shame they didn't make one with the apes in the present day. That could've been such a cool movie. Tim Burton was perfect for this at the right time. Maybe it's because I was a kid who knew so little about the world that this was movie magic for me. I love it.

title: Better than I thought
text: Once again it is summer and the big blockbuster movies come out and they all stink such as Jurassic Park 3. (Which you can read my comment on if you want.) But this is not a bad movie. This is a great movie. Mark Wahlberg does a terrific job and so does the whole cast. It is incredibly interesting how it is made. Now since I am only a thirteen year old boy I have not seen the original but the person I saw this with says that they are incredibly different and it is hard to compare this and the 1968 version. When I heard a few years ago that they are making a remake for Planet of the Apes  i didn't think that it was going to be very good and I already knew it would be very hard to make with just the apes and at the end there is over a couple hundred apes. They had put in an extrordinary amount just when they had put the names up at the beginning. Although it is a good movie it is also confusing at the end. I won't ruin it for you but be prepared to use your brain in the last few minutes. Well it is a very good movie and I hope you found it as entertaining as I did.

title: Mixed
text: This film is very mixed. There are some good ideas like the science fiction time travel element that sets it apart from the original. The action and makeup was decent. However, the acting was really over the top and you can't feel much for these characters.

title: What were they thinking? Hollywood bunk once again.
text: The original Planet of the Apes was awesome for its time. The number of follow up films produced prove it. I admit with each new sequel the quality of the story went down, but one tends to be forgiving because they were made so closely together and had some cohesion.  This new film doesn't have that luxury. They took a chance and changed the story and failed miserably.  The original had implications of mankind's destructive nature which caused this twisted society to be born. In the new version the ape society was born from an astronaut not following orders. How Trite! I'll say that the make-up was impressive, but so what. I'll take a story with some depth and meaning any day.

title: Triumph! Why I believe 'Planet of the Re-Makes' IS better than the original 'Planet of the Fakes'... !
text: (Original: 3/10. Remake: 7/10.)Firstly, let me warn readers that this will be more of a rant than an even-minded critique; so if balance and objectivity are what you're searching for, you'd be better served by seeking out a positive review of the '68 version... I'm in the mood to make possibly unfair comparisons, and I'll make no attempt to hide that - so if you don't find yourself disgusted with me at this point, then read on...* I watched the original last night; Heston put a black mark on the film for me straight away. He has the sense of authority and presence only of a poor man's Clint Eastwood; and he looks like he would be better suited to working in Infomercials, with his manner of gazing earnestly into the camera and intoning gravely. OK, to be fair; Wahlberg is no better here, but it makes for a more believable crew and surroundings if the 'leading man' has gone AWOL and you don't have someone who carries his reputation before him constantly looking to unduly milk significance from the script. Wahlberg makes a better Everyman, so you see him more 'in character' than when you watch Heston, who typifies a Hollywood landmark.* You don't think of Kubrick and his Odyssey, when you watch this update. The sinister overlords are revealed much more stealthily. Unfortunately, Stanley cornered the market for 'primate roaming barren landscape' imagery just a few months after Schaffner's work opened, and there's no doubt which is the more memorable image in these modern years. Such is life. Burton doesn't even try to approach from such an angle, and it works. I suppose that's one reason I can get aboard the 're-imagination' train, because at least we get a newer look...* There's less 'blithe imperialism' tossed about in our politically correct days. "Give it a few weeks and you could own this place", someone mentions to Heston on our first trip. OK, now I as the audience think you DESERVE to be subjugated for your arrogance! All our modern young explorers want to do is repair their mistakes, though; so yep, they're the winners of my sympathy vote. Chalk up another 'moral victory'...* A bigger budget and more 'experimental' supporting cast may mean we get better makeup; but what's much more crucial is the improved interpretation of speech. No more do we have to put up with creatures who intimidate and horrify us with their appearance, but nevertheless all have voices that remind us uncannily of the nearest fishmonger from down the high street. Happily, this time our villains manage to sound unfamiliar and scary, to boot!* The forefather possibly started a flagellation fetish for those would be conquerors of brave new frontiers, further exploited by "A Man Called Horse", amongst others... Luckily, Burton opted for uneasy laughs instead; hanging our human friends in cages as an in-joke. It would thankfully be another few years before "The Passion of The Christ" caused some squirming in seats and revived masochism as the cinematic trend of the age...If you ask me; it looks like the passage of time does favours for ALL civilisations... !

title: Great effects but misses the point of the story
text: This slick version fleshes out the brutal details of the original but lacks its memorable storyline, social commentary, vision and beautiful original soundtrack. The metaphoric value of the book/original film are lost by the fact that humans here can already speak - english as usual -so the only superiority the apes have is physical. In fact, since all the humans were killed on the space station, who were all those long-haired Harley Biker dudes (the "humans") descended from?  Without the constant philosophical criticism of man's evil nature(throw in guilt and original sin too, what the heck), it turns into Humans versus hairy Roman empire-Mafiosa-Nazi-etc.-type aliens (Tim Roth is a composite of many movie evil archetypes). It looks like they borrowed the plot twists and F/X from the new "Lost in Space" movie, but that movie didn't really have to compete with the original series. The ending is reminiscent of the book BUT doesn't make sense in terms of time travel in our universe, so if he went back in time in an alternate universe, all quantum universes being equal, then it's just a coincidence he returns to an ape-ruled earth (rather than an INEVITABILITY which was THE POINT in the book/original film). To put it another way, if Burton's movie came first, noone would be inspired to remake it 30 years. Great effects, costumes and menacing apes but very uninspiring.

title: Evolution of a Classic
text: Tim Burton was careful to call his take on "Planet of the Apes" a "re-imagining" rather than a "remake."  And he does quite well here.  This version has a dark look that works to a point.  The ape makeup on the actors does look convincing.  And having them actually move like apes was a nice touch.  But, to tell the truth, the new twist ending didn't really make sense.  And I did miss seeing the Statue of Liberty in this version. Perhaps Tim purposefully left Lady Liberty out because people expected her?

title: Captivating but doesn't fit the saga
text: This story has nothing to do with the narrative world of the previous ones, it is understandable knowing that it is a reboot, but it does not fit with the recent trilogy either, so this movie manages to have countless holes in the script, as well as some things don't end up convincing due to what they had told us in the previous ones, although the direction makes us interested in this story and its characters, despite the fact that it is convenient in some parts. Despite that, the third act is very slow and the ending is unfortunately meaningless and we could never find a convincing explanation for it, plus it doesn't fit the logic that we had been described in the previous ones.I think it's good at making us curious about this world in which the story takes place, but the original, certainly manages to give us a compelling and much more complete narrative.

title: Did not work for me for ONE MAIN REASON
text: Now that I've finally seen the big Planet of the Apes remake, and before I look again at the reviews. I am asking myself why the movie just didn't work.  And I think I know.It wasn't awful, not to me anyway.  I enjoyed the effects, I enjoyed Elfman's score, the makeup was wonderful, the acting of all the ape characters was pretty terrific, the plot was at least interesting.  Those are all good things, and made it an endurable experience, not like, say, Nightfall.So what was wrong?  One factor.  MARK WAHLBERG.He's just *nothing.*  He's this bland, flavorless, rice-cake/styrofoam object filling up air and reflecting light rays.  Not Rufus Sewell obnoxious/bad, not David Birney talentless/bad, just... this-was-supposed-to-be-a-steak-and-it-turns-out-to-be-tofu bad.I will never see Boogie Nights, so I will never have a comment on his "work" in that, I don't remember him from Perfect Storm, so I don't know if Wahlberg is capable of being interesting.  The part wasn't written terribly interesting (but think Sean Connery, John Wayne, Jimmy Stewart - a talented actor can *make* a part interesting).  Doing a lot of standing around and staring, occasionally broken up by some moving around and staring, won't breathe life into a part.And when he did do something or speak, I found his character unsympathetic and centerless.Now, I didn't think much about the original while watching, because I think such comparisons are unfair and usually irrelevant.  But I feel I need to say one more thing: Charlton Heston.  Not one of my favorite actors, but compare the life and scope of that character to this listless... thing.Too bad.  The movie could have been a lot of fun.

title: Emotionless
text: The best way to describe Planet of the Apes is mechanical.  It's a high-tech movie made by a high-tech machine.  It is coldly put together like a car on an assembly line.  The actors are so laden down with makeup, emotional expression is impossible.  Even actors who are lucky enough not to wear any makeup have one-note performances: p***ed-off.  Tim Burton, whose fish-out-of-water thing is getting real old, forgot to add what made Batman, Sleepy Hollow and Beetlejuice work - a sense of humor.  This is, after all, a ludicrous situation.  Why not treat it as such?  Instead, we have Mark Wahlberg who seems to have a permanent scowl etched into his face.  Where is the wisecracking Arnold when you need him?  Tim Roth is no better.  While his mannerisms and swagger are excellent, his over-the-top anger makes his General Thade into nothing more than an enraged chimp throwing feces at everyone in the film (and the audience).  Somebody please call the animal control unit!  Planet of the Apes is SO cold, SO angry, and SO dark that I finally became bored with the whole thing.  Burton, however, is clever.  In an effort to generate repeat business, he tacked on an ending that is so baffling, audiences will be lined up a second and third time just to try to make sense of it.  Lacking the clarity to be shocking, it is simply an inexplicable, absurd anomaly.  Like the rest of the movies this summer, Planet of the Apes fails to live up to its promise.

title: Tim Burton is obviously losing his touch
text: STAR RATING:*****Unmissable****Very Good***Okay**You Could Go Out For A Meal Instead*Avoid At All CostsA while ago,Tim Burton directed such twisted fantasy classics as the Batman films,Beetlejuice and Edward Scissorhands.But recently,he churned out the rather turgid Sleepy Hollow and followed it up with this uninvolving and unnecessary remake of the original 1968 Charlton Heston movie.There are some noticeable in-jokes in the film,for instance,wheras the original is remembered for it's classic ''Get your hands off me,you dirty ape'' line,this time the ape bit is replaced with ''human'' and Michael Clarke Duncan is brilliantly cast as a big hulking soldier ape.No one else sadly is however.Mark Whalberg is totally unconvincing as a leading man action hero,and Helena Bonham Carter makes a complete fool of herself as an ape.Throw into this a totally far fetched story and you have a film that you should probably stay away from.**

title: It'd be nice to forget the original but...
text: It'd be nice to forget the original but, this is not an original idea. The shock value provided by the original 1968 film is lost here. Hollywood is running out of creative ideas for films every time they "remake" old movies and make movies based on video games.People say Tim Roth was excellent in this film? I could hardly understand him under the growling and mumbling. Helena Bonham Carter's make-up was Amateur and Mark Wahlberg was awful.Luckily I'm a male and Estella Warren provided the stimulation for me, even though she got to say about five dumb lines.What's good about this film? It looks good, just like Estella too bad there wasn't anything else.Rating: 5/10

title: Apes Rule Once Again
text: What took so long to re-make this 68 sci-fi classic? I had been expecting it since the early 90's! From reading the reviews, however, I get the feeling that it was probably only me who made that prediction. Why did I predict or even insisted that there would be a re-make of Planet Of The Apes?  Well, for one thing, I believed that the advanced cinema techniques could add so much flavour to the original screenplay, which was superbly revolutionary (please read my review for the original Planet Of The Apes 68' to see why I consider the original screenplay to be "revolutionary"). I have always thought that the original Planet Of The Apes was full of imaginative thoughts but it lacked juicy action scenes that could have made it even more fun to watch (however even this drawback didn't stop it from becoming a classic sci-fi, probably the best of its genre). The other reason why I expected a re-make was because I wanted to see my most favourite sci-fi saga being re-imagined, as director Tim Burton put it.
