text: Tim Burton and company definitely double down on "Planet of the Apes" as a Jewish parable, with Mark Whalberg playing a slack-jawed Moses to the human slaves, along with a few apes, whom he leads through the desert of the forbidden zone, evading capture by crossing a sea of sorts, even, and to the mountaintop, where, near by, he wanders off to communicate with the burning bush of his ruined spaceship. He also wars with the various tribes of apes, to deliver the promised land of equality to all... or some such thing. There's the chimp god from the stars, too.It's an entirely unwarranted remake. Although the makeup and CGI effects are OK, I, at least, had no desire to see an attractive, talking, super-intelligent chimpanzee, such as Helena Bonham Carter's Ari. Nor do I care for the suggestion of a love triangle between Ari, Whalberg's Moses stand-in and a female human, who unlike the original film's Nova, can talk, but still has nothing worth saying. Worse still, Tim Roth merely snarls and jumps around, jacked up on CGI, and the human boy who wants to be on the front lines is just laughable.

title: One of the Worst of All Time
text: The terrible reviews I read beforehand in no way prepared me for how truly horrible this epic disaster truly is. Tim Burton has failed terribly before, but never worse than this. One star is one too many. Please do yourself a favor and resist any temptation to watch this. John Travolta's epic sci-fi bomb, Battlefield Earth, is more watchable and interesting than this. At least it was original and did not butcher and tarnish a classic franchise, one that has been successfully remade since Burton's 100% awful remake.I like Mark Wahlberg, and it's pleasant to see him so young and handsome and heroic. But it does not redeem the film. Hated it. With passion. With a bullet. With great regret.

title: Remake + Tim Burton = Excellent Movie
text:
This movie was by far another wonderful movie from one of my favorite directors, Tim Burton.  I loved all his other movies  ("Sleepy Hollow", "Edward Scissorhands," "Beetlejuice," "Batman," etc.)  but it had everything I wanted from a Tim Burton movie- special effects, great cast, wonderful score (composed by the great Danny Elfman),  and a surprise ending.  It's just like the 1968 original "Planet of the Apes," but, the new one's different.  I recommend this movie to anybody who's looking for a good movie this summer or who's a Tim Burton fan.
A+ ****** stars (out of ******) 10/10

title: Terrible remake of a movie that was only halfway good anyhow
text: Absolutely the worst film yet by Burton, who seems to be getting worse with each film he directs.  A miserable script loaded with cliches is only the first of many objectionable aspects to this film.  This is the kind of movie where every time something happens, you'll be sure to hear someone shout out "he's lost his gun!" or whatever it is to let everybody know.  Carter is really awful and so is Wahlberg, who can't play this straight and be convincing.  Very nice effects and photography, but poor music in the John Williams mold by Burton's crony Elfman.  Heston appears in a nonsensichal scene to spout out his most famous catch-phrases from the first movie.  Very poor results.If anyone else out there also saw "Sleepy Hollow", they will probably have noticed, as I have, the declining quality of Burton's films.  I've heard that this particular project was produced by others and that Burton was brought in as director, in which case his judgement should be questioned. But I think he has allowed any possible vision he might have had earlier in his career to slip; the evidence is there in the films.  In "Sleepy Hollow", he couldn't decide what kind of movie he was making, whether it was a comedy or a real horror movie, and the population of british character actors (Chris Lee, etc.) made you also think it was kind of a monster rally film (those are never scary, as horror fans know).  The movie couldn't succeed on either horror or comedy because it was so schizophrenic, and no style had been developed to smooth the two together.  "Planet of the Apes" is much the same way, and the result comes off more like "Total Recall" or "Tango and Cash" than like sci-fi.  He's also fallen into the rut of so many other "big" directors of trying to satisfy the entire possible audience.  Word to Burton, if you're out there -- pick something and do it straight, or use some style to peice it all together (as in "Mars Attacks" or "Beetlejuice") or you might as well retire, because people like me that are fans of your movies will stop going.

title: Terrible, terrible, terrible!
text: Man, am I glad to have missed this movie in cinema. Just saw it on TV now. I rarely get upset about a movie, but I am now: Terribly uninspiring, un-original and one-dimensional, one-way story, terrible acting, especially Wahlberg (who looks and talks like an idiot most of the time) and the blond chick (Warren?). Actually she is not acting at all but only trying to look good all the time. The only decent performances come from Bonham Carter and her big hulky gorilla companion during the escape (missed his name, some ex-General). Tim Roth is too one-dimensionally "bad" to be of any compelling interest. He should have declined this lame role.Terrible, senseless and completely out-of-the-blue ending after the (very poor and thin) "story" is concluded already. The costumes/make-ups and production design are good (2001, so no surprise) but do not save this movie at all.Tim Burton clearly can do better than this. I can't understand what he found in this script as he had a very heavy and uninspired hand here. Complete waste of time and money... utterly disappointing. For me, this Apes is one of the worst Sci-fi movies ever made, and to compare it in any way to the 1968 movie is an offence to the latter.

title: Pierre Boulle lives!!!!
text: I read the novel in jr high and thoroughly loved the ending.  Now that Tim Burton's film is out I can enjoy the ironic ending Boulle had visualized (only set in DC rather than Paris).  This is a much better film than the original.  Thank you Tim!

title: Very, very low rent (and sloppy) version of the classic film
text: Tim Burton could've done better, but instead he chose to do this, a remake of a movie that didn't need to be remade (could the reason for the remake possibly be for, oh dare I say, MONEY?  Maybe Fox didn't have enough yet?). And while I guess if by some dumb luck Burton is the right choice for a re-telling, but that's not the point.  He has made many fine re-makes (Batman the topper, also Mars Attacks, and Sleepy Hollow) but this isn't one of them.  This is in the overall view over-flashy, conventional (much, much more than the first if that one had any convention in the first place) and confusing. I mean, at least the ending in the first one was exciting and questioning. This one just almost says the point of this film was Back to the Future (or past) with primates.  Dumb logic.  Also the characters have less charm, humor and coolness that came with the first one; Wahlberg has nearly no emotions in scenes that parallel the ones in the first, and I can see why Heston is now Sir Heston.Only things to possibly watch for- a hilarious cameo from Sir Charleton Heston himself (I'd just as well sneak in the film for that one scene again), makeup that nearly matches the first one, although the first one was a breakthrough, and some OK visual effects.  Some Die-hard Burton fans will find some use here (once in a while it gave a thrill or two), but other than that, keep your damn paws off of this damn, dirty film!  Between C- and D+

title: Awful remake of great sci-fi classic
text: I've just seen the movie, and man did I sit through one of the most tasteless, tacky, non-inspired remake of one of the great sci-fi classics there is out there...I know it's tough to make a good remake of an older film, with regards to the conflict between fans of the original film and the fans of modern-day action, blockbuster movies, but - come on! A total rip-off of the original plot, except for the classic ending which had to be different since the ending was so surprising and by now well-known in the original, an un-inspired casting (lets face it; Mark Wahlberg will not be remembered for his great acting skills) and an over-all feeling of "Oh, I know what's going to happen next" throughout the movie. I felt totally cheated and exploited after coming out of the theatre!My five cents worth to you: Save your money, it's not worth it!

title: Monkey Business
text: Oh, my god it has finally happened: Tim Burton has directed an absolute stinker. From the opening minutes, where Wahlberg gets on a rescue-mission for his chimp (!) to its final "surprise"-ending (which is everything, but no surprise) this movie goes nowhere. No action, no script, no suspense and no sense at all - not even good visuals, which Burton is known for. What made the director and the producers believe that this is a movie? It seems as if the whole crew had no idea what they were doing. The acting - especially by "star" Mark Wahlberg, who once again proves that maybe he is the most overrated actor ever to emerge from Hollywood - but also by theater veterans Roth and Bonham-Carter - is completely dull. Well, at least it fits the movie. Be sure to miss this one, you could spend your money in a more reasonable way- like throwing it away!

title: Do not compare to the original
text: This movie stands on it's own merit. The original was a timeless sci-fi classic. A stand alone. I was obsessed with the original, sequels, TV show, merchandise, anything ape! I used to draw ape faces all over my Pee Chee folders! (Kids, ask your parents). So I qualify as a huge fan! This movie does have it's flaws but it's not the abomination some reviews have said. It's good popcorn fun!

title: Expensive monkeys
text: It takes a plethora of qualities to make an outstanding piece of cinema. Many things can go awry, from direction to production, casting to lighting. Any one thing can put the whole thing off kilter. Try watching The Texas Chainsaw Massacre, to a background score of 'The Sound Of Music' and you may begin to see what I'm driving at. It just doesn't ring true. It would come across as, if not ridiculous, then certainly somewhat odd. This is how I felt about this film. Mark Wahlberg plays a United States Airforce space pilot who also trains, luckily for the plot, monkeys. It would be easy to harp on about paying peanuts, getting monkeys and other such witticisms. Instead of blindly denigrating this film, as many have done, it would seem more politic to look at the reasons why. Hammy acting, cliched one-liners, `Never send a monkey to do a man's job', for instance. Lack of plot; Star thrown into space turmoil, gets stranded on an unforgiving planet dominated by Apes. Apes catch star. Star escapes from potential slavery. Star gets home again safely. Everybody's happy. Apart from the audience. Widely slammed by critics and punters alike, and fairly so. A poor excuse for a film which tried, and miserably failed, to live up to the original. Bad, bad, bad. Even the token appearance from Charlton Heston could not save this from ignominy.

title: how to make a bad movie with big budget
text: oh come on!, when are they going to stop doing things like this?, when are they going to realize it doesn't matter how much money they spend on fireworks and publicity... if they don't spend some few cents on writing a script that is not insulting to the viewers' intelligence, the movie is nothing but garbage? well, I've had enough of these nonsense, stupid scripts, with all the plot holes, corny sentimental moments and recycled jokes.  Sure I enjoyed the customes, the visual effects and the sexy blue eyed blonde, but I would have enjoyed it more if the movie showed at least a fraction of the impact the original series did. Tim Roth, Helena Bonham Carter.. they were good enough, frankly I believe they are wasting their talent on garbage like this.  I wish them better vision to choose better scripts in the future. Only one more thing:  I'm really dissapointed at Tim Burton.

title: Possibly the worst dreck I have seen this year
text: I debated through the whole movie, "should I leave this mind numbing experience, or might I miss something original and entertaining appear?" Alas, the answer was... I should have left.Mark Walhberg again shows he can't act his way out of a .... paper bag? When he is attempting to show pain, his pathetic grimace looks like an act. When he attempts to lead the humans in the final confrontation, you can see what's going through his head: Hmmm, I can't act, let alone lead this rag tag bunch of humans. I HAVE NO COURISMA.Then there are the technical issues regarding the pod, able to fly about like a space ship in and out of the atmosphere? At least Charlton Heston had a real ship to crash into the earth with. And then there are the  plot holes and contrivances I could drive a Mack truck through. Arggg, enough.Sorry for any errors, omissions, or spelling mistakes.

title: STICK WITH THE ORIGINAL
text: An adequate summer blockbuster, but a very poor film nonetheless. Poor attempts at comedy, designer apes and an inexplicable ending. Wahlberg looks like he's on drugs, and the film is a mess. Burton has done much better, and this is not a vintage effort.Check out the 1968 original. Aside from the great ending, it offers a much better intelligent angle on race and the nuclear weapons.

title: Definitely Something to Go Ape Over!
text: Sorry, I couldn't resist the bad pun.  Ah... finally, this summer there is a true summer movie, featuring not only the big budget, cool special effects and the action, but also a seasonable plot and acting to rake in tons of teenagers' (as well as their parents') summer-job money.While I don't know/care to discuss the budget, it certainly went to good use.  The make-up effects are amazing (the make-up in the original was just as amazing when it was released, but look how far make-up artistry has come!); the big action scenes near the end featuring flank after flank of the ape army are truly a sight to behold.  Unlike in the original series, there are multiple species of ape on this planet, including chimpanzees, gorillas, and even a few orangutans.  All look amazingly realistic, physically way more intimidating than any "human" character could ever hope to be.  It must have been a nightmare for the actors under the makeup though.Besides, looking fantastic, the apes actually act like apes!  It's just so interesting and exciting to see an ape character such as General Thade yelling at someone in English, then jumping and climbing around, screeching in anger.  Next to that, it's really not possible for the human actors to contend at all... I mean they're not bad, but they are easily overshadowed by the apes, especially the soldiers, who not only look menacing, but through their harsh tones of voice and shrill screeches, are menacing.  It's too easy to forget that there were originally people underneath all those apes. Along with their appearance and manner, the apes' society is also interesting.  There is an ape religion, with the belief in a soul (and subsequent belief that the human "animals" don't have souls).  Other aspects of their society mentioned in the film include inter-special marriage (e.g. a chimp and an orangutan), a senatorial government, and humans, depending on age, sold as pets or slaves; there are even "human rights" activists.  While it may not offer as much social commentary as the original series, it's still enthralling enough, and it's great that the writers decided to offer details on the ape's religion, which is also a vital part of the plot near the end.  The only complaint I could offer about the society portrayed is that, like the original film series and unlike the book, the apes don't use vehicles.The unfortunate thing about summer films is that they usually end up sucking a few years later, as they are based solely on the special effects.  Tim Burton and crew have broken that mold with Planet of the Apes, which holds through all the way to the twist/ending (which is different from the original, and, though definitely an unexpected surprise, just a little bit of a let down).  See it for the special effects, and see it again for the intricacies of the ape society, religion and plot.

title: Planet of the (j)apes
text: Keep this filthy stinking movie away from me you damn dirty humans.Hands up who cringed at the awful reworking of the classic 'filthy paws' and 'damn them all' lines from the original film?Save for the insight into the origins of the 'planet of the apes' and the adherence to the original novels ending, I was more than let down by this production. And as much as I would love to give Rick Baker and his team praise for the make up, what were they thinking of when designing the female chimpanzees???Sorry Tim, but you ain't no organ grinder!

title: Literally defines the term LAME
text: Tim Burton is my absolute favorite director of all time and he rarely strikes out but when he does, it can be quite embarrassing. Case in question: the 2001 remake of one of the most famous sci-fi films of all time.I do have one confession. I've never actually seen the original 1968 film but I am familiar with the story. Here, astronaut Leo Davidson (played forgettably by Mark Wahlberg) crash lands on a distant planet ruled by intelligent apes. From there, he treks with a small band of outsiders towards these mysterious, ancient ruins which may hold the key for his return home.Where do I begin? Well, the cast is thoroughly wasted and this film has quite a cast (David Warner! Michael Clarke Duncan! Paul Giamattei!), the special effects are pretty generic, and the production design is slimy and claustrophobic. On top of all that, the final battle is very lackluster.Adding to all this, the ending is a joke. While the original film had an ending that was surprising and strangely appropriate, this one feels forced and confusing. Additional sore spots include a bland score by the usually reliable Danny Elfman and a pace that BEGS for a steroid shot.You may be wondering are there ANY redeeming values? Well, Charlton Heston's cameo is pretty good but since it is just a cameo, he's not in long enough to truly save it.What else can I say? This film stinks.

title: absolut ridiculous
text: I really looked forward to see Planet of the Apes, but it was a huge dissapointment.The settings and masks are great, but that is the only good aspect of the film. All other things are really annoying. Mark Wahlberg is not acting, he is just in the movie, looking stupid. The other actors are also not very good.But the worst point of all, is the story. It is absolutely ridiculous! For example: the apes are lying unconsiousness on the ground, but the humans don`t attack them, no, they wait until they are up again! This is just one example for the stupid story, but it would take too long to tell them all.

title: A good movie
text:
I don't understand why the other reviews are so harsh on this movie. The design, the costumes, the acting and the story with a nice twist at the end of worthy of good praise.
It's not as good as the new planet of the apes movies but it still holds its own as a well made movie.

title: COMPLETE AND UTTER BOLLOX!!!!!!
text: Dont waste your time with this film, its crap and a waste of money, the effects are the only thing to its credit. its filled with long boring scenes, which all result in a boring film and the ending is the worst ive seen 2 date, COME UP WITH SOMETHING ORIGIONAL GODDAMN IT!If ya wanna see a good version of this watch the old one, its better directed, better acted, and a better story by far!#

title: Dreary and Bad
text: What has happened to Tim Burton?  Given a big budget he just can't seem to put it to decent use.  And, what is worse, he turns perfectly decent actors into inept mumblers (although talking through several inches of latex can't be easy).  Even the great David Warner seems to be wholly uninvolved with the drab performance he is giving.  This is just a very bad move and that is a shame, considering the technical tricks that were used --- and wasted --- in the enterprise.

title: Never send a man to do a monkey's job.
text: Do I have the right to comment on this? I mean, I missed the movie I was laughing so hard. This is a movie about a man torn between two females: a blonde and a monkey. You have to see the slutty "Oh!"-look on the face of the blonde when the guy kisses the monkey to know what I mean when I say this movie is hilarious! Anyway, although many efforts went into this--or so the dvd told me, I wondered about the security of a space helmet which was open at the bottom. And why can't the man land a pod right once when the monkey does it so easily! Never send a man to do a monkey's job! The movie's quality allows me to poke fun at its weak spots, the make-up is pretty good, and the ideas not so bad. It's funny that they managed to have the two major gorillas be played by ethnic minorities: The loyal African american colonel Michael Clarke Duncan and the loyal Asian servant Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa.

title: what a waste
text: I like Tim Burton. Really, but I'd like him to take his hands off the Apes story. This new film shows where the cinema is going thru. Very very bad characters, poor dialogs, Just hi-tech effects ( the original movie's make-up is better than this one in my opinion if you think the 32 years between them. ) and jumpin scenes. this film would only be a poor cover of a great movie.also many logical problems occur in the story. We have to wait till another new "planet of apes" to learn what the heck happened to th earth, and believe I dont want to watch it even for my curiosity.

title: bleh, not even worth renting the DVD
text: I was initially quite interested in hearing there was a remake of this venerable classic movie. I wasn't really very happy to find out Mark Wahlberg was starring in it, but I've been wrong before about how someone can hold up a role so I decided to give it a go.As others have said, Tim Roth does a good job, Helena Bonham Carter is pretty decent, and most of the others are basically blase. Marky Mark, however, was a disaster. He has absolutely ZERO on-screen presence, he can't act well enough to even convince me that he is a human being, much less a astronaut, and the movie suffered badly because of this. I didn't care about his lead character, I had no idea what was going on in his head at any time, he never showed fear, anger, happiness, or any of the myriad emotions that most real people have. It was truly awful. Charleton Heston may have overacted in the 1968 version of this movie, but at least you could associate the word "act" with his performance. And Charleton had the on-screen presence that was so lacking in this version.Others have mentioned some of the various plot problems, including the ending, so I won't go into them except to say they are there and they make a number of plot events implausible. I would also like to point out that, once again (just as in the original POTA), the presence of horses on this "planet" is yet another obvious plot problem.As a straightforward action film the movie is pretty decent. The ape makeup and the ape movement is pretty damn good.Overall, I was considerably disappointed in this version of "Planet of the Apes" It had no originality, they chose the wrong leading actor, and the plot had huge holes. If you want to experience "Planet of the Apes" rent the original...it's so much better that there isn't really any comparison (except for the title). That's too bad, too, because this movie needed to be technologically updated.

title: Tim Burton's worst film to date
text: What ever happened to one of the most innovative and brilliant storytellers of our time?  Well, he made the kind of typical summer action fodder that could've been directed by anybody available out of film school...and in fact, they probably would've done a better job. They would've at least have put half of a thought into the dreadful script.Mark Wahlberg plays an astronaut who traveled through some sort of wormhole and landed in a planet ruled by apes. (gasp!) Except this time around, the apes squirm through groan-worthy dialogue, nonsensical plotting, and showy special effects that constantly reinforce in my mind that this money could've been put to about 10 independent films that would have been considered 'masterpiece' next to this tripe.As much as I enjoy the superb acting talent that is Tim Roth, his performance as evil ape leader Thade is nothing more than an intense composition of slouching and heavy breathing.  Luckily for him, the makeup allows he as an actor to maintain some dignity and most of the crap-dialogue is hidden behind his groans and sniffles.And alas, the always dependable Hollywood tradition of taking the male and female leads and hooking them up at the end without any relationship development or cause. And the "haha, we're so clever, aren't we?" way that Hollywood intermingles references from the original POTA into this one. Sigh...Instead of seeing this, spend the night in and call up some friends and rent 'Ed Wood', 'Edward Scissorhands', 'Batman', or even to a lesser extent 'Sleepy Hollow', and reminisce about the days when Tim Burton was a man of vision and originality...not shame and ridicule.

title: The first big movie deception of the 21st Century
text: As a big fan of Tim Burton, I've been to see Planet of the Apes (2001) without reading any critics or comments. Big mistake for it is everything except a Tim Burton movie : cheap scenario, very bad acting, dull characters, ludicrous ending  and so on. The list of negative points is too long to be written here. Only 1 little positive point : Tim Roth playing an amazing way but that doesn't save the movie from drowning into the depth of absurdity. There are enough very untalented movies director in Hollywood to shoot this big piece of s**t. Why a great director like Tim Burton has "committed" this unbelievably stupid movie ?

title: Without comparing it to the original, it still fails.
text: Tim Burton is one of my favorite directors/producers now working in the motion picture industry so I was interested to see what he had done with _Planet of the Apes_. The original movie stands as a classic of the sci-fi genre and many people, myself included, wondered why they choose to remake the movie. Fortunately the current _Planet of the Apes_ is more a reinterpretation of the material than than a remake of the movie and on that note it succeeds.However, the results are disappointing to put it mildly. There are enough plot holes to drive a Mac truck through. Often I found myself looking at my watch to see how much longer the movie would be lasting and felt my intelligence being assaulted. Some effects,  especially several jumps the apes make, would be more at home in _The Matrix_ than here. The occasional resused/reinterpreted line from the original movie are delivered poorly and come across as a weak attempt to pay homage to the original. While the story line itself was OK, plot holes aside, the script writing was lacking and the delivery of the lines by the actors more so. Interestingly enough, the best acting job is turned in by Charleton Heston who make a brief cameo appearance. Overall the production value was good, however, the apes village would be more at home in a fantasy movie than a sci-fi flick and as for the the much heralded make-up, I found it lacking, save for the gorillas. Of course one has to mention the ultimate ending of the movie which reeks of being tacked on and proves that sometimes movie makers just add too much footage for no good reason. The final few minutes should have wound up on the cutting room floor. All in all, it is a failure. Everybody makes a real stinker every now and then and Tim really has one here.

title: Impressive
text: Tim Burton re-imagines Planet of the Apes. To put it simply, I enjoyed watching it. The original Apes films are masterpieces of cinema to be sure. So Burton decided that instead of merely retelling the original story, he would put his own spin to the tale. As such, it should be appreciated as a film in its own right and not a mere rehash. The cast, namely Mark Wahlberg, Helena Bonham Carter, Michael Clarke Duncan, etc., gave pretty impressive performances. One of my favorite bits has to be Charlton Heston's cameo. In ape makeup, no less. I will not spoil the ending here. it has to be seen to be believed, but I can assure you, you won't forget it. Highly recommended.

title: Apart from Helen Bonham Carter, there is nothing worthy about this movie.
text: Apart from Helen Bonham Carter, there is nothing worthy about this movie....And the surprise ending?! The thought of a sequel is even more annoying. Save your money, wait for the video and ignore that too.

title: Truly Awful Remake
text: The 1968 version was truly a sci-fi masterpiece. The remake however, was not. The fact that the humans were not mute was completely un-disturbing, and meant that some terrible dialogue was included. As humans go, the acting was woeful, especially Estella Warren's performance. On the positive side, the special effects were impressive, the soundtrack was flawless and the ending was a welcomed shock, however this less than makes up for the rest of the movie. A huge disappointment for fans of the original movie series.

title: Profound or Campy?
text:
I. What? So. I don't know.You see. Uhm. Wait.
That was one of the many problems with this movie was it supposed to a profound commentary or a campy movie?Some of the dialogue was embarrassing. "Can't we all just get along." Bad acting especially Estelle Warren. Great lips a plus but that's it. As for Marky Mark if it wasn't for this movie we would have 'Entourage' so he gets a pass. Great costumes but movie just didn't work.

title: Candidate for the Golden Turkey Award
text: Sorry Tim, I've enjoyed most of your other films, but this was disappointing. I just couldn't work out if this was supposed to be a parody of the original version or to be taken serious adventure/drama. I loved the old Charlton Heston movie, but this was not anywhere near those standards.So what was wrong with it? The make up and special effects weren't what you expect to see in 2002. Perhaps better than the original, but not that much better.There were so many logical lapses that I just kept shaking my head at it. Yes I know that it is a sci-fi movie, but there has to be some realism in it anyway.The acting was on many parts poor. Mark Wahlberg as Leo could have been replaced by a log. What Estella Warren was doing there except running around looking confused and pretty I just don't know. Certainly not acting. Helena Bonham Carter as the ape Ari was Ok, but no more. The same goes for Tim Roth as Thade.The ending just seemed to be glued on. Left-overs from the cutting room perhaps? It didn't add to the story, but just left you confused. Worst of all it was a clear opener for a sequel. Shudder.

title: Underrated doesn't even begin to describe it.
text: I think I might be the only person in the world that loves this movie. I found it to be an immensely entertaining, compelling blockbuster with an interesting story. I love the tale of how the apes came into control and how everything is so shocking at first but then warps around on itself in the end; it all relates. The epic battle at the end was very well-done and just plain badass. The makeup for the apes and the art direction were just sensational (as these two aspects always are in Tim Burton's films). The style is pretty un-Burton (there's no Gothic elements or anything like that) but it still immerses the viewer and Danny Elfman's score does a great job of putting us into the world. In blockbusters you're never really looking for great performances, but Helena Bonham Carter and Tim Roth were both very good. Burton's decision on the ending creates one of the biggest stunners I've ever seen. It's chaotic, confusing and immensely terrifying. Unlike the rest of the world, I love it.

title: Hugely disappointing
text: What a disappointment, especially in light of the budget provided, the technical resources available, and the talent assembled.  Isn't the fundamental rule for science fiction/drama to create in the audience the willing suspension of disbelief.  POA 2001 creates a plausible beginning, suckering us in, but thereinafter Mr. Burton forgets that his moviegoers have working brains.  The over the top libertarian of Helena Bonham Carter's chimp, the worthlessness of the humans' lockup, the ease of their escape, their extraordinary skills of horsemanship (this is an astronaut and a group of human primitives suddenly riding full tilt), the massive and immediate human rebellion all are too unbelievable.  Mark Wahlberg never once projects any sense of real fear, danger or comeuppance in this world turned upside down.  Compare to the original, in which Chuck Heston's nakedness metaphorically captured his utter helplessness and astonishment at his turn of events.  The uniformed Wahlberg preserves his modesty, but also his apparent sense of management and control in an inherently wacky situation, and we never really wonder about his well being.  Unlike Heston, he seems never to be in real jeopardy.  Tim Burton should have used some of the f/x budget for some competent screenwriting.  In fact, after this inferior fiasco, I wonder why Hollywood's producers ever bothered to settle the screenwriters and directors strike threats. Let them walk.  Trained monkeys could have done as well as they did in Planet of the Apes 2001.  I'll bet the repeat viewings of this effort will be nonexistent.  It could have been a new franchise, and a wonderful new step for imagination.  Another opportunity lost.

title: And the Horses?
text: This movie is a very big disappointment, it looks like it was made by some rookie trying to copy Tim Burton style. Neither the scenarios and make-up are outstanding like it was said. And the holes in the story? -Were did the horses came from? They were riding horses in the ship? I don't think so. -Why there were so many species of apes, chimps, gorillas, etc, etc; when in the ship there were only chimps? -Where was Cornelius? One of the most important characters in the book was left off? This is to say that this movie should be avoided by Tim Burton fans... or not...

title: Terrible. Special Effects don't make a good movie.
text: I left the theatre wondering what sort of opinion the makers of this film must have of the audience.  Do they think we're stupid?  Do they think we will accept anything they put on the screen just because it has special effects?  What was the point of making this film?Despite being very courageous to even attempt re-making such a popular and well known movie, the perpetrators of this waste of time and effort seem to have forgotten some of the cardinal rules of movie making.  It's great to have special effects and lots of make-up artists working for you but a decent screenplay and some talented actors might have helped, too.  The actors in this debacle were one dimensional, at best, with the most believable character being that of Pericles.  There was little if any development of the characters and there was no  hint of the messages found in the original.The worst part of all of this is that the altered ending of the movie opens up the opportunity for a sequel.  If it gets made, that's one movie I won't be spending time or money seeing.In summary, this is a thoroughly forgettable movie that deserves no more than the score I gave it: 1/10

title: Very Entertaining, just don't compare it...
text: After seeing two really bad summer fiasco's (AI and Tomb Raider), I finally saw a movie where I smiled as I walked out.  Granted, some of the lines were questionable.  I saw it opening night in Westwood Village (the UCLA crowd) and when Dirk Digg... Leo said something to the extent of "I'm going to show something that will rock your world," everyone in the theater began chanting, "BOOGIE NIGHTS, BOOGIE NIGHTS."  Also, that wannabe model/synchronized swimmer/waif did not need to be in the movie... what role did she play?  Hmm... semi-eye-candy is what I give her.  Regardless, the rest of the cast pulled this movie together rather well.  Tim Roth was amazing, Helena Carter was decent, as well as Marky Mark himself. Visually, the movie was stunning... absolutely great.  Props to the Prince of Weird >Tim Burton.  Danny Elfman (will there be another Boingo album?) = never fails to set the mood.  The flick has some good twists, good action sequences, and all in all was a good movie all on it's own... please just don't compare it to the original... watch it as it's own movie.

title: Battlefield Ape
text: I still cannot believe that the users of the IMDB have given this crap a rating of 6.4.  I will say this: the performances were good, there was nothing especially WRONG with the directing, and the effects and makeup were everything that you would expect, but in many respects, this drivel reminds me of another ill-conceived sci-fi project.  You could probably guess what that is by the title of my comment.Battlefield Earth has been panned non-stop by critics all over the world, but is this really much better?  Come on...This film's ending is the most incoherent copout I've seen in years.  The script is completely unoriginal, the action sequences are muddled and unexciting, and the attempts at comedy are cringe-worthy.  Both are big budget mistakes.  The only difference is that this one was successful (and ok...maybe not quite so laughable).  The fact that this film has at this point grossed around $US350 million internationally is a huge indictment on the intelligence of your average human being.  If you haven't seen it yet, don't.  If you want some decent sci-fi entertainment, see Jurassic Park 3.  It may not be the epitome of originality, but at least it delivers what it says it will.Tim Burton was, until this film, a symbol of originality, style, and great black humour, but this could just as easily have been directed by Michael Bay (except he'd probably find some way to sneak in a dogfight between the apes and humans in F-15s so there'd be more explosions).To Mark Wahlberg, pick better projects.To John Travolta, you're finally almost off the hook.

title: Steaming pile.
text: I loved the original.  It had a lot more to it than a simple sci-fi flick. Everyone agrees with that.  Did I expect this remake to be up to the same level?  No.  I went in with a fresh perspective, letting the movie stand on its own.  What a mistake that was.One plot' point that bothered me was all the people wanting to see the man who defies the apes, since they defy the apes every day by congregating in roving bands of scavengers evading capture.  Also, there is a difference between giving the ending a hanging twist, the sort that requires you to think, and incomprehensible one.  Oh, and the two swiped lines from the original ("Get your stinking hands off me..." and "Damn them...") had the feeling of being forced into the script.  They just did not flow.Warren is a horrible actress.  Wahlberg was fairly stiff.  Bonham-Carter was a caricature.  Roth was the stereotypical mister-mean-man.  The script was just plain weak and the craft of storytelling was nonexistent.So, I thought I would read the book.  Let's see, the beginning was nothing like the book, the ending had little in common with the book, the middle wasn't really that much like the book.  However, there were talking apes... So, yeah, it was similar in that respect.I am glad I only rented this.  Well, not really.

title: Great movie until the end!
text: I thought Tim Burton's "Planet of the Apes" was an exciting, enjoyable remake of the original that exceeded my expectations....UNTIL the absurd ending that was nothing more than a cynical ploy by Burton to make you wait for the sequel and then pay good money again to find out what it meant.  I won't reveal the ending, but it made me change my vote from around an 8 to a 3...it ruined the movie for me.  Be forewarned!

title: Say it isn't so, Tim!
text: When I heard all the critics bitching about how terrible the new Planet of the Apes movie was, I was unfazed. I knew that there would at least be the signature Burton touches I love so much to get me through a poor script. Imagine my distress when I found none. The movie had great potential; I don't know what went wrong! Mark Whalberg, Helena Bonham Carter and Tim Roth are all spectacular actors, but here they were either cardboard cutouts, or merely annoying. Sleepy Hollow, for example, was not a great movie by any means, but at least it had Burton's flair and imagination. I'm sorry to see that one of my favourite directors of all time has now jumped on the Gus Van Sant bandwagon (I'm referring, of course, to that normally amazing director's stinker of a Psycho remake). If there was anything good to be said about this movie, I would tell you.

title: animals going wild!
text: I've read some of the comments and I won't add another one that trashes the movie; we get the point! This is a typical reaction of moviegoers who are kinda uptight about certain films, mainly those who deal with humanistic philosophy of good and evil, like Lords of the ring, Star Wars or the Star Trek series. Probably Dungeon and dragon players too. Kinda nerd? I thought the movie was okay, not great but Burton did a good job considering he was touching sacred material (a cult film, woooow!). And I especially like the ending which was like a finger (guess which one!) pointed at those freaks who like to have an ending that answers all questions for them and let them think they are intelligent. It reminded me of the ending of Hitchcock's the Birds which still drive people mad because it doesn't explain why the Birds decided to attack. Who cares: it's a movie!!!

title: Bad taste in your mouth..
text:
It's not often that I find a movie that I literally wanted to walk out of during the film.  This movie just happens to be one of those movies.  Mark Walhberg was not the cause of this movie to stink, nor was it the acting in general.  I liked the acting and the special effects.  However, the story and script should never had made it past the producers.  In fact, I am surprised the ink in the pen wanted to write it out.  This whole story does nothing but tarnish the original movies good name.  I literally, as soon as I left the cinema went and rented the original Planet of the Apes to wash the bad taste this one left in my mouth.Let's compare the new movie to the old;Actors: Charlton Heston & Mark WalhbergWhile Hestons brand of acting may not appeal to all, it IS brilliant acting. Mark Walhberg is an up and coming star, this is true, but for him to rise to the level that Heston sits upon, Mark is going to have to start looking for some seriously good scripts and take some more acting lessons, maybe even from Heston himself.  ADVANTAGE: OriginalSupporting Ape Cast Old & Supporting Ape Cast NewApes are Apes but there are aspects from both the new and old films that I liked.  The Original movie had Dr.Zira and Dr.Cornelius and who could forget Dr.Zaius, who were all pretty great characters which added a lot of character interaction and development for Hestons character(Taylor). While the new movie has Ari? An Ape with a serious case of the hots for Walhbergs character(Leo).  ADVANTAGE: OriginalSupporting Human Cast Old & Supporting Human Cast NewBased on the fact that the original only had Linda Harrison as Nova, I have to give the advantage for this class to the new movie.  ADVANTAGE: New MovieSpecial Effects:While the old has some fantastic sites where they shot the film, we do have to give the new movie the advantage in the special effects department. The only thing I really did not like where the Gorillas that were leaping distances of 30 or so feet.  Advantage: New MovieStory:Well this is the big kahuna.  The old movie had an amazing script.  The new movie was geared too much towards quick action where the old movie was a lot of character development with enough action to keep it interesting.  After watching the new movie there were definite aspects that I really would have liked to see in the old movie.  Such as the fact that the Apes were using primitive weaponry.  Makes sense.  Also they lived in the trees, again.. makes sense.   I was very dissappointed when the humans in the new movie opened their mouths and could speak perfect english.  WOW, it's actually very  difficult to see, at least in my point of view, how the apes could regard humans, that can speak just as eloquent english as they.. AS SAVAGES. Or question whether or not they have souls??  Hello?!?!  I thought the whole reason they were "savages" was because they could not be taught, were stupid and were almost neanderthalic in behavior.  What I saw in the new movie was an excuse to have at least a few more characters for Walhberg to talk to since they did not have the character interacton with the Apes. I liked the idea or Thade.. but he was just a tad bit too insane for my liking, then again, maybe there just wasn't enough character developement for me to like him.  Overall.. ADVANTAGE: Original
In short, this movie is a waste of time, don't see it, don't rent it, don't buy it.  I give it 4 thumbs down

title: What the hell?!
text: Well, this film is Planet of the Apes in name alone.  Well, and the fact that it's about a Planet.  With Apes on it.  For anyone who has read the book, the original book, you'll know what I mean.  It bares no relation whatsoever to the original premise.  The humans talk (wtf?) and the apes appear to have evolved from genetically modified chimps in a few thousand years (yes, all of them.  Including the Orangs and Gorillas.  There are two types of chimp too).  The defined political structure has also been chucked out the window.  And the ending?  What the hell is that meant to be?Anyway, if you haven't seen the originals (been on Soror for 100 years or something) and haven't read the book, then you might as well see this.  The acting is good, and it's semi decent if you don't care about the original stuff.  There are some good moments and nice SFX.  But, it's tripe.  Next thing you know there will be a Star Wars film set in 1960's Chicago...

title: OMG!!!! What a load of crap!
text: I am 54 years old. I watched Planet of the Apes when it was in the theaters. The original of course. I was 10 the first time I saw it. I watched it a number of times in my life and it always was fascinating to me.This....I just don't know how to describe it. It has nothing to do with the original story. This Tim what's his name seems to think that because he directed a few notable films (never liked him by the way) that he has the right to basically.... well, rewrite the Bible! The film has no plot, no character development, no direction. It's just a simple fill in the screen for two hours of monkey business. NONSENSE! My apologies to this current generation. Please do not rate the Planet of the Apes story on this (cough, cough) film. As backwards as it might seem, watch the originals. Yea, I know that films that old may not appeal to this age of film making, but watch it as a history lesson in film then. You will not be disappointed.I will, however, say that The Rise of the Planet of the Apes film is a great movie. I hope one day that a REAL director will produce a faithful rendition extrapolating from this film. One can only hope.Please, please, please, please. DO NOT WATCH THIS FILM FOR YOUR OWN SAKE.

title: A wasted opportunity
text: My expectations prior to this film were high. Being a big fan of the original film I hoped that this new version would come some way near its excellence. In my opinion it came nowhere near. Many key elements of the original were changed, but why? To cater for today's audiences? So as not to be accused of copying the original? If Tim Burton or anyone else could make a decent copy of the original that would be great. Why were all the humans able to speak? The actors who played humans didn't even have anything decent to say so it would have been preferable to have had them mute. Yeah the script was that bad and surely the muteness was an integral part of the original. The film had some 'to be expected' special effects but no substance while the original had very little in the way of special effects and so much more substance. It seems that Tim Burton used the cover of special effects (like so many other film directors these days) to hide a poor script. There are many other aspects of the film which I could comment on but I don't want to give any of the plot away so I'll refrain. I suppose you must expect a remake to be of inferior quality, you only need to look at the vast majority of remakes to know this. This film, unlike its predecessor, will not stand the test of time. Hire out the original and enjoy.

title: A Refreshing look on a classic.
text: Planet of the Apes could perfectly be a part of the selected group of good remakes. This group of films could include movies such a The Fly, The Thing, and some others. The criteria to be a part of this selection would be that every new remake should try to take distance from the seminal classics. Those old and dear movies are classics, there's no sense in make the same movie using the same script and so. If there's any need of release a remake it is necessary a new take on the same tale.Tim Burton has done just that with his version of Planet of the Apes, and also has made the whole myth of this saga his own. Leo Davidson is a hard action astronaut but still he's very innocent just like many of the heroes of Burton. And these Apes who are a distorted image of us as society (greedy, intolerant). The special apes that don't follow these ideologies are the good sensitive beings. I think this is probably one of the most important messages in every good movie of Tim Burton, the special outsider view of the artist in a world who's not sensitive.Owning an amazing design of make-up, scenarios, and lots of practical FX, P.O.A is honest to the old fashion style of Sci-Fi .This is the remake that the seminal classic of 1968 deserves. A great cast of actor and actresses is here and they deliver over the top performances even wearing pound of Makeup! This new version pays homage to the first Planet from the first minute to the last. It deserves an absolute 10.

title: planet of the apes
text: Lets start with that tim burton isnt right director for this kind of films and his directing and how he overall made a film didnt worked very well,this film however has a nice cast who did a good job considering with what they had to work with,only wahlberg even in his younger age wasnt so good actor and his deliveries wasnt able to competite to much better actors in film,action was in some moments solid but seconds after it become cheesy and poorly choreographed and without skills to direct a good fight sequance,this film is one of weakest of the franchise that only made a one great film

title: Couple of Monkeys have been written this to
text: This is bad, I cant even find one part in this movie that I actually liked , I think its stupid mostly , it was also only one female monkey and she had makeup ,,, come on.

title: WOW! I hated this piece of garbage more than Pearl Harbor.
text: I was vomiting for a week after seeing this "movie".  I love the original Planet Of The Apes.  But Jesus H. Christ why would you ruin a classic with this? Mark "Marky Mark" Wahlberg reprises his role once again as doing something he sucks at but getting a lot of money for it.Tim Burton, tisk freakin tisk, someone should be homeless for what they did to a classic.  Maybe we should let doctor Zaius kick your ass, and I would help.Well, altogether it was a waste of time 1/10

title: Underrated and overhated
text: In prep for our viewing of "Kingdom", I did a COMPLETE Apes marathon! I hadn't seen all of them before, and it felt like the appropriate time. And coming to the Tim Burton entry, I was excited! I loved this movie as a kid, and you know what...I STILL love it! I sincerely CANNOT understand why everyone hates on this movie so much! I don't think it's perfect or anything, like, I feel Mark Wahlberg is a bit miscast here (even though I'm still a big fan of his work). This film had some really cool ideas, that they were, unfortunately, never allowed to explore/expand. I feel that if we had gotten a sequel to this one, perhaps explaining that ending a bit, this film maybe looked at a bit differently...IDK. The makeup is impressive, the performances (for the most part, again, still not the biggest fan of early Wahlberg here) and the score...OMG, Danny Elfman's score here's one my favorites of his! I have ALWAYS loved this movie, and know that I'm older, I appreciate it even more; bummed out that we never got the follow-up to it. Give it try, you just might realize it's definitely not nearly as bad as some may claim!

title: I liked it
text: I think there are more than enough plus points in POTA to make it well worth watching. Firstly I think the make-up of the apes and the way they move is outstanding, the whole look of the film is excellent. The music by Danny Elfman is great. Tim Burton does a great job directing the action. I thought all the actors were great, apart from Wahlberg who I find a little wooden, I thought the same about him in The Italian Job but he's not that bad. Tim Roth is the best and makes a great villain, one of his best performances since Rob Roy I feel. I'm actually surprised how many of the IMDB users seem to hate this film, probably because the ending doesn't seem to make sense. I too found the ending baffling but I enjoyed the ride in getting there. I must say It took me a long time to get round to seeing this movie, I eventually picked it up very cheaply in a supermarket and I'm glad I bought it. Sadly I think the overall reaction to this film has killed any chances there were of there being a Planet of the Apes II. Pity because I would have loved to have to seen how they would have tried to explain the ending. Also I must say I enjoyed this Tim Burton film a lot more than some of his others namely Batman Returns and Mars Attacks, I think he delivered a great movie here. Oh well each to their own ***7/10***

title: disappointing
text:
i've never watched the original POTA, and never read anything about this movie except the outline (man stranded on a planet inhabited by apes). so you can say i started off fresh, without any forethoughts or good/bad expectations.. and after watching it, i'm quite disappointed.
the movie was very low on character developments, i can hardly remember any names save Leo, the main hero, and some 2-3 more. one thing that bugs me a lot is the female apes. the way they're portrayed is simply.. disturbing.. i dunno maybe it's just me. and the human blonde babe! she's obviously being paid for simply walking around in that jungle outfit and looking worried (and pretty at the same time). she's hot, though. and mark wahlberg is just plain bad here. i like him in some other movies like three kings, but here he just dont have that hero feel.the script needed a lot of work, with lots of plot holes (why did/didn't he do this?/ why does this happen when that doesn't?). but while everyone bitches about the ending, i kinda like it, as it finally grabbed my attention, there, right at the end of the flick.disappointing movie, really.

title: Wasn't as bad as most say, 10/10 for costume /makeup
text: This movie may lack on having a better story, but it still have a good story (but post-credit scene could have been good if it was followed with a sequel, but because it didn't happen, post-credit scene is now a sore for this film). But costume and make up and acting is 10/10. I believe even today it beats CGI ape-pination, and acting as apes by those actors was top notch, because it was civilized and humanized apes which in my opinion makes it true to the picture of the film. They are not too ape-ish and not too human-ish. If the movie was a bit longer and there's was a bigger human vs ape story in the planet of the apes, it may have been a big hit. But it is still a really good Planet of the Apes film. It just that expectations was too high for such a big franchise. I believe it was we'll done by Tim Burton and His Film Crew.

title: 2 out of 10
text: It was late on Friday evening and I was tired, probably too tired to get up after 30 minutes of the film and turn the DVD player off. The story is not much, really, and neither is the acting. Wahlberg has none of the charisma necessary to play a hero. Finally, the ending of the movie is the worst one can think of, defying all logic.

title: Please leave classics alone!!!
text: This movie(if you want to call it that) was a complete debacle!!! I really wish that people would leave the classics alone and come up with new ideas. It is impossible to try to capture the feel of the original movie, even with modern CG effects. Then to add insult to injury the producer even went as far as to re-write the movie to their liking! The only place this should have been seen was on the cutting room floor, and that is even being nice! To the Producer... please... if you want to remake a movie... please choose something that you have a chance at making better instead of ruining classics that will be around longer than you will! What a legacy for you to leave... I destroyed a classic!

title: Disappointed?? Oh yes!!!
text: I've never seen the original Planet of the Apes, so I went into this movie cold.  I had no expectations other than what I've seen on the previews, and Tim Burton's reputation.  The only thing I really liked about this film was the make-up effects (except for Helena Bonham Carter's make-up.  She looked more like Michael Jackson than a "lower" primate).   ... And, I would have changed the ending.  I hate it when movies go for the obvious sequel ending.

title: Weak
text: Remakes are a hazardous business. Shown not least by all the completely wasted remakes floating around out there. And it seems remakes are all the rage today, considering how many movies are actually based on previous works. Right now the Asian industry is the one being plagued the worst by this trend.When it comes to unnecessary remakes i would have to rate this 2001 remake of the classic "Planet of the apes" as one of the foremost. This version of the movie is not without it's qualities, but in general it's a step down from the original in many ways. The social pathos is more or less completely removed, replaced instead with a focus on action and comedy. While the original movie commented on segregation in society and the arbitrary treatment of certain groups as lower standing, this movie doesn't deal with the themes at all. Of course there is a general discussion going on through the movie, and a tension between liberal and conservative powers, but it never feels like more than window dressing.The qualities here lie mostly in the sure-handed visual style that is director Tim Burtons hallmark. The effects as well as the set designs are top notch, as is the sound and music. The acting leaves a mixed impression. Tim Roth is quite astounding as the evil ape commander Thade, Mark Wahlberg is his usual pale self as the protagonist. The acting from the rest of the cast is decent enough.The qualities of this remake fall tragically short of making up for it's weaknesses. I feel that a remake should always have something new to offer if there is to be a point in remaking a movie in the first place. Not only does this movie have nothing new to offer, it even deducts many of the points of the original. And that makes this one of the most pointless, and even degrading, remakes ever. I rate it 3/10 for the entertainment it still provides despite it's obvious weaknesses as a remake.

title: Waste of apes
text: A planet full of nasty apes is a great idea. Someday somebody will make a great movie about it. Until then you'll have to watch this one:Wahlberg is lost on a strange planet and who of all people does he encounter? Kris Kristofferson! Complete with his groomed beard portraying some kind of a caveman. One wonders why he isn't wearing cowboy hat and boots. Then we have little Tim Roth as a British(?) chimp. Burton orders: "You're a chimp! Act like one! Make at least 10 grimaces a second!" And Roth obeys. He is the bad chimp, so he tries to look really mean, but doesn't. Roth also hops around a lot. It's real method acting, you know. As if the bad apes aren't, well, "bad" enough, there are also "good" apes, who talk like liberals, so the kids who watch this mess hopefully will turn out as "good" citizens one day. Of course they won't listen to the drivel of the good apes. It's too boring. Talking of boring: Wahlberg gets captured by the bad apes in a boring way and soon escapes in a boring way. Then he's on the run and has to talk a lot to the other humans and a female chimp (Carter) which has the desire to be just as smart as him. Sometimes we see Roth the chimp, who wants Wahlberg back. he gives orders to his favorite gorilla, then hops out of frame for the most time. At the end he and a lot of other apes get whacked in the head by Wahlberg and his feel-good-posse. Some big apes roll around on the floor in deadly combat. The final duel belongs to Wahlberg and Roth the little chimp, which leaves the monkey completely bonkers. Finally a real chimp saves the day and shows Roth and the others how to act. Obviously Burton had no influence on the animal. The last minutes gives us a tiny impression what this remake maybe should have been about, would it have been made by a director with a vision.

title: Um, it looks really cool, but...
text: Looks great! Less filling! Costumes, makeup, sets, direction, acting, all were adequate or better for a sci-fi action flick. I liked how the apes were more apelike than in the original. But the writing...Almost all the tension of the original was missing. About twenty minutes in the story arc was readily apparent, I figured out the time loop, and started to predict just about every major plot point before it happened.Then, there was the ending. At least what had come before had mostly made sense (allowing for some real puzzles, like why was a research ship obviously not built to land carrying horses?). In the original POTA, the ending not only managed to answer all the questions the rest the film posed while remaining completely consistent to the rest of the story, it was surprising because it wasn't an answer you expected. With this one the ending is unnecessary, as the story loop is already complete; totally inconsistent with the plot; and surprising only because it is so completely illogical. For me, the ending knocked a 'six' (mindless fun) down to a 'four' (just mindless).  With no reasonable expectation of a successful return to his own time (not to mention, no way of getting back to Earth with only a service pod) he should've just stayed there. Human/Ape society, and this movie, would've been the better for it.

title: Awful
text: 2 great movies from my youth have been remade into more modern versions and both are horrible. First is Poseidon adventure. Second is this Planet of the Apes remake. Its almost like Burton went out of his way to make a totally bad movie from the original. Just making the humans able to speak in this newer version was a major mistake. Not to mention almost every actor in this movie is miscast. Giamatti had to go out and make a movie like Sideways after this bomb. If they are going to make another movie in this series, maybe make one in the period between Beneath the Planet of the apes and Escape when the 3 apes go back to modern times. Curious how they manage to fly back when from what i remember, Heston's space craft sank and the one Brent used was pretty much blown up. Either way, a bad remake. Message to Hollywood - stop making remakes, aren't there enough good scripts available over there.

title: Loved it! Underrated
text: Tim Burton remake of Planet Of The Apes is underrated. No deep message like most of the franchise but the comic relief gives some breath. The acting, Human eyes underneath it all makes it more real for me. Ending people cry about was a nice twist.

title: should be called Planet of the Pants
text: A horrid, hateful, hash of a movie. A totally needless exercise. What is the point of remaking a perfectly good film made less than 30 odd years ago? Put simply, it's because Hollywood has run out of ideas. Why waste effort trying to create something new when it can simply rehash superb older movies and create garbage.For all you people out there who've never seen the original I urge you to. It's a wonderful and powerful film with a truly exciting and surprising ending, which if you don't know will come as a startling shock.I saw this 2001 abomination when it first opened I was hoping that perhaps Burton might be able to do something with it - sadly, Burton did. He took a fantastic film and turned it into a turkey, filling it with tedium, nonsense, overblown effects and Walhberg. It's so obviously a film made by committee - 'we can't have the humans silent! We need a sexy, strong female freedom fighter, we need massive war! We need sexy female apes! And we need to out-shock the original film's ending with an ending so shocking, the audience will leave their seats shocked by the shocking revelation of it all!' Boy, was I shocked.There's so much wrong with this film I'm not going to even try.Don't waste your time with this, don't waste your money.It was shown on TV recently and I thought I'd give it another go and work out when it goes off the rails. Actually it's not difficult to spot. It's happens just after the main credits have finished rolling.I'm surprised the entire film isn't just listed in the goof list.Goof - the entire film.Avoid and save a precious couple of hours of your life. Because when you're lying on your death bed wishing you had a few more hours of life left, you're gonna wish you hadn't wasted them with this trash. I know I am.

title: Would the real planet of apes please stand up? (it aint this one)
text: Not good! Rent or buy the original! Watch this only if someone has a gun to your head and then....maybe.It is like claiming an Elvis actor is as good as the real King.

title: Pathetic.
text: Being a big fan of the "other" PLANET OF THE APES films, I rented this DVD despite my aversion to all things Tim Burton.  Once again, he doesn't fail to disappoint with his uninspired direction.  Even the ape makeup looks second rate, which is unforgivable considering the monstrous budget of this monstrosity.  Mark Wahlberg proves once and for all that he is not an actor (as if BOOGIE NIGHTS wasn't proof enough).  I was embarrassed for genuine talents such as Tim Roth and Helena Bonham Carter.  No doubt their paychecks motivated them since it couldn't possibly have been the cliche-ridden screenplay.  I rented this DVD on a special $1 night and I still feel ripped off.

title: Great New Visualisation of the "Planet of the Apes" Idea
text: As a fan of the original Planet of the Apes movies, I really enjoyed this new motion picture.Normally, remakes suffer from the fact that they are just copies of the original movie, mostly without the excitement or fun of it.Planet of the Apes is a new attempt to use the idea behind Planet of the Apes. Thus, it is worth to be seen even by die-hard fans of the original movies.Mark Wahlberg can never match the quality of Charlton Heston, and was probably not a good choice, but the Apes are even more realistic and differentiated than in the old movies, as far as their characters are concerned. The girl which was Nova in the 1968 movie is also much more intelligent and has more to offer than just to look good.All the cruelty of manhood is being shown to as like in a fable on the example of the monkeys - sorry, apes! This content alone makes it really hard to create a bad movie upon it.Planet of the Apes (2001) is really worth the money, it has impressive shots to offer, a smooth storyline, interesting characters and an idea which should make us think about ourselves and our history.Only the end is really poor and doesn't fit the rest of the movie. It looks as if this was only added to ensure future sequels. It is very primitive and doesn't match the quality of the actual movie.

title: Unwatchable.
text: I loved most of the original movies. Heck, I loved the tv show too. I didn't read any reviews of this, and bought it on DVD because, heck, its Planet of the Apes, and made by (iffy) director Tim Burton.I turned it off about halfway through. I don't care how many DVD gimmicks are on the disk, it will never get near my player again.Boooooo!

title: A loser
text: Sure proof of the coming idiocracy was this pointless, pathetic remake and the fact that it has a rating higher than 2 stars.The title should be changed from "The Planet of the Apes" to "The Planet of Tim Burton Collecting a Paycheck."I am stunned that so many reviewers focus on the mindless ending to this movie, when the entire movie is mindless.One gets the impression that the scriptwriters were writing under deadline duress, panicked, and decided to do drugs instead. Meanwhile, if you watch the behind the scenes making of this film, you also get the distinct impression that Tim Burton knew the script was crap and so he gave up on it and treated it like a joke that he was getting big bucks for delivering. Which it is.But having said all that, I have a suggestion for a sequel. In the sequel, Wahlberg, Roth, Helena Bonham Carter, Burton play themselves. They all get into a spaceship and try to go back in time to change the future where no remake of the Planet of the Apes will appear on their resume. After 2 1/2 hours of mindless hijinks and special effects, they emerge in modern day to find they didn't change a thing, because as Alec Baldwin's character states so glibly in Glengarry Glen Ross: "a loser is a loser!"And anyone who read the script for this film and didn't walk away was -at least in this instance - a loser.

title: Planet of the Mopes.
text: One word comes to mind: Stinker! I waited thirty years for this freak show. Numbingly disappointing. A gargantuan gas bag of celluloid claptrap. Tim Burton's dreadful spin on a four-star classic renders off a slickly produced, but lethal aroma of a movie, that, when looked at closely, would have even the gorillas at the Bronx Zoo scratching their heads in disbelief. Burton's big mistake (I think) was creating a different, unfamiliar ape universe from the previous series. Strangely, I believe the film he achieved in remaking here was the Wizard of the Oz. Mark Walberg, the lead, is no Charlton Heston. He's too short and grim. Someone needed to tell him to lighten up. He spends the entire film behaving like "Dorothy." I know. I know. He wishes to go home despite meeting two potential love connections--one human, one ape. AND he starts a global civil war for good measure. Nice fellow. He mopes around the planet like some kind of self-centered jerk. Tim Roth's character is the worst kind of evil: boring. He jumps around the cheap sets as if he was suffering from a terminal case of ants-in-his-pants. I did, however, enjoy Danny Elfman's pulsating score. And Rick Baker's make-up for the apes deserved more recognition and some awards. Also, I felt the Christo-like red tents, that the ape army used on their march across the wasteland, were beautiful and abstract. There are occasional stabs at social commentary--but they fall flat. Rod Serling and Pierre Boulle must be turning over in their graves.

title: Excellent remake!
text: Some fans of the original will complain that it's so different, but in this case that's a strength.  Planet of the Apes was always one of my favorite movies and this one is even better.  It has a deeper story line and when you leave the theater, you're still trying to figure out the end.  I went with 3 other people and we all had different interpretations.  It was exciting, intelligent, emotional and the make-up was outstanding.  The soundtrack was fantastic too.  Very Tim Burton.

title: Box-Office Hit, Artistical Flop.
text: I can't understand why so famous and really talented director as Tim Burton can take so obviously poor screenplay and made this rubbish!Hey! It's not much better then BATTLEFIELD EARTH! Sometimes I thought it was directed by Ed Wood, but with mega-budget.Great make-up, and really evil Tim Roth can't save movie where we have no Tim Burton's style, indifferent Mark Whalberg in title role, terrible plot holes and, at last, silly finale.I was very, very disappointed! Rating 3/10.

title: Not good
text: Very bad. First of all, Mark Wahlberg phoned this one in, and I can't blame him. His character never showed any real concern with the plot, his only concern was to get back to his ship. That is fine, but when the storyline (macro level -ape vs man, micro level the humans on this planets apparent desire to rebel against the apes) hinges on the hope that he will- he is the humans savior. He doesn't care, and any effort to care seems half hearted at best. The writing is terrible, wasteful and at times just stolen and ba****dized. If we aren't supposed to compare this movie to the original, then why did they steal superb lines from the original and force them into this one? Early in the movie, on the spacestation, one of the scientists tells Wahlbergs character that the female apes are the aggressive ones. I thought at that point there would be a female general on the planet of the apes. Was there? No. Did that line ever come into play? No. So why have it in the movie? It didn't further the plot, it wasn't funny, it wasn't interesting, it provided nothing at all. Is this nit picking? Perhaps, but it just goes to show how unattached the people making this movie(and films in general) are to the point of cinema. Shakespeare never wasted a word, and here these people are, using millions of dollars to produce a story and they can't even get a quality script written. All this movie is a chase scene, but the end of the battle scene is ridiculous, the only way the writers could save their hero, and the apparent peace that arises between man and ape is forced because no real discussion of the topic occurs. The ending makes no sense, only cents- it is the launching pad for a sequel to try to explain what the hell happened. I'll only touch on the awful directing (hey Burton- why does everything important have to happen when it is dark) and the complete lack of attention to detail (Estella Warren's character was supposed to be the love interest- but the female ape and wahlberg had more chemistry, ape costumes looked just like ape costumes.) Did anyone else notice that at the bottom of the lake in which Marky Marks spaceship crashed was brighter than the dark jungle in which he crashed? Do the fish in that pond have lightbulbs? This movie was the pits- and if fits right in with the rest of the garbage I've seen this year.

title: Burton's Movie Lacks Innovation, Is Disappointing
text: Tim Burton has proven to be a director with vision.  Many of his previous movies broke new ground artistically, like Beetlejuice, The Nightmare Before Christmas and Ed Wood.  They were wildly imaginative, visually intriguing and entertaining.  That is why I was so excited to learn that Burton was directing Planet of the Apes.  I expected him to take the classic Apes from the 60's and give it his own Burtonesque twist.  I expected ingenuity and to be immersed into a weird futuristic ape world.  What I got was a modern-day Hollywood formula movie.  It is as if all the creativity and intrigue of the original had been beaten out of the film.You know the story.  An astronaut crash-lands onto a strange planet ruled by primates.  Humans are on the planet too, but the humans are considered `animals' and are treated as slave labor.  The biggest problem with Planet of the Apes (2001) is that it is simply not captivating.  There is no discernable plot, except that the astronaut wants to get back to his mother ship, and the apes want to make him their slave (or kill him.)  And while other `slice of life' films may not need a plot to succeed, sci-fi epics do. There is nothing compelling here to move the action and characters (and us) forward.  The result is . . . boredom.  Burton's job at a minimum with this film was to entertain us.  He fell far short.Mark Wahlberg plays astronaut Captain Leo Davidson in a performance that is largely inconsequential.  Helena Bonham Carter is Ari, a female ape (and unspoken love interest) who cares about the plight of the humans. Carter's performance is measured and effective.  Tim Roth portrays Thade, the leader of the ape army.  Roth is a fine actor whose performance here is at times captivating, and at other times one-dimensional.  The actors who play the humans, Kris Kristofferson and Estella Warren, are almost as unimportant as Wahlberg.  I liked the original movie better when the humans just grunted. Also, Charleston Heston even shows up in disguise to waste away a scene with us.To be fair, the makeup and special effects in Planet of the Apes are well done.  The costumes and sets are all good, if not too dark (but the art direction is disappointing when compared with Burton's previous works).  The music, by Danny Elfman, is great, if not distracting.The film's final scene, which I will not give away, has been deemed by some as clever or cool.  I think not.  Imagine if you will, what closing visual would be as evocative as the Statue of Liberty scene in the original movie? I guarantee that if you allow your mind to wander, you will guess it. That's not innovation, that's more of the same from Hollywood.  What happened Tim?

title: Apes Rule
text: Planet of the Apes (2001)This movie was terrific and had non-stop action from beginning to end. The scenery was very beautiful, the photography...breathtaking; the lush forest, the expansive wasteland, the dark brutish city.Leo Davidson  (Mark Wahlberg) is a flyer for the Air Force on a floating base in space itching to fly out of there into the deep and do his job.  But instead they send the genetically altered monkeys, just like canaries into a mine.Well Leo's furry fellow astronaut is in trouble out in space and Leo goes out there to bring him and the flying pod back in an unauthorized rescue mission. And as you can probably guess, from there things take an unexpected turn. Crashing into a simian world Leo has to fight the persistent General Thade (Tim Roth) and his army of apes.  General Thade has a merciless hatred for humans which is boundless and unexplained.  And so the story flows from one battle scene to another.The story is simple and therefore easy to understand; the battle for survival.   The battle for freedom from slavery.  The battle for dignity and self determination.The fantastically twisted ending leaves an opening for a sequel.  Usually it disappointments me when a movie leaves too many loose ends for the purpose of creating a sequel; but this is not the case here.  This movie and it's story is over and leaves an opening for (I hope) another exciting movie.`SweetVenom' Bob

title: Tim Burton's Unique Different Kind Different Version Of Planet Of The Apes Which i Thought Was Pretty Okay.
