text: Mark Whalberg Plays An Astrosnahnt Who's Space Pod Has Landed On a Deserted Apocalyptic Planet Which it Has Population Happened To Be Taking Over By Apes As He Leads a Group Of Human Fighters To Go Up Against The Apes. The Film Also Stars Michael Clarke Duncan, Tim Roth, Helena Bonham Carter, Paul Giamatti, Estella Warren, Kris Kristofferson And The Original Planet Of The Apes Star Charlton Heston. i Thought Tim Burton Did a Very interesting Take On a Planet Of The Apes And The Story To it.

title: So ditzy, even an ape-man wouldn't sit through it
text: Was this film a joke? Or did Burton lose his mind?Let's start with the few positives first: the ape characters were rendered well. The make-up, costuming, characterization, even the quadrupedal movements by some apes; excellent stuff. Bonham-Carter's work was fine, although she looks like she just had a wardrobe malfunction or something. By the way, she's in so many Burton films, you'd almost think she knows the guy. Anyway, all positives are lost amidst a big, dumb, growling, lumbering primate of a flick.Some astronaut ends up in a post-Apocolyptic world filled with evolved primates, directly adapted from the original. But, after that, the story resorts to Sunday afternoon serial tactics, and throws cerebral thought into the tar pits. A battle scene where bodies are constantly being tossed in the air: come on. The whole battle scene is just a mass of extras shouting, grunting, and slashing each other to bits. But no meaning to why it's being fought, or what the outcome means.Loud stupid, unintentionally campy. The director's paycheck was unearned. Beware the farcically moronic ending; it's so utterly ridiculous that it's sidesplitting. It's also a brazenly obvious set-up for sequels (that were never made, lol).Good to laugh at with friends.

title: Unlike the original which is good.... but...
text: but it's a very weak story with unremarkable special effects and full of gaping holes.  Which is bad.  Very very bad.I went in expecting a good movie that would live up to the name of the franchise, despite the presence of Burton in the director's chair.I cannot believe a story resembling an early draft and not much more than a comedy sketch in someone else's production would have received final approval and the go-ahead by an entire studio.When it's available on video (DVD), watch this along with the original 1968 Apes.  If you care for nothing more than MTV special effects, maybe you'll come away with a distaste for the original.  But if you value any type of consistency and plausible story, in an implausible world, then the newest Apes movie will leave you wanting a lot more.  Not even Helena Bonham Carter nor Tim Roth, both whom put forth excellent performances, could save this picture.  Paul Giamatti was brilliant - his performance might have been a little too comedic over-all, but again, that was a problem with the writing. His performance was stellar.  Mark Wahlberg has chosen far better roles in the past.Ah, Burton signs his name on another ruined production.  He certainly has earned his over-rated respect directing this type of swiss-cheesed fluff. The picture does nothing to advance the state of cinematography or story telling.  It adds an easily forgettable movie to the Apes line-up.  If nothing else, at least a sequel, with someone else handling direction, doesn't stand much chance of being any worse.POTA-2001 earns a solid (1) rating.  Wahlberg offers a one liner which would sum this picture.  I'm only paraphrasing... "you shouldn't send apes to do a man's job" - and that there points to one of the biggest holes in the entire story.  No spoilers though.  Watch it for your own opinion, but do yourselves the favor of going in expecting very little.

title: I Never Imagined It Could Be So Bad
text: Planet of the Americans - This is what happens when you take a film with substance and put it through the hollywood machine.   Buy the best special effects - the respected director - the British Act-ToRRs - the composers - the make-up and the most hyped STAR.This film was agonising to watch.  It was as though someone had fed the plot summary into an American English word processor and pressed the button "Generate Script".Classic lines such as "I'm having a bad hair day" , "C'mon Guys! Let's Go, I have an idea, We've only got one shot!" and "OK kiddies who wants some asprin"This film was Dumbed Down for its (12) rating which must surely be referring to the IQ of the writer.  So entirely predictable were the plot twists that I almost fell asleep.I give this movie Zero.

title: What was the point?
text: Until the end of the film this was an entertaining 6 out of 10.  It lost a mark at the end for leaving a bad taste in the mouth thanks to an appalling and ridiculous ending. It made no sense. Until then it was an entertaining film.  Visually amazing, the make up superb and Carter and Roth gave excellent performances. The story just never sparkled, however.  This may be connected to the fact that Walberg doesn't have much screen presence.  Comparing to Heston for a second (not just to compare to the original, but also to compare to a great leading actor), he commanded the screen, made you care what was happening and drew you into the film.  Marky Mark may know how to model underwear, but a great actor he aint.  There is something about him that made me just not care.At the end of the day, unless you've something new to say on the subject, someway to improve it beyond dated makeup, remakes are just pointless.

title: old memory
text: I am very surprised IMDb rated this movie lower than 6. I watched this movie when I was in elementary school, it was a groundbreaking setting to me back in that age. The spaceship, the monkey spaceman, and the time-traveling, and the complete developd apes society, all these settings were awesome packed. I watched it again many years later, and I had some different thoughts about the ape girl.In the movie, human girl and the human guy didn't have a happy ending, and I felt pity to the girl when I was little. However after the second watch, I felt much more touch with the Ape girl. She is a noble birth in apes planet, yet she is smart, curious and full of sympathy to human unlike other ruthless apes, they treat human as pet or slave. When she was attracted to a human, she was so brave to fight the society. I couldn't figure out this conflict when I was little, because kid only knows hero and heroine should be together. Simple left me after I grow up. Last mind of the rewatching, I would want to say, it is OK to be different because your inappropriate might be right in future. Even your love is across species. Lol.

title: Same Title, not Same Movie
text: Tim's work has been impressive, original story telling, thoughtful attention to detail.  What he has done in the past shouldn't give free reign to everything.  The love of the story of this magnitude should be respected. True Tim is Tim, the only thing that is the same between films would be the title alone.  On the note I must say that I have seen better, Helen's character could of, would of is consist of just her make-up, I could see so much more to that character.   The entire movie is based on the effects, not so much in acting.  So if you like effects, you'll love it.  Just don't expect another remake.  That is my 2 cents, but I could be wrong.

title: Started off strong, then got really bad really fast
text: This movie, especially the ending, was very poor.  It started out very promising, and I certainly enjoyed the crew seeing it's own future transmission.  After that part, though, the movie went completely downhill. Estella Warren, as far as I can tell, was in the movie solely to get young teenage boys to come out to the movie for the eye candy.  The ending was especially bad.  How does Thade exist in 2329 AND 2029.  It just doesn't make any sense, any way you slice it.  I'm also wondering if Tim Burton joined PETA just before the making of this movie, because the ethical treatment of animals message was really, really heavy-handed.

title: I fell asleep... effects without a movie!
text: while watching this piece of crap! The Day after, I saw a 1min Trailer - that one minute included all, ALL what was at least not boring to watch...so don't waste money or time on this one, get the original, it's much better though the effects might not be up to date...

title: Id' rather spend my time sleeping!
text: I'm as disapointed as can be!The worst thing about it (I have to get this out of my system!) was the awefull predictablility! I had expected at least some sort of surprise during the movie. But NO!!!Not that I wanted anything like the original, nor "The Usual Supects" or "From Dusk Till Dawn". But atleast a little surprise!Ok, I have to say the apes are excelet (though I didn't really like Thade as much as the general IMDB users)If you havent seen it, DONT go to the movies RENT IT!!! (it's not woth a trip to the cinema, but in your own couch it might be ok!)One last thing...Trailers are meant to be informative and tempting NOT revealing!!!P.S. don't mind my bad spelling, I went out and got locked after this disapointment!

title: Best movie ever
text: This best movie I watched in my life.This best movie I watched in my life.This best movie I watched in my life.

title: Why Do This
text: Tim Burton proves in this one that improving a modern sci-fi classic is nearly impossible. When remaking the 1960's classic, it created some ticket sales because of the original franchise. The trouble with this remake is that the golly-gee whiz special effects of today are put in as replacements for the original dramatic script of the past epic film.The result is definitely mixed, and skewed towards the lower end of the scale. The remake is so focused on using these new special effects, they create a new ending for this film which is truly horrible compared with the original Rod Sterling epic.The story of reverse evolution theory is classic with Ape evolving from man, and Tim Burton's legion of fans might get a kick out of this, but my take is to see the original. It tells the story better and is dominated by drama more than special effects.

title: boooo!
text: Only a couple of good things to say here. The makeup is, of course, amazing. Rick Baker deserves awards galore for his work on this film. General Thade is probably the best villain I've seen on screen since Darth Maul, but being probably the worst movie of the year, likely no credit will be given. The dialog is insipid, the acting is grade school and the action never gains momentum. What a waste of a premise. No scathing social commentary, no clever nods to the original (only a few stolen lines), no real development of any kind. Save your time and see something else.

title: what a boring movie !
text: I just wonder how is it possible to dispense so many money to make such a pour film. Except the apes everything has no interest in this movie and we can't say that it is better than the first version of 1968. Just one thing : if you want to laugh just go and see the five last minutes (I don't want to say anything more).

title: Movie of the Summer
text: This movie is by far the movie of the summer.  I didn't like the original but I loved this!  Tim Roth plays one of the best villans that I've ever seen.  This movie keeps you thinking and leaves you thinking even more after the credits. ****10 out of 10!******

title: What a waste of a good novel
text:
I saw the original and thought it was great.  This "re-imaging" was so vastly inferior to that, that it's a wonder the script ever got greenlit to begin with.  I had heard that the film was bad, but I liked the original so much I rented it when it came out on video anyway. What a mistake.I didn't simply dislike this version because I'm a fan of the original, it is truely a horrible horrible film.  The script is pathetic and the ending seems like it was made by someone under the influence of heavy narcotics who didn't care about whether it made sense or fit into the movie or not.
This film is almost ridiculously campy with the bad dialogue and lines thrown into it simply to elicit a slight grin beased on a connection from the first film.  The apes act ridiculous and you're never left with the feeling that this could actually happen given the absurd things they do. I'm surprised Burton didn't throw in a monkey car that runs on bananas or something.  There's even a little dwarf that runs around collecting money like a chimpanzee would do at the circus.  Even if they took all the "ape camp" out, it's still a pathetic movie. Mainly because of the script and the horrible directing by Burton.  The stunts look pretty bad and fake. Many things don't make sense, like why apes would ride horses if they can move faster than horses anyway.  Even Wahlberg gives a pathetic performance.The only entertainment value in this entire movie is the "funny" things that an ape society does that compare with what humans do.  The only redeeming thing about renting this trash was that it was the best sounding DVD I've ever heard, and REALLY gave my 5.1 surround system a work.  Almost worth the rent to check it out until some better DVDs come along that have sound work as good.

title: Tim How Did it All go Wrong - Stick to Gothic 'Horror'
text: Oh dear, I had such high hopes for this film.At first I was worried when I heard that 'Planet of the Apes' was to be re-made. It all seemed like a rather cheap (well not if the budget is $100m) attempt at a 'sure-fire' summer blockbuster - but on hearing that Tim Burton was to directed I began to look forward to seeing the finished product. After all wasn't this the man who had brought us Edward Scissorhands, Sleep Hollow and BeetleJuice.But after seeing the film all I can say is stick to gothic horror Tim. It doesn't engage at any a level, its not exciting, not at all interesting, predictable and worst of all the shock ending makes no real sense. It does look 'authentic' and the make-up was first class with Tim Roth and Helen Bonham Carter doing their best to kick some life in a hack script. But with little success - a dead dog (or ape in this case) is still a dead dog. One of the worst of the Summer 2001 blockbusters.

title: Full of sound, occasional fury, signifying nothing much
text: All right, I give up - why was this film ever made?I tolerated Burton's Batman and Chocolate Factory remakes, because he demonstrated real respect for the original materials - the Bob Kane comic book, the novel by Roald Dahl. But this ape film not only undercuts the original (while trying to look oh-so-much-more impressive), it also trivializes the novel by Pierre Boulle.Pierre Boulle's novel was a fable exploring the post-WWII problems of racism, nationalism, war and nuclear war. The world had already danced close to the brink of self-extermination in WWII: if we believe all the reports (and alas, there's no reason to doubt any of them), some 150 million people lost their lives during ten years of one major conflict after another, from the invasion of Manchuria and the Spanish Civil War to VJ day. That was a larger number than that of the population of the US at the time.Military-Industrial Complex profiteers notwithstanding, it became clear to intelligent people across the globe that ethnocentrism was not healthy for children and other living things, and it was a decent person's duty to say so as clearly and decisively as possible. "Planet of the Apes" may not be a great classic of literature, but it's no throwaway for a rainy day.To rip the heart and mind out of Boulle's story - well, what is the point? The world doesn't need yet another "alternate universe" comic book display of flexing ape muscle and tasteless jokes masquerading as wit. If all this is merely taking place in an "alternate universe", just so we can have a peek at a possible "alternate universe", then the "adventure" is nothing more than the protagonist's daydream.All we can do is shout "Wake up!" at protagonist and film-makers alike, and hope never to see such a self-indulgent waste of money on a theater screen again.

title: WORTH the TRIP - PRIMAL ENERGY to the MAX!
text: Whether you see movies like this one for the saga, the heroism, or the action, you won't be disappointed.Make sure you see this one in the theater first; don't wait until it comes out on video. Much of the energy and intensity is conveyed by the audio and the especially moving soundtrack. So, unless your Stereo-VCR speakers are the size of a laundry basket, and your TV screen is the size of a beach blanket, enjoy PLANET of the APES on a gorilla-size scale: Splurge for the tix & ENJOY !!

title: Not an ape,A DOG! The stench should have put an end to awful remakes forever
text: The saddest observation(s) on this lame-dog, utterly unnecessary remake are that it managed to squander the contributions of three alumni from the classic original: RICHARD ZANUCK-responsible for green-lighting the 1968 version when he headed 20th Century Fox in 1967,was also at the helm of this travesty of cinema-- it also wastes CHARLTON HESTON, the great mega-star who so effectively inhabited the character of GEORGE TAYLOR (here in ape-make up panting through a clichéd, embarrassingly written cameo/death scene), and once again poor LINDA HARRISON (Nova in the first two APES entries) is reduced to a token 3 second cameo shot,essentially lampooning her original character.This film's announcement created a huge buzz in Hollywood, and among the fan-base of the original classic APES franchise. Instead what audiences receivedwas a pathetic, unengaging,poorly executed load of overblown B.S Tim Burton seemed to very removed from his usual hands-on approach that made his best work so imaginative. The make-up is pretty well done, but unappealing and the actors sure had their work cut out for them, trying to reinvent the genius of former characterizations made by Kim Hunter, Roddy McDowall and Maurice Evans.--but all was for naught with such a lame-ass script, lead character and senseless "action".I will say that H Bonham Carter did do a respectful job at her character, and gave a noble performance. But she was conducting it aboard a sinking ship.Weeks after this 2001 version opened (to 120 MILLION dollars worth of box-office!) the tragedy of 9/11 occurred, and it was quickly forgotten-where it has remained at the very bottom of Tim Burton's resume.And judging from most every other comment on this board, the bottom of the barrell-period!It never should have been made-plain and simple

title: The Worst Tim Burton I've Seen
text: Tim Burton has made many great movies (Beetlejuice, Edward Scissorhands, Nightmare Before Christmas) but the Planet of the Apes remake was horrible. I really didn't get why he remade this movie since the first one wasn't even that good (The Simpsons musical version with Troy McClure was better).  If you've seen the original and/or any of the sequels you've seen this one. Too many corny puns in it and a lot of other things.  It barely garners what I gave it as a rating. 2/10

title: ugggghhh!!
text: Whenever I hear the name of "Tim Burton", I always cringe. Severely! I knew this movie was doomed from the word go. I could have made a better Planet of the Apes movie myself, blindfolded, with both hands tied behind my ankles. After having seen this movie I am truly convinced that for Tim Burton, Edward Scissorhands is about as good as it gets. I don't understand how the industry continues to applaud and lavish this director with accolades. He just simply isn't all that good of a director. And he proves it time and time again. I remember when this movie came out in theaters. I knew better than to waste my time or money to go see it or to even rent it on DVD later on. I just got done watching it on TV a few moments ago. It's about adequate for TV, but only just barely. However, I've seen TV shows better than this movie. So that should say something. I won't waste anymore time critiquing this movie other than just to say this: don't bother with this re-make, do yourself a big fat favor, go and rent the 1968 original instead, or better still, buy it. You'll be glad you did!

title: "Apes" will rule the week-end.
text: Went to the sneak preview on South Beach tonight (Thursday 07/26/01).  Do NOT listen to anyone reviewing this movie that tries to tell you the ending. This version remembers its earlier incarnations so the mythology continues. The special effects and music are excellent.  The story is new with plenty of original twists that make this an exciting movie to the very end.  "The Planet of the Apes" should make the dinosaurs of Jurassic Park extinct once more.  RULE THE PLANET.

title: Can you be entertained watching a terrible movie?
text: I am not quite sure how, but watching the worst movie of the summer was not a complete waste of time.  It has been a while since I saw a movie where the audience actually groaned and mocked the movie while it was playing.  The movie is so poorly written that it should have insulted each one of us watching but the Tim Burton visuals do help pass the time quickly.  We were stuck there so we made do, don't waste your money and you will be ahead of the game.

title: One of the worst remakes
text: This movie is one of the worst remakes. Although it is very spectacular, the main thought of the original story is lost in it. This thought was that the humans became animals and the apes are the superior species. Humans are not only unable to speak but even to think. They are driven by their instinct. Apes are not only able to speak and to think but they even walk righted. The only "good" thing in this film is the ending that gives back the ending of the book. Although the ending of the original movie was not bad as well. It made the possibility to make some sequence for it. This movie can not be continued (Thanks for the Lord for all the small miracles!) and has a very stupid story with a very stupid beginning. Don't waste your time, watch the original instead. 0.1 out of 10.

title: What happened to Tim Burton?
text: This is a bit of a first for me, the first time I have ever been disappointed in a Tim Burton film.  POTA isn't a bad film (great sets, costumes and the odd great performance) but it could have been made by any off-the-shelf hollywood director. The pacing was very odd, the last third was just spent waiting for the film to end, by myself and the cast.  Tim Roth was excellent, probably the only pleasure in the film.  Come back Tim.

title: A Different Planet of The Apes
text: Of course you have to compare this with the original Charlton Heston film, and I think it stands up pretty well, the storyline is a bit different, with the Apes occupying a different planet and not a future Earth, the humans can speak and the end is very different, but apart from that, it more or less runs like the original, there are even a couple of famous quotes copied from the original film, but that was a good point. Near the end, the astronaut chimp that Leo Davidson (Wahlberg) lands on the planet, days after Davidson did, but he was behind the chimp in the shuttles when leaving the spacestation, which did not ring true with the story! and the twist ending was a bit odd, but possible, the odd thing about it was the apes as 70's style over-the-top cops, I assume made intentionally like that.Mark Wahlberg plays it Ok, however he did not look too surprised to discover the apes and the fact that humans populated this new planet in a different time, also his dialogue was a bit quick at times. But apart from that it was good, The others did ok, Helena Bonham Carter was quirky, but the best was Tim Roth as General Thade, you can see he put his all into the character. Charlton Heston and Linda Harrison from the original even had cameos in this.It was made well, the Ape costumes were much better than the originals, hardly surprising. the scenes were good, and photography excellent, as were the special effects.It does not have the style of the original, so that is why I only gave it an 8 rather than 10 for that, but apart from that it is very good, apparently Tim Burton wanted longer time and more control over it, but didn't get it, if he had I think it might have been a lot better.

title: Dumb and disappointing
text: It's indicative of today's Hollywood machine, that a great story, with real bite, and genuine originality, can be so mercilessly reduced to just another action blockbuster. It's also very depressing to realise that the director responsible was once a 'maverick', with a unique take on his usual subjects, with a propensity to stay away from the commercial, and eke out the esoteric.Tim Burton's re-imagining required little imagination at all. Comparison with the original 1968 film is, obviously, unavoidable, which is as it should be. Because only with this comparison can you see what a major disappointment this version is. Practically all essence of the themes of evolution, religion, the questions of the way we treat our planet, and the way we treat each other (which are probably more pertinent in this age of genetic modification and cloning etc) are either ignored or dealt with swiftly to bring on the next set piece. Charlton Heston's spaceman has to deal with an inability to communicate with both the apes and the humans (through his lack of speech and their lack of understanding) making him an outsider from both species. We go through that wonder and frustration with him. In Burton's film there are no such devices, we are simply given the 'us and them' option, and all philosophising is glossed over in order to accommodate the next chase. Which is what this movie ultimately turns into..one chase after another. The original's council meeting is replaced with a flippant, and jokey dinner party scene. And, tellingly, there are no allusions to human experiments, instead it appears that humans are good enough as slaves and not much else. One of the many lasting images from the 1968 version is Heston's discovery of his lobotomised co-astronaut. It makes no sense that humans who can communicate with one another, and who outnumber the apes by four to one are not the ruling species. Just one of the holes in a weak and dumbed down plot.Much has been made of the ending, but here, at least, Burton has the sense to at least try something unexpected. Once again, however, he has fluffed it in order to quicken the pace. The apes seem incredibly open to the suggestion that the humans were there first, just as Leo gets over the shock of talking apes rather swiftly so, too, do these apes have an unlikely ability to accept Leo's 'understanding' and explanation of 'Calima'. Heston finding the doll in the cave at the denouement of the first movie is a revelatory moment for both audience and ape - nothing in the remake surprises us much.If you can forget the original (or if you haven't seen it), and if you can bypass the dire script, there are things to enjoy here. Although the first half is far too set bound (with some unimaginative CGI), the climactic battle scenes are very well realised. So, too, are the apes themselves, with some incredible make-up effects, and physically engaging performances (mainly by the extras!). Tim Roth injects the much needed energy in a scene-chewing, but also scene-stealing turn as General Thade, arguably the highlight of the whole picture, and Charlton Heston's cameo is good fun, the only glimpse of any humour and irony in the movie. Paul Giamati's slave trader is simply embarrassing.Major disappointment all round.

title: Boring Movie 100%
text: This movie was 100% boring, i swear i almost died from boredom at the theater. It wasnt funny and didnt really hve that much action in it either, it was BORING and i hope whoever out there that liked this movie, god be with you in the future when you find out what this movie was really like and try to jump off a bridge or something like that

title: I WANT MY TIM BURTON BACK!!!
text: The man who directed this soulless and totally unnecessary new version of Planet of the Apes cannot be the same man I have been adoring for the last 15 years. Where is the man who gave us wonderful and entirely unique movie experiences such as Edward Scissorhands, Nightmare Before Christmas and Sleepy Hollow? My theory is that he desperately wanted that his films make money again after the not-too-enthusiastically-received likes of Ed Wood and Mars Attacks, (how else can you explain his fruitless endeavour to resurrect the Superman franchise?) and after the relative success of Sleepy Hollow, he managed to gain access to Fox's resurrection of the Planet of the Apes franchise. However, I think that the studio interfered heavily with this "reimagining" of their beloved franchise and prevented him from making a usual Tim Burton film. The result is a terribly ordinary action adventure which is also an insult to the tradition of pessimistic sci-fi films that the original was so proudly part of. I cannot believe that my favourite director has his name stamped on this. I feel really deserted and I'm sure there are many Burton fans out there who feel the same way as I do. I WANT MY TIM BURTON BACK!!!

title: The Planet That Burton Built
text: I feel like I'm destroying any credibility when I say this but, despite all the negativity around this, I don't think this is awful. Let me clarify, it's not good, it's just not terrible.For starters, and really the strongest point of the movie, the apes look amazing. The acting isn't awful, and I'm not generally a Wahlberg fan. Then there's the story and all that which are mediocre at best.The problem here is that this movie has to do the Burton thing and go to the weird and bad places whenever given the chance. Put someone, anyone but Burton here and I legitimately believe this is a vastly improved movie.As it stands, this is background noise. The less you pay attention, the better. You can enjoy some great costumes and makeup, some fascinating sets and when you don't focus on it, you don't have to deal with all the crazy.

title: Planet of the Fakes
text: When I heard that Planet of the Apes was coming to theaters I was excited. I had vague memories of the T.V. show from when I was a kid, but not enough to give me any real high expectations of the movie. Now, even with no high expectations, and not knowing what the eventual outcome would be, I was still disappointed.This movie was really predicated upon action and suspense, but little other content value. The standoff at the end was OK minus the incredibly stupid and cliché stunt by the young boy. The story just lacked creativity, especially in light of my having seen the original Planet of the Apes. There was absolutely no comparison. The story, the dialogue, and even the ending was so cutting edge and socially relevant. Planet of the Apes 2001 did not do justice to its predecessor.

title: You Maniacs, You F@#$%ed it up!!! Damb you, Damb you all to Hell!!!!!!!
text: First there was New Coke 1985, Then Godzilla 1998, And now Planet of the Apes 2001. What was Tim Burton on when he was making this awful remake of the 1968 classic? Wasn't Cabin Boy,Mars Attacks & Sleepy Hollow bad enough for us movie goers? This film makes Planet of the Ape fans wanna cry! Why is it that new movies nowadays with great makeup and special effects has to have an awful plot? They just don't make them like they use to! Tim Burton obviously can't afford good movie writers. That's probably why his latest movies were so weak. Charlie and the Chocolate Factory is an exception. At least it has a lot of plot. All though I haven't seen Big Fish yet! I just hope that Corps Bride does well. Even better than James and the Giant Peach. But Planet of the Apes, Forget it! Don't waste your time for this movie. It just ain't worth it! It's not a movie you wanna go ape over.

title: Excellent, Without doubt better than the original
text: You have to go and see it! Tim Burton has out-done himself again! His Idea of what the ape world should look like is completely different, and better than the original, without doubt this movie is worth going too see. I don't really want to spoil things, just go and see the movie!

title: Terrible... just terrible
text: Many others have eloquently lent their perceptions, and I concur wholely with their assessments... and so I will hope that my brevity will not belie my reasoning as I say: this was a travesty of an idea to begin with, and Tim Burton made a mockery of an excellent film.This movie can only hope to be forgotten by the passage of time, rather than remembered for the abomination that it is. I am sure that many of the actors are thankful that their faces cannot be seen, as it perhaps spares them from the shame of being recognized on the street as having been a part of this wretched, awful, poorly-contrived movie.And I won't even begin to discuss the trite ending.Avoid this movie at all costs. Watch the original film.

title: Burton can do much better
text:
I saw the film on preview night over in the UK. Had missed much of the hype, though with it being Tim Burton, I looked forward to it. I cannot say that i was hugely disapointed, and certainly I cannot agree with much of the over-reaction of many of the reviews - it is neither wholly awful, nor is it wholly wonderful.
However, leaving the cinema, i had an rather strange feeling that I, or maybe the film/Burton had missed the point of it somewhere along the line. (I suspect it may have been the former rather than the latter,.. but i`m not so sure...) The film looked sumptious, of course. The make up, and sets have to be seen at the cinema to fully appreciate the workmanship and realism with which it is presented etc. This was ofcourse enjoyable, as indeed you would expect in return for its budget. And yet, I was still left wondering what was the point of making it - to improve it or the idea, to make a straight forward  blockbusting action film - i suspect not. I had a sense that Tim Burton had a strong mental picture of what he wanted, but was unable to reproduce it on film, and in trying to capture it, lost it completely.
Tim Burton seems to have great warmth for the original film - there are many references to the original film (some i missed, some i got), but he does not seem to have felt an equal warmth for his own film. Much of what i have been so impressed with his previous films (with the exception of Mars Attack )- the gothic, dark and eccentric caricuturations( if there is such a word !) of, I suspect his own childhood, (Batman, Edward Scissorhands, Beetlejuice and to some extent Sleepy Hollow) and the warmth in which presents them is oddly lacking here. Only in moments do you glimpse this, and sadly for the main part of the film you are unable to distinguish the films director from that of any other director- and this is a shame, he can and has done better. He calls this film an re-imagining of the original film rather than a re-make - I am hopeful that his imagination is more fertile, and i suspect that we may see a return to his more original storytelling soon.The acting is also worth noting. Much of the this is mainstream with the majority of the cast resorting to walking around bow legged (and with ill fitting underwear no doubt) to suggest a ape like gait. Mark Wahlberg doesnt seem completely at ease with leading a film yet - either that or he isnt quite the finished article. Helen Bonham Carter plays her part well, but it is Tim Roth who steals the show, with a very powerful and eye catching performance - though, it seems to me, he stole his performance ( or copied, or was inspired ) from Michael Ironside who, bar the make-up, snarls and grunts his way round every part i have seen him do in exactly the same way - I thought it was him for large parts of the film !Dont be completely put off by this review, as this is, of course only my opinion - dont wait till it comes round on video - give it a chance and with luck you will enjoy it 6/10

title: Rushed, shallow, and uninvolving
text: It's hard to talk about this movie without touching on its production history. This is a poster child for a studio using a recognizable name to hit a release date. They were going to release this in July of 2001 no matter what, and they rushed everything along. It's possible to deliver a good movie with a constantly changing script like The Great Escape, but it's more of a recipe for a mess. Tim Burton was not given any time to figure out his vision for the film, and he just filmed, at breakneck speed, a script that didn't know what it was or what it was about.Captain Leo Davidson is a pilot on a space station orbiting Saturn who's in charge of ape pilots. When an unusual electro-magnetic storm sweeps by, they send in an ape who promptly gets lost, and then Davidson jumps into a pod without orders to try and find him. He gets hit by stuff and crash lands in a forest on a new planet. Before he can settle, he's swept up in a chase of apes looking to round up humans. By the time Davidson is in a cage, being carted off to Ape City, a grand twenty minutes have passed in the film, and that's the greatest source of the movie's problems. It just simply moves too quickly, covering everything too shallowly, and more concerned with visual spectacle than actual storytelling.On the space station, we get introduced to two humans beyond Davidson, and neither of them matter once he's off the station. On the planet, we get views of about half a dozen humans who are going to tag along with Davidson through the end of the film and they never make any sort of impression. The apes do a better job, though. There's Thade, an ape general and the chief protagonist, and Ari, the human rights loving daughter of a senator. The thing is that this movie feels like their story, but they don't get introduced until the half hour point and they are very much not the focus. Davidson never gets any sort of emotional connection to anything on this planet, insisting on just getting off as soon as possible. So, our main character is a vessel obsessed with a single object and refuses any emotional attachments, while two of our supporting characters have the actual emotional support but are so far pushed into the background that every moment feels like it comes out of nowhere.Davidson escapes, brings along his human companions and Ari, picks up the slave trader, Limbo, who had bought the humans from the military (whose only purpose seems to be picking up humans in forests), and they walk into the Forbidden Area. Meanwhile, Thade visits his father in the one scene that probably exemplifies everything wrong with this movie in microcosm.So, Thade's father is played by Charlton Heston, proving that he's a great actor even under fantastic ape makeup. In this scene, we get introduced to a character who's never been seen before and gets discarded by the end, an object of great value we've never seen before and gets destroyed by the end in what's supposed to be a great dramatic moment, and callbacks to the original movie that end up falling flat. There's no setup to anything that happens in this scene. It all just happens in quick succession, and none of it impacts with any emotion. It's a dead scene that's supposed to be full of meaning and winks to the audience that end up working against it. Much like the rest of the movie.The thing about callbacks is that they are jokey by nature. It's hard to make a callback of something extremely well known work dramatically because we all have the, "I know that reference," reaction that undermines the dramatic import of the moment. So, when Attar looks down at Davidson and says, "Take your stinking hands off me, you damn dirty human," the audience is chuckling instead of feeling any kind of fear. When Charlton Heston says, "Damn them...damn them all to hell!" we have the same kind of guffaw instead of any other emotion at the death of a character, who we haven't seen before this very scene.I'm not sure when it became de rigueur for pretty much every action/adventure movie of a certain budget to end with a battle scene against two armies, but Planet of the Apes is one of the most ridiculous of them. An army showing up out of nowhere in the minutes before the battle, flying apes with super jump abilities, and the death of side characters with dramatic feel that fall flat is how this whole thing works out. It's bizarre and it betrays the fact that no one understood where the dramatic core of this movie was.There are no ideas at play in this film. It's just a bunch of people running around for two hours without ever giving the audience any time to think about any ideas or characters or even setting.I've avoided talking about the original because this re-imagining of the idea works so poorly on its own that there's really no need for comparison, but I do think that a comparison is justified in order to help explain why the 2001 version fails so badly. Just look at the first half hour of each of them. In the original, we get a very clear idea of who our main character, Taylor, is and what he believes. We get a steady build on the setting of this new world that comes to a shock at the sight of apes riding horses. In the re-imagining, we have a bevy of characters running around talking in inanities that don't matter, special effects, and then an action scene without ever getting to know anything about our main character, Davidson, other than that he loves his ape and wants to get it back. It's thin at its absolute best, and that's not very good.This was Tim Burton's lowest point, but because of studio pressure on the production timeline, it could be excused to a certain extent. However, he went on to make Alice in Wonderland, so we all know that he had further depths to explore. This is a prime example of how not to reboot a moribund franchise. But, the ape makeup is absolutely fantastic, the movie looks pretty good most of the time, and this might be my favorite Danny Elfman score. So, it has that going for it.

title: Just Not the Same Without Charlton Heston in a Loincloth
text: Tim Burton takes a disappointingly literal approach to remaking the 1968 cult classic, and what he gives us is an undistinguished action film, not necessarily worse than any number of action films produced in a given year, but so much worse than it could have been given the source material and Burton's fierce imagination.Tim Roth is the standout among the simian characters -- he actually scared the crap out of me. The shock ending to the original was so well known that Burton knew he had to come up with something different, and to tell you the truth I can't even remember what it was; that might give you an indication as to how effective it was.The opening credit sequence is this film's high point, and it all goes downhill from there.Grade: C

title: Nice plastic suits - shame about the rest
text: Tim Roth seemed a bit apologetic at the Edinburgh Film Festival premiere of this movie `It's just a bit of fun . . . treat it as a bit of fun' he kept saying. Well Tim, get a family of four together with nowt to do on a Saturday afternoon and it might be a bit of fun. Gather several hundred film addicts together for the surprise movie of the festival and expecting the same reception is a bit much (especially when they could see it at half the price the next day when it went on general release). The costumes are very good: technology and makeup has come a long way since the first cult movie classic of the same name. Unfortunately script seems to have gone backwards. The movie starts promisingly enough with a space station time-slip introduction. But having gone to enormous lengths to create the situation and life-like apes, the whole thing is ruined by resting on awful dialogue and corny 20th century jokes that are guaranteed to avert any suspension of disbelief. These super-intelligent apes toy with humans that they capture and one can't help feeling the filmmaker is toying with the audience too. One is reminded of Director Tim Burton's reputed comment that he only wanted to make movies in order to make money. If he has shown great originality and creativity in recent films to suggest he didn't mean that, this film, on the other hand, simply looks like little more than one narrow filmmaker's dream come true again . . .

title: not as good as the original
text: The `reimagined' version of this story pays due homage to the 1968 classic (at the time of its release the biggest sci-fi film yet made) while retaining Burton's unique flavor and comic book atmosphere.  But comparing this to the original is like comparing Li'l Debbie snacks to Hostess-a little more style but a lot less tasty saturated fat.  Wahlberg stars as Air Force cadet Leo Davidson, stranded on a strange planet after flying recklessly into a cosmic anomaly (I believe the proper sci-fi CYA term is `a rift in the space-time continuum').  After Davidson finds the planet ruled by simians who keep humans as slaves he escapes from their clutches, finds a few sympathetic monkeys, and sets off across the country to find his ship and get back home.  The group runs into a little trouble finding any crewmates, but what they do find is the truth behind the planet's origins in a finale not nearly as fun or coherent as the original film's surprise ending.Putting plot issues aside for a moment, what you'll like about the film are the ape actors.  Tim Roth hams it up wonderfully as the ruthless ape leader Thade, even if his performance leans a little too heavily on the snarl and glare department.  Helena Bonham Carter is bewitching as Ari, an upper-class liberal ape who even manages to flirt convincingly with Davidson on their journey together. Paul Giamatti is actually funny as the orangutan slave-trader Limbo, rather than the usual obnoxious comic relief fare.  And Michael Clarke Duncan and Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa are excellent as Attar and Krull, two old war comrades who have now found themselves on opposite sides of the battlefield.  Unfortunately, the human counterparts in the film are much less impressive.  Kris Kristofferson steps in and out, stopping briefly to perhaps pick up his paycheck.  Estella Warren may as well not be there at all as her role seems to be defined as merely a pretty face among monkeys. But the most disappointing role by far is Wahlberg's, who in the past has been at least charming, but remains wooden throughout this feature.  For someone billed as the hero it's a bit off-putting that his entire focus remains on getting back to earth-in the end he spends about two minutes being noble before blundering off into the weakest `shock ending' I've seen in a film since Fight Club.But even with feeble lead performances and plot holes bigger than a baboons hot red ass we still get a few kicks out of the story.  Burton also isn't afraid to pull a couple of one-liners coupled with a Charlton Heston cameo that will set fans of the original laughing out loud in the theater.  And while POTA 2001 is not going to impress any die-hard fans of the first version, this might not be a problem-chances are, many of the young audiences watching today (sadly) never got around to seeing the forerunner for comparison.

title: Decent enough to be seen but not to be memorable.
text: This film, directed by Tim Burton, is a sci-fi work based on a simple script: an astronaut inadvertently falls on a planet similar to Earth, where humans are subjugated to a dominant monkey race. From there, he tries to organize a resistance and create conditions to return to his ship and travel back to Earth. That is, Burton didn't know how to use his famous creativity to show us something new. This story is almost entirely something we have already seen and read (if we consider the origin of everything, Pierre Boulle's book), dressed in new clothes, more modern or different. The work of the actors is generally acceptable, with Marc Wahlberg standing out with the main role, followed by Helena Bonham Carter and Tim Roth. The human characters are downright poor and main character's love interest attempts always seem out of context. Overall, it's a movie good enough to be seen but not enough to be remembered.

title: A horrible, absolutely horrible movie
text: This movie couldn't be any more bad.   Clearly, the creators of this fill were more worried about how to grunt, look, and walk like an ape, than in conveying a story.   The dialog is, for the most part, grunts on the part of the apes, and practically non-existent on the part of the humans, with the exception of the lead (male) character.   The lead female character has perhaps no more than 3 or 4 lines during the entire movie.As for the story, its ridiculous and unbelievable.  Yes, yes, I know -- we're talking about a sci-fi movie where apes rule the world -- how realistic can it be?   My answer is this: when we see a movie, we allow the writers/directories to withdraw a certain amount of fantasy from our fantasy bank account.   Subsequent withdraws are at the cost of the movies believability.  Continual withdraws, as this movie does, have us thinking the writers are idiots and the movie ridiculous.   In the case of Plant of the Apes, this couldn't be any more the case.Rating:  1 out of 10.

title: Don't compare to original, don't hold against it
text: This reimagining is sheer eye candy, but through the surreal direction of Tim Burton's past features, what is wrong with this? The original 1968 film was heavy on themes of social tension, the hierarchy of class systems, and evolution. In my opinion, there is no need to improve on the first film simply because there was no room for improvement. It seems that this film is designed for popcorn summer entertainment and it does not sell short of this intention. Tim Burton's dark vision is one of the strongest directorial forces of all time. Whether it's the dark comedic tone of "Beetlejuice" or the ethereal romanticism of "Edward Scissorhands", the man is genius and "Planet of the Apes 2001" is no exception. I do forgive him for "Mars Attacks" though.

title: the worste movie I have seen in a long time
text: This is the worst movie I have seen for years! It starts ridicoulus and continues in the same way. I thnik when is something going to happen in this film,,,, and the the acting is worse. The ending lifts it a bit and saves the movie from a total flop. Mark Wahlberg is a bad actor in a bad movie. Sorry Tim Burton Batman was good but this one sucks.

title: Hollywood strikes again
text: This was so poor, not a scratch on the original.  I have really come to expect this from Hollywood, they have so much money but they can hardly ever make a decent film. The script was pathetic, but what can we expect from these "America saves the world" type films.

title: A fun movie, though not burtons best
text: Ok let me say this outright.  The people who were expecting the original planet of the apes are idiots.  The original, though it had its strong points dragged on to long.  The extended walking in the desert scenes were just silly.  And for all these people are hanging onto, it is still just a B-movie. Tim Burtons version, which is exactly that, is tim burtons version.  It is pretty silly to compare it because the whole entire movie was reworked. But people forget the whole entire original book was reworked to have some commentary on racism and nuclear war in the original movie.  But back to the point.  I went in this movie expecting burton to deviate, even hoping. That is exactly what happened, burton reworked everything.  Thank GOD.  (no offense, but the original is a pretensious, seriously flawed, sixties, B Sci Fi movie, that has alot of inconsistancies to it, but it is probably the funniest movies I know of, because of all those reasons) Let me put it this way, this is a film that burton did for fincial reasons, mainly to fund his pet projects(Ed Wood the most notable). I was not expecting greatness, i was not expecting this to be sleepy hollow or ed wood.  I was expecting this to be a b-movie.  The acting was bad, but who cares, all acting in action movies is bad, the exception being batman, where jack nickolson brought it to a whole new level.  That and i did not think burton wanted good acting, or he would have cast his regulars.  Tim burton saw this movie as an opportunity to indulge in the b-movie genre, and make a bundle(which he will).  It was not supposed to be high art, just a fun sci-fi movie, and it would be foolish to expect anything else.Visually the movie is not so trademarky burton, but his touch is there. Yeah some of the battle scenes are silly, and in fact there are alot of inconsistancies.  But who cares.  The movie moved along very well, though a bit to fast at times.  The movie alone is worth seeing for the charlton heston apperance, which is possibly, and probably intentionally on burtons part, the funniest scene in the movie.   So go see it, but do not expect a masterpiece, or a loyal remake of the original(which never was a masterpiece).

title: Junk
text: You know when your walking along and you step in something unpleasant well this is that something what a load of crap

title: Mistake
text: I am bothered by the perception of almost everybody seeing this movie. The misconception of this is that it is a remake of the original movie. It is NOT! It is his own perception of the book. I think it was well done. People, when you watch this movie, keep that in mind. IT IS NOT A REMAKE!!!!! I am not a huge fan of Wahlberg, but he still seems to do well in this film. I also agree that the effects were extremely impressive. And if you need help figuring the end, it is easy. What happened is that you don't see that the General was able to travel back and take over and change the planet. You are not meant to see it when it happens. So when you see this movie, don't compare it, take it on it's own merit.

title: A film that's as disastrous as it is completely useless.
text: You gotta hand it to Burton: when he makes a bad movie, he makes a BAD movie. I question whether they had any real idea of what made the originals so great. Gone are the unique philosophies, nuanced characters, solid comedy & entertaining old-school sci-fi thrills. In their place is the very worst of turn-of-the-century big budget bores: visual dullness, story ineptness, bland characters, tired performances, & a gluttony of embarrassing fan-service callbacks.

title: What a movie???
text: I don't understand why I gave this movie a 4 star rating is just to bad, I'm sorry that I saw this flick it has a very bad script and bad acting.

title: Summer of Disappointment My ASS
text: Luckily for everyone Planet of the Apes didn't follow Tomb Raider and the many other summer movies into the major disappointment catagory.  Simply put, the latest from Tim Burton is exciting, perfectly paced, and a hoot! Rick Baker's makeup is the most convincing makeup work ever to grace the screen.  The performances by those wearing it is phenomenal.  Tim Roth may be one of the most engaging FX aided villains ever as General Thade.  The story isn't too complicated, nor is it nonexistant as we have come to expect from this summer's crop.  It lacks the predictability that makes so many FX laden movies fall on their face.  This is a movie that will be mixed with critics, mixed with fans of the original (this strays a lot from the classic's elements), extremely popular with young audiences, and worth everyone's dollar at the box office.  Only gripe is the casting of Mark Wahlberg.  He can usually turn in an engaging performance, but he's no Charlton Heston.  The ending is a mind blower, but teeters on a little too confusing.  Yet, you will leave the theater wishing the sequel came out tomorrow!

title: apelike
text: How in the name of everything holy could Tim Burton do this to us?! The director best known for "Beetlejuice", Batman", "Edward Scissorhands", and "Sleepy Hollow", gives us something that looks like it should star Arnold Schwarzenegger. Everyone knows what happens, but the dialogue is just silly - mainly mocking the original. Mark Wahlberg, as hero Leo Davidson, does as good as he can, but he can't escape the fact that this movie (correction: this remake) should have never been made. The only remotely interesting scene is the end. All in all, Wahlberg suffers, as do Helena Bonham Carter, Tim Roth, Michael Clarke Duncan, and everyone else. Dreadful.

title: What?
text: I enjoyed this film, having seen the original I expected great things. The story was poor i admit that, but the scenes were great and the opening sequence was very good. It was worth a watch but i wouldn't go expecting great things.One of the main things which makes or breaks a film is its ending and unfortuantly the ending was poor. It doesn't make any sense and if someone could explain it to me i would be ver grateful.

title: "You apes sure made a monkey / You fine-lee made a mon-kee out of meeee!!!"
text: Um... okay.Well, this is darn near indistinguishable from the original "Planet" except that it *looks* better.  That's funny, you see, because the original *sounds* better, so to speak.So, what about the Surprise Ending?I won't spoil the THREE (count 'em) surprise endings.  The first two were pretty darn obvious.  The last doesn't leave you much to think about except for the nasty, bile-like taste of subverted racism.

title: Dull.
text: While it's not possible to fully talk about this movie without taking the ending into account-- which I'm not going to do-- I will say that no matter WHAT the ending turned out to be, it was definitely not worth sitting through this dull, boring, illogical mess.The make-up is fantastic.  Let's get that out of the way right now, so that we may focus on how uninteresting any of the story or characters were.  Mark Wahlberg coasts through this one, with no character to play, other than a very animalistic, primal human (ironic, no?) who only wants to get back home.  Helena Bonham-Carter and Tim Roth have some fun (and give fun performances) playing their parts, but any political commentary is lost as each scene is just an excuse to blow something up, smash set pieces, or set something on fire.As an action movie, it's so-so.  As a clever, thinking-person's film (which is what the original movie was and is), it fails completely.  In 5 years, no one will remember this "re-do" ever existed.6/10.  Make-up and special effects are NOT enough to make it a good movie. Will someone take away William Broyles Jr.'s parking pass, please?

title: Why Tim, WHY?????
text: Why Tim, WHY did you make this movie? Why Tim, WHY didn't you just make a remake of the 60's film when you decided to do the film anyway? Why Tim, WHY did you go with the lousiest story ever when you decided to go with a different story than the original? Why Tim, WHY didn't you follow the Apes-rules set in the orignal films?Words coming out from a true Tim Burton fan! I've loved all of his previous directing jobs. They've all been great fun, original and marvelously directed. But this is some of the lousiest piece of crap I've seen. Just goes to prove that nobody's perfect, I suppose. The Apes-concept just doesn't work with the Burton-touch. That, a lousy story, Elfman's most uninspired soundtrack ever (his music usually rules), recycled lines and lousy and uninspired acting by the actors sums up to a memorable ordeal - of how NOT to make a movie!Add this to the list of horrible summer movies of 2001! Avoid seeing this film, it's not worth the ticket! Treat yourself to the original Planet of the Apes or any previous Tim Burton project instead, by renting or buying them on DVD... Whatever you do, don't give them a reason to do a sequel on this crap - and they will, if enough people see it! I give this movie 2/10. Why not 1/10? Because even an uninspired Elfman soundtrack is enough to save an extra credit...

title: Not as good as earlier version
text: The casting was poor for the second version and the acting and the plot are awful. The movie makers went to great lengths to get the ape army to walk like apes, but Helen Bonham Carter never learned how. The special effects were of course much better than in the original but they do not make up for its other shortcomings.

title: An Uneven Remake
text: `Planet of the Apes' is one those movies in which you can virtually see the downward slope from beginning to end. After a supremely evocative score by Danny Elfman, an introduction that grabs the audience, masterful atmospheric cinematography and a presentation of the premise that maintains our interest, the movie goes downhill. Essentially, the second part of the movie is little more than a cat and mouse story and does not match the expectations set up in the first part The movie has some great make-up effects, and the special effects in which the apes jump or throw others up in the air are very entertaining to watch. It seems that Tim Burton has a `signature' special effect in each of his movies: In `Sleepy Hollow' it was the decapitations, and in `Batman', the flying sequences over Gotham City. I heard many voice comments that they were disappointed by the movie. I believe that's partly because of a mismatch between its main body and the ending: up to the ending, the movie treats the subject matter as a science fiction story with only a touch of social commentary, whereas the ending is very much in the spirit of Pierre Boulle's biting social satire.  If the two elements had been better integrated, the ending might not have seemed as abrupt. The movie does deserve credit in that it did not attempt to replicate the well-known ending of the original story, but find its own twist. Nevertheless, as a social fable it is weaker than the original. I still recommend this movie because, despite the drop in the second half, it is entertaining and the cinematography and special effects are well worth watching.

title: A Disappointing and Disjointed Mess!
text: Let me start by saying that I am a huge Tim Burton fan. I consider his visions on film absolutely fantastic! I see Tim's hand in about  the first 2/3rds of this film.The last  1/3rd seems like the work of "suits" rather than "artists. While the film has a certain awesome visual style-give Rick Baker the Academy Award for Makeup right now-we are constantly challenged to suspend disbelief for shallow plot points and trite dialog. Forget character development. Forget logic and check your brain with your ticket stub. The ending (which I will not reveal here so as not to spoil for those who have not seen yet) is a nightmare. I understand that there were possibly 5-7 different endings- maybe a DVD Special Edition or definitive director's cut could make more sense than this "barrel of  monkeys." Hollywood get original. Less effects more story. No  more sequels - I'm feeling sick.

title: What is up with that ending?
text:
I heard a lot of things about this remake, most specifically the ending, but I had never watched it in its entirety. I watched it a week before Kingdom of the Planet of the Apes and I am completely baffled by a lot of things in this movie.Positives for Planet of the Apes (2001):
The Apes make-up effects by Rock Baker are phenomenal and it's the one effect of this remake that is better than the original. That's it for positives.Negatives for Planet of the Apes (2001):
The fact this movie was directed by Tim Burton is baffling, because it doesn't feel or look like a Tim Burton Movie. Mark Wahlberg as Leo Davidson is one of the most boring protagonists I've ever seen in a movie. Tim Roth as General Thade is intimidating at times, but he acts overacts too much in the movie. Also, the Apes jumping 30 feets in the air is way too goofy. Finally, the ending to this movie is the worst endings I've ever seen in any movie. There is nothing about this ending that makes any logical sense whatsoever.Overall, Planet of the Apes (2001) is a remake that didn't have much going for it to begin with, but it's completely destroyed by have the absolute worst movie ending I've ever seen in my life.

title: This movie was horrible and here's why.
text: I do not read about movies before they come out nor do I watch the previews. (I remain in the lobby until the film begins.) I walk into the theatre with a clean slate. I sit down wanting to be entertained and for about two hours my imagination should flow. With Planet of the Apes this is what I saw. 1) A beginning credit sequence? On a summer movie? 'Take it easy,' I said, 'you're just anxious for it to begin'. 2)After the credit sequence concludes we see a space station. A title appears stating that it's 2029, a mere 28 years from now. I squirm, the future date should have been left to my imagination 2)On the space station we see Mark Wahlberg interacting with his comrades. Nameless, numberless comrades. It dawns on me that Wahlberg maybe the only major lead. 'Oh no, he's good but he's not that good.' 3)After a monkey is shot out into the unknown in a space probe, Wahlberg, who was against this idea, straps himself in a pod of his own and states, "Don't send a monkey to do a man's job." My heart sinks. 4)Wahlberg crashes into a very fake looking sound stage jungle set. I'm instantly taken out of the movie. 5)But then I perk up when the apes appear. They jump through the air and leap through the trees with wreckless abandon just like I hope monkeys do. I like this. 6)Upon his capture Wahlberg grabs onto an apes legs. The ape responds with a knowing wink, "Get your stinking hands off me, you damn dirty human!" I'm out of the movie again. 7)The apes and their captives arrive to another claustrophobic sound stage which they warmly know as their city. 8)Darn near every shot is a close up further inducing my claustrophobia. My best defense is to fall asleep. 9)I wake up sometime later. It turns out that the apes are afraid of water so to get away from them Wahlberg suggest to his merry crew to cross the river. Ari, the friendly she-ape is afraid. Wahlberg says, 'Don't be afraid you silly nit, we'll be on horses and horses are good swimmers.' She submits and they proceed to cross the five feet deep river. Question: When the apes see the horses safely swimming to the other side why don't they follow? 10)We discover along with the main characters that Wahlberg's space station passed through the same time warp he did but crash landed 3,000 years before and that, presumedly, the smart little monkeys aboard went crazy and killed all the humans. And then I take it they evolved into the warlike big apes we now see. In only 3,000 years of evolution??? 11)As for the trick ending that everyone has now heard about. Can someone please tell me because I fell asleep again. I'd like to state for the record that I loved Starship Troopers.

title: Great
text: This is a great movie. Mark Wahlberg does a great job on being a hero, and Tim Roth plays a great jerk for an ape. Tim Burton made this movie come alive. I hope everyone gets a chance to see this great movie.10/10

title: My take on POTA
text: I think that the best possible review for the latest Tim Burton movie comes directly from the source material, Pierre Boulle's 1963 novel "Planet of the Apes.""I soon succeeded in convincing myself that well-trained animals might well... become expert in in all the human arts, including the art of cinematography." -Pierre BoulleTim Burton was so wrapped up in the idea that this was about the apes, that he apparently was humanitarian enough to let a real live ape write the script.The film was 15% Planet of the Apes, 15% Tim Burton, and 70% Hollywood Bull Crap.The plot is thin, the dialogue ridiculous, and the ending a completely predictable insult to viewer intelligence.  Fortunately the special effects are perfect... so what you end up with is a lump of coal wrapped in pretty wrapping paper.A waste of potential!

title: A Non-Intimate Version of the Original
text: 6 August 2001. This updated version reverts to the clash of warring parties and focuses more on ape authenticity, then the more intimate original version which focused more on the individual diversity and complex interaction between man and ape. The silent humans in the original version gave the movie a much more dramatic feel. The original ending was one of the best stunners in the league of "The Sixth Sense," and "The Crying Game." The original held much more of sci-fi instead of the usual us versus them wargames. The original was more thrilling, mysterious, and scary, ominously.

title: Don't waste the ticket price...
text: Wow, what a bummer! As I am a fan of the original, 1968, movie, I was excited when I heard they were doing a re-telling. I thought that with today's effects technology, and a story idea as compelling as Planet of the Apes, I thought there was no way this could fail. But boy was I wrong. There is utterly no character development aside from pointing out to us who are the villains and who are the heroes. There was no motivation for General Thade's (Tim Roth) hatred or Ari's (Helena Bonham Carter) great compassion. To call the plot shallow would be to imply that there was any substance at all. And all the inside jokes concerning the original series got old, too. However, nice touch having Charlton Heston appear in a cameo as General Thade's dying father. Mark Wahlberg, who has consistently turned in very good performances in films like "The Perfect Storm" and "Fear," falls flat with a one-note character stolen from the pages of a comic book.Sure, the effects were great and the costumes were superb, but no matter how much make-up they pancaked onto my grandfather at his funeral, he was still lifeless, as was this film. All in all, a disappointment; no drama, no suspense, no depth of plot. Just another forgettable action film. My rating: D.

title: Unmemorable but honourable attempt to revitalise the Planet series
text: During a failed detour, Air Force astronaut Leo Davidson (Mark Wahlberg) lands on an alien planet where apes rule the world and humans are their slaves. It is pretty much a straight forward remake of the 1968 sci-fi classic as opposed to the recent Andy Serkis fronted reboots which takes the premise in a different way. There are pretty good moments including the opening titles which are delightfully scored by Danny Elfman, making us feel we are certainly in Burton's take of this world. Tim Roth is very good as General Thade; a sadistic warrior ape who is frighteningly murderous and untrustworthy. Roth has a lot of fun with the role and does provide the films standout moment towards the end, delving into the scary energy that chimpanzees can have. The classic twist ending is effectively done and a good homage to the original. Paul Giamatti is also pretty good as the comic relief of the film and it's a helluva role! The production was documented as pretty troubled. As soon as Tim was recruited to direct, there was already a release date a year away as the studio were desperate to start the franchise up again. Script rewrites were being done while sets were being made just weeks before shooting began. Under immense studio pressure, the shoot sounded stressful and tight with editing having to take place in conjunction with the shooting. All the while undergoing personal issues, it's no wonder that the film unfortunately doesn't fully stand up on its own. It's no fault of any crew or cast member who do give it their all; it's just circumstance and bad timing culminating in a rushed and churned out Hollywood flick. There's a certain charm however to seeing Rick Baker's ape make-up work which is a nice homage to the original while also embellishing on their more animalistic mannerisms. It also marks the first collaboration with Helena Bonham Carter who has started a family with Burton since and went on to star in all of his films throughout the '00s

title: great film
text: this is a great film. the original was also great. but you cannot compare the two. as tim burton said, this is not a remake. it is a re-thinking of the original story. so, after taking that into account, this new apes movie is a great, great film (i'm biased though, i think tim burton is one of the most creative directors ever).

title: This is NOT Burton's best film!
text: Remakes come in all shapes and sizes. What's the reason for making remakes of the classic movies that fitted well? Some remakes get to show a different side of view like Martin Scorsese's Cape Fear in 1991 where rather than showing a happy family in peril (like in the original 1962 classic), Scorsese shows a dysfunctional family filled with anger and a disease where it made audience applaud for De Niro's character.Tim Burton is known for making movies in a goth emblem from Beetlejuice, Batman Returns (the best of his work), Sleepy Hollow, Edward Scissorhands and much more. Now he directs this 1960's classic about how a man from space gets stuck in an island filled with talking and vicious primates. Mark Whalberg is Capt. Leo Davidson who doesn't do much except try to wow women with his boyish good looks where one of his lab chimps goes inside a space rocket and leaves the space station where he goes into another planet. Leo tries to find his pet until he realizes that once he arrives everything is upside down with humans in cages and use for enslavement while primates (Gorillas, monkeys, orangutans, etc.) rule the planet. The leader is General Thade (Tim Roth, who stands out) who wants to abolish all humans from the face of the earth. His henchmen involves the volatile Attar (Michael Clarke Duncan), Limbo (Paul Giamatti) the fool, and sweet Ari (Helena Bonham Carter) who crushes on Captain Leo.If you seen the original movie about how the humans and some of the chimps fight off the bad primates, there's a twist in the ending. There's no enthrallment, no cheers, it felt as if certain scenes from the trailer worked rather than the film itself while breathing in relief after I walked out of the theater.

title: Very Disappointing
text: I was fired up to see this movie.  I went right away so no one could spoil the surprise ending.  I was extremely disappointed in the film and urge you to save your 9 bucks.  For the record, I think the original was excellent. Here are the main reasons why this movie falls short. (No spoilers) - Many plot holes - Cheesy humorous references to the first movie...why is this necessary? Apparently, they rightly felt that this movie couldn't stand on it's own. - Stereotypical bad guy (ape) - Stereotypical good guy( female ape , made up to look like Janet Jackson) - Drags at times. - Gratuitous "surprise" ending...not well thought out and inserted merely for the sake of having a surprise ending like the good, first movie.Rent it when it comes out and you'll see what I mean...or better yet, go rent the original.

title: Not as good as the original
text: When the first good comment for a film is great make-up, then you know your in trouble. The Planet of the Apes remake is no where need as good as the original film. It was filmed by Tim Burton, but he really was just a gun-for-hire, a film that was not made with his usual Gothic style.Planet of the Apes is set in 2029, and focuses on Leo (Mark Walberg), a US air force pilot based on a space station. On the station the air force use apes to help do tasks and pilot small pods. A wormhole opens and one of the apes is sent to investigate. When it seems that the chimpanzee was in trouble Leo follows the apes through the wormhole. After going through it Leo crash-lands in a strange jungle and encounters humanized-apes. He is captured with other humans and sold to slavery. Leo is brought by a human-sympathiser, Ari (Helena Botham Carter), and with other humans escape from the city. This leads to them getting chased by the ape army, led by General Thade (Tim Roth).As I say, the make-up by Rick Baker was very good and truly Oscar-worthy. The special-effects were good, and there was some good action scenes. However the film was lackluster and really a by-the-numbers affair. There was a poor script with this film, and the story telling was nothing like the original film. There was nothing deep about this film and just shows apes as evil and humans as good. In the original film humans were neutral and all except Charlton Heston were mute whilst the apes were more of a mixed-bag. The original Planet of the Apes was seen at time as a satire, for example the backwards issue of not teaching the theory of evolution. In this film the idea of religion was decent, but could have been more. The remake was really just a chase movie. The acting for the apes was good and well casted. Helena Botham Carter is always good and Tim Roth loved playing the evil general. Michael Clarke Duncan was also decent in it. However, the human actors were not so well-developed and this film was not Walberg's finest hour. I also didn't like Paul Giamatti as an Oranga-tan slave trader, he was only in the film to add comic relief. The other major problem with this film was the ending. The original had a great ending which everyone should know. This film's ending was sub-par. I did not like how the battle ended and the aftermath of the battle (similar to my opinions to X-Men 3). Everyone has also criticised the plot-twist at the end.I admit, when I was younger I did enjoy the film from an action-adventure viewpoint; but even then I did not like the plot twist. However, this film does have it fans like Mark Kermode and Richard Roeper.One to miss in my opinion.

title: The movie was really good
text: i would just like to say that planet of the apes was a really good movie. the only thing that i did not like about it was the ending but i think that they are thinking of making another one and thats how they decided to end it. oh ya and Mark Wahlberg is really hot!!!!!!!!

title: Disappointed
text: I had high expectations for this film. Man, was I disappointed. I don't want to spoil the ending, but the original film had the best ending I've ever seen. When Tim Burton was the director, I was sure he would find something just as good or even better. He didn't.The film is one long fightscene and the actors smell bad. It isn't very realistic either. Especially when you find out that the apes learned english from Americans. I mean, if that's how they learned it, how can Helena B. Carter speak with british accent all way through?It appears that the actors must've chosen this script because it was a remake of a classic film-history film. And because of the directors name. Tim Roth is wasting his talent. Why won't anybody give him a charater as a major bad guy in a human-film? If he hadn't been hiden behind a stupid mask I'm sure he would've stole the picture from a (once again) poor performing Mark Walberg.If you like lots of action and nothing ells, I'll give this one 9 out of 10.In my own book it gets 3, from the fact of Charlton Heston being in a cameo!

title: Needed editing
text: I am a Tim Burton fan. I respect his work because he dares to leave his imagination free, in an arty yet commercial way. I always enjoyed his movies, but after continuously watching them for many years now (especially since they were released on DVD), I can finally spot their weakness.You see, some annoying feelings come to surface when you watch 'Batman' or 'Sleepy Hollow' for a tenth time. They are boring movies! Or to be fair, the are movies with long, boring scenes.
