Evidently Tim Burton seems to fear and respect every frame he shoots while editing and this behaviour creates very long dialog scenes, that work against the pacing of the movie.Long dialog scenes that don't provide exposition should be cut in a non-drama movie. Let's face it, Tim Burton has never worked with a 'Taxi Driver' script, so most of the long dialog scenes should be divided among action scenes.Also, the suspense doesn't change much in his movies. 'Sleepy Hollow' runs in the same way from start to finish, so does 'Batman'. I must say that his best work, is his comedies and maybe he should try to transfer the mood of those films to his other work too.'Planet of the Apes' is bad and I'm not talking about the ENDING, which is the best part of the movie. Only a moron would try to analyse what really happened there. Have you noticed that stupid people, always need to lower every situation to their own standards, in order to understand it? Of course this creates even more confusion (to them) and they won't get this ending no matter what, so let's proceed. By the way, true cinema is about expressing emotions and not opinions. If you need to state an opinion, the printed word is the perfect medium for it.The biggest mistake of the movie is this Burton element. 'Planet' needed aggressive editing, in order to become fun and not boring, which is what it is now. Specifically the dinner scene and the escape scene in the village. Burton treated this script like it was 'Godfather', so we watch the apes discuss over dinner about every day and social matters for ten minutes, like we care. They're talking apes! On with the story please! Obviously they wanted to balance the action with some drama scenes, but the writing is very bad. A lot of other scenes are boring too and should be deleted, since they destroy everything. Burton seems to have lost his humor in this movie too, since these long scenes could work if they were funny, but they are merely irritating.Unfortunately the script is quite weak, so even if that editing took place, it wouldn't make a masterpiece out of the story. Mark Wahlberg looks like a little kid in the whole movie, possibly because of Burton. He wanted him to become this anti Charlot Heston, an action hero who's in the movie only for the fun ride. It just doesn't work.On the positive side, Burton shows off his craftsmanship for one more time, providing us with some fairy tale images and an introduction in a space station, which is the most spectacular cinematic work since 'Superman'.'Planet of the Apes' shouldn't be made at all. How can you recreate perfection? What's next, a remake of 'Lawrence of Arabia'? Anyway, for once more Burton made an action movie that doesn't stand the test of repetitive viewings and this is because of his fear for aggressive editing.4/10

title: Why did they bother?
text: Watching this garbage was a complete waste of time. I had pretty high hopes with Tim Burton directing, but he spent way too much (time and money) on the dumb things: makeup, effects and not enough time on the important things: story, character development.  It makes me wonder why they bothered to make this crap. Answer: money, the movie is rediculous and has no value add to the original. Sure the apes look more real, but their dialog is rediculous and a huge missed opportunity to even make the apes scary: something that shouldn't be too hard.I hold Burton responsible for this blunder and I'll never see another movie he makes in the theatre again, he's violated my trust by churning out this crap. He should be embarrassed and retire.Oh well, at least I have the original on DVD.

title: racist?
text: I just watched this on tv.  I agree with the earlier comments rating this as mediocre and illogical at every turn (within the bounds of the fantastic premise of course.)  I haven't read most of the 1238! comments but don't see any bringing up an aspect which jumped out at me.  __  To digress, I was stunned to see that, when the film Ghost Busters was turned into a tv cartoon series, Aykroyd's & Murray's characters were transferred not unlike the originals but Ernie Hudson, the one black ghost buster, was replaced by an ape!  Planet of the Apes strikes me the same way.  __  I'm white and do not presume to speak for blacks but I cannot see how this movie, with only one token black human surrounded by otherwise entirely white humanity, can avoid coming off as comparing blacks to simians.  Yes, I realize that this flick is presenting a lame, elementary-school-level case for liberalism.  I do not however see that as negating the fact that, while the film repeatedly instructs us that slavery is bad and that intolerance is bad, the humans are basically purely white, which means that the other set of characters (the apes) must represent blacks.  __  A weak claim is made that humans enslaved apes and now, after turnabout, apes have enslaved humans.  The problem with that is that humans do not use apes as slaves.  Hmm, who did whites used to enslave if not apes?  Blacks.  So then, if this society represents a reversal of our own, who must the apes represent?  Blacks.  __  Other fantasy films successfully make the desired point by either having characters of different colors or races on both sides, thus pointing out that intolerance is not inherently caused by racial difference, or by having characters with cultural differences which in no way resemble actual ethnic or racial groups.  I am in no way saying that the apes in this film resemble actual blacks but I am saying that some of the characteristics (besides their ability to ignore the laws of physics) they exhibit are exactly how bigots used to make fun of blacks.  __  Am I the only one here who was alive before the civil rights movement and thus what I'm talking about is totally foreign to the rest of your experiences?  Please explain to me how I am reading things wrong, if I am.

title: Makes me want to stare at the sun so I don't have to watch movies like this ever again
text: Remake of Planet of the Apes....worse than battlefield earth, worse than Howard the Duck and much much worse than Congo.  This movie sets the bar for awful not only in film but in metaphors for life.  Tell your friends only to see this if they want motivation for killing themselves.

title: Bad, bad news
text: This one is an absolute shocker! I can't believe, Tim Burton is responsible for this mess (but then again, everyone can have a bad-hair day). The story makes no sense at all. The characters are all one-dimensional, their actions implausible, the attempts at humour feeble. The whole Ape culture/religion is a sad mush of Ancient Rome and Early Christianity. And the ending, people were raving about it, but it's a complete letdown, kind of: 'Oh, we gotta go out with a bang, like in the Original. But it has to be a different bang....Mmmh, don't have any ideas...Oh, let's just do this  OK, won't spoil. One positive thing : The gorilla masks are quite scary (and allow the actors to hide - which is probably a good thing).

title: Not as good as it could have been, or should have been.
text: While this movie did have a couple of upsides to it, like Tim Roth's excellent performance, the make-up, and the gun thing with Heston; I still feel like I should have just mailed the theater $5.50.It was way to over the top and exceeded the limits normally given to action-adventure films.  I know that the concept of the movie is over-the-top in and of itself, but c'mon.  Heston's last line as he dies was murder.  I think Burton went a little to hollywood.

title: awful
text: I was so excited for this movie, and man, what a let down.  Granted, casting, make-up, costuming, and sound were wonderful, but that's about it. The script was poor, and actually made the audience laugh at parts that weren't supposed to be funny.  Everyone coming out of the theatre gave the movie two thumbs down! The ending could've been better written by a 5 year old!  Don't waste your money on this one!

title: The Original was MUCH better
text: Hardly can hold a torch to the socialpolitical themes that the 1968 original tackled.  Obviously, special effects are well beyond what could be done then.  The action holds your interest, but the story is lacking.  If this is a "re-imagining", the Mr Burton would have done well to stick with what the original did so well.  Then, we might have a movie well worth watching.

title: Don't be hatin'
text: I can't help but think that people who call this movie 'horrible' are mean spirited. In fact, one reviewer gives a completely false description of how ape civilization started which makes me think he hasn't even seen the movie, but is only spreading bad hype. Folks, maybe you haven't seen some of the other movies that came out this year, but compared to the likes of "Mummy Returns", "JPIII", "Swordfish" etc., Tim Burton's POTA is a modern-day "Citizen Kane".I understand people don't like to see their favorite movie remade, but that's no reason to diss this movie. Besides, it's not a remake, it's a re-imaging.The original movie was a social commentary. The new POTA is a sci-fi action summer movie, and I don't see anything wrong with that especially if it's done the way Tim Burton did it. Racial inequality and fear of nuclear annihilation don't plague the world as much as they did in 1968. The story line is basically same.The acting is top-notch as opposed to the original's melodramatic and sometimes over-the-top acting. Mark Wahlberg gives a subtle and understated performance. Paul Giamatti provides great comic relief. And can you say Academy Award Nominee for Tim Roth and Helena Bonham-Carter. There are a lot of complaints about bad dialog. I must have overheard it, because I don't remember any cheesy or nonsense lines.The ending was fascinating. In two years, no other movie, besides Memento, made me think about it as much. The makeup and cinematography are absolutely amazing, as is the kick-ass score. I see how someone could get frustrated with the ending, because it makes you make use of those damn brain cells. Tim Burton used the original novel's ending, so when you trash the ending, you also trash a sci-fi classic.So don't listen to all the bad hype. Go see the movie and make up your own mind.

title: A great re-interpretation and under-rated film ruined by nostalgics
text: I for one love this modernised view of Planet of the Apes. Coming from a younger generation of Film viewers, watching movies with 30 year old plots and FX isn't as captivating as newer renditions with updated technology and plots. The Hatred towards humans feels more genuine especially from Thade as well as the fear shown when the apes realize the power marky has. Obviously the makeup and effects are a lot more advanced which helps remove some of the silliness of the notion of a planet ruled by apes. I enjoyed the ending, it makes you think and left me wanting to see more, perhaps the ending meant nothing whatever the case it left people thinking and debating. I would love to see a sequel to this version if it were possible.

title: Damn You, You Maniacs!!!
text: You really have to wonder sometimes about big studio decision making. Do they screen movies like this and pat each other on the back, hand the director a cigar and crawl off to bed thinking how incredible smart they all are? Or is it that halfway through production, it all begins to fall apart and money already spent cannot be recovered and the project becomes a salvage effort. The balloon ego of an overrated director is pricked, and although he must still put his signature to it, decides to punish the studio for its blindness to his genius vision, by handing them a bomb that they all hope people wont recognizes. Who knows, I actually believe that while movies in the past have been miscast, this is an example of a movie having been misdirected. Burton's world creation just doesnt work here. Its completely claustrophobic, and unrealistic. Contrast to the original classic, which utilized all open panoramic scenery that was disturbingly too realistic. Burton creates a Gilligans island atmosphere, and coupled with the horrible story - you get a bad bad movie. So lets recap, you have a good book to work with, a great original movie to study, and the end result is this piece of junk that ignores both. Again, its not Burtons fault. He is a one trick pony, and some of his movies are great. But selecting him to make this was stupid, and allowing him to actually complete and release it, dumber still.

title: Excellent Apes and Music, but No More
text: I agree with a lot of the commenters.  The apes and their clothes were fabulous.  But the sets and the plot weren't.  Actually, I thought this movie was boring.  There was no characterization.  Motives for actions were hard to discern.  (Maybe the idea of the Mark Wahlberg character was: What happens when a basically shallow, dumb person ends up as the key man in a complicated situation?  Answer: He becomes a vehicle for action  --- of which there was a lot.)  I think that this movie is summed up in the credits which were somber and elegant all by themselves --- the film is about great costumes and the power of design.  But That's All, Folks.

title: Planet of the Oops!
text:
I'm not entirely familiar with all of the other Planet of the Apes films, but I don't think there could be anything in any of them that would change my mind about the 2001 version. We start off with an electrical storm in space that results in some serious time travel, just like we saw in Lost In Space, which results in our hero winding up thousands of years in the future and on an unknown planet. Seconds after surviving the crash landing of his pod on this mysterious planet, Leo Davidson (Mark Walhberg) finds himself surrounded by fleeing HUMANS. The first thing I thought was that there are humans and apes on an unknown planet in an unknown galaxy roughly 5000 years in the future, but later we learn (also as seen in Lost In Space) that Leo's ship also passed through that time warp and landed in the same place, leaving the humans to go into submission to the out-of-control apes that were on the ship for experimentation, and the apes themselves were left to evolve and take control, ultimately turning into the hard-nosed apes that ruled the planet when Leo crash landed. That was a mouthful. Pretty creative though, once we are eventually informed as to what the hell is going on. So Leo is stuck on this planet where the roles are basically reversed and exaggerated between humans and apes, and now it is entirely up to Leo to save this planet's version of the human race from the oppression of the apes. Tim Roth delivers a horribly annoying performance as General Thade, the militant leader of the apes who is so filled with hatred for the humans (for reasons never made entirely clear) that he operates just like a machine. He's always grunting and growling and always has his head tilted downward like he's expecting physical confrontation at all times, and his constant guttural tone of voice makes him almost amusing after a while. One of the biggest problems with this movie is that the apes are so well made up, but they also have tremendous intelligence, as is made evident by their strikingly human eyes, and yet they switch back and forth from normal speech to the same screeching and screaming that you hear from the monkeys at the zoo. There is a scene where General Thade is told that the humans crossed the river using the apes' own horses, and he jumps all around the place, screeching and jumping and breaking things, and then he's back on the ground talking like a warrior. It's so hard to take this stuff seriously.Helena Bonham Carter is excellent as Ari, the weirdly attractive ape who is disgruntled with the way that the humans are treated by the apes, and who turns against her own kind to help the humans escape. There is a childish scene at the end of the film where Leo kisses Ari that is sure to get a laugh from any audience, while the stunningly but almost weirdly beautiful Estella Warren provides the human love interest. It's a good thing that they had a human woman in this movie to take romantic interest in Leo, because without her we only have Ari, who is 100% ape but who acts exactly like a human woman while interacting with Leo. For the first half of the film, I was a little nervous about the possibility of a little bestiality happening somewhere in there. So we know that Ari is helping the humans because she is disillusioned with her violent species, but they are also accompanied by another ape - Attar, I think (hey, half the fun was trying to figure out who was underneath all that make-up, right?) - and we never know why he agrees to go along, knowing that he will face severe punishment upon returning, which is one of the movies more simplistic but peeving oversights. It is, however, the ending of the film that ruins it beyond all hope for being saved.
At the beginning of the film, when Leo took off in the pod toward the electrical storm, he was going after the pod of his chimp, with whom all communication had been lost. He gets swept away in the same electrical storm as the chimp got caught in, and winds up on the planet described above. At the end of the film, the chimp comes through right in the middle of the climactic battle between the humans and the apes, and the apes bow down to him as their god. This was actually a pretty clever scene, because he was, in fact, one of the first apes of their civilization, and then Leo trades places with him, leaving him with Ari (and with an obviously broken leg, which we're left to assume turned out okay) and taking the ship back to his own time. And General Thade, I guess, was just left sulking under that console on the ship forever, doomed to live the rest of his life as a loose end in a sub-par sci fi movie. It was bad enough that everything on the ship still worked after thousands of years, now they have to leave stuff everywhere unexplained.So we get back to Earth, Leo survives the entrance through the atmosphere and then miraculously survives another violent crash landing without a scratch, and he finds the Lincoln Monument is an ape (when I saw Lincoln from behind, I jokingly said to myself that it would be an ape. I was disappointed and amused to find that I was right). This could, of course, mean only one thing. Seeing how there was barely an explanation for the English speaking humans and apes on the planet on which most of the film took place, and there was literally none at all given for the apes replacing the humans on Earth, we can only assume that they ran out of money or they are just setting up for a sequel. My money is on the latter. Stay tuned for part 9 (or so).

title: Planet of the Apes
text: Let me first start of by saying Tim Burton is a visionaire, he has proved that over and over with films like Beetlejuice and Edward scissorhands, etc... but as far as telling this classic tale he kind of got lost along the way in expressing his vision on this tale. Resulting in the end in having more and more beautiful pics and awesome action cut scenes but the story stays behind, and even though the actors do put on a great show, as we can see that Tim Roth is on a roll while portraying a vicious Ape General, even a bit over the sadistic side. But nevertheless it is an OK flick, just that when u expecting the great story told in the novel u would come out deceived.But for pure entertainment reasons I would go for it

title: When is the Sequel coming and whats with that long stupid trailer????
text: Man I went into this movie really thinking it was going to be a dog because of the poor trailers for this movie. I mean does every movie have to show the dumb trailers that either show you every laughable line or worse yet, show you a synopsis of the whole movie??? I think a simple teaser would suffice for any and all movies before they are released. Unless we are all turning into little children as adults and need the whole movie pratically explained to us before going to go see it.Anyway, this was a very good version of POTA. I was very pleased and a little surprised at the outcome of the movies ending. They practically gave it away, probably for the slower people who like long trailers.This is very much worth seeing and I hope they get the sequel done by next year. They better not leave this one hanging too long. They never made people wait too long in the past series.Thanks, Gary

title: Spend the day at the Zoo
text: This is an awful film.  Poor direction, poor cinematography, poor acting, weird casting (Kris Kristofferson?), ridiculous dialogue--is it a serious film, or is it a parody?  Who knows?And the incomprehensible conclusion!  Don't bother rewinding and rewatching. It makes no sense.  Do yourself a favor.  Skip the video and spend the day at the zoo.

title: Generally weak redo leaving behind all the important plot elements of the original
text: Redoing a well-known, landmark movie is always, one would imagine, a challenge. Where the original depended so heavily on a surprise ending for its overall impact, the task is heightened to daunting. One would say, perhaps, even impossible.Tim Burton -- whose directing credits include films such as Batman, Beetlejuice and Nightmare Before Christmas -- was always going to produce the goods when it came to dark sets, evil villians and eye-popping special effects. So while he doesn't disappoint there, that alone is not enough.The major problem with this film is the atrocious plot, which is so unlike the original this film can hardly be termed a remake. The screenwriters have changed just about all the important plot elements, characters and events. This perhaps was a necessity, and possibly the only way to approach this task, but it is at the same time unfortunate. Everything in the film seems like an "alternative", an idea that may have been dropped in favour of the real thing the first time around.The film suffers from a profound lack of character development, and a 'flatness' of emotion which alienates the audience. Where a Jurassic Park or Star Wars Episode I focus on the special effects to the detriment of character and plot, this film takes this error to its extreme. We are, it seems, to marvel at the special effects so much as be entirely satisfied without any other elements. So much time onscreen is dedicated to celebrating the visuals of the world that Burton has created that we have no opportunity to understand it on any other level. One feels that large chunks of this film were cut and that a Director's Cut is inevitable. Perhaps that will provide the meat that this so desperately needs.To be fair to Burton, he worked with the screenplay he was given, and it is in this that most of the problem lies. The performances are generally good -- although Wahlberg is terrible as the hero -- and Tim Roth is excellent. Perhaps like Batman, Roth is this film's Nicholson, and makes the film worthwhile on his own.And then there's that ending. While I won't describe it for fear of robbing you of the small thrill that it provides, I will say that it is the most tangential and irrelevant ending imaginable. It literally appears to belong to a different film altogether, and is really a trite and blithe attempt to stun the audience the way the first film did. It is remarkable that any experienced director or writer could believe that simply tacking on a disconnected idea at the end of a film could provide any shock whatsoever. The result is a "Huh?" where there should be a "Wow!".Overall, Planet of the Apes fails in so many ways that remove the special effects and fine actors and a major flop would emerge. The film will no doubt be broadly watched and enjoyed for it's visual elements, but does seem to offer this lesson to all screenwriters and studios out there: if you can't think of how to possibly remake a film, and you're wracking your brains and have to think really, really hard, then please, just don't.

title: Not worthy of the original.
text: What a bad film! I like to think of myself as a Tim Burton fan. However, I feel that when he gets a big budget, his work suffers. Ed Wood was his lowest budgeted film and was by far his greatest work. "Mars Attacks" and this "Ape" movie both had big budgets and were really horrible. Someone needs to tell Hollywood, that when you revisit a classic story, bring something new to the story. Special effects alone is not enough. I believe that Hollywood thought that by just having more elaborate costumes and apes, they would have a better movie, wrong! The story was just paper thin and the script was one of the worst ever. The first hour of this film was just a bunch of campy jokes. I have never seen more uninspired performances. However, to be fair, the actors had nothing to work with. The story is just patched together. Few characters are developed or have any importance. Man, this was a bad film. However, people will consider it a smash hit, because of the box office totals. However, most of the money taken in by this film was in the first week, so the negative word of mouth had not gotten out yet. This film has dropped like a rock since week one. Let's hope that Burton can return to actually telling a story and a weird story at that. That was one thing this film was missing, there was no "Burton Weirdness" anywhere. Bland and boring. * out of *****.

title: Worst movie ever
text: The previews of this movie were very promising: directed by Tim Burton, with such stars as Helena Carter and Tim Roth, and a huge budget for special effects, it had the potential to be one of the year's hits.  However, a smarter move on the part of the directors would have been to scrap the film, and screen the preview in theaters.  This film in the region of the worst film I have ever seen.  Mark Wahlberg, as usual, adds nothing to the film with his despicable acting and moronic facial expressions, except the impression that he is severely constipated; Tim Roth (who has contributed to such great films as Reservoir Dogs and Little Odessa) was physically painful to watch; and I still don't understand why they bothered to include Helena Carter in the cast at all.  It takes a flight of the imagination to imagine Tim Burton saying "cut!" on the set, and being pleased with what he had created.  Bottom line: DO NOT SPEND ANY MONEY ON THIS FILM.  The actors are pathetic, the new ending is as pointless as it is absurd, and Tim Burton should beat himself in the face with a frying pan for this one.

title: Its a good flick... with a poor ending.
text: Okay by now I'll assume you've heard there is a "surprise" ending for Apes. I mean in the original story it turned out the "planet of the Apes" was Earth all along, so Burton had to avoid that, and he did, nicely, but he then felt obliged to do his own twist ending and that is where the movie falls apart. This movie was an interesting visual journey with a nice background mystery (how did the apes get this way?) although when all is said and done I am left wondering two things: 1- Where did they get all the horses? And 2- Where is Rod Serling in the end shot? I can almost hear him saying "Picture a man far from home..."

title: Nothing like the original, which is pretty much the point.
text: I have read the other user comments and found that you were complaining that it was nothing like the original.  Well, you're right, but that was Tim Burton's point.  It isn't a remake or a sequel, just simply Burton's take on it.I thought that this movie was very entertaining.  Mark Whalberg was pretty good, Micheal Clark Duncan was great, but the real credit goes to Tim Roth as the evil Thade.  My mom thought that he was pretty scary and almost left the theatre.But there was one thing that was wierd, which many people have pointed out: The Ending.  It was pretty twisted, but I'll buy the DVD to see the other endings.Well, I'm gonna go see the movie again because I love Tim Burton and the movie is really cool, (half of the credit goes to Rick Baker's make-up, which will no doubt be nomminated for an oscar)HIGHLY RECOMMENDED

title: Monkey's Fall Down
text: What a bad, bad movie.  The costumes were nice and it had a scene or two that was interesting, but overall, the movie stunk.  Apes who leap 60 feet in the air, dialogue that would be better found in a WB Sitcom, and effects right out of the Saturday special on TNT, leaves the viewers less that satisfied.  I saw this movie on opening night and when the credits ran, a few of the patrons applauded.  Nothing new for opening night, but when people began to boo and hurl leftover popcorn at those who were clapping...that was new and more entertaining than the movie.Burton made many blunders with this one, oh it had such potential.  Estella Warren's only function in the movie was to be a trophy wife, I think she had all of 2 1/2 lines to deliver.  Marky Mark Wallberg was less than stellar and his character is one that you will root for the crazed apes to kill. Only Tim Roth and Michael Clarke Duncan made this movie worth watching. While Roth's character (General Slade) leaps around like a frog, he is a good villain and Duncan's character (Attar) is enjoyable to watch.Overall, you would be better served to watch "The Mummy" all over again, as you will get the same thrills, better acting, and, can you believe it, a better story line.

title: Oh my god, this is a real stinker!!
text: Never before I felt a movie SO rushed. The acting is pretty bad, and there is plenty of horrible and cliched dialogue. I haven't seen the original, so I can't really make a comparison. I will only tell you: This movie just plain sucks. Avoid it!! (the ending DID work for me. The problem was the rest of the film).

title: The entertainment value is not even close to the 1968 original
text:
(2001) Planet of the Apes
SCIENCE- FICTIONQuite bad retelling of Rod Serling's idea about Mark Walberg disobeying orders to save a monkey in a pod lost through an unidentified space cloud which is really a time warp! Once through the cloud, his pod then crashes to a planet inhabited by English speaking apes and as the movie progresses unsettling things start to reveal about the planets transformation! All I can say is that with this ending, contradicts the whole movie even before it's shown, leaving viewers with more questions than answers! Check the original "Planet of the Apes"instead. The first of seven movies actress Helena Bonham Carter collaborated with director Tim Burton.

title: Mixed feelings
text: Awesome costumes but an absolute CRAP movie...they should have kept closer to the original story-line and avoided the love triangle confusion.  It was embarrassing to watch the two women vying for the attentions of Mark Wahlberg.

title: Some great performances squares out the unnecessary use of violence.
text: Inevitably you must compare the 1968 original with the 2001 reimagining. What I missed the most was the scientific approach that the original had. Showing why the apes' beliefs were covered in lies and why humans actually were intelligent.In this Tim Burton movie it seems he has to add the violence and fighting needed to get the big movie producing budget from 20th Century Fox.In one sequence Leo (played by Mark Wahlberg) points a gun at an ape, but is told to not sink to his level (the ape was a trader-in-humans) by Ari (magnificently played by Helena Bonham-Carter). Yet in the end there is no problem to fight the Ape army in Braveheart-style.The whole magic usually included in Tim Burton movies is never there, and somehow he falls for the blockbuster-syndrome: a cool action-hero and a lot of incredible stunts.And the ending, without spoiling anything, must be the worst ever displayed on the screens.However, the costumes and make-ups are incredible, but they are in line with modern movie-technology. They could give one or two Academy Awards next year. But I don't understand why apes covered in body-hair/fur would want to wear clothing or uniforms. Overall, the great performances by Helena Bonham-Carter as a Senators daughter and revolting youth preaching humanism and equality and Tim Roth as the dangerous and evil general Thade makes this movie a pretty good entertainment and raising the Rating to 5/10.

title: Not bad
text: Now, for those of you who need help with the ending ...... He somehow went forward in time, not back, to the future planet of the apes. Silly, but that's my explanation.As to the show itself, a fun caper, some decent commentary on the human race, some huge gaps in logic, the apes are living a medieval life. It was funny seeing Heston as the dying ape. All the characters were too one dimensional."Do humans have a soul" ?! - interesting question 5/10

title: Lighten up, folks
text: I mean, c'mon, its a film about about big talking monkeys. Lots of them. A whole planet, in fact. What are you expecting, Shakespeare? A deep insightful meditation on th nature of man? From Hollywood?? Its just Marky-Mark Vs the Giant Monkeys (plus that chick from Kangaroo Jack). How much plainer can I make it? Lighten up, chill out, relax. Go with the flow, enjoy the cheesy dialouge ("I'm gonna get my Chimp back!") the non-sensical plot, and the bizarre human-ape-human love triangle. Oh, and that ending was the best I think I've ever seen in my life. I don't think I've ever come out of the cinema laughing so hard.Just lighten up, folks.

title: Disappointing
text: I wasn't sure what to make of this film.  Was Tim Burton doing a parody of the first movie?  It felt like Fox was rushing through production to complete this movie before a writers strike and sacraficed the writing itself.  The film never really explains itself and relies upon the audience knowing the premise of the first film for plot guidance. When I saw this film, the audience actually exploded in laughter during the final scene clincher.  Was that supposed to be funny?  The only saving grace of this film was the acting of Helena Bonham Carter which makes Marky Mark's acting appear even worse than it is in their scenes together.  I should have waited for it on video.

title: Well made movie even though it was full of holes.
text: This movie was extremely entertaining to watch.  Mostly, it was quality filmmaking.  The story is definitely lacking in several places and you really have to forgive certain things that don't make sense but it makes a great summer blockbuster.  It is absolutely worth seeing.

title: Get your hands off my money, you damn dirty apes!
text: I will give this movie some credit; it's not just a remake, which is probably the best thing it has going for it While the make-up is great, the film ends up being too serious to be campy, too silly to be taken seriously, and there are more loose ends than an unraveled sweater. (Which are sure to be tied up by the obviously sequel that the end sets up)Mark Walberg's tries to find his monkey and lands on a planet where Monkeys are superior and humans are the lesser primate. The make-up is astounding, and Mark proves to be a pretty good no-brain action star. Tim Roths is a pretty good monkey-gone-bad, but as I said before, this movies too silly to be taken seriously and his intense performance is kind of lost.After it's revealed how the monkeys got the way they were, (and why their english was so good) the plot just get's silly and builds up too a fairly laughable ending. The blond girl, Estelle, isn't bad as far as models-turned-actresses go, but her character serves no purpose other than to give 14 year old boys something to look at. Plus, even with more makeup than the cast of Cats used for 20 years, the best apes-actor is still the real thing, Mark's chimp Pericles, who gives a better performance than half his human-cousins.It's not a bad movie, it's a style-over-substance movie, but hell, so's most everything else that's at the theater. But underneath the latex it's just a campy monkey movie destined for cult stardom.To quote Troy Mclure "I guess you made a monkey out of me!"

title: Think back to when you first heard the news...
text: When I first heard they were going to "re-imagine" the original Planet of the Apes I just about freaked out. It is impossible. The original has such an intense impact. It works because the viewers are expected to suspend disbelief at least a little bit in order to really feel the power of the movie. The original runs more like a parable or an urban legend than it does a believable action movie. This was also in a time where almost all movies and TV shows were done in the same vain- look at Alfred Hitchcock films, The Twilight Zone, and even Welcome Back Kotter - the list goes on and on. In this day and age people want to criticize the reality of everything and the filmmakers(and TV producers) see that as a challenge. This fact makes Planet of the Apes(2001) fail. I admit that after finding out Tim Burton and Danny Elfman (both of whom I am a gigantic fan) were on board I got very excited. I believed it might be done properly. I knew it couldn't be done but still got suckered in. After seeing it I realised that what I knew all along really was true. The costumes and makeup were perfect and so were the sets but there is no denying that this movie falls flat where the other made it's mark - the ending. They did pretty good with the story by putting a whole new twist on the origin of the Planet of the Apes, but in the end it all turned sour. When I first watched the original I thought of how they were going to end it and there was a certain ending that I (and many others) thought of that would make the movie stupid and very cliche. Thank god they didn't do it and instead made history. Unfortunately the new version of this movie has the EXACT twist ending we were afraid of seeing in the original. Very stupid, very easy and worst of all VERY unimaginative. I was actually cringing in my seat hoping they wouldn't end it the way they did. All I can say is "Bummer".

title: Yes...A Remake! (& a Poor One at That)
text: The difference is this; the makers took a little from all 5 prior Ape films, plus the TV series. Any reference to the original novel is non-existent.All that hard work recreating the (improved?) makeup has come to naught when the movie doesn't ride on a good script. At least the 1968 original took its time to pace the story properly to create some sort of suspense. The 2001 remake jumps from one scenario to the next in episodic fashion that leaves no room for the viewer to really care what happens to anyone. And except for the last half hour, you never get the feeling that you're out in the open air. Everything feels claustrophobic; like being on an over crowded sound stage.I still appreciate many of Burton's other films, but this is a misfire with too many cliches that most of us have seen before. And it seems that so much time was taken with the makeup; so much time was taken with paying visual homage to the original and its sequels; that they forgot to let a proper narrative flow take over the story and at least include a LITTLE logic (and I'm not even referring to the ending). The homages? 'Ari'...spell it backwards and put a 'Z' in front. Any more, I'd rather not spoil...you might have fun spotting them on your own when referencing 'Planet..', 'Beneath..', Escape..', 'Conquest..' and 'Battle..' (and the short lived TV series and cartoon).Stick with the original...as long as it is in wide screen (the pan & scan sucks to the point that you miss half the movie, especially when there are characters and events taking place on both ends of the wide screen).Perhaps the writers should have spent a little less effort calling this a 're-imagination' and instead used some 'real imagination' to create a compelling staple in the sci-fi genre that this deserved.5 out of 10

title: Style over substance
text: This movie has great looks, the apes (with a few exceptions) really look apelike, you've got lush jungles, deserts, big, action packed fight scenes, and a whole ape city that looks totally realistic. Director Tim Burton wasted no expense or effort to make this a visual feast. Too bad he didn't put the same effort into creating a terrific story, especially since there was so much potential to work with. The 1968 original is considered a Sci-Fi classic, not just because of the story, but also the issues it dealt with. It used a society where apes are the top species to comment on and satirize our own society. There are moments of this in "Apes 2001", but mostly it's another big budget action film, only with actors in monkey costumes. As proof of this, the lead character, played by Mark Wahlberg (aka Marky Mark) is just another hotshot fighter jock, meaning there's no problem he thinks he can't solve by simply blasting the bad guy to bits. Which is a shame, since it would be much more interesting to see him outwit his enemies, thus showing who really was the superior species. Also, it doesn't help that the female lead, played by Helena Bonham Carter, doesn't even remotely look like a real chimp. I guess Burton & Co. couldn't resist making her look sexy, complete with a fashionable hairstyle. So, ultimately what you have is lots of good looks, but not much in the way of brains. I'm looking forward to viewing the 1968 original, just to see how this film falls short by comparison. 5/10

title: Call it a letdown, worsened by the forces of shoddy screenwriting.
text: Burton's singular vision is missing from this mishmash of a remake, part sci-fi, part adventure, part ape-human romance, but unsatisfying on any level. Mark Wahlberg's pallid turn doesn't help and neither does the PG-13 rating which proves confining

title: Smarter than the Original
text: The original Planet of the Apes has been around for over 30 years so It's not that big of a suprise that the fans of it didn't like this version. They left their comic book stores and went to the theater expecting a shot by shot remake of the original. Well -- suprise! -- This wasn't a remake. Tim Burton's Apes was a different story all together with a similar --more sensible-- plot.   This one, in my opinion, was better. It contained connections to not only the first few movies in the series but to the novel as well [examples being with the GREAT suprise ending or the 'fun for the whole family' monkey named Pericles - who sadly died in the book]. Also, The Special Make Up Effects to this 2001 version --when analyzed-- blew the original out of the water. Rick Baker's work to this is his best since 'an American Werewolf in London'. When you combine all of that with Danny Elfman's pounding score and Tim Burton's smooth direction you get something that hasn't been conceived since Warner Brothers' BATMAN was released.   Oh, and In regards to a few news group critics' spiteful reviews, Tim Burton's visual style is very much evident in this million dollar 'Blockbuster' movie. If you'll think back to the cold white/black contrasting space station segments or the jungle / desert shot lay-ups then you'll realize that a sort of Hitchcock reminiscent style of frame composition is present. That's pure Tim Burton. The colors and set designs are prime examples.   In my opinion, Don't you compare this one to the original, it's a great movie on it's own. It explains more than the original did --or the book-- and makes more sense, like how the apes speak English. Tim Burton hasn't done something of this calibre since his 1989 comic book film renderings. So in summation, for all of you whiny little 1960's Apes Fanatics, just think about the references this one made to the original, Think about how much better the old one could have been and think mostly about why the movie made so much money - if it was so bad? Tim Burton's a genius artist and this film was his pallet.

title: Silly and sophomoric
text: It's easy to feel sorry for the actors in this weak update to the Sci-Fi classic.  These are cartoon characters with about as much depth as a rain puddle.  The script they're forced to use is chockablock with utterances such as "I'm sick of this human" which kicks off the key battle scene. And, simply "Gotta go," as Leo (Mark Whalberg) bids adieu to his gorgeous model Daena (Estella Warren).  Maybe the only reason to see it is to try to puzzle through the twisty ending.  Better yet, have someone tell you what happens and save the money.

title: No point to this film - avoid!
text: The original Planet of the Apes is a much more satisfying picture than this pathetic attempt. There is no point to this film. There's no strong narrative, there's no strong plot, and a major miscast!Marky Mark gives his worst performance yet, there are no layers to his acting in this one! He looked bored!The film lacks original plot ideas, anything new is laughable. The humans serve no purpose in the film, there's no conflict amongst them. The whole slave thing is old and tired.The make-up is tremendous, Baker deserves all the accolades! The direction by Burton is easily one of his worst, he needed a lot more time to develop the picture. Visually, the film is excellent, dark and moody at times. A sequel might be better handled by Burton, I think it's suited to his eccentric style.Stick with the original, miles better than this post-modern work.

title: A horrible re-make of a classic
text: This movie has fails to create any sense of empathy towards its human characters.  There is absolutely no reason to care for the humans aside from the fact that they look like us.  Very poor script. I have no idea why Tim Burton let this script, with its crappy dialogue (I'm going to get my chimp!) be realized into a film that will waste millions of people's lives as they sit in darken theaters for no reason.

title: Better than I remember but the ending.
text: I remember watching this in the theater and being extremely disappointed. The original POTA is imbedded in the culture and it's ending can't be topped. In this reimagined version you can't have a twist ending, nothing can beat the original. Looking at it again it's makeup and acting ( not Mark Wahlberg ) is exceptional. The creepy way Lia looks at Davidson is culminating in a crowd inducing cringe kiss. The new ending might be interesting to those people who have read the book but it disappointed everyone else. So much work and potential waisted on a weak ending. It's better than my first reaction maybe you should give it a second watch.

title: Tim Burtons Best
text: This movie is definitely Tim Burtons best. This movie also gets criticized by many people which it does not deserve at all. It is entertaining and has terrific make up work. I think it should get nominated for an oscar for its make up. The movie did not make as much money as I expected. It made $178 Million and I expected it to make at least 200 million but there was so much competition that i think it did fine, and will do much better on video and dvd.

title: It's just not Burton!
text: My Take: A few good moments and some fine make-up work, but not Burton's very best movies. Director Tim Burton, so far, has started and continued a promising career as a Hollywood filmmaker. So far, his first films I saw was "Beetlejuice" and "Batman", both are well-done. Burton continued such masterpieces like the sequel "Batman Returns", "Edward Scissorhands" and the highly acclaimed "Ed Wood". Even his dark comedy "Mars Attacks", which proved a little different from his other films, is still a great funny entertainment, which was a little better than the too-serious "Independence Day". Besides, when it comes to Burton's different film, it can only be this, a remake of the classic adaptation of Pierre Boulle's classic "Planet of the Apes".Just by looking at the results of this film, I'm sure that Burton was out of place here. No matter how brilliant he is as a director, the epic genre is something he's not in to. His films are usually the bizarre, or fairy tale-like films, combined with some dark comedy and satire. "Planet of the Apes" has none of those. It's a full-blood epic that revolves around man battling a more intelligent species that they weren't aware that will out-evolve them. In other words, the plot for "Planet of the Apes" is darn serious. Burton, most usually don't take everything seriously, and likes to look at the weird side. Since this film has no room for any of those, it's easy to see a failure. The make-up effects by Rick Baker are truly superb, giving each Ape character its own different look and personality. I guess that more than makes up for the films blander human characters, say Mark Wahlberg as a bland, often unconvincing action hero. Certainly, Tim Roth as the overreacting human-hating ape Thade, Helen Bonham Carter's human-loving ape Ari and many of the other simian co-stars steal the show, providing some terrific performances while under that heavy does of make-up. It ain't Burton at his definitive best, and PLANET OF THE APES certainly doesn't end being the summer's biggest blockbuster (even JURASSIC PARK III has more to offer than this). An intriguing yet misguided disappointment. Rating: **1/2 out of 5.

title: Rules
text: I thought that the movie was great. Being a big fan of the first movies. I was happy wish the new version. I can't wait for a sequel. It was different then the first in that it gave a great leads into sequels. Like why was the planet uninhabited at first and the end had a great twist to start right there. The Apes themselves were outstanding. I love that Charlton Heston was in the movie and thought all of the main characters were great. I would say that everyone should own a copy of this DVD. It will make you wish you had seen it on the big screen (I did so I am happy). The only bad thing is that instead of being 2 hours long it should have been four.... lol... then i wouldn't have to start it over so soon and have a larger story line.

title: Just Awful!
text: Sorry everyone, this reinvention of the 1968 classic just isn't up to par. Mark Walhberg as the astronaut is awful. His acting ruined what might have been a strong male lead. He is not believable in his role. The ape make up is Oscar worthy, though at most times it distracts from the already weak plot and make most dialogue incomprehensible. This film parodies the previous "Ape" film with several one-liners. This is not supposed to be a comedy or satire, it is a "message" movie on how we treat and behave towards other beings. At least that was what the novel and 1968 version was about. I think another problem was that the director did not know whether to have the apes behave like apes or humans. Dd they evolve and become human like or retain there ape behavious and just learn to speak? So many questions? Goofs? Disjointed plotlines and other errors that cannot be detailed without giving away the plot. Enjoy the make up and effects but that's it!!!!!

title: Melody Perkins Strikes Back
text: Marky Mark,fresh off of the success of the blockbuster smashes "Fear" & "Boogie Nights", does battle with simians from another planet in Tim Burton's monkey nonsense of epic budget.On par with the first two sequels in the previous series,but not nearly as wrenched as the the justly forgotten TV series,or the last sequel,"Battle" for that matter. At least it's better than the Disney remake of Mighty Joe Young,saved only by the special effects of ape wizard Rick Baker,who did honors on both,& in an uncredited role,wreaked vengeance as the title role in the infamous 1976 King Kong version of the often told tale.While on the subject of Dirty Apes & remakes,one only wishes that Peter Jackson had cast the lovely Miss Melody Perkins (who has a small cameo role here),in the part of the damsel in distress role made famous previously by Fay Wray & Jessica Lange prior in the upcoming third take.She had the beauty & the brains,not to mention the cunning charisma, to pull it off.

title: A New Masterpiece!
text: I loved this movie.  When I first heard that Planet of the Apes was being remade, I was so incredibly disgusted.  I loved the original series of movies, and I felt there was absolutely no way they could even come close to making a decent film.  And I was pleasantly shocked.  Right from the beginning of the film, you could tell it was directed very well.  And the movie kept a very good pace, I was never bored.  I loved the costumes, the music, and the attention to detail.  I also thought the film was very well acted by all.  In a weird sense, I was reminded of Star Wars, maybe it was the scenes of the ape city.  The ending, I'm not sure it sat well with me, but I understood why it was done that way.  I really enjoyed this film, which is a very rare occurrence these days.  I'm a movie snob and tend to only like the older films.  But this new film was very good and I highly recommend it.  The story stands out on it's own and doesn't need the original films at all.  Even Charlton Heston's cameo was great!

title: Excellent retelling of a classic film!!
text:
Apes rule! This movie is simply fantastic! From the great special effects, to the incredible cast, to apes that look and move like apes, nothing is missing. Roll over Heston, as Mark Wahlberg now rules the planet as head human.The story is different from the original movie, however, director Tim Burton did a very credible job in this film. The movie begins with Mark Wahlberg going after his lost chimpanzee into an electrical storm in space. This electrical storm sends our hero hundreds of years into the future, where he crash lands onto the planet of the apes. I will stop with the summary here, as there are many unexpected occurences throughout the movie.The greatest part of this film, is the casting of Tim Roth as Thade, the ape general. This is definately the best acting job he has ever done.
Take a chance on this one, I really do not think that you will be disappointed with it.

title: Rated H for HORROR -- and for horrible.
text: OK - They definitely tried to make this one different from the first film -- hence the term re-imaging. Of course, like the first film, it was only BASED on Pierre Boulle's novel. Like the 1968 film -- the only thing this film has to connect it to Pierre Boulle's work is the title (and a single plot twist). This film does deal with the same moral issues as the original (bigotry) and has some interesting angles of political ambition thrown in to the mix. However, the film ultimately failed to capture my interest as the original did. The characterizations were just flat and 2-dimensional. The ending was the only thing that was shocking. THADE had been beaten, yet his defeat ultimately won him the world he had sought to make.This twist ending was straight out of the book, but I wasted my time for all intents and purposes. If they wanted to resurrect the franchise, they should have done a continuation from where the originals left off. I rate this film H for HORROR and horrible.

title: Anger doesn't begin to express my feelings.....
text: If there is a bigger waste of time than this movie was, please let me know so I can avoid it at all costs!!! Makeup:  good, set design: outstanding, acting: awful, script and dialog: the worst piece of rubbish yet this year. Just because it is said to be a revision doesn't give it the right to completely be disrespectful of the audiences intelligence. To go from sleepy hollow (which I enjoyed throughly) to this?  Tim why don't you write your own movies anymore? The original was thought provoking, insightful, revolutionary, and downright entertaining.  This........this was worse than Armageddon!!! This is what happens when you let Hollywood decide what is best for a remake...oops I mean redelusion. Blah. I'd rather watch the Battle for the Planet of the Apes (the weakest of the series) on a 24 hour loop then ever see this again. At least Aldo would make me smile with his terrible acting because his was probably only paid in peanuts (no pun intended) due to budget restraints. Not paid a fortune like Marky Mark to be the Hero in this movie. He can only muster himself up to sounding like Dirk Diggler in the documentries from Boogie Nights, only there is no fake apendage to help him out this time.........I must stop now or I will explode....ahhhhh!!!!!

title: CANNOT WAIT FOR THE SEQUEL! TIM BURTON BETTER MAKE A SEQUEL! AND MORE SEQUELS!
text: This dramatic, dark, deceptive and very entertaining tale of action, fantasy, black humor, romance, and drama was brilliant! Great make up work was put into this movie, some brilliant performances by humans and apes and I've never seen the original but I'm convinced that this one is much better! I better not give you the ending, BUT I CAN TELL YOU RIGHT NOW THAT TIM BURTON BETTER MAKE A SEQUEL OR 2 OR 3....! WHATEVER!

title: Depressing
text: Have just watched this and am completely unmoved.I am a big fan of some of Tim Burton's work.  I was never that big a fan of the original movie, finding it a goofy B movie that has seen its reputation grow in recent years much like the band Kiss.  So I did have some hope that, despite the mixed reviews, I might come down on the positive side.Early on, I sort of liked it.  I liked the way the apes acted more like apes in their movement and mannerisms, but soon I felt that it was becoming unnecessary comic relief - sort of like bad old movies poking fun at racial stereotypes.  And yes, Wahlberg is a failure in the lead role.  He seems curiously detached and his performance just sucks energy out of the movie.But Estella Warren is the tip-off here.  We have a supermodel in a skimpy outfit who serves no purpose in the film other than someone/thing to look at.  Why is she here?  I am convinced more than ever that this element, as well as others, ended up there as a result of market research and studio demands as opposed to anything resembling "artistic vision" by the director.From there, I can only think that we are starting to witness the downfall of Burton.  Much as Coppola went from "The Conversation" and "Apocalypse Now" to "Jack" (not that I mean to say that Burton's aspirations were ever the equal of the messages that Coppola conveyed in his best work).  Any pretense of Burton as an artist or visionary is gone with this film.  He might as well direct Lethal Weapon 5 next.

title: Out of this world (parden the pun)
text: Well Tim Burton has done it again. With amazing special effects,makeup and sound but unlike most big summer block-busters this has a great script and nearly tops the statue of liberty ending. The acting is great as well. Especially Tim Roth as the main villian General Thade. Behind Shrek,Evolution and Swordfish as quality films of the summer.

title: 5 out of 10
text: Tim Roth and Michael Clarke Duncan are fantastic in their roles and they truly convince as evolved apes.  Mark Whalberg and Estella Warren, on the other hand are more wooden than a log cabin convention.  The make-up is impressive, but from such a visionary director as Tim Burton, you'd have expected far more.  It seems that the executives were convinced that as many references to the original 'Apes' film will be funny, but instead they only emphasise how much worse this 'reimagination is'.The apes are great, it's the humans that don't convince.

title: Well...there it is.
text: Yup. Hollywood has made another expensive movie from an older movie. Some of the scenes looked unrealistic, but expensive.There were attractive people.  (More than the earlier film, I might add.)I paid $8.50 to see it.I left satisfied that I would not have rather seen any other movie out right now.My friends heartily agreed.I feel that if I sneaked my cat into the theatre he wouldn't have understood.I don't understand, either.My lack of dissatisfaction for the film was average.I don't know when I'll want to do this again.I don't think I will buy this on DVD, but there are other films I don't own, also.Yup.  There it is.

title: Those nostalgic for the original take heart- there's still only one Cornelious
text:
Show of hands...how many of you were secretly ecstatic over the thought of A. Marky Mark, er, Mark Wahlberg (excuse me) all muddied up running around a Tim Burton set and B. that they were even remaking this accidental classic, which easily is near the top of America's Cheesiest Films Of All Times list (right below Blackula, Killer Tomatoes and Jon Waters' purposely cheesy farces of course).For those too young to remember, Planet of the Apes first appeared in 1968. It was a sensation with audiences and panned by critics. The costumes were state-of-the-art for the times and the sets were as other worldly as they could portray in a sixties Star Trek quazi-realism way.Those who enjoyed the first version(s) even passed up the concession stand goodies for fear of losing that comfy close-up seat. The suspense of what the apes would look with all the modern gizmos the FX folks have at their disposal nowadays was almost unbearable. Like with The Grinch's recent successful transformation into 21st century-gadget- hoopla- infused- bing- bam box-office magic, TPOA does not disappoint on that level.As for the the rest of the film? Well, the plot is as deep as Green Eggs and Ham and the "human" cast is about as exciting as an instructional video on an anal polyp removal from the lower bowel of a brown field mouse, yet still, mad-director Tim Burton left just enough camp to keep it, surprisingly, enjoyable.The story goes...Astronaut; Leo Davidson (Mark "softly spoken" Wahlberg) is aboard a space station USS Oberon, training primates to play Astronaut. One starry night he is told to send one of these Chimps out to research a menacing energy field approaching fast on their starboard side.The "canary in the coal mine" never returns...So, Leo, bored with his mundane duties anyhow, jumps into a delta pod to rescue the fellow, and, surprise, gets transported through time to a place ruled by...He crash lands safely in an eerie swamp. But, before he can shake his banana dry, he is over run by a group of fear-for-their-lives types ricocheting through the forest being pursued by dressed, orating, violent apes. Leo is trapped, along with these ratty anorexic -Mad Max looking- extras each with a perpetual glaze over their faces like deer locked on headlights (or Nick Cage in an emotional scene), and sent to market. The market is run by Limbo (brilliant Paul Giamatti) a sleazy Orang creep.Leo and a boopsie faced tribe gal, Deana (Estella " be careful of bimbo typecasting  dear" Warren), meet in one of Limbo's human slave holding cells. She's smitten, but he's focused on his personal inner dialog, his sequel, "Exit El Quicko from the Planet Of The Apes."They end up working together and gather a few others including, human rights activist girly ape Ari (Helena Bonham Carter). They all escape the city and head to "rendezvous" with Leo's space colleagues who have been sending out a signal to him via his space age transmitter he rescued from his sunken space pod. The humans hope Leo is their savior fallen from the sky to save them from the mini-Kongs that suppress them. Leo hopes his friends are waiting for him, just over the mountain rangeThe fleeing party faces some pretty mean mother-apers en route to Shangri-La! One ape in particular, General Thad, (Tim Roth) hates humans in a Hitler- southern plantation owner-circa 1800 way. He wants the filthy creatures (humans) completely annihilated and is schmoozing with the ape senate to get his wish. Leo is just what the nefarious Thad ordered when praying to their almighty Semos for a sign the humans must all go. With Leo's frightening display of intelligence and back bone, the senate will be scared bananaless into giving Thad the Marshal Law decree he so desires.
Will Leo and his new tribal friends make it to the space command center before Thad's wicked army finds and crushes them? Is Leo the god they have waited for all these years? Could the last fight scene be tackier?Don't worry, I'm not ruining anything here for you...It's so telegraphed G.W. Bush would know the ending half way through. Okay, maybe right before the credits at least.The story is a tad blasé. You may find yourself adrift about the screen, looking for something to busy your brain when Mark and crew aren't battling the Apes. Which brings up a kind of humorous point of observation, Wahlberg's "Leo" has like three sentences of dialog in a scene, then smacko, he's immediately in primal combat again; like an odd ballet of film you watch and keep a mental metronome swaying in your head1-2-3 fight, 1-2-3 fight.TPOA is really all about the visual treats; like watching intense thespian Tim Roth bounce about like an extra at Ringling Bros. & Barnum Bailey Circus of the Cruel in his cute little money, er, ape suit. Tim Roth's "Thad" was super creepy. Hate oozes from his furry little pores to the point were you feared he may really have gone rabid. Even with all the schtuffamagal Roth had burying his features, the feeling and depth from the actor beneath came through. Or Helena Bonham Carter, all made up in ten pounds of latex, a far cry from the West End beauty she is, for sure. Still a lady, even as an ape.Then there's MM Wahlberg. His picture is in Compton's Encyclopedia under "example of the Male Homo Sapiens " -In my version anyway The man's body is, simply, dare I say, perfect. He's a double cream serving of Pistachio Ice cream with a hidden layer of marshmallow fluff. Scrumptious. Leo was a dull character so MM's signature "whisper" delivery worked. I think I need a Boogie Nights fix...TPOA has quite a few exciting moments. Enough to recommend it. Those nostalgic for the original take heart- there's still only one Cornelious (Roddy McDowall) and this is not a replacement, it's just another look at a pretty wild concept , modernized for the new generation to enjoy.
An aside: Danny Elfman, Timmie Burtonski's favorite music man, is back incahoots producing the film's score. As always, Elfman delivers a catchy, flowing gently ominous orchestration of notes.Snack recommendation: Banana nut pound cake and Pistachio ice cream.

title: Pretty disappointing.
text: I expected the new 2001 Planet Of The Apes movie to be a high-tech blast of chills, thrills, and spills.  It had none of that, I was not chilled or spilled.  But I was thrilled at the end! That was pretty cool.  But I won't tell ya anything about the ending so don't worry.  Of course, the ending was nothing compared to the original- (and if you haven't seen the original I won't give that ending away, either.) Some scenes were quite ridiculous, though.  And the storyline was not as good as the original.  Although at least Tim Burton had his own special storyline instead of copying the original's. Overall, it wasn't a bad movie.  If you like movies without blood and a lot of swearing, and you are not totally opposed to science fiction, I think you won't be disappointed, but won't be exactly thrilled either.Not Too Shabby!-madmax-1

title: Mediocre
text: I remember watching this 2001 film by Tim Burton for the first time on VHS/DVD in early 2003 when I was a preteen. I thought it was going to be amazing but it's not very good as the orignal one which was released in 1968. It's kinda mediocre. Not all remakes/reboots are good as the original ones, you know.I prefer to the orignal 1968 version and I'd say it is definitely way better than that bland 2001 film and Rise of the Planet of the Apes and its sequels are way better than that 2001 same film as well.I don't dislike it at all but it's just not great as the classic 1968 film or the reboot of the Planet of the Apes film series. I'm afraid I'll just have to totally forget about it and move on.

title: Wanted to fling my feces at the screen
text: Argh. There was a time when Tim Burton had a flair for the visually interesting. Remember Gotham City? Sleepy Hollow? The Afterlife waiting room in "Beetlejuice"? Not anymore. Here he had a chance to re-create a whole planet and my response was a huge yawn. The movie's not all that good either. It's not sure what it wants to be at times - a run-of-the-mill action flick (With cliched dialogue); a remake of the original; even an English bedroom farce (when Marky Mark & Friends escape they HAVE to run through the bedrooms of each important ape in the city, apparently). It also criminally mis-uses Michael Clarke Duncan and Tim Roth. In the end, the whole thing ends like an episode of "Sliders".

title: Beware of the apes
text: Much like most of Burton's work, visually stunning, but lacking in substance (a la Sleepy Hollow).  Kudos to the make up and effects teams - outstanding visuals.  How many more chances will this director get to waste money, talent, and effects. Movie is slow, unexciting, uninspiring, improbable and has numerous plot holes.  The ending will not leave you with a sense of irony but will leave you scratching your head like a chimp.  A disappointment.

title: I thought I was going to see Jurassic Park 3!!!
text: I saw this movie in a single-screen theatre in Minden, a town just south of our cottage. I thought I was going to see Jurassic Park 3, but this was playing instead. Anyways, I'm not sure why I stayed. This is a really bad movie and, even though I can't compare it to the original which i haven't seen, I'm sure the original made a lot more sense at the end. Even though I thought Estella Warren was dead sexy, the movie stunk like crap.I did eventually see JP3, which was better than this movie but still the worst of the JP trilogy. I still say this is the worst thing I have seen in the theatres.

title: remake or re-creation... weak either way
text: Crash landing... capture... escape... battle... the end.  Intricate plot isn't it?  Burton decides to sidestep any meaningful themes in this film, and that's a shame.  There are a dozen social issues that could have been examined in the movie, but apparently Burton was in a hurry to get to the Braveheart-style Ape vs. Human battle.  As for the acting: Wahlberg was a jerk, Roth was too dramatic, Michael Clarke Duncan was bland, and Estella Warren hardly said a word.  The only worthwhile performance was from Helena Bonham Carter.  As for the ending, it's sad that Burton felt he had to match (or top) the original by throwing in that outrageous ending.  He fell short by a longshot.  I suppose the movie was entertaining if you didn't compare it to the original... but can you really watch it without comparing?

title: Beats the original!!
text: Either the NRA has taken over this page, or I saw a different film as most of the other IMDb users.  If this film proves anything, it's that Tim Burton is one of the greatest creative minds in cinematic history.  When I saw the trailer I feared this one wouldn't be as dark as his previous efforts, but there are still plenty Burtonesque images for the fans to be happy.I saw the original Charlton Heston film and although I appreciated the camp qualities and the shock ending, it was basically nothing more then a long episode of the muppet show.  This version has so much more style and the apes are truly impressive, you forget they're just humans, unlike in the original.  Rick Baker deserves an oscar for his work. I also think Mark Whalberg makes a much more realistic hero then Heston. While Charlton was happy enough to fight 'them darn monkeys', the only thing Whalberg cares about is to get the hell out of there, with or without the other humans. About the 'twist'ending (don't worry I'm not gonna spoil it), well I didn't see it coming, as did nobody else in the audience.So don't let all the negative reviews scare you, this movie is really worth seeing!!

title: A silly monkey movie..
text: Tim Burton has gone steadily downhill since Beetlegeuse.  I thought directors were supposed to get better with experience. This movie is a waste.  The special effects, makeup and costuming are fine. But the plot has holes large enough for several large semis loaded with gorillas. The character development is weaker than Schreck...its just a waste of actors and money.  I would go see almost anything else if you are in a movie mood.

title: Good, but not good enough
text: The trailers were good, and I'd heard that it was supposed to be a good movie. Unfortunately, I left the cinema quite disappointed.The costumes and make-up was magnificent! The special effects were very good (though we're all becoming used to computer generated special effects these days, aren't we??)But the story was pathetic and poorly acted. Disappointing, even.

title: Apeheart!
text: I approached with caution...having been a fan of the original films.  I rented the film on DVD, sat back and waiting to be disappointed.  I wasn't. Tim Burton takes the original idea and makes something new (and better?) out of it.  Fans of the original film shouldn't consider this a remake, more a homage.  Burton adds his own twists, which work well, and the ending is more than adequate (especially when you're trying to top the shock ending of the first film).  I can't believe I enjoyed it, but I did and would recommend anyone who was put off should give it a chance...

title: Burton's Reimagining: The Major Problems
text:
Like almost every viewer of the latest "Planet of the Apes" who has chosen to comment on the film, I too have been disappointed by the latest version, seeing how it falls short of the freshness that Tim Burton brought to many of his films. In some respects though, I am not as harsh in my criticism as others.It is naive to compare Burton's latest film to his more offbeat successes like "Ed Woods," "Edward Scissorhands," and "The Nightmare Before Christmas". Those were personal projects, conceived and driven by him, not projects like the "Batman" films which were studio-driven and intended, first and foremost, as money machines. As such, it was highly unlikely that he would have been allowed a great deal of license. (Remember the fate of his planned version of "Superman" with Nicholas Cage? I'm sure Burton does.)However, Burton *can* be faulted in two places. First, the one point in the story where originality and daring might have played a role was in the Leo/Ari/Daena relationship. I wouldn't call it a love triangle--even though it was promoted as such--since Wahlberg's Leo never registers any particular emotion towards either female. Part of this must be attributed to the script which doesn't give him any lines or action to suggest attraction towards either Bonham-Carter's Ari or Estella Warren's Daena (though that a more resourceful actor could have communicated something nonverbally).Despite having Bonham-Carter display obvious interest in Wahlberg, Burton fails to follow through by having his Leo reciprocate (or at least display ambivalence about a female chimp flirting with him).
The studio's reported objections to a graphic love scene are not surprising. What *is* strange is why Burton introduced the idea and then failed to develop it. Certainly a skillful director can explore the idea of such an unusual relationship without resorting to explicit sex; but Burton just teases us with the idea and then drops it.Equally disappointing is the ending. While I will not divulge it, I think it is enough to say that it has no meaningful connection to what precedes it. A "problematic" ending of a film at least allows workable interpretations. Burton's ending does not. A *major* flaw in any sort of story.

title: Summer movie filler...could've been better with more thought and time...
text: A summer movie, popcorn, bad script and cool FX...The Make-up creations by Rick Baker kicked butt!!! But I cannot recommend the 'new' version of 'Planet of the Apes' even for that point. Tim Burton has helmed a film that has the 'taint' of 'HOLLYWOOD' all over it...I was expecting a PIZZA HUT box to show up on the obvious sets...Everyone involved has simply hacked it out...besides the rightious make-up, the only other noteworthy aspect of the film is the decent acting by the actors playing APES...(Especially Tim Roth as the main villian...he was very menacing...) those without make-up had little or nothing to do. Sitting down and thinking it over, I realized that I hated seeing this film, and hope that Tim Burton and all involved will have better luck on their next projects...I'd rather watch 'Dude where's my car?' that sit through this big budget hooey again...4 out of 10

title: Very Good, Original Story
text: This movies deserves a rating of 8 just for the surprise twist at the end, about which I will say no more.I hadn't really been expecting that much from this when I rented the video; I rather thought that the "Apes" franchise had been done to death back in the late 60's - early 70's, with a collection of movies and a TV series that went progressively downhill and became more nonsensical with each installment. But I was very pleasantly surprised by this movie, which was very entertaining and - if I recall correctly (although it's been many years since I read it) is more consistent with the story of Pierre Bouille's original novel. So, my advice is that if you're either avoiding this or watching it because you expect it to be like the "Apes" movies of thirty years ago, plan to watch it on its own merits instead.The cast was in general very good. Mark Wahlberg did a fine job as the astronaut Leo Davidson, stranded on this nightmare of a planet (for him) with no obvious way of getting home. Tim Roth as his primary ape antagonist, General Thade, was also very good. I had a mixture of reactions to Helena Bonham Carter's role as Ari, the human-loving ape. Her performance was quite good, but, frankly, I found her character to be rather irritating. It's a necessary role. We have to see these divisions in ape society, but the character just didn't appeal to me in the same way as, say, Cornelius and Zera did in the original movie. I also thought the ape makeup was rather weak. Frankly, they did a better job thirty years ago.But those minor criticisms aside, I really did enjoy this movie. It was a fast-paced story that held my attention, there was enough humour to make it fun, and enough drama to make me wonder how Davidson was ever going to get out of this. And - as I said at the start - the end itself is worth watching the whole movie.I rate this as an 8/10.

title: Why did they do this?
text: There is only one thing to say about this movie. Uuuugggghhhhhhh!!! No plot, bad acting and an ending that confused everyone in the theater killed this movie. There are some movies that are classics without a remake. Tim Burton, shame on you.

title: the apes lose the plot!
text: I have just returned from the cinema, having looked forward to this film as Tim Burton is god and I have always liked the original film.However, what started as quite an enjoyable sci fi romp quickly degraded into a godawful mess.  We were expected to believe in the characters and actually feel for them, but how could we when we barely knew their names?  When discussing the film with my friend afterwards we were referring to "blonde slave girl" and "helena bonham carter" and "that guy from the green mile".  but that wasn't the only problem with the film.  The script was full of so many plot holes that by the time the end rolled around you were scratching your head and wondering if they were going to explain it.  they didn't. and then the ending... well, when  trying to fit it in with the context of the preceding story it smacks more of an opening for the sequel... will marky mark escape from the planet of the apes, tune in same time next week!  oh, tim, tim tim... i still believe in you.

title: good, worth a watch
