text: 'Planet of the Apes' (2001) should be watched as a separate film and not as a re-make of the original film because the two films are completely different. I think that a lot of people did not enjoy this film because they tried to compare it to the original 1968 film. In truth, the stories and characters are different. Remaking the original film would not have been a good idea because most people know the ending; this film takes a different approach. The human lands on the planet, and he is taken hostage with some other humans, and together, they learn the history of the planet. In this film, however, the presence of a villain character is an important part of the film. No, this film is not as good as the 1968 one, even though they are different stories, but it is still enjoyable. The script was done well, but it was not as engaging and not as memorable. It's captivating as an action/adventure film with some science fiction elements, even though it does not go the extra way to create a true classic. Still, it's good if you're looking for something fun to watch.

title: Unnecessary Remake
text: PLANET OF THE APES   * *   Unnecessary remake brings nothing new to the table in terms of imagination or inspiration.  Performances by Helena Bonham Carter,  Tim Roth and many of the others playing apes are the only redeeming features.  Everything money can buy, expensive sets, makeup, costumes and actors, can't make up for an incoherent and illogical script.   Finally, if the average movie  goer has to research the internet to try to understand the final scene, then the moviemakers haven't done their job.

title: Don't bother to "monkey" with this dog
text: I was appalled! I waisted how much on this? Even my popcorn had a funny taste! This movie lacked it all: Acting, script, direction, logic, originality and, most of all, heart.   I saw the original in the theater in first release- I took (pardon me tortured) my daughter to the first release of this re-make. She was bored, I was enraged- we both wanted to leave early and get back in the mall. I have only walked out on one movie- "Visiting Hours" - but was considering a repeat ! Only the critic's comments about the "silly ending" kept me in the theater and, when it came, I said "I waited for this?" Yah, the makeup was superb... so what?  Yah the special effects were 21st century... so what? I liked the scene with Charlton Heston repeating his "Damn them to Hell" speech... ummm   thats it. Oh, Ya.. did i mention the popcorn was stale?                               2 out of 10

title: too fast!
text:
Does this movie MOVE! Don't blink or you might miss - the plot? You didn't miss it, it really was that short.Here's a tip off for a bad script: If you see more than one name in the writing credit, WATCH OUT!There are alot of reviews of this blockbuster, so I will just ask a few questions which you could answer as you watch the film:Was Michael Clarke Duncan was the only ape that sort of looked like himself? (A nice touch that George Lucas did in the Phantom Meanace).Did you catch the meaning of CALIMA? CAution LIve ANimals, easy to miss!If the apes wanted no one to go to CALIMA, why was the it so poorly protected?If it was the center of their universe for thousands of years and so easy to reach, why were there no apes AT ALL there? Wouldn't they come to "worship" at least?How come Davidson all of a sudden cares about this kid? Just exactly what was the point of having him stay behind the ship? Who was the kid? What the heck was going on there?Did you care at all when Kris Kristofferson got killed? Nope!
Did you care a little when a couple of guys in Davidson's original band got iced? Only a little.What was the point (from the writer's point of few) of taking out the (cool) gun? He brought back later, anyway. With two guns, that might have been fun. One guy shooting up himself was just stupid, didn't you think?Just exactly where did all the aps and all the humans come from? I mean, seriously, would the humans live so close to the apes if they were rounding them up as pets and slaves? Give me a break! I'd have found a better neighborhood.  (On top of that, there's a little problem of genetic diversity here of there were no natural apes and humans on this planet in the first place. But, we'll give Tim poetic license on that).So, the GOD arrives, literally out of the sky in a space ship. NO ONE is scared of this technology AT ALL. They recognize this is a prophecy come true yet they have NO PROBLEM letting the UNCLEAN Davidson walk right up to their DEITY.  Then, they proceed to beat the daylights out of the diety nearly kill him.  (I guess that answers why no one was worshiping). Question: Is there a story here or not? No!Would a good alternate title be "Crouching Humans, Hidden Monkeys?"Who exactly would have the Lincoln-esq Thade have liberated to get the statue? I think it might have been humans, don't you? So, maybe Davidson didn't do as bad as is implied. (But, now, it looks as if he should have stuffed the girl into the capsule with him, eh?)How did this movie get made? Here's a senario:(Office of Richard Zanuck, producer)
ZANUCK: What did you think of that script I told you to read?FLUNKY: Great movie, sir.ZANUCK: Who does the make up on "Star Trek?" Do we have anyone who can do that stuff?FLUNKY: Yes, sir!ZANUCK: Don't just stand there? Where's my bagel?(Two days later, Tim Burton's office)ZANUCK: Well, Tim, what do you think of the script I sent over. My brother-in-laws newphew's Dentist calls it "The Visitor."BURTON: I wouldn't have my name associated with this recycled waste. It's a remake of Planet of the Apes!ZANUCK: I knew that.BURTON: Well, then, get lost. I don't do remakes!ZANUCK: (non plussed) We're offering 25 million.BURTON: Well, my Rolls is looking rusty. OK! I'll do it!

title: Lacking yet fun
text: Misguided rehap of the 1968 film gives the apes more character than the humans! Wahlberg is underwritten as the astronaut who has only one major objective: get the hell out of there. Movie doesn't quite surface as potential genius, lacking thought and enigma that could leave it memorable. Still, Burton's own slick style and ambitious special effects make for a fun romp. Excellent, necessary score by Danny Elfman carries the film well.

title: I got myself hyped about nothing.
text: All summer i was waiting for this movie to come out. I thought it was going to be really cool. I was disappointed. Don't get me wrong, this had great make-up, costumes, and art derection, but it left out alot of things. For the most part this was a good movie. It just wasn't what I had expected. Action in it was cool. It could have done better on dialog. but that's just what i think.

title: A terrible film that totally sells out.
text: I was anxious to see this film, thinking that it might pay tribute to the greatness of the original. What I found was that the film was poorly written, and it lost all of the flavor of the original. All of the social commentary is gone, as well as all of the mystery. The plot has been replaced by some substitute filler, and the entire thing wreaked of recycled plastic. Although I did find some scenes laughable (most notably the ones that required acting) I would see it once just to know what I am talking about. If you are looking for some of Tim Burton's better work, look elsewhere.

title: a weak summer movie
text: i was hoping for so much more than this from a director as good as tim burton, but i left the cinema extremely disappointed. visually this film is impressive, you can see nearly all the budget being shown on the screen, the apes themselves are very convincing. the main problems lie firstly in the acting (the apparent love between Estella Warren and Mark Wahlberg is laughably unconvincing).... only Tim Roth and Helena Bonham Carter show any form of skill... the second problem is the terrible script which doesn't waste it's time in resorting to cliche and annoying post-modern referential dialog.... and the ENDING(!) is the biggest load of rubbish I've ever had the misfortune to witness this film pales in comparison to the originals

title: People need to calm down
text:
Take this movie for what it is, not a remake, but a completely different approach to the same concept.  It's not an epic like the original, it's more of a popcorn thriller.  Visually, it's incredible.  Everything else was just OK.  For what it is, I think the movie is awesome, but I like everything Burton has done.  People need to calm down and stop acting like it's the end of the world b/c of this movie.  It wasn't supposed to be a remake, and it's not. 
The ending was cool. . I took it as a parallel universe.

title: The little movie that could... but didn't.
text:
Planet of the Apes has many things going for it.  The first three are the creative minds of Tim Burton (director), Rick Baker (Make-up), and Danny Elfman (Music).  The sets and locations work well with the costuming and make-up to give this an original look and an authentic feel even though it is a remake.  The cinematography and music work well together because neither one overshadows the other making the combination very powerful.
The acting was good and I must take my hat off to Helena Bonham Carter and to Tim Roth who did exceptional in their portrayals.  The supporting cast didn't stand out like Carter or Roth, but they did a good job of holding their own ground.  Mark Wahlberg's character, Leo Davidson, is the classic military hero who never shows too much emotion because he is trying to stay in control of the situation.  It almost seems that if Wahlberg weren't an actor, he would have actually been this guy.  Estella Warren's character could have easily weighed down the movie by being the typical sexy woman, but thankfully Burton never really draws attention to her in that way: we know she's beautiful, but we don't need to waste 20 minutes of the movie proving it.  She doesn't have any dense lines bent at attracting Wahlberg or any slow motion shots of her character taking a hot bath.  Instead Estella Warren does a good job of playing a character simply caught in the story and reacting in a realistic way.  A personal favorite part of mine was the cameo appearance of Charlton Heston, who almost has the same classic line that he had in the original.The story, though shaky at the beginning, quickly regains its composure and holds the audience's attention.  Once upon the actual planet, there are many satirical references to the way our society has treated animals, the environment, and each other (in cases of slavery).  It is this ability of holding a mirror to society that has made Burton a genius in his craft. Even though the storyline is a tad simple and any audience member can guess or just about guess how the whole story transpired, it doesn't matter because we are trapped in this world and we become interested in the characters interaction with each other.The ending is what could have wrapped up the entire experience into a good movie but didn't.  The last ten minutes of the movie was a horrible attempt at a twist ending.  If you watch closely you can see the movie end, but for some reason, another whole ending is added.  The problem with the second twist ending is that there is no bridge that connects this ending with the rest of the movie, so instead of discovering an ending you didn't even know you were looking for, you leave the theater thinking `Ummm ok, that doesn't make very much sense.'  The storyline should take you from point A to point B, but the ending tells you that you are actually at point C and doesn't attempt in any way, shape, or form to explain how you got there.I gave this movie a 5 because it has the attempt, it just doesn't have the follow through.

title: Buy or rent the original, please!
text:
Having seen Planet of the Apes 2001 I decided to rent the original series (not having seen them since the age of eight). I suppose I should thank Tim Burton for that.Burton has produced a standard "good versus bad" action flick, with special effects and stunts succeeding each other rapidly (presumably to distract from the lack of dialogue or characterisation). It is a shame on at least two counts: one would expect more of Tim Burton (this is a film Emmerich would make); more importantly it lacks the ambiguity and moral challenges of the original series. General Thade is wicked and our hero (whose name I fail to remember) is resourceful, brave and no doubt washes behind his ears.
As I say, stunts, special effects, make up, the occasional twist. Like anyone of a dozen films every summer. Get the original.

title: A good Ape,,,
text: Ok remake of P.o.A's series. Had the Tim Burton feel, nice cameo's by a few old stars, great special affects to boot!

title: Pretty poor
text: Yeah... pretty poor.I didn't even know this existed until a week or so ago. Gotta be frustrating for all involved that they were in a remake/reboot of 1968's 'Planet of the Apes' that wasn't the 2011 version. This one walked so that one could fly etc.Speaking of flying, what the heck is with the high jumping apes in this? It looks so silly and doesn't add anything; a very odd choice. It is, though, a surprise that this film flopped given who got attached to it. Tim Burton as director, with the acting talents of Mark Wahlberg, Tim Roth, Helena Bonham Carter, Michael Clarke Duncan and Paul Giamatti. It's neat that Charlton Heston and Linda Harrison (stars of the original) made cameos, though.Wahlberg feels a bit miscast, though Bonham Carter and Giamatti are solid; the latter particularly seemed to enjoy the role. The film does have a Burton edge to it, as expected, but this is one of his weaker films no doubt. Some other negatives, for me, include the make-up, esp. For General Thade, - I'm in the minority there - and the story's pacing.

title: Another attempt at a remake of a great film that ultimately fails
text: Usually they blame the director when a film goes awry...but I'm afraid that this time the blame must be put on the moviegoing audience. I actually can't believe the overwhelmingly positive response by fans and critics alike to this movie!Okay...it looks great...but there are several major flaws...first, did anyone else notice how a few of the apes (Paul Giamatti's "Limbo" in particular) too closely resembled The Grinch?...second, notwithstanding the great acting by Tim Roth, everyone else seemed stiff as a board...third, and most importantly, and without revealing the ending, did anyone else notice how preposterous it was for that ending to be possible? There is NO possible way that the events at the end of the film could have followed anything that came before it. Instead of a twist ending that meant something, we are left with a sense of confusion that seems to have been tagged on to make jaws drop...until common sense prevails and you realize that they couldn't figure out how to end it in a realistic manner.I guess that the average moviegoer will walk away semisatisfied at what amounts to little more than style prevailing over substance...something we have too long settled for...but as always, most people will forget about it as soon as the next overblown hyped summer blockbuster comes along!

title: Burton provides an entertaining yet flawed ape escape
text: Tim Burton has a unique, dark style that sets him far apart from other filmmakers of his generation, and he has a knack for getting the best efforts from his crews and actors.His "reimagining" of "Planet of the Apes" is a rare instance in which those qualities never come to the fore. I won't bother with prattle comparing this to the 1968 original, simply because I haven't seen it and don't plan to anytime soon.He brings back nearly the entire crew he worked with on the superior "Sleepy Hollow"  costume designer Colleen Atwood, production designer Rick Heinrichs, editor Chris Lebenzon, and composer Danny Elfman, but this formidable unit fails to fully click this time around.Makeup guru Rick Baker (the "Nutty Professor" series) is responsible for the impressive simian facades, but most of the time they look instead like very expensive Halloween masks that muddle the actors' voices. The diction left much to be desired; some characters speak too low and fast (I sat in the fourth row and the theater had THX sound), and some baritone-voiced males sound as if they're talking with their mouths full.The acting is adequate but sometimes as stiff as the monkey mugs, starting with a wooden Mark Wahlberg as the centerpiece of the film, Leo Davidson. He is an Air Force captain, yet he works way up in space. The setup for his eventual crash landing onto the Planet of the Apes is flimsy and rushed. When that time comes, he doesn't look too concerned about being alone and stranded, and eventually imprisoned, in a strange new world, and he goes through the film as if this is all small potatoes to him.Thanks to bad dialogue, he inadvertently forges what may turn out to be the new pickup line of the 21st century: "I can show you something that will change your world forever."Needless to say, the simians are the best thespians, and that's not saying much. Tim Roth hams it up to the hilt as the villain Thade, but he can only do so much in a movie of this style. His chief henchman, played by Michael Clarke Duncan, verbally berates and knocks a few humans around here and there, and snarls lines such as, "Get your stinkin' hands off me, you filthy human!" and "Bow your heads!"  And, that's it.Helena Bonham Carter is solid as Brit-accented human sympathizer Ari. Coincidentally, out of all the Apes, she looks the most human as well (and is nearly a dead ringer for Michael Jackson). Paul Giamatti, on the other hand, is annoying as Limbo the orangutan, the film's thin attempt at comic relief.The weakest link, as if it isn't too obvious, is Leo's gang of human fugitives, especially an annoying teenage boy and the token Black man whom we all know will get knocked off at some point in the film. They have no personality and serve no purpose in the plot whatsoever except to chip in with a cheesy line here and there. Supermodel Estella Warren, playing a slave girl whose father (Kris Kristofferson) is killed by the Apes, is as pointless as a broken pencil. Her skimpy outfit contained more depth than her screen presence. Most of her activity consists of staring into space with her mouth agape.By the way, I didn't realize the Planet of the Apes contained any beauty salons, because she manages to look like she just stepped out of one whenever she appears on screen.Oh, and Burton brings aboard his squeeze Lisa Marie once again for no apparent reason. This time around, she's buried under an Ape mask. As usual, she has nothing to do here except display her one-dimensional feminine wiles.The cinematography, courtesy of Phillippe Rousselot, does a nice job of stressing the foreboding, moonlit jungle environment. It's the only saving grace of the lackluster action sequences, especially in the beginning just after Leo crash-lands and finds himself in the middle of a wild huntdown of humans by Ape soldiers. Elfman comes through on the music front; because of his powerful score, I loved the opening credits sequence.Unfortunately, while Heinrichs' sets are always a visual treat, they aren't as gripping as his Oscar-winning work from SH. They are small and constricted due to the fact that there are sometimes too many characters cavorting on the screen. Upon seeing the Apes' village for the first time, I couldn't help but think of the planet Endor from "Return of the Jedi." The wreckage of Leo's USAF space station, however, is fantastic. It's also the location of a surprising twist in the story.Now to the plot. The reason why it falters for the most part is what ultimately crippled "Shrek": it has an unpleasant air of preachiness to it. By itself, the plot is as thin as Wahlberg's music career, but in a twist that seems rather uncharacteristic of Burton, "Apes" plays the race card. This I didn't care for. I'm aware that this angle is in the original, but it's a white elephant in Burton's version.And yes, an Ape actually utters those infamous six words...I'm sure you know what they are.The suspense factor is all but nil, and the plot twists leave behind numerous holes, such as, for example, the controls on the destroyed space station being able to work despite the wreck apparently being thousands of years old. (Plus, where did all those horses, the Apes' sole means of transportation, come from?)Then there is the well-publicized "love triangle" between Wahlberg, Carter and Warren that Burton hinted at in interviews. To make a long story short, if you plan to watch this solely on the basis of seeing this angle, you're in for a disappointment.Sorry, but I won't waste my breath on Charlton Heston's forgettable pot-and-kettle cameo.Save for the aforementioned chase sequence after Leo's crash landing, the action and fight scenes are pathetic. Simple punches send both humans and Apes flying a few dozen feet into the air. And don't ask the Apes to hit targets in the water that are two feet from the shore. The huge Apes-humans showdown near the end is a yawner.The much-ballyhooed ending is both surprising and ambiguous. Though Burton has vehemently denied any rumors of his helming a sequel, the conclusion is like that of a comic book and does leave the door wide open for a second installment.The film's most comical moments occurred offscreen. Before shooting began, the actors had to undergo "ape training" to learn primate mannerisms, and spent hours in makeup before stepping in front of the cameras. On "failing" ape school, Bonham Carter quipped, "I was told I had AADD  Ape Attention Deficit Disorder." On becoming an Ape: "It's flattering to be cast as a chimp, because you know they haven't cast you for what you look like." Duncan hurt his ankle while filming a pivotal scene with Kristofferson, who slipped, fell, crashed into Duncan and wound up having to get stitches. Duncan was rushed to the hospital (yes, rushed for a turned ankle  that's Hollywood for ya), in full makeup, no less. When he announced himself to a room full of patients, they burst into applause.While "Planet of the Apes" has some major flaws, it doesn't mean it's not entertaining, which it indeed is, but it just doesn't have that signature Tim Burton look and feel to it. It's ultimately just another Hollywood action flick.After all is said and done, his best effort to date still remains "Sleepy Hollow."  7.5/10

title: 1 Hr 54 mins too long...
text: This was one of THE WORST movies I have ever seen in my entire life (and I've seen Sugar and Spice, Jane Doe and Smokey and the Bandit III). The only part worth seeing was Chartlon Heston's cameo. If you MUST see this movie, walk out after that part, go into another theater and watch another movie, any movie will do (and I do mean ANY). I wish I'd brought a book.

title: Too dark and too many unanswered quetions
text: Tim Burton rally can pick them can't he? Having already had to take one of the most popular comic book characters to the big screen in Batman, he then had to recreate the legend of Sleepy Hollow, before turning his eye to one of cinema's all-time classics in Planet of the Apes.Mark Wahlberg was cast in the role of main human (likened to Charlton Heston's in the original) whereas Britain's Helena Bonham-Carter was given a chance to rip up the bodices and put on the make up to become an ape along with Tim Roth and Michael Clarke-Duncan.After being dragged through a wormhole in the middle of an electrical storm, Captain Leo Davidson (Wahlberg) crash lands on a remote planet where humans are the slaves and apes rule. A sympathetic primate named Ari (Bonham-Carter) is against the suffering inflicted on humans by apes however and helps Leo along with the other human slaves escape. Eager not to let their capture get away, the ape army led by Thade (Tim Roth) and Colonel Attar (Clarke-Duncan) give pursuit as Leo frantically heads back to his ship.With so much to live up to in following the original, Tim Burton was always going to struggle to win over fans of the first. His work is as usual, dark and mysterious with most of the action taking place at night. Although adding to the planet's mystique, Burton's style does also often make it difficult to actually figure out what's going on. His re-worked ending is intriguing yet leaves many questions unanswered, with few of the plot lines coming together to complete the picture; this despite the fact that barely an hour of story has been stretched out to fill nearly two.The scenes of violence toward the end are well choreographed, but are also disturbing with all-too-lifelike apes and humans literally beating the life out of each other. It's partly from this though where the one saving grace liesThe quality of the make up work is excellent as Tim Roth, Michael Clarke-Duncan and Helena Bonham-Carter, amongst others, are transformed into perfect ape-creatures. As was shown with Godzilla however, special effects are nothing compared to solid story and the writers fail to offer anything new that can match let alone eclipse the original.Planet of the Apes 2001 is by no means a bad film, but with so much to hype and expectation to live up to it was always going to fall short. It's worth seeing for the make up jobs alone, but if you a real treat then rent the original.3/10

title: This was a Tim Burton movie???
text: I can't wait until the IMDb link to the goofs in PLANET OF THE APES gets active. It should be a loooooong list!Aside from the many goofs already listed in past postings, I agree this is one terrible movie. The acting (except for Paul Giamatti) is bad, the changes from the original 1968 version do not improve upon the story, and the special effects are mediocre. The ape makeup looks great, although it's hard to understand what some of them are saying. The costumes for the apes look terrific too.If I never knew from the credits that it was directed by Tim Burton, I would never have guessed from watching it. Where is his distinctive touches? His films in the past have a very influential look to them. This film emulated the most mediocre elements of basic mainstream science-fiction tripe. A truly horrible movie to make after the wonderful SLEEPY HOLLOW.

title: All looks and no plot
text: I have to agree that the makeup and visual effects and even the look of the movie are vintage Tim Burton. Compared to the original film the ape effects are great, and actually make you feel that you are seeing human sized apes, and not some guy in a monkey suit. A+However all looks and no plot make for a bad film. The film starts of promisingly enough, but one we get to the planet of the apes it is as if the scriptwriters figured just shooting scenes of flying apes and a ragtag group of humans trying to escape (Hmmm sounds like something from the Wizard of Oz) would be enough. F-One feels sorry for the cast for having to muddle their way through this script, but then cast is not up to the task of even handling this script. Only Tim Roth as the evil General Thade turns in a great menacing performance, and winds up out acting the rest of the cast. D (Roth A+)And let's no even talk about the ending! Anyone who has watched any sci-fi films involving wormholes, etc, must have seen where this film was going from the opening few minutes. As the final climatic scenes, yawn, made me wish I had some popcorn left over to occupy myself with something useful, no wait I could have put the bag over my head to hide me from the shame of wasting $12.50!!

title: Not a bad remake, but it could have done much better
text: The 2001 remake of the original 1968 classic, "PLANET of the APES" is directed by Tim Burton and starring Mark Wahlberg as the lead character and since I'm only doing three of the PLANET of the APES film reviews, I decided to start off with this one.The sixth film produced in the Planet of the Apes franchise, it was loosely adapted from Pierre Boulle's 1963 novel of the same name and the 1968 film version. It tells the story of astronaut Leo Davidson crash-landing on a planet inhabited by intelligent apes. The apes treat humans as slaves, but with the help of an ape named Ari, Leo starts a rebellion.The film also stars Tim Roth, Helena Bonham Carter, Michael Clarke Duncan, Paul Giamatti, and Estella Warren Development for a Planet of the Apes remake started as far back as 1988 with Adam Rifkin. His project nearly reached the pre-production stage before being canceled. Terry Hayes's script, titled Return of the Apes, would have starred Arnold Schwarzenegger, under the direction of Phillip Noyce. Oliver Stone, Don Murphy, and Jane Hamsher were set to produce. Creative differences ensued between Hayes and financier/distributor 20th Century Fox. Chris Columbus, Sam Hamm, James Cameron, Peter Jackson, and the Hughes brothers later became involved.With William Broyles, Jr.'s script, Tim Burton was hired as director, and the film was put into active development. Lawrence Konner and Mark Rosenthal rewrote the script, and filming took place from November 2000 to April 2001. Planet of the Apes was released to mixed reviews, but was a financial success. Much criticism focused on the confusing plot and ending, although Rick Baker's prosthetic makeup designs were praised.The story is a little confusing, but it is easy to look at for me, but for everyone else, a lot of people and critics and also fans of the franchise hates this story and the ending. The ending is just confusing also, but it's easy to overlook these two major flaws.The music by Danny Elfman is just awesome and the song that plays during the end credits titled, "Rule the Planet Remix" is awesome, mixed by Paul Oakenfold and composed by Danny Elfman. The rest of the music including the opening theme music is just spectacular and the film does wonders with the music.The visual effects and makeup is just spectacular also, but Rick Baker did the prosthetic make-up effects for the apes and it is a blessing of him. The visuals are a little cheesy, but works for this type of movie.The acting, is just good and bad. The only credit that will be given to is Mark Wahlberg, his performance as the lead was amazing. Helena Bonham Carter, Estella Warren and Michael Clarke Duncan puts on really good performances as well, but they can get way too over-the- top in some of the scenes. Paul Giamatti is hilarious and he does an amazing job. Luke Eberl and Erick Avari is in the film, too, but they're performances were a little confusing. Charlton Heston has a cameo as Thade's dad. Tim Roth plays the villain, Thade and he is okay, but even then, he is over-the-top as well.Overall, with the 2001 remake of Planet of the Apes, it's not a bad re-imagining, but it could have done much better than this. I like and hate this remake of the 1968 original classic.Despite its financial success, 20th Century Fox chose not to produce a sequel, and later rebooted the franchise in 2011 with Rise of the Planet of the Apes.

title: Total c**p
text: Worst movie I've seen in a decade... sweet jesus, how did this happen.  It says this has to be four lines long, but that's a problem cause I think saying it was a total suckfest with no redeeming qualities sums it up pretty good.  Well, look, I just got four lines.

title: Tim Burton's new torture device.
text: Don't get me wrong; Tim Burton has a lot of talent. Most of his films have some eerie, dark atmosphere and quirkiness that's irresistable to most viewers.Something that this film doesn't have.The only impressive aspect of this remake are the elaborate set designs and convincing make-up (watch out for Michael Jackson's cameo as Ari).At first, the film impressed me. It looked cool, the score was good. Then I noticed a pattern in the film.Dialogue scene to running, to more running, back to dialogue, more running, rinse, wash and repeat.Mark Wahlberg is a good actor but he's quite laughable here. Wait until you see his speech about rising up against the apes. This one suffers from the age-old cliche of the band of people too afraid to fight back for the freedom with no choice otherwise. Well, unless they want to die and be put in slavery (at least that would take off the running time a bit).The female character (insert model's name here) is simply used for the sex scene, but there isn't one. The big budget is used for the cool battles that couldn't be done on a small budget. But there is no big cool, entertaining battle. It goes on and on. Should I talk about the ending? If you enjoyed the film you'll say "Wow! What a smart, intelligent ending! Now, if I just knew what it means..." and weeks later you're still puzzling over it until you realize Tim Burton has wasted even more of your time thinking it actually makes sense. Hey, if you're going to have a huge twist at the end most won't figure out, at least make what came before it interesting and atmospheric like Mulholland Drive or something.

title: Waste of Four dollars and Eleven Cents!
text: I was unfortunate enough to pick this movie up today at the local video store after seeing a slightly above average rating on this site.  Sadly, this is the first time the ratings have been, in my opinion, totally inaccurate.  From the savages to the apes, I can't help but laugh at the pathetic dialogue, poor, uhm, acting?, and the, well, general atrocity of the overall movie.  The blond savage was the highlight of this movie with her sequined(I didn't actually notice the sequins, but it was commented by the rest of the excited crowd gagging on the movie), tight-fitting, low-cut cave woman swimsuit, and I can't forget to mention the sexy red lipstick she manages to keep smudge-free throughout the movie. *note:  i just heard "what a crap movie!" as i'm typing this review.  For some odd reason, the rest of them are still watching the blockbuster.Don't waste your time!!!

title: A strange and Wonderful Love Letter to Insane Sci-Fi
text: Sci Fi- It's often scolded by most in this world, and sadly now such Sci-Fi films are most viciously attacked by their own fans! The fact it that this is a flawed movie, saved by Tim Burton's fantastic Visual Style and Danny Elfmans terrific score. The Cultural references are terrific: but once they are scrutinized further- sure it's unlikely that Apes would develop beautiful armour reminiscent of Ancient Armour worn by Turkish Knight in their religious wars, but man they look terrific and fill this strange world with a rich history and culture! While most merely see "REMAKE" up in lights and scoff at Hollywood- the film is more of a tribute to The concept of what Planet of the Apes has become, evolved with the help of fans through a horde of crappy sequels and weak spin off television series to the point where Pierre Boulle and what we know as Planet of the Apes are actually worlds apart. Bravely however, the films controversial finale is not to be taken seriously in any way! The ending which I will not give away, is an homage to many things.It's a tribute to Insane Sci- Fi, The deliberately profound endings to both the original film and Boulle's novel, and having a bit of a chuckle.It's like the Twilight Zone without taking itself seriously in any way.

title: did everyone see the same movie?
text: slow, predictable, and lacking any real magic at all.  I didn't care if all the apes died or the humans were wiped out.  The big battle at the end was about as "epic" as the jim carrey fight scene in Dumb and Dumber.  Cheese ball ape-human love scene with some out-right horrible add-ons, like having the young boy ride out to help and oops, don't you know it, his horse falls. I guess since humans are animals and don't have horses readily available we shouldn't expect them to be doing and jousting are dressage.  Predictable ending that lacked the jaw dropping effect of the original.  Terrible cameo with Heston, ain't it funny the president of the NRA is now dressing up in ape make-up and preaching the evils of technology and guns.  The make-up was beautiful and some performances were actually good, but the real problem is, if you're going to use the same name as the original, it better be as good as the original.  I expected better.  Sleepy Hollow, Beetlejuice, Edward scissor hands..... Tim Burton was not up to par with planet of the apes.

title: Could have been a lot better!
text: This remake of the Planet of the Apes was okay. I feel the movie was not well-written. The characters are way too underdeveloped (especially Wahlberg's). The movie does have a great sense of artistic direction (the scenery, make-up and props are very enticing and alluring). However, I feel the movie moved at a way too easy by-the-numbers pace. There was never any real drama or suspense invested into the script. The interaction between the characters is often stale and almost wishing to be something more redeeming. Another aspect that really confused me was regarding the humans on the ape planet. These humans were obviously able to speak, thus they were intelligent. So, why were these humans unable to have formed a much stronger resistance to the apes?  (In the original Planet of the Apes movie, the native humans were more underdeveloped like cavemen who still could not speak.) The ending of the 2001 remake was too weak and only guarantees us the possiblity that someone else might provide us with another sequel.My advice: catch this movie on cable and don't bother to rent or buy it.

title: Planet of mockery!
text: About 5 minutes in after the opening titles I knew this was going to be a criminal miscarriage of what could have been. Character exposition in the opening sequence was axed in order to bustle the hero (or lack of one) into the so-called action as soon as possible. What results is a woefully underdeveloped series of events thrusting us along on an adventure that is laughable and miserably cheap. Tim Burton's influences lay in many obscure and cheesy drive-in sci/fi movies and TV shows of the past (which he actually tries to pay homage to rather than satirize) and it's not surprising that this film plays like Lost in Space meets One Million Years BC meets Claude Rains' version of The Lost World meets Planet of the Apes. If Burton felt that people would be excited at the prospect of seeing his own self-indulgent vision of the Book and Heston's classic, full of gawdy touches typical of his style, he was badly mistaken. His realization of Batman was far more successful.When I first saw the commercials for this movie I was immediately taken. Images of marching Ape armies and the atmospheric visuals inspired hopes of a science Fiction action epic like no other. Spartacus conquers the Apes as it were. Sadly it was all window dressing and the truly best parts of this movie are ALL in the commercial spots. What we are subjected to is an unspeakably badly written visual feast which belies a very limited budget lurking just below the surface. The only reason to see this abomination is for the costumes and make-up design, as well as the production design (aside from the space station and space suits which look to have been stolen from the 2001 prop vault).The original planet of the apes is not one of my top ten favorite films but it is an honest and intelligent piece of science fiction. Though a bit of a talk fest, it does bring up some very thought provoking issues (thanks to the great Rod Serling) and ends on one of the most powerful and stunning climaxes in movie history. It's a film deserving of its classic status and rated a better remake than what Richard Zanuck and Tim Burton have foisted on us here. In fact, Zanuck should be fined and his producer's license suspended as he was also in involved in making the original.Any and all intellectual content is missing leaving us with good actors buried under mounds of make-up. Except for Wahlberg, who should have just been buried. This guy is the most vacant action hero since Keanu Reeves in Speed. Aside from disobeying commands in order to rescue his chimp, his motivations are unwritten, leaving him to loaf from one scene to the next muttering little more than "hey" or "what" or "whatever", while glancing more than periodically at his Tandy hand-held. The guy has the intelligence and personality of a soapsud. An actor with a grasp of dead-pan humor might have made this character zing. Wahlberg just sits there, looking constipated as another IMDb reviewer mentioned.As far as the other cast members are concerned, what is the deal with Kris Kristoffersen. He has two lines then gets run through with a spear. Estella Warren is atrocious as the obligatory female human. She's no Raquel Welch in the looks department and is an even worse actress. Helena Bonham-Carter is wasted, as is Tim Roth as Thade and Michael Clark Duncan as his Right-Hand Gorilla. One wonders why they hired big-name actors to be unrecognizable under all that latex when they could have hired medium priced actors and saved some money on the budget. Marquee power I guess. As good as he is, Michael Clark Duncan just sounds like the guy who played Worf in Star Trek.As far as Charlton Heston's uncredited cameo as Thade's father, spouting familiar lines he used to condemn the Apes in the original, though here in reversed context: maybe in another script, with a better director for the material, it would have been sly and humorous. Not here. The same goes for other memorable lines quoted from the original.Much has been debated about the ending, which is about the only pure Burtonian stamp on the movie. It has no relevance other than to set-up a sequel (would anyone care to see it?). It pays homage to Serling and is a twist on the original's shattering ending, but really it comes off more of a tribute to Marty's nightmare sequence in Back to the Future Part II than anything else.What we're left with here, in the wake of other deficient hack jobs such as U-571, The Patriot, Pearl Harbor, and How the Grinch Stole Christmas, is a clear message that a great deal of Hollywood no longer cares about providing their audience with a well written and performed production once their marketing machine has lured us into the theatres. If people keep falling for it it's going to end up sealing the end of quality entertainment for good.Here's hoping that The Lord of the Rings doesn't turn out to be a mishandled treatment of Tolkien with GREAT commercials.

title: Lookit the Monkeys! Plot?! What?!
text: Well, I won't pretend to be a professional critic... just a guy who saw a terrible movie. I'd been hot to see 'Apes' since it was first announced so I went to see it on opening night. When the lights came back up I sat still, stunned at the atrocity I had just witnessed.Let me see if I have everything right... the days on this planet are what... 100 hours long and the planet itself is sometimes huge, other times somewhat larger than a football field, but not by much. The continuity problems were a constant, and I do mean CONSTANT distraction. The story line was insulting to even the most forgiving sci-fi fan and the acting, well... for the humans it was tepid at best.Now... the apes themselves. Hands down, the technical Oscars will be gobbled up by this movie and deservedly so. Despite all of the flaws, the work put in by Mr. Baker and the actors themselves <Tim Roth was, as always, fantastic>  to give a complete and realistic image of a talking monkey made 'Apes' worth the trip. Just don't go in there expecting anything more than a technical spectacle and you should be fine. Me? I expected so much more.... and I wish the kid had been left to the apes. Who the heck was he anyway? I didn't even know his name yet I am expected to care? Sigh... go.. see the movie... but check your brain at the door.

title: Rather than making a bad pun, I'll just tell you it stunk.
text: I hope whoever green-lighted this "Planet of the Apes" remake kept the receipt when he sold his soul to Satan.  It might be tax-deductible.  I can't possibly imagine why the heck they chose to (1) remake a film that still holds up just fine after three decades, or (2) completely remove all the likeable characters and cool plot twists from it.  The only way anyone could possibly like this movie is if they'd never seen the original.  Also, this movie had the stupidest ending I've ever seen.  But hey, at least the Apes looked better...which I believe was the entire reason they decided to remake this movie in the first place.  If you're thinking about shelling out the money to see this movie, save your money and buy the original on video.

title: The Ending Destroyed the Movie!
text: My father bought it on DVD and I watched it with him. The movie was quite good right up to the ENDING!!! The ending basically ruined the movie. If they ended it totally differently, It would have been an awesome ending. The Ending came out of nowhere when all they had to do was end it with Mark Whalberg crashing into his mother ship to make the cycle complete!

title: Some amazing technical achievement but...
text:
Planet of the Apes is a breathtaking spectacle, a technical masterpiece highlighted by Rick Baker's remarkably emotive simian make up. 
This is an exciting film, one that sets up beautifully at a near future research station in some unidentified area of space.  Once Mark Wahlberg arrives en medias res at the Primate Ruled Planet, we are carried through a remarkably other world, a masterpiece of set design.  In addition, choreography of primate movements is entirely believable, a foreign yet familiar fusion of primal simian movement and human barbarism. 
Where the film begins to show its warts is its inability to follow up on the plot premises it establishes.  Various mentions and trappings of mysticism, which serve the film well, disappear under the relentless pacing. Wahlberg's prophecied astronaut is not significantly charismatic enough nor spiritually aware enough to be the centerpiece of a film that wants badly to do more than simply be another big, dumb action movie but seldom achieves more than those humble lows.And in the end, an error in editing, direction, writing, or all of the above brings a film to lows that I was perfectly will to accept, warts and all. The last 10 minutes almost ruined the film for me (and I won't spoil it for everyone but ask yourself it makes any sense at all when watching it).  This is one of the most insufferably bone-headed, senseless finales in filmmaking history.

title: Silly nonsense
text: What a disappointment.  Someone keeps forgetting that in movies there are things called "characters".  These "characters" should be written well and portrayed with good acting so as the audience that has spent its hard earned money may relate to them, believe in them, and ultimately give a damn about them.  Poor Mr. Burton, this film has but a trace of his talent.  It you love bad dialogue and some cool looking dudes in Ape suits  this movie is for you.  The best part was when Bubbles got his but kicked.  I'm sorry, but not even a descent performance by Tim Roth could save this plotless film. I haven't seen the original since I was a kid, but from what I remember there were a few characters in it that people gave a damn about. Two thumbs down.

title: Something unexpected came up...
text: I like this movie!  This is a really good movie... yet I don't know what it is about it that makes me like it.  That's the strangest thing.  I actually saw this movie in theaters because a friend asked to see it (I only wanted to see Jurassic Park III).  Turns out it could almost be called one of my favorites!I have never seen the original.  I'm sorry to say this, but I don't know if I ever will since this remake was so good.  I am satisfied with the way this one was done.  I am afraid of disappointment if I watch the original.The plot is excellent, first of all.  There's a nice plot twist at the end involving the origins of all apes that puts everything together and just feels right.  There is plenty of action and, in a way, romance, too.  It's a great sci-fi flick with plenty of action.The storyline isn't too original--escape, then get reinforcements to fight off the antagonists.  But it still does its job.  It keeps you watching.The music is composed by Danny Elfman.  He has a certain militaristic flare in this movie which really sounds good.  The music is excellent, taking on tribal drums at some points and bombastic themes that whirl together perfectly.The costumes are great.  The apes look just like they should.  The graphics are decent, but not overall groundbreaking.I was and am still really impressed with this movie.  It has a lot of things that kept me going and makes me want to watch it again and again.  But I can't compare it to the original.  I wouldn't even if I had seen it.  I can only say that this movie is really great.

title: If your airconditioner is broke & you need get out - maybe
text: They put a lot of time and effort into getting the apes right. But they forgot to put the same effort into the story.Good:the apes Helena Bonham Carter Charlten Heston as an ape.Bad:Mark Wahlberg - why does Carter and the humans follow him? He is a jerk.Carter says this human is different - How? The eyebrows on the female chimps - I'm sorry they annoyed me. Every "surprise" I could see coming a mile away.

title: Don't waste your time
text: Although I am a fan of the original, I went into this movie with few expectations sinse I had already accepted that it was trying to be a Summer Blockbuster and not a well-made story that really made you think like the original did.However what I wasn't prepared for was how simply BAD it was. Not only was the plot nonsensical most of the time but when you could understand it you didn't want to; it was one of the most convoluted  and childish storylines I've ever had the displeasure of watching.The ending helped the movie slightly despite it clearly being "tacked on". However this isn't saying much because by this time most people have given up hope of it turning into even a decent movie and are happy to just sit back and watch the intense action and super-weirdness that the ending provides.The whole movie can be summed up as a waste of potential. It wasted one of the best franshises out there. It wasted one of the most "talented" directors out there, Tim Burton. It wasted some of the best actors out there, Helena Bonham Carter and ol' reliable Marky Mark. It even wasted its cameos of original "Planet of the Ape" actors with crappy parts. And most importantly it also wasted moviegoers time.To sum it all up: don't see this movie unless you're amongst people who wouldn't mind you throwing popcorn and yelling obsenities at the screen.

title: Just the name and lots of money
text: How dare they? I was hoping to see something new, modern and interesting. What I did see, was Marky -I look so good-, a bit blabla and a very expansive looking decoration and mask. Nothing more. I had some hopes, that the Three angle story, the hero, the ape and the girl will get more weight at the end. The character girl was so ironic and the ape the one to fall in love with. No, nobody must have had the ambition to use the tones of money something like this cost, to create an interesting story. The voting in imdb.com is 6.1. What is up with you? Don´t you know, how a good film looks like? Sad, but true, let´s hope, they don´t sequel this one,tooRichard

title: What a bummer....
text: the movie simply was not good. Tim Burton had good IDEAS, but never executed them well. the movie was so god awful predictable. there were NO surprise story twists(EXCEPT the ending which was AWESOME), and no reason to care for any of the characters(well, i cared about the lil' chimp in the spaceship). Tim Burton DID develop the ape social structure very well, but it took HALF the movie to do so. the whole humans versus apes battle was not exciting at all. The action just wasnt good.the big PLUS of the movie though were the Apes. The makeup and set design were awesome, and the actors LOOKED like apes! so, kudos to Rick(or rich?) Baker for the makeup, but that wasnt enough to save this movie.it is worth going to see once.

title: Not what I was hoping for, sadly.
text: I am a HUGE Tim Burton fan, the only two films I don't *love* of his are Ed Wood and Beetlejuice, sadly, Planet of the Apes was very close to falling into this category also.There were a lot of things going for the film which were realised at times, the feel of the planet is great, the acting is generally top-notch, the soundtrack is fantastic and the ending - although unfathomable - was atleast unexpected, and that's good in a strange way.Where it failed was in the HUGE plots holes and convenient devices used to drive along the story. All the plot-holes have been mentioned elsewhere in this review section, suffice it to say, there is little ways of getting around most of them. They just don't make sense ! - and the chimp saving the day was a very poor way to end it.The actual plot runs thin half-way through the movie and the final battle was rather anti-climatic I thought. I will go and see a sequel if there is one, but with a lot less excitement than I had for this film.I can't say it wasn't good, because I never looked at my watch during the cinema, but it wasn't the best BLOCKBUSTER SUMMER movie of the year (that was Jurassic Park 3 and earlier Bridget Jones and Hannibal), but it was entertaining enough. Sadly I will always feel the *most* apt word for the movie is "Disappointing".Yd.

title: Tim Roth as the Feral Chihuahua
text: I REALLY wanted to like this movie.  I'd hoped Tim Burton would bring the same clarity of vision he brought to Sleepy Hollow, Ed Wood and even the first Batman.  Instead, he gave us the second Batman: some great visuals, a few strong archetypes and a terrible script.  Tim Roth as the feral chihuahua was ridiculously over-the-top and not in a good way.  Perhaps Rick Baker should've stopped punching Estella Warren in the mouth long enough to find her motivation.  Or at least a personality.  This was a straight-ahead, cliched escape movie, with no pause for character development.  The ending wasn't as bad as many suggest and is definitely feasible if you consider that Thade's ultimate fate is left up in the air.  It'll take some explaining but it's possible.  All in all, I'm hoping Burton will take a pass on the sequel and let someone with stronger STORYTELLING skills take over.  NOTE TO JOEL SCHUMACHER: THIS DOES NOT MEAN YOU!

title: Burton spins the boredom out of the original.
text: I was only seven years old when the original "Planet of the Apes" was released in 1968 and, compared to other films of that era ("2001, A Space Odyssey,"  "Bullitt,"  "You Only Live Twice," etc.) I was able to recognize "Planet" for what it was: pure, unadulterated schlock, and boring schlock at that.  The sorry parade of Ape movies that followed into the '70s was my first experience with Hollywood's "Sequel System" of pumping as much revenue as possible from any spavined idea that is a hit with audiences.  This may, in fact, have been an early iteration of that now-standard practice.Needless to say, I had no expectation of anything more than a mild diversion when I wandered into a matinee showing of Tim Burton's take on this shriveled old chestnut. To my surprise, and despite the fact that Mark Wahlberg sleep-walked his way through the entire movie, it worked a lot better than the original.  General Thade (Tim Roth) is by far the most engaging character in the movie, and the only one that overcomes his ape makeup with an identifiable personality. I was almost rooting for HIM by the end of the movie.Burton's portrayal of the preening, officious Ape Elite and their personal habits is a sly look at some of our own human foibles. I recognized a couple of ex-bosses during those scenes. Original cast member and current NRA President Charleton Heston has a cameo that becomes hilarious when he shows son Thade his "proof" of human ingenuity. I wonder how many viewers missed the humor in that because they are ignorant of Heston's NRA activities? It's refreshing to see an actor of his age and station who is able to poke fun at himself.Happily, this "homage" to the original carries enough originality to keep it interesting (let's just say there was never a Statue of Liberty on this planet) and has better pacing and a lot more action than the original. The effects are seamless and there is enough humor to break up any monotony.The movie climaxes about 10 minutes before it ends, which is too bad. The last few scenes are a total throwaway (and perhaps a foreshadowing of the dreaded Sequelitis), but hey, we can't all be Shakespeare all of the time.

title: Not Good.
text: This movie was, well, not too good. Okay, I'll admit, the actors did good monkey imitations, but that's about ALL that went well with this film. The characters were unbelievable, seeing as they made stupid, spur-of-the-moment decisions that tended to make no sense whatsoever. The plot was also a mess. Imagine, taking the three main Star Wars movies, and crushing them all into a two hour movie-would you have any idea of what was going on, or why??? No. This is what Planet of the Apes feels like-rushed. Not to mention, the ending: what was with that??!?!?!?! There were so many plot holes and inconsistencies that I still don't know what happened, or WHY. With this movie, you leave the theater going, "Huh?" It's not a great way to spend 2 hours, trust me.

title: I've seen David Lynch movies that made more sense than this
text: Absolutely horrible.  God only knows what Burton was thinking with this. This movie lacked the intelligence to make it a "make you think" film and the action to make it an action film.  It falls somewhere in between.  The ending tried to be as clever and shocking as the original, but was simply idiotic.  Avoid this movie.  If you want to see a movie with a great surprise ending, watch Memento.

title: Not too gr"ape"
text: Hated it!  I terribly disliked the original so I thought this new version would be different.  It was in a way but it still has a disappointing ending.  After viewing it I had to do some reading the rest of the night to get it off my mind.  The point of humans and apes living in harmony was appealing but it should have stopped right there.  It was very disheartening to get away from one nightmare and crash land into another.Save your money, save your electricity. Don't bother!  Humans rule!

title: Best viewed by apes.
text: In the context of the present day audience awareness the original Planet of the Apes (1968) has many flaws but the time travel reasoning and the rise of the apes made some sense. One is inclined to be a little more forgiving given that the movie predates the first moon landing of 1969.As for the 2001 effort, it is very poorly constructed. Most will abandon hope after the first 60 seconds - why have a monkey control the space pod at all? Poor logic and sloppy story line permeate the entire movie.Kids and lovers of wired apes might be amused - everyone else should run for the exit.5/10 being generous

title: Flying Monkeys?
text: At some point, while watching the hordes of marching soldier apes as they rocked side to side like Stevie Wonder on speed, I had a sudden cinematic flashback - yes, I had seen this before: the flying monkeys from the Wizard of Oz!  Slow paced (it's a thin story, so the plot had to be squeezed out for all it was worth like the last tube of toothpaste on a deserted island) and mundane, I started wondering when something was actually going to happen.  Nothing ever happens, not even an ending.  Ok, there was an ending, but it wasn't like finding the Statue of Liberty buried in the sand... Skip this and watch reruns of FARSCAPE on the telly - far more entertaining.  And why *is* Mark Wahlberg a movie star, anyway?  The chimp astronaut had more charisma than Markie Mark.

title: F#ck the Critics
text: This was an awesome movie and I don't care what anybody say, it wasn't a perfect movie but it was very entertaining and kept your attention the whole way and this was the movie that showed me how good of an Actor Mark Wahlberg is, he was great in this movie.

title: Roth sells out! Puts on Ape Suit!
text: This movie is a muddle, lots of things make no sense, not the least of which is this; why are all the big mean apes afraid of little Tim Roth, jumping about like a gnat? And why is Estelle Warren wearing lipstick? And just how many millions did it take to get good actors to dress up like apes? I won't even address the ludicrous ending, or the waste of Tim Burtons great talent doing drek like this. Please, Mr. Burton, go back to your original films, stop with the Hollywood crap! We your fans miss you!

title: The makeup was the best part...
text: And I'm not talking about Mark Wahlberg.  Any fan of the original POTA can see just how pathetic this remake is.  Forget the fact that the original 1968 version had an underlying message about racial intolerance.  Now we have a film with absolutely no message.  Ok, maybe there is one, and that is "how to make money".  How else can one explain the casting of Charlton Heston's original character with Marky Mark?  Or how about wasting Tim Roth and Michael Clarke Duncan underneath especially good makeup?  What's with casting another vapid supermodel with no talent(Estella Warren) in the female lead?  These factors, plus a horrible script, are all ingredients for disaster, and that's just what this film is.  Rent the original, and save yourself from the mess that Tim Burton has created as he slides downhill.

title: Get your hands off me, you damn dirty human!
text: Tim Burton has always been an atmosphere artist, and in Apes he does an excellent job.  The scenery is compelling, and the ape costumes are fantastic!  There is a cloud to that silver lining.  It's called, character development.  He does a below average job portraying Wahlberg's character, the star of the film.  Other characters get slightly better treatment, but what about the kid who Wahlberg's character saves as the ape army attacks? Almost no background, just a couple of shots of him being insubordinate to Wahlberg, a person that the humans on the planet are in awe of.  Would a kid really be that brash?The story is good, the acting is fine, the scenery is superb.  The climax of the film is great, though I won't spoil it for anyone who hasn't seen it. However, one thing can always ruin a good movie: a bad ending.  Let me just say I think Mr. Burton wanted to see apes in police squad cars and ape tourists.  The last five minutes ruin an otherwise very good summer flick.

title: Rule the Planet!
text: More of a reworking of the idea rather than a remake of the original. I must admit I was pleasantly surprised by this effort. Of course, it was never going to be as good as the original, the ending to the Charlton Heston classic has to be one of the best endings to a film in movie history. I was satisfied that things were well enough explained throughout this film, for example, the talking humans, and how the apes got to inhabit the planet in the first place. What I couldn't work out was the ending, I wont go into details for those who haven't seen it, but I do feel that because the 1968 classic had such a shocking and thought provoking ending, the writers of this version almost `felt obliged' to try and live up to that and as a result it doesn't really make any sense and tie in with the story you have just followed for the past 2 hours  or maybe it does and I just missed the point!, either way  FAR too confusing! (Although it screams "sequel!" - how convenient!!). Wahlberg is okay as astronaut Leo Davidson, while Tim Roth is wickedly good fun as cruel military ape `General Thade'. Charlton Heston appears unbilled as Thade's dying father, who's character name is `Zaius'  is there a doctor in the house?

title: Another example of why Burton and Roth are so good
text: "Planet Of The Apes" clearly has the "Tim Burton" seal on it, but unfortunately shows both imaginative and argumental development voids, which I blame not to bad directing, but to an irregular script, revised and changed thousands of times, due in part to the late entrance of Mr. Burton in the project. However, here I'm going to focus on the most positive points, rather than the negative ones.The Seal I talked before is present as in any of Burton's films. I mainly refer to the conception of the eccentric, delirious, out-of-this-world characters and to the Gothic-romantic, fantastic art direction this films radiates (I don't have to mention previous examples, but Batman, Nightmare and Edward are and will remain in our minds). Danny Elfman gives again the best of himself with a dynamic, at times majestic score where percussion leads.The apes are incredible, they work, they really rock in the show. Not only for Rick Baker's make-up masterpiece (which deserves not the nomination but the Academy Award NOW!), which gives them live and expression unlike 1968's sort of dummies, but because they are credible... and light years far more credible (and even more human) than the film's humans, except for Mr. Whalberg. The script said they had to talk this time.Can anybody tell me if they liked them? If they found their importance to their dialogues? And why Stella Warren hasn't been issued with the "manikin" label, as Jake Lloyd was in "Episode 1"? The native roles show no interest and slow the rhythm of the movie.Now, returning to the apes, I have to talk about the real showman:Tim Roth as Thade. Exceptional. Histrionic. Aggressive. Cool. Evil portrayed as an ape. As the Ape General, he gets so very deep into the role that you end up thinking Roth, after all his extense and peculiar filmography, has finally turned crazy and really believes he's a monkey free in the stage. He is of the very few actors, along with Gary Oldman, Edward Norton and De Niro, which I consider as chameleons:ready to face any kind of role, however obscure, violent or psychologically strong they are.About the rest, I'm definitely getting in love with Helena Bonham Carter (another example of the ape's astonishing expressivity),and Mark Whalberg is fine as always. I liked his role, in comparison with Heston's in 1968, because he is a pure survivor who wants to go home with his friends and family (he just doesn't fit in that planet), while Charlton arrived there by accident and became a revolutionary hero. .To finish with, about the ending: perfect. I love it. And I love it because 1) It is different, it's of the few which make the viewer's imagination work, so anyone can figure out an explanation to the ending the way they want, 2) Its philosophy, the paradox it represents, which I'm not going to tell, and 3)It is extremely "Burtonesque"."Planet Of The Apes" reflects again the style of an excellent director, but shows his vulnerability in works he doesn't personally project (remember the initial idea came from James Cameron), in which a studio, and not himself, determines most of the finished work. However, an entertaining film, recommended to any sci-fi lover. And an advice: read the original book by Pierre Boulle for another view of the story... Vote --- 8/10

title: What a load of bananas
text: You wanna see a bunch of guys in ape suits?  Okay, this is your film.  You wanna see good acting?  Go far far away, as far as you can from this movie. The only one worth his weight in bananas is Tim Roth, but don't go expecting to see his Four Rooms/Resevoir Dogs personality because you'll never recognize him.  Kudos to Roth for actually ACTING.  Everybody else, well, I stick out my tongue and beat my chest at you.  And who would have thought that all of Charleton Heston's classic lines would be hijacked by the apes themselves?  And this "incredible new twist-ending"?  They could have brainstormed a thousand years and never come up with anything sillier.

title: Horrible Movie
text: This movie is one of the most horrible movies I have seen in a very long time.  From the very beginning of the film, it is obvious that Planet of the Apes is just another costly bloated piece of trash that Hollywood has been quite adept at producing in recent times (Phantom Menace anyone?).  Tim Burton's stamp is all over this movie.  However, his style (along with Danny Elfman's great music) hardly make up for one of the silliest and emptiest scripts ever.  How in the world did it take 3 people to write the cliched dialogue and come up with the completely improbable scenes that saturate this movie?  Everyone screams, "Wow, the special effects were awesome!" The special effects were great, but special effects do not a movie make (Phantom Menace anyone, again?). To make things worse, the ending of the movie was so open that you can see at least nine sequels coming out of it.  I sincerely hope that the makers of this film will reconsider making any more movies like this one, and I hope Tim Burton will go back to making better films.

title: Pale imitation pulverizes where original mesmerized
text: A pale imitation of the 60's classic, obviously made only with the intention of raking in big bucks at the box office.  It has no resonance, no spark, no soul.  No reason for being.  I was suckered into seeing it by the promise of Tim Burton's visionary direction; but the end result could have been filmed by anyone (just a few more explosions and it could have been Michael Bay). While sitting through it, I indulged in a fond reverie of watching the original in a theater, way back in the day, mesmerized.  Monkeying around with this classic only left this audience member pulverized.

title: No surprises at all
text: I could guess the story from start to end after five minutes. Everything bad that we human have done to animals and fellow humans should now fall back on ourself. That was it. Not even the end was any great surprise. Boring.

title: Felt outdated for it's time and lacked what made the original at least intriguing
text: This wasn't a terrible remake but it wasn't really good either. I like remakes that change things up a bit while having some essence and premise from the original. And this movie did change things up a lot compared to the original but it took a lot away from what made the original good. The movie felt like it was more about racism than sci-fi ideology and theory which I found to be interesting in the original. And it lacked the creepy and mysterious sci-fi elements that was in the original. It's a watchable movie but it just goes in a very narrow and direct direction and not in a good way either. Nothing is really imaginative and it just didn't get me immersed or interested on what was going on. I was just going along with it until it ended. The original "Planet of the Apes" was far-fetched but this was is more non-believable and even absurd. Also maybe if it tried to modernize it in a cool sci-fi direction it might have been at least somewhat entertaining but it lacked that as well while having the similar corniness of the original. The apes being apes didn't even play a crucial part in the story.4.5/10

title: A perfect translation
text: I have no idea how people could bash a movie like this. Movies like these (ESPECIALLY Sci-Fi movies) are very rare, and i must admit, when I was walking into the theatre, I thought this was going to be an awful movie ripping off the previous "Planet of the Apes". I was so wrong.The movie starts off with Leo Davidson (Mark Wahlberg) in a USAF Starbase that experiences a strange nebula. The captain sends out one of Leo's monkeys to explore the nebula, but they lose contact with the monkey. Leo jumps in another spaceship and goes looking for the monkey (Which was very strange in the beginning, but they had to get him on the planet somehow, I guess). When he gets trapped in the nebula, he goes forward in time and lands on an alien planet (Unlike the previous movie, where Leo lands on a futuristic earth). He encounters a group of humans who are running from the apes. Leo is very confused, which becomes a major point for the beginning of the movie.The film is a direct remake from the original, but is much darker, thanks to the wonderful directing of Tim Burton. He captured the atmosphere from the previous film perfectly, but he also added a bit of an extra touch by making the apes seem much more menacing. The performances aren't Oscar-worthy, but they aren't bad (Including Mark Wahlberg, who I think was always a good actor since his starring role in the movie "Boogie Nights), and the make-up by Rick Baker is sure to get him an Academy Award. The music by Danny Elfman is amazing (Including the opening theme, which in my opinion is probably one of my top 5 themes) and it perfectly captures the atmosphere in the movie. But probably the most controversial point in the movie is the ending. It was either you understood it, or you didn't. Luckily, I was one of the people that understood it, and it almost made the movie for me. But without spoiling any of the ending, let me just say this: It's very sequel-friendly (Which in my case is a good thing)Review: ****1/2 / *****

title: This movie was pure drivel, absolute crap. Rent South Park instead.
text: This movie was pure drivel, absolute crap. Rent South Park instead.  I'm not sure what was more painful, the $5 matinee ticket price or the fact that as I sat through it I was trying to figure out what I was going to do for the rest of the weekend.  Plot was predictable and there were not surprises. Not even the "surprise" ending.

title: The apes were better
text: I have to say it held my interest but only when the apes were on screen-the only well developed characters were Tim Roth's Thade and Helena Bonham Carter's Ari. The "human" cast was weak beyond words and what in God's name inspired someone to cast Kris Kristofferson-of ALL PEOPLE-in this flick? This group deserved to be enslaved simply because they were so pathetically vapid, they'd have a hard time surviving on their own. Mark Wahlberg showed as much emotion and sensitivity as a toilet seat and one just can't imagine him as David leading the robotic humans over the Goliath apes. It also seemed way beyond the bounds of reason that ALL the apes would suddenly become tolerant and glad to consider their former slaves their equals-as we all know too well, racism and bigotry are not so easily erased. And the ending was just plain asinine, and all you Mensans out there who say oh, it makes crystal clear sense, fits right in with the plot,are just thinking too much. I get free cable so it didn't cost me anything and for that I'm grateful.

title: An exercise in what not to do.
text: In brief, this is a tragic example of a movie that should not have been made. I am not saying that the original was so amazing that it is blasphemous to re-do it, far from it. What I am saying is that this movie is so lacking in a compelling story that the truly amazing Ape effects and acting are utterly wasted. The human actors are uniformly wooden and seemingly unaffected by thousands of years of oppression, not to mention that lipstick and hairspray seem to have been developed in the jungle somehow.If you can overlook the glaring plot holes, and somehow completely ignore the, lets face it, ridiculous ending, then you stand a chance of appreciating the truly fantastic apes. If this movie could have been made without the human element, it would be an excellent portrayal in itself, as it is, this film never rises above mildly entertaining. If you are old enough to have seen the original in it's time, you will probably loathe this disaster.

title: What Was That?!
text: That was a complete waste of time. The script was so jagged, simple and ridiculous that it was almost painful to follow. The visuals like most of Hollywood these days were good, but forced to compensate for the badly written script. May be it was written for an audience of monkeys.

title: Every director has his weakest movies....
text: and Tim Burton is no exception. Even the greatest of the filmmakers in the world occasionally will make a movie which is just way too flawed to be classified as a good movie. And that's how I feel about Tim Burton's remake of the classic "Planet of the Apes". Maybe it's just one of those movies that shouldn't be remade, or maybe Burton just didn't want to make the movie, or something like that. But whatever the case, it wasn't a very pleasing movie.First off, it's just plain boring. The storyline is worked pretty weakly and much of the acting is terrible. True, the apes were portrayed pretty good and the film did have its moments. But still, about sixty or seventy percent of this movie was just dull and full of unnecessary parts and characters.At first, I refused to believe this was a Tim Burton movie, but then again, like I stated earlier, even the greatest of the great in any business make their mistakes here and there.

title: bad, bad, bad. Wasted opportunity.
text: I have two huge quibbles with the movie, both of which represent giant lost opportunities where the movie could have been actually interesting:1) the original movie featured humans who were somewhat devolved from the human race as we know it now.  Incapable of organized rebellion.  Thus it made more sense to have a strange space man come down and be seen as truly 'different' from the others.In this new version the humans, as we see them, don't seem particularly stupid, just overpowered.  For Markie Mark's character to be singled out as somehow 'different' doesn't make any sense whatsoever, because the other humans speak, reason, communicate, and organize without any difficulty.A shame, then, that this version lost the whole idea of the space man leading a race of humanoids who appeared normal yet were somewhat strange and incapable.  The only disadvantage humans seemed to have in this movie was some lack of muscle strength - and only barely.2) The portrayal of 'stranger in a strange land' is always very compelling. The audience puts themselves in the stranger's shoes and thinks, how would I react?  What would I do?  Would I stand up and say "hey, I'm not a normal human like these others, can I talk to someone in charge here?"  Would we lie in wait to suss out the situation before 'taking sides'?  Would we ask questions of our fellow captives?  There are any number of things we would do or contemplate.However this movie just charges through that whole stage of the story and explores none of these possibilities.  The moment he (literally) hits the ground, Markie Mark assumes the role of 'one of the hunted humans' and never makes any attempt whatsoever to say, "hey, wait a second, can someone explain what's happening here?  because I have an interesting story to tell. Hey apes, i may be smarter than you assume."Lost opportunities, both.Plus the movie expropriates so many 'catch phrases' of American race relations dialogue as to be nauseating ("Can't we all just get along?" "Separate but equal" etc. etc.)  Talk about bonking us over the head.And the ending is as preposterous as everyone says.Pretty costumes.

title: Oh, so THAT'S the surprise ending
text: Surprisingly contrived maybe, or surprisingly pointless.  The original had a memorable twist at the end, so I suppose they felt they needed one too. I'm torn between whether the idea behind it was bad or just poorly executed. Either way, I can see why they didn't want it to leak out. It wasn't a horrible movie.
