The effects were decent and the make-up was outstanding, but I just couldn't help thinking all the way through that I should have been enjoying it more.  I tried, but it just wasn't happening. None of the people I saw it with really felt satisfied at the end.  And the Goofs page for this film should be pretty interesting once people get going. Maybe my expectations were a little too high, but I was glad I saw it at Matinee prices.

title: Laughable
text: OK, so loose-canon Mark Wahlberg decides to violate regulations and orders to rescue his monkey friend who was sent into a strange nebulaic disruption (a la Star Trek: Next Generation), and winds up hurled through space and time to a "strange new world" where apes rule.And there begins my sadness.I'm sorry for seeming smarmy, but I would have expected so much better from Tim Burton.  Although direction wasn't the main problem with this film, the writing was 2-dimensional and atrocious to character development.  It relied heavily on apes screaming and tossing humans 20 feet in the air at the drop of a hat (not that I blame them; I would've done the same to Mark based on his wooden performance).  The battle scene was solved with such an element of corniness, the teeny boppers behind me with eyes glued to Mr. Wahlberg actually came to their senses and laughed.  This movie deserved better craftsmanship of plot vehicles.The only really redeeming thing about this film was a "pretty good considering" performance by Helena Bonham Carter, monkey makeup and all. She found a wry character and an interesting crush on Mark Wahlberg's character, handling everything that she came across with a fair amount of grace.All in all, the movie is worth checking out- once.  And on video.  It ranks higher than "Starship Troopers", but is certainly not the best thing that Tim Burton has laid claim to.

title: Infused with political undercurrent.
text: There's only one thing worse than paying $8.50 for a movie that has an axe to grind:  a movie with APES doing the axe-grinding.It's hard enough to suspend one's disbelief and get into this whole farce based, essentially, on Darwinistic evolution (which in itself is nothing more than ideological dogma, rather than anything truly scientific).  But to believe, in a "relativistic universe," where we all supposedly evolved by pure chance without intelligent design nor moral purpose, a BEAST like an ape is going to develop a moral sense and espouse a knowledge of "right and wrong" (where this came from is never stated) is just laughable.  And this is almost how the movie comes off.I would have been more able to suspend my disbelief had the apes--ALL the apes, been truly beasts.  It would have been horrific and been, FINALLY, this remake's only shot at equalling (let alone improving over) its 1968 original by creating a more potent nightmare.  Instead, it tries to re-create the original's formula--as if any of us would still be "oh'd" by the notion that this "actually could happen."Been there, done that.So, instead of exploiting the truly hellish potential of this concept, we are constantly reminded that this is a remake.  No risks are taken.  No opportunity missed to "sensitize our political ignorance" (thanks, Ms. Ape). For lessons on creating a masterful (read 'believable') science-fiction world, the makers should have studied Ridley Scott's ALIEN and BLADE RUNNER, or Cameron's TERMINATOR series.

title: Bad script
text: Average sci-fi movie which was held back by reckless script and lack of attention to detail.Good special effects though but do not expect a very intelligent movie.Action packed and with some thrills for sure but the original 1968 version is so much better folks.See this one only for curiosities sake if you are a big sci-fi fan.Marvel at it's magic and laugh at it's obvious flaws.......

title: Not sure if I count this as a reboot anymore.....
text: So after watching the entire collection in the 'timeline' order... The only way I see this movie fitting in is following the 1974 movie when Cesar learns of the original timeline of his parents. So it's changed and this movie could be explained as one of the "different lanes into the future" as described in the 1973 and 1974 movies.As a movie with in of itself it's still not great. But I do think it has a place in the timeline! But that will only make sense after watching all of them...

title: Just a bunch of former-models without any dialogue.
text: Terrible dialogue, average acting.  At times, boring.  But...a lot of apes screaming and yelling and generally acting like a bunch of monkees.  Now that made my day!  Some questions:1. Where did the buxom blonde human find such a great plastic surgeon on that god-forsaken planet?  And how did she always manage to wear make-up, even after going for a couple swims?2. Did anyone else find it a tad unfair that Mark Wahlberg stole the chimp's spaceship?  I mean, after all this hubbub about apes and men living together in equality, the brash spaceman learns nothing and leaves the chimp behind!3. Didn't you wonder whether those soldier apes were stolen from the Klingons?  I was waiting for Picard and Worf to emerge...

title: Better storyline than original, but could have been even better...
text: I usually prefer originals to the remakes, however this one is an exception. I was trully surprised by Burton's handling of this story with a respect for the original in intent. The cameo appearances and treasured lines we all look to hear were brought back and with a twist in context. When reviewing the deleted material on the DVD, I was puzzled why two very detailed scenes were redone which tied up a couple of loose ends the finished story failed to answer. The time differences were not great, so I am not sure why they were removed. With the exception of the choice of Mark Wahlberg (who I still feel cannot act his way out of a paper sack) Tim Burton did a superb job. This one is worth the purchase if you have a great home theatre system.

title: Unfulfilled Potential
text: This film could have been more. More social commentary about the simian civilization. This film was too concerned about violence in the simian-human civilization. There could have been more humor to serve as a vehicle for social commentary. It appears that Tim Burton wanted to make a more serious film than the original. The ending was a clumsy leading to a new film series.

title: wake up!
text: unfortunate that someone must explain things to a viewer...  is this a flaw with the movie, a fault of the director...  or just a lack of intelligence and imagination on the part of the viewer...?the ("much-controversial") ending makes complete sense and does not deserve the discredit it has received--  remember "...alternate futures...?" "...multiple contexts...?"  "...infinite time-loops...?" As long as CPT Leo Davidson keeps re-launching into the "electro-magnetic storm,"(--their terms--), he will encounter random, possible futures...  As suggested by the encounter with the "unknown" "Mayday" which is, infact,by the Oberon commander (Lt Gen. Vasich???). That's HIM(!!!) in the mayday, in case you didn't get it... But since it hasn't happened yet, it's a clue as to the time-dispatial aspect  of the "cloud" in space...  (Not to mention the "chimp" appearing AFTER Mark Wahlberg int the "future"... Were you sleeping...? Or did film just get too difficult for you...?" less imaginative viewers continue to complain... I thought it was a good movie, overall, although I don't like the use of close- to medium-shots during the chase&capture scenes in the first few minutes of the film...  This is the only point where I find this re-make markably inferior to its predescessor (which I saw in the theaters on it's initial run as a child...) The first film shined superior here with its use of long shots and suspension of clear "ape-"shots...  But then we all knew what this second film was about, didn't we? A congratulations to Tim Burton...  Continue the  good work...

title: Yeah! What bas rutten said!
text: I think bas rutten summed it up pretty well. I got the DVD of the Planet remake for free from the video store, and I still got ripped off! 2 hours of my life that I'll never get back! Yep, cool CG, adequate make-up (I'm not as impressed with the make-up as are others) and an uncredited cameo that made me smile when I realized who it was under the make-up. Aside from that, I can't think of anything else that's noteworthy about this movie.As I watched the remake of Planet, my mind began to wander.... I lost interest in the movie and was preoccupied with making a mental list of crappy movies that must've "looked good on paper." That is, instead of screwing up classics like Planet, go back and remake old movies that had potential, but didn't come through for whatever reason (direction, editing, cinematography, screen adaptation, etc.).

title: Guess Tim did what he could...
text: As a HUGE Tim Burton fan, I must say I was disappointed. Problem is I think Burton did what he could with a script that probably could fit on infants fingernail. At most, three lines are exchanged between the actors which leads to an almost non-existent dialogue. Some scenes sparkled with magic, but sometimes it felt like the scenes were pasted from Xena, Warrior Princess.This of course, made it difficult for Mark and the rest of the actors to create personalities which actually were interesting. I was however impressed by Tim Roth and the other monke..I mean apes.Time-travel.Always trouble.In this case,big trouble.MAJOR trouble.I didn't understand a thing.At least the ending opened for a sequel and hopefully a better one. (And why on earth did the little chimps have to play basketball??)

title: Watch it for the effects, not the story
text: I had mixed feelings about this film.Let me start by saying my enjoyment would have been greatly increased had this been a pseudo-sci-fi, action, ape-based flick that stood on its own merits instead of being associated with "The Planet of the Apes".  There were certainly things in this film which made it worth seeing.Despite what is said, the visuals and effects were interesting.  There was enough story to at least hold the interest of most.Sadly, what it lacked are those elements which made the original PotA good. The original had weak effects to be sure and the plot even had its problems. Nonetheless the depth of the plot, the debate about the content of man, the thoughts and concepts that were classic, are all missing.  I would have hoped that in a "re-imagining" the philosophy and concepts would have CHANGED; but not that they would have been omitted.I still use illustrations from the original to elucidate points.  I didn't walk away with such a feeling from this movie.  The debate between superiority of human vs. ape has been reduced to scant allusion to racial tension.  There is enough illogic to not deserve itemization (the horses have already been discussed quite throughly).  Worst of all was the ending. My friend and I are quite familiar with sci-fi, fantasy, irony and great literature.  We "get" most every reference.  However, BOTH of us looked at each other and said "huh"?  While there may be some explanations for this they didn't even establish enough clues for some healthy hypothesizing.  It seemed just "thrown in" and out of context with the rest of the movie.To close out the critique I will just state that there is a positively tragic movement in Hollywood to "dumb down" every creation.  It's like Hollywood has the touch of mental mediocrity.  You'd think for scores of millions of dollars they could somehow come up with a story and content worth the millions of dollars of effects.  Give us something that can stimulate our minds, not just our senses.  I fear this "re-imagining" fell prey to this phenomenon.That being said, I return full circle to the fact that this movie enough going for it to have been enjoyable were it to stand on its own (and taking into account the current brain-dead state of today's Hollywood scripts). There were a couple homages to the original movie which gave us a laugh or two.  As I said, the effects and even visual composition were worth seeing. If you wish to see a movie to go "ooooh" and "aaahhhh" over the effects as opposed to the "invisible effect" approach (where you are engrossed in the story, not aware of the visuals being "effects"), then you will enjoy this.I would recommend watching this.  Just enjoy it for what it is and don't expect a level of content comparable to the original.  At the very least, this movie is FAR beyond the level of any "Apes" SEQUELS, which had thoroughly useless plots without the concession of good effects.

title: A very good movie
text: Planet of the Apes was done extremely well for a remake. I thoroughly enjoyed this movie. It was not far-fetched and silly like other recent movies. There was no jumping through glass, and not getting a scratch type movie. And I was not over overwhelmed by so much action and special effects. The special effects were outstanding, and you could sometimes make out the faces of the actors. I give it *** 1/2 stars out of 4.

title: A painfully contrived, good-looking mess
text: 2001 may well be memorable as the prime year for really stupid movies.  Tim Burton's ambitious attempt to remake a dubious classic is certainly not the worst offender of the summer, but it may be the one that wastes the most potential.  In trying to avoid the pitfalls of most remakes, Burton and his scripters have tortured logic to contravene the "surprise" ending of the original to the point that their story makes little dramatic or logical sense.  With decent make-up (the lady apes are a little silly-looking), cool sets, and impressive stunt-actor acrobatics, the movie has great visual appeal, but the story veers between an allegory of man's inhumanity to man-like beings and an epic action film without ever managing to be entertaining.  See coincidence stretched once again to the breaking point, lame one-liners that no one laughs at, meaningless characters who serve no dramatic or thematic purpose, all in the service of a story with no real point.  Have to applaud the hilarious scene where perennial NRA pimp Charlton Heston as a dying father ape reveals that the secret family treasure is a hand-gun, and some of the ape cultural touches (loved the way they mounted horses) are really neat, but generally this movie left me feeling like I had wasted over two hours of my life and several points of my IQ.  And after this summer, I don't have much left.  Easily Tim Burton's worst movie.

title: Am I the only one who's glad
text: Roddy Mcdowell didn't live to see this movie? Unfortunately Kim Hunter probably heard about it & got sick to her stomach.What in the name of God??????? All the Ape faces brings to mind Halloween masks with the backs out. Shoulda recycle "Nightmare before Christmas" & "Corpse Bride" puppets or told it in CGI/animation. & again the low-lighted sets? Memo 2 all involved in film financing & distribution movie: keep his man away from remakes of any type especially musicals &, except for "Mars Attacks", this genre. & and talk of too many humans. The original two Apes films kept the human numbers to less than 20 to my recollection.I thought I'd never say this--The role of Captain Leo Davidson SHOULD HAVE WENT TO JOHNNY DEPP! He's got more versatility; will at least try to stretch his acting (Although for my taste he's being more and more horribly miscast in Timmy films). He was excellent in "Astronaunt's Wife"--Pretty Boy Wooden on Kazoo Wahlberg? Oh please! Or how about this casting Michael Keaton if not Depp??? Timmy B don't know how to cast a male lead to save his life! In terms of female leads he does better with HB-C but her in this???? IMO she should have been skipped over for casting in this flick at any & all levels. Elegant &/or down the down to every woman, whatever the character type or past & present, is her forte. As much as I hate her squat screen time role in "Charlie & the Chocolate Factory", it wasn't a SCI-FI Film! Get Veronica Cartwright, Robin Curtis, Terry Ferrell any experienced sci-fi actress who could rise above the level of unbelievable.The reasons I believe Timmy B had Chalty Heston doing his little bit here are 2 fold: 1) thought it would wow fans of the 1st movie ergo they'll come in droves trying to find what scene he's in; & 2) promised he'd pad Heston's bankroll. In case of reason #1, next time he wants to draw in fans of a media icon to a cinema adaptions, especially in the area of sci-fi, talk to Michael Bay regarding his casting of a main robot character 2007 movie adaption, for crying out loud!Oh wait a sec, just remembered--"The Astronaunt's Wife" wasn't directed by Timmy.

title: A bad movie
text: I like the concept behind the Planet of the Apes franchise, and I like all of the people involved in this project.Beyond patronage and past accolades, there is simply no hiding from the fact that this is a bad movie -- poorly written, poorly directed, and poorly filmed.It stands as a kind of parody of the original films, combined with only the sort of slow boiling inner turmoil that Tim Burton seems to understand.Instead of being indifferent to this film's existence, I wish I could watch this film more than once a year like any of the "real" Planet of the Apes films.Herein lies the beauty of cinema... one can dream.

title: A movie by monkeys for monkeys (or apes or whatever)
text: Hello, Tim Burton are you out there! No you are not. You were "out there" before and that why I've loved most of your movies, but you've really crash landed with this boring, conventional and leaden remake of "Apes". (I can't believe that I'm using the words, boring, conventional and leaden in association with your name.) In fact this movie was so bad that my friend and I walked out of it BEFORE it ended. This is only the 2nd time I've ever done this in my life. Fortunately for you I'm only 2 years old (if I was living on Pluto that is --I'm actually 43). Hello Mr. Broyles and your co-screenwriter did you ever see "X-Men"? It had similar themes about racism and segregation but it kept it speeches to a minimum preferring to show rather than tell us. I got tired of talking apes early on in this movie (or was it a stillvie because it didn't move much). Barry Sonnefeld once said that when he was done making a movie it was as bad as possibly could be. Well guess what Mr. Burton you proved his point with "Apes". However you are in good company and I'll tell you why. Tim Burton's "Planet Of The Apes" is the biggest disappointment since Stanley Kubrick's "Eyes Wide Shut". Bring back Catwoman.

title: So bad that it's kinda good
text:
Tim Burton is obviously a B-Movie fanatic.  I bet he has Roger Corman's entire collection.  Why else would he make a good film about a terrible filmmaker (Ed Wood)?  Why else would he make his own B-movie contribution (Mars Attacks), and why else would he remake the most famous B-movie EVER? 
Well I will say one thing; Burton is true to the genre.  What we have with Planet of the Apes is a somewhat diverting, overbudgeted, ridiculously scripted and acted movie.  However the worst part of this movie is not anything inside the movie.  It was the promotion.  This movie looked like a serious sci-fi attempt to succeed where the old version ridiculously (and entertaingly) failed.  But Tim Burton is unfortunately too true to the original.  Sure the make-up and special effects were cool, but there was nothing truly spectacular.  There were no moments where the audience was left in awe.  The battle sequences were huge disappointments and there was no real conflict set up anywhere.  It seemed that the screenwriters tried too hard not to let the movie drag and subsequently there was no tension or catharsis at the end.  The enormous cast is given criminally little to do.  Especially Tim Roth.  Yes the same Tim Roth that a few years ago created the deliciously evil Archibald Cunningham in Rob Roy is wasted.  His character Thane does nothing but snarl, growl, and bare his teeth.  There are attempts to make him human, but the script keeps the character so flat that the audience doesn't hate him, they just think he is annoying.  Luckily Helena Bonham Carter, Michael Clarke Duncan, and Paul Giamatti are all given a little more to do, but none of them are really compelling.  As for Whalburg, I can't find a thing to say about him, which means he did his job, but he didn't necessarily shine.  So the characters are flat, there is no dramatic tension and no catharsis, save at the very end when you find yourself laughing hysterically at how incredibly bad this movie is.  And then you realize that Burton is laughing too.  He meant the movie to be bad.  his tongue is planted firmly in his cheek.  And then you think maybe just maybe it's not so bad at all.
But while this movie succeds in being good by being bad, it falls way short of greatness.  You may be entertained, but I guarantee you will be disappointed.  5/10

title: dismal remake
text:
`Planet of the Apes' is a joyless, soulless and utterly pointless remake of the 1968 sci-fi classic.  The original film had two strong elements going for it:  its expansive visual style and its playful spirit.  Both qualities have been effectively eliminated in Tim Burton's update, along with the sense of wonder that came, thirty-three years ago, when the material was still innovative and fresh.  What viewer can forget the time he first saw that stunning final shot of the earlier version, with a weary Charlton Heston coming upon the remains of the Statue of Liberty - then bellowing in outrage at the tragic reality hitherto unrevealed to both him and us? Burton, not wanting to be a slavish devotee to the original (and not wanting the audience to know everything about the story in advance of entering the theatre), attempts a similar `surprise' ending here, but the execution of it is so ludicrous, confused and clumsy that all one can do is scratch one's head and giggle in bemused befuddlement.Much of the effectiveness of the original `Planet of the Apes' lay in its deliberately paced buildup.  The early stretches of the film, in which Heston and his fellow astronauts wandered the desert in search of life, helped immensely in generating an atmosphere of suspense and mystery.  In the new version, however, the lone hero, Thade (Mark Wahlberg), crash lands on the planet and, almost instantaneously, finds himself caught in this strange world in which evolution seems to have taken a reverse course, where apes speak and have dominion over docile humans - though they're not quite as docile as they were in the first version since in this edition the humans speak, rendering absurd the idea that the apes would consider humans to be a subspecies.   Also, in the original version, much of the time was spent focusing on Heston's attempts to convince the apes that he was every bit as smart as they were.  Thus, much of the pleasure of the film came from the fact that there seemed to be a duel of wits going on between apes and humans  a contest that often took the form of high-spirited, clever and even witty dialogue exchanges.  For all the ludicrousness of its premise, the original `Planet of the Apes' was not a DUMB movie.  I wish one could say the same for the remake.  The plotting in this version essentially boils down to little more than an extended and distended chase story, with apes racing madly after humans from one dimly lit locale to the next. 
And here we come upon another problem with the movie  one it shares with many modern action flicks, actually, especially those made by Burton.  It is simply shot too dark.  One of the qualities that distinguished the original film from most of the sci-fi adventure films that came before it was the near-epic feeling created by its beautiful wide screen images of the desert setting.  These shots lent a visual impressiveness to the potentially childish material and helped to bring an aura of seriousness to the proceedings.  In Burton's version, however, the visual style is often dark, cramped and confining, not at all conducive to the sense of majesty and awe that Franklin Schaffner's version afforded.Wahlberg is a bland substitute for Heston who, dressed only in a loincloth and hissing virtually every line through clenched teeth, seemed to sense the camp potential hidden beneath the story's surface  a fact not acknowledged by the stolid Wahlberg (or by Burton for that matter).  How we miss the charming personalities of Roddy McDowell and Kim Hunter as the sympathetic ape characters.  Poor Helena Bonham Carter, in the Hunter role, doesn't get to recite even one vaguely amusing line.  It seems amazing that a movie made thirty-three years ago would take itself so much less seriously than a film made today.  One would expect that a filmmaker like Burton, known for his ability to find humor in the most macabre of situations, would be the last director to take such a humorless, deadpan approach to material like this.   The original `Planet of the Apes' managed to combine the elements of originality, suspense, humor, irony, surprise and visual acuity to create a work of lasting value and interest. My prediction is that copies of it will still be on video store shelves long after this remake has hit the bargain-price recycling bins.

title: What a silly movie - see it if you must.
text: The best parts of this movie were Tim Roth's deliciously evil general and Danny Elfman's music.  I had a great time with my friend making fun of the movie as we watched it - flying monkey theme song from "Wizard of Oz" and the "Star Trek" series action music.  At one point we made a reference to the Monty Python "dead parrot sketch" - when the first wave of ape soldiers got hit with the afterburner and were lying in the sand - "they're not dead, just stunned." What a silly movie - see it if you must.

title: weak
text: i saw this movie, expecting something special, after getting a raving review from a friend. What did i get...let down. The first entire hour, is filled with mindnumbing violence, and a total lack of good dialogue. What i wanted to see, logic put into its place, as mark wahlberg explains his story to the apes and enlightens them, however they still reject him and thus the war breaks out. For anyone who is a fan of the first, there is no doubt that it was far superior. Old Guns and Moses was much better in the title role, as opposed to our renegade hero who doesn't have much to talk about, in the movie all in all, the movie sorely needed much better dialogue, and a stronger plot integration, as opposed to a movie of pure violence, simply throwing apes in the title roles. the idea of this movie was action not plot, however, action always takes the back seat to a good plot, never vice-versa, explain first, then fight despite my disliking of the movie, i hafta admit, the last quarter of the movie was alright, and i was fond of the ending, and the last plot twist i give the movie a **1/2 out of ***** and i hope that the sequel will be better,though it probably won't be

title: Thank God I saw it for free
text: Okay, I'm not Matt Drudge, I'm not going to give away the ending.  But I will say this.  If you like movies that FORCE you to make leaps of faith as to what is going on, if you like trying to figure out why a "good" actor like Kris Kristoferson is in the movie for a total of 30 minutes, then this is your movie.  If you know that remakes almost always stink and that your better off trying to get laid in a convent then this movie is not for you. Sorry,  but if you can see it for free like I did, you'd still feel like you've wasted your time.~Q

title: Great entertainment
text: This movie is plain fun. I liked the original movie, but the fact that the monkeys behaved like humans annoyed me. Chimps are really aggressive. Just as in this movie. Man, I love this new apes. They act like intelligent monkeys, not humans. The plot maybe somewhat empty, but it's not written to make you think but to entertain you. The ending is good, it's enough open to leave room for a sequel. Go see it and try not to think about the original movie. Have fun! 9/10

title: WASTE OF TIME!
text: i went into this movie thinking it would be a good, fun movie, i was way off.  the story was bad, the humor was stupid and it was very predictable. it also had barely any action and way to many apes screaming and howling. i really reccomend not bothering seeing this, especially with the line you have to wait in to just get in.  you may think differently and very much enjoy this movie, but you're probably wrong.

title: Why?
text: The Good: 1. Tim Burton 2. Mark WhalbergThe Bad: 1. Tim Burton + 2. Mark Whalberg + 3. The Bad Script = 4. A waste of time and money. The waste of time and money goes both ways. It is a waste of time and money on the behalf of the people who made the movie, and the same goes for people hoping that a Whalberg and Burton hookup might be worth while.This is what happens when you mix a great director with a good actor, yes Mark Whalberg can act, and a bad script. this should never have gone through if the script was so bad. The only thing that was a little better was the ape outfits, but it couldn't save the movie. Better luck next time to both of them.

title: Best movie ever!
text: Well, not really... but it was a lot of fun.  For all those who didn't like it, I'm curious what you were expecting.  Did you really expect a movie about angry talking monkeys to be a masterpiece?  Yes, it has it's flaws, but for the most part was well executed.  Tom Rothwas pure evil, some have said that he was "too evil", but isn't that the point of a super-villain?  His character was over the top, and I loved it.  The only real flaw for me was that Mark Whalberg kept slipping into Dirk Diggler, but I was able to ignore him for most of the film.  As for the ending, it was great.  I don't think that it was supposed to be logical, so stop whining!  It was a great over the top way to end an over the top film/concept.  So...go see it, expect to be entertained, not educated and you will love it!

title: Tim Burton has always been overrated
text: It may be a bit late to weigh in on this film, but I feel compelled to if for no other reason than that Tim Burton has just arrogantly messed with another classic, Charlie and Chocolate Factory, and has once again screwed things up. Burton has no concept of plot or acting, his style is entirely visual, and he is dishonest as all get out when he wants to make a point. I'm sorry that Tim had problems with his parents, especially his father, but that does not justify his screwing with classic stories so that he can whine once again about how parents just don't understand you and might even abandon you.Having got that off my chest, I would like to summarize POTA as follows. The movie makes no sense and the reason it makes no sense is that the director has no vision, no sense of a story that he wants to tell. Even the highly touted ape makeup is a mistake, because the director has no idea whether the apes are supposed to be subhuman or better than human. As a consequence they behave in a manner that simply leaves the viewer confused.I am a biologist who has studied behavior in apes, so I might be more picky than most, but I defy any viewer to answer the following question. Why are all the female apes chimpanzees? I have watched the ape village scenes several times and to my view there is not a single female gorilla or orang utan in the entire place. Also these female chimps don't look like chimps, but like some sort of odd chimp/human hybrid, which might explain the attraction between Marky Mark and Helena BC, but otherwise feels just thrown in (This is what I mean by Burton throwing logic out the window to make his themes fit his preconceptions). For example why does the female chimp (Carter) have eyebrows, a trait missing from every primate but humans? Also why do chimps, which seem to make up the vast majority of the apes, walk upright except when they charge? This makes them very ineffective as warriors. They can't hold weapons, so why do they wear armor? The acting in this film is confusing and few characters seem realized, and once again I think Burton is to blame. In Burton films the only actors who are memorable are those willing to create their own characters and overact shamelessly, e.g. Michael Keaton's Beetlejuice, Nicholson's Joker, DeVito's Penguin, Walken's headless horseman. In this film this tradition is carried on by Tim Roth's Thade, a character so psychotic it seems amazing that anyone takes him seriously. The cast includes some good actors, but all are handicapped by bad direction. For example, Paul Giamatti an excellent character actor, tries hard to create a believable character in his whining sycophantic slave trading orang utan, but he is made up as a female rather than a male orang utan, which collapses the character completely.Other actors fare no better. Wahlberg, at best a charming male ingénue, cannot act like a leader, so I was startled by the idea that all the humans would follow his lead when he seems to have no idea as to what he's doing throughout the entire film. The other humans seem to be merely tagging along looking confused. Michael Clarke Duncan, subtle and wonderful in the Green Mile, here plays sort of a King Kong who can talk. As a subtext, why are the Gorillas played by Afrcian American actors, and the chimps by white actors? This leads me to what I think is Burton's greatest weakness, his ability to direct actresses. The only actress who has ever turned in a memorable performance in a Burton film is Michelle Pfeiffer's sly, slinky Catwoman in Batman II. Otherwise excellent actresses have been left to flounder by Burton, e.g. Christina Ricci is Sleepy Hollow, Kim Basinger in Batman. Given this history, I find confusing all of the hostility and crass comments about Estella Warren's performance as Daena, the only human in the film with any personality. Estella Warren is a powerful presence, who in every film in which she appears works from the premise that she is, at the least, the equal of all the male characters and that she is smarter even than most of those. She tries to pull that off in POTA, but she is left to flounder, trying to work off the giant vacuum emitted by Marky Mark. Warren acts using her face to communicate subtle emotions and changes of mood, but that tactic backfires in this film, where subtlety is lost. She gets no perceivable reactions from Wahlberg, who seems lost in his own world, and she has almost no scenes with anyone else. As a result Warren has little to do but look distressed and confused. I think most of the negative comments directed at Warren's acting come from silly insecure young men who feel that a pretty woman should not also be strong and competent, and simply want to ogle her.To summarize, this film is probably the worst big budget film ever made, but don't blame the actors. As they say in Russia, fish begin to stink from the head. In this case the head is the director.

title: All Window Dressing, No Substance Here!
text: So sad! As a fan of the original, and Tim Burton as well, I had high hopes for this movie.  Well, dispense of any ideas of suspense or sci-fi drama! This movie is totally predictable, but COMPLETELY, TOTALLY, nonsense.  It has become a complete fantasy, with no tie in to reality or logic that made the original so compelling.OK, the filming and mood is nice, but the story is so stupid you will cry.Save your money.  Rent it later if you have to.  But take my word...one of the biggest disappointments awaits you here.Soon to be covered by MST3K!!

title: yawnfest
text: Outstanding makeup and possibly the most evil screen villain since Darth Maul won't save this movie from being placed on many peoples' worst lists of 2001. Insipid dialogue, rote acting (by humans, mostly) and action sequences that almost never gain momentum are but a few of the indignations marring what could have been a triumphant revisitation to the Ape planet. After seeing this, after seeing another down in the up-and-down career of Tim Burton, I almost wish this HAD been made by originally planned director Oliver Stone with Arnold Schwarzenegger starring. That version may at least have enjoyed some campy fun.

title: Tim Burton needs Batman and Batman needs Tim Burton
text: Tim Burton's new vision for the "Planet of the Apes" is completely dumbed down for the increasingly tolerant American movie audience.  Why can't the studios just bring out the original films, instead of remaking them? I will admit that I went to see this film with as much trepidation as going to see Gus Van Sant's misguided redo of Hitchcock's "Psycho" a few years back. This isn't as bad as that, but it's very close. Franklin Shaffner's original 1968 film is a classic (yes, classic!).  It holds up very well today and should be seen by anyone who hasn't. The new version has none of the political and social satire that makes the original so fun to watch.  I knew that Mr. Burton wouldn't even attempt a political film, so we are left with a fairly mundane film in which our new time traveler encounters a planet ruled by apes, and then immediatly wants to get the hell out of there.  The problem is there is absolutely no danger.  Mark Wahlberg doesn't face immasculation or lobotomy like Charlton Heston faced in the original. He is only faced with a villain that hates humans, but we never find out why.  Tim Roth is quite good in the role, but we need a backstory. The film does brighten up for a few minutes at the midway point, with a brief cameo.  Let's just say it's the best acting in the film. If we are going to have to sit through remake after remake, please let's try to make a film that is inspired.  Tim Burton is a very original filmmaker, who this time out is hampered by a very poor script. If William Broyles cannot come up with anything more witty than an ape saying "Get your stinking paws off me, you damn dirty human!" then perhaps he should start working on that script for "Apollo 13 Part 2" What the audience should be saying is "Keep your stinking paws off of classic movies, you damn stupid producers." In conclusion, I hope that Tim Burton can find some way to get the "Batman" franchise back from Joel Schumacher before he causes any more damage, save Michael Keaton from doing "Jack Frost 2" and stop screwing around with classic films from the past. As for Producer Richard Zanuck: PLEASE DON'T REMAKE 'JAWS'or 'THE STING' Leave those films alone for the love of God. COMING SOON: 'PAPILLON' STARRING LEONARDO DECAPRIO AND JASON BIGGS!!!

title: It' GRREEAAAATTTT
text: I went in seeing the Tim Burton Planet of the Apes, with my hopes aimed low.  I loved the first Planet of the Ape, though i have yet to see the entier series, I was wondering how they were going to pull this off.  I was very suprised.  The angel that they took was better than i expected.  They didn't go for a "Remake" of the original, but took some elements of the first one, and gave a Buton-esq spin on things.  WARNING< SPOLIERS:  The direction of not making the planet Earth was much better.  Knowing that nothing could live up to the orginal, they basicly said "Screw it" and gave a whole new origin to the Apes.  Mark Walburge's charecter is very belivable. Unlike Chuck Heston's charecter, Walburge's Leo excepts that apes are in control.  He could care less.  All he wants to do is get out, get this monkey, and go home.  The ape in the movie are also presented more human like than that of the original one.  They are more reminisant of people in the mid to late 1800's as where people were into slavery, those who flet it was wrong, began making their voices heard.  Same as with the Apes.  They felt that Humans where inferior, and thus should be slaves, but then there where those who felt that humans should be free and equal.  Tim Burton was an excelent choice for director.  Though Planet of the Apes was an odd movie for him to make (unlike the genius Sleepy Hollow, which he was born to make)  Burton really makes what he has to work with, work.  The dark theme of the  movie is not the usuall "Gothic" dark that Burton has in most of his movies (Edward Sisccor hands, Batman 1 and 2, Bettle juice, Sleepy Hollow)  he gives a dark theme that is some what moody and evil.  My only small problem is that they used the great Chuck Heston on liners, only the Apes said them.  But it was Chuck Heston himself that redeliverd his great "Damn them, Damn them all to hell" line, but as an APE!!  I recomend it highly.

title: Almost nothing of value
text: I just saw this tonight and it reminds me of "The Phantom Menace". Besides the villain, there is nothing salvageable in this movie. The acting does not exist, the characters are uninteresting, the plot makes no sense (especially the end) and I cannot tell for whatever reason they chose to do this. If you really have to see this movie, take ten bucks, set it on fire, then beat yourself on the knee with a sewing machine. It takes less time. Tim Burton should be destroyed for making this film, thank God Arnold backed out.

title: Another Disappointment in a Summer Replete With Mediocrity
text: Does anyone else out there fondly remember summers past when James Cameron would wow us with intelligent action flicks like "True Lies" or "Terminator 2," or Steven Spielberg would show us the true measure of his genius with an Indiana Jones adventure or the original "Jurassic Park"?  Much to my dismay, those days are long gone."The Mummy Returns" was an exercise in overkill.  "Pearl Harbor" was a tedious bore.  "Tomb Raider" and "Swordfish" were both so thoroughly awful they don't even merit discussion.  Spielberg's "A.I." was a pretentious mish-mash of vague concepts.  And you know things are bad when the usually reliable Disney delivers an uninspired dud like "Atlantis: The Lost Empire." Only slightly better were "The Score" (buoyed by its actors) and "Jurassic Park III," whose makers were wise enough to give us only 90 minutes of a rapidly tiring novelty.Which brings us to this disgrace.  While I am not a huge fan of the original, I am sure this version is sure to enrage those who are.  The writers of "Planet of the Apes" have substituted a series of lame jokes and puns for an actual plot, while subjecting us to a bunch of bland, one-dimensional characters and familiar action sequences.  The incessant screeching and growling of the apes stands as the most annoying redundancy in a film since the depth charges of "U-571."  Only the superb make-up by Rick Baker et al. make this film worthy of a one-time viewing.Finally, some thoughts on the director, Tim Burton.  For the life of me I cannot figure out why so many people adore his work.  Yes, I love "Pee-Wee's Big Adventure," and the original "Batman," while no masterpiece, is one of the best comic book movies to date.  But his track record of late is atrocious:  "Sleepy Hollow" was awful, and until I saw "Mars Attacks!" I never thought I'd see Jack Nicholson give a truly bad performance in a film. I will give "Beetlejuice" full marks for comedic value and originality, but "Edward Scissorhands" is a cheesy sentimentalist abomination.I find it interesting that "Ed Wood," far and away Burton's best film, is the one least remembered or mentioned by his legions of acolytes.  The talent of which he is capable shines through that film, but it appears he has sacrificed it for the allure of big-budget bombast like "Planet of the Apes."  Chalk Mr. Burton up as another casualty of Hollywood's war on artistic filmmaking.

title: Welllll....
text: Ok, we saw the film on opening night. It was showing on 3 screens at a multiplex and every showing was sold out. We waited to see this at the 10:20 showing-so maybe I expected too much or was tired. Having said that... The movie was so-so at best. The makeup was phenomenal as were the special effects. The apes were BRUTAL. Exceedingly so. This is one PG-13 movie that our girls will not go see for a long while. We carefully screen "older" movies and deem some appropriate-this is not one of those. The original was so fantastic-perhaps it was too good to ever improve upon. This version did stick closer to the original book story, however. Lastly, the ending was horrible. I have no interest in re-watching this movie, once was more than enough. Happy Viewing!

title: So predictable
text: Overall I would rate the movie as poor.  The last 20 minutes especially were so so predictable.I am also find Tim Burton's dark, gothic style sets and use of lighting is starting to get boring.  He has used the same style in Edward Scissorhands, Batman and Sleepy Hollow.It would be good if Mark Wahlberg displayed more than one set of facial expressions during the movie as well.Don't waste your money.

title: As a fan of the Original
text: although i liked the movie as a whole.even though it was studio bound and didnt look like a $100 million dollar movie.the cast were good.i think the hero was too young.russell crowe would of been better or arnie.infact there was talk of arnie and oliver stone doing this movie.well i did like it the main villan has a poor send off but maybe thats for the sequal.i do recommend the movie.its certainly better than mars attacks.though i would of liked to see the apes armed. 8 out of 10

title: Worst Burton movie I've seen
text: I read the movie reviews, thought "that's not too promising", but when a friend pointed out that it was a Tim Burton movie, I agreed to watch it. Burton usually provides nice twisted stories and wonderful sceneries. But not this time. There is none of crazy of Mars Attacks, and too little of the moodiness of Batman. None of the skilful storytelling of Sleepy Hollow. The apes are wonderful and quite believable, except for their wild jumps. The ape city is fabulous. But the rest is rather bland. And the story sucks big time! It is too predictable, too simple, just done without feeling. If anyone is surprised at the end, I am amazed.The acting is quite OK, Helene Bonham Carter does a wonderful job as an ape. The crazy ape Thade is a lovely psychotic. But the hero is wooden, and the babe unnecessary. The movie had me twisting in my seat wishing certain scenes would end quickly. The logic at the end, when here can choose between staying and being everybody's hero and have at least one human and one ape girl to enjoy himself with, but instead goes off into space and into a storm is just mad. If I were the guy, I would stay and not risk the storm again; never know where it would put me.The one redeeming quality is the few massed scenes were the ape legions leave their city and the attack at the big battle at the end. And the apes' make up, again.

title: Flat, predictable, and boring.
text: Standard Hollywood action fare which we have numerous times seen before. The film is completely flat and predictable with zero originality. Canned food, as opposed to a delicious meal that one might expect.

title: BORING!!
text: I was so bored during this movie!  I would not see it again or recommend that anyone else waste their money on it!  There were some good parts in it, but not enough to make it worth your while.  Mark Wahlberg's acting was horrible!  A speech he gave to motivate the humans was the most pathetic thing I have ever heard!  It wouldn't have motivated an ant!  The effects were pretty cool, but don't waste your money.

title: eh....
text: I had extremely high expectations when i entered the theatre, for the first 3 quarters of the film, my expectations were being fulfilled, however.... with the last quarter i became a tad bit disappointed. Aside from the ending, i would say that it was a pretty good movie.

title: Makes No Sense
text: This movie should've had a "To Be Continued..." caption tacked onto the final scene just like those bad soaps from the 80's. It just makes no sense whatsoever!The movie has no tension, bad pacing and relies way too much on fight sequences than on dialog/story.Maybe it was the movie theatre I saw it in but was there any score to the movie? If there was I didn't hear it.A few observations:We don't really care Leo (Mark Wahlberg) tries to rescue his pet chimp, it's way to early in the movie to care, put it down to bad writing.None of the human characters has anything of interest to say so why have them speak at all in the movie?Flying apes? That's what it looked like to me. Sure, the stunt looked great in The Matrix and MI:2 but do we have to have it every movie, even one with apes?Nice cameo from Mr. Heston, and he gets that great line again!The battle scene at the end is a very bad rip-off of Braveheart/Gladiator, if you can't better it, leave it alone!As for the ending... well, you'll have to see the movie for yourself but rest assured, it doesn't work. If you've paid close attention to the movie, it's wrong, if not impossible. It's a cheat, a scam, a cliffhanger that has no cliff to hang you from.Save your money and rent the original.

title: WHAT A CHEESEDI*K ENDING!
text: I've seen a lot of bad movies lately and I refuse to pay full price anymore because the quality is crap!  But this one is truly a stinker for the ages. I am continually amazed that people shell out their hard earned money for a story with so little forethought.There were so few entertaining scenes that I found myself yawning through most of it and just as we seem to reach a (aww) happy ending that explains everything.  Marky Mark flies through the universe in about three minutes, lands on earth, and sets the scene for probably one of the worst sequels that will ever be made (Next to Jurassic Park II of course).Exactly how stew-pod (book reference) do movie makers think we are?  How much crap will we actually put up with before we refuse to go to movies anymore?  Oh yeah, never mind, JP 3 made 80 million last week,  guess that our stupidity has no limits.Save your money, read and book and leave something to the imagination.2 out of 10

title: Absolute disgrace to Charleton Heston and Tim Burton
text: Most likely fooling millions of hopefuls, this tragedy of a film completely epitomizes the absolute disgrace to all movies made by Charleton Heston or directed by Tim Burton.  I hope my warning will at least keep a few from seeing what they will be disgusted with two and a half hours later. First, the apes are unrealistically strong, and this factor throws the entire main conflict out of proportion making the story that much harder to fathom. Second, the humans can talk, which throws the story far from a Planet of the Apes movie in the first place (this may just be personal preferance). Last, the ending ruined any good coming out of the movie.  Charleton Heston's great scene couldn't even make this movie.  I personally thought this movie not worth the paper that the money I paid to get in was printed on. That's just me though.

title: short but sweet
text: Awful, just awful! Bad casting, bad acting and not a patch on the original. It could have been so much better. I know the idea is somewhat far fetched about apes ruling the earth, but the original film was entertaining and thought provoking. This version is just downright silly. Sorry, but it stinks!

title: maybe the best movie of the summer
text: when i went to see this movie with a group of my friends, my expectations were low. I figured it would be a cheesy ripoff of the first, since i already knew it had little to do with the original. i also used to like mark wahlberg in movies like three kings and the perfect storm, but the more i see him in interviews and in public, the more i wished his career died with the funky bunch. however, this movie was a very pleasent surprise. The make up was incredible, especially when you take into consideration the massive cast who all needed to be made into apes. i was also impressed with the way the actors who were portraying the ape characters moved and acted like the real animals. also, i was able to put mark wahlberg's over-all annoying behavior when he's off camera  aside, and really enjoy him in this movie. the only thing i didn't really buy was the relationship between mark wahlberg and estela warren, who plays a very hot slave woman, human of course. towards the end of the movie you get the feeling that there is supposed to be a deep meaningful relationship between them, that simply wasn't built up enough. the only other low point was when mark wahlberg kisses the ape woman who has been helping them. this was supposed to be a very sensitive part of the movie, but the audience on hand that day responded with a resounding "EEEEWWWWWWW!!!" One of my friends even yelled, "GO FOR THE BLONDE!"(Warren) No one laughed at his joke but everyone felt the same way. the best part of this movie was the ending, which i would never give away. but i will say it meets, and nearly outdoes, the original ending. with all of the big summer dissapointments i've seen in the last few months, Planet of the Apes was easily worth the money, do yourself a favor and see it.9/10 stars or if you go by the four star rating: 3 1/2 out of 4

title: It's not Scottish so it must be....Crrrrrraaap!
text: This was so inane and awful I actually for fun starting picturing Jean-Claude Van Damme in it for laughs. I think what's so flabbergasting about it's awfulness is it's the same director who brought us Edward Scissor Hands and Sleepy Hollow. How did such cheesy dialog and typical action movie twists and turns get by him. Maybe they should never give large action movies to more artistic smaller budget directors. They get so swallowed up the studio machine protecting it's investment in a franchise and happy meal tie-ins kinda way. I bet someone like John McTiernan might have actually been a better choice. We'll have to see what he does for Rollerball. This movie makes Mighty Joe Young look like a Dickens classic.

title: The worst movie I saw this summer
text: This movie is a joke!  One of the worst movies I have ever seen!  The only thing that kept me from walking out of this nightmare was Estella Warren. Not only do I think Tim Burton has completely lost his originality and independent risk taking but Mark Walburg???  This guy is the most over rated actor to date.  Are you kidding me, all he does is breath heavy and talk breathy in every movie he's ever in.  My rating for this flick would be GARBAGE if there was one.

title: Hum Drum and Conventional
text: "Planet of the Apes" was a surprisingly conventional, if entertaining, sci fi movie, complete with references to the "Star Wars" and "Star Trek" movies, as I expected more imagination from director Tim Burton. Mark Wahlberg was also surprisingly bland, as I'd liked him in other dramas and I was about the only female in the audience so I guess he's not that much of a chick draw, though I go to about all sci fi movies anyway.I'm a big fan of Tim Roth but would absolutely never have been able to tell that he was the chief bad guy general without seeing his name in the credits. The ape actors could have been doing voice-overs for animatronics for all the make-up let them emote, which I hadn't felt in the original movie, and Roth's voice really got into the role (he'd turned down the Snapes role in the Harry Potter movie for this?).But sound was the best part of the movie, and it was really loud. Danny Elfman's score was so good, sounding like those Japanese drums a lot of the time, that I paid more attention to the music than to the special effects.(originally written 8/21/2001)

title: Eeeeeh Eeeeeeh Eeeeeeeh! A-pe +
text:
Being a lover of the original series I was nervous to say the least. But Tim Burton surprised even me. His take on the ape story is just as good and fresh as the original! This film starts off fast and keeps moving. Burton's dark avant-garde  style of film making does not interfere with this flick. And yet his style is all over. This film has witty dialogue, GREAT special effects, and great ape performances from all. The "monkeys" in this version are so much more menacing here that I just may have nightmares. Mark Whalberg's debut into super-stardom is also noteworthy. His mile a minute, never stop attitudes is refreshing and brings his character to life.
I won't go into the story but I will say I didn't think Burton could offer an ending as creative and shocking as the original... but guess what? HE DID IT.... twists and monkeys abound! Go ape and go see it....

title: One of the Worst Movies ever
text: I was a fan of the original Planet of the Apes and all of its sequels, which told a fairly convincing story.  This new version blows all of my expectations away.  It was one of the worst movies I've ever seen.  The acting was terrible and if we ignore the little facts (like how easily Ari let herself be lead by humans or how Daena has lipstick and a boobjob on this planet), the overall plot made no sense.  This movie was made to have a sequel, because there was no explanation of why earth was exactly as it is now, just with apes.  All in all, DON'T SEE THIS MOVIE!!!

title: This movie was clearly a 6 till the last 10 minutes which, made it a 1.
text: This movie was clearly a 6 till the last 10 minutes which, made it a 1. This movie falls under the category of phantacrap.  The end of the movie must have been conceived while under the influence of some amazingly boring drugs.  This work is staple 70's crap that has been digitally remastered to spread poor film viewing to the new generation.

title: Tim Burton Misses One
text: What happened? Tim Burton assembled most of the key elements for science fiction success; outstanding makeup, good actors, excellent score, himself directing. But he left out one critical ingredient, a good, tight script. And that omission, in my opinion, sinks the movie. I salute the filmmakers for not wanting a total remake of the original (and better) "Planet of the Apes", and that they wanted to put a different spin on the story. And they did, changing many key plot points including the ending. But there are serious problems with the script, among them: (1) Humans speak English, but don't have much to say. There's not even a hint as to why they think they're in the position they're in. (2) The movie has a blatant political/social message that is forced-fit in to key dialogues. (3) The ending is so bad as to be laughable. The makeup alone is worth the price of a rental, but the movie really never takes off. It's certainly not as good as the original.

title: Planet of Apes + Star Wars + Back to the Future = Silly
text: Very disappointing. Most of the criticisms are correct (no plot, bad acting etc.) but I also thought that the special effects were so-so. *Very* derivative and I can only assume that everyone was in it for the money. So save your own money and avoid. 3/10 (5 for Tim Roth and -2 for the rest).

title: A feast for the eyes!
text: The story is not quite as good as the first film, but is definitely alot of fun to watch. The one downfall of the film is the overall substance of the human beings and their relationship with one another.  It was pretty cold in that area.  I would have given the lead to a different actor other than Mark Wahlberg. His character needed to be as big as the apes in the film.  And the apes in this film were just as good as the characters in the first movie.  Super makeup by Rick Baker and the sets looked fantastic.  One final note...I wish the battle scene at the end had more substance and a little more thought put into it.  This would have given the film its climax that it badly needed.

title: An excellent movie...right up until the last ten minutes.
text: The special effects and the makeup in this movie is the stuff of legend. The script is tight and moves at a respectable pace.  The acting is above par given the accomplished supporting cast.  Now the downside...Mark Wahlberg isn't a strong enough actor in his own right to carry this film. His character doesn't grow at all from the start to the end.  And speaking of the end; I'm not going to give it away but it made no logical sense in the context of the story that we had been watching for the previous two hours.  I was completely hooked into the movie until this ending that seemed as if it was filmed later and tacked on.  If they had left off the last ten minutes of the film I would have given this movie an 8.  But the crapola ending brought the whole picture down to a paltry 5.

title: Don't waste your time or your money.
text: Tim Burton, Mark Wahlberg, Tim Roth - could it be that bad??  Yes!!  Its that bad and worse.  Don't waste your time or your money.  I did not expect much but thought I would at least be somewhat entertained.  I was wrong. This movie is boring and stupid.  The same things seemed to be happening repeatedly and pointlessly.  Roth's was the only part that had any kind of emotion or character.  On the surface there should have been tension in the plot but none whatsoever was conveyed.  The dullness of the characters and even the so-called action scenes, was astounding.  There is no mystery about the ending of the film and it would be another waste of time to try to decipher one.  I suppose it would have been an even worse film if there had been no "surprise" at the conclusion - but I'm not so sure.  I think the end just added another note of idiocy.  Its difficult to understand why any critic would ever recommend this film.

title: Oh. My. God.
text: This is the movie I have been waiting for 30 years to see, ever since I peeked over the back seat of the station wagon at the drive in theater waiting for Doctor Dolittle (http://us.imdb.com/Title?0061584) to start.  I was five years old, and this was before the days of real ratings.  Besides, the original Apes movie was rated an amazing 'G' as was that other talking animal film we went to see.That said, I was terribly disappointed in the 2001 re-visioning of the 'Planet of the Apes'.  Tim Burton is one of my favorite cutting-edge directors, and Danny Elfman a top composed.  The cast looks excellent - on paper, but in reality the characters are mainly one dimensional and shallow. The possible exception is Helena Bonham Carter as Ari, who at least seemed to have fun playing a rather muppet-like Chimp/Human rights activist. Burton didn't dare go anywhere but the obvious places, and even with the attempt at a surprise twist ending (which left me slack jawed at the sheer disconnectedness of it).  There were so many opportunities to build these characters in an otherwise visually stunning universe.  Would it be bestiality for two sapient members of different species to actually explore their apparent sexual tension that Burton was trying to portray?  Could it have been possible for Daena (Estella Warren) to do anything other than pine and heave her fur-bikinied breasts about?  There was a real opportunity to explore something here that Burton ignored.  And Burton usually hits these on the head.The first ape line of the film made me dread what was an otherwise decent start to the movie.  I won't reveal what it is, but it was too obvious an attempt to try to a) make you laugh, b) set the tone of the film, and c) nod to the original film.Overall, I give this film a 3 out of 10 for an overall impression.  I give Rick Baker a 10 out of 10 for an AMAZING bunch of creatures.  I give Mark Wahlberg (Capt. Leo Davidson) a -2 out of 10 for mailing in his performance and avoiding any sort of commitment to his role.  Helena Bohnam Carter (Ari) gets a 7 out of 10 for her role, and Tim Roth (General Thade) gets 8 out of 10 for being a peeved chimpanzee and a vicious character, and making me truly dislike him.  Or was it the complete shallowness of his character that I hated?  Wait, I give Tim Roth an 8, and I subtract two points from Tim Burton for not allowing such a fine villain to have any depth for a total Tim Burton score of 3 out of 10.  Visually, the film gets 8 out of 10 from me.Nutshell summary:  A mediocre attempt worth seeing for the makeup and soundtrack, and for the uncomfortable laugh at the end when you realize how much Hollywood is spending to produce crap these days.  This film is definitely worth a rental, but save yourself the $8.50 to see it in the theater.

title: Pretty good I thought
text: This film isn't nearly as bad as lots of people are making it out to be, there are weak areas and it isn't perfect but most people just got over-hyped and expected a perfect film. There's some good characterisation for Ari and Thade and the plot wasn't all that bad and leaves plenty of room for a sequel. Some people thought it was boring but they are just petty minded simpletons who went to see a horror/action film which is more like the originals and don't understand anything outside that. Don't go expecting more of the originals, like Burton said, it's not a remake, more of a rehash.

title: A Stinker! Absolutely Horrible!
text: This is by far Tim Burton's worst film.  Some nice visuals and performances don't offset a truly terrible script.  Also, further enhanced by an audience-groaning stunner of a bad ending.  A waste of time and money--Burton's a fine director who should stay far way from big-budget studio-tampered behemoths like this.  Ugh.

title: Ari's true identity
text: Everybody's making such a big deal about the makeup in this film. I have only one question... Was that Latoya or Michael? I hate to say it, but I actually found Roddy McDowell's Cornelius a more convincing ape than most of these apes. General Thade looked great, but so many of the others.. I mean what the hell were they? I couldn't look at Helena Bonham Carter without thinking of Michael Jackson. But then I thought, wait.. maybe it's Latoya.

title: a nice try
text: The revision "Planet of the Apes" pretty much lived up to my expectations as a not-too-good nice try. By itself it makes a reasonable action sci-fi but falls far short from the great originals. Although it does try to make a statement of some kind, it is far too obviously and shallowly done. The characters were also a let down, being quite one dimensional.That said, however, should the movie be judged by it's own merits, and not seen in the shadow of the original Planet of the Ape movies, it does deserve some credit as far as entertainment is concerned. It follows a good, exciting and 'non-stagnating' plot, and the viewer remains interested throughout.Overall; a nice try but should not have tried to follow in the foot-steps of the originals.

title: Great movie, but green ape sidekick ruins highscore.
text:
I watched the 1968 Planet of the Apes and afterwards I was amazed how well I liked it. It was sent on TV and I thought like " I am going to die along with the movie runtime " but it was really good. So therefore I thought that Planet of the Apes Redux, or whatever one calls it, would be fun to see. And when I read Tim Burton had directed the whole thing I was even more excited. Edward Scissorhands- director doing a redux of one of the true movie classics, is that great or not.So I saw the movie and I was delighted to see how the masks had got even more realistic. And we also had Mark Wahlberg performing quite good, but alas he did not prove to be better than old Heston of the original. Helena Bonham Carter as sweet ape Ari was perfect for the role but this human-beings-seller in green? A typical sidekick, and I have never liked sidekicks. He has these spot-on comments to the movie's happenings but this true " evil ape empire "-feeling at once gets toned down by this fellow.
Tim Roth plays evil ape general Thade, the ultimate bad guy, breathing a little bit like Darth Vader in Star Wars. Michael Clarke Duncan have been showing off for the Apes- posters, so naturally he plays a great role as armyleader Attar. I have now seen the movie three times, one time on cinema, two times on VHS and I can't still figure out how the ending was like.

title: Movie for apes,not for people
text: I could have never imagined that something more idiotic from "mummie 2" would come to me this year,but it happened...The remake of the famous and outstandingly good "Planet of the apes" from 1968,I think...I went to the cinema anxious,I came out p***ed of.What the hell was that?The incredible "flight to neverland",the characteristics of the apes,idiotic plot and outline,and MOST OF ALL,the image of the true,brave,intelligent,handsome all-American heroe.I wanted to vomit on the carpet and leave the cinema.Like all American air-pilots,this one has a knowledge of pursuading people(apes),making weapons,riding,fighting simultaniosly with 300kg gorillas,natural lidership...Go home Rambo.Make place for one and only captain Leo Davidson!Incredible.And the pure,pure acting of an "Victorias Secret" model goes well with the movie(we all know who that is).The director is a genious of its own kind.Tim Burton.Yeah.I think everyone will notice the unforgettable clishe-scene of the "american airborn" hero on the horse and the sunrise(or sunset,whatever)behind the mountains waiting for the final countdown.Truly original.The only think missing is the pack of Marlboro (welcome to...) and Morricones score from "The good,the bad and the ugly"...

title: The original was better, but the 2001 version was fair.
text: This movie is not bad if you don't compare it to the original.  Do not see this movie if you enjoy good acting and a great story.  But if you have the mind of a 12-year-old boy, you'll probably enjoy yourself.  The movie was not as stylized as other Tim Burton movies.  And I use the word movie as opposed to film.Most of the characters in this movie are two dimensional cardboard cut outs. There is not one character who we get to know with any depth.  This is a major flaw of the movie.  Because the audience really doesn't care about what happens to anyone of them.  I suppose that some people would believe that the audience's loyalty it is built in - since the audience is human and we would naturally root for our own kind.However, in the original we get to know Cornelius and Zira and therefore cared about what happened to them, even though they are chimpanzees.It both helps and hurts to have seen the original.  It helps, because you a familiar with the background, you don't need to have things explained to you.  However, it hurts because you will inevitably compare the two works - the 2001 version failing in almost ever respect to a comparison of the first.Watching the two will only make a person realize how little acting and directing talent there is out there today.  Some might say, the past is not better, it was just different.  That would be ridiculous. No objective observer,  looking at the acting talent in the first one, (Charlton Heston, Roddy McDowall, James Whitmore, Kim Hunter, Maurice Evans), could argue that today's version, with its cast, is actually a better movie.  Even the mute Linda Harrison character Nova, said more with her eyes and facial expressions, than the updated Daena (Estella Warren) with all her lines of dialog.  Charlton Heston's death bed scene (as Gen. Thade's father) is about the only real piece of dramatic acting in the whole movie (2001).  Although, to his credit, Paul Giamatti's Limbo character does provide some nice comic relief throughout the 2001 version.In the original, we had political, social and cultural commentary.  Today's version has very little.   When it does attempt to offer some, it is so brief and mealy-mouthed in its delivery that it only serves to weaken the picture.That's the real weakness of this movie.  It doesn't know whether it wants to be gritty and dark or light and campy.  All to often, it falls into the latter category, hurting its otherwise fine production values.  (Quite unlike some other Tim Burton movies). It rates 5 out of 10 stars.

title: disapointing
text: Thought there would be more to it. The end was dumb, movies are better when they are sumed up, not just left to wonder. If there was more stuff explained in it, you kind of had to piece stuff togethre, also he should not have kissed the monkey.

title: Editing Action
text:
I've begun to appreciate the massive value of editing action sequences. When it's done well, there aren't any questions about who's hit whom, where the action's taken place or whether the sequence is even plausible. 
In "Planet of the Apes", I think that the editing sucked lemons. 
In fact, the movie as a whole was really three inches shy of being very annoying.  I found myself admiring the make-up, for heaven's sake! 
If you must see it, check your brain in at the popcorn stand.

title: Lots of wasted potential
text: This could have been a great movie, but they dug themselves into a hole and then couldn't figure out how to get out.  I enjoyed the up until the "battle" scene.  Then things stopped making sense.  Leo's big plan turned out to be a dud.  The humans should have been wiped out.  Then, even though the highly trained human pilot crashes not once, but twice, we are expected that the chimp pilot experiences none of the same problems and can land his pod without difficulty.  Why does a cute chimp landing in a space craft make the apes suddenly believe that the humans aren't so bad after all?Then there's the stupid "suprise" ending.  The whole movie is based on the premise that the smart apes evolved from genetic engineered apes that crash landed on the planet with the humans.  So why are we supposed to suddenly believe that Leo would crash land in a second parallel world where Washington D.C. looks just like ours, but everybody is an ape instead of a human?  This ending had nothing to do with the rest of the movie.It had potential, but it bombed instead.

title: Childish, very childish
text: This was a very disappointing film. It was far too childish for my liking. The bad ape, was ridiculously "bad". He was putting faces and making sounds with the apparent intention of being scary. Clearly intended for the younger audience. There was even a "smart ass"-"joking" character, as in the typical Walt Disney films.

title: Better than I honestly expected!
text: I went to see a preview of Planet of the Apes with some reservations. After all, I grew up with the original movies, and didn't think Tim Burton was the one who should "revisit" the franchise.  But the special makeup was incredible, and the mannerisms by the actors seemed so realistic that it blew me away.  Tim Roth is amazing - truly menacing, and wonderfully intense.  And the explanation of how the planet's inhabitants came to be was one of those last-minute "Oh - NOW I see it coming!" moments, where it wasn't obvious from the get-go.  All in all, I'd highly recommend seeing it!

title: Simply Awful!
text: Please people, stop feeding this stinky movie with your hard earned money! Lord of the Rings is just around the corner, then you can see plenty of people running around in makeup.  Stay away from this bad movie.  Only good thing about the movie, is giving Chuck his props with a cameo.*Note to the studios, you suck if you even try and make a sequel to this. Oh and Burton if you indulge them, you suck even worse.

title: What Else Left Besides Makeup and Effect?
text: The biggest problem in the Planet of the Apes is that there are no deep feelings within the characters. Leo (Mark Wahlberg) does not care for any of human on the planet of the apes but himself. His goal was just get himself out of the planet as soon as possible. The director knows too well that he is not a hero, that's why he decided to add a scene of heroic rescue of a young boy in the movie. But it doesn't help to make him a better character but too obvious of an effort. Ari (Helena Bonham Carter) was a confusing idealistic character that she believes ape and human should be equally live together. But the movie fails to show her feeling when she watches human killing her own kind. Instead of an internal struggle inside her, she just blindly help human beat up her own people. And the third main character, Daena (Estella Warren) she was just a pretty figure follows Leo everywhere until the end. It's not her fault that she couldn't act, it's the movie doesn't give her any chance to act. It was a failure when Leo farewells to Ari and Daena in the end, there's nothing there to drive the audiences to any feeling. It's as if we watch some stranger say goodbyeThey could have brought up much more than this. They could use the scene when Ari heard about how human treat Apes on Earth (lock in the zoo) as an ironic moral in the movie. But they didn't go further Everyone agree that the makeup in this movie is awesome. There's no doubt about that. But beside the makeup, Tim Burton directed nothing shine in this remake of sci-fi classic.Everyone agree that the makeup in this movie is awesome, but beside the makeups, there's nothing shine in this remake of sci-fi classic.HinxLinx

title: No Story, very bad ending, just a hide and seek movie, very bad
text: This movie as no real story. An ending that is totally out of context and not in the line of the movie, it is only good to make a sequel. It is just a hide and seek movie (get in and get out like a bad alien movie) Only the mask are a little better that the one in the original.

title: i thought i expected better
text: The movie was great, but not as great as the original Planet of the apes which was made in 1968. There are a few reasons why I did not find this film more interesting than the original: number 1, if the humans were mute and the apes hated them more, the movie would've been great because there is more conflict, number 2, Cornelius and Zira did not appear and I liked them because they were good actors in the original and in the second Apes saga and the last, but not least, there was no reason to remake the Planet of the apes, I mean, of course it's an entirely different generation and kids are curious of why they want to remake it, just to let them know that there was an original movie of the Apes in the late 60's. But, there was no reason to do a remake of the apes because the original movie was a huge success.My rating: 5 out of 10 stars

title: animal planet
text:
Having never seen the 1968 version, I went into this not knowing quite what to expect. It occurs to me that this film wouldn't exist without the Charlton Heston version and its sequels. Imagine if Franklin Schaffner had never adapted Pierre Boule's novel. Do you suppose that now someone would still come along and say, hey, that would make a good movie? Actually let me re-phrase that: would that make a movie ANYONE would be interested in seeing? Not likely. So having seen Tim Burton's newly 're-imagined' "Planet of the Apes," am I glad there was an original whos coat-tails it could ride? Well, it's not terrible. At times it's downright interesting. Ultimately, though, it's just unnecessary. But that doesn't mean you can't enjoy it as long as it's around. Like any Burton film, this one is about escape. It transports you to another place and time. The sets, the makeup, the effects all work hard to create this temporary reality. It's convincing but, visually, I was hoping for something more like "Sleepy Hollow." I was never amazed by anything in "Apes" but was stunned by some of the things Burton and his crew accomplished on such previous films as "Sleepy Hollow" and "Batman." "Apes" seemed like fertile ground for the same visual opportunities, but Burton doesn't make good. At best, he's made the kind of cheesy sci-fi he poked fun at in "Mars Attacks." The irony!
