This didn't look or feel like a Tim Burton film at all. Where is the weird coolness that creeps into every single shot? Think of "Batman," how it more than overcame that horrid script with Palance and Nicholson, along with Burton's twisted vision of Gotham City. And where did the humor go? Burton picks NOW to get serious? THIS film? I mean, if this was the best he was going to do with "Planet of the Apes," he should have just stuck his name on it as producer and let some up-and-comer direct (actually, that will happen with the inevitable sequel, er, sequels). Not even Tim Burton can save us from Summer 2001, a film lover's nightmare.
Grade: C-

title: I cannot believe how bad this movie was
text: Let me just start of by saying that this movie was a total waste of time, money, effort and was possibly the biggest dissapoinment I have ever seen.With all the hype behind the movie I expected a lot, and I mean a whole lot more out of this.  The acting was second rate at best, characters were so predictable, and the plot so thin that I was about ready to get up and leave 1/2 way through the movie.  How many of you out there actaully managed to predict the movies ending at about the half way point???  And the Ka Li Ma thing?  Makes you think they ripped that off from Star Trek when the spacecraft came looking for "v y ger".Absolutley no premise was given to the scientific background that would make such a series of events possible.  Not just the time shift but the whole evolution of monkeys into something more.  If in the thousadn years or so that the monkeys had become dominate then why had the humans not also changed?  Wouldnt the humans be a lot smaller and dumber?  And all the perfect teath in the movie?If you have to see it wait for the video to go into the $.99 special of the week section.

title: This Movie Stinks!
text: I am a huge fan of the original series, maybe that's what ruined the new one for me. I was looking forward to an all new installment and what we got was a boring plot-less mess that decides to use movie lines from the original as jokes. The Makeup and sets are great but who cares? This movie is lifeless and dull for the first hour as apes sit around discussing human rights.The New Planet of the Apes lacks the mystery and intrigue and character the first movie had and only decided to capitalize on the fact that Apes can talk. The ending is a ridiculous mess too that only sets up a sequel possibility. This movie is garbage and you should spend your time watching the original instead. I came as close to crying when I walked out of the theater as I ever had in my life.

title: Score one for Marky Mark
text: When I first read that they were going to do this remake I thought it was a ridiculous idea. The original premise was so silly that I thought if there is one movie that did NOT cry out to be remade it was this one. I was incorrect in assuming this. The prosthetic makeup is so much better than the original(you can see the actor's real faces beneath the ape facade)that the biggest hurdle is immediately overcome. Tim Burton excels in working unusual concepts in his film and this is more of the same. Mark Wahlberg fits as the protagonist and while he is not Laurence Olivier the material isn't Shakespeare either. I went expecting little and was pleasantly surprised. With people staying away from the theatre in droves this summer I don't think the film will do that well in the box office but I will recommend it.

title: Puke
text: I don't want to sound rude or anything but this film is stupid, pointless, dumb and boring. OK, it's better than some films like the remake of "Moulin Rouge", but i mean that's just like saying that hanging is better than stabbing. I found it hard not to burst out laughing hysterically when I saw some weird looking ape-guy jumping all over the place saying dumb-sounding stuff like "Kill them all". What the hell happened to Tim Burton, the director of the fantastic "Ed Wood"? The end of "Planet of  the Apes" suggests that Tim Burton was intending to make a sequel, but I hope for the sake of respectable cinema, that this will never happen. 5/10 (that's being pretty generous too)

title: Jon Monsarrat review: sub-intellectual but not awful
text: I'm not very arty and I don't expect films to contain exceptional choreography or makeup. But I do expect it to make sense, be engaging, and have a moving plot. And I like car chases and when stuff blows up. And I like science fiction.But even with these factors in my favor, I was very disappointed by Planet of the Apes.The film is poorly acted -- especially the natives, and the world does not seem realistic, so instead of being spooky we don't really get drawn in. Most importantly, I don't like a sub-intellectual film that insults my intelligence. Some of the plot twists just didn't make any sense. The original version had something to say; that all gets lost here.What a disappointment, and the ending was brutally concocted and unsatisfying.Who should see this film:-- Sci-fi film buffs who didn't mind the stupidity inthe remake of "Lost in Space", or "Independence Day"(which admittedly is a lot of people)-- I can't think of anyone elseI regret I can only give "Planet of the Apes" an uninspired 5 out of 10.

title: Horrible....
text: This film is quite horrible... I can't believe they've made so much hype about that! The plot follows no logic. It seems that the writer stopped the film at that point so he'll have two more years or so to make the story sounds logical. The end is so pathetical that looks like a comedy and not a sci-fi adventure. It's bad directed, things are just thrown away and the scenes have no elaboration. The camera work is nothing but elementary, and, also, the make-up of the female monkeys looks fake and unreal. A real class on how to NOT make a film. 2/10.

title: Awful Ending
text: This was a very entertaining film until......the worst,most illogical ending of any major film that I can ever remember. The ending was so awful that it ruined the entire film for me. Tim Burton,what were you thinking? or were you thinking at all?

title: I was into this film
text: The story behind Planet Of The Apes is such a great one that it is almost impossible to mess it up. This new version of the film thankfully does not do that. I liked the original and I like this one as well. It adds a lot of special effects to an already great story to create something that I would want to experience again.

title: Planet of Crap
text: This movie sucks.  The plot is W-E-A-K and rife with holes.  The acting was on par, but the script was horrible.  With so many writers, how could it be so bad?  One can only guess that so much attention was paid to the makeup (fantastic) that a good script was overlooked.Tim Burton has officially sold out and Mark Wahlberg is capable of so much more when he has a good script to work with and a director more concerned with storytelling than points on the back end.If you just HAVE to see "Planet" on the big screen, save some money and go see a matinee.  Or better still, just wait until "Chimp Week" on Animal Planet.

title: Not even for free
text: A real turkey and I want my two hours back.This is not a worthy remake of the Chuck Heston original.  The plot tries to have twists, but they are more like contortions.  The acting is terrible and the costumes are pretty bad for the most part.If you want Planet of the Apes, watch the old one.

title: Should have stayed in the can
text: Tim Burton blew it with this adaptation.  The original is a fine film; the 2001 version is horrid.  The story is bad, patchy, and poorly fleshed out. The characters are no one I would want to relate to and the sideplots are meaningless and distracting.  The worst part of all is the "return" to Earth.  What was Tim Burton smoking when he came up with that?  Bad, bad, and bad.  If you could give less than a one, I would.

title: Bleh
text: OK, so they can build houses, but cannot build boats or bridges? I'll take that. Space ships power still there? Alright, and all the little fun holes I won't even bother on. The ending? Yuck. A movie where the time travel is worse than what Bill and Ted's excellent adventure, and an ending which tries but fails to get close to the original. Wooo another monument used, how impressive. (snore)

title: Comparison to original luckily stops at the first credit
text:
Yes, I too caught that AMC Planet of the Apes festival back in 1998 and learned the whole, convoluted chronology of the original series.  I also learned that somehow, apes just learned to talk on their own, a lot like evolving, but maintained their hunched appearance and brutish looks.  You couldn't call the original series science fiction, because it wasn't really based on science.  In fact, in order to really enjoy any of the original films, you had to forgive a lot of fuzzy logic.This new "revisioning" of the original film makes a whole lot more sense of how apes learned to talk and walk upright and possess all those "human" qualities without having any overt explanation scene.  It just makes sense on its own if you really think about it.  You don't have to though.Anyway, Mark Wahlberg proves again that he was never supposed to be a hip hop star and acts his way very effectively through this pretty darned intelligent film.  First off, leave it to Tim Burton to make comedic yet emotionally trying jabs at bestiality.  If you see the film, you'll see what I mean.  Secondly, we see how operatic life in politics can be, and still be fun.Tim Roth leads a tremendous supporting cast of action movie veterans.  Of course, you won't recognize any of them through the amazing make-up.  The action is amazing, and artfull while the story moves at a locomotive pace.
Honestly, this movie never stops.  And we all expected a big twist ending, better than the original, but instead, we get a twist ending with such a huge sequel come-on that I almost vomitted.  The ending manages to work, come out of left field, and tickle you pink, all at once.  I was either elated or nauseous, I can't decide.  Overall, a really good film.  Better than the original, possibly.  The 68 classic had no limitations as to how high morally it could reach.  So this new revisioning decides to change gears.  Don't walk in expecting a social commentary.  Walk in expecting a summer rollercoaster ride with a seemingly infinite shelf life.  Your grandkids will be asking you if you actually saw it in the theater.

title: Do not give out the name
text: Well, this movie is good for eating popcorn however, the original one was sooo much better than this one. The plot itself is not original however it has some changes which I won't spoil for you. The acting was average. The make-up was  really good, the special effects were cool as well. Directing has the typical Burton style.The movie is very entertaining however, if it wasn't because it has that name it wouldn't be so good. I am not disappointed but I'm not amazed because it is an average movie.

title: Helena Bonham Carter looks like Michael Jackson!
text: Tim Burtin is one of my favourite directors, but as soon as he has to deliver a Hollywood blockbuster (Batman returns) he sucks Big Time. This is one of the worst movies I have ever seen, they should have casted Kevin Costner so you would have been warned. The story is totally uninspired, you don't care about the humans or the apes. Another thing than happens to often in modern Hollywood movies is that they spent all  their money and energy on technical stuff and forget about storyline and character development. I didn't care about this film and the only thing they achieved is that they made Helena Bonham Carter look like Michael Jackson!

title: Not as good as the first one...
text: All though this was an excellent movie with awesome special effects and costume design, it still can't compete with the original Planet of the Apes. It was not at all what I expected. I expected a total remake of the movie (same exact story, same characters, etc.). However, this movie has a more easy-to-understand story.

title: Is this the best they could do?
text: Tim Burton announced that this is a "re-imagining" of Planet of the Apes. What he did was "re-imagine" it into the dud of the year. I don't want to spend a lot of time comparing it to the original, but it's nowhere near as good as the original. During the first 45 minutes, I was partially impressed. There was some great makeup and a few decent dialogue scenes. But as soon as Wahlberg and company escaped, it was all downhill. Once the battle scene came I was rolling my eyes and laughing. The action was pretty boring compared to some of Burton's better films. The last 20 minutes just drag on and on. And what was the deal with Tim Roth's performance? He spent the whole time growling and trying to act scary. To me it came off as a bad impression of Mr. Furious from Mystery Men. There were some genuinely entertaining moments, I'll give it that. Charlton Heston's cameo being the high point. But I spent most of the movie waiting for it to end. I found the original Planet Of The Apes to be an intelligent movie. It had great themes on the relationship and treatment between Humans and Animals. And while Tim Burton does play on those themes in the early parts of this film, it loses all sight of it in exchange for a load of action sequences.I'm sure that there is an audience for Tim Burton's Planet of the Apes. I'm just not part of that audience. Just like Psycho, Planet of the Apes is a film better off not being remade.

title: The story has more potential.
text: This film is Tim Burtons remake of Schaffner's "Planet of the Apes" from 1968. Mark Wahlberg surely was not the best choice for the protagonist. Take a look at old Heston in 1968, he did a great job. He's a leader, a strong man with authority. Mark Wahlberg lacks those charisma. Compared to Heston he looks really poor - a half-grown boy trying to command. The rest of the film looks like a more or less solid film. But Tim Burton likes to show some weird things in his films, but this time it made a medium film worse. I am talking about the unrealistic end of the film (!!!). In my eyes it was not logic and useless.

title: Not bad, but still a disappointment
text: Pierre Boulle's original novel of apes ruling an earthlike planet is an absorbing and truly terrifying piece of science fiction. Unlike the 1968 film version with Charlton Heston, this film retains (an Americanized version of) the original ending, which actually works pretty well. There are good scenes along the way too, but somehow, the story just doesn't quite make it. Excellent performances by Helena Bonham Carter and Tim Roth shore it up a bit, as does the superb make-up. In the end, though, poorish special effects, unmemorable music, and a seeming indecision on the part of the filmmakers as to whether to stick with the original story or write one of their own mean this movie just doesn't work as it should. Watch it by all means, but a classic it is not.

title: A horrible, cliched, schmaltzy waste of money.
text: As a huge Tim Burton fan, I anticipated greatness and creativity. Imagine my dismay as I sat through a big-budget Hollywood crapfest with the worst dialogue (so laughably bad!). The special effects were cool, but there was nothing remotely Tim Burton-ish about this movie- this is exactly what you'd expect from some hatchet artist like Michael Bay, not from the usually delightful Tim Burton. I am thoroughly disgusted by this- he has clearly fallen for the Hollywood method of fearlessly distributing crap, so long as he makes a buck (or a million). DON'T see this trashy, stupid, waste-of-time movie. Mark Wahlberg's acting is totally sub-par and boring. The rest of the characters are background filler and serve no purpose. Tim Burton is capable of so much more. Let's hope he chooses something more substantial with original dialogue next time.

title: Burton's best since Mars Attacks
text: Planet Of the Apes with Burton's vision was a good movie. It had action, memorable one liners, good pacing and a great twist ending. The movie didn't get the credit it deserves but it was really good, or at least I liked it I can't wait for the DVD.

title: Disappointed and offended
text:
Although I'm not a fan of the previous Planet of the Apes movies (I've never seen them), I was pretty excited about seeing this remake/sequel.
Unfortunately, I was very much unimpressed with what I viewed. The special effects were great, the scenery was realistic, and the cast seemed to be very talented (opinion not based on this movie). However, they were lacking in one MAJOR department: the script! As someone said before, I agree that you and a bunch of your friends could have written a better screenplay for the movie than these talented, well-paid writers did.There were many interesting directions this movie *could* have taken and didn't. I noticed that in the beginning of the movie, the woman scientist on the spaceship mentions that with chimps the female is dominant sexually. Of course, this led me to think; `What an interesting twist to the movie! The female apes could be really domineering instead of the males!' But instead the comment seemed to hold no relevancy to the rest of the film whatsoever! It turns out there were hardly any female apes at all, and those were hardly very aggressive.Maybe I shouldn't have gone to see the movie with such high hopes for a great flick, but I did. I am officially insulted at spending good money on a film that seemed to have lots of possibility but no delivery. For those of you who haven't seen the movie and plan to, my advice to you is to go into the movie with lowered expectations and maybe you'll appreciate it more than I did.5 out of 10

title: Loved original, hated this one
text: All the advances in makeup, computer graphics, and whatever other expensive high tech stuff went into this film could not overcome a plodding and ultimately boring script and pedestrian acting. Where are Charlton Heston and Roddy McDowell when you need them? I never thought I would say that.

title: poo
text: Always start with something positive:  Helena Bonham Carter is fun to watch. The ape-like activities are very well done.But for a movie with an ostensibly socially-aware theme, this movie is a pile of poo.  This movie is not only offensive to female humans but female apes as well.  Check out the three scientists' descriptions of the electrical storm in the early part of the movie.  So much has been learned about the real power wielded by female apes that you'd think the writers could have done better than make the females just mating machines.  Even Helena Bonham Carter's character is barely one iota removed from passive female status.And my nominee for most superfluous character of the year is the teenage human boy on the horse.  The moment you see him in the ruins scene you know exactly what he is going to do and exactly what the result is going to be.And how many camera shots traveling up Estella Warren's body does one movie need?  Pretty fortuitous tear in her bodice that reveals her cleavage, wouldn't you say?I get more and more angry every time I think about this movie.  Tim Burton, what's happened?

title: Special effects do not make up for plot and script weaknesses
text: A poor excuse for a movie.  Tim Burton needs to take about 5 years off and go reorganize himself.  This movie had no soul, no cohesion, and a really insipid script with all kinds of inconsistencies and errors. It is a shame to see a big budget movie like this when there are so many really talented directors and script writers just struggling. Hollywood continues to prostitute itself and Tim Burton has now joined the ranks of the brothel-panderers.

title: From Chimpan "A" to Chimpan "Z"
text: I just saw Planet of the Apes last night and I must say, that I rather enjoyed it. It had really elaborate sets and outstanding effects, especially the make up for the apes. I'm a huge fan of Tim Roth and despite what people say about his performance in this movie, I really enjoyed it. I thought that some parts of the movie were kinda funny, but it may have just been the people who I saw it with that made it funny...hmmmm...but I gave it 8 out of 10, because I think it's a movie you should go and see. I mean, the original was a cult classic and this version pays homage to it. Check it out!

title: Missed Opportunity
text: This would have been a much better film if Tim Burton had not sought out to "reimagine" the original story.  Granted, the makeup and special effects do surpass the original, but that is where the superlatives stop. The story in the current version just does not work.  It does not adequately explain how the apes came to be where they are.  The ending does not have a fraction of the impact of the ending of the original film.  It is ridiculous and illogical.  This is one movie you can wait for the video on..and only if someone else pays for the video and invites you over.

title: A curate's egg
text: For those not familiar with that expression, it dates from a 'Punch' cartoon of 1895, where a nervous curate is breakfasting with his bishop.Bishop: I'm afraid you've got a bad egg, Mr Jones.Curate: Oh, no, my Lord, I assure you that parts of it are excellent!So, parts of Tim Burton's 'Planet of the Apes' are excellent. The lifelike and varied ape makeup, combined with the effort that has gone into making the apes... well, apes, and more individual than the oppressed humans can manage to be, makes their society utterly believable. Helena Bonham Carter delicately brings out the character of Ari, shewing us that a full face prosthesis need not handicap a great actress, and Tim Roth camps it up completely as Thade (which you may not think is a good point).On to the bad parts. Mark Wahlberg does nothing to arouse my sympathy, or indeed interest. It doesn't help that his character is halfway between James T Kirk and Dorothy from the Wizard of Oz, and does not develop at all throughout the film. The plot is stupid, ridiculous and yet utterly predictable, and forces characters to act unrealistically. The eventual resolution is contrived and unsatisfying, it gives no extra depth to anything, in fact, it seems to be the only way the writers could think of to finish off the plot. The ending is tacked-on and inconsistent.I would recommend avoiding this film unless you really have nothing better to do, and no expectations of intelligence. But stylistically it's worth something, and Helena Bonham Carter's performance is worth adding a couple of marks, so reluctantly, i give it 4 out of 10.

title: Could someone please turn on a light?
text: Ugh!!!  Aside from some inventive costumes and makeup, this movie blows. That is, when you can actually see what is going on.  Predictably, the sets were dark in an attempt to make it appear foreboding.  But, my God, the writing was atrocious -- and that blonde with the bee-stung lips......! I did enjoy Helena Bonham Carter, but she was one of just a few bright spots in the film.  Marky Mark was so-so, but Tim Roth was WAY over the top.  It was cartoonish.  The first 15 minutes of this film was so badly written and acted, I nearly walked out of the theater.

title: I have, with trouble, figured out the ending to this movie!
text: Okay, this would be easier if you all knew about time paradoxes like in Star Trek.  Don't stop reading because I mention Star Trek.  Here goes: (One thing you have to know first, when Mark goes through this storm in space, he thinks he is taken to another planet, when he is really taken to another time on his). If you remember, when he was crash-landing on the "other planet" (Earth), his digital calendar was moving the years ahead very quickly.  He was going into the future.  The space-station he came from was pulled in too but not at the same time as him.  The space-station got pulled into a time 1,000's of years before him.  That space-station was carrying many genetically enhanced chimps.  When that station landed (crashed), the apes got out, killed the humans and populated the planet.  Since, Mark was sent to a time ahead of that, the apes had already evolved (genetically enhanced).  So, they evolved.  Remember, this is Earth.  Remember that at the end when Mark locks the General in that room he doesn't kill him.  So, after Mark leaves to go back to what he thinks is his planet, but is really another time, the General escapes and still has his armies so he exterminates the humans.  Mark goes through the time portal and really instead of going to what he thinks is Earth, he goes ahead in time even farther, to where the apes have evolved into a society like ours.  The statue (Abraham Lincoln) is of the General because he saved the planet for the apes (by exterminating the humans).

title: A very average movie
text: I found nothing noteworthy in this movie. The story line was ok. The acting was competent. The effects were good, but not outstanding given today's technology.This movie managed to get campy at times without having any redeeming qualities to compensate for it. It struck me as very politically correct and thus didn't really have anything to say.It is a simple action flick, and an average one at that.It is immediately forgettable, except perhaps for the ending which breaks any chance of the movie being self consistent.

title: Close. But no banana.
text:
Perhaps there's no such thing as a bad Tim Burton film, but Planet of the Apes comes perilously close. Visually the make-up is generally impressive  the overall effect of seeing so many simian humanoids at once is quite overpowering, even if most of the set-design is pretty unimaginative.
Tim Roth's performance as a sort of Richard III ape is perhaps the most memorable  his strangulated restless manner is reminiscent of the mortally wounded Mr Orange in Reservoir Dogs (although he wasn't a monkey). Bonham Carter is also impressive in a decisive departure from her flowery Merchant Ivory image. Only the make-up lets her down  her visage seems to have been tampered with in an ultimately futile attempt to make her look her like an attractive ape. This fails. On the other hand, Estella Warren's Daena is far too much like a supermodel to look like a convincing native girl.So why does Planet of the Apes fail? Here are some ideas.1) Why do the humans on the planet speak? In the original film and the novella there was a direct human-apes reversal situation  the humans could not speak or communicate anymore effectively than monkeys can on Earth. That was why the arrival of Heston's character stirred the waters. Here the humans are clearly ruled over by the apes, but given their supposed mastery of technology' which the apes lack, there seems no real reason why the apes should be so dominant. Burton seems to be striving for a civil rights parallel. Roth's ape even misquotes the reactionary Senator Barry Goldwater at one point. But this paradox still makes little sense.2) Too much of the dialogue is banal or just stupid. There are a number of signs the film is rushed.3) The comedy' orang-utan is annoying. 4) Wahlberg is no action hero. He got away with it playing a porn actor but not here. 5) The ending seems to be an attempt to echo that of the novella. Yet that made sense. This one doesn't. It is not clever, just inexplicable. I HEREBY DEFY ANYONE ON THESE PAGES TO EXPLAIN THE ENDING SATISFACTORILY! It's impossible - it's nonsensical.Overall, not a disaster, but highly disappointing.

title: Respectfully Disagree
text: I would like to respectfully disagree with jackzen from Wales. To be fair though, I will preface this by saying that I never saw the original TV shows, and if there was a book, I never read it.But, that said, I would say that this movie stands as a fine piece of work in it's own right. It was, I believe, very well acted and filmed, and I believe that the plot was basically good. I did however dislike the ending, but don't feel that it was a fault of poor plot, just personal taste.I won't say more, because I don't want to spoil this for anyone that has not seen it. I believe that it is a movie you will enjoy watching.

title: So Much Promise Turned To Waste
text: You know what happens: human crash lands on planet ruled by apes that can talk and think humans are beneath them, human has to fight to survive, twist ending. Blah, Blah, Blah.This new "Planet Of The Apes" is probably the most-hyped and most-anticipated summer release for 2001. You've got extremely dark and stylish director Tim Burton paired back up with scoring buddy Danny Elfman. Cool ape costumes and Marky Mark out in front. How could any of this go wrong you ask? Well, it does.Now, don't get me wrong, I did like this movie. That was until the last ten minutes of the film. The ending is so ridiculous that it cause the rest of the movie to make NO SENSE at all. The ending is terrible and I cannot express enough how much sense it does not make! I'm not going to give anything away, but you aren't missing anything life-changing. The movie was good, except for this contrived and senseless plot twist that is completely tacked-on.Besides the fact that the movie ends up not making any sense after it was on the right track, the musical score, I hear, had to be completely redone mere days before release. So, the new score has no resemblance of Danny Elfman at all. It's your generic action movie score. Thanks, studio executives! That's why you guys collect the money to back the film and you leave the movie-making to the movie makers! What an original concept.I don't need to go into the story or the plot, you know it. The only thing you don't know about is the new ending, which causes the whole movie to be worthless. Oh, and did I mention that there is no resemblance of Tim Burton's style anywhere? Then I'll say it here: nada on the Burton style.I was really, really excited about seeing this movie. I really was. But then the ending made no sense, which I cannot repeat enough, and it all went to hell.

title: Bad Remake, Zero continuity, Serling turning in his grave
text: This is a horrible remake/ new version of this classic movie. There is no continuity. Characters appear and disappear for no apparent reason. A troupe of Mark Walhberg and other humans and Apes trek across the Forbidden Zone - I thought I was watching the Wizard of OZ. The movie is packed with through away 'one-liners' making it more like an action comedy instead of science fiction.

title: A Devolved Reimagining of Apish intelligence
text: All the intelligence of the original movie, its surreal philosophical confrontations, and its meaningful indictment of human stupidity have been lost. This was a good effects film, but it doesn't even come close to the original POTA film. Rent the original instead.

title: Just imagine...
text: Okay, sure, it's very (very) cheesy here and there. I laughed where I'm sure you're not supposed to laugh (although most people did). But if you can get past the cheese, and just kick back and let your imagination flow for a while, this is a really good movie. The monkeys.. sorry apes, are not just ordinary humans that look like apes, they have their own culture and ways. There's alot of aggression and sexual tension between them, and things boil down to who's the strongest. I liked all the twists, the last one being a predictable one, but it can still tickle your imagination, if you let it. So, I say open your eyes and ears and go see it. There are not a whole lot of movie out there that works from beginning til end, if you compare them and their plots to real life. "Planet..." never tried that, it's all about a  really cool experience, and Tim Burton is a master of making that happen. 8/10

title: The first is really good, the last part sucks
text: The first part of the movie is really good, and keeps up with the original, it even is a little better - but the last ½ hour (give or take..) really sucks. I was so disapointed at not only the ending, but also the story that leads to the ending. So if you ignore the ending, it's a 8 or 9 movie - but since the last ½ hour is there - I give i a 3...

title: peeeuuuuuuuuu
text: I saw the clips,I read the bad reviews but I went to see the movie AND BOY DOES IT STINK, The story line is horrible,the acting is hamy,the sets looks like they came from the 68 version,in one scene the set even moves. This is Ed Wood meets the apes.

title: SILLY? Let Me Count the ways!
text: This film had two saving Graces.  First Chris Christoferson was killed off early,... mercifully.  Secondly In spite of a rather silly story, and even through heavy Monkey Make up and costuming Tim Roth's wonderful acting abilities and power shined through.  When you are an actor who is so powerful that you can overcome a crappy story, silly dialouge, heavy make up...neigh full body and face masks, and still come through powerfully, That is Brilliant Acting.  To Tim Roth I say WELL DONE.  As for the rest of this film it is Politically Correct, Ultra liberal Rubbish, repleat with Gun Control and "The uppety House Homo-Sapien" What utter drival.  If that weren't so bad we then have a Captain who disobeys a Lt Generals Direct order in the first ten minutes of the movie.  Hmmmm Where was General Patton when we needed him?  Well of course disobedience is to be expected, after all we here on planet earth have changed our armies moto from "Be all that you can be" to "A One man Army" (sic)  So this rebel disobeys the general not to save the universe from some great plauge, or solar or neutron or nuclear distruction but  to chase a Chip into a time Warp...you see, there were no instruments or technology advanced enough to detect what may exist in this mystic ciderial "coal mine" the scientest just had to send a chimp with the brain the size of a potatoe flying his little pod into the unknown.....yeah right! What ever the faults of the first Planet of the Apes Series of Films, They are Masterpieces compared to this disaster.

title: Fun!
text: I don't know, what the big fuss is all about! I had a fun night out! I mean, what did you expect from Mr. Glorious (Tim Burton for others...)? The lesson I have learned a long time ago is: Expect the Unexpected. So is it this bad just to make a film for people to entertain? And entertained I was. The script could've been better, the make-up less like the Jacksons and so forth. But all they wanted to do is tell a story the old-fashioned way, by just telling it. I mean, we all know the philosophical backgrounds since 1968, no need in going into them too deeply again.The ending, the ending... I thought it was really brave what they did. They new, they couldn't top the original one. Leaving so many things in the dark by simply not telling them might for some be inacceptable. For me, it was a bold fresh breeze in the mainstream-movie-business.To all those bickering about the ending being "illogical":(for those, who want to get into it stone-cold, please stop reading!) Do you really need an explanation for everything? Just accept the fact, that it happend that way. The film doesn't explain how, just THAT it happend. With all the Time-Jumping around, there are loads of ways the ending works perfectly well. Just use your own imagination! For all those who disagree please send a Mail. I would really want to know, what you have to say to the ending of "2001: A Space Odyssey"...

title: big expectations, even bigger letdown
text: i was expecting a great movie since i'm a enjoy tim burton's movies. I was amazed with sleepy hollow and was looking forward to this movie. but what i saw was a piece of crap!! the story made final fantasy's look incredible, the acting was pathetic (except for the apes), the ending was horrible. and what's with charlton heston's speech? how can it be so full of clichés; i really hope someone gets fired for that one. so, kudos to tim roth, micheal clark duncan but the rest of the movie is awful. please don't make a sequel!!!

title: Well Done but poorly acted.
text: It seems the actors in this movie were so busy portraying apes that they forgot how to deliver a line. Tim Roth over-acted completely, start to finish, and Michael Clarke Duncan under-acted. The ending is also completely out in left field; come on, would the apes really have evolved EXACTLY like we did? I don't think so. Okay, I've just listed all of the flaws with this movie that I can think of. Otherwise, it was well choreographed and had a decent plot. Even Mark Wahlberg did a good job.  I think, given the ending, a sequel will be ridiculous, but there's not much that can be done there. Go see the movie, though. 7 out of 10 stars.

title: Apetrastic!
text: What a great movie, yes i have seen the original but this new one is as brilliant as Charlton Heston's' one (He even was in it).The special FX, makeup and some decent monkey acting this film discovers how apes make apes out of us. Some nice fights too in there along with some great battles.This film is very underrated this is a solid sci-fi with everything you need in a good movie. So what other people think that it wasn't a patch on the first. I'm not comparing that I just enjoyed every monkey moment of this.9.1 / 10 Ideas: 8.0 Effects: 9.2 Acting: 8.8 Story: 7.5 OVERALL: 9.1 "GREAT APE MOVIE"

title: Boy, did i sure wish this was a re-release
text:
I'm not going to get into any of the murky details of the film.  I won't talk about the little amounts of acting because i blame that on the writing. I won't get into the details because, like i said, they are murky at best. This is a two hour effects powerhouse except that when you look under the hood for the engine you realize what's running the show is a bunch of monkeys.  THe movie fell short in too many areas for me and the cool monkey outfits and such could not overcome this.  There were more plot holes than in a slice of Swiss cheese and each and every hole was a dark, endless one. Spinning you deeper into a vast array of nonsense and excuses to get Marki Mark to his next ordeal with the monkeys.  I would only recommend this movie to those who love completely mindless action movies and for big fans of Marky Mark walking around breathing heavy and doing nothing much else.   Other than that i would not recommend this to my worst enemy.  It was a formulaic mess and a shameless attempt at using a classic story that has become part of our culture to make money and make the hollywood big-wigs smile a little wider and their wallets a little fatter. 
Kudos to them because as i've read now that the movie grossed 70 million over the weekend.  They made the perfect, mindless fodder that thousands of kids go screaming to the theaters to watch. They'll think the apes are cool and Marky Mark is cool and in the end that's all that matters.  In the end Tim Burton, whom i once cherished as a director, will be regarded as a master mind.  Why?  Perhaps you should look under the hood and ask him yourself as he tosses your oil filter out and makes a bigger mess.  "Hey Tim!  Why not a 're-imagining' of 2001 next!"

title: Why?
text: Why would you remake a classic? Why would you spend 100 million to make such a bad movie? And for that 100 million could they not have come up with a better script?This movie is horrible, save your money and catch the original some weekend at 2am... And if you really want to see what this remake is like, then catch one of the sequels to the original planet of the apes. Those are just as painful..

title: Got To See Again And Again!
text: 2nd night the movie opened, i went to the drive-in (along with Kiss Of The Dragon) and watched it with a good friend.  We both thought the movie was awsome.  He had already seen the older Planet Of The Apes films and stuff, but all I knew about it was Talking Apes Controlling Humans, but it is so much more.  I would love to tell you all about but I don't want to give it all away.  Everyone "BOW YOUR HEADS!" cause you MUST see this movie, and go see it again.  See it till you're eyes bleed.  The make-up makes the actors really look like monkeys ("No! We Are APES!")  It really is amazing, but don't take my word for it, go see it for yourself! Again & Again & Again & Again...Plus, go see it again, haha

title: Great movie, but doesnt stay true to the originial
text: I remember watching the original, with good ole NRA leader, Charleton Heston.  I remember it being meaningful, instead of this new-age "save the little people" approach that try to teach us animal rights and how humans are cruel and unpredictable.Let me just get this out in the open, the ending sucked.  Sure it was a surprise, but it made no sense and it forces a sequel to explain it.  I would've enjoyed it better if it was more like the original (and not the book).If you've seen the original, it's nothing like this version.  He lands by himself and is quickly thrown into the conflict.  A minor change (that I wasnt expecting, actually) was that he could talk as soon as he landed, where in the original it took Heston a while to talk.  Dr. Zaius is back, thrown in a comedic role thus losing the serious role he had back in the original.  Again, it's just a matter of taste.  If you want a reved up, updated classic...this is the movie for you.Something has always bothered me.  It was in the original and in this one as well (I dont know if it's the same in the book as well), but why doesnt the main character get that HOT human chick?  He seems more interested in that female monkey!  Sheesh, Estella Warren is very VERY hot, and she's a Canadian as well! ;)  That chick from the original was hot too, but she's like 4 000 years old now... :(The effects were there, the musical score was there...the plot and development of characters was not.  We get a sense of the theme, but neither the main character or his human friends are developed in any way.Overall, it's a very enjoyable movie, however they took a lot from the original that hard-core fans such as myself dont like.

title: Rather entertaining, rather memorable, rather good
text:
I think Burton did well in creating Planet of the Apes for a generation that did not know it, and as well, keeping the ones who did satisfied. The acting by the human-played apes was marvelous, mannerisms such as hoots and grunts in amusement, anger, or excitement were quite well done.  Burton was also able to create a scientifically logical theory behind the concept, engineering the thought that the primates were tampered with in the human image, and taught English when they were genetically engineered, which all of course was fantastical but eerily plausible.  The ape culture was intriguing as well.There was moments where I was saying, "Wow, that was a really great idea".  However, there was also times when I found myself saying, "Jesus Burton, not that!", although the latter was less common.
All throughout his career, Tim Burton was trying as hard as he could to balance entertainment with his cinematic vision, and this time he struck gold.
All in all, Planet of the Apes is not the kind of remake that people who loathe action films would enjoy, nor people who despise art films, but if you have no preference (Or you can at least stand both), the new Planet of the Apes is truly great science fiction! My only complaints were the blonde supermodel (Paper thin character), and some really lame dialogue(More character developement would have been nice too).  Both a B movie and a cinematic marvel (If it's possible).Ah, and on a final note, Helena Bonham Carter (the period-piece-princess) made a rather attractive chimpanzee!

title: Better than the original...almost.
text: *SPOILIERS*I think this movie was re-edited shortly before it's release. I say this because there are two things I've noticed: One, the line in the trailer "Bring me the space man!" is omitted. Two, there is not one, but two big plot twists in the film. The first one is cool and works well, the other is HORRIBLE. Burton, if this was your fault, you are an idiot. If it was Fox's fault, all you studio execs are idiots.The similarities between the original and the Burton films are few. There's the forbidden zone, there's a quick cameo of Dr. Zeus (ever so briefly, you have to be looking for him in the background). There's a bigger cameo of Charlton Heston as General Thade's father, also saying the like "Damn them! Damn them all to hell!" which brought on cheers in the crowd. There's also the first line between Marky Mark and an ape: "Get your hand off me you damn dirty human!" which wasn't received so well.The main plot twist was a good adaptation of the original, and perhaps a bit more realstic. However the second one brought on "boo's" from the crowd. People were really p***ed off at it. I won't give it away here, but let's just say that the other 99.9% of the film BARELY makes up for how bad this ending is.Tim Roth as Thade was INCREDIBLE. He stole the show. He was evil incarnate, and I'd watch the movie again just for him (and then I'll walk out of the theater right before the crappy ending).9/10, would have been a 10 but minus 1 for the ending.

title: Entertaining, Nice look
text: I liked this movie much better than the original.  The story was good, and I love the look of everything. The sets and the character make-up were wonderful.  Thade was an excellent character, as was Ari.  I'm interested in buying this one when it comes out on DVD.

title: "Damn Them All to Hell !"
text: The new installment to the "Planet of the Apes" saga is a skillfully made film.  It combines a new adaptation to the familiar story of the original. However, it is by no means a remake.  The new movie has some very striking similarities, but is a new and different film.  This "Planet of the Apes" uses enough of the now famous content, that made the original great, to sell it to the older fans, as well as a new story to win over a younger generation which would not properly understand the social gripping message of the 60's version.  This film is clearly Tim Burton's best work.  The cast does a very good job, especially considering all of the makeup.  Charlton Heston steals the show as Gen. Thade's father, proving once again that no one does a "Planet of the Apes" film like Mr. Heston. Despite the overall excellent nature of this film, it is flawed in one major aspect.  This film has no star quality.  No offense to Mark Wahlberg, but he is not capable of carrying a summer blockbuster by himself.  Mr. Wahlberg is a fine up and coming actor, but he has not yet reached the point in his career (and maybe never will) where he can open a film by himself, let alone a major film such as "Planet of the Apes".  Wahlberg tries his best to play the reluctant hero, but the key word is "tries".  He lacks the major presence that Charlton Heston provided in the original.  Wahlberg is unable to sell himself as an "action star".  His lines are not believable, and are quite commonplace.  In order for such a film to have been properly done it would have required a big time action star.  That star could only have been Arnold Schwarzenegger, whose name was mentioned for the Wahlberg role. His presence in the film would have made a big summer hit into a mega summer blockbuster.  Just imagine Arnold delievering the lines "I'll be back..you dirty apes!" If the casting directors have any sense they will make sure that Arnold is back when they make the sequel. Despite all of this it was still a very entertaining film. 3.5 out of 4 stars.

title: FINALLY!! A Summer Movie That Doesn't Disappoint!
text: The Apes are here at last!! Bravo! Boy, are they "mad, bad, and dangerous to know."Planet of The Apes is one of several movies that I earmarked to see this summer season. It is the first that did not disappoint...in fact it actually exceeded my expectations.  Let's get something straight, right off the bat, I did not go to the theater expecting to be enlightened. I went to be entertained and Planet of the Apes is extremely entertaining. The costumes and makeup are first rate. Rick Baker should, deservedly so, garner another Oscar for his work. The apes are REAL...more real than the dinosaurs in the disappointing Jurassic Park 3. The actors were great. Tim Roth is menacingly elegant as General Thade. Michael Clarke Duncan and Cary Tagawa are excellent in the student/sensei roles. Helena Bonham Carter...ah well, is it me or does she actually look and perform better as an ape?  Paul Giamatti almost steals the movie as the human slave trader, Limbo. The human actors were...well...human.  The movie isn't called Planet of The Humans is it?I'm a fan of the first Planet Of The Apes. This film is as good in some parts and much, much better in others. Go see the movie, sit back and enjoy.

title: Better than expected
text: Just a quick word to say how I enjoyed this movie. No, it is not perfect, neither was the original. This one was very exciting to watch. The film is always visually interesting. The CGI work is top notch. The battle action is suspenseful, and the apes running along side the horses is unworldly.  Most actors did very well, under what must have been very heavy makeup. A successful re imagining of the original. The hero came off a little like "Gladiator" meets the planet of the Apes. No problem here. The twist at the end was a good one. See this picture, don't expect Hamlet, and enjoy. Fine entertainment.

title: A movie which I didnt expect much from and enjoyed.
text: Well, I have never seen any of the original Planet of the Apes movies so therefore I cannot compare between them. But after seeing this movie I might just go out and rent them. The costumes and sfx in this movie are pretty amazing, and it has a good cast. And overall its a movie I enjoyed, I give it a 8/10.

title: Great new visionary Planet of the Apes
text: Tim Burton has once again created a visually stunning and a "new" Planet of the Apes. It is NOT a remake; and never tried to be but another "tale" on the same concept as the old movies. The old ones were great as well - masterpieces in itself. But this DOES NOT reduce the great work that Tim Burton has done in creating this movie. A great movie and well worth watching in it's own rights. If you want the "old ones" - watch the old ones; if you want to watch a great new movie - watch this one. And WHY not watch both the OLD and the NEW ones.Happy viewing!

title: Paul Giamatti Shines as Limbo
text: I loved this movie, it was a very good remake of the original.  I especially liked the performance of Paul Giamatti as Limbo, the human slave trader.  He turned in a very funny, juicy performance; I especially liked his joke concerning keeping human teenagers around the house -- very cute!

title: Burton gave us another masterpiece!
text: First of all: I'm a HUGE fan of the original 1968 POTA. And this is not a remake of that movie. It's simply a reinvention of the same story, filtered through the eyes of one of the most creative Hollywood directors. Everything in this show work in a perfect way: the screenplay is inventive and brilliant. All the performers gave their best, in particularly Tim Roth portraing the main villain, General Thade, and Helena Bonham Carter under the make-up of the kind chimp Ari. Costumes, art direction, special effects are amazing! Great part of the success of this film is due to the wonderful make-up effects by the genial wizardy of Rick Baker and the complex score composed by the talent of the sublime Maestro Danny Elfman. Main titles (music and images together) are simply astonishing! Absolutely a must see by all the fans of fantastic cinema. Rating: 9/10.

title: the ending made the movie!
text: It is by blindly choosing the unknown that everything in the world gets thrown upside down. He enters a time warp, finds that he has traveled in time (forwards, backwards -- who knows?) Ends up on a planet dominated by apes that his ship previously planted there -- irresponsible time travel with powerful results over the course of time.Then there is a whole lot of action, climaxing to the insight of the hero. One man has the insight into these phenomenon... and what does he do? when he gets the chance he jumps right back into a time warp and sees the results of his actions as they have spiraled out over time.. He left a peaceful situation on the ape planet only to find that had he stayed, the course of history could have been drastically different. Thought provoking movie wrapped up in a modern day action flick.

title: Apey good
text: This movie was magnificent. The scenery, the script, and of course- the makeup. this movie is one of Tim Burton's best pieces of work. But there has to be a sequel! The ending is so mysterious that you have to know what happens! This was a masterpiece but there just has  to be a sequel!

title: There's Something About Monkey....
text: And with that comment goes the first, last, and only bad primate pun in this review.Leave it to Tim Burton to take a familiar franchise or story, keep enough of the source material to make it familiar, then add his own unique twist. "Planet of the Apes" is much like "Batman" or "Sleepy Hollow" in that respect.  You know what you're getting, but not sure of how it's going to be told, or what surprises lie along the way.This is "B movie" fun at its finest.  Of course, you're dealing with a film about talking monkeys, so if you're going into this film expecting something overtly serious, you're not going to find it.  It's a very surreal film, both in its ideas and in watching the human-like apes, swing, beat their chests, ride horses, and carry on conversations.  It's fascinating and a little scary at the same time.  Burton's quirky sense of humor is definitely apparent in the ape cities.  The make-up in this film is great, especially the gorilla soldiers.  The actor cameos are fun to spot (Watch for Heston - Burton does a good job in paying homage to the original series), and the twist in meaning of the original film's dialogue is definitely worth a laugh or two.The story was an interesting take on the original series.  At times it was silly (and seems aware of this), but not necessarily in an unpleasant way. The biggest problem that I had with the story was in the resolution (I thought a lot of the conflict issues were too neatly and conveniently tied up).    Burton also did a nice job providing a new spin on the classic film's infamous "Statue of Liberty" scene.  There definitely seems to be plans in the works for a sequel by the way it ended.I think this film will get some criticism for what it is, but you know, this isn't the type of film that is going to teach you something about yourself, nor will it provide the solution to all the world's problems by the time the end credits roll.  I had fun with this.  It was wild, it was campy, the acting performances were good for this type of film, and the special effects were entertaining.  I enjoyed this film for what it set out to do, and I'm glad it's not simply a rehash of the original film.Burton has still been unable to let me down, and still remains one of my favorite directors.  I'll definitely add this to my "Burton DVD" collection.

title: Although good, could have been much better
text: Planet of the Apes while good, could have been much better. The actors, I feel gave great performances and were very convincing as apes, however, the story line was poorly developed. In the original POTA films, there were hundreds of apes that looked exactly alike, so although you knew their names it was hard to distinguish each ape. In 2001 POTA, Rick Baker did a wonderful job of creating a wide variety of apes with very different physical features, however, most were never called by their names. Even the human's name were not mentioned so although you could tell them apart, who were they? I feel that this film is worthy of a sequel, if for no other reason than the performance of Tim Roth as General Thade who needed a female in the worst way. I believe that if a sequel is made, Tim Burton will redeem himself or at least I hope so.

title: Roger Ebert missed the main point
text: In case you missed Roger Ebert's review, he didn't like Mark Wahlberg's role as a hero, or his lack of heroism in the movie.  He must have been asleep during the part where his character points out to Carter's female ape character, that "...we are not alike, you care about everybody else but yourself."  For me, this whole statement defines the movie. He only wants to go home.  He only cares about himself.  And all without the arrogant 'attitude' we're used to seeing in movies.  It's either Look at me I'm cool, or Look at me I'm a hero, Wahlberg's character and final decision in the movie pave the way for turning upside down everything you ever thought you knew about what's really going on.  A perfect sci-fi where the seemingly explainable goes unexplained.The plausibility of the opening year at 2029?  A stretch...only if you believe we're in the same reality, which you will find out becomes one for the X-files.   The original 1968 movie left you with a shock, so you could figure out the timeline and the ape evolution.  This movie doesn't try to shock, as many are thinking it's supposed to.  It's actually supposed to make you THINK who came first, human or ape?  You will realize that you would have never reached this point if Wahlberg walked the path of the true hero.

title: One of the best remakes ever, but from where did the horses come?
text: Tim Burton turned out to be the right man for the job of remaking a cult classic. Casting Helena Bonham Carter and Tim Roth as the lead chimps allowed for Oscar-caliber performances, though I doubt the Academy will award a sci-fi remake (lol). Moreover, Tim Roth is sort of reminiscent of Roddy McDowell while Mark Wahlberg is the same of Charlton Heston (who appears as Thade's father, a cameo in the tradition of casting the original players of a franchise). Moreover, Paul Giamatti's orang utan character Limbo, a slave-trader, plays well to the crowd as an excellent source of comic relief.The origin of the apes and the movie's exposition gel well, despite the downpour of negativity from the so-called critics. Hints to the origin pop up in the exposition with such examples as the female scientist announcing a role that the pivotal chimp character, Pericles, is to undertake (I'll keep that role hush-hush).As for the setting, die-hard cult fans of the original films will not be disappointed. While the film is being marketed as happening on another planet rather than a post-apocalyptic Earth, there is a scene in the movie that plays to the original. In other words, Burton didn't mess much with his adaptation, only changing minor details as he had done with "Batman" in 1989.Finally, for those cynics who like to pass science-fiction off as superficial, this movie offers up a taste of abolition, reversing the roles of "dominant" and "submissive," much like what was done in the film "White Man's Burden," starring John Travolta as a white inferior to a rich Harry Bellafonti. It even shows how children are affected by slavery, in ways such as Limbo giving a human child to Thade's little daughter because she wanted a pet.

title: Great all round film.
text: This film has taken a bit of a bagging and I did not know what to expect. POtA is a great "retelling" of the orginal. The story is simple and well rounded with only some minor faults. The major fault is how do the humans find out and track down the hero so quickly.The best part of the movie are the characters especially the apes, all played very well especially Tim Roth.The twist at the end is not to bad and does leave you thinking.

title: Good but not as good as the original.
text: I was so looking forward to watching Planet Of The Apes and in the end i wasn't disapointed athough i dont think this version had the same impact on me as the original. The special affects are superb as is the story and like the original it has a great ending. I'm not saying what happened was a suprise because mostly everything that happened during the film was very predictable but dont let that distract you from what is an entertaining movie. When you have a movie that involves such heavy make up you lose a lot,when it comes to acting,which is a shame because you certainly would not have know that underneath all that make up there was superb actors such as Tim Roth and Charlton Heston. In fact they could have saved thierselves a lot of money and had lessor actors in the apes role.All in all a couple of hours of good entertainment. 8 out 10.

title: Don't underestimate the knowledge of the Apes....
text: Tim Burton has done it again. The movie is not a remake of the original version of 1968, but a complete new story with the same kind of ending as the old one. Tim Roth is doing a great job as General Thade. His eye expressions are excellent. The movie is absolutely worth watching.

title: A Real Summer Treat
text: Lots of action, a great sound track , special effects and make up, made this film an enjoyable two hours on a hot July evening. Helena Bonham Carter as Ape Avi is wonderful...so were the apes of Tim Roth and Michael  Clark Duncan. Very menacing for sure. Tim Burton has done a fine job putting this remake together.I rated an 8 out of 10. Visually, it won't disappoint anyone. If you like action and fighting, it is here also.

title: Please stop comparing. Wahlberg is 'Leo' not 'George'.
text: Please note that Planet of the Apes (2001) is not a re-make of Planet of the Apes (1968).  It's a re-telling of the story.  And please look up the word "re-make", which in the context of "filmmaking", means "to make a film using the same story as that of an old film".  To expand on that definition, it's means that in that same story, all the same characters are used like that of the original story, and the script is, more or less, the same.  Examples of true re-makes include Sabrina and Psycho.  POTA (2001) is not a re-make, because Mark Wahlberg's character was Leo Davidson, not Col. George Taylor.  If 2001's version was supposed to be a re-make, you would see Tim Burton use the same characters, but he did not. So it not a re-make.  Please stop comparing.  Comparing 2001's POTA to 1968's POTA, is like comparing Tim Burton's Batman (1989) to 1966's Batman: The Movie!!!!!!  They are not the same!!!!!!!!  That's sound ridiculous!!!!!The title for both films are the same, but that's it...the plot is different, the characters are different....stop comparing....My review of Tim Burton's POTA is very positive.  I was very impressed with this film.  POTA (2001) was one of a few films I was willing to go see in a theatre this year, and I was not disappointed.  Kudos to Burton and the cast and crew of POTA (2001).  No need to make people understand the film, if they can't use their own heads.  GO SEE POTA (2001) TODAY WITH AN OPEN MIND if you haven't seen it yet...OR SEE IT AGAIN, SO YOU WILL SEE THINGS YOU MISSED THE FIRST TIME AROUND, and enjoy it even more, like I did!!!Can't wait for the DVD for this one!

title: Cardia Arrest
text: Okay, the movie was pretty good.  I gave it a high rating for all the obvious reasons, i.e., special effects and makeup.  However, it appears that Mark Wahlberg's character, or himself, has massive cardiovascular problems. A little before, and almost constantly after he leaves the ape city where he was a prisoner, he's in a state of shortness of breath.  He's gasping for air in nearly every scene, even after he walks a short distance.  Take a look for yourself.

title: If You're Remaking Classics, Here's How to Do It
text: Tim Burton has the right idea here.  This isn't just "let's shoot the same movie all over again with different actors", it's actually a fairly different take on the same material.  The basic concept remains the same, but it's most definitely a different movie.One of the most noticeable differences is in the apes themselves.  They're a great deal more bestial, athletic and...well, ape-like than their 1968 counterparts.  Charlton Heston was threatened by the apes because they had guns.  Mark Wahlberg is threatened by the apes because they are, as one might rightly expect, much more than a physical match for a human.  I did miss the caste system that ruled the simian society in the original, but that probably has more to do with the script overall being much less allegorical than Rod Serling's 1968 screenplay.Mark Wahlberg is an appealing enough hero, though there's not really much of a character to play.  Tim Roth is, as always, a terrific villain and probably the most convincing of any of the apes.

title: Visually brilliant, scriptally good but not great
text: The apes look good and are menacing in Darth Vader manner.  The characters ape or human never really get time or the opportunity to grow.  The script does just enough to try and explain the main characters actions but a lot more time should have been spent on building relationships between the characters.  The pace of the film is good but the most disappointing part of the film is the ending just before the ending.My advice is to sit back and enjoy the film because it looks great and for the most part is engaging and interesting.

title: the original POTA meets Back To the Future
text: Great use of humor in here.  I don't know why people think the script is bad.  I thought the ending was better than the original because Leo, unlike Taylor is in immediate danger.  If it doesn't make sense to some of you, why don't you take time to interpret?  Remember, the ship Thade gets stuck in may still be of help to him.  I don't want to give away my interpretation of the ending, you people better start thinking for yourselves.  All I could say is you can't forget that time travel is very possible in this movie. Both this POTA and BTTF have their main characters find something changed when they get back their times.  I like the adrenaline-pumping plot.  The dabbling of humor in it also helps. It dips just enough into the animal-human relations(and relations within the same species) to prevent distorting the plot. OK, it's not possible for Thade and Ari to speak with British accents if their ancestors learned English from Americans but who cares about small mistakes like that?

title: A set-up for many sequels to come
text: After seeing this Planet of the Apes, I wonder if they will make 4 sequels to this too. Unlike the original movie, this one leaves you with a lot more questions. At the end of the original, we realized that he was on earth after all. Simple as that. But this movie leaves me with so many questions that I am counting down the days till the next one is released. I compare the ending of this movie to that of the original Star Wars.....abrupt. But I did indeed enjoy the movie, for several reasons. One was the great special effects and terrific Make-up and Costume usage. (Give em the Oscars now). I had to keep reminding myself there were humans under all that make-up. I didnt care too much for the beginning, it just seemed a little far-fetched, like this might have been the best idea out of a bunch of bad ideas on how to begin the film. Man risks life for monkey? As it went on, we saw the viciousness of General Thade and wondered "Whats up his butt"? Although thoroughly p***ed off the entire movie, Thade does display a side of him that is very human. His scene with Heston as his father bleeds with politics, because the one possesion he has of the humans is a gun, and considering its Heston, Pres of the NRA, I couldnt concentrate on what they said to each other, because I was chuckling at the Irony of this scene. Heston saying humans are dangerous for creating this kind of technology? Did I hear that right? Wow...... We have all heard of movies that are too slow. This one went too fast. I wanted more explanations, and more about the apes...the general daily life of these apes is hardly delved into, and we go into the sequels knowing very little about them, except they dont like humans and they screech a lot. The ending did leave a lot of doors open for sequels, but will this movie go down as being better than the original? Probably not. Will this movie be remembered for its stunning visual images? Yes. And thats why you should see it. Dont get too entangled in the plot...because you will be tangled for a while. Enjoy the movie, and wait for the sequels to explain what we dont know.

title: What's all the fuss about? - it's fine!
text: I spent a long time reading review's of new new Planet Of The Apes here at IMDB. I got the general impression that this movie was a waste of time. Yes, Estella Warren spent the entire movie uselessly pouting with those inappropriately glossed lips.  Yes, Mark Wahlberg was not nearly as dynamic and emotional as would be expected for someone crash landing on to a strange planet to find himself suddenly faced with ape-rule.However, I still enjoyed the movie very much.  Tim Roth as Thade was a powerhouse, Bonham Carter was good and Michael Clarke Duncan as General Attar was perfectly cast.  He actually made a very funny quote which I read about in a newspaper.  He said "when my agent called me about a part in this movie, I knew I wasn't gonna be no human!"Anyway back to my comment... this is an entertaining movie, yes it is. Purists, please stop this quest for perfection, it doesn't exist, not anymore anyway.  Entertainment is what matters.  Planet of the Apes with Charlton Heston is brilliant, and emotionally stirring, but it is history. Appreciate it, but move on.  Please.

title: A Good Film
text: I thought that the film was good.  I did not really have any preconceived notions other than the "Burton" touch.  His films are usually dark but beautiful spectacles in my opinion.Sometimes I wonder why people take movie plots so seriously.In the original, a lot of political statements were made (not unusual for Sci Fi films of that area).  It was safe in that genre to make political statements that would be blasted in other genres.The original Planet of the Apes series adequately addressed the issues of the time.  What would be the purpose of reiterating it in 2001?I actually liked the plot.  It was an interesting take or twist of the original.  There was some tongue and cheek dialogue as well.  The ending was the kind the either you liked or thought was really corny.  I liked the ending though, even if it did catch me off guard.I really liked the movie and would buy the video when it becomes available. I am really happy though, I saw it on the big screen.The choice of actors was excellent, I think Tim Roth stole the show, he was so convincing and seemed to enjoy every minute.  I was impressed with the good job that all the actors did.  It did not look easy.I wonder what Tim Burton will do next.  He is truly an artist.

title: Great film. I have a few quibbles
text: Taking this movie for its own merits instead of needless comparison to the original, I thought it was quite good. As many have said, the acting (at least of the apes) was astonishing. The villain chimp (Tim Roth) and Ari the sensitive chimp (Helena Bonham Carter) were amazing, both the acting and the technology to support the believability. Yes, the ending was strange and didn't follow logically whereas for the most part the rest of the movie was logically self-consistent. However, it was a good ending and I'm willing to reserve judgment to see how they develop it in the next film. My few quibbles with the movie were these: * I didn't see any gorillas on the space station and such large apes seem entirely inappropriate to the space mission, so where did the gorilla breeding stock come from? * I realize the apes are stronger than humans, especially the gorillas, but when they hit someone, the impact of the punch was ridiculous even considering their strength. If you could hit as hard as 5 Mike Tyson's on his best punch, you couldn't even come close to getting the target rocketing through the air like they did. And if you hit that hard, it would seem to be instant death but wasn't in the movie. I know, I know, Hollywood needs to really exaggerate. * The year was something like 2032 that it all began, right? Well, there is no way the world will even be close technologically and space achievement in 31 years. Transportation pods smaller than a compact car that can land on an earthlike planet and launch again? The apes genetically engineered to be very smart? The military has a massive space station?                This would be more believable in 2132. Enjoy, Jon

title: Decent But not great.
text: The movie was decent, not great but good enough to be a good remake. I'm a Tim Burton fan, and while I think that this is not his best film, it's still worthy enough to be a part of his work. The make up is great, and Tim Roth probably gave the best performance of a villain I have seen in quite some time.It's good but it needed a better Story.

title: Worth a look
text: I went into this movie with no expectations.  I loved the original, but understood that this was a re-imagining rather than a remake, so the movie was bound to be at least a bit different.  Burton does an excellent job of visualizing what a city built by primates might look like, vaguely jungle-like, but with buildings.  The plot is at least as good as the first one-I found that whole humans are mute angle just a bit much in the original.  This deals with rights of a stronger group over a weaker, touches on the dangers of allowing military leaders to make political decisions, and in general creates a believable world, especially when it becomes clear just how the apes got there in the first place.  (Just a note of science here-genetically altered chimps can only mean mixing DNA with a compatible species and we share 99% of the same DNA as chimps)  Carter and Roth are outstanding, details such as the gait of the apes are considered and the special effects are kept to a minimum.  I admit I am still undecided about whether or not I like the ending, but let's be honest here-Burton would be less than human if he wasn't planning on a possible sequel.  So why the uproar?  It's not every day you get to see an interspecies love story either.  There are some minor complaints I had, such as why Wahlberg was hell-bent on trying to get all the way back to Earth in what was obviously nothing more than a landing craft, but that hardly detracts from what was an enjoyable and entertaining movie. I recommend it.

title: The apes are among us.
text: I never saw the original 1968 Planet of the Apes, which was extremely popular but I decided to give the 2001 version a watch. Tim Burton once again proves just how great and Gothic that he can direct a movie, Burton has the darkest touch of anyone in Hollywood. Being a Bigfoot enthusiast a movie like Planet of the Apes is just a must see for me. This movie is more than just about a human who has to battle an ape for the rights to get along on the planet. Apes are shown and portrayed as being very smart and clever Burton must have done his homework as he well showed in this movie for example apes bury their dead and of course they can't swim, and Bigfoots are the same way! I strongly believe that apes and bigfoots are among us all anywhere that is proven with the ending of this film!

title: Forget the original and watch with fresh eyes, this is more honest to the novel.
text: Not such a bad film as some people have reported, I actually liked it, and I'm also deeply worried about the talk of the many cuts made.Allegedly Tim Burton made it as close to the book as possible, and even included some scenes such as a human-ape love scene. However, this is also one of the main reasons why fans of the original Heston film were upset, `where is the Statue of Liberty scene?' Well, it's not in the book!However, all this aside, and it is a really enjoyable movie. I'm a growing fan of Mark Wahlberg, and he just proves why yet again with his talent shining through. There's a superbly crafted ending here too, and one that I so enjoyed. This was another sticking point for some critics.My advice would be, drop the ideas from the original, and go and see this movie with fresh eyes.

title: a thoroughly enjoyable film
text: Despite all the bad reviews "Planet of the Apes" is a thoroughly enjoyable film.  Perhaps Wahlberg, while clearly trying to avoid the over the top melodrama of Heston's character, could have been a little more passionate at times, but the apes, especially Thade and Ari are wonderfully portrayed with a rich dimension helped along by Rick Baker's fabulous makeup effects.You must bear in mind that this is 21st century post-cold war America and this is a Tim Burton film.  There is no substantial socio-political commentary here, although there are plenty of gentle nods to racism, classism, sexism, religion, and the rest---along with several well placed winks at the original production [including a splendid cameo by Heston]. This is much more of a "fish out of water" and "search for belonging" movie that is Burton's specialty.

title: Believe me, this is no remake!
text: Everything you ever thought about the Planet of the Apes, is wrong!  Tim Burton takes this story to a whole new level.  The entire story is unique, the characters and set design, even the outstanding makeup, are Tim's signature.  You have to see this movie, it actually makes you think a bit about the way humans conduct themselves.  That's one thing I always liked about the original Planet films, they give you this unique view point on the human existence.  However, this new version give an entirely out of this universe look on life, literally.  You won't know what I mean unless you see this flick.  Trust me, you won't regret it.

title: ...then go rent the original
text: I was pretty satisfied after walking out of Planet of the Apes, and I couldn't see how many could outright complain about the movie. Then I heard it...for the first of many times..."It's not like the original". How many people walked into this movie expecting to see the original? These people should have saved some time and effort and rented the original. For those of us wanting a fresh look at the story, we couldn't be disappointed. You have Mark Wahlberg and Tim Roth doing outstanding jobs...especially Tim Roth. You have fantastic make up work by Rick Baker. You have Charlton Heston making one of the most ironic statements in history about guns. What more could you ask for? Possibily a little more of Tim Burton's touch, but that isn't a huge complaint...it is still a fantastic movie, even without some of Tim's signature looks. If you aren't expecting to see this movie and watch the original all over again, then this movie is for you. If you want the original, just redone with Mark Wahlberg, rent the original and use your imagination. To make up for the lack of Tim Burton's touch in this movie, I would suggest following this up with Sleepy Hollow.

title: Tim Burton rocks!!
text: I've just come from the cinema after watching Planets of the apes, and i can only say that it was one of the best i have seen for years...I've always enjoyed watching movies made by Tim Burton and this one was no exception!

title: Very Well Done
text: Firstly, I think the original Ape movies are among the finest films ever produced.  The entire series is brilliant and I frequently watch them.  I'm not a big Sci-Fi fan, but those movies are just about the best representation of a mix-and-match between social satire and pure "what if" filmmaking that makes viewers question themselves.But anyways, the new Apes movie is no different.
