The only thing that I really have issues with is the fact that some of the characters didn't really serve much purpose.  I don't know if they had all their lines cut out or what, but they don't really do a whole lot for the film.  Even Mark Wahlberg doesn't have a hell of a lot of dialogue.  But the film starts off much different than the first, and continues along that idea.  Most of the same themes are revisited, but skewed a bit.  The cinematography and makeup are both amazing.  This movie lived up to my expectations.  Go see this movie and judge for yourself.  I heard people coming out of the movie and saying that it sucked.  But, they probably have no basis for comparison if they haven't seen the originals.  I would give this movie 9/10.  Nearly perfect.

title: A good satire depicting human nature and apes that can act humanely
text: I had never seen a good science fiction movie since "Star Wars: Phantom of the Menace" until I saw "Planet of the Apes". Although the two films are about future human interplanetary adventures, "Planet of the Apes" stresses more on human compassion for and understanding of other living creatures. The film is also a good satire on men's foolhardy behavior to launch nuclear wars that could annihilate everything on earth only to find that, in the end, they would be ruled by "wiser-than-human" apes. For such a good film, all the kudos go not only to Director Tim Burton but also to all the crew, particularly the makeup artists, set designers and the actors.

title: Edward Scissorhands trip to Planet of the Apes
text:
I have been so often disappointed in the past going into movies with high expectations: Indianna Jones and the Last Crusade, Phantom Menance, Batman, to name a few.  So I suppose my learned skepticism somewhat saved Planet of the Apes for me.  I had absolutely no expectations for this film, after having enjoyed the first one so much.  And of course, the new version does not live up to the original.  The original was filled with layers of political, racial, and sociological themes; and it had an incredible ending.  And who can match the tortured, almost humorous essence of Heston.  Oh, and it was fun too. 
But the greatness of the original does not make the new version a bad movie. In fact, it was in my opinion quite an enjoyable movie.  It surpasses the original in terms of its visual effects. While the theme/story is more simplistic, it is very well told; it moves very fast and fluidly, yet is not so packed with chaotic action (see Armageddon) that it does not allow for slower moments that can be saviored.  For example, there is a great scene with Heston in a cameo.  I wonder if he knew what he was saying when he said it: humans are deceptive and dangerous and are even more so because they have guns; beware of them?  Not exactly the NRA's mantra.  Anyways, he had a great cameo.  There are many other humorous moments as well.  Basically, the movie did not take itself seriously.  It tipped its hat to the original without trying to mimick its feel.  It is obvious Burton wanted to have some fun with this movie, paying tribute to the original while at the same time trying to give this movie its own unique perspective.  I believe he succeeded and I believe that that is the movie's saving grace.

title: Good but had the potential for excellent
text: Really enjoyable, good remake, the attention to detail is very impressive however the character development could have been stronger.Good piece of escapism, nice to see a half decent sci-fi film again, however the potential was there for a more complicated storyline.The film also was crying out to be more violent and even a little gory, but has obviously been sanitised to give it a 12 certificate(uk) to cash in on a younger market, shamefollow up films a certainty

title: Tim Burton Does it Again
text: First off, Tim Burton is one of my all time favorite directors.  Batman, Beetlejuice, Nightmare Before Christmas, all excellent movies.  All of that aside though, this is one damned good movie.  The special effects and make-up look fantastic.  Each ape actually looks different from each other one, and they all move like you would expect an ape/human hybrid to move. The acting is great, especially Tim Roth.  His character Thade is one of my favorite parts of this entire movie.  I have to say I think that the only real weak link is Mark Wahlberg.  I usually like Marky Mark too, but this time his performance seems to fall a little flat.  I know alot of people probably aren't going to like this one.  Some people will mistake certain aspects as being corny, but that can be said about just about every piece of Science Fiction in existence.  The end is good, maybe not as good as the beginning of the original, but good nonetheless.  Overall I enjoyed this film a great deal and recommend it to all.

title: Great popcorn flick
text: Terrific "retelling" of a classic sci-fi pop culture icon. But this ending will leave a lot of folks scratching their heads like monkeys. You should really rent and watch the original film first, which I think was still better than this new one but just as enjoyable. While the original 1968 film was more a statement against nuclear war, Tim Burton's 2001 version focuses more on racism and religion. Still, it's the best popcorn movie of this summer.

title: Visually Stunning, Impressive... and of course, Flawed Version of "Apes"
text: I first became a fan of the "Planet of the Apes" saga when I was 12 years old. HBO was showing the original film and I came in on the scene in which Charlton Heston's Taylor was being interrogated in the apes' court. I was hooked from that moment on. I bought all five original films and watched all of them countless times and re-bought them when Fox put out the THX-Widescreen tapeset for the 30th anniversary. What did Apes do for me? Well, to begin with, it made me examine my religion. The end result? I determined I wasn't Christian. It also made me want to be a film director even more. THIS WAS WHAT SCI-FI COULD DO. Even the weakest entry of all, "Battle for the Planet of the Apes," was above standard sci-fi entertainment.So here I am, 22 years old, exploring religion, life, and directing my first ambitious independent film, which is even titled as a small homage to the fourth "Apes" film, "Conquest of Area 52" (there will be an IMDB entry on it next year sometime). "Planet of the Apes" is among my biggest reasons for wanting to make films and it's impacted the way I think as well.I've read the wonderful Pierre Boulle novel (and own the first printing, which I um, borrowed from my high school library) and I will be buying the "Apes" TV series on DVD. And of course, I saw Tim Burton's "reimagining" of "Planet" on opening day.From the beginning, I'm already biased. The original Apes saga was my Bible. To paraphrase, "Everything I Needed to Know I Learned From Apes." Heh-heh. Tim Burton... love the guy. He made "Ed Wood," one of my top ten favorite films. His unique visions and styles have always intrigued me. Admittedly however, Burton normally did not have strong points in plot or character development. His "Batman" films were a mixed bag, not showing enough of the psychology of what it meant to be Batman, but they were so visually entrancing that I am still able to watch them on their own merits. In fact, both "Batman" and "Batman Returns" get an 8.5/10 from me. "Mars Attacks" is a joy to watch on the right day, and the same goes with "Edward Scissorhands" and "Beetlejuice." By the time he directed "Sleepy Hollow," I felt that Burton had evolved so much as a visual storyteller that he really could not be judged for weak plot or character. That's the way he wants to be as an artist, so let it be.But...This time, he's done "Planet of the Apes." If it were anything else, like say a remake of "2001", I could still watch it and not crucify it. No, this new version is not anything worth crucifying. "Apes 2001", shall we call it, has the all the Burton standards- plot and character on the back burner, awesome visuals at the forefront. What sets Burton aside from say, the biggest hack of all time Michael "Pearl Harbor" Bay, is that while his character drama may not be the most engaging, it's not exactly boring or annoying. It's just SIMPLE. This version plays out like the 1968 version except cut down to the core: an astronaut crashlands on a strange planet, he gets caught, is imprisoned at Ape City, gets away with the help of a lovable chimp, goes into the Forbidden Area, finds out the origin of the apes, and leaves the apes to go home. That last part is the only thing really different in the overall structure, except this time, the film does not end there, and we get an ending which both pays its respects to Boulle's original novel and Franklin Schaffner's original film.There are several references this version makes to the original series. With the Apes army we get a nod to "Beneath." With the love story, er, triangle, there's a similar feel to Zira and Cornelius' plight in "Escape." The look of the astronaut costumes is very similar to those in the first two. And the origin of the apes rings in similar tone to the fourth film, "Conquest."Did I like it? I've only seen it twice, so its a bit hard to say that without going, "except for this... and that... and this... and that..." What I liked: the cinematography, the sets (which are never all that real-looking but invoke memories of illustrated children's books, which is a Burton constant), the movement and makeup of the apes (maybe the two most noteworthy things done here), the cameos by Chuck Heston and Linda Harrison (Nova from Apes I & II). I also liked the love triangle between Ari, Leo, and the blonde; this was very humorous. Wahlberg didn't add much depth to a written character already lacking depth, but he certainly had the right expressions for his character. I wouldn't be particularly overjoyed by my stay on the Planet of the Apes either. Helena Bonham-Carter is always good in whatever she does, and her character in this was endearing enough to accept her makeup, which differs greatly from the others. Paul Giamatti's Limbo may be the best character of all, providing the most comic relief. Tim Roth as Thade is brilliant, as are the rest of the key players. I didn't appreciate that the social commentaries were sometimes rather clumsily slapped on; indeed a lot of the time they seemed like desperate attempts by Burton to put SOMETHING in there saying ANYTHING when the script had little to give him (Burton arrived on the project fairly late and had little time to shape the film).Overall, this 2001 version of "Planet" is far better than it should have been, given the success it had to live up to. It doesn't hold a candle to the original, and I certainly never expected it to. I'm glad Fox put a commercial artist in charge of it, rather than a commercial hack such as the afore-mentioned Michael Bay or Tony Scott. It may have been more intriguing had Oliver Stone worked on it (Stone was attached several years back).Tim Burton did the near-impossible for me: I didn't want to kill him after watching this. And for an Apes fanatic such as myself, that is saying a heck of a lot. Let's all hope that when Fox greenlights the sequel, they don't hand it over to Joel Schumacher. I'd take Ed Wood's Planet of the Apes over his anyday.I do have one quibble I think is more than worthy of consideration to even a non-Apes fan not familiar with the original series:We know where the Apes come from in "Apes 2001." But why the heck would that space station have HORSES on it?! Sorry, I'm not gonna take the old lame scientific explanation about how life on other planets must be similar. I may be a Darwin enthusiast, but come on. That's stretching it.

title: Visual achievement make up for plot deficiencies
text: I must say, after seeing the PotA edition of Exposure I took their advice and went into the movie without considering that this was the second adaptation of a French novel from the sixties--trying to watch it as if it were an original script.  That gave me no expectations and disappointment that things were so different.The surprises (including Charlton Heston's cameo) just kept me glued to the screen.  I even enjoyed the ironic twist at the end even if it made very, very little practical sense.  Paul Giamatti deserves extra credit for an outstanding comedic performance.  Tim Roth has never been sexier.My only disappointment was the serious lack of explanation, mainly toward the end.  I think they allowed way too much freedom for our imagination and we deserve to know just how (...)Rich Baker can look forward to his Seventh Oscar for Best Makeup at next year's Acadamy Awards.

title: Very Slick homage with great effects.
text: I just saw this movie in the theatres and I left with a smile on my face. That's all one can ask for. There was social satire, humor and Estella Warren wearing little clothes for the guys, and Mark Wahlberg for the ladies.  There was great make-up by Rick Baker for the techno-philes and Tim Roth for the acting buffs.  Tim Burton directs very well; the visuals in this movie were great.  The ending was clever and fun and I enjoyed the movie.

title: Excellent entertainment, although not Burton's best...
text: Sure, this new adaptation of Pierre Boule's classic novel Planet of The Apes isn't a wonderful exploration of human behavior or something like that, but that is not it's target. Instead it tries to be an incredibly entertaining summer movie, while still being intelligent and retaining Burton's gorgeous visual style. And with that in mind, it fully accomplishes its goals. First of all, the soundtrack, made by long-time Burton collaborator Danny Elfman is up to the composer's high standards. The brutal percussion-based sounds of his score fit the movie perfectly. The story is very satisfying and the ending is excellent. Touches of clever humor add to the script. But, of course, what steals the show is Burton's gift for creating memorable images and his army of apes, led by General Thade, a memorable character played to perfection by Tim Roth. For this movie, Burton often leaves his trademark dark and blue colors, but the movie still has his wonderful touch. As for the apes, they are very impressive. The cast is good, without having very hard jobs to do, but as I said earlier, Roth shines. So, this may not be Tim Burton's best movie, but it is the perfect summer entertainment, offered to you by one of history's greatest directors.85%

title: Great Summer Movie
text: Forget all of the critics. This is not supposed to be a physiological thriller. This a great movie. Visually spectacular.This movie delivers excitement and lots of action. I cannot wait to see the sequel. This (so far) is the best of the summer of 2001.

title: I loved it!
text:
The new Planet of the Apes flick is sheer entertainment from the very beginning, right down to the insanely amusing finish. Tim Burton directed it, but it doesn't seem like a Tim Burton film. He seemed to want to pay more of an homage to the original than change it with the distinguished macabre feel of his other films. The story is great. It has been modified a bit, but nothing has really changed. Everyone in the film is superb especially Paul Giamatti as the wise-cracking comic relief. Though some of the plot twists and situations don't really make much practical sense, they are all interesting and brilliant. A+!!
            9/10

title: An original plot makes all the difference
text:
I was pleasantly surprised with this one.  I was expecting a re-done plot with new affects, but Tim Burton takes the extra step to make an all new movie.  I enjoyed the first Planet of the Apes and I was very happy to see this one had a completely original plot.  This gave the movie a new flavor. 
The story, for the most part, was well presented and it made sense as well. However, there were a few areas which it was a little weak and where there were errors Wahlberg's character of a military officer with a science background, would not have made.  Wahlberg was good and helped the film along.  Tim Roth was also good and gave the film a sinister side.  Michael Clarke Duncan gave an explosive performance which in my opinion gave brought a lot if character to the film really helps make the film.Overall, good and worth your while (8 out of 10).

title: King Simian's Mines
text:
In 1968, the world's fascination with outer space was still largely in the science-fiction realm. Sure, we'd put some men in space, but no one had landed on any foreign worlds. We imagined, through the voices of such authors as Arthur C. Clarke and Isaac Asimov, interstellar travel and advanced civilizations. But all of that seemed to be part of the distant future in 1968.Here were are 33 years later, and while we haven't traveled to other galaxies or met any other civilizations (advanced or otherwise, Whitley Strieber's experiences notwithstanding), we have put a man on the moon and are hard at work on the international space station. In short, in 33 years we've come a long way, baby.Anyone who has seen the original 1968 Planet of the Apes knows that the ending is a real kicker. I certainly won't give it away here, because there's an entire generation that hasn't seen the movie and most certainly should. Suffice to say that the original is unique, not simply another sci-fi flick.The new one is termed a "rethinking" of the original. Tim Burton, who gave us Edward Scissorhands, Batman, PeeWee's Big Adventure, and Sleepy Hollow,is the director here, and the film is full of his stylish touch.Mark Wahlberg is Captain Leo Davidson, an astronaut in 2029 on a small space station that is conduction experiments on chimps. An electrical storm strikes, and a chimp is sent out to survey the cause. When the animal does not return, Davidson launches himself - against his commander's orders - to find him. Next thing he knows, his space pod is crash landing on an unknown planet inhabited by talking, aggressive apes - with humans as slaves.Davidson is captured by the apes along with other humans, but escapes. His plan - get back to where his pod crashed, find his GPS-like device that will allow him to locate his mother ship, and get back home. But it's a long way back to the pod, and he suddenly has thousands of apes after him.Luckily, he has on his side Ari (Helena Bonham Carter), a kindhearted ape who feels empathy toward the humans. Ari, of course, symbolizes animal lovers on Earth; she cannot understand why her fellow apes treat their humans so badly. "We can learn much from them," she claims, but her claims fall on deaf ears. Davidson, with the help of Ari, leads a small band of refugee humans (including the Daena, played by the delicious Estelle Warren) to his pod, where he makes some startling discoveries, none of which will be revealed here. (If you've seen the original and know the surprise ending, the discoveries Davidson makes are as intriguing as that ending.)Hot on the trail of the astronaut and his friends is the evil General Thade (Tim Roth) and his fiercest warrior Colonel Attar (Michael Clarke Duncan). The makeup jobs on all of the apes are astounding, and the actors are completely unrecognizable under their disguises. The general has been told by his ailing father (an uncredited Charlton Heston, who starred in the 1968 original) that humans, in the time before time, humans brought violence to their planet; now that apes dominate, humans must be destroyed.
As with the original, this is a fascinating treatise not only on how we treat  other animals but on how we treat ourselves. Is it truly accurate to say that humans are civilized and the apes are the savages? The film actually makes you think about such things, but it's no philosophical hodge-podge of mumbo-jumbo. It's a exciting, powerful movie, worth watching on just about every level.

title: Weird....But good movie.
text: This is a good movie.  I love Tim Burton's style.  The character's were good, the scenery(as always in a Burton movie, especially Batman).  It was very cool.  Everything was all good until...the ending. That came outta left- field.  I won't tell you guys the ending but, let me till you that it had me and other people little confused on how it happened.  The score is GREAT. Danny Elfman rules. The score is a little like Batman.  Also, the opening Credits are EXACTLY like Batman, which is great. 8/10- Go check it out.

title: Best movie of the summer!
text: I found the movie Planet of The Apes very interesting. Although I admit that I never saw the original series, I found this movie very entertaining. I also found that it was very refreshing, I needed to see a good movie this summer. I'm not interested in the mindless comedy of American Pie 2, or even The Princess Diaries. Even though I walked into the theatre slightly sceptical of "talking apes", I walked out completely satisfied. Definately a movie that will leave you thinking even long after it's over. If your sick of all the teeny bopper movies, and ready to see an unforgetable tale of human kind being turned upside down, I recommend this movie to you!

title: It depends on how you expect it to be...
text:
I enjoyed this movie about ten times more that I thought I would. I guess that when you expect a movie to be kinda dumb and pale in comparison to its original version, then the good qualities of the new version can catch you by surprise and provide a lot of fun when you least expect it.
I had been disappointed by Burton's "Mars Attacks!" (It could've been a classic considering that amazing cast), so I let some friends drag me to "Planet" with more than a little trepidation.In one of the earliest scenes, the lights of the space station all go dark, and I heard probably half a dozen people around me whispering various versions of "what, no emergency lighting?!", so I thought "Here we go; more Hollywood dumbness unleashed upon the screen..." but within the next few minutes things started picking up...and from then on I was completely along for the ride.My favorite part of this movie has got to be Danny Elfman's propulsive score; I can't wait to buy this soundtrack. It's great! My second favorite aspect of this film is Tim Roth's wild portrayal of Thade; he delivers quite an inventive homage to great SF villains, all the way back to Ming the Merciless! There are some scenes in which his character is so malevolent that it's spine-tingling.As for the ending (NO SPOILER) - I think it's all intended in fun, with a nod and a wink, not to mention unleashing a spectacular pun upon humanity! (Anyone who's already seen it should get it.)So come on folks, lighten up - this one is pure entertainment. Thanks for the good time, Mr. B!!

title: ...oozes with style.
text: This is definitely one of the better films I have seen this year, perhaps even the best.  Tim Burton once again delivers a movie that oozes with style, class and sophistication, with a world so detailed and believable it's almost mind-blowing.  Not being familiar with the original movie/tv series myself, I didn't quite know what to expect.  I knew from the few articles I had read that Mark Wahlberg plays a pilot who crash lands on a planet ruled by apes, and in an interesting twist, finds himself as the "alien".  The story is a great concept and really brings up some interesting issues to think about.  This is one of the things I appreciated about it.  It is one big role-reversal but in two different ways.  Firstly we're no longer the master species in control, we're the animals without the souls to be used and abused. Secondly, instead of being discriminated against because we might be black, white or purple, we're now discriminated against because we're simply human. It says a lot about how we as humans treat others, whether it be animals or people...  I really liked this movie.  The actors were great, especially Tim Roth as Thade.  I've never encountered such a menacing, intimidating character as Roth's Thade on screen before.  Helena Bonham Carter's Ari was curious, naive and likeable and Mark Wahlberg didn't disappoint.  In general, all the ape actors did a fantastic job and combined with the stunningly detailed make-up, pulled it all off in a very convincing fashion.Danny Elfman is the man responsible for the film's score and I remember thinking during the credits, "Hmm, that name is familiar..."  I will definitely remember his name from now on.  The score is excellent, and at times spine-chilling, particularly during the opening credits.I'm an every-movie person and I really couldn't find much to fault Planet of the Apes on.  My only gripe is that like so many movies these days, it leaves you feeling just a little unsatisfied somehow..  Maybe it's how film-making has changed these days, or the new techniques they use, I really can't put my finger on it.  But with this film it's only a minor thing.  See it.  You wont be disappointed.

title: Well put together movie but...
text: I really liked this version of 'Planet of the Apes'. The costumes were excellent and the acting was very well done but I was really p***ed off with the ending. I feel the lead up to the ending needed to be explained more. Over all it was a good movie.

title: Wonderful
text: I was hoping I would enjoy this film and I did!!!!Planet of the Apes really is a wonderful and engrossing film to watch. It has a unique look throughout, with some wonderful and vast sets and locations. The scenery is always slightly different, and that makes it interesting to look at.The conversations between the characters are involving, entertaining and in places even charming. There is some very amusing humour in there as well, nothing hilarious, but enough to get a laugh from the audience.... "There's nothing you want around your house LESS than a human teenager" for example, or the Ape with false teeth!The plot is also good. And to a certain extent keep you wondering what will happen next. Mark Whalberg is excellent as the main character. He's just the type you want in a film like this. Lets face it, you wouldn't want Sylvester Stallone or some other muscle bound 'Conan' type bloke down there. But Whalberg makes a very believable main character. General Thade's character is fantastic throughout also.Finally, you know throughout that SOMETHING will happen at the end. It was inevitable. And what IS at the end was very satisfying, hard to get your head around, but really cool none the less.And anyone who thinks that your a shallow individual for thinking that a 're-make' (or re-imaging) is good, is totally wrong. Planet of the Apes is a fine film that entertains throughout and doesn't disappoint anywhere......... and thats ALL anyone can ask for!

title: Better than the original
text:
Tim Burton´s re-telling of the novel "Planet of the Apes" by Pierre Boulle is a stylish and exciting adventure. In the year 2029, astronaut Leo Davidson (Mark Wahlberg) travels through a storm in space and is separated from his comrades. He lands on a remote planet, where humans are slaves and the apes are rulers. He is captured but attempts to escape and tries to revolt against the apes. You might think that a new version of "Planet of the Apes" from 1968 would be a bad idea. But since the story in the new one is rather different than in the original, it becomes a whole new film. Burton´s version comes up with many interesting ideas. He develops the racial issues more than the first one did, and questions the real differences between the humans and the apes.
The acting is first class all the way, Mark Wahlberg is perfect in the leading role, but the real stars here are those who play apes. Helena Bonham Carter, Michael Clarke Duncan and Tim Roth are all excellent, especially the latter. Roth is terrific as the evil General Thade, a character whom in the wrong hands could have been a bit silly. But Roth makes him a great villain, and he actually steals the show. I would love to see this British actor in more big budget productions in the future. The acting through the very realistic ape costumes is definitely something worth seeing.Overall, I liked the new "Planet of the Apes" better than the first one, and I still liked that one a lot. But the new one has better actors, cooler effects and a clever and entertaining script. It´s not perfect, the movie becomes a bit sentimental and cheesy towards the end, when Wahlberg tries to motivate the humans to fight. And why does it always have to be a kid who wants to be a hero in these big summer movies? I first thought that it was only in the "Jurassic Park"-trilogy that this was common, but "Planet of the Apes" was no exception.  This is still the most exciting adventure I´ve seen this year, and it´s nice to see a summer movie with both brains and muscles. And I liked the ending, even if I didn´t understand much of it at first. But it certainly blew me away, just like Michael Clarke Duncan said it would, in an interview I read.
* * * * out of * * * * *

title: Terrific Movie
text: I just previewed this movie at the theater that I work as a projectionist for last night. I especially enjoyed the great audio in the movie. Halfway through the movie and especially in the battle scene I was right on the edge of my seat. Very very good movie, well worth seeing.

title: Excellent for remake standards!
text: To start with I'll just say, the original movie is a true classic, a lot better, and I advise you to see it. Also You'll understand this movie a bit better.Visually this movie is wonderful, and the new ape suits are incredible. Unlike the original movie, the apes have a more realistic appearance, they act more, and sounds a bit more like apes. But the apes are still the dominat and intelligent species on the planet. This movie is more based on the original novel by the French author Pierre Boulle. And I'm sure he would be pleased with the story arc in this movie, even though all the french factors have been Americanized.Mark Walberg show us a strong performance, and the movies "villain" general Thade, portrayed by Tim Roth, is just terrifying. To be candid the two adversarial roles really saved this movie.It may not be as mind-boggling as the original movies, but it's still well worth watching. It's great for remake standards and shouldn't be compared to much to the original.

title: Roddy would be proud!!
text: Well,I had been waiting for the last few years (after hearing of a new Planet of the Apes being in the works)for this film to become a reality.After many script changes (not to mention stars & directors) was it worth the wait?YYYYYYEEEEEEEEESSSSS!!This version ROCKS! Now, I am almost 40 years old and grew up with the original films,TV series & cartoon.I was an apeaholic back in the day!I had everything from the Mego figures to the Don Post masks. I had realized early on,that this was NOT a remake but a "re-imagined" Planet of the Apes by Tim Burton.I am not a huge Tim Burton fan,though there are a couple of his films I enjoy.After seeing his version of POTA last night,I have to say that I am very impressed!Great story,great acting and fantastic make-up! Though the story and the names have changed,Burton's film is exciting to the core.I will not give much away as the movie has yet to be released on Friday,but I will say that there are more than a couple of original POTA quotes thrown in and the ending is a nice twist (as it was in the original). Don't be too hard on this version,even though it is not the APJAC vision,it stands on it's own!APEAPHILES ENJOY!! 9 out of 10.

title: Plot holes, yes. But, please, slavery not one of them!
text:
Yes the movie has some pretty serious plot holes, all described in other reviews and won't be repeated here.  I don't want to ridicule other reviewers, but to suggest that the apes would not enslave humans, or consider them savages because THEY CAN SPEAK ENGLISH and display intelligence is unbelievable baffling.  The very point of the whole D*** movie is to point out how unfair and bigoted people (or apes) can be.  Of course it's illogical, that is the point !!!  Has no one heard of the basically continuous human history of enslavement of our fellows ????  Funnily enough there was ample evidence of intelligence and language there, even English, and yet slavery went on!  All this real life enslavement with one hell of a lot less motivation (greed basically) than is provided the apes in this movie.  Please if you are going to go on and on about plot holes at least stick to safer ground. 
Do the other plot holes really detract from the movie, decided for yourself. I thought the whole look and feel of the movie made up for the its other shortcomings, and that it was a worthy remake of a much loved classic.

title: Rod Serling would be proud
text: Tim Burton has managed to take a science fiction classic and "reimagine it" in a way that manages to be both faithful to the themes of the original film, while accommodating today's action-demanding audiences.Of course in many ways the film IS superior to the 1968 original. Rick Baker's makeup is a marvel, and more than makes up for his King Kong debacle of 25 years ago -- even though they still can't seem to create an ape mask that doesn't make the actors lisp. The action sequences are fast-paced and brutal, and the actors do such a marvelous job ... er ... apeing the moves of primates you're forgiven if you think Burton tossed a silverback or two into the melee just to liven things up.Mark Wahlberg is a disappointment as Leo, coming off as a one-dimensional jerk. The only times he shows any real humanity is when he interacts with a favorite (real) chimp, though he's certainly capable in the action sequences.Helena Botham Carter as the cute, human-loving Ari is the best thing in the movie, presenting a very well-rounded character when she isn't making lovey dovey eyes at Leo (best not to think about it too much). Estella Warren as a sexy slavegirl gets to show off the best lips in Hollywood, engage in an aborted catfight with Ari, wear very little, and go off in a huff of jealousy when Leo seems to want to spend more time with Ari. I get the strong feeling her best moments were left on the cutting room floor. It's always good to see David Warner and Kris Kristofferson, though their time on screen is brief.Tim Roth is fun and scary to watch as the villain, Gen. Thade, while Michael Clarke Duncan makes a menacing figure as Thade's right hand ape.Look fast for Linda Harrison -- the original slave girl in the original movie. Rick Baker himself also appears as an ape. And Burton's longtime love Lisa Marie makes her obligatory appearance, with a funny bit as a snotty, horny ape.The biggest laugh in the file comes from an otherwise dramatic cameo by original film star Charlton Heston. I won't spoil the reasons why it's funny -- only clue: it's not just in the dialogue.Nor will I spoil the ending. I was confused by it at first until I realized... it was CLASSIC Rod Serling. Once I realized Burton was paying homage to the Twilight Zone -- and let's not forget Serling co-wrote the original film -- everything fell into place.My only advice to Burton is to let sleeping apes lie and not attempt to reimagine the other films in the original Apes series. This is a good one-off, but best to move on to the next idea.

title: Good movie but nowhere near original
text: Planet of the Apes is a pretty good film but it had its ups and downs. The movie is about a astronaut named Leo (Mark Whalberg) who gets sucked into a portal and lands on a planet where apes rule. Tim Roth plays Thade, an army general who hates all humans. His right-hand man Attar (Michael Clarke Duncan) follows and executes all of Thades orders. Leo escapes with the help of a compassionate ape named Ari (Helena Bonham Carter) and is now a fugitive on the run from the apes. This movie I liked but I don't think was 100% perfect. I thought the make-up was not as good as the originals. The acting was pretty good by my standards. Like all Apes movies, the endings have to twist which this one did. Overall this movie was good, and recommend to sci-fi fans, but probably not to Apes fans because it really wasn't a remake in my book.8/10

title: Very nice effort
text: As a retelling, this story was very good, if a little predictable at times. I think the only down sides for me were the lack of any acting talent in Mark Wahlberg, and the obvious 'we're planning a sequel' ending.  Other than that, it was a very enjoyable experience, and the addition Heston was a treat.  But to be perfectly honest, Helena Bonham Carter is one sexy monkey. :-)

title: Chimply, A great time!
text: I think first of all, one can easily separate the two POTA movies, as both, while sharing some elements, have VERY different stories. Mark Wahlberg stars as an soldier who is based on a space station which is experimenting with using chimp controlled spaceships. When one chimp is lost in a spacepod during an exploration of a magnetic space field, Wahlberg takes off (unauthorized) to find it. When the pod enters the field, Wahlberg loses control as well, soon he crash lands in a jungle. And he is VERY quickly introduced to the dominant species on the planet ;) The story which follows is very tightly directed by Burton, and is very well acted by Wahlberg. Helena Bonham Carter and Tim Roth are (as usual) excellent and don't let the make up (which is designed by the always outstanding Rick Baker) get in the way of the performances. Finally, as usual, a GREAT score by Danny Elfman.

title: Some questions
text: A question to the author or the director: Why is the movie ending with the apes again being dominant? After the captain has showed humans and apes to live together, how can apes win again? Either apes and human cross breed and apes genes were dominant or the author or the director might have answer.. Your answer will be greatly appreciated. The movie is overall good for a fiction but I think can be made with a fantastic story in sequels. I do not think this is a remake of the 69 movie. Even the director himself might have tried to make this a remake. I see no possibility of this one matching anything with the first movie.Thanking you.BGhimire- A Physics and Philosophy student

title: One of the Years Best!
text: Tim Burton does a spectacular job of re-imagining and re-telling planet of the Apes. In watching Tim Burton's Planet of the Apes you can see the simularity's to the original film, but Burton also manage's to tie in his usuall twists and turns that make him such an amazing and one of a kind Director. When watching this film you tend to forget that there are only people under all that fur and makeup and not real Apes,thanks to Rick Baker.As if all that is not enough the casting for this film couldn't have been much better. Tim Roth Plays Thade the General of the Apes that despieses the humans.Tim Roth Delivers an unbelievably frightning performance that he should be recognized for. Helen Bonham Carter gives an absolutely steller performance as Ari. Ari is an ape that has pity for the humans because she see's how poorly they are treated by the Apes, after she meets Leo Davidson (Mark Whalberg)  she starts to realize that Leo is different from the other humans and she starts to believe in the humans more and more. Mark Whalberg Delivers a good performance but nothing that he will be remembered for. And last but not least Danny Elfman, Elfman composed perfect music for this film which I guess was not that big of a surprise because he always gives a 110 percent. Great music, great acting, Burton+Elfman= Great Movie!!!

title: Strange ending
text: This was truly a great movie, I loved it! The ending though was really strange! So I really hope for a follow up!But I recommend it! Tim Roth plays the role of general Thade great! I´ll just say one thing to you: SEE IT!!!!

title: Great tribute to a classic film
text: This movie is a stunning tribute to the original films.  Tim Burton took elements of the original story and created something surprisingly new. Tim Burton, as always, demonstrates incredible cinematography; the ape makeup is near perfect; and the acting is fine (Tim Roth as Thade is particularly good). People complain about it's "plot holes" and "confusing ending".  The movie doesn't conflict with itself, does it?  Since when are movie makers required to spell out every detail of the story they are telling? It's not as good as the original, but it's got a lot going for it. Don't let the whiners who are afraid to think about a movie after it's over convince you not to check it out..

title: Not a perfect movie, but...
text: An enjoyable one, none-the-less.  As I was watching it, I thought to myself, "You know, I'd really like to see this with my 9 year old brother".  It's a slightly original action movie that supplies enough twists from the usual good guy v. bad guy flick to make it interesting.The movie makes some ham-fisted attempts at social commentary.  At one point in the movie an ape played by Paul Giamatti even exclaims "Can we all get along?" That line has been parodied so many times, it's almost painful.  In fact, as memory recalls Tim Burton had Jack Nicholson say the exact same line (to a much greater comic effect in "Mars Attacks!"  The racism allegories seem so forced, it's distracting.  You almost expect Helena Bonham Carter's ape character to organize a big human-ape chain and start singing "I'd like to teach the world to sing"But aside from the failed commentary, the movie succeeds.  All of the performances were above par. Tim Roth treaded the line of overacting, but never crosses it and makes a great, and perpetually angry, Thade.  Micheal Clark Duncan surprises as a loyal, and religious gorilla general.  Mark Walhburg makes a convincing action hero, although the tough guy role doesn't allow his trademark less-than-brilliant charm to come through as well.  And Estella Warren, well, she stands there with a look of constant surprise on her face. But, hey, she looks great doing it.The only thing I thought was missing was more of Tim Burton's trademark quirkiness.  If you had shown me this movie, and told me to guess the director, I would have had no clue.  Burton's eye for the odd is what excels good movies to great ones.  But, all in all, a fun couple hours. I'll give it:7.5/10 bananas

title: Lusher Visual Style, Better Script
text: I thought the new re-creation of "Planet of the Apes" had a lusher visual style and a better script. Of course the new technology also made for upgraded f/x in a film heavily dependent on that end. The acting was commendable generally, but especially by Helena Bonham Carter & Tim Roth behind all that monkey make-up.

title: Wow, the apes really need some prozak!
text: I know, the apes being villains, that they're not supposed to be the nicest of characters, but isn't it a little unrealistic that EVERY SINGLE ONE OF THEM walks around all day grunting and growling?  The only apes in this remake that aren't mad all the time are Ari (Helena Bonham Carter) and Limbo (Paul Giammatti), and that's only because Ari is the "hero ape woman" and Limbo the comic relief.  Of course, the humans in "Planet of the Apes" aren't really any better.  They're either really nervous all of the time, or really angry.  Maybe if both races calmed down a little, they'd have some peace!Aside from the prozak prescription, this was a reasonable remake.  Not Burton's best, not by far, but his directing it makes it a lot better. The fight scenes are entertaining, and Tim Roth delivers as the evil General Thade.  Unfortunately, Roth is the only actor who delivers a great performance.  Sure, the others weren't bad, but they didn't match Roth's ability to basically "become the ape".  Even Oscar nominee Michael Clarke Duncan moves a little roboticly sometimes.Still, a good, dark sci-fi thriller, 7.5/10.

title: 8 year olds dude
text: This was a good movie visually speaking.  However, the jumping monkeys got old after a while.  Maby if they had a monkey saying some old cliches... oh wait, that's what they did.  It's just too bad they had an 8 year old write the dialogue for the movie.  I didn't pay to see a new take on a pop-classic just to get cliches tossed at me for a couple of hours.  Not even all the special affects could cover the corny dialogue used to try to make this movie funny.

title: in my opinion a new classic
text: Planet of the apes in my opinion a new classic. Tim Burton did a really excellent job on this movie. Mark did some good acting too. The special effects were really cool in the movie. The music helped out with the atmosphere. I dont anything bad to say about this movie at all. Everything about it was great. I really think this movie will be remembered for a long time. I scenery was really cool looking. I recommend this movie to anyone and everyone. This is a movie families can watch together. Plus the ending was really cool. In my opinion. So take my advice watch it sometime.

title: One of the best sci-fi movie......
text: One of the best sci-fi movie tha i ever seen. Movie about 3 astronauts that land some where in the galaxy after 2000 years that they leave earth,and descover planet of apes and humans are primitive like apes in our days. this movie have a moral message, I look at this movie like aprotest against nukleer bombs and war when in the end of the movie "Taylor" say "they finely do it" he meens that finely people destroy them self whit they bombs and primitive animals [apes] conquest the earth. This movie have a big problem : "Taylor" playd by Charlton Heston come to earth and belive all movie that is not earth......so hove apes speeke english ??? the biggest problem wit this movie is if some one speeks so it will be only english even in out space.... and when "taylor" comes to city of apes is normal that they speeks english ---in other planet---

title: Quit moaning
text: Sometimes I wonder if people go to the cinema purely for the purpose of moaning and sniping about the films they see. While I will admit that far too many films are moronic today, so to are far too many of the audience. The original Planet of the Apes is undoubtedly a good film with some stunning moments ( it's wonderful how a film gets elevated to the level of masterpiece when people need a reason to moan about its sequel / remake ), but the potential was in the premise for a different type of film. For all the original's strengths I think you'd be hard-pushed to claim it was exciting, or visually interesting. Tim Burton has seized the opportunity to explore these possibilites, resulting in a highly entertaining if undemanding film. As a complete redraft of the original it is ultimately a very different entity, but it in no way embarrasses  the original nor takes anything away from it. Honestly, what do the 'how dare they do this to a classic film' brigade imagine is going to happen? Do they think the original is going to cease to exist? That from now on people will only ever discuss the remake? Unlikely. There is little in this film that will cause much discussion, but then I've never heard anyone discuss the original either. And yes, the ending is obvious and not as good as the first one ( as the most known 'twist' ending of all time they could scarcely have repeated it ), but there is nothing in the original that scarcely comes close to the amusing satire on human behaviour to be found in the first half of Burton's remake. Most important of all (and this goes out particularly to those who decry the tarnishing of the original 'classic'): This movie is FUN. You can't say that for the '68 version...

title: Monkey in the Middle
text:
Here's a rarity - a review of POTA that's not a rave or a pan. 
Obviously it is a good-looking film, with terrific costumes, photography and make-up.  It is also usually compelling storytelling - not Pierre Boulle's PLANET but not the original film either.  Points for originality for sure. I like that the humans could speak - their lack of speech in the first film was never effectively explained.  Even though the film is fleet, there is a noticable lull after Neil and company have successfully fled ape city. Burton wisely gets right on to the film's conclusion and (surprise) ending post haste.  But while the story flies by, the character development is non-existant and the love story is divided between the female of TWO species.  To be fair, our leading man is not the most compelling actor - but Heston was no Olivier either.  The story has multiple holes - where did the horses come from anyway? There's no sign of any non-ape or human life except these equines but no clue is given as to why there are no other creatures about.  The cameos by Heston and Harrison are badly handled though the refs to first film are fun for fans.  The surprise ending manages to combine the shock of the original with the option for a sequel.Burton's film lacks the scope and epic feel of it's inspiration and it will doubtless join the LOST IN SPACE film on the rental shelves.  Now if someone were to make Boulle's vision - that would be something.

title: Another disappointing summer movie
text: So far I've seen Pearl Harbor, Moulin Rouge and now this movie and I had great expectations for all three but they turned out to be a big disappointment. Especially this re-make of Planet of the Apes was so disappointing that I'm even embarrassed telling I went to see it. My next movie choice will be Captain Corelli's Mandolin and I hope it won't be another disappointment. Where are the good movies?? Anyway, the atrocious acting in Planet of the Apes was embarrassing to watch. I liked Mark in the Perfect Storm but in this movie he was horrible, also miscast, I believe, remembering how Charlton Heston was so much a better choice in the first movie. I agree with so many other negative comments about this movie and so I won't repeat them. All the promotion that went into this movie made me believe it was a worthwhile movie but what a waste of time and money. By all means, go see it if you're that curious to compare it with the first one, the list of people disappointed will only grow longer.

title: Okay
text: I liked this movie. I think the original is better but this version is still fun to watch. Can someone explain the ending to me please? The ending of the original was surprising but this ending was confusing. I am also sick of people who don't know that this film is a remake (or re-imagining). Neither the original or remake is like the novel. Both versions leave out the huge ape city and the fact that the apes drive cars and fly around in helicopters. I know that the budget of the 1968 version was not big enough to include everything but we're in the 21st century now and these things could have been included with computer effects. Overall, a good movie. *** out of ****

title: Plan 10 From Outer Space
text: My fears when I heard that 20th Century Fox had enlisted Tim Burton to direct a resurrection of their "Apes" franchise was that he would omit most of the spirit of the first series of films, rely on production design and quick editing to carry his movie, and spend a lot of money making it...oh yeah....and it wouldn't be any good....And...it isn't any good!!!!! The only "ape" character who is able to look convincingly like a gorilla rather than a man in make-up is Michael Clarke Duncan. Now, of course, one could make the same complaint about the original, but one of the stated reasons for remaking an SF film is that the special effects have progressed to the point where the story can be better told. Not the case here.....Because the film relies so heavily on production design and quick editing, the viewer is never able to invest in the story or the characters. Mr. Whalberg, you are no George Taylor, though in some calculated way, I'm sure you appeal to a certain demographic.This is a film contrived by marketeers and sociologists. Apparently, Mr. Burton shot 6 endings in an attempt to find the one that would guarantee the most box office. The one that made it onto the print is non-sensical (unless it is explained in a sequel). If you want time travel, Star Trek has done it ad nauseum over the past few years. Mr. Burton isn't doing anything new here.The original film had facets and layers. No characters were truly evil, none truly good. George Taylor was a cynic and a loner. There were aspects of adventure in the story, aspects of suspense, social commentary, comedy, all done in a subtle enough manner, with enough change in theatrical pacing to make it a classic that still stands up to repeated viewing today.The new film is "good guys vs. bad guys", there's the requisite central antagonist, Mr. Whalberg's sole motivation appears to be saving his pet chimp, and his only expression is a blank stare.Lines from the original film (there are two of them that I could tell) have been thrown in, and delivered with little context, and therefore not fitting into film. They serve as a reminder of the superiority of the first series.The marketeers have called this a 'reimagining' of the first film. Mr. Burton likes to 'reimagine' other people's work: Batman, Sleepy Hollow, Mars Attacks. His one good film was an affectionate (therefore, non-moneymaking)tribute to the "B" movie film-maker Ed Wood.Mr. Wood would be proud of this remake. Both Burton and Wood share an 'understanding' of SF, and this is a film that stands proudly and comparably with "Plan 9 From Outer Space". Congratulations Tim and Fox. Well done!!!!!

title: Is there a Part II Planet of the Apes for the year 2001 or beyond?
text: I have seen and greatly enjoyed the 2001 version of "The Planet of the Apes". At the end of the movie, Walburg goes forward in time whereby the Apes are now more educated in modern times. Was there a part II that was made starting where the movie left off at? If there was and I missed it, it should be on video, correct? if it is, can you tell me where it is being sold? The movie appeared to continue with General Thaed sitting within the memorial that Lincoln would normally sit. So this tells me that a Part II was made but I think I missed it. Mark Walberg took the space ship that his chimp landed with on the Planet of the Apes and took off back into outer space through the time cloud, then went into earths atmosphere, crashed landed on the Lincoln Memorial, and saw General Thaed as the father of the civil war. Really got to have the second part. I wish there were a part II. If not will there be one to come?

title: A Very Impressive Movie.
text: I've seen the original Planet Of The Apes and I think it's very good but this 'new updated version' is even better. Mark Wahlberg is brilliant as are the rest of the cast, including: Tim Roth, who plays a real baddie here, Helena Bonham Carter and Paul Giamatti and the little monkey who had a starring role here. The special effects and make-up are obviously amazing and *definitely* deserve an oscar nomination. The twist-ending was a little strange but it was really good and it looks as if they will make a sequel, which I'm more sure will be just as great. I give Planet Of The Apes a 10/10.

title: Worth a watch.
text: I have been reading many of the comments made here-in and I think that most of them are over the top. Obviously it can't be compared with the original movie but I am not going to go into great detail or attempting to analyse it. I just think that Tim Roth was brilliant.

title: A mixed bag of monkeys
text: Doggone it!  I went to see this movie hoping to keep out of my mind all recollection of the original 1968 movie.  Then this remake goes and quotes the original version again and again, in the clunkiest, most ham-fisted way! "Get your stinking paws off me, you damned dirty human!"  "Damn them all to hell!"  Feh!Actually, this movie wasn't all that bad.  It didn't stink to high heaven, which is as much as I seem to hope for in a movie these days.  The story (of which I will reveal nothing - I don't want to spoil it for anyone) is very good, with lots of nifty twists.  The Pride of Dorchester MA, Mark Wahlberg (remembered in Boston as Mahky Mahk), is quite good as the protagonist human.  On the down side, Paul Giamatti's human slave trader of an orangutan provided an irritating dose of little needed comic relief, and Helena Bonham Carter is surprisingly shallow, not showing any presence from under all that ape makeup.  (The same cannot be said of Tim Roth, who exudes much menace as the scary monkey of every little kid's nightmares.)Overall, I'd have to say a very good story was given a formulaic action-movie treatment with some very irritating moments, but not enough to ruin the movie entirely.  It helped, of course, that I saw this at a matinee, so I only had to cough up $5.  Given that, I'd say I got my money's worth.Rating: six stars on my Manos scale.

title: No plot, no dialogue, no drama, no darkness, bad ending
text: If you would like to see this movie, you may possibly be entertained. However, I was not. I saw this with two friends. After the movie one said, "Can anyone make a good movie anymore?" The other said, "I feel like I'm now dumber after watching this."To make a movie about talking monkeys work for me, it needs to be very, very dark. This one wasn't, so the frightening and suspenseful scenes become rather humorous. The plot is very simplistic, but that doesn't keep it from having many holes. The dialogue is either non-existent, pointless, or trying to sound cool and technical when it's not. Poor Estella Warren had about five lines in the whole movie. There are some points in the movie where they try to play some sub-plot drama points, but they do not play them up enough for us to understand their conclusions. The entire film lacks drama altogether. And the ending, namely, from when the fighting showdown starts until the credits, ruined what little the rest of the movie had to offer.Bright points would be the costumes. Not even the action sequences were bright. But costumes were very good. And the human-trading monkey provided some much-needed laughter.My advise is to please not waste your money and time.

title: Fun
text: I enjoyed it.  It had what it promised.  It had action, great makeup and a very villanous character.  Overall it was interesting and fun to watch. Grant it, it wasn't the best taht they could do with this movie but if you're looking for a fun action movie to watch then go see it.

title: APES is not so bad of a PLANET...
text:
PLANET OF THE APES: BThe plot of "Planet of the Apes" doesn't take much thought. Leo Davidson (Mark Wahlberg) crash lands on a distant planet run by ape people. They're scary, aggresive, and they hate humans. They inprision humans and make them slaves. But, Leo is the macho, egotistical type (a must for these kinds of movies). He breaks out along with the beauty Daena (Estalla Warren) with the help of ape Ari (Helena Bonham Carter). General Thade (Tim Roth, one scary looking dude) quickly finds out about this and doesn't take to it lightly. He gathers his whole army so they go searching for the humans. Attar (Michael Clarke Duncan) is humble assitant who is second in command.
For about 45 minutes of the movie it wasn't looking so good, because of the character of Leo and his cliché. The characters were kind of a problem. They were old and tired. Ari posses the most heart, though. Also, a love triangle emerges between Ari, Leo, and Daena.. Th film seems scared, though, to take on the subject of "inner-species" dating. It doesn't, until about the last 30 minutes, give us anything we've already seen before. Except great make-up. But the thing about it is, it's a lot of fun. I picked up the problems I listed above, but really didn't care. Tim Burton, personally, is my favorite director. He has yet to make a bad film. He has a certain style that is dark and ominous, Here, it is muddled and doesn't show up until about the last 30 minutes. You can sense it's there but it doesn't show up  until then.
"Planet" has one of the greatest endings of the year, which is the high point of the movie. It's also got some other neat twists in it along the way. So, despite it's many problem, "Planet" is an enjoyable, often funny, often scary, summer movie.Note: Pay attention to Danny Elfman's tremendous score. He had done most of Burton's films and each score is terrific. I don't feel he gets enough recognition, so I thought I'd mention it.

title: If you don't try to compare it to the original, you will enjoy it!
text: Being a big fan of the original Planet Of The Apes, I went to see this movie with some trepidation.  Fortunately for me, I found out beforehand that it was NOT a remake, but a re-interpretation of the original. Knowing this, you shouldn't expect many similarities between the original movie (other than a few lines), and this version. About the only thing really similar to the original is "Apes ruling humans." The similarities essentially stop there. I thought the makeup was superb, and Tim Roth's Gen. Thade was an outstanding nemesis to Mark Wahlberg's Capt. Leo Davidson. Michael Clarke Duncan was a GREAT Gorilla! I think that, as long as you don't try to compare it to the original, you will enjoy this movie.

title: Save your money!!!!
text: I don't know where Tim Burton gets his ideas to make a movie but somebody, someday should wake him up.  I could go on about the endless flaws in this movie but I just don't have the time.  I will touch base on a few to keep those interested in viewing it far from it.  In one instance, Captain Leo lands in a mud filled swamp on the Ape planet.  Sure enough when they show an underwater scene the water seems clearer than the Great Barrier Reef.  I paused the DVD to see if I could see Coral.  Another HUGE flaw is the fact that the Apes hate humans much like humans dislike wasps in cars. Funny thing is that the Apes live so much like us humans all the way down to their Versace clothes.   Like I said, I could go on and on but I will not.  This movie is awful!!!!  2 out of 10 stars.

title: Stick With The Original
text: There was absolutely NOTHING good about this movie. It was predictable, and cliche ridden. In the original, Heston's character could speak when no one else could....the suspense built waiting for him to speakout & show that he was more advanced than the other humans. In the remake, ALL the humans can speak, and there's nothing that differeniates Wahlberg's character from the others. The story was terrible, to say the least. People say "oh, but the special effects were great". Well that may be true, but don't you need a story to go along with it? Is this what the movie going public has become? And, is it too much to ask for some acting to be thrown in there, too? Lastly, where did that blonde get the lipstick she wore throughout the movie? I knew going into this film that it wouldn't hold water compared to the original, but this was just an all around bad movie.

title: Human See Human Do.......
text: There is a certain perception that is suggested when Tim Burton takes the helm of a movie. That perception is that you'll see something very different than the usual lint that's produced after good movies are tumbled about in the Hollywood dryer; with all their wrinkles removed, sickly pseudo fresh (like a Downey fabric sheet that touts it smells of `Fresh Rain' yeah right), and softened as not to cause chaffing. But Burton is different. Burton has vision. Burton is a visionary. I have uttered those words before in reference to his litany of twisted, incredibly clever and dark films. Burton's early shorts, Vincent and Frankenweenie, are things born of a mind and an eye that's capable of seeing the world through gray colored lenses. Pee-Wee's Big Adventure, Beetlejuice, Edward Scissor Hands, The Nightmare Before Christmas, Ed Wood, Batman, Mars Attacksevery one of these movies had that visionthat dig up the dirt up and put it under the light feel.Which is why then, with Planet of the Apes, I can claim as the only explanation for such appalling drivel is that Burton completely and utterly sold out for the lure of a `Big Budget Hollywood Summer Blockbuster'. Who better than Burton to `revisit' P of A (as Burton nearly screams in every interview that this is NOT a remake), one of the darkest and engaging sci-fi films made? But, here's the question: if this is not intended to be a remake, then why not cast that famous Burton vision on this piece and make it something more strange, moredare I sayhuman? Take Burton's other filmsthe hero is most often an odd, socially maladjusted, misunderstood, feared, decidedly melancholy, alone, scared and scarred, but somehow better than the lot of others around him. His characters, in their own eerie way, show the more benevolent side of human nature.So, then Mark Wahlberg's self-serving Leo in P of A is someone NOT from Burton's world. So, then the `plot' (and I use the word `plot' with hesitation) of P of A is also something not Burtonesque. Thus the whole experience is such a total let down that it makes one wonder if big budgets and high profile stars stifles anything creative as easily as a 40ft wet blanket thrown on a single lit match (enter into evidence America's Sweetheart). Burton usually strives on lancing the boil of our perceptions and getting to the raw under layer of culturesand P of A (the original was a hearty, if campy, examination and damnation of the snobbery of humans to dub ourselves as rulers of any planet) would seem to give Burton the chance to perform a wonderful social surgery.The gray colored glasses though were replace by the $green$ colored lenses, and so we are left with just another shell of a movie. The only vision Burton can see, for what are supposed to be genetically enhanced apes, is that they will emulate human social customsthey will form armies, they will have a senate, conduct dinner parties and sport Jackie O bobs; this is visionary? Hardly. In the end all we learn from Burton's P of A is the same thing we see in too many movies and the same thing we see in nearly every nook and cranny of the world; whoever can beat one's chest the loudest, whoever can physically beat the other side down, whoever has better weaponry will ultimately prevail. Burton had the chance to show a better wayinstead he merely aped his lesser peers and created another loud, ridiculously expensive and mindless testament to violence.

title: The Horror!
text: As a sci-fi fan (and a fan of the original movie) I was drawn to this remake. I had plenty of doubts after seeing the trailers, cast choices etc., but had hoped that Burton could do something interesting with it. Suffice it to say, I walked in with the "lowered expectations are best met outlook".My god, what a waste of time and money this was. Once in a long while my judgment lapses famously, Apes is the winner this time around. Never mind being true to the theme of the original, suspension of disbelief and such - this movie has no redeeming qualities that I can cite; casting and acting were poor, the story was bad beyond belief, and the visuals & effects were weak to laughable. I have enjoyed some of Burtons past flicks, but this effort seriously calls his talent into question.Save yourselves...

title: Nice planet, wonderful apes, threadbare film
text: Full marks for the art direction, and I'd like to give even more for costumes and make-up.  I find it hard to believe that this film, dreadful though it was overall, wasn't nominated for an Oscar in any of these categories, especially given some of the lacklustre work that WAS nominated, like "Amélie"? and "The Fellowship of the Ring".  And it's not as if any of the other art direction nominees are particularly dazzling, either.  But "Planet of the Apes" IS dazzling.  The world has its own intriguing version of everything, from tents to buckles to embossed armour designs, and the ape suits are so invisibly convincing we forget that there are human actors underneath even when we have a live chimpanzee as a point of comparison.Tim Burton began life as an animator and the best film he's had anything to do with ("The Nightmare Before Christmas") owes almost everything to his fantastic designs.  But, as is becoming increasingly clear, he rose to hislevel of incompetence when he became a director.  "Planet of the Apes" is superb visually, but in no other way.  And even to say that it's superb visually is misleading.  The climactic battle scene is wrong in almost every way it's possible for a climactic battle scene to be wrong: it's all confusing close-ups of characters whumping one another, with no overall design, or end, in sight - until the deus ex machina that we'd all seen coming an hour ago descends to bring the tedious violence to a merciful end.Burton clearly WANTS to be able to spin a gripping yarn.  Why else does he tell this particular story?  But he can't draw us close to any of the characters, he can't tell the difference between mushy cliché and invigorating simplicity (the "inspiring" dialogue manages to be banal without making any sense), and he can't take three paces without tripping over his own irony.  Irony?  More like flippancy.  Comments like "You can't solve the human problem by throwing money at it - we tried that, and all we got was a welfare state that nearly crippled us" are the work of screenwriters who live in terror of being caught out being sincere about something, who want to cover their tracks by suggesting that, not only don't they mean what they're saying, they don't mean anything.Anyone who doubts that Burton's film is flippant through and through will have their doubts dispelled by ending.  The original film is famous for the twist at the end - so famous, in fact, that that particular twist cannot be used again.  A pity, for it was a good one.  It made sense - more importantly, it made sense OF the earlier parts of the film - and it had a good deal of poetic force.  Burton decided to ditch poetic force and all that jazz in order to preserve the least essential aspect of the twist in the original - its shock value.  His ending is shocking, all right.  It makes no sense.  It's easy to shock if you're prepared to break off the narrative in mid-sentence and start talking nonsense.Mark Wahlberg is as unappealing as he ever has been, and it can't all be the script's fault.  He goes through the whole film without once dropping the belligerent expression of an ex-rapper who wants to maintain his "cred". And Estella Warren looks like one of those almost supernaturally unappealing models who grace the pages of the latest generation of men's magazines (Maxim, FHM, etc.), with computer-generated skin and computer-animated anatomy, dressed up as a cavegirl - not for the film, but for a photoshoot.P.S.:  What the hell did Burton mean when he said that this wasn't a remake, but a "re-imagining"?  What's the distinction?  I thought remakes WERE re-imaginings.

title: As Long As You Don't Compare it to the Original...
text: I'm going to say that I love the original. It's great. The sequels to it get a little strange, but the first one is wonderful. Now, this movie I rented to see with an open mind. I knew that they can hardly ever do better than the original when remaking a film, so they always get crap and do their best to compare.My advice: don't compare. Sit back, relax, and forget everything you know about the first one. You may just enjoy it. I must say, a plus from the original is that the people talk. But the whole kissing the ape was just wrong.Being a person who doesn't believe in evolution, I find I have to swallow my tongue while watching both the first one and this one. Leave your personal beliefs at the door, along with anything you know about the original, open your mind, and you may just like it.

title: Too noisy monkey business?
text: Franklin J. Schaffner's 1968 version of Pierre Boulle's novel was the first film I saw when I started my moviegoing career at 13, so rather inevitably it would take a lot for this new one to surpass my wonderful experience from then.Except for Tim Burton's film to be pacier and noisier, one of the important differences is the fact that the apes here are apier (e. g. swinging in the trees and so on), and the ape masks and costumes have become more flexible which altogether should add up to some improvement.On the other hand the incessant onslaught of computer-generated special effects unfortunately dwarfs the actors much of the time (especially Mark Wahlberg), and further the philosophical aspects and debating are toned down compared to the old version.All in all this was somewhat of a disappointment. Certainly not because Tim Burton has made an un-professional or amateurish movie, but because I cherish Schaffner's film more for sentimental reasons and not least for having a more adventurous feel and a narrative flow (and drive) that is missing here.A circumstance I hardly understand myself as Tim Burton's film is choke-full of great images, noise, action and commotion in general.

title: Upside down all over again
text: As in the original film, we are once again taken into an  upside down world. The film cleverly avoids imitating the original but at the same time makes amusing references to the original. The sly sense of humor extends to having Heston in ape makeup talking about the dangers of human ingenuity and cruelty -- as he refers to a human gun. I guess the current leader of the National Rifle Association has a sense of self-mocking humor after all.Tim Roth is excellent as a bad-guy who is one of the most  threatening villains since Dracula. The film is worth seeing just for his performance.The story is an interesting allegory about the injustice of human-animal relations as well as human-human inhumanity. Tim Burton seems to be having a field-day playing around with perspective, human-ape evolution arguments, and even space and time.It doesn't have the surprises of the original film, but that's only because it isn't the original. It does, however, deliver a good cynical and comic jolt at the end just as the original did.

title: worth repeat viewing
text: I went into this film with low expectations after being pretty disappointed by Mars Attacks and Sleepy Hollow. Also the facts that Mark Wahlberg was starring, and the film was still being edited just days before the release, I took as bad signs. However, I enjoyed the movie so much I went back to see it again two days later. My biggest complaint would probably be the inclusions of homages to the original films, as they were distracting from the new one. There seem to be a lot of people upset that the movie wasn't as "serious" as the originals, but how serious can you take a film with talking gorillas?? It's a fun science fiction film, and the cheesy one-liners, far fetched science, and comic relief were very enjoyable. Sort of like Burton's Batman or Beetlejuice. One thing though, if I hear Burton or any of his studio pals on TV or in print saying the word "re-imagining" again, I will probably vomit. The ending was great, and I am looking forward to the sequels as well as an extended DVD.

title: Tim Burton does it again...
text: ...that is, take an old "classic" and make it more faithful to the source material. From the same man, we've had a Batman who acts more like a real millionaire whose parents were murdered in front of him as a boy would, and a Sleepy Hollow that reads more like a Shakespeare play, highlighting as Washington Irving's original story does how badly this overrated poet's dialogues fail to reflect real human speech. In this new version of Planet Of The Apes, we get to see an air force pilot who behaves like an air force pilot, an ape civilisation that behaves like an ape civilisation, and a metaphor for the civil rights struggle that reads more like the X-Men feature film than the restrained, "don't want to upset the powers that be" style of the television series.I've read on this site that the film is simply rehashed in order to suit those with short attention spans. Not true. All through the film, one thinks of how a simple collection of apes from a research station could have evolved into almost-bipedial, talking ones with more distinctive personalities. The next few sentences may spoil any surprises, so those of you who have not seen the film yet can scroll past them at your leisure. One aspect of the film I found a bit disappointing is the fact that the original talking ape who is referred to as CMOS by his descendants is never fully explained. His origins and the reason he is called that are never really talked about, and I originally thought he would be the monkey that Wahlberg's character shot off into space in order to rescue. I must admit, however, that ending the battle between the humans and the apes by having said monkey land right in the middle of them was a fine touch. The metaphor for religion by showing that CMOS, this figure the apes worship for being the original free ape, got to start his own civilisation by murdering the humans who were originally caring for him, was an ingenious stroke. My only real complaint relates to the ending. I won't spoil it for those who haven't seen it yet, unlike some internet sites, but were I in this pilot's position, I honestly would have stayed. It's not every day that one gets a chance to help build a new civilisation with two very different races are just learning to work with each other. Compared to the planet Earth as it is today, and it shows no signs of ever getting better, it is a real paradise.Given all the displays in the film of appalling behaviour towards humans and each other by the apes, and how they resolve themselves, I think Tim Burton's reinterpretation manages to drive home a point that I seriously doubt the original films and television series would have been allowed to. The fact that not all racism is white-on-black seems a taboo subject in 2001, but one that this film handles metaphorically in an intelligent way. Give it a try without the prejudice of original Apes series fans to blinker you, and it may just surprise you. Encourage yourself to think of a better ending, though. Encourage yourself to think of all the different ways the apes could have evolved, in fact. This is not Planet Of The Apes Lite... it is Planet Of The Apes non-Disney style, something we need applied to more old "family-oriented" piles of cobblers.

title: Its Planet of the Apes, set for a new target audience.
text: Unfortunately I've seen a few bad reviews of this film floating about, at first i thought that this was because of the films somewhat confusing ending.  Now i see that people didn't get the idea behind the new film. The film IS a 're-imagining' or whatever you want to call it, and it is not a 're-make.'  If you go to the cinema expecting to see the original 'Planet of the Apes' only with different actors and better effects you will come away feeling disappointed, if you go expecting to see a Tim Burton film on a par with the likes of 'Sleepy Hollow' and 'Batman' and with different messages behind it you'll get what the film was trying to do.  This is a problem of any film trying to do something thats been done before, the film its self is lost in the comparisons, take 'The Phantom Menace' for example, if you hadn't of seen 'Star Wars' you'd probably thing it was a great film on its own.Long story short:  They've taken the original 'Planet of the Apes' and set it to a new target audience.  Take that into account when you see it and you'll see a truly great modern film.

title: A big rotten banana
text: This was one colossal waste of time.
