Some unbelievably goodmake-up (was that Tim Roth under that General Thade monkey-face?) and costumes (more cool leather outfits than amotorcycle jamboree) and art direction were thrown away on a plotthat could have been written by the proverbial 1 millionchimpanzees with typewriters and infinite time.  Wahlberg justdoesn't have the majesty of Heston in the original, and comesacross as a teenager locked in the monkey cage of the zoo afterdark.  Estella Warren may show someday that she can act, but youcould have placed any supermodel in her role (my vote is HeidiKlum...but I digress) and had no ill effect on the movie.  A puremoney grab for the spin-off ape dolls and the inevitable sequel.  Ijust got the impression that there were a lot more connectingscenes that were lopped off in the interests of time (let's hope so,anyway, otherwise Tim Burton's slipped on a major banana peel). The DVD may give us clues, but in the meantime, save this one forthe discount Tuesday...

title: A short
text: The idea that anyone would expect for this to be a complete remake is completely silly. In fact taking the basic idea and writing a whole new plot is nice. WARNING: This deals with the ending.  The story does take place on the Planet Earth. I don't think enough people got this. In the original "apes" Heston gets sent forwards in time which is the big "surprise ending". In the 2001 "apes" Burton has the clock forward to make you think they are following the old plot. In reality Mark goes back in time and the Station in following him gets sent even further back and populates the Earth with men and apes. Then when he goes back into the future he returns to a world that is the outcome of the man/ape war. This isn't a remake think of it more as a remix.

title: you have to do one thing to enjoy this movie
text: Do not think.I managed to forget all about how much I enjoyed the original movie - but that one never inspired me to think anyway.This movie hits you over the head with such rampant stupidity right from the start that you are forced to think about it. And once you start thinking, you will know after the first fifteen minutes exactly how the story will climax, so you may as well leave for an hour or so since it just gets worse (although you might want to stay just to see Charlton Heston actually giving up a gun), and come back for the last fifteen minutes just to see the non-surprise ending, since it is no surprise at all if you think about it - did you really expect them all to just get along? Then again I told you not to think if you really want to watch this movie, so you have been forewarned.

title: Very disappointing, but pretty, and isn't that all we can ask these days?
text: Planet of the Apes remake - it's not good. Too much dialogue that elicits groans, plot elements that don't make sense, poor acting, wooden dialogue, predictable "surprises" at the end. It's obvious that no one connected with this movie had much respect for the original series or for any intelligent member of the audience. On the plus side - the sets were fabulous, the ape costumes great. Some individual scenes were quite striking. Filmed in the dark, with the Dolby soundtrack cranked up to 11. See it in the theatre at matinee prices so you can get the full benefit of the special effects which is about all that is worth watching anyway.

title: where is the writing?
text: I have been disappointed to one extent or another all year long.  Usually, I pick one or two movies each year which go on my "buy the video" list.  Last year, it was "The Matrix."  This year so far, it's "Shrek."  What do these two have in common?  They were well written.  Good writing, when accompanied by good visuals and a good score, can make a movie great.  "The Matrix" and "Shrek" prove that people actually appreciate good writing.  Most of the reviews concerning "Planet of the Apes" complain about plot holes (bad writing), the ending (I liked the reviewer who revealed the clue Ape Lincoln---in fact, the ending may have been "forced" on the writer because of this pun, and now they have to make sense out of that pun by writing a sequel that explains it), uncreative face-offs / battle scenes, and character development.  I think this country is full of good writers, but they apparently only infrequently make it through the Hollywood meat grinder.I have to agree that "Planet of the Apes" suffers tremendously in the writing department.  I liked only three characters, Ari (a fine line between human compassion and simian behavior), General Thade (convincingly evil), and the human slave trader (a few good laughs).  These characters were minimally written, but at least they had character.  No other ape or human in the film was developed.  Estella Warren was totally devoid of any character, and did not exist in this plot for any reason.  She wasn't even good eye candy.At the very least, the movie should have ended after the chimpanzee in the pod removed his helmet before the ape masses, giving Burton more time to develop the characters from the beginning of the film up to this point.There are many points to make about how to write a good script.  One point is that a battle between two good characters is almost always more interesting than a battle between a good and evil one.  As a point of reference, think about the ending of "The Vikings," where Kirk Douglas and Tony Curtis battle to the death on a seaside castle.  You really care about both characters.  You don't want either one to die.  It's so much easier to play the "I want comeuppance" card than the "tragedy" card in a battle scene. In "The Vikings," it's not even brute force that determines the victor.I love science fiction, and my favorite is still "Aliens," which defies most sci-fi cliches in the sense that it's an action picture with good writing and a child who actually enhances rather than detracts from the film. However, "The Matrix" is on my top five list.  Hopefully, the Matrix sequels will be well written.In short, Hollywood needs to go back to basics and only film well written stories.  I'm sure there are thousands of average people out there who could do a better job (the reviews here prove there are a lot of good heads) writing a movie like this.  But the average person will never get a chance.So, if you go see "Planet of the Apes," do so for the visuals and a decent score.  Maybe that's enough for casual entertainment.  But it won't stir any activity in your brain (unless you write movie reviews afterward!).

title: Could have been much better
text: This COULD have been one of the best movies of the year. But alas, twas not. As soon as he crash-lands the story goes badly downhill and never really seems to get going again. I would recommend this film to anyway who always likes to know what is going to happen in the next 10-30 minutes every 10-30 minutes. Make up and effects are as you would expect, superb. Also Estella Warren plays the part of a "wild" slave girl brilliantly and the guy who plays Thade...well. Nothing short of brilliance in a all round not too good film. You'll be sitting on the edge of your seat throughout the entire film (bearing in mind the point of this is to fall off and get concussion so you DONT have to see the whole film) and as one last piece of advice. Leave 5 minutes before the end of the film. It's too obvious anyway and it's down right confusing unless you happen to follow the whole film. Overall, not too good, but had the potential to be a hit. Shame really considering all the originals were masterpieces...

title: Yawn
text: This should not have been billed as an action/adventure movie because it wasn't. It was a long running drama that was only saved by the ending.  I don't recommend this movie. It was okay.  Just okay, not great, not amazing, just average.

title: Yeesh, what a bad, bad movie
text: Tim Burton didn't put one ounce of imagination or creativity into thislong, dull film.In fact, he stole ideas and characters from more films than it ispossible to mention.  He's like a music writer who patchestogether everything from a 2-bar phrase to a 16-bar phrase from50 different oldies to "create a new song."Just for example, though, let me mention a few.  He stole frommovies spanning the spectrum from The 10 Commandments (ironically not the Charleton Heston part, the Edward G. Robinsonpart), to The Time Machine, to Star Wars.  And along the way heeven swiped bits from The Wild Geese, Andrew V. McLaglen's1978 film and Red Dawn, John Milius's 1984 film.  I can't imaginehe admires either film, but he wasn't above pilfering from them.Oh, yeah.  Jai-alai cestas?And of course he stole the whole "shocking" ending.

title: Apes take over control
text: I can´t remember the original movie (although I´ve seen it years ago) but this one really wasn´t a big hit. If you wanna see a long movie about the question what would have happened if apes ruled your neighborhood or you already have a monkey as a pet then I suggest you should have a look, otherwise watch a movie with more human actors instead.

title: Very Entertaining
text: This was a very good re-imagining of the 1969 classic. I went to the theater with high expectations (because, let's face it, it's Tim Burton), and this movie struck a cord with me, because it is my favorite Sci-Fi film in the last decade and a half, the movie was 'Aliens'.Mark Wahlberg did a very good job as the lost Capt. Leo Davidson, but my hat goes off to General Thade himself, Tim Roth. He was *excellent* as the sadistic, human loathing primate villain. Michael Clark Duncan also was perfect support as Thade's brutish right hand man, Colonel Attar.Every one who was an ape did an excellent job at moving like actual primates. The score kept you with the flow of the movie, the choreography was marvelous, and the acting was good. The action sequences were very intense, and the chase between the humans and Thade's Army was very suspenseful. There was an outstanding surprise to the end of this movie, it was very unexpected. I recommend this movie to any one who wants an exciting, special effects adventure, but this movie also has a very surprise end, good acting, and a great plot.        Do not compare this to the original, because the only thing connects them is a title. Also, Charlton Heston made a pleasing cameo as Thade's father, and blurts out the most famous quote in sci-fi movie history! If you have a choice between this, and Jurassic Park 3, pick this, because this has excitement AND brains. 9/10

title: The Planet has been Ruled!!!
text: Many emotions struck me while watching one of the summer's most anticipated films Planet of the Apes'. Yet, the emotion that struck me the most was that of ingenuity. Director Tim Burton proves himself as an ingenious filmmaker and he proves it twofold in this exciting, inventive and thrilling film. The sets are spectacular, costumes are terrific and Danny Elfman's musical score captures the essence of the film as he does with all his musical compositions for Burton's films. The producers of the film have stressed that this is not a remake, but more so a revisiting' of the original. Anyone who compares this film to the original is gravely mistaken due to the mere fact that the 2001 version has been dichotomized by one of the soon to be' legendary alternative filmmakers - Tim Burton. This film widely separates itself from the original as seen from its' first frame and takes off on a whole new different direction. The film opens with a great credit intro. sequence displaying Danny Elfman's fierce musical score which sets the film's tone not as an unrealistic fantasy, but as a rousing sci-fi/adventure. The opening scene depicts Wahlberg's ill-fated space station attempt at conducting test runs with the ape species. After a mishap forces him off the ship, Wahlberg's character Leo Davidson finds himself crash landing on a distant planet ruled by apes.  This is where the fun begins Director Tim Burton puts a classic spin in this film invoking the notion of role reversal. In this planet, humans are the pets, the slaves, in essence humans on that planet are all the things we as humans on this planet earth shape and torture our inferiors to be. A great scene is one of the very first that immediately displays the intelligence of these iron fist creatures conversing around the dinner table about the threat of the human species. Enter this year's ultimate movie villain  General Thade. The incredibly underestimated and unrecognizable Tim Roth plays this overachieving ape villain who is hell-bent on the total annihilation of all humans with fierce audacity and destruction. Upon the dissection of this film as a cinematic lesson, one will discover many plot holes' - (Did Leo Davidson and Ari, his rebellious ape escort have a love affair?) Many more plot holes -  (Did Leo Davidson and Estella Warren's human rebel Daena also have an affair?). Mysterious deaths not explained - (Why exactly did one character so unexpectedly sacrifice himself for the sake of others and the rest of pack continue on as if nothing happened?) These mind-benders as well as others will occupy the intelligent filmgoer's mind for quite some time after the film.Yet, these questions can all be put to rest because Burton does not set out to win awards with this film (Except for Best Make-Up come Oscar time for Rick Baker). This film is merely a means of the best of the popcorn blockbusters' this summer. As well, we see Burton's maturity as a Director in relation to the grandeur of a film. Let's face it  the revisiting of the classic apes' films is a huge undertaking. And for Tim Burton to create and present a richly satisfying, fun film is quite the achievement. Anyone who expects a brash film course should not watch this film. This film wants the audience to have fun and to dwell into a world never seen before in this uniqueness. Therefore in this sense, the film scores some big points in terms of imagination and vision.  The film makes it a point of paying homage' to the originals yet distancing it enough so it is not afraid to make fun of itself. Furthermore, despite its surreal qualities, fantastic set pieces and incredibly true to life ape creatures brought to life by a wonderful cast, the film's major drawback is that it seems too dark and animalistic for its' own good. We are all aware that Burton's visionary uniqueness is brought forward with dark sets and spooky visions. Yet, it seems as if Burton intentionally wants us to know this is his creation even when we are entangled within the film, resulting in the darkness and primal aesthetic being overused. But in an odd way this is what adds to the genius and excellence of it all. Resulting in this film easily regarded as one of Burton's best films.Giancarlo's Rating: ***

title: The late Rod Serling would be proud of this ending created by Tim Burton....
text: What is all the buzz about the ending to this movie?!?  I almost fell for all of the bashing that you IMDB fan-critics were saying about the ending to this movie. Luckily I watched it for myself. Whew!!!! What a creepy ending!!! I walked out of the theater thinking about it.  It kind of gave me that eerie feeling like the end of the Blair Witch Project. I think Tim Burton took the right direction in going this route with the ending.  When I thought about it it made sense to catch us off guard with this version to the end.  I mean if you saw the original Planet Of The Apes you already knew what to expect for the remake but Burton fooled us all and I think some of you fan-critics do not like being catched off guard like that. Despite the fact the battle at the end was stop short due to a "MONKEY" arrival and despite the fact that Estella Warren was the only "female human" that looked like she had access to a hair stlylest and a makeup person this movie was AWESOME.  You know whats scary....after watching Sleepy Hollow and Planet Of The Apes, Tim Burton is starting to grow on me. Damn!!! I never thought I would say that....

title: On second thoughts...
text: Maybe I don't enjoy this film more than I would enjoy the original Planet Of The Apes films, or even the television series, but Tim Burton's recreation of them has gotten a pretty raw deal, all the same. People scream that the makeup effects weren't well done. Well, what do you expect from an attempt to synthesise human faces with ape bodies? I felt they were done just the right way... such that they looked like apes but the actors were still recognisable.Tim Burton's deft touch in the set design and photography lends his usual dark edge to the film, making it far more grown-up in appearance than the pastel-like sequels to the original Planet Of The Apes, especially the television series. Everything looks a lot more believeable, and the sets appear much more functional. The Omeron looks much more like a deep-space research station, and the flight pods look more like they were designed for their purpose.Mark Wahlberg is good as a caring human being, and I really believed in his compassion for the monkey, but he doesn't quite possess that leader quality. I think it would have been better if he'd been supported by one or two more humans from the space station. The ending, such as it is, had me a little perplexed too. Here is a man standing on the verge of a brave new world where men and other members of the animal kingdom can be educated to work together in harmony, he has a beautiful woman who wants him, and he decides to go home. Sorry, I just couldn't buy that, but then, it's pretty plain to me that the Earth of 2001 just sucks.Still, with all the barbs about inter-species arrogance, reverse racism, and the origins of cults, Planet Of The Apes is one film that should be given a fairer hearing. Maybe the critics of today just need to put down their Bibles, their filmmaking guides, and their prejudices towards old, outmoded special effects, and just lighten the hell up.

title: A horrible ending to an otherwise great movie.
text: The movie was very cleverly done up until the last 3 minutes.  After that I wish I had walked out of the theatre.  The ending is so bad it makes the film look like a masterpiece that is crossed with Battlefield Earth.

title: you think you're better than me...and you probably are!
text: Uhoh, big surprise...a big special effects movie with a stupid plot caused by misbudgeting (i.e - $50000000000000000000 dollars spent on special effects, and then they paid the writer in tuna sandwiches which he quickly devoured before returning to his cardboard-box home) see: Godzilla, Batman & Robin, Practically every Sci-Fi movie since Return of the Jedi. Mark Wahlberg was horrible (another big surprise...not!) the average door-to-door vaccum salesman would have been a better choice. Helena Bonham Carter (disguised by thick layers of polyurethane and "you can see all their mistakes on every close-up shot" make-up) was the only one who played their part well. She seemed oddly out of place, but made the movie a little more watchable. The ending was so absurdly stupid it gives me an aneurysm every time I try to think about it. The genius of it is: It's stupid on every conceivable level. It doesn't matter if you're Steven Speilberg or Steven Jones (the 80 year old crazy looking janitor at Homeland), you're simply un-able to like the ending at all. What's really sad is that this could have been a "good" movie. Wahlberg sub-par acting skills could have been overlooked if they just didn't add all the stupid scenes. If you choose to inflict this movie upon yourself then you'll know what I'm talking about. Certain things just didn't need to be there. Estella Warren, for instance. Her character did nothing of relevance at all. There was no romance between her and Wahlberg, she only had a few lines, but you could tell that they were trying to give the impression of romance, but it didn't work at all. And, despite the fact that she has lived her entire life in a desert wilderness being captured by Apes and forced to do slave-labor, and then escape, her lip-stick never fades! It's amazing! It seemed like a really "americanized" film though, all the way. But, if about 20 minutes of the film was cut (including, most-importantly, the retard ending) then I would give it like a 7 out of 10. But as is I'd have to give it a 7 out of 100

title: A disappointment
text:
I really wanted to like this movie. It was very unfortunate that I did not. This isn't to say that there aren't good qualities, because this film does have wonderful moments. The parts, though, are greater than the whole.
The main problem, as I see it, was trying to recreate the original Planet of the Apes in the first place. The original was released at the peak of the civil rights movement, and it's message of tolerance and understanding had much more meaning back then. Now, without any social relevance to justify it, the film comes off as nothing more than a loud, disposable summer flick. Of course, if anyone could even come close to making a good POTA remake, it'd be Tim Burton. His vision of the apes' world is incredible, and he comes very close to making the film work. The makeup effects by Rick Baker are also an impressive achievement, but, once again, it played better in the original because it was new. Another thing that made the first one so brilliant was the clear social distinction between ape and man. The film made the humans appear inferior through one very obvious, but effective, manner: it took away the humans' speech abilities. This made them more animal like, and it made Charlton Heston's character more relevant. But in this new version, the humans can speak, which makes their inferiority to the apes unclear. Physically,  the apes are much stronger than the humans, but the humans out number the apes 4 to 1. And the new hero, played by Mark Wahlberg, has no clear attribute to make him stand out to the benevolent "human rights activist" Ari. She notices him for a somewhat creepy sexual attraction. The most disappointing thing about this new version, though, was the ending. I won't give it away,because it was a surprise, but I was very let down. It unsuccessfully tried to recreate the startling final shot of the original, but without the aspect of suspense the whole epilogue seemed forced and sloppy, not to mention ludicrous. On the bright side, there is the aforementioned Burton and Baker, some welcome (but slightly misguided) comic relief, and a sexy human heroine in Estella Warren, who has an incredible body but a very sketchily defined character. Overall, I can't honestly recommend it to fans of the classic original, but non-discriminatory summer audiences may enjoy it.

title: Great Production values, but cheap-shot ending
text: It must be our species' somewhat perverse curiosity that'll make this remake, or as they say in their publicity material, "re-imagining," one of the summer's boffo hits.  I am not big on science-fiction, but indeed, I was very curious to see Tim Burton's darker version of an already dark story. For the most part, the film holds up since Burton gives it a lot more intensity than the original.  However, notwithstanding everything, including Mark Wahlberg's lightweight performance, the much debated ending is a cop-out; a cheap shot of Hollywood's creative bankruptcy.  It just doesn't make sense, and isn't worth debating about because it is shot thru w/ holes. Why they didn't end earlier, with Leo just leaving the planet, is beyond me.

title: Weak plot, mediocre acting and incoherent fight scenes. A disappointment
text: This remake should never have been attempted. Tim Burton gives the film a distinct look but forgets completely about the plot. The story is weak and the jokes mostly fall flat. Mark Wahlberg looks lost in the lead. He lacks Charlton Heston's personality and intensity. The fight scenes are incoherent but slick. The final battle's resolution feels like a cheat. To make matters worse, there's an unnecessary epilogue which left me shaking my head. This is probably a case of being too clever by half. The film is better avoided. See it if you must with a finger on the FF button! Overall 3/10

title: this movie hurts
text:
I'll cut right to the chase: This movie was really stupid.  No, worse than stupid, so far beyond stupid I can't even use real words to describe how stupid it was.  It was Uberstupid.The story is no secret.  Even if you've never seen the ultra-cheesed-out original you know that an astronaut lands on a planet inhabited by a bunch of smart monkeys, and doesn't like being pushed around.  As a kid I remember reading the "Apes" comic books with the little 45's in the back, and those left an indelible mark on my brain: images of aggressive monkeys dressed in hip 60s-style war togas; atomic bomb-worshipping men; general world destruction.  And of course I remember the evil Dr. Zaius.The new "re-imagined" "Planet of the Apes" left mental scars as well -- not scary or thought-provoking scars -- just plain old scars, like when you fall off a jungle gym or something.  We begin our uberstupid-ness on a space station somewhere near Saturn, where some scientists/astronauts/people-in-white-clothing are training monkeys for solo space flights.  Leo Davidson (Mark Wahlberg) likes the primates enough but he wants a shot at flying for himself.  When an electromagnetic (aka "time-travel") storm comes too close to the station, Leo decides to rescue a monkey that's already been lost in the static.  He (of course) encounters some bright lights and big booms, and ends up crashing on a nearby planet.As soon as he arrives, Leo realizes that things are a little off. He, along with hundreds of other humans, are kept in cages by walking and talking apes who want to trade them or kill them or brand them, or all three.  But Ari (Helena Bonham Carter), the daughter of the Apes' political leader (and who bears an eery resemblance to post-surgical Michael Jackson), doesn't think humans should be abused and caged. Leo convinces her to purchase him from slave-trader Limbo (the hilarious Paul Giamatti) as a house-servant.  Ari also buys Daena (Estelle Warren), the fiesty daughter of Kris Kristofferson who has a thing for Leo and dresses like Raquel Welch in "One Million Years B.C."
Leo and Daena end up working as caterers at Ari's father's dinner party.  Guests include a snooty orangutan, a vicious gorilla named Colonel Attar (Michael Clark Duncan), and General Thade (Tim Roth), a Danny Devito-like chimpanzee who compensates for his short stature by growling at everything and jumping around a lot.  When Thade's not wheezing like an asthmatic Jack Palance, he's trying to win over Ari, who's not really impressed with his Alpha-Male routine.  She'd rather mate with the heroic yet sensitive spaceman, who returns Ari's longing glances and finds beauty in her ability to write with her feet. But Leo also yearns for Daena for some reason.  An odd interspecies love triangle ensues.Anyway, impatient Leo is anxious to get back to his ship, so he easily escapes from the ape city, taking Daena, Ari, Ari's gorilla bodyguard, and a few other stragglers with him.  They travel over jungle and desert on their way to Calima, an ancient ruin that holds the secrets to the Apes' origins (gee, what could they be?).  When we discover why the place is called "Calima" I have to wonder how stupid these apes really are.Thade and his army march to Calima to have it out with that pesky astronaut once and for all, and then some other stuff happens that will either confuse you or disappoint you.  Or both.  Characters seen only briefly until now suddenly take presidence, only to disappear again.The ending is just as random.The monkey actors are generally decent, but are held back from being great by mumbling incoherently beneath rubber masks and waddling around like, well, like monkeys.  The humans ain't that great either. Everyone is this movie just needed to shut up.  Every time someone opened their mouth I rolled my eyes and prayed it wasn't yet another line taken from the original movie thrown into a new and supposedly funny context.I don't know why this ended up being so bad.  Tim Burton is a fabulous director who's brought marvelous vision to the screen before he wasted his time with this disjointed and sloppily-directed project. The "Planet of the Apes" story is a microcosm of racism and classism and how opposable thumbs are the coolest by far, that sort of thing. The new movie is a microcosm of stupidity.  It's like that really obnoxious friend we all have that's hyperactive, vain, loud, and a lot less funny than s/he thinks.  The comic book had all but one human lobotomized or mute, leaving that one desperate guy with no other choice but to escape and find his ship again.  The apes were also a lot more scientific and a lot less animalistic, which in itself is quite frightening. But aside from the screeching and howling and Thade's ultra-hip armor, the apes in the new version aren't even all that scary.  There's nothing left to Burton's story but broad strokes of one-dimensional characters who just happen to be in the same place at the same time.  Just when it seems there will be the slightest bit of depth to anything, it vanishes like Charlton Heston's cameo.Grades for "Planet of the Apes":action: C plot: D acting: C- special effects: B- overall: D+/C-

title: But were any humans harmed in the making of this film?
text: I get suspicious when the director pumps up the audio, darkens the set and puts elaborate monkey suits on the actors. Oops, sorry I meant Ape costumes. If the Naked Apes in this film learned anything from the 1968 edition, they certainly forgot to include it. Except of course voting Charlton Heston to his rightful species. The story is decent sci-fi integrating humans, simians and robotics while taking the original story beyond the basics to challenge your imagination. The dialog though was uninspired with all the tired stereotypes with an ape/human twist. Like we haven't seen the original and endured the ironies the first time 'round. Go to see this film for the effects, the costumes, and soundtrack - with earplugs. Some one higher up the evolutionary ladder should have been tapped to write the screenplay.CyCy

title: Nothing To Go Ape Over
text: I normally wouldn't write a comment on a film unless I had something good to say about it.  Planet of the Apes had many good possibilities.  I was expecting to see a movie with political statements about humans and apes co-habiting a planet and the struggle to gain equality as an analogy to animal rights and civil rights struggles in the modern world.  Why I ever expected anything more than what this movie really is, is because I had faith in Tim Burton to remake and give new birth to an older conception.  I feel that the audience was robbed.  Tim Burton has made nothing but a summer blockbuster. Just about everything about this movie was down right horrible.  Why a brilliant actress like Bonham Carter would have signed on to a film like this is inscrutable.  There were points in this movie where it had potential. Perhaps a longer look at the lifestyles of the evolved apes in the city, or even an examination of the scattered human villagers and their daily lives would have proved worthwhile.  This would have given Burton more leverage to work in some of his normally fascinating set designs.  However most of the scenery looks like a 30x30 set of plastic plants.  The make-up of the apes was impressive, but this does not make up for the lack of story-line, development, dialogue or plain ol logic.  Any promising political ideal introduced is later destroyed by unexplained actions of apes or humans. The characters are 2 dimensional. they are cliché characteristics of any action movie villain, hero, damsel, and comrade. Although it seems like the actors put in quite an effort with nothing to work with. This movie could have easily been made by the likes of John Mcteirnan or James Cameron. Maybe I have given Tim Burton too much credit, or anticipated way too much out of his capabilities.  Really when you consider it Burton has made very few satisfying films.  Much with the help of Johnny Depp, Ed Wood, Edward Scissorshands,  even Nightmare Before Christmas.  With all of these notable films audiences  have gotten many more disappointments, Mars Attacks, Batman Returns, and now Planet Of The Apes.  Maybe Burton's next effort will heal these open wounds.  I hate to see a genius such as Burton sell out his artistic vision.

title: This is not a good movie!
text: Everything that was good about the original is gone from this movie, Wahlberg is terrible, the story limps along from set piece to set piece and Tim Burton seems to have decided to concentrate on making an action movie. Some of the ape make-up was incredible but I thought Helena Bonham Carters make-up was awful with its painted on eyebrows and lipgloss! The ending of the original was perfect and made up for any deficiencies in the rest of the film but this movie has a typical Hollywood happy ending with a contrived twist bolted on to the end as a nod to the original. I did want to enjoy the movie but I was just glad when it was over!

title: The Evolution of the Ape...
text: Those of you who watched this version of that 1960s sci-fi classic about intelligent simians on a mysterious planet having dominion over mankind in the distant future were probably in for a little surprise (assuming you've seen the original).I would have to say that this latest film incarnation by Tim Burton is not at all a remake, but rather a retelling of the apes story from a perspective of pure fanfare and entertainment.  Yes, there were several references throughout the movie on the morality of treating fellow humans, apes or any walking-and-talking being alike with respect and contempt.  But there is a difference between this year's version and the original classic starring Charlton Heston.In 1968, the original `Planet of the Apes' revolutionized the sci-fi genre through its shocking image of mankind's future on the Planet Earth.  Of how an inferior species such as the apes could grow in power and intelligence to rule over humans, largely because mankind itself had used weapons of mass destruction on each other, therefore contributing to a series of events leading to ape domination.  Because the 1960s were such a turbulent time both politically and socially for the American people, the youth could especially empathize with the film's antiwar message.  I'm sure no baby boomer will ever forget the gut-wrenching conclusion of Heston pounding his fists on the beach sands and damning all of humanity to hell after feasting his eyes upon a half-buried Statue of Liberty.  Such scenes reflected the frightening times of the Cold War and Vietnam War, both looming as a shadow over the U.S. and other countries during that decade, and the whole movie itself directly reflected the mood of the times.Burton's version is quite a departure since it focuses on simple adventure entertainment and stunning visuals rather than any symbolic metaphor on the dangers of a worldwide engagement in nuclear war, or for that matter, any epidemic.  Instead of Planet Earth being the venue, Burton seems to have taken us to another world in another galaxy, therefore giving us a fresh take on the apes story.  At least this time around, the human slaves have the ability to talk.  I will never forget such scenes as Mark Wahlberg's pet chimpanzee landing in his space capsule from the sky during the climax of the ape-human battle.  These and other highlights made `Planet of the Apes' the escapist formula it deserves to be.  There are many inside dialogue references to the original `Apes' film, but I suggest you go see that version first in order to catch them all here.The movie is also blessed with a bunch of gifted performers.  Mark Wahlberg is OK as the chief protagonist.  But Tim Roth practically steals every scene he is in as the villainous ape general Thade.  With his experience as a stage actor, Roth magnificently portrays an enemy who is thoroughly corrupt and demonic with no hint of remorse.  Helena Bonham Carter provides an example of simian benevolence through her open-minded chimpanzee character. And Michael Clarke Duncan, being the huge man that he is, is at times terrifying as a gorilla commander.  Oh, and yes, keep an eye out for cameo appearances by Heston and Linda Harrison, stars from the original `Apes' movie.One common element between the two versions of `Planet of the Apes' is that both have a shocking finale, but for those who have not seen either, I will go as far as that!  For sheer pleasure, I rate this 8/10.

title: Planet of the Apes never really knows what it wants it does have a spectacular ending though
text: This is a tough movie to review.  In its defense, the movie has a charm that I can't resist.  The special effects, while nothing to write home about, are good.  The makeup effects are brilliant.  The story is interesting and involving.  But overall, the movie seems a little undercooked.That is a weird feeling to have in a Tim Burtin movie.  His movies are filled with gorgeous and unusual visuals, unusual characters, and flat-out different ideas.  But this "re-imagining" of Planet of the Apes does not seem like a Burtin movie.  It does not have crazy visuals, interesting characters, or anything unusual.  The movie is dry as it can be.  It's filled with crap dialog.  The actors look like apes, but when they speak it sounds like they have a cold (due to the large amount of makeup, but it could have been fixed with dubbing or something).I think that the movie had a large amount of potential, but it was not left in the oven for long enough.  Fox really rushed this movie and it shows. Not in the special effects, but in the story.Not all of the dialog is bad.  There are some nice punches here and there. But the over all script seems rushed.The characters flat out suck.  I'm sorry, but they do.  Especially the astronaut Leo played by Mark Wahlberg.  His character never seems shocked or amazed at this planet full of apes.  There is a moment of adjustment, but he gets used to it too quickly.  If some one dropped me on a planet full of apes, I would freak out and I think most other people would too.  Honostly, his character is rather boring and not interesting.  The only good characters are Ari (Helena Bonham Carter) the ape that has a soft side for humans, Limbo (Paul Giamatti) an ape slave trader, and possibly Attar (Michael Clark Duncan) an ape soldier.  But everyone else just seems, well, boring.One real gripe I have is with Tim Roth who plays the ape general Thade.  He does a good job, but he breaths real heavily and it gets annoying.  He tries to act like a total "Evil monster" but it would have been better had they just made him into a more emotional guy.  It's fine that they made him into a fearless psychopath, but it would have made the beginning moments (where Thade talks about his love for Ari) more believable.The best part of the movie is the fabulous, Twilight Zone ending that I would never dream of giving away.Over all, the movie seems lackluster and, well, boring.  It's not a bad movie, but I think had they had more time to work on it, it could have been truly great.  I liked the first movie a great deal, but I really wasn't looking forward to this too much.  I guess I sort of sensed it would be this way.  It is worth seeing, but it still lacks a narrative force that makes me want to see it again.  It's sad that they didn't take more time with this, because it had GREAT potential.  Oh well, it's still better than most of the crap that's out.  Except AI.  AI is still the best movie of the year, in my opinion.  Don't bring the kids.6/10

title: Enough of "retro-lovers"
text: Well, i just have to say one thing. This movie is really good, and, WE FEEL the movie...the only problem is this: don`t try to compare ot with the originals. Let that "retro-stuff" out of your mind.Tim Burton is great, even Wahlberg acts really good. 2 fingers up for the Ari`s and Tim Roth`s facial expressions....the sounds are great...

title: A GOOD MOVIE RENTAL.
text: I paid $8.50 to watch this sad remake and TIM ROTH (General Thade) had been the only worthwhile thing in it. The other characters were disappointing and shallow. So what if the slave trader guy was FUNNY?!? The special effects were NICE, but that was to be expected. Marky Mark's character made me angry throughout the entire movie. I wish his character had died.

title: Disappointing movie, could have benefitted from better editing.
text: I can't stand movies where the characters are stupid.  The new Planet of the Apes immediately got off on the wrong foot with me when in the first few minutes of the movie Leo Davidson (Mark Wahlberg) disobeys his commanding officer and takes a pod cruiser from the station.  It's stupid and it makes no sense.  The script writers could have come up with a dozen better ways to get him out into the storm in the pod.  It just makes the characters unbelievable from the start.Once we're down on the planet, things move along, but we don't seem to make any real progress in character development.  Why does Ari (Helena Bonham-Carter) care so much for the humans?  What's with Karubi (Kris Kristofferson)?  He shows up, but the character never develops.  Daena (Estella Warren) is easy on the eyes, but contributes little else. Ultimately I didn't really care all that much about these people.  There was no outpouring of sympathy from the audience when any of the characters died. That's because no one cared.I could possibly accept the complete lack of characterization if this were an action flick.  It failed there also.  The climactic fight sequence needs re-editing.  The climax was incredibly slow moving.  The pacing during the climax was all wrong.  For no apparent reason, this kid that we barely see and know nothing about (Birn, played by Luke Eberl) is all over this sequence.  Why?  Please, cut him, or at least make us care about him.  The climax needs to be tightened up a lot.Leo also manages to reinforce his stupidity with his plan (or lack thereof) for the climactic battle sequence.  Why blow your one big shot on the initial charge?  Why not come up with a plan that take advantage of your enemies obsession to make a bigger dent in the attacking army?  I like movies where the characters are smart or clever, again the characters just stumble along here with barely a semblance of a plan.  (Leo's escape sequence earlier in the movie suffers from the same problems.  He gets away, but it's mostly dumb luck.)The conversion of Attar (Michael Clarke Duncan) is also just not believable.All of this could have been fixed with a better script and better editing. Perhaps what disappointed me most was that you could see a good movie stuck behind this mess.  I can't help but feel that with just a little more work on the script and with better editing this could have been a good movie.

title: Great movie
text: I just saw this movie and i can tell you that is really great!, all in burton bizarre view of the original.First you must stop comparing Cheston (in a cameo btw) whit Wahlberg, they are diferent, and if any of you read any burton´s commentary he sad that he never try to top the original, he only wants to praise it. The make up is top noch, and thank god burton hates to make any overkill CGI efects, that plagues many of new Hollywood "super productions" And for all of the people crying about that humans "did talk" heres Burton´s view of it:second striking difference in the re-imagined APES is the fact that the planet's homo sapiens can actually talk. If you recall, the original portrayed humans more as animals (much like how apes are seen today), hunted and caged for sport by intelligent (almost human) apes. In Burton's film, the dichotomy between the two species presents a truer political allegory  a more spot-on metaphor for socialComing to this planet [at this point in] its evolution where the apes are still retaining some of their primal instincts, even if they're at odds with themselves  you have some apes that are kind of moving more humanesque, you've got apes that are wanting to maintain their apedom and you've got people who still talk. Eventually, the history of this planet will probably go the way [of the original], but the human's self-esteem is still being beaten out of them at this stage.'My complains? yes how the hell Estella Waren keeps a incredible make up all the movie, please!!! make it ugly and dirty, even few scars heeheSimply the best of this summer, and i really love the ala Twiligth Zone ending!!!

title: Absurdist Fare
text: My only real comment is...If you are going to spend all that money and time on make-up and sets, why do you not allow a chance for the audience to appreciate them by running the camera past every scene at 100 miles per hour?As absurd as this movie was, I enjoyed it. Kind of sad that the rest of the audience I was with didn't get all the jokes...

title: Damn them,damn them all to hell!!!
text: Well, I can't damn them ALL to hell. Some of the movie was really good. But most of it just didn't work. Let's get to it. 1. The Good; The Make-Up; There are only two words to describe Rick Baker's make-up: In-genious. The guy has always been the best and now he has surpassed even himself. His ape-make-up is flawless. Even apes with a short amount of screen time have amazing detail and individuality in their features. Baker easily has an Academy Award coming for his work here. The Acting; The Best Actors wore the most make-up. Everyone in an ape suit busted their butt and delivered first rate performances. Maybe they had to work harder to overcome wearing tons of make-up, maybe I just credit them with good acting because they were wearing all that make-up, all I know is that the made up actors were more expressive and convincing than the barefaced actors. 2. The Bad. They cut out it's brain, those bloody baboons! Sorry, I coudn't resist. That's a line from the original movie. It gets the point across. All the great satire that the original possessed is gone,cut out, eliminated. The book was mostly social satire and the original movie was pretty true to that. But not this one. It flirts with satire,it dabbles in it,it buys a ticket to the game but never gets into the same ballpark as the original movie as far as the satire and social commentary. It's watered down. I know they were excpecting lots of kids to flock to this flick, but I think the apes brutality was really underplayed. I'm not even talking about violence , much of which occurred off screen. Except for Thade and the profiteer Limbo, the apes weren't all that nasty to the humans. There is even an Animal Rights group that supports Human Rights. I never felt the overwhelming,oppressing menace that I felt with the original movie. Also, when the two big silverbacks locked up for their Big Fight, it was so anti-climactic. I expected fur and blood to fly when the arch-rivals met, instead I saw a slap fight between two mincing flight attendants. The Acting; Amazingly, all the actors without make-up were about as emotive as a wooden bedpost. There was no need for the humans to talk in this version, none of them said anything worth hearing. That's it. I hate, and I mean I really hate to say it but the "Making of.." video is a better time

title: Good? Err, I don't know
text: This is a difficult movie to rate. As a stand-alone I guess it is quite alright. When compared to the original, it is weak. If one doesnt make the mistake of comparing the two of them, then one can really enjoy it in a standard-action-movie kind of way. The original was very politically charged and had a philosophy behind. This remake was a pure action flick, no deep thoughts here. Tim Burton is as always an excellent director so the movie is visually pleasant to watch. The ending wasnt too good. I can see the idea behind it but it failed miserably and just left a bad aftertaste. While it really has nothing to do with the original movie (except apes that talk and rule the humans), it is really hard not to compare them two while watching the movie. Therefor I, with some reservations, would not recommend it to people who have seen the original.

title: Not the best movie I've ever seen, but a darn fine one!
text: Tim Burton never ceases to amaze me.  His eye is second to none and his films have that "look" to them.  My neighbor commented that the 2001 version of "Apes" was the best movie he's ever seen in his entire life.  While I wouldn't go as far as saying that, it was still well worth the price of admission!I'm not much in the way or writing long, drawn out comments, but let me just say that the ending MAKES this movie, it was the perfect fit, even if it was a tad predictable, I couldn't help but grin and give a silent "oh, man!" to it.My only major problem with the film is Mark Wahlberg.  He is a fine and up and coming actor, but I haven't latched onto him yet.  Perhaps one day I will.  He's hot right now, and he's certainly better off than his "Marky Mark" days.As far as other standouts, Paul Gianetti is a riot as Limbo, and Charlton Heston is excellent in a cameo apprerance!Highly recommended viewing.***1/2

title: THE APES WERE COOL... BUT THE HUMANS SUCKED!
text:
This movie wasn't as bad as some people made it out to be. I found it much more entertaining than the hideous Mummy Returns, and the boring, uninteresting Final Fantasy.Like most 'block buster' movies these days this flick is tops in the C.G.I department but woefully lacking in the plot department. However...BEST STUFF:The apes. Their costumes and makeup were excellently rendered. Their mannerisms were convincingly ape-like (e.g. the tree climbing, the loping gait, fear of water), and they were well-performed by their actors. (Thade, Ari and that elderly Orangutan slave trader come to mind)The different species of apes living together in the ape city. Some of the best ape make up I've seen had to be that huge Orangutan with the enormous cheek pouches and jowls. I liked the idea of chimps, gorillas and Orangutans living together in one big community. The set designs were very pretty.  There's lots and lots of picturesque visuals to look at.NOT SO GREAT STUFF:The human hero. Marky Mark may do better in Funky Bunch music videos (!!) and underpants commercials but he was completely uninteresting here. Spends most of his time running around but hardly looks like he is in any danger. Boring. Thankfully the apes get more screen time than M.M.
The Humans. 99% of the humans in this movie were merely extras in cave man clothes given very little to do. There's supposed to be a romance between M.M and Blonde Cave Girl (B.C.G) but nothing happened (maybe I missed something). Her character seemed to have been added simply to make B.C.G look prettier than the ape woman!The story. Oh dear. I liked this movie for the apes, but the humans and been-done-before plot spoiled it! The numerous holes in the plot must be deliberately ignored in order to enjoy this movie. Why not just forget the humans and have the whole flick about the apes? THE ENDING. It's yet another (SIGH) Hollywood'ised End Act! It's meant to be a shock ending, but surprise, surprise: IT SUCKED!! But it does pave the way for POTA part II!

title: Engaging in parts, but otherwise just alright
text: PLANET OF THE APES **1/2The remake of the classic is actually quite good.  The story evolves around a space mission that goes wrong when a space pilot is transported into the future to a place where human beings are ruled by the apes.  The dilemma for the pilot is simple in that he wants to get back to his original era but to do so he must put his faith in those he knows little about, not least a female ape who has rebelled against the brutal treatment of humans. Wahlberg's performance is a little stilted for my money and the typical gung-ho swashbuckling American hero comes through in trumps but he cares little for the land he leaves behind.  The scenery is superb and the way the apes move and react and indeed look is amazing.  There are a number of sub plots, but the most interesting one evolves around the whole scenario of totalitarian ape rule.  Helena Bonham Carter's performance is excellent and I felt a sense of real urgency about her personal quest.  The film all boils down to the stand off near the end whereby some of the militaristic apes learn the truth about their existence in that they were once controlled by humans.  All in all a good movie that was enjoyable, but could have focused more on the inter-race relations and a little less on the selfish quest of Wahlberg's character to just get the hell out of there!

title: Visually stunning but otherwise same old Hollywood plot line.
text: Tim Burton presents a magnificent movie for the eyes, but alas opts for the usual poor screen play. I left the movie feeling that I had been well entertained. The magicpecial effects, make-up, musical score all produce a feast of movie fantasy. The ape-ing is inspired. Tim Roth, as the fanatical Chimp General, is worth the price of admission alone. Paul Giamatti has some nice moments, but no-one else is given much to do except to imitate apes or fearful humans. The female chimps look too much like the original Kim Hunter, bereft of facial hair and facial creases.As usual with these kinds of movies the throw away line is ever present, and some make for a good snicker or two. I wonder how many people caught the irony of Charlton Heston defending gun control!It's really best to see this movie with your inner child on your lap, and leave the critical adult home. This is especially true for the ending which gives a momentary smile of pleasure at it's salute to the original, as long as one doesn't think about how it doesn't make any sense!

title: Movie: A-
text: In my opinion this is a fine film and deserving of better treatment than its gotten here. Tim Burton brings his unique bag of tricks to a film that is perhaps uniquely suited to them. His dark Gothic visuals blend surprisingly well with the topic. The plot contains much of his trademark satire, which replace the heavy moralising of the first film and makes for lighter, more summereaque fare. The cast has its ups{Helana Bonham Carter and Tim Roth being the standouts} and downs {most of the human actors seem to be chosen for their physical archetypes}. The Danny Elfman music is superb as always, adding to the powerful action scenes which stress the sheer physical strength pf the apes . The only major criticism I have is the bizarre ending, which does come as a small shock to those who haven't had it given away for them by some useless trailer trash. But it doesn't mesh well with the rest of the film and actually to me makes a sequel harder to visuallize. All in all, I think this movie is the most entertaining film this summer {altho' that's not saying a lot}, worth your time and money and deserving of better reviewers {both for and against} than have been shown here so far.

title: Great Movie Overall, in Spite of Mark Wahlberg
text: I agree with everyone who has commented that the Makeup is great as are the effects.  In fact, while there are some that trash the ending, I happen to think it was really good.  If you are the type of person who doesn't like to have a movie ending spelled out for you, you'll love the thought provoking ending of this version of Planet of the Apes.  Not unexpectedly though, the movie was great in spite of Mark Wahlberg, who is a terrible actor and really did not add anything to the movie.

title: Damn Dirty Remakes!
text: Damn dirty remakes!Ooops. Don't call it a remake. Director Tim Burton (Sleepy Hollow) prefers words such as "reenergizing," "reimagining," or "reinventing." He even went so far as to request of Fox Studios that the name of the movie be changed to The Visitor. That request was vetoed, as well as the hot monkey love scene between ape and human that was in the original "reinventing" of the 1968 sci-fi classic (which was written by Rod Serling, based upon a much-lauded novel by Pierre Boulle). In this version, Mark Wahlberg (A Perfect Storm) plays the Charlton Heston role, sans loincloth (nope, not what you're hoping for ladies -- Marky-Mark insisted on being fully clothed from head to toe here). He's Leo Davidson, an astronaut who crash-lands on the mysterious, dangerous planet inhabited and ruled with an iron paw by intelligent apes. Helena Bonham-Carter (Fight Club) plays Ari, the "human rights activist" type chimp who risks her life to help the astronaut, and buxom blonde Estella Warren (Driven) completes the strange, almost love triangle. Tim Roth (Lucky Numbers), who excels in playing the villain, goes bananas here with furry malice as the militant human-hater, Thade. I'm reluctant to use the word disappointment here (I'm sure Burton could help me come up with a more imaginative one), and I wouldn't were this not a Tim Burton Film. I hold him to a higher standard than I do most other directors, and I was expecting to see his quirky stamp all over this movie. Unfortunately, it wasn't there. The landscapes and overall look of the film are relatively Burtonesque (thanks to his Sleepy Hollow production designer, Rick Heinrichs and the excellent cinematographer Philippe Rousselot, who is a first-timer to the Burton camp). But the feel of the movie, the heart of it, was not what I have come to expect from Burton. Had this version of Planet of the Apes come out by any other director, I would have judged it less harshly. The ape makeup, aside from the too-glamorous females, is expertly done by Rick Baker, who is no stranger to the celluloid simian. He did the makeup effects for Gorillas in the Mist and Mighty Joe Young. I predict he'll be at least nominated for an Academy Award for his work on Planet of the Apes. The atmosphere of this film is darkly fantastic -- from the makeup, to Danny Elfman's score, to Heinrichs' sets -- it's just too bad the atmosphere does nothing more than shroud a pretty standard story and stock characters. There was some cheesy dialog and tired stunts (for example, a young boy who insists on fighting against the ape army is pinned beneath his horse -- for no apparent reason -- as the enemy closes in upon him. Don't even bother wondering how horses evolved on the planet from the original stock of apes and humans.). Don't get me wrong: Planet of the Apes is definitely a worthy popcorn flick, and will surely be one of this summer's biggest blockbusters. The money is all up there on the screen (Burton wriggles out of saying just how much by stating it cost "More than X-Men, less than Titanic"). There's great action and super-exciting chases and battle scenes, and the actors are fine despite the fact their characters are pretty one-dimensional (the most fully-realized character is Bonham-Carter's, though her Cosmo-ape looks threw me off a bit). Perhaps the most engaging roles are the cameos: Lisa Marie is the sexy chimp trophy-wife of an orangutan senator, and Charlton Heston makes a memorable appearance saying the word "damn" as only he can, and holding a gun. Overall, I recommend Planet of the Apes for fun. Just don't expect anything more than a remake (sorry, Tim).

title: Big Letdown
text: I went to see this movie opening night and boy was dissapointed. I'm not a big fan of Tim Burton. But I saw Mark Whalberg in three kings and The Perfect storm and he wasn't ha;f bad. I also thought that Helena Bonham Carter was great in Fight Club. The Movie starts off alright. It had excellent makeup and fairly good special effects. The acting wasn't bad either. Up until the ending it was about a c+. But once it got to the end it was downhill. I was just plain p***ed off. I reccomend seeing this just so u can see what i am talking about. My final rating. D.

title: Superb Film
text: Can I start off by saying despite what people say about critics, they do prove their worth like warning us about trash like Pearl Harbor so in the case of Tim Burton's POTA I would merely say they are wrong but then everyone sees the film in their own way. I'm a fan of the original series and was looking forward to this version. Of course it has its bad points like some atrocious dialogue like "..a human from the stars" from Helena Bonham Carter but its a more ambitious film with more content and ideas than say Jurassic Park 3 which was just another tired franchise film. The ending was a fun homage to the original and was not supposed to top that original film but is a part of Tim Burton's reimaging. Mr Burton said in a recent interview that he would rather jump out of a window than make a sequel even though Fox want to turn it into a franchise so maybe there should not be a sequel but just let this film stand as a worth successer to the 1968 version. I can't wait for the DVD with the extras to savor from this excellent version. 10 out of 5

title: A fine film that in no way resembles the original, ending is crap.
text: Well, well, well, where DO I begin with this film? The beginning is a nicely done introduction, letting you see what Mark Wahlburg's charachter is all about, he is the classic american hero He doesn't take orders well, which makes you wonder why he is in the Air force, but whatever, this Is an action movie, and the plot takes a side role to the suspense and fight scenes anyway.  The film wastes no time enslaving him, and wastes less letting him escape, it gets better after he leaves the hatefull city, and the interesting side plot about his divivded love between the gorgeous human, and the intelligent, compassionate ape.  The final battle does an excellent job of tying up all the loose ends, both by fulfilling the ancient prophecy, and taking care of the antagonist Thade. There my like for the film evaporates as Tim Burton ends it with something only one large fan of the original series has been able to explain to me as "jumping to another dimension". I don't know about you, but "another dimension" is code for, "the writers ran out of GOOD ideas". the biggest shock of all comes after you've seen the film, and then realize that Mr.Burton shot an additional 4 DIFFERENT endings, and THIS is the one he chose! overall: two hours of entertainment, followed by 10 minutes of mysterious crud.

title: Dumbing down for the current generation?
text: Whether written or film, Sci Fi works best when it's either ahead of it's time and cautionary, or of it's time and satirical. The original Apes' films fell in the latter camp, using the generation gap of the late 60s, the optimism and expectancy of the moon shots and (increasingly) the racial tensions building up in the states as its themes. Tim Burton's film does neither, living with the glib message that "we should, uh, just all get along and live with each other".Though there's a fair amount of spectacle to enjoy and a cracking performance from Tim Roth, POTA is ultimately unsatisfying. Up to this point in his career Burton was part of that small (miniscule?) group of American directors who had managed to deliver witty, scary, ironic, enjoyable films AND managed to get them distributed to your local McMultiplex. POTA sadly whiffs of compromise and poor editing ending up being confused and confusing.Go and see it (at the end of the day it IS fun) but don't let the phrase "hang on, why...?" appear in your mind at any point and don't be be tempted to wonder that if, in 30 years during which we've been able to shrink computers to a tenth of their size and digital watches have come and gone, monkey make-up still looks as ropey as it did when Roddy McDowell first started piling it on to spook Charlton Heston.

title: A different take on the Ape concept.
text: When I first saw the original "Planet of the Apes" film on DVD, it blew my mind.  It was such an incredibly moving film and was so brilliantly well done.  Even the 1968 ape make-up was amazing.  So when the 2001 film came out, I was anticipating seeing it.My first sitting of the film was somewhat mixed.  The opening progresses quite quickly and jumps straight into the point rather than dilly-dallying with any character development.  There was an awful lot that happened in the film, and I didn't really get the chance to process it all until after the film had finished.  That's not to say that the plot was hard to follow; it just took me a while to process everything that had happened.  During that delayed reaction, I commented rather negatively on the film, but once I'd processed it all I appreciated the film a lot better, and thus the film was much better.During my second viewing of the film, I saw it for what it was: really good sci-fi action film.  That's not to say that the re-working of the film is a bad thing: the remake gives a fresh angle on the ape concept, which can be a great thing if it's executed correctly.  And the 2001 version of "Planet of the Apes" executes it brilliantly.In the modern film, genetically-enhanced monkeys pilot survey pods through unexplored space while the humans stay safely on their space station.  When one such monkey is lost in an electromagnetic storm, pod pilot Leo Davidson (Mark Wahlburg) decides to attempt a rescue.  With his navigation instruments down, Leo crash-lands on the planet of the apes....just as an ape hunting party is rounding up a fresh wagon-load of human slaves.Critics will say that the new film completely ignores Pierre Boulle's original novel, but it doesn't.  The modern story is very different certainly, but it is still closely tied with the novel.  Human-sympathising ape Ari (rendered absolutely superbly by Helena Bonham Carter) suggests a reason for why Earth's apes don't speak ("the way you treat them; maybe they don't want to"), which comes from Boulle's original novel.  And the movie's ending (one that'll make you gasp out loud) is lifted straight from the original novel.Everything about this film is excellent: the modern ape make-up is amazing, the peformances are of an incredible standard (especially Helena Bonham Carter and Tim Roth as the human-hating ape Thade), and the characterisation is just as superb as in the original film.  The film is brutal enough to make a statement about man's inhumanity to man (and ape), yet there is still a definite humour in the ape parodies of society.This truly is a great film.  Go out and enjoy it.

title: I'll be seeing this one again.
text: This was my most anticipated film of the year and I was not disappointed. Like many others, I have been a huge fan of the original Planet of the Apes since I first saw it in 1968 and had great misgivings about a remake. Once I learned that Tim Burton was to direct I knew that I would be seeing something wonderful. There isn't any other director around today that I would have picked to make this film. I was also delighted to learn that he was not just remaking but re-imagining the entire story which opened up huge possibilities. The result is an exciting, rousing adventure with thought-provoking ideals that set it apart most of the bang and blow-up action films put out today. It manages to keep many of the elements of the original that made it so enduring while adding new twists to the story. The make-up by Rick Baker is astounding. Certainly his best work to date. The cast is uniformly excellent with special kudos to Helena Bonham-Carter, Tim Roth and Paul Giamatti. This film must be seen on the big screen. I'll certainly be seeing it again at least once if not more.

title: spoilation creation
text: Great make-up...big deal. I can see that in my own mirror! Not that I hated the movie, I didn't even mind so much the stupid ending and the cheesy thumbs-up chimp. I was too irritated by Estella Warren. OK, she's beautiful. Happy for her, but that was her only purpose in the whole movie! Why was she the only one to be running around half naked and with her cleavage showing(Maybe apes don't have cleavage)? Maybe I was supposed to be so blinded by her lips that I didn't notice that the little girl(that was taken as a pet and then rescued) seemed to disappear. Maybe I fell asleep and missed something, but what happened to her? I don't remember seeing her after that. I guess you can't have a movie without the token woman and cute kid, even if it is ridiculous. Another thing...since when do apes fly around like Peter Pan? I think a simple jump would have sufficed. I should be hired as a movie consultant. I could save these film studios a lot of money!

title: not terrible but a senseless remake
text: I didn't find this film as terrible as I thought I would.  I am a big fan of the original films and was very skeptical of a remake.  Some of the allusions to the original were clever, but not all of them.  One of the biggest flaws, to me, was the fact that when I left the theater I didn't remember the names of many of the characters.  There was also a lot of wasted talent here (everyone but Tim Roth) and Marky Mark is no Charlton Heston.

title: Talk about having a monkey on your back..
text: Tim Burton delivers once again.  When talk first began about an update for "Planet of the Apes" I was taken back when it was first reported that Arnold "The Terminator" Schwartzenegger was tapped to play the lead in the James Cameron directed film.  Thank all that is wholly that Burton took over. Could anyone really see Arnold delivering such lines as "get your stinking hands off me you damned dirty ape!" Talk about your comedy films.Burton, who is probably best known for his dark and mysterious works such as "Batman" (the first one and only really worthy one) and "Sleepy Hollow", has scored once again with his retelling of "Planet of the Apes"  By showing a certain reverence to the original ( the above referenced line by Heston is now spoken by one of the apes ) as well as certain character names (Nova for one) he has given it an original twist and (although I must admit a somewhat confusing) ending that will have people talking in the breakroom for days about it.The actors, story all of it is first class and well worth the admission price.  Remember, these aren't your 1968 apes.  Burton has them behaving less human and more ape-like, complete with hanging off the ceiling and grunts and squeals.  But then again, when a director like Tim Burton takes on a project as daunting as "Planet of the Apes" he must feel the pressure of having the monkey on his back.This is two hours of make believe that will do just that -- make you believe.  enjoy.

title: Decent DVD...don't expect much
text: This movie was filmed in what is now the famous "I-am-so-depressed-o-vision" The makeup and costumes were fantastic..Danny Elfman doesn't really do anything new with the music other than crank the volume up in pivotal spots... Tim Roth does a great job being p***ed off the entire movie..but you never see his character go anywhere....I am still trying to figure out where Estella Warren got all the lipstick on that barren planet..yet she couldn't find a full set of clothes..Kris Krisstofferson was a waste of film...and Charlton Heston makes a cameo..This movie was so stupid I couldn't wait to turn the thing off.On a positive note..the DVD is pretty nice..it has many behind the scenes features..showing stuff that you probably missed in the movie..because you were busy in the bathroom gagging..I give this film ..no bananas..

title: Different, but the same.
text: Finally saw this film recently.  I was expecting another duplicate of Planet Of The Apes '68 with hyped-up special effects and celebrity actors (well it did, but they where apes).  Acting was ok, Wahlberg was not that great (loosen up man, it's just a movie), but found Tim Roth, Paul Giamatti, and Carter to be very entertaining.  We got a completely stand-alone movie that went in a different direction than the other five films with the same namesake (or maybe not, we may see...).  I can see where alot of people may not like this movie. For one, I think too many people went into the movie thinking it was going to be more closely related to previous films, from what I understand they where not even going to call it "Planet Of The Apes". Overall it is nothing spectacular, a few nice surprises on the way, but equal to most action/sci-fi movies out there nowadays.  As for the ending, come on people, not every single big-budget movie has to have a happy, close-minded, all mysteries solved ending.  It's refreshing to have a thought-provoking ending.  Although, I did find that the apes driving cars and all that a little awkward looking, not because they are apes, but something just did not look right, and somehow if this whole thing was supposed to be a two-way time travel deal and the apes took over years and years ago, I would think that cars, buildings, and so on would look slightly different, then again maybe they took over a few years before he got there in the end, who knows?  In most cases, sequels can kill a series of movies, but in this case I think it can only get better if written and directed correctly.  One thing is for sure, I am sure they could get the audience and sales for a second movie just based on people wanting a resolution to that ending!  I got stuck watching the crappy pan & scan version and to me the shots where framed way to contrived for a movie like this, then again maybe I just need to see the widescreen version.  Overall I gave this a 7 out of 10

title: No action + bad script + bad plot = Shockingly bad movie
text: Q:  What do you do when an action film has little or no action?A:  You start analyzing script, plot, character development, acting ability...etc.Guess what?  The script is poorly written and contains major plot and character inconsistencies.  The plot (and about 10 sub-plots) never gains continuity or momentum.  And we learn virtually nothing about the characters. I know I shouldn't be worrying about this, but when there is no action, what else is there to do? I guess the acting was OK--I mean, Tony Danza's not in it.Tell your friends not to see this movie if they want action.  This is not an action film!P.S. Mark Wahlberg's character seemed to adapt very well to being hurtled through space and time, crash landing on a planet, and being captured and enslaved by talking apes.  I wish I could adapt that well.This movie stunk with a capital "S".My two line review of this movie is "Shockingly Bad".  I expected so much and got so little.Go rent the first one--please!

title: Terrific! Great Movie!
text: This is a great movie! The special effects, and the retelling was excellent... In my opinion theres no beating the original, but this was a great recreation.  If you liked the original, this is a must see!

title: A typical Hollywood attempt at a remake...typical failure.
text: Everyone we talk to agrees: Planet of the Apes 2001 is a disappointment. Did they spend a ton of dough to make it? Yes. Is it a blockbuster like Armageddon, Independence day and the like? Almost. Did Shrek and even American Pie 2 make more money (which means more warm bodies and eyeballs)? You bet. Without giving away the weak plot, Tim Burton has screwed up, and had his first bad story, bad acting and his first sell-out. When analyzing a movie, I look at the director's choices: cast, editing style, photography, dialogue and subtext. Cast: Mark Wahlberg deserves a huge movie, he deserves the cash and the popularity. Michael Clark Duncan is typecast as a big tough guy. Tim Roth plays a good bad guy. Helena Bonham Carter could have been replaced by anybody. The savage humans were poorly used, and where did the female human store her MAC makeup kit? Editing: Typical use of quick cuts, swish pans, high speed shutter shots, typical of current batch of action films, usually disguising a bad action sequence. Photography: adequate, did not give away effects, slow motion overused in action sequences. Dialogue: Terrible. Granted, even the Star Wars films have crappy dialogue, but the actors pull it off. Much of the conversation is trite, and the exposition is blatant. The humans should not speak, making the astronaut all the more unusual to the humans and the apes. Subtext: Not enough of it. They hardly touch upon the whole issue of the sensitive apes wanting to free the humans. And the sappy speech by Helena about the human who came from the stars...gimme a break.That being said, the makeup was good for the men, bad for the women, overdone for the female human lead. The sets were overdone. If they had metal helmets and spears and shields, why are the cages made out of wood. The whole time for bed escape scene was too campy for this film. Finally, as a movie that keeps one's interest, this movie fails. About 30 minutes in, I wondered if it was over yet. Thank goodness it's over now. Rule the Planet? I'm afraid not, Tim. Stick to superheroes and Johnny Depp. And if you've got Kris Kristoferson on your payroll, I think the world is ready for Pee-Wee Herman and the Last Crusade.

title: Very intense
text: I have not yet seen the other Planet Of The Apes (or it's affiliated films from the 70's) so I will make no comparison. Well, I might have seen them, but I was very young and don't recall them or since i9t was the 70's I might have been stoned...who knows.Anyways...I look forward to the sequel...I think this movie is very good...especially all the work and effort that went into it and with 20 minutes of uncut film added to the script, would have made this a kickass film.The only flaw that I found this to have is that Estelle Warren's character served no purpose aside from looking good in skimpy clothing and LIPSTICK...now where would she get LIPSTICK and MAKEUP and EYESHADOW from in a JUNGLE?And why did all the humans have perfect white teeth?Oh yeah...what was the initial reason of the purpose for the humans in the final cut film? Maybe to show us that even in the jungle that we can have a nice tan and well manicured hair and nails.To claim this movie to be bad is wrong...it just missed the mark...and with a staff of over 600 people and so much to do, I'm sure that some oversights can happen when you are directing a film and Tim Burton's oversights were proper character development and motive...but aside of that I think he did a wicked job....as well as EVERYBODY ELSE involved in this film from stunts to makeup, costumes, painters, props and EVERYBODY...I was overall pleased.

title: Solid remake.
text: Tim Burton's remake of Planet of the Apes, is a solid, entertaining action flick. The apes are outstanding, the humans, though not as good, are passable. This is just guilty pleasure summer fun. Overall, Tim Burton's remake of Planet of the Apes, is solid, entertaining summer fun. *** (out of four)

title: What were they thinking?
text: My overview is that the special effects and sets are good, the make up and costuming are excellent, the dialog is silly and the plot is ridiculous. The lesson learned is, don't monkey around with a good thing! What more can I say?Recommendation:  Go to Block Buster and rent the original movie.

title: Very good remake!
text: A lot of surprises in Tim Burton's version!Who would have expect an anti-gun message from Mr. NRA himself,or that Helena Bonham-Carter 2nd best performance[after 'Fight Club',of course]would come from her in a monkey suit?! A few words about the twists[Don't worry,I'm not going to reveal them, just provide knowing insight for those who saw them]!!
