The first one is obviously a tip to Rod Serling's original ending.The second one I think most people could guess from the opening scene,but it's a funny goof on 'Beneath the Planet...'!The final big twist may seem confusing,but I think Tim Burton wanted to set up a sequel based on 'Escape from the Planet...',and I think this may be one to watch for!

title: Good movie while it lasts
text: The movie is good but not memorable. helena Bonham Carter has twinkling eyes. The tacit love scenes among mark Wahlberg and her are touching. It's amazing how humans can feel threatened all the time . Estella Warren's worship of Mark Wahlberg is challenged by Carter's enthusiasm and worship of the humans. By having this love triangle in this kind of movie plot, Tim Roth did an excellent job potraying humans versus apes, their likes and dislikes. The last scene , to many a confusing ending with different interpretation, is the best scene.

title: Brilliant remake of the 70's movie
text: I managed to see an advance preview of this movie and it just blew me away. All the acting was unbelievable and it had a brilliant script to boot. I suggest that everyone should stop whatever they are doing and go out and see this movie.

title: An insult to the intelligence of 12-year-olds
text: As a committed fan of the original movie, and also of the under-rated TV series, I felt duty-bound to see Tim Burton's reinterpretation, despite the off-putting hype. What I saw can be simply and honestly summarised. Special effects (the least consideration of any cinema-goer whose IQ achieves triple figures), very good. Make-up, very good (Thade especially). Mark Wahlberg's acting, monosyllabic and wooden. Helena Bonham-Carter's acting, a little better than her usual low average. In my native England this movie carries a 12 rating (i.e. suitable for viewers of age 12 and over), which slightly over-estimates the level of intellectual maturity required. A complete absence of plot and character, but a superabundance of noise and violence. Much jumping and gratuitous aggression from the apes, considerable banality from the humans (especially Wahlberg). Given the considerable resources available to Burton we are entitled to something considerably less moronic than this flimsy, catchpenny movie, which cynically exploits brand loyalty and the reputations of director and cast. The truth is that this film will not bear scrutiny six months from now, let alone in a decade or so's time. None of this will matter. Mugs like myself have ensured that it was a box-office smash. More fool us.

title: Great Movie!
text: Although, still not as good as the original Planet of the Apes (1968) it was pretty darm close! Great make-up work, great music,and special effects!! Planet of the Apes (2001) is a must see movie! Michael Clarke Duncan, Helena Bonham Carter, Tim Roth, and Paul Giamatti do a great job as their parts of Attar, Ari, Thade, and Limbo! You've really gotta see this movie, and also the original Planet of the Apes (1968), Beneath the Planet of the Apes, Escape from the Planet of the Apes, Conquest of the Planet of the Apes, and Battle for the Planet of the Apes!

title: Burton's apes.
text: Did you remember the film you saw before? Did you remember the hunting of us by the humanroled wild apes? Had you been influenced by the  "human" doll of innocent baby ape? Or, did you want to feel that old shiver when you see the old acquaintance ruin at the end?  So you are in wrong movie! But; if you  came to the theater for Tim Burton, it's okay: If you say that; since I won't ask for "why", the answer "by chance" is not a disappointment for me, you won' t search for support of Darwin. You will enjoy nearly as if in Mars Attacks or Bettlejuice with the rich effects, colorful scenes and very very convincing apes! But if only Burton would make a movie like Edward Scissorhands, again.

title: Great Movie!
text: Although, still not as good as the original Planet of the Apes (1968) it was pretty darn close! Great make-up work, great music,and special effects!! Planet of the Apes (2001) is a must see movie! Michael Clarke Duncan, Helena Bonham Carter, Tim Roth, and Paul Giamatti do a great job as their parts of Attar, Ari, Thade, and Limbo! You've really gotta see this movie, and also the original Planet of the Apes (1968), Beneath the Planet of the Apes, Escape from the Planet of the Apes, Conquest of the Planet of the Apes, and Battle for the Planet of the Apes!

title: Chewing gum for your brain
text: Planet of the Apes will not give you a mental workout.  It will not show you a skillful piece of cinematic mastery.You will not be wowed by the tightness of the script (it isn't).  You will not be impressed by the structure of the plot (it's hole-filled).But, no question, you will be entertained.The makeup is first rate.  The real actors among the cast (Helena Bonham Carter, Tim Roth) do better than reasonable jobs with the limited material they have been given.  The special effects are -- special.You will be intrigued and entertained for the entire movie -- right up until the pointless, nonsensical, tacked-on, made-for-sequel surprise ending. Once you leave the theater with that nagging problem gnawing on your psyche, the remainder of the movie crumbles into a heap of mental rubbish.My brain snacked noisily on the movie for two hours.  Then the flavor ran out in the last minute of the picture.  So I spit it out, gave it not another thought, and moved on to my next piece of cheap gum...

title: The ending just ruined it for me
text: I think Tim Burton has shown in the past that the aesthetic and his love for 1950's B films are the predominant factors in how he goes about his work, and this time it was the latter that ruined that work for me. Time and again, Burton has disregarded the entire concept of suspension of disbelief, and that's fine, but when the end of your film is as ludicrous as that of the new Planet of the Apes, it makes one forget the positives the film may have presented. Not as good as the original (what remakes are?), I found everything in the film to be 'acceptable', even some of the cheesier heroic scenes from the Wahlberg character, but the ending just went too far. That drastically changed my impressions of the film, which I was thinking of as a 5 or a 6 until the finale reduced it to a 3. Wait for HBO: You won't be missing much.

title: "Apes" 1968 is to original Star Wars as Apes "2001"...
text: ...is sort of to Star Wars: Phantom Menace (only better with no annoying sidekick)As far as the acting, the apes do a great job dealing with the challenges of walking differently (*almost* completely upright), and the humans are also very good. The romance subplot does not overtake the movie and is not very obvious. The direction, with Tim Burton at the helm, would have to be said as really good. Like a music CD can have good songs badly produced (or vice versa), this is a pretty good movie with a great director. The dark sides of other films like Edward Scisorhands and Batman don't influence the style of "Apes", and the genre allows him to play with things. I would recommend that you see the movie at some point, but be aware that the ending is not the greatest of endings.

title: Striking visual and philisophical feast
text: I just got back from a sneak showing of this film and it's still running through me. First of all the film moves so quickly and is edited so smoothly that the force of the ruling apes pulses through each frame. Thade, the fierce leader played by Tim Roth, intimidates the viewer and flies through the air to viciously end any who oppose him. I found myself recoiling everytime he took flight to horrify and kill a human. His is a villain I was truly afraid of, which is a first in a long while. The visual style of this film is uncanny, the colors and the tones of each scene and setting a complete feast for the eye. I could spend my life looking at this film and never tire of it. The sets and costumes are absolutely stunning and gorgeous - alot of it looks like it was designed by costume designer Eiko Ishioka (Bram Stoker's Dracula (1992) and The Cell). Lisa Marie as Nova was hysterical. Miss Helena Bonham Carter is very pleasing to watch as always, and surprisingly Estella Warren, the blonde beauty, has very, very few lines and a very small part. An unnamed child who tags along has more lines than her. The film's pace is so brisk I thought by the first twenty minutes they were almost halfway through the movie, but then more and more happened and began to unfold. Some of the best discussions about religion, politics and slavery can be found in this film, making such a bold and correct statement about how though species may differ, their ideas that allow them to live due to belief in a higher power are all the same, on this planet or elsewhere. Religion is an invention of higher intelligence, though that's not to say that religion itself is intelligent - in fact it's rather illogical and nonsensical for a "higher" species such as ourselves. We consider our species so much "better" and "perfect" that we assume that if there is, in fact, a God, it made us in its likeness. If you think about it, we have never even entertained the notion that the higher power may in fact be something of a different species, if any at all. No, THAT'S absurd. (Roll of eyes). The action sequences were powerful and well directed, but that goes without saying, seeing as this IS a Tim Burton movie. I rather enjoyed that it wasn't Sleepy Hollow 2. Although that film is genius and Tim Burton's trademark, I'm glad he stretched his creative muscles and ventured into a different territory of filmmaking, at least in its style. Although his films carry a very similar theme - someone lost in a world of absurdity with very few but existing traces of sympathizers and saviors. Tim Burton's Planet of the Apes stands as its own film, and not a remake. It's powerful, philisophical, moving and fierce. It will leave its mark. In me it already has.

title: Contrived Load of Crap
text: We saw Planet of the Apes at a free movie screening...I was glad I did. Because if I would have paid money to see this, I would have cried myself home.It's a comedy...it has to be.  And a bad one at that!  The ending is unbelievably stupid.

title: Another Boring Remake
text: I don't think this has any spoilers, so...Let me start out..the visuals were stunning. It is more action-packed than the original in many ways. That's it.I saw the original again a few weeks ago and I thought, just because, let me pull out my dusty 2001 version. They have two things in common, period. They both have apes, they both have humans at a lower level.The incredible drama and interplay of conflicting beliefs such as racism, nuclear holocaust, intolerance, animal vivisection never appear in the newer version, so...and now I ask the obvious...WHY remake a classic with something only created for green screen shots?I can only come up with one answer and it saddens me. Very few of today's younger generations don't have the same attention span as "us" older folk. I can't imagine them sitting through (let's face it) the rather boring action-wise first few minutes of the film:but, the problem is, those first few minutes help to set up the entire movie; something the remake doesn't. I can imagine it would be like making a 16 year old sit through "2001." No zooming spaceships, no lasers, no action or fighting.I am vehemently opposed to most remakes. Granted, there might be a handful at most that improved upon the original, "Dracula" pops to mind, but very, very few. I wish directors would get some imagination and try to think of something PARTIALLY new. I know the Bible, Ecclesiastes 1:9, said, "there is nothing new under the sun," but come on. If you can't do any better than a remake it's time to hang up your directing hat and go fishing until retirement.

title: Overstatement of the original
text: Some people may call Tim Burton Judas for his reinvention of the 1968 classic "Planet of the Apes",but before you cast the first stone pay in mind that Burton is worshipping the film here, not exploiting it.And it shows. This is a overstatement of the original that in my honest opinion did not have to be remade. The special effects here are brilliant,but in all you have to give Mark Wahlberg his props and so that he can prove that can he,well can be in a movie with action and great special effects. You may laugh at that last sentence,but I don't see an Oscar on Charlton Heston's wall for the original(since he has already have several from his Oscar-winning Ben Hur). Tim Roth,Kris Kristofferson, Estella Warren,and a shocking performance by Micheal Clarke-Duncan as the General and cameos by Heston,Linda Harrison(who played Nova in the original),Kim Hunter and George Clooney are added bonuses in this one. A Must See!

title: I like the Burton-version more than the old version!
text: This afternoon I finally watched Planet Of The Apes by Tim Burton. Majorly cool movie. I still remember watching the old version when I was still a kid. I somewhat liked that stuff, but I didn't expect I'd still like the idea now that I'm grown up. But now I finally understand where the storyteller was coming from. He just turned the real world around and made monkeys treat human beings the way human beings treat monkeys. When I was a child I didn't see it like that. I just took it as a story about a planet of apes, but not really like a story somewhat criticizing the way monkeys are treated by us. Pretty cool. And as far as I remember I like the Burton-version more than the old version.

title: Monkey Madness at its Best
text: Pick, pick, pick : ). Sure you can quibble about the details, but I grabbed the kids and took them to see it when it first came out and no one was disappointed. We all got a kick out of it and afterward we rented the original so that we could compare. The kids thought the newer version was better, but I suppose a lot of that has to do with the updated technology and all. Now that they've gotten hip to DVDs and all the features they include, they want me to get it for all the inside stuff so I suppose I'll preorder it here. The make-up jobs in this film were certainly much better than in the original. I expect that will make its category at the Oscars. I had no problem with the acting, Tim Roth is always great, look forward to anything he's in. I didn't get Wahlberg's performance till I thought about it a bit more and realized that was his character, a bit selfish and tunnel-visioned. He kind of deserved the ending ; ). And I rather enjoyed seeing a different version and wouldn't mind seeing more directors do this. Seeing the second version of Psycho mimicked shot for shot left me cold. This version of Planet of the Apes still dealt with the important issues and I'm glad for that. We all had a lot of discussion about the nature of human behavior and how we all need to get along somehow. I know the cynics are scowling now, but its true. I see some folks don't get the ending and I'm not sure I do either. Perhaps that was intended, because it was left wide open for a sequel. Anyway, I'm not going to quibble, it was enjoyable and fun to watch, worth the money. Lord knows we could use a little entertainment nowdays.

title: Mediocre and mildly disappointing remake which lacks imagination.
text: Tim Burton's remake of Planet of the Apes is a very disappointing addition to his other films. Having seen Batman, Beetlejuice and Mars Attacks! I am surprised to see this unwelcome addition to his list. To be fair though, this is probably his first mediocre film. Its not a disaster and it has its good moments, but there's not enough fresh material in it to make it very memorable. Mark Wahlberg is the film's `hero' but the role really doesn't suit him. While in films like Boogie Nights and The Yards he had good supporting players, in Planet of the Apes he just can't carry the role. On the other hand, Tim Roth is very moody in his role as Thade, the film's menace. Helena Bonham Carter is good as the female monkey with a heart, but the make-up is unconvincing. Most of the other performances are standard but nothing award-winning. The film's direction is surprisingly bland giving Burton's usual atmospheric style. There has been a lot of controversy about the ending. I for one liked it and although it was a big surprise, I thought it was very clever. Overall, Planet of the Apes isn't a bad movie, but it could have been much better. It's good fodder for the eyes but after watching it, you'll probably forget about it straight away. 5.3 out of 10.

title: a Tim Burton classic
text: This was a fantastic film, the best of the year...so far.  I say that because Lord Of The Rings hasn't been released yet.  This one had it all, great visual and special effects, and a wise choice to use costumes instead of CGI for the apes.  A fantastic cast, great script, and some of the best directing by the one and only Tim Burton, one of my all time favorite directors.  I give this film an 8 out of 10, go see it at any price, you won't be disappointed.

title: Excellent Re-imagining
text: Positively one of the best movies this summer. Great makeup, great visuals, great performances = great movie. Now it isn't perfect, but don't listen to these other guys you've listed fifty billion problems with it, they just didn't get it. But if you like action, science-fiction, and apes, go see this movie. Trust me!

title: If it weren't for Tim Roth......
text: I really wanted to like this film.  I went in pumped up but left feeling disappointed because I probably expected too much.  They did a good job distancing themselves from the original film.  This film has a surprise ending that's not as good as the one in the original (which is my favourite ending in ANY film) but is still very nightmarish.  Unfortunately this movie's mid section drags mercilessly and I wanted to leave the theatre.  It starts off very well and ends well in the last 40 minutes or so but about 45 minutes in the middle of the film is just plain bland.  Mark Wahlberg wasn't well casted.  I didn't buy him as an astronaut and adventurer at all. Helena Bonham Carter, Michael Clarke Duncan and especially Tim Roth all have their characters nailed down perfectly.  Roth's General Thade may be one of the top five villains in movie history.  The savage nature of his portrayal made him a great sadist and the make-up spoke a lot for him as well.  Rick Baker could earn another Oscar for his make-up work but Tim Burton was not the man to direct such heavy material.  Burton is good for decorative pop culture stuff found in comic books ('Batman') or heavy indoor and artsy production design stuff like 'Pee Wee's Big Adventure' or 'Beetlejuice' but somehow he just couldn't get me excited enough to embrace this remake of a legendary motion picture.

title: Don't Bother.
text: This movie was just plain horrible, it didn't do the originals justice, and is probably one of the worst Tim Burton films I have ever seen, The Movie was bland at best, and was a total waste of my $8.The thing that disturbed me the most, was the ending, while it was quite a twist, when I was watching it, I was thinking to myself "I've seen this before...." ... The ending of this movie did indeed resemble a frame in a "Jay & Silent Bob" Cartoon, (I have the issue in front of me, I managed to dig it out). now it may be total coincidence ... but ..... well ... who knows?My Grade on this movie: D

title: exciting, funny, intriguing
text: ahhh, finally a Hollywood action blockbuster with an intriguing story! Here is the best film of 2001 so far bar none! Critics are just critics, and will never be able to enjoy a movie without picking it apart. This was a marvelous film in so many ways. The script is extremely well written and keeps you guessing. In the end you'll be dazzled and confused, but no less amazed! What made this film so enjoyable was the grand sense of humor and pacing. It was never boring and some of the apes were hilarious. The ending, which has been much talked about, is wonderfully twisted and different than usual. Wouldn't it have been boring if Wahlberg just came back to Earth with a happy ending? Knowing Tim Burton you know something weird had to happen. Wahlberg gave a great performance as the earnest astronaut. From the opening scenes I knew this film would be great. The credits sequence was extremely imaginative and beautifully done. Everything in the film was superbly done. Ape City was truly eye-popping. I couldn't tell if it was done by computer or models. I loved Charlton Heston's little cameo. He really explained the mechanics of the story in just one scene. And it's a fascinating story at that. I highly recommend this film. It's probably best if you haven't seen the original, since I haven't and I really enjoyed this one. So go see it and have an old-fashioned good time at the movies. Best summer action film of the year.

title: Don't treat this as a remake and you'll enjoy it.
text: Burton's "Apes" is a new movie. If the film were a straight-up remake then of course it wouldn't hold up to the original but guess what?, no movie can ever hold up to what the original laid down, so why try? Burton obviously recognized this and did a great job with a NEW story. Great work.

title: They didn't blow it up!!!
text: Let me start by saying that this remake isn't the original.  It isn't a cold war commentary which has deep and philosophical things to say about man's innate desire to destroy himself.  It doesn't have silly looking ape masks or NRA president Charlton Heston kneeling before the Statue of Liberty yelling "they blew it up!!!"  It couldn't have these things because for what it's trying to be in this time, none of the aforementioned details would have meaning.Let's face it folks, 1968 and 2001 by their very nature demand that two entirely different films be made (even if they both happen to be called Planet of the Apes).  As an intelligent, all be it wacky filmmaker, Tim Burton knew when he made the new film for the masses of 2001 that it would be viewed as little more than a mindless summer blockbuster, backed by all the advertising that the Hollywood machine can muster for one of its potential goldmines.  He knew that it wouldn't be considered "art" as the first has become since 1968, and he knew that Americans, by and large, don't want to see art at multiplexes during the summer (witness the demise of A.I.)This all considered, it's incredible to me that there is a preponderance of negative reviews for this film on the IMDB.  "It has no plot."  "It has no good characters."  "It isn't the original."  Of course it has a plot! (And don't say the ending made no sense because if you think about it for more than a minute, g-d forbid, it just may)  Of course it has good characters! Who do you think acted below all that (incredible) ape makeup!  BUT, as I have said already, I admit that it isn't the original.Tim Burton should be given a great deal of credit for putting this film together.  He did as good a job as can be done today for a film like this, given our society's need to be perpetually entertained.  The new Planet of the Apes has echos of its predecessor... not too many nor too few.  It is a remake, but it is its own film.  It is neither a masterpiece nor a disaster. If you've seen the original, think of these things when you enter the theater and you'll probably be happy when you leave.  If you haven't seen the original, first of all see it... second of all, see the remake.  It's a worthy update bringing 1968 up to 2001's speed.

title: Good not Great.....
text: Well. i just finished seeing a very hyped kids movie. It seems like a kids movie to me because the action was very tame, hardly no blood whatsoever.Don't get me wrong. I still liked the movie. But it could've been better. The action was top notch the costumes and makeup artist should get a award for their effort. The movie was lacking the good 'ol "V" word that i love in action movies. VIOLENCE. The story was lackluster also. Man finds ape planet, man tries to escape ape planet. the ending seemed like a sequel.my Rating 7 out of 10.

title: Chuck has nothing to worry about
text: Huge Disappointment. As a fan of the original 'Apes' and Tim Burton I was doubly disappointed with the new "Planet of the Apes" The story is almost non-existent. The dialogue is terrible and/or self-mocking. The much-heralded make-up by Rick Baker is actually not that big a leap from 1968 (except perhaps for Tim Roth and the orangutang). And as for the new shock-ending-please! It might have worked except for a stupid illogical name turning up (you'll know what I mean when you see it). All in all, much anticipated but a major disappointment

title: Great movie - odd ending - say "sequel"
text: I'm a big fan of the original movies. This version is fairly well based on the original concepts. Some good action (for apes).  An okay storyline. I felt the ending was a little twistful but it's one way to leave it open for a sequel. I recommend seeing it.

title: Suitable only for children
text:
I thought I would be one of the lucky ones. I never saw the original movie nor read the novel so I thought I would be able to judge the movie   on its own merits and have an enjoyable two hours.Well, if you have not yet seen the movie then please, save your money. The movie has little in the way of merits - the ape costumes are impressive,... but that is about it. The music is cliched, the plot is completely inconsistent, the script would have been more intelligently written by an eight year old and the actors are put to shame by those in Final Fantasy.
I found Pokemon more entertaining and thought provoking.

title: Not the disappointment purists make it out to be.
text: Is a movie bad if it doesn't live up to its ideal potential? No. Does "Apes" live up to such a potential? Not quite. Is Burton's "Apes" a bad film? Absolutely not. And this coming from one of the original's biggest fans. Where the original Apes film (note that I only refer to the first of the original series...no business involving underground A-bomb zealots or Ricardo Montalban as a circus master in this review, thank you very much) was more character driven and used social and political issues as its driving force, Burton opts for a richly visualized, humor-laced action film that features more Saturday-matinee gusto than most films I've seen in a long while. It's a different flavor of ice cream from the first folks, and it's still tasty. And while I won't give away the much-talked-about twist ending--which I quite enjoyed--I managed to find a perfectly logical (though mightily implausible) explanation for how it could have happened...and before the final credits even began rolling (based on elements laid out earlier in the film.) Misters Burton and Broyles must have done something right if I reached such a conclusion that quickly...and if I'm right, and they've done what I think they've done for the reasons I think they did them in that finale, I personally would love to see a sequel. On a scale of 1 to 10, I give this "Apes" a solid 8.

title: Great Special Effects!!!
text: "Planet of the Apes" is a great retelling of the 1968 classic film. The film is crammed with awesome special effects and eye-popping action!! This is a fun film to see in the theater like I did. Mark Walhberg is great!!! This is a great film that shows you how good of a director Tim Burton is. This is a great hit movie!! I give this film a 10 out of 10!!!! You have to see this!!!!

title: BATMAN OF THE APES!!!
text:
If you've seen one Tim Burton movie, you've seen them all, and once Mark Wahlberg lands on the monkey planet you know you're in a Tim Burton movie--dark, depressing, and with lots of offbeat humor.And Tim Burton's PLANET OF THE APES is BATMAN, BEETLEJUICE, and EDWARD SCISSORHANDS all added to the original PLANET OF THE APES to make the latest of the Hollywood remakes, and it's still not as good as the original.But Mark Wahlberg is sensational as Astronaut Leo Davidson, young enough to make you believe he's fighting for his life, and tough enough to make you think he can win.  Estella Warren is as good as advertised as Daena--in the same science fiction sexpot role that Raquel Welch started in ONE MILLION YEARS, B.C., and that Linda Harrison improved upon in the original PLANET OF THE APES.  Warren looks even better than her predecessors, can run better, and can actually act.
Unfortunately, this PLANET OF THE APES has no flow, no focus, and none of the sense of isolation that Charlton Heston--who has a terrific cameo in this version!--made you feel in the original--how could one man survive on the Planet of the Apes???Wahlberg carries the movie, but when you get to the disappointing ending, instead of the feeling of awe at the end of the original, you have a feeling of "I WANT MY MONEY BACK!!!"
Tango2200@Hotmail.Com

title: Not Fit For Man Or Beast
text: "Planet of the Apes" LOOKED great! The make-up was phenomenal, the ape mannerisms were top notch and the production design was excellent! Some have complained about the overuse of wire work, but in all of the movies I've seen, this is where it belonged. Charlton Heston's line was delivered hilariously for those who remember the original! Upon entering the theatre, I refused to compare this film to the classic since it wouldn't be fair, so I judged it solely on its merits.I don't care for this movie. I expect more from my movies than just eye candy which is all POTA has to offer. The story is cliched, thin and excruciatingly slow,  characters are one dimensional and the film never reaches a climax. For all intents and purposes, the film ends twice and both endings are equally ludicrous.If you MUST see this in the theatre, load your favorite disc in your Discman and listen to it while looking at the awesome visuals - you won't miss a thing. If you want to see a movie with a great story and awesome eye candy, rent "The Matrix".

title: Zira Must be rolling in her grave!!
text: When I Went to see this movie i was excited a remake of a movie i loved directed by Mr. Nightmare Before christmas himself Tim Burton i saw the trailers and thought to myself the apes look great this can be bad it just cant. Boy was I wrong this movie was bad "Dude Where's My Car" bad alright not that bad but you see my point. The acting was good but there was no understanding this story line it didnt make sense and the ending was really bad. Im not going to RUIN The ending or anything *Cough*ape monument in washington looks like big un-named president sitting in chair*cough**cough* sorry i got bad movie stuck in my throat. i give this movie a 4 out of 10 even though it was bad it looked really good. My applause to Estella Warren for looking hot all the time

title: A good one, a mixture of gothic horror and adventure.
text: OK, so there was a flaw. He went forward in time and his base stayed on same time. So the ending didn't fit. The only way to make the ending fit was for him to have gone back in time and his base ship to have gone even further back. Then, when he returned to his own time that black ending would have been feasible (he should have stayed and finished the job). If you pretend this dating then the events were consistent and feasible (given acceptance of time travel, etc.) Either way it was a top movie. The apes were more primitive than in the original; no guns, and their behaviour was more ape-like. There was a gothic atmosphere to the ape culture which I liked, and the kind of individual variation in attitudes that could be expected of any culture. There's always material for dedicated flaw-hunters but I'd give this one 8.5 out of 10.

title: Tim Burton's Epitaph: He Did What He Could
text: Critics are a little harsher on this semi-return-to-form from Tim Burton than I would have thought from how consistently engaging the picture is. While not as bewilderingly impersonal as SLEEPY HOLLOW, APES still bears the earmarks of a Fox  $100-million-dollar movie--which is to say that the third act takes a turn into James Cameron and GLADIATOR territory that is most unwelcome (and seems designed to provide gung-ho trailer fodder).Audiences will probably be divided by the finale, an attempt to recoup the badum-bum finale of the 1968 APES; it's a little hamhanded, but I think it works. And the incredible deus ex machina that cuts short a not very well executed Maximus-style combat climax is so touching and out of left-field it feels almost Spielbergian. But until then, the movie works as a well-masticated mouthful of the original APES' hidden subtexts: Burton's APES proliferates metaphors of racism, animal rights, individual self-destruction, and militarism-versus-effete-government in virtually every scene. The themes buried in the Franklin Schaffner APES may not be as probingly essayed here as...oh, I dunno, they would be in a Todd Haynes movie. But they are rather surprising in the context of this very big movie--which, to Burton's everlasting credit, must be the lightest on action scenes of any blockbuster of its kind in years. The Burtonian wit is there--especially when Mrs. Burton, a k a Lisa Marie, does a simian dance of sex for her bloated orangutan husband, who trembles like Pontius Pilate ogling Salome. And it's there in Paul Giamatti's side-of-the-mouth quips as an amoral trader of human slaves. (This is the kind of humor George Lucas was attempting, and failing at grotesquely, in THE PHANTOM MENACE.) Much has been made of the "flatness" of Mark Wahlberg's performance as the human hero, but I think he gives the role just what's necessary--an unsentimental desire to get the job done and get out of Dodge. Much has also been made of the hambone-chewing, sucking and swallowing of Tim Roth, who plays the evillest of the apes; as with Ben Kingsley in SEXY BEAST, Americans seem to respond to British villainy when it's spelled out with a magic marker. Better performances come from Helena Bonham Carter, who weaves bits of chimpanzee physical behavior into her role as a tremulous human-rights activist--a sort of chimpish Patty Hearst--and even from the model Estelle Warren, who is perfectly credible opening her mouth and perfectly heart-stopping when closing it. The script is a sound one (even if there's a bit too much time spent following Wahlberg walk around a wilderness staring at a Palm Pilot-like compass) and Burton brings more flair to even the most expositional images than any of the other eligible hacks could possibly bring to bear. Since this movie is  guaranteed to make a sockful of loot, will somebody let Burton  make another ED WOOD or MARS ATTACKS?

title: Mark is not the Good Dr.
text: I was have breakfast at the diner with my friend Chuck, the ultimate "palnet of the Apes" fan, and having our usual discussion about time-travel, worm holes, and why Charlton Heston couldn't go that fast to perform time travel, First, he couldn't carry the amount of fuel necessary to make the trip, even if going near the speed of light, because as he approached even a fraction of the speed of light, the mass of the accelerating object increases.  Of course then the time to an observer moving at that speed would seem to slow down relative to an observer outside of that frame of reference (time dilation effect).  This was explained by Albert Einstein in the early part of the last century.  Worm holes are another consequence of Einstein's relativistic theories. Regardless of how a being views the "device" that propels the travelers in both movies, I must concede that the first movie was better written, and that even in fantasy with a willing suspence of belief, there are certain rules of internal logic that should be followed. That is why so many people are struggling to make sense of this movie.  In a good movie one does not need to work that hard.  Dr. Who was a much better time traveler, and the writing was much more consistent.  Besides, the hero in this movie can't even fly a space pod as good as his ape assistant! Saying that this movie is as good as the original is like trying to say the "Who Wants to be a Millionaire?" requires the same brain power as "Jeopardy."

title: great ending
text: While there were some parts of this movie that were too campy for my tastes, the ending is brilliant.  It's not just a surprise shocker, but actually based on the original ending from the novel, which had been changed for the first film.  The first film stands on its own, of course, but it was an inspired idea to go back to the novel in order to give this new film its own edge.

title: Biggest cinematic disappointment of 2001!
text: I saw WORSE movies than 'Planet Of The Apes' in 2001, but I didn't expect any of them to be good anyway. This movie however should have been something special, but turned out not only to be the biggest disappointment of the year, but one of the biggest of the last decade.Tim Burton has never made a movie this mediocre before! Even his most flawed movie (up til now) 'Mars Attacks!' was more interesting and entertaining than most of his contemporaries best efforts. Everything about this film is a mess. Not just the asinine script, but the direction is dull, the decent cast is wasted under the unimpressive make up, and the "surprise" ending a complete anti-climax.  Avoid this one, it's absolutely awful!

title: One of the worst movies I have ever seen!!!
text:
In case you can't tell from my one line summary, I really thought this movie was a terrible waste of my time and money. Unfortunately, my husband wanted to see this, so I went along to be polite.If you love science fiction, you will hate this movie.  If you hate science fiction, you will REALLY hate this movie even more(if that is possible). Let's see, what what missing from this movie?  Character development, interesting dialog, interesting plot , good acting, character motivation, an ending that made sense...I could go on, but you get the idea. 
Obviously, this was a blatant attempt to cash in on the original (and vastly superior!) original Planet of the Apes. My suggestion, don't see this movie, don't even rent it when it comes out on video.  Rent or buy the original movie, and save yourself some wasted time and money.  One other comment, Mark Wahlberg might want to go back to singing for a living, 'cause he can't act to save his life!!!

title: In the Mist
text: I'm taking a break from Burton movies after this one.  I just don't like his makeup philosophy and here his vision is watered-down.  Too often this resembles the work of someone else, not Burton.Mark Wahlberg wasn't what made 'Three Kings' and 'Boogie Nights' strong.  He was presentable because the source material is strong.  Here his source is weak.  Under that weak of a structure, he collapses.Overall, the (obvious) subtexts of the original have been exchanged for simple action.  First level science-fiction.I don't see what's so confusing about the ending...Final Analysis = = Cinematic Dud

title: ending makes sense if you've read Boulle's novel
text:
All the confusion over the ending is understandable if you have not read the original Pierre Boulle novel on which Planet 2001 (and its predecessor, to a much lesser degree) is based.Boulle spends a lot of time on evolutionary theories and we learn as the story develops that Cornelius, a very bright chimp scientist, is on the verge of a discovery that will destroy the foundations of the apes' beliefs concerning their evolutionary superiority.In Boulle's Ape world, the apes believe they have always been the intelligent ones and the humans have always been incapable of rational thought.  Cornelius discovers the opposite to be true during his archeological dig in the forbidden zone -- he finds among the ruins a human doll with a voice mechanism, which hints at the previous existence of a hi-tech society. (a similar scene occurred in Planet 1968).The real shocker comes towards the end of the novel, when Cornelius, desperate to show that apes are not just skillful imitators (he is afraid that this truth may explain their progress up to this point -- they have simply copied what humans have already done throughout history), demonstrates via shock therapy on human subjects that he and his colleagues can actually tap into HISTORICAL human memory and shock subjects into babbling about events that took place hundreds of years ago.
Some of the snatches of vocalized historical memory reveal that humans rested on their technological laurels, became lazy, and, before they knew it, apes had taken over their world.  Snatches of these ancient memories reveal that apes were hungry for knowledge while humans were hungry for leisure (what, humans hungry for leisure?!  never!)  The takeover was violent and humans were enslaved.  Fast forward to Boulle's planet Soror and you have apes in control and mute humans with brains turned to mush.When Boulle's hero Ulysse Merou heads back to earth, he too is shocked to discover that apes now rule his home turf.  Yet, how hard is this to believe when we've already seen what has happened on Soror?  The formula is well-understood by now.  Superior species accomplishes much and then loses its edge.  Formerly inferior species, long discriminated against, tortured, etc., takes advantage of human sloth and eventually assumes control.In Planet 2001 we have seen the same thing.  Leo returns to earth naively expecting it to be similar to the way it was when he left.  Thade is worshipped here for the same reasons he was feared/worshipped on his planet -- he is the alpha-warrior and leader of the apes.  What happens on Earth is similar to what happened on Boulle's Soror.  Human minds melted after too much television, pornography, and sports/entertainment.   Though Leo eventually went back in time to return to earth, he still had to make the trip back to earth and that means hundreds of years have passed while he's been in space.  Thade's legend is well-known throughout the cosmos at this point and we should not be surprised to see him worshipped on earth as well, where he's obviously been the inspiration for the ape takeover.One last note: during the feast at the senator's home early in the movie, we hear one of the table guests exclaim (paraphrase):  "We're getting lazy, we should be careful lest the humans take over."  This is a nice homage to Boulle, who works the reverse angle in his novel when the human electroshock subjects reveal through historical memory that it was the human race that dropped the ball the first time around.The lesson is clear:  let your mind melt and you will perish.  I think the homage just mentioned actually telegraphs the plot of the sequel, in which the apes will be corrupted by the same mindless entertainments that corrupt us today.  Leo will lead a revolt and a new breed of humans -- men and women hungry for literature and learning -- will rise up and reclaim their planet.

title: Much to like, much to hate
text: There's a lot to admire about the remake, and a lot to hate.It's an admirable attempt at a re-imagination of the saga but, please - why, oh why, were certain scenes played for laughs?The underlying story is so intrinsically interesting that surely it warranted a serious approach. Do serious approaches exist in modern American cinema? Would "Soylent Green" contain line-after-line of Arnie's witticism if they were to make it now?I'm not a huge Science-Fiction fan - for the most part, because most of these films never suspend my disbelief - but they can work, and they only work when they're played straight.I know that on rewatching the original, many have commented on Heston's bad acting or the film's just plain silliness in places, but give it the one credit it deserves - it played the concept straight-as-die.Most detrimental comments of the original derive from a certain misplace nostalgia:On rewatching, we feel like the film lets us down in some way - That's because our memory of the film is stronger than the film itself, and it tells us that we should expect so much more because the incredible premise of the story has haunted so many of us for so many years.All I asked of the remake was that it treated the story respectfully.I knew I shouldn't go in there expecting a comparable ending or a scene-by-scene remake, but does a re-imagination mean we have to deal with Paul Giammatti's ridiculous slave trader, or Wahlberg's cardboard stock hero one-liners, Heston's embarrassing cameo or the Senator's wife's home-in-the-Hamptons dialogue?Take the remake's phenomenal art-direction, make-up and effects, (and Tim Roth's amazing performance) mix it with the originals heart and you'd have one hell of a movie. Instead we have an off-the-shelf, early 21st century popcorn pusher. Come on Burton, what ever happened to the kind of imagination you had when you enthralled us with Scissorhands?

title: the best movie of Apes i've seen-GREAT
text: The performance by the cast are pure class. Mark Wahlberg as Capt. Leo Davidson was superb. Tim Roth as General Thade was exellant as a ape and a villian and i say he should at least be nominated for the Oscars as Supporting actor. Helena Bonham Carter as Ari was great and sexy even as an ape. Michael Clarke Duncan as Colonel Attar had a great performance and the scariest ape there. Estella Warren as Daena the sexiest and portrayed as a normal human to save herself and others was brill. i hope they would make another movie this. Great!

title: Mark is great in the movie!
text: i would just like to say that planet of the apes is the best summer movie and the best movie i have seen in a long time....it is funny and full of action....the actors/actresses such as Estella Warren, Mark Wahlberg, Michael Clarke Duncan, Tim Roth, and Helena Bonham Carter did so well as their characters and they made the movie better with how they really got into their characters...and for everyone that was an ape/monkey/orangutang they did so well in the training and in the movie and i would just like to say that they made the lives of apes become real and i think this re-make was so much more realistic and interesting and i love the ending because it makes you want to see the next one of planet of the apes and i have to say that i hope everyone stays the same characters....and for all the actors, makeup artists, directors, producers, composers, and the rest that were involved with the film did so well and i am glad to see such a great movie be on top....thanx buh bye!!

title: Only the one race will rule here
text: Tim Burton "Planet of the apes" is fine breathtaking picture which I enjoy so much. I've seen it two times and want to see more. Tim Roth as general Thade took very big part of the plot and used it in a very good way. He's aggressive, scareful and, I think, acts just like Napoleon of the apes (because of his small height). Helena Bonham Carter as Ari looks very lovely, ironic, and sometimes shy. I liked Mark Wahlberg as Leo Davidson less than previous characters, but his eagerness to get away from the planet and what proceeded to his escaping makes him unforgettable. Also I liked that there were no "four-letter" words in the picture. Danny Elfman created unusual electronic-orchestral-percussion score. My rating is 9/10.

title: Crap: DON'T WASTE MONEY ON THIS
text: Was there any actual acting in this movie??  Characterization amounted to grunting, snorting, chest-beating and the occasional "me the big man with gun, me lead group through forest, you woman, you listen to me, that applies to ALL species."  Mark Wahlberg's pseudo Henry V St. Crispian's Day speech amounted to crap: "sometimes a single man can do great things".  The implausability of ALL of it amounted to crap, and in general, this movie was crap.  In conclusion: AVOID if possible.

title: Wait for the video
text: I went to see Planet of the Apes and got just what I expected. Tim Burton could do a lot better than this, but it wasn't terrible. The apes looked pretty good, and the movie was full of twists, which made it more fun. The ending surprised me, but I don't plan to see any sequel. This is an average film--not to good, not too bad--but I would suggest waiting for it to come out on video. The acting of the apes was good, as well as most of the human characters. After a while, however, it became a little boring seeing people fly through the air over and over again. ** out of ****.

title: Cliche ridden cheeze, please!
text:
bad, bad, bad.Cliche ridden from the start and only momentarily salvaged by the purposefully vague ending. nice job, only two hours too late... Suffers from deep amounts of cheese (Damn them all to hell... pleeze!) with a complete lack of attention to tone. as soon as it started to get going... bam! - I was drowning neck deep in overdone cliches and or cheezy dialog way out of place in regards to the previous scenes tone...
** out of 5

title: Absolute monkeyshines
text: It's hard to believe anyone could sit through this absolute waste of time and believe it is anything resembling a good movie.  In fact, in terms of plot, character development, social commentary and even flat-out action, this remake not only doesn't hold a candle to the original, it isn't even on the same planet.  Having seen the original "Planet of the Apes" recently for the first time in many moons, I was impressed from start-to-finish, but especially impressed by the first five minutes in the spaceship, where Charlton Heston sets up everything that follows with a wonderful speech (into a recorder) about the passage of time on the ship as opposed to Earth and how he hopes it has resulted in a better world and society.  We all know what happens after he crash lands and finally finds the answer to all that has happened to him.  Here, we have Mark Wahlberg, a fine young actor who frankly can't hold a candle to Heston, and a completely meaningless fifteen minute opening in a spaceship that sets up absolutely nothing but cheap shocks and silly explanations some ninety minutes later.Without rehashing the inane plot, I'll just say what I liked about this movie as opposed to what I didn't like:  Helena Bonham Carter's Ari character and absolutely nothing else.  It wasn't funny, it wasn't suspenseful, it wasn't shocking, it wasn't exciting, it wasn't thought-provoking.  It was absolute monkeyshines, in other words.  Even terrific actors like Bonham Carter, Michael Clarke Duncan and Tim Roth couldn't elevate it for me.  None of the new characters could even hold a candle to the original's Cornelius, Zira and Taylor, and even Estella Warren's human "love interest" (who is totally ignored by Wahlberg's character throughout the film) compares unfavorably to Linda Harrison's Nova, which is pathetic considering she was the weakest link in the 1968 cast.  And what was with that totally unfunny slave trader character?  I felt the same way about him as I did Jar Jar Binks.  Put him out of our misery and do it fast!  Also, the film is grungy, dark and depressingly shot, easily one of the ugliest summer films I have ever seen.In short, I think I've made the point that I didn't like this movie.  And I won't even get into the totally bogus, unnecessary and implausible (to say nothing of dopey, incoherant and impossible considering everything else that has happened before it in the story) surprise ending, which appears to have been tacked on and serves as a surprise for no other reason than to supply a cheap shock that only the absolutely gullible will swallow.  Everyone else will feel cheated.  As a matter of fact, that is who this film is for: gullible fools who will swallow anything Hollywood spits out of its computer and be grateful for it.  For everyone else, you have been warned.  (1 out of possible 10)

title: Avoid POTA entirely, go to the zoo...
text: Ok...so, normally when I head out to the movies I have a pretty good idea of what I'm going to get. I made the mistake of expecting something from this, um, 'pseudo-remake' of Planet of the Apes. It looked fantastic (the make-up and costuming was amazing...) and the score was rather intriguing...but the 'acting' was, well, sub-par (to put it nicely). I don't know what was going through Tim Burton's head.At no point during the film did I think that any of the characters (simian or otherwise) were believable. The dialogue (what there was of it, anyway) was appalling. Characters acted rashly for no logical reason, and there didn't seem to be any cause for these actions. The super-intelligent apes treated the humans like dirt...but why? There was no explanation for anything.The worst example of this lack of explanation comes at the end. I won't say what happens (don't want to ruin the 'fun' for everyone), but its absolutely impossible and it really doesn't make sense. Sure, it was jaw-dropping...but only since it was utter nonsense...As opposed to the original, I don't know what Burton's purpose was (other than <chi-ching> $$$). Well, in any case, kudos to Carter, Roth, Duncan and the rest of the apes for going to school and learning to act like an ape. And as for the 'human' cast, maybe they should have gone to a school to learn to act like, well, a human (emotions are an integral part of life)...The bottom line is: if you want to look at a bunch of animals, go to the zoo...oh...and stick to the originals...

title: Well Done!
text: I haven't seen the original Planet of the Apes even though i've been meaning to.I just saw the new version brought out 10 minutes ago and I think it was very well done.  I'm sure some changes are made for the reason, unfortunately i've seen the ending of the original.Mark Wahlberg was pretty believable as an astronaut who lands on a planet inhabited as Apes who rule it.  Tim Roth's character probably ruled the film as an awesome Tim Burton Villain since the Joker with the original Batman.  Nothing alike but still wonderfully played.So far one of the best movies of the summer no doubt.I give it a 7.5/10.

title: Whack to the Max!
text: First off I expected a good movie, similar to the other movies from Tim Burton.  There wasn't much good in this movie that I could see. It starts off with a space ship that has a strange resemblance to the Quake symbol.  The space ship also somehow has gravity even though it doesn't spin or have any explanation as to how gravity is achieved.  The other thing that was kinda weird was that Marky Mark puts on a space helmet right over his t-shirt so if he was actually exposed to space he would die, it didn't even seal.Okay, the movie is okay, the costumes, and masks are great.  But obviously all the budget went to those rather than making a good movie.  It had great potential but just never got to the good level.The time travel isn't explained well enough and the obvious screwy ending is setting the viewer with a to be continued feeling. Suggesting that maybe a sequel will be coming even though most sequels are terrible.  The movie had too much money making stuff in it and not enough Tim Burton.If you want to see this movie I would suggest waiting until the video comes out because I felt like I was always one step ahead of the movie, including the ending.  It was not worth $8!

title: I payed money to see this...
text: This is a terrible film. I have nothing against a good no-brainer action film, but this film is terrible. It's more hole than plot, even before you get to the "twist". The make-up's not bad and generally the effects are passable, but they're nothing special either, and they certainly can't rescue the film from its profound and obvious deficiencies. The performances are atrocious, even from those members of the cast that I know to be capable of much more. The plot is what most sticks in my craw though. Without even dignifying the "twist ending", the rest of the story makes no sense whatsoever either. It's terrible. Just awful.

title: Great movie, if you understand it
text: When I walked out of the theater, I was initially disappointed; I thought it was nothing special, and didn't really understand the ending.  After one day of trying to figure it out, I realized that this new version of POTA is great!  A lot of the people who say it 'sucked', obviously weren't paying attention.  Complaints about the super-strength of the apes, and the exaggerated leaps are wrong.  The apes were GENETICALLY ENHANCED, that's why they EVOLVED and turned into the talking apes that they are.  How else would the apes have revolted against the Oberon crew, unless they had that strength? The ending, although extremely confusing, is good for two reasons: would you REALLY want a cliché ending where Wahlberg goes back to Earth and lives happily ever after, and it causes discussion and deep thought even long after the movie is over; something that is rare in movies today. Roth's performance steals the show, while Wahlberg does an OK job (not like you'd expect him to be spectacular anyways).

title: Not as bad as the reviews
text: Being a fan of the original movie and a Tim Burton fan I was very much looking forward to this movie. Then I read the early reviews coming out of the States and almost didn't go to see it because of the criticism, but I decided to go to make up my own mind.I have to say that I was pleasantly surprised, it was nowhere near as bad as I was expecting. There are a few things that let the plot down and stretch credibility, but then you have to expect that with science fiction movies. Why would they be using monkeys to pilot probes, when even now they have automated ones? Why does the Chimp's pod turn up at that exact minute when it has been missing for thousands of years?? You just have to suspend your dis-belief and go along with the story. If you can do that then you will probably enjoy it. Let's face it, the original doesn't stand up to any degree of scientific analysis either, so why analyse this one?There has been a lot of talk about the endding, to me it made perfect sense, I don't see what all the whining is about. It is obvious that he has gone foward into the future of the same planet, he never went back to Earth. Thade has obviously made a comeback and has lead the apes in a reconquest of the planet, and they have now developed technology (perhaps with the help of the data banks on the ship, now that they know they are there). Simple as that. Why are people getting confused and thinking he went back to earth?? That really would make no sense at all!The only strange thing about the ending, is why oh why didn't he stay with Estella Warren! She wanted him, and he left!! Now that really does stretch credibility!Another interesting thing is that there appear to be several species of apes (Gorillas, Chimps and Orang-Utangs as far as I can tell), and yet they all get along fine and live under the banner 'Ape'. Surely to a Chimp a Gorilla would be as alien as a human! After all humans are a species of ape as well! It seems that this movie is displaying the old human arrogance that there are humans in one catagory, and the whole animal kingdom in the other and that we are the superior. I think it far more likely that each species would hate all the others, just as we see in nature. But that would make the movie far to complicated!

title: Here we go again...
text: My summary above doesn't refer to the recent explosion of re-makes and sequals, etc, but to the recent trend in Hollywood, which can probably be traced back to movies like Jurrassic Park and Independence Day.  I'm not going to go on about the make-up or the behaviour of the apes in this film or the visual style - all these sorts of things, as with the aforementioned movies, are highly comendable.  What concerns me is the lack of narrative, character, or emotion these films have.  While it is worthwhile to exploit new technologies and groundbreaking visuals, film is (or at least should be) a visual way TO TELL A STORY.  Let me repeat that.  TO TELL A STORY. Imagine reading the "Book of the movie" after seeing this film, and see if the story, without all the wham-bang action and spectacular scenery, has any effect.James Cameron spent enourmous effort researching the visual style of the early last century, and both the rise and fall of the Titanic.  Although the story he included was cheesey, high-flying campy romantic fluff, somehow it worked and made (some) sense, and was intertwined with the visuals.  In Apes, all we see are the visuals.  It could have been a silent film for all the dialogue was worth.More specifically, could someone please tell me what the extra human characters were there for - I mean aside from sex appeal (Chanel-5 girl), political correctness (black guy) and who knows what (spoiled brat kid with no name)?And maybe someone who thinks that ending was brilliant could tell me why? Surprise endings only work if they make sense.  Marky could have landed in the Saraha desert and been arrested by camel-riding Santa Clauses and it would have about as much sense.As far as I'm concerned, the original movies (yes, all of them) had focus, good, well defined characters, and more plausabile, interesting, science-fiction content.  And really, the make-up of the new one is better, but is it really leaps and bounds (no pun intended) forward of the job they did in 1968?  I think not.  For those who will contend that the original series' sequals were nothing more than commercially driven,  money-makers capatalizing on the success of the original - well, here we go again, eh?Despite being an avid Tim Burton and Apes fan, I can easily say this is the worst Burton film, and the worst Apes film.As far as the screenwriters are concerned, I only have this to say: "Damn you!  Damn you all to hell!"

title: The whole movie is flawed...
text: WARNING: I will be talking about the ending, and possibly some other events that may "ruin" it for you. Just so you know.Yes, the script was bad, no charater development, useless people (Warren). most of those are talked about in the other reviews.Yes, as I said before the script is pretty bad, but some things can be the actor's fault. Some of mark's (leo davidson) lines were very poorly delivered. In my opinion, marky shouldn't have joined the Funky Bunch, and he should have gone to acting school (or a better one if he already has). Besides him, everyone one's acting was pretty good, but some of Duncan's deliveries were also poor.Yes, I liked this movie, but I did like the original better. It seemed that everything that was wrong with the original, was good in this one, what was bad in the new one, was good in the old one. Was Burton trying to make it better, and just missed the things that were good, concentrating only on the bad parts?Yes, the ending was bad. When Marky (leo) landed on earth (it wasn't the same planet, the solar system is our own, and it is earth when they show the large picture). He lands on the steps, and sees that the memorial now has Thade's head on it. The cops pull up, apes jump out, in full cop clothing, they pull guns on Leo. About this time I put my head in my hands, and just lost it. I laughed for a couple minutes, because of how rediculous it was. Hoping, that there was more, but no. Sure to be more if and when there is a sequal. Will it be a reimagining of the second original (lets hope not)?Yes, many people have tried to explain the ending. This specifically mentioned before in the movie contradict those theories. I have my own, which, fits EVERY thing mentioned in the move. It's not a realistic ending, but it FITS with EVERYTHING.

title: Arrrgh!
text: This movie is awful! awful! awful!  I was bored during the opening credits and it never got any better.  Like most other Tim Burton movies it is long on Nifty Costumes and short on trivialities like plot, dialog, pacing, character development, and general depth.  The alleged spoofiness is too uncommitted to raise even a wan, jaded smile, and the socio-political commentary was copied off the back of a cereal box.  I must congratulate the other Users on this site for concentrating on this movie hard enough to articulately explain some of the myriad reasons why it is so awful; my own mind simply rejected it wholesale.  Blech.  Urgh.

title: Quite entertaining though not in the same class as original
text: Entertaining in a modern dumb action film way.  Don't expect to have to think too hard.Now the reason I actually registered is the end of the film. The trendy twist that they tacked onto the end of this film actually took quite a few marks off of the score I gave this film. The end makes no sense at all in the context of the film and can not be explained by any of the internal rules as set out within the film. I would love to see an explanation of the end produced by the writer as I am convinced they would have no explanation.

title: Every character under-developed
text: There was virtually no character development.  Especially with some of their actions you really need that to get anything out of the story.  The ending meant nothing to the story, only to set up a sequel.  Nothing in the movie will make you think on any profound level.  I left the theater thinking it was an OK movie, but for no real reason.

title: Not Tim Burton's Best, Certainly Not His Worst...
text:
This film will always be much debated amongst Tim Burton fans. The original idea of the movie was not to re-make the classic film, but to "re-imagine" it. At first, this seemed like a brilliant idea. Who better to direct a new version of Planet of the Apes than the odd yet brilliant Tim Burton?Well, great ideas often do not lead to great finished products.And that is what this film really is. It is not a great movie. It is an average, sometimes funny(especially Paul Giamatti), sometimes thrilling(battle sequences are amazing) film. But as a whole? Average.
The problems with the movie all come from the fact that Burton did not know exactly how he wanted to re-imagine the movie. Should it be a serious, sci-fi version? The last 20 minutes seem to point in this direction. Should it be a "spoofesque" movie that doesn't take itself too seriously? The entire middle section of this movie seems to point in this direction.In the end, this film is confused and awkward. Tim Burton wants you to like this movie, it's clear the entire time. Unfortunately, the acting is strained and the movie too muddled to ever develop into a classic.I am suggesting that this movie is worth renting or going to the theater, but it's not worth owning(unless you are a huge Burton fan). This movie is better than Mars Attacks and Sleepy Hollow, but it does not even approach Batman or Edward Scissorhands.I give this movie ** out of **** stars. Add one star if you are a dedicated Tim Burton fan.

title: Weak story clings to spectacular visuals
text:
Visually, this film is what you might expect from the man who created Batman and Edward Scissorhands.  The attention to scenery and detailed makeup and costumes were wonderfully crafted and grabbed the viewer's attention from the beginning.  So now you've gotten used to the ape planet, what's next? The story and characters.  That's what this film seemed to lack.
The original Planet of the Apes had the advantage of a brand new idea (to anyone who hadn't read the book) to enthrall the audience.  The story was new and the characters had feelings and interactions that fit well with the effects.The 2001 version, unfortunately, had Mark Wahlberg playing an unfeeling robot of a character.  From the moment he lands on this mind-blowing planet, he never deviated from his primary motivation.  Granted, this is a necessary element for all scripts, but usually the motivation is complimented with other story elements and characters along the way.Wahlberg's character never takes notice of any other character or for that matter, any event that is taking place around him.  This becomes frustrating for the viewer as a story is desperately trying to reveal itself but is constantly stunted by the main character.As for the ending, well, it's a thinker.  I'll be interested to see if the sequel will acknowledge more than one perspective or dimension to the story. (6.5/10)

title: FANTASTIC
text: this film was absolutely brilliant Tim burton is by far my best director.what i liked about this film was it had action,comedy (little bit),a great villain and a good story but like everyone else i didnt quite understand the ending but i have been told the reason it was left that way was because they are making a sequel witch will explain what happened.... hopefully, but that was the only bad thing about the film. I havent seen the original so i cant compare the two. so i would give this film 9 and a half out of 10

title: Planet of the Lip Gloss
text: First of all, I would like to say I liked the film... in spite of all the problems I had with it.The ape make-up rocked!  If not for Ari's (Helen Bonham Carter) "too human" make-up, it wouldn't take you too long to forget that they were actors only made up to look like apes.  Tim Roth WAS Thade! Both Tim Roth as General Thade and Paul Giamatti as Limbo deserve a nod come Oscar time. Unfortunately the majority of the cast looked as though they were phoning it in.In a couple of scenes you could see that Estella Warren was wearing heavy lip gloss but this could be a cinematography problem as in another scene it appeared as Mark Wahlberg was also wearing lip gloss.As for the story, it is one that a non sci-fi fan would assume was "good" science fiction, however it wasn't.  The plot had holes the size of Texas and there was no sign that anyone had tried to fill them.  The original movie ended with a "Gosh WOW!" and this one ended with a "what the f..., HUH?"  I can still remember coming out of the theatre after seeing the orginal for the first time with a sense of wonder.  Of course that was back in a time when the thought of the human race nuking itself to oblivion wasn't that big a stretch.  I was thinking about the ending of that film for weeks, I doubt I'll be thinking about the ending of this one tomorrow.  One good thing to say about the ending is that it more closely echos the ending the book "Monkey Planet" by Pierre Boulle than the original film did.Having said all these nasty things, there is still much to enjoy about this film.  The direction was very good and the score was delightful.  The music over the opening credits was very much an homage to Jerry Goldsmith's original score.One can only hope that the inevitable sequel can shed some light on the confusing ending.

title: Tim Burton does it again!
text: 'Planet of the Apes' is yet another example of Tim Burton´s excellent director skills. When Burton gives us a movie we can be sure not to get another Hollywood show of their big special effects. Instead we get a movie where the superb effects are just minor details that support the story´s substance.Burton´s "remake" of 'Planet of the Apes' is as surprising as the first because the story is different. Yet the themes are the same: racism and equality being the most important. Another theme in the movie is the complexity of time travel that Burton deals with in the same way as e.g. ex-Python Terry Gilliam did in '12 Monkeys'.The apes are outstanding e.g. because of their walk and their interactions in general. Another thing I truly love about this movie is that the music score has been kept in the same stile as the score in the original Planet of the Apes.All in all an exceptional movie that is a must.

title: Sky Messiahs and Conqueror Apes
text: This is a movie weighted with the planet-sized immensity of the original series of Ape films, which I grew up on. All part of an education in a time, the '70s, where men could be reflected in evolved apes, their penchant for cruelty and misunderstanding, horror and revolt, subjugation, was still poignant. In Tim Burton's film, there's no deeper meaning to the situation, not many today under the age of thirty and living in America have any true idea of the danger of being human, of being the superior creature on the planet, whose drive for self-destruction might just give birth to a new world order, run by man's genetic ancestor, the ape.Tim Burton doesn't concern himself with reflecting the human race. He just sets out, along with Tim Roth and Helena Carter, to show just how awesome an intelligent, weapons-using, armored gorilla is. Also, there's an entire Ape psychology to go along with the advancements, the 'human' qualities. Apes explode in frenzies of blurred animal movment when startled, they smell at one another to perceive lies or fear, they use touch as a constant reminder of their closeness, just as they did when they didn't use tongues or swords as weapons.So for your money, you get a bunch of stiff, annoying 'humans', all of whom speak perfect English (a plotless point, since in the original film humans were animals, speechless--here, despite being subjugated for thousands of years, humans talk but don't say anything at all, no different than they do today, when the fact is these humans living as squalid jungle rats  should have devolved over time to about idiot level, about the same as your average high schooler, say) and its obvious that Burton could give a hoot about any of the human characters outside the hero Davison, an astronaut who falls from the sky and becomes a messiah. All the rest of the humans squeak protest and get crushed by Apes. And good riddance, because it's the Apes that the movie is about. How cool is it to be able to jump twelve feet in the air, use your feet as hands, and be stronger than three or four big strong men, with the fighting ferocity of a primal beast? That's why Burton made this flick.Tim Roth also gives probably his best performance, as zealous military commander Thade trying to hide the truth of the Ape Planet's origin. Helena Carter's Ari simply is the sexiest woman with facial hair and chimp hands you will ever see. And there is the fantastic ending.For me, the ending 'shock' works like I wouldn't have thought it would. Fact is, the story behind the ending, the implications, the actual love and appreciation shown for Rod Serling's 1968 script, is what makes it work. And sequels can be made, just like in the 70s, because it is the APES' story, just like it always was. If I'd seen this movie when I was a kid, I'd be loping on all fours like a charging gorilla or jumping out of trees and off furniture for weeks, all while emulating Thade's savage up-from-under glare. What Burton does is make me remember how great I thought Cornelius and Dr. Zeus was when I was an ankle-biter. Apes ruled then, and they rule now.

title: Disappointed, insulted and fed up
text:
What more can be said about the new Planet of the Apes (POTA)?  Truly, this so-called summer blockbuster insults moviegoers with its trite storyline, excessive and inappropriate violence, monochromatic acting, inaccurate, contradictory and illogical sequences, implausibility, lackluster performances, and poor direction.  To call this a remake of the original 1968 version is tantamount to pouring ketchup on a gourmet meal.  The makers of the original POTA and the author of the original book must be gnashing their teeth in absolute outrage.  What is wrong with this puppy?  Let me present a few examples:· In the beginning sequences, what four-star general would ever tolerate such insubordinate language from a mere captain?  Or for that matter, what general would speak so contemptuously to his star crewmember?· What rational human being and ostensibly highly trained military officer would flagrantly disobey his general and subject himself to such an absurd physical risk to reclaim his monkey?· If the apes used the humans as a valuable resource such as servants, why would they treat them so abusively defies all reason.  To use humans to pull the cages of other humans is a waste of valuable resources, when they could have just as easily used horses that would have accomplished the task far more efficiently.· The original POTA had various elements of their society that were sensitive and intelligent.  Why make them all appear to be such a raving band of lunatics, particularly their leader?· Does this Mark Wahlberg have any emotion at all?  Clearly, he could have emailed his performance in rather than waste our time and money to watch him go through his ridiculous antics.· When in the initial scenes the humans are escaping from their cages, does it make sense for them to dash through bedroom after bedroom rather than simply flee the premises?  Clearly, the scenes are a poorly contrived vehicle to bring some humor into this dismal display of MTV chaos that no doubt stimulates the average junior high school student to gape in wonder and awe.· Why in the world would the leader of this unruly zoo seek to destroy all the humans?  There are no electronical or other mechanical assets to assist them in their daily living.  It seems they would simply be destroying their own major assets.· If the original ancestors of the apes were these chimpanzees contained in the spaceship's cages, where did the gorillas and the orangutans come from?· If as Mark Wahlberg states in the spaceship that the nuclear power of the ship lasts for thousands of years, why is it that it is only good for one thrust to knock out the ape's attack?  If that was indeed a blast from the ship's engines, it would surely have fried all the chimps to a crisp, not merely knock them out so they could regain consciousness all at once to resume the attack.· This story has been used so many times and in so many forms that it defies all descriptions of triteness and predictability.  I cannot imagine any writer worth his salt turning out such dribble unless severely brain-damaged, high on drugs or alcohol, or simply senile.  I further question the inaction of the director Tim Burton when presented with such nonsense.  Does he believe all audiences are retarded?  Perhaps so.
In any event, I've spent far too much of my valuable time with this poor excuse for entertainment.  If Hollywood continues to turn out such poor excuses for amusement, we are doomed as the world leader in the entertainment industry

title: Apes being apes.
text: I liked this, though it's NOT better than the first, it certainly has it's good points. They are:*Great makeup. Rick Baker is tops.*Decent acting-though Roth is overkill, I liked Carter, 'Bear' from Armageddon, Bart Giamatti's kid and even MarkyMark. He has a decent Mr Bland everyman about him that kinda works. *F/X are good.*Sets range from impressive(try to tell which desert scenes were shot in Arizona, then Australia, Utah, etc), to YUCK(some of the interiors were right outta the Flintstones) to OK(the ship).*The 'Twilight Zone' ending doesn't make sense unless you keep it in a Twilight Zonish other world. Otherwise it's goofygloo time.*I liked the chimp.*Battle scenes meant to be impressive were a Little ludicrous at times-oh no another wave of Big Monkeys is chimping over the rise at me! But I liked it anyways.*Burton I usually dislike but here, as in 'Sleepy Hollow', he pretty much played it straight and delivers another mainstream hit. Good deal.**1/2 outta ****, a few things to jump up and down about. Don't go ape but do see it.

title: MAKING APES OF US ALL
text: *SIGH* Once again another sci-fi remake with big budget effects and a dull and pointless story line that is light -years behind the original 1968 film. The Rod Serling screenplay in the 1968 version was such a witty and insightful parody I can still remember the scenes and dialogue today. There is NOTHING memorable about the remake.
