This movie was doomed from the start because the surprise twist ending in the 1968 version could never be redone. So instead the film makers pathetically come up with their own surprise ending that is a stupefying non sequitur. What a waste of celluloid and ape makeup. The move made monkeys of everyone!

title: ...and the kitchen sink
text:
I've just watched this film on DVD. You know the one. Two DVD's worth which seems to incorporate every thing including the colour of the kitchen sink they used. Isn't it scary that this shows that they seemed to have taken everything into account except the script?I followed this reworking' up the point where the Space introduction ended and we ended up on The Planet of the Apes' and it was about here I realised how poor the film was.As a basic example; in the original, at least it had the sense to say that the reason society had evolved  the way it had was because the humans were at the Stone Age level where they hadn't even developed the capacity of speech. As a result the apes had evolved faster than them and were able to dominate them. This reworking didn't even bother to do that. I don't think I'm being too pedantic by saying, if the humans could speak why were they still wandering around like caveman? It seems such a fundamental flaw to the plot, I felt it rather insulting to my intelligence.Then again, so many things seem to suggest that the script was written by a bunch of precocious High School students. As someone else has pointed out in these reviews; it's full of quotes from the original  - including the famous `Damn them all to Hell!'  which have absolutely no relevance to the current movie. You can almost see the writers of this thing sniggering behind their hands saying `I know, wouldn't it be cool if we put this line in!'
The DVD shows they spent months on getting the make-up right, the movements of the apes right, etc. etcwe even had a very boring documentary about how much effort Danny Elfman put into writing this score, but who was looking at the story? Were the people behind this movie too frightened to say to Tim Burton because he's such a `visionary genius' that the film didn't make any sense?I dunno, what does it matter? This film was a commercial success so it must be good. The only small mercy I can think of is that that, once upon a time, Tim Burton seemed the obvious choice to visualise `Lord of the Rings'. After seeing this movie, thank goodness he didn't.

title: The planet or the movie?
text: Oh dear! This is the kind of venture that gives Hollywood a bad name.Talented people making a total dud of a movie. The original POTA was a great adventure movie with an interesting Sci-Fi premise. This version, however,is bleak, violent and muddled.The plot holds little of interest and many of the scenes are in darkness and simply unpleasant in tone. Mark Wahlberg must be the least charismatic leading-man of his generation and he annoys throughout.Danny Elfman's score is loud ,intrusive and headache-inducing. The ending is a bit of a mystery and countless geeks have speculated endlessly on this. However, by the time the ending came I didn't really care about this movie and its characters. Remakes can be done well but their very existence and the number of them indicate the lack of ideas in Hollywood.

title: Eh, Oh Dear!
text: For me this has to be one of the most disappointing re-makes (or should I say re-imaginings I have ever seen. Why? well lets just start off by saying that Mark Wahlberg was a wrong choice for the lead as many would probably agree, with the acting somewhat blah.It just didn't do it for me. Sorry but I'm sure Tim Burton could've done better as the movie as it's somewhat forgetful after watching.I'm just glad I didn't add this one to my DVD collection. Huge elaborate and big budget, please it's starting to become annoying seeing so many Hollywood remakes becoming a thing of the past. . For me anyway.Not impressed.

title: Give it a break!
text: Ya' know movie critics are bad enough; but "wanna be" movie critics are the worst! This is a great fun movie about monkeys, excuse me "apes".  You can't deny the special effects are great. I enjoyed it. I don't know what these other reviewers were expecting. I don't think any of the actors expected to get awards for acting like monkeys, nor took on the role for the acting "stretch".  I assume they wanted to play the roles because it was fun or that they liked the original.  And you know what "it is not the original"... it is a different movie.  I get so sick of people comparing remakes.  You can't make them identical and why on earth would you want to?  Get a life and find some good things in the things you do and don't be so critical. Judge this movie on what it is not on what you think it should be.  I think this movie is worth seeing and I think the ending is a great addition.  So what if it leaves the franchise open to a sequel? That's why our film community is called an industry.  I appreciate Mr. Burton giving me the opportunity to think a little bit more about the movie rather than handing the ending over to me.Go ahead and give this movie a try...

title: Common Sense
text: I saw the film on opening day with hopes for air conditioned diversion, I got exactly that.  I am going to see the film again today with my father so I decided to check the showtimes and noticed that there were something like 520 reviews and checked some out.  You people are really moronic.  Anyone who was disappointed by this film did not use common sense.  Do you really think a movie this big, with this kind of budget, this kind of A-list director and this kind of cast was really going to satisfy you when it comes to plot and character development?  There has not been a hollywood movie out in years that has satisfied my intellectual yearnings, I have stopped seeking this kind of satisfaction in a hollywood film because it is Sisyphean.  This film did exactly what I expected it to do, it kept my attention for a full two hours.  Anybody who wanted to have the social commentary of the first movie, the melo-dramatic over-acting of the first movie, the garish orange costumes and the justified willful suspension of disbelief that the first film supplied you with you should have rented the first movie and stayed home.Anyone who enjoys Tim Burton's beautiful productions and just wants to sit in an air conditioned theatre for two hours without expectations should see this film, maybe even twice if your father missed it when you went with your girlfriend the first time.  And for the jackasses who keep trying to fault the film on its technical "inaccuracies" and anachronous plot holes: shut up and sit down!  It is popcorn fare for popcorn people.  You want to discuss technical boo boos, go to StarTrek.comI'm sorry I have to be so harsh with you but you have to learn somewhere along the line that Hollywood will not satisfy you anymore.

title: Planet of the Offensive Stereotypes
text: What a confused and pointless piece of junk.  OK, so the costumes were well-done.  And Helena Bonham Carter and Tim Roth do adequate jobs representing the oversilly, stereotyped liberal ape-fascist ape dualism. But this rushed, ridiculously overviolent mess looks like it was churned out in about one month a/la last year's sci-fi classics "Mission to Mars" and "Red Planet."  And, here's my question to the makers of this flick:  Why is every "ape" in Planet of the Apes 2001 stereotyped in the most offensive colonial worldview way?  Examples:  The violent, military apes are all like African "savages."  The sly, merchant ape is like a Jewish Shylock from Shakespeare's Merchant of Venice.  The wise, senator ape is like a royal European Anglo (above the dominant military savage apes).  The metaphysical/religious apes in the street are like turn-of-the-century W.D. Griffith stereotyped morphine-smoking Chinese-Americans with fu-manchu beards and long straight hair.  And, in an annoying modern twist, the adolescent apes are like miniature Fred Dursts, backwards hats and all anti-"adult" attitude.  Oh, and let's not forget the human stereotypes: Mark "I always play the same part" Wahlberg as macho space "captain," Estella Warren as the full-lipped Barbie Doll sex object, and faceless adolescent boy playing the "I want to prove I am a man by fighting in a war" part so steretypically.  Hey, if this is the way the book was written, fine.  But you know what?  I don't think anyone should consider this type of overly simplistic stereotyped character manipulation as "entertainment" anymore. Hollywood, William Broyles Jr., and Tim Burton:  Have you no clue that these stereotypes are an ugly waste of everyone's time?  But, I know, this is just "entertainment."  As long as it's "entertainment", that's OK.  What else? This movie has absolutely no plot or character development whatsoever.  It is like a series of quick scene ideas spliced together very haphazardly. There is little chance to get to know or empathize with anyone in the film. Most of the human characters are so character-less that their actions seem unbelievable.  And what of the setting?  Very, very strange.  Yes, it's got that dark, Burton touch, but it almost doesn't make sense in this film. There's something too small, almost stagelike about the setting of this film that goes against the expansiveness of its theme.  This is supposed to be about someone traveling millions of miles from earth and it feels like they've gone about twenty feet.  And there's no real sense of an "ape world" on this planet; it's like they all live in a little box (and there's only like one hundred of them there).  And what was with that scene when the humans were escaping and they kept running through all of the apes' houses? It was like something out of The Three Stooges or Abbot and Costello. Finally, in relationship to this last "funny" scene, there's the inconsistency in the approach to this film.  Is it supposed to be campy or is it supposed to be serious?  It just doesn't know.  You could have heard a pin drop in the theater (which was quite full) when I saw this and the apes muttered "funny" lines such as, "Get your damn dirty hands off me you stinking human" and "Can't we all just get along?"  Uh, what?  I'm sorry, Tim Roth, but I simply don't get this film.  I think it stinks in every way possible.

title: Planet of the Grapes (Sanitized version)
text:
When I took my son to see this, I tried to set my expectations real low, as I had read the reviews. The visual eye-candy is 100% brilliant, and it's not a disagreeable way of passing 2 hours, so what's wrong? Unlike the original film, the humans haven't regressed mentally, in fact they seem quite cultivated. The film contains no real challenges, no warning of ecological disasters. This film is just a "product" there is no religion, no politics, no racial problems. In fact humans and apes can get along just dandy, just with a twist of the director's pen.
This is the Planet of the Apes series "Phantom Menace". Tim Burton: remember the anguish we all felt in the original film when we saw all human history reduced to the head of the statue of liberty poking from the sands... THAT WAS CINEMA!!!

title: No social elements needed when loving special effects
text: Just like the other comment states, the movie lacks every kind of characterisation and social statement.In fact, the main characters is in fact seeing how the humans are treated by the apes, thus the apes being treated by humans in our life, and still he doesn't even come close to thinking: aren't we humans doing something wrong in our world?No, he keeps on stating: in our world, the monkeys (and all animals) belong in cages.It is a pitty that the director did not go into this more deeply.It is like watching Animal Farm, but without words, thus being interested only for children.Did I like the movie however? Yes very much ! The special effects are superb, the monkeys are very scaring, Thade is brilliantly casted and acts like he truly is an Ape's general.Really nice when watched in a big cinema with a big screen and great Dolby surround sound!I liked it very much, although it could be a historic movie.Too bad.

title: It looks great, but...
text: Let's get real here.  The remake is fine for today's audience. But I must stress this point. Tim Burton did a fine job visually, but there can be no comparison between the '01 Apes and the '68 version.Dramatically speaking, scene for scene, these newcomers to the Apes myth have dropped the ball. Where are the scenes with "Leo" confronting the Ape Senate? Wondering, along with us as an audience how this "Ape" world could have come to fruition? Those narrative points are sorely missing here-- so Leo becomes a most passive hero. Do we care for him? Do we follow his point of view with much fervor? Not much. But we dig the visuals, and we don't like Thade too much, so we go along with it. Ari is a breeze of fresh air, for sure. But they dropped the ball when it comes to nailing the apes v. human conflict at the climax. I'll take Taylor with his rifle holding Dr. Zais hostage any day.Am I nuts? Where's the drama in this new version? What are the stakes involved? What happened to Cornelius holding the doll that mutters "mama""? I love Danny Elfman, too. But, for God's sake, give me a little Goldsmith to ground me on this one.

title: And the winner is....
text: Tim Roth, for being the only decent performance in this whole mishmosh. Mark Wahlberg, for yet another uninspired characterization and yet another rung down on his descent from dubious stardom in that stupid porn piece of garbage Boogie Nights...next stop, sitcom guest appearances? Estella Warren, for Best Breasts in a talking monkey movie Paul Giamatti, for his convincing portrayal of Paul Giamatti in a rubber mask. Tim Burton, for his biggest fan disappointment since that overpriced book about the Oyster Boy or whatever that piece of crap was.  Please Tim! Even a sequel to Franken-Weenie would have been better. 'Nuff said.

title: Good Housekeeping Seal for brainless summer fare
text:
Short on substance and long on flashy peripheralia (ie, costumes, art direction, FX) -- which is my typical lament of the past ten years of film history. Mind you, it's NOT A TOTAL WASTE OF TIME, but Marky Mark, er Mark Wahlberg, can't carry the film. Estella Warren needs a few more pounds of collagen in her lips, and Kris Kristofferson's role was a throwaway. On the plus side, the humorous Paul Giamatti got a lotta laughs, and Tim Roth was thoroughly despicable and frightening.Some of Marky's weakness is due to the script changes... the humans can talk. Ok, so then what makes Wahlberg so special to the apes? They don't even comment on his spacesuit. Talking humans is a serious stray from the crux of the Swiftian novel by Pierre Boulle, with its Gulliver's Travels -like reversal of species. Meanwhile the second half of the flick degenerates into a long chase and so-called-epic-sized battle, neither handled well. While the film surpasses the original in costumes and FX, it owes everything to its 1968 precedent. ie, the introduction and exposition of the apes moves much quicker because of our familiarity of the original.
The apes themselves are superior to the original in make-up and movement and cultural detail. The ape city is more impressive. But while the specifics of the FX are more impressive than the first, they are nevertheless over-the-top. Even the Foley artists-- every step, every wrinkle of fabric, every thump of the chest is horribly amplified (maybe it was just the damn multiplex whose volume levels were through the roof). In regards to the FX-ridden films of recent years, I was reminded of Laurence Olivier's remark about make-up (which doesn't apply to this film's make-up; it does apply to FX and film-making in general): exagerrate only one detail of a character (the long nose of Richard III, for ex.), otherwise the whole face becomes a meaningless mass of putty -- the performance becomes marred, not enhanced. The same rule applies to FX. Director Burton and most of our FX-crazy film-makers would do well to quit poring over every little technical doo-dad and spend more time on dialogue and plot.Oh, and I can't stand physics-defying FX ... apes that leap 20 feet in the air... apes that aren't vaporized by a horrendous rocket blast but are merely stunned for a few seconds... apes that punch a man so hard he flies 15 feet off the ground (when such a force would decapitate him)... men who survive being knocked 15 feet off the ground and arise to get knocked 15 feet off the ground a second, third, and fourth time (this isn't the mark of the character's heroism; it's the mark of a director's sadism. If he's not sadistic, then he's immaturely fixated on the visuals of slinging a body through space.) The opening segment provides a more plausible explanation, if you demand some kind of logical time-anomaly reason which the first version lacked. But then the time paradox in the closing really falls flat. It seems tacked on for the sake of an obligatory Time-Paradox twist.  And for the obligatory sequel.

title: I am wowed again and again by such a reverent remake.
text: Tim Burton never ceases to amaze me.He had me from "Pee-Wee's Big Adventure", kept me in awe through "Beetlejuice", "Batman", "Edward Scissorhands", and "Nightmare Before Christmas" and has not slown down since.Burton has a way of turning an ordinary story, perhaps even one you've seen before, into a work of art.  He turned the campy original series "Batman" into a dark, seething masterpiece of a film.  He transformed his own "Nightmare" into a moral tale that kids and adults could both appreciate.And now he has remade "Planet of the Apes" with reverence and technical prowess.From the get-go, this film has you hooked with its brooding atmosphere and careful storytelling.  The plot is carefully laid out from the beginning, and even though you might begin to think you know what's going to happen, you are constantly surprised.I found my jaw hanging open throughout the whole sequence where the hero (played by Mark Wahlberg) crash lands on the planet.  The effect was so well done it was hard to imagine it being anything but totally real.In classic fashion, the heroic characters are super-good, though not without their flaws, and the villainous characters are supremely evil.  The roles are reversed in this film, with the apes being the masters and the humans being the ones who are caged and kept as pets.  By the way, monkeys don't make very nice masters.  Which reminds me, the addition of a young monkey girl keeping a small blonde-haired waif as a pet was a classic Burton touch.I don't feel like I can talk too much about the plot without giving it all away.  From the first moment of the film to the surprise ending, it's a non-stop roller coaster ride of a movie, and might possibly now be one of my top five films of all time.  It's a masterful work of art.  Tim Burton surely has his place in history now as one of the greatest directors of all time.I have not read any reviews of "Planet of the Apes" before writing this review, as I did not want them to taint my feelings about the film.  Even if the critics pan this movie, though, there is no way my feelings will change. I am in awe.Finally, I cannot end this review without a nod to Danny Elfman, my favorite singer/songwriter/composer of all time and a frequent Tim Burton collaborator.  Elfman's music in this film is quite different than his usual style, but at the same time fits right in with the theme and darkness of it. The beginning of the film is like "Batman", with a close-up shot through the credits while the music builds up an-almost frightening momentum until the movie actually begins.See it.  You won't regret it.

title: Great retelling of a classic story
text: When Pierre Boulle wrote the original book "The Monkey Planet", he was mostly known for the classic story "Bridge Over The River Kwai".When it was made into a movie in 1968, Charlton Heston ingrained this movie permanently in our minds.  He was also a driving force in the creation of the original, having read the original book and helping to bring it to the attention of the money men in Hollywood and carrying it from original concept to final completion.In fact, the original movie is such a classic, it spawned 4 sequals and 2 TV series (1 live action and one animated).  It's influence was so wide, that when "Welcome Back Kotter" premiered on TV, the character Arnold Horshack carried a POTA lunchbox wherever he went.This new version in many ways is both closer to the original book, and also deviates much more.The effects and makeup in this version are spectacular.  Much as the original revolutionized makeup for decades to come, this one will also show it's influence for a long time.  Rather then use computer graphics to create the apes, the use of makeup and appliances is spectacular.Tim Burton did a fantastic job on this movie.  And of course, what is a Tim Burton movie without Danny Elfman doing the musical score.  Combined, they have made a movie that is sure to be a classic for years to come.One of the biggest differences is that the classes of ape are not as seperated as they were in the original.In the original, Chimps all wore green and were scientists.  Gorillas wore black and were military, and Orangutangs wore orange and were clergy/politicians.  In this they are more diverse, and there even seems to be hints of cross-species breeding.  This makes for a much more diverse history, and more potential for both conflict and support.Also, the humans in this version are able to talk, but they strive to hide that fact from the apes.  And as the humans are more human then in the original, the apes are more ape like.  They frequently jump around and climb on things, write with their feet, touch and groom each other, and in general are more like evolved apes should be.The cast is excellent, with both Michael Clarke Duncan and Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa playing excellent roles.  Michael Clarke Duncan is one of the best new actors in the business today, and this role is as far as possible from The Green Mile.Tim Burton added several subtle and not so subtle pokes and images from both the original and contemporary society into the movie.  From Charlton uttering his classic "Damn them all to hell" again, to an Orangutang saying the Rodney King line "Can't we all just get along", to having another orangutang rub himself with flower petals while upside down, very reminiscant to "American Beauty".Of course, the most memorable part of the original movie is the ending. The image of Charlton Heston looking at the wreckage of the Statue Of Liberty is forever burned into our minds.  In much the same way, this ending will also be burned into our minds.  And in many ways, the ending this time is much closer to the original ending as written by Pierre Boulle.I am curious to how they will do a sequal to this movie.  In today's market, everything from American Pie to Wayne's World have sequals.  And this is really the first time that a movie spawned a series of sequals (the 007 movies do not count, since they do not sequal in any order, and were based on a series of books).  So it will be interesting to see if this movie spawns a similar series of sequals.If you loved the original movie, you have to see this one.In addition to Charlton Heston, look for a cameo by Linda Harrison, the actress that played Nova in the original movies.

title: Not the original...Thank goodness!
text: Let me preface this by saying that I am a huge Tim Burton fan. He could direct a remake of Ernest Saves Christmas starring Pauly Shore as Ernest, and I'd probably like it. Well, maybe not with Pauly Shore.Having said that, let me just say that I loved Planet of the Apes, but here's the catch...DO NOT go into it thinking about the original. Forget everything you know about Planet of the Apes starring Charlton Heston, and think of this as a brand new concept, and I'm pretty sure you will love this movie as much as I did.I mean, think about it. Burton directed "Sleepy Hollow" which really didn't follow the original story, but can you honestly tell me that "Sleepy Hollow" was a bad movie?The original "Planet" is a classic. I am so glad that Burton didn't do a shot for shot remake of it, like that horrible "Psycho" remake a few years ago.By the way, the Heston cameo will go down in history as one of the finest cameos ever. Ranking right up there with his cameo in "Wayne's World 2".Like I said in the summary, this "Planet" is not the original, and thank goodness for that. It's a brand new movie with brand new apes, and brand new humans. Burton you continue to amaze me!

title: Better than expected
text:
I've never been a fan of any of the "Planet Of the Apes" movies. But yesturday changed that.  This recent version of "Planet Of The Apes" is brilliant, I was shocked by how engrossed I was while watching this movie, it's simply unmissable.Forget what the critics say about this movie, Tim Burton, (Sleepy Hollow, Batman) has once again gave the audience something to be amazed by. 
9/10

title: Bad film BAD! BAD! Film.
text: Wow, this movie is really bad.  It is mediocre in almost every way.  The actors sound terrible trying to deliver dialogue through those ape masks and the racial overtones are insulting.  Not wildly insulting, just a bit lame. Yea... I would describe this movie as really lame.

title: Apes v's Humans-"Rule the Acting"
text: The original Planet of the Apes was an epic of sorts, the remake, or re-imagining' as director Tim Burton prefers to refer to his film as, is slightly different, it strives for a more simple action film, which is not necessarily a bad thing as it proves to be a, linear, but nonetheless entertaining hour and half or so of film.The standard of acting varies considerably, on the whole the ape characters are acted superbly, most notably Tim Roth as the evil General Thade. Helena Bonham Carter is also good in her role as human rights activist Ari. The greatly underrated Paul Giamatti provides a little comic relief as Limbo and Michael Clarke Duncan, who played the giant John Coffey in `The Green Mile', is well suited in his role of Colonel Attar, a giant silver back gorilla. Sadly the human characters are far from as interesting, not to say that the acting on a whole is bad, just a little wooden at times. However Mark Wahlberg is a worthy successor to Charlton Heston (who has a little cameo as Thade's father). Sadly the weakest part of the film is Estella Warren, who plays Daena, it is quite clear that she is in this film for one reason only, and that's not her acting ability.The ape make-up, done by Rick Baker, of `Star Wars' fame is absolutely amazing. Several different species of ape are recreated with exceptional realism, and when compared to the original it is clear how far special effects make-up has come.The ending is a bit predictable, a little ill conceived and on the whole a rather confusing affair, you really need to see it to understand why, it is clear that Burton was aiming for a twist worthy of the original, this is where he falls short as his ending is a little messy, although it does leave it open for a possible sequel, so watch this space.On a closing note, it is quite sad to see that the twisted genius that is Tim Burton, the man who brought us Beetlejuice, Batman, Edward Scissorhands, Ed Wood and Sleepy Hollow, has apparently been manipulated by Hollywood into making a film for the mass market, hence the 12 certificate, to increase merchandise possibilities. It still has all the visual expertise of Burton but lacks the darkness associated with most of his films. However `Planet of the Apes' is still a highly enjoyable film, if not as memorable as the original. So I highly recommend it to anyone who likes their films with plenty of action, great special effects, and full of apes.

title: It was awesome!!!!!!!!!!
text: Hey everyone i just wanted to comment on "Planet of the Apes" i think it was a great movie and they picked a real good person to play "Leo Davidson" (Mark Wahlberg)...i think that Mark Wahlberg is such a great actor because he can be so many characters..and make it look good...and for all the apes such as Helena Bonham Carter, and Michael Clarke Duncan were so good and so well trained to be apes and monkeys...i think that the new "Planet of the Apes" was well made (fixed up) it is much more realistic and the director Tim Burton and all the makeup artist couldn't have done better...i have heard from Mark Wahlberg that there is going to be a part 2 or second one and i can't wait until that comes out because the first one was awesome!!

title: Disappointing
text: I admit that I've only seen the original for the first time this month (though I'd seen a making-of-the-series show and thus was aware of the basics), and I acknowledge that this new version is only supposed to be inspired BY the original -- not a faithful adaptation.  Therefore I was prepared to accept the new movie on its own merits.Even so, I walked out of the theater scratching my head and wondering why they'd bothered doing it at all.Yes, I love Tim Burton.  Yes, the costumes, make-up, and sets are amazing. Yes, it was fun, had some good lines, and featured some marvelous acting on the part of Helena Bonham Carter, who was remarkably believable in her chimpanzee-inspired mannerisms and movements.Other than that...so what?Without spoiling too much of either movie, I have to say that the message of the original was far more intelligent.  It really made you stop and think: who's right, who's wrong, do we have any right to judge the apes or should we learn lessons about our own failings in theirs?  This one was merely simplistic summer-movie fare, with a predictable plotline I was correctly forecasting as little as five minutes into the movie.(Yes, and I easily guessed the "surprise twist ending" everyone is raving about.  Yawn.  You want a REAL surprise twist ending, go watch "Sixth Sense" or "Unbreakable.")Last but not least, I find it interesting that Heston's character was likeable precisely because he WAS such a crusty cynical old b*****d. Wahlberg's "brash hotshot pilot" persona conforms to almost every "hero" stereotype in the book...and, thus, is entirely bland and uninteresting, though I do not knock him as an actor.  I DO give the writer(s) full credit for not going the obvious route with the annoyingly "perfect leggy blonde" potential love interest, but other than that...well, not much I can say.In short: rent the original and pretend you don't know the ending.  You'll get your money's worth.

title: sticking with the theme and style of the original films
text: I am a big fan of the original films and I enjoyed this one just as much, if not more. It is the perfect balance of sticking with the style of the original films and branching off as its own film. I enjoyed it very much. The special effects are great. Marc Walburg to a great job, as did the rest of the cast.

title: Pedestrian Planet of the Apes
text: As one who reveres the 1968 original, I admit to approaching this "reconstruction" with some amount of skepticism, but I was determined to go in with an open mind.  I tried to like it but in the end I'd have to deem this attempt at a new "Apes" as a disappointment.Sure, Tim Burton's masterful visual style and Danny Elfman's evocative musical scoring are in full effect as always, but in service to a mediocre script that plays like a typical action movie.  The pointed social commentary of the original film, released at the height of the civil rights movement and the Vietnam War is not quite as effective here.Sure, there's also a couple of plot twists that rival the final revelation of the original.  A couple of classic lines from the original are cleverly worked in, and Charlton Heston, who carried the first picture and made us believe in the story, this time plays an ape. Nice touch!But the bottom line is, there's nothing new here to justify the time and expense of this film.  I expected more from Tim Burton!

title: Not to bad for a remake!!!
text: Well well, very impress about that remake, I mean I am sick ofthose old show and movies that they remake, no more inspirationor what?  But that remake was good.  I loved the costume over all,they were fantastic, they play of Tim Roth as the mean Ape was thetop, I would like him to get the award for the mean bad guyhehehe!  No but he was great.  The action scenes were alsoamazing...  I must say that I am not crazy about Estella Warren as aactress, but she might get better, I was a little disappointed to seea nice cast like that and having her for one of the major character... but it was ok...  I tried to watch it as if it was not the remake, and itworked, maybe that is why I liked it more than some people I know. Anyway it is a very nice movie to see...  enjoy it!

title: Not as bad as often said, however not as great as the original!
text: Boy, I went with the greatest expectations to the cinema, because I´m a huge fan of Franklin J. Schaffner´s unique Sci-fi classic! And yes, there are three plausible reasons to watch this film:1) Estella Warren is damn hot!2) Tim Roth is giving another over the top-performance!!3) The make-up F/X of Rick Baker are really outstanding!!!But...This is a typical Hollywood mainstream production! The end is a cliché and the snappish satire from the brilliant original is totally missing! Instead of it you`re getting a breathtaking, but finally also very empty popcorn movie, enriched with some pseudo-moral..! Actors like Helena Bonham Carter, Michael Clarke Duncan or Paul Giamatti are doing solid jobs, but the excellent Roddy McDowall, who played Cornelius/Cesar, can´t be replaced be anyone!! Not a bad film at all, but definitely not as great as the original!!!

title: Marky Mark and the Monkey Bunch
text:
It's hard to be objective with this new vision of Planet of the Apes, as the overwhelming desire to compare it with the 1968 original is almost too much to bear for any would-be movie critic with too much time on their hands. However, a word of caution  they are two very different movies.  The original, with its world-weary Heston, moralising anti-nuke plot and the gee-shucks-can't-we-all-just-get-along narrative, plays out like one of the better episodes of Star Trek.  Tim Burton's take on the simian planet is a million miles away (literally) from the Franklin J. Schaffner version, and so we have the action and the hokey chimptalk, but none of the social relevance.  This, quite frankly, damns the film, damns it all to hell and makes it yet another summer blockbuster of running about and shooting at nasty things.However, considered out of the context of the whole Apes saga, this is a damn fine no-brainer popcorn-flick with plenty of action, plot twists, rugged heroes and monkey madness.  Helena Bonham Carter makes a decent chimp, Tim Roth makes a decent psycho-baddie and Mark Wahlberg makes a decent, well, underwear model.  There is enough to keep your average film junkie happy and the movie does not outstay its welcome.
Hollow, but entertaining nonetheless, Planet of the Apes (2001) is not a bad film and is only disappointing when compared with a) the original b) Tim Burton's back catalogue.  It's also a damn sight better than the four sequels and the TV spin-offs.  Come to think of it, The Simpson's Planet of the Apes Musical may not be such a bad idea after all...

title: See it for the Apes
text: I really enjoyed The Planet of The Apes, if for nothing more than the dark and brilliant world created by Tim Burton. Every frame is packed with so much detail and so much action you won't want to blink. What Burton paints with images, Danny Elfman matches with sound, with yet another excellent score. But it's clear from the get-go that the real stars here are the apes who look and move so wonderfully realistically, you'll forget that they're not. The makeup is so good in The Planet of The Apes, it's hard to see the actor behind the mask. But this seems more an asset than a liability for the ape actors who all put in very strong performances. Unfortunately the 'human' actors are another story: Mark Wahlberg is clearly out of his league and depth here and really struggles to carry the lead. There's a scene where Wahlberg tries to rally the troops and he was so bad, it's funny. Estella Warren looks great but does very little in a role that is really not much more than window dressing.As with many visually stunning films, more care and attention was paid to the look of The Planet of The Apes than the script, so we're asked to make some pretty big leaps of faith. The Planet of The Apes it's definitely NOT a movie to think a lot about when you leave the theater, as many plot points don't hold up well on re-examination. That said, I recommend The Planet of The Apes; it's a very enjoyable movie with a look you won't soon forget!

title: Great special effects
text: The original film was outstanding. Thirty years ago, the plot of apes taking over the earth was shocking and very creative in its concept. Now, over the years, we've seen just about every kind of creature appear on the earth. The main character here didn't have the eloquence of Charlton Heston. The end of the film was confusing since he returns back in time to earth, but finds that it was being run by apes. Also, the script deviated from the original one. Aside from the rather slow, confusing plot, the make-up for the apes was outstanding. The scenery was bare, twisted, dark and sinister. The actors who played the apes walked bent or ran on all fours. I think it was good for the action scenes which were not overly violent or bloody. It would be a good family film for children over 10 years of age.

title: 2001 - Year when Tim lost his talent
text: It's amazing, and even scary, when guy like Burton turn into garbage- maker. People said, that Planet of the Apes is shallow. Well, of course it is! But adventure movie, even at best are shallow. Indiana Jones is not very deep, but as example of movie art is sophisticated, and extremely well made. That's the difference: Planet of the Apes is a failure not because of weak background (AKA: The meaning of..., the philosophy etc.), but of the weak first plan.We can see, how black-hole open between script and execution, we've got characters without character, like Estella and Kris, we've got hero without one single good moment in entire movie. I mean, really Mark..."Why are you helping me?" - asked Mark. "Because you are special" answered Ari (Helena B-C). No Helena, he is not...What else can I say? This predictable movie is boring, stupid and unconvincingly. After 40 minutes I wish that some better race punish stupidity of humans and apes, but it never happened.At least I must say, that Planet of the Apes is a lot better that recently garbage of Burton-rotten-chocolate-factory. But that means nothing.

title: Too many flaws
text: Planet of the Apes has some major flaws to get over, and despite a solid final 30 minutes, the film has some problems.  Mark Wahlberg comes off as a cocky punk, and his acting is so wooden and one-dimensional, you wonder what they were thinking when they cast him.  The tendency is for Hollywood to cover all the bases, so you get your generic supermodel, mouthy 12 year old boy, cute little girl, and so on.  Roth was fine, but overall the script was nothing special, the battle scenes were uneven, and the preachy subtext about racism/animal rights was as subtle as a hammer on the head.   There were some entertaining moments, but add this movie to a long list in the past few years as case studies for "What's wrong with Hollywood" or "How to Monkey up a good idea" or even "Why must Hollywood always Ape old classic movies?".

title: Go Bananas! Go Ape! Just go see this movie!!
text: First up. I don't think this is as good as Burton's other work. Edward Scissorhands has been his best so far- I think because it was his concept, it was so bizarre and yet he made a boy with Scissorhands the most emotionally engaging story I have ever seen. As the critics said "beauty told in simplicity".Planet of the Apes (POTA) is very distinctive from the opening credits as a Burton film. There are elements of 2001: A Space Odyssey and other little movie references to be found throughout the film. Wahlberg is ideal as the Taylor/Leo character. As an actor he can't go as far as some others but the role is suitable for him. The supporting cast are excellent as apes/chimps/gorillas- the whole bag of bananas. While some will see their antics and comments as corny or cliche, keep in mind this is Burton's own vision (reimagining- that itself is now a cliche!) of Boulle's original novel "Monkey Planet".The social comments are very clever and will have you chuckling at certain points. Look out for a classic moment where Burton's partner Lisa Marie performs an exotic ape dance for her man, err ape, err orangutang. The make up is amazing and the set design of Ape City is very stylish. The only quarm I have with it, is it comes across as more like "Ape Housing Commission" because it seems so small or claustrophobic.The story is strong, but missing certain power in some parts- however where one element weakens, Burton knows how to fill the screen with something else to take your attention away. I have no doubt in saying Rick's makeup will score him a 2002 Oscar at the Mann Chinese Theatre, not to mention a few others possibly for other areas....And the ending. Oh, the ending. Many will not like the ending, but many will be very intrigued. I thought the ending was unreal- totally Burton!I definately reccomend you go see this film. It is one of the better films of the year. It is not Burton's best, and in a way he has slipped. But we are talking about Burton here, so rest assured he will quickly pick himself back up and create something BRILLIANT again! I'd give it 7 out of 10 bananas.

title: Marky Mark can't carry this flick
text:
Just saw this over the weekend. It's bad. Not bad meaning good either, OK? Mark Wahlberg is expected to be the hero, but he can't keep this dog alive. Nice costuming, effects are OK (but what's up with that upside-down fishbowl Wahlberg puts on his head when he takes off in the pod?).
The dialog is pathetic. Estella Warren has what, 8 lines through the whole thing? The comic relief was lame. The best (unintentional) comic relief was when the commander tells Wahlberg, "No more arguments, your monkey launches at 16:30!." There was inappropriate laughter at other dialogue as well.Just overall quite lame, you can wait for it to come on HBO or Cinemax.

title: Great special effects... Painfully bad script and plot.
text: I went to this movie with real anticipation considering the great cast, Tim Burton at the helm and thoughts of the classic 1968 original.Anticipation is the only thing this movie offers.  It's awful!  If they had let me in for free, I would have asked for my "walking in back."The makeup was amazingly good, but 20 minutes into the movie, the great special effects could not make up for what was painfully obvious.  The plot and script were just downright laughable!This is a "see jane run" script and plot nearly all the way.  Really, it's that bad.  No... on second thought, it's worse.

title: Great flick, confusing ending.
text: I just got home from seeing this movie. I went in not expecting much, but boy did I get a surprise. This movie very definitely does the original justice, and then some. Though the movie was at times predictable, the story was rather original and very entertaining. Throw in Estella Warren in a loincloth, and we have a winner. :-) I enjoyed it right up until the end, then they lost me. I didn't get it. I'll probably spend the rest of the day trying to reconcile how the story got from point A to point B.

title: A missed opportunity but fairly enjoyable.
text: WARNING! PLOT POINTS REVEALED! Hmm, Tim Burton tries his hand at a remake - sorry, "re-imagining" - of the 1968 "classic". Inevitably, comparisons to the original abound, however, not having seen the original thankfully precludes me from such comparisons (though, yes, we all know it was the Earth. damn them).Burton's film is helped firstly by his imagination. The ape abodes and milieu are beautifully and naturally presented. The considerable advances in makeup technology allow more depth of character to be achieved when it comes to the citizens of the ape community, and the sheer variety of simian forms and facial expressions is itself impressive. The only quibble I would highlight is the "muffling" of the actor's voices and the obvious difficulty which they had speaking through the stuff, however this was not too distracting. Wahlberg meanwhile is a sound action hero, but provides little sympathy or interest for the viewer. Bonham Carter is well drawn as the radical humanist ape, but the "semi-romance" between her and Wahlberg seems half-hearted and therefore uninteresting. A rivalry between her and the ridiculously-costumed human love interest is just a waste of time, and the girl really serves no other purpose but eye candy and therefore becomes annoyingly superfluous to proceedings. Roth, however, is superb as General Thade, chewing scenery like nobody's business and delightfully hamming his way through revenge dialogue and lots of shouting and leaping about. His body movements too are by far the most excellently observed.Clearly Burton does not wish us to take the film too seriously, given the comic touches which he has added, which include a slightly farcical (and very predictable) lampoon of the Lincoln memorial. The ending, however, does indeed seem tacked-on - useful for interchangeability (he apparently filmed 4 different ones) but not so good for continuity. Considering Burton had a choice of endings, it would appear that he chose the least original, however, it is refreshingly surprising to find that the ending is not as upbeat as may have been expected from the more sentimental proceedings of the rest of the film. All round this is still a good watch, but you can't help thinking that there was far more potential in the material. Burton avoids re-hashing the political stance of the original, however the result is visually stunning and well imagined but with little beneath the surface. Roth steals the show and provides most of the interest throughout the film, and it's a shame that Wahlberg and Bonham Carter never get much to work with.

title: Not Burton's best, but...
text: The fight scenes are tremendous, and although the twist is not quite up there with the best (That honour goes to The Usual Suspects and The Shawshank Redemption), it does make you think. However, the film feels like Burton-lite, like MI2 was John Woo-lite, the apes have caged Burton here. The aesthetics show flashes of his sensibility, but his gothic romantic style is virtually absent. Also, Mark Walberg and Helena Bonham Carter  are poor and miscast.However, Tim Roth and Michael Clarke Duncan are superb, with a true apish spirit. And whoever says there's not going to be a sequel is either lying or is forgetting what has happened before ("It's not a sequel, it's a continuation!")

title: It is a Love/Hate Barrel of Monkeys!... I mean Apes...
text: It seems to be a trend this particular year that there is alot of movies hitting the big screen that are either loved or hated and sometimes lack a satisfying ending. In this regards "Planet of the Apes" 2001 is no different, however once again Tim Burton reminds us how wide the imagination can spread.If your like me and are generally unsatisfied with the tripe peddled to the masses in modern day supermarket cinemas then you'll understand my pleasure when a Tim Burton movie comes out. He does things just that extra bit different to most film makers that sets his films apart and makes them a refreshing experience. The first feeling I had when leaving the cinema was "I need to see that again". Partly because of an unusual problem with the ending, and partly because Burton's "Apes" was an absolute riot.I want to get the plot issues out of the way first; the film is not different in plot to the original in 1968. He arrives, he is captured, he escapes, and there is conflict about the origins of Apes and then a twist ending. No surprises here. This version of the story holds together really well. That is up until the conflict sequences towards the end. Sometimes I wonder if they change writers in these films but the person who thought hard about the script suddenly stopped thinking about it and the movie seemed to suddenly lower a level or two. I am not saying it was poor, no not at all but not up to the same standard as the rest of the film up until that point. Although one must remember this is a film about Apes, and what Apes they are!These walking talking Apes are absolutely fantastic. Unlike the original they all look very different to each other and they actually act like Apes. If you have ever been to the Zoo and Watched the monkeys play you'll know what I mean. Tim Roth was absolutely outstanding and totally convincing as the evil Ape, I was completely in awe of how convincing his character and monkey suit was. Not only was the make-up outstanding but they also must of studied how Apes behave because they had the personalities and behaviour habits down to a fine art! Watching Them hang from the sealing, leap from tree to tree and go berserk was an absolute riot and I enjoyed every minute of it!The humans and the hero on the other hand are a slightly different story! They are obviously not the focus of the film so there are no strong performances, certainly they do not get much screen time. As for Mark Whalberg as Leo he is probably the first true to life hero. There is absolutely nothing special about his character and in the end he does nothing special either except give hope to the humans on this upside down world. He is not an over the top action hero, he is more of a "nineties man" with no special traits except his inability to accept Ape control. But we all would object I believe. This is what I liked about Leo, he was ordinary and even when he was trying to motivate the humans at the end no one fell into the trap of an over the top inspirational speech. he sounded like you or I would making it up on the spot. Tim Burton once again gives us a different spin on an old icon.Finally we come to the very end and probably the main point of confusion for everyone. No matter what your theory is I think we all need the script writers to come forth and "please explain!". I did like the ending but originally it did confuse me and there are so many conflicting facts in the story that prevent most logical conclusions that my mind was going to explode. All the same I implore you not to let this be a deterrent as the film in totality is a marvellous experience.I don't want to give this movie a rating because it is again definitely one of those films, which you will either love or hate. These kinds of films generally cause discussions of great length and analysis and no one will ever agree particularly on a theory for the end of this one. However I certainly loved the film and believe it was worth the price of the admission. The best thing to do is go and see it for yourself, making up your own mind is the most satisfying thing about it all.

title: I have to say it. Tim Burton's retelling of Planet...
text:
I have to say it. Tim Burton's retelling of Planet of the Apes is more fun than a barrel of monkeys.OK, that's off my chest. No more monkey puns, I promise.Seriously, though, Planet of the Apes is one rip-roarin' summer outing, filled with thrills, action, adventure, wit and bits of funny (dare I say, monkey) business. I know, I know, I promised.And for those film buffs who are fond of the original, Burton's version includes a couple tips of the hat to that movie.Mark Wahlberg stars as Capt. Leo Davidson, a deep-space pilot whose ship gets drawn into a magnetic field and hurled into the future. He crash lands on a planet where apes are the dominant species and humans are hunted, captured and sold into slavery.Despite being darker than the original, Burton's film is not as heavy handed nor as sanctimonious.Some of the movie's flashes of humor are surreal as well as typically Burton: An organ-grinder ape with a midget or an elderly ape taking off a wig and removing false teeth as he prepares for bed. Then there are the parents who buy a little girl as a pet for there young daughter. The seller advises the parents to get rid of the girl before she reaches puberty: "One thing you don't want in your house is a human teen-ager," he says. You don't have to be an ape to realize the truth in that statement. Touches such as these are what stamps this movie with Burton's brand.Lines that hearken back to the original movie are sprinkled throughout: The first words spoken by an ape to Davidson as the astronaut is regaining consciousness and grabs the simian's foot to try righting himself are: "Take your stinking hand off of me, you damned, dirty human." Anyone familiar with the first version of the film will, of course, recognize the irony in that piece of dialogue.Another of Burton's in-jokes is to have Charlton Heston, star of the original, play the chimpanzee father of Tim Roth's Gen. Thade. The young chimp goes to visit his dying father. Both have one thing in common, a hatred of humans. With his dying breath, the elder spews out his vile: "Damn them, damn them all to hell," he says before expiring. That is the famous line Heston's Taylor shouted at the conclusion of the original after discovering the planet's terrible secret.The performances throughout are top-notch. Wahlberg plays Davidson not as some gung-ho hero, but as a confused and somewhat frightened explorer who only wants to return home. He is reluctant to lead the human rebellion; his only objective being to find a way off this upside-down planet. This hesitation is what makes his character believable and vulnerable.Roth is ferocious, cunning, cruel and savage as the fascist chimp who wants to rid his planet of all vestiges of humanity. He leaps and bounds as if he had springs on his feet. It is a masterful turn.Helena Bonham Carter is Ari, the chimp who believes that apes and humans can live in peace and as equals. Hers is a smart, compassionate characterization.Michael Clarke Duncan is big and brutal as Attar the gorilla aid to Thade who blindly follows his leader until his faith is shaken.
A fine comic outing is given by Paul Giamatti as Limbo, the ape slave trader making a living off the misery of the humans he captures. As the battle between apes and humans looms, the cowardly Limbo pleads, "Can't we all just get along," echoing the words of Rodney King.Much of the success of Planet of the Apes goes to Burton's technical crew, especially production designer Rick Heinrichs and the legendary Rick Baker who created the ape makeup.Burton's musical collaborator, Danny Elfman, provides another fine score, though it is not as memorable as his work on Batman or Sleepy Hollow.The movie's only letdown comes at the very end where Burton tries to outshock the finale from the 1968 original. He comes close, but falls short.Otherwise, Planet of the Apes is what a summer movie should be: An amusement park ride filled with lots of action, stunts and a few laughs. This is one feature in which the expectations lived up to the pre-release hype.

title: Too Many Questions Arise From Movie.
text: The beginning of the movie really sets up the rest of the movie; "Marky" Mark is not going to be acting in this movie.This movie left me me with too many questions.1) If the Planet was uninhabited when "The Oberon" crashed landed there, and the apes and the humans were the only ones on board, where did the horses come from?2) Why isn't Captain Leo surprised to find out everyone speaks English?3) What was the point of Kris Kristofferson being in this movie?4) What kind of an ending was that?5) Why should I really care?If you see this movie for any reason, go see it for Tim Roth and Pau; Giamatti.Two opposable thumbs down.

title: It's science fiction people
text: I'm tired of reading comments that state the ending is 'unrealistic' or 'implausible' or 'it doesn't make sense'. It's make believe. Things can be made up. Does everything have to be spoonfed to this lazy american society? Talking computers did not exist in the early 70's. So maybe Kubrick's film 2001 should have not included them. That's silly. If Burton wanted to warp time back and forth then more power to him. It's FICTION you can make things up.

title: Far from top banana
text: Tim Burton's remake of "Planet of the Apes" is pretty silly. He has"re-imagined" the story by removing all of the heavy implicationsand morals of the original, and replacing them with special effectsand corny satire, interspersed with brief, undeveloped fragmentsof theme. Burton is more concerned with the look of the Ape planetand their inhabitants than what they do - and the result is rathershallow. Out the window goes the science-fiction intrigue of theoriginal, in comes a surprise ending... and by "surprise," I, ofcourse, mean "confusing." Burton has essentially done nothingmore than dumb down the classic and make it look better. Whichhe certainly does - the settings, costumes, and make-up work is,as always, spectacular. Like "Batman" and "Sleepy Hollow," Burtoncan flawlessly create a world more sinister and eerily realistic thanany original could imagine. While the first "Planet of the Apes"featured humanoid people in cheesy ape-masks walking arounduninteresting terrain, this version has exponentially morebelievable apes that climb trees, build ape cities, walk with aape-like shuffle, leap high in the air, and fight amazinghand-to-hand combat battle. The misty swamps and torch-litforested ape-towns are brilliantly created. The acting is not aproblem, Helena Bonham Carter and Tim Roth are good in theirroles, while Mark Wahlburg is given nothing more to do than flexhis muscles and run around. But, unfortunately, "Planet of theApes" has always been about more than just men running awayfrom violent simians. Burton's plot just doesn't cut it - it's hard toignore the holes in the logic and the ending seems mindlesslyrandom. Other distractions - such as a painfully bad three-way lovetriangle between Wahlburg, his female ape savior, and a femalehuman slave - further take away from anything meaningful onemay try to take away from the film. Overall, like most Burton, it looksgood but doesn't quite satisfy.

title: Witty , Wry , and Wonderfully Warped
text: Hilariously funny and lots of tongue in cheek humor kept me entertained at this movie on a sweltering hot and humid afternoon. My 9 year old and my 16 year old loved the action which there was a lot of and the 16 year old was fascinated by the time travel possibilities and the wry view of evolutionary possibilities . I especially got a kick out of the "religious" overtones. Overall , it was witty and wry and wonderfully warped . I loved it.

title: It's actually pretty good - give it a go
text: I was dreading it, but contrary to most of the commentators, I rather liked Burton's remake. I was expecting the worst (especially since I  had originally heard that Arnie was to star) but I was pleasantly surprised. Remaking such an icon is a big ask at the best of times, and Burton does his best, bringing  his typical dark edge to the film, but he apparently had to battle the studio every inch of the way, and the interference shows in the lack of overall cohesion.That being said, the film has many great aspects. Danny Elfman, as always, excels with his score, and the opening title music is superb (turn it up LOUD!); this is no mean feat since the POTA1 score by the great Jerry Goldsmith is one of THE great film scores.If for no other reason, this film is worth seeing for Tim Roth's bravura performance. He steals the picture as the ape general, Thade, imbuing the character (and the excellent makeup) with a performance of such mailicious psycopathy that he'd have undoubtedly been nominated for an Oscar it he had been playing a character in a gangster film.Mark Wahlberg is a likeable screen presence and getting better, though hardly a 'great' actor, but with talent like Roth and Bonham Carter alongside him, even in the ape makeup they tend to dominate. He's a somewhat stolid performer and as noted elsewhere, he pretty much plays the angry-intense thing most of the time, but that's basically all he has to do here, and the real stars are the apes anyway.Design, makeup and SFX are great, much lusher and more detailed than the rather spartan California look of the original. Some people were obviously very disappointed by the ending, and there's no way even Burton could have topped the original in that respect. There's a lot of humour too, and some very funny references to the original (Chuck Heston's uncredited cameo is great).No, it's not the greatest sci-fi film ever made, and no, it's obviously not even the film Tim Burton wanted to make, but in spite of all the fiddling and the disappointing aspects, it's still a diverting and often entertaining watch. I've certainly seen MUCH worse.

title: A parody? A social satire? A darn fine movie!
text: I saw this recently at a preview show in Japan and I have to say that, despite being an affectionardo of the first series of films, this one rocks!The special effects are what you expect these days, special, and the make up is a true work of art (it's really difficult to tell who's who, though I think the main guy might be Mark Whalberg under all that stuff.) and the writing is crisp, if obvious.A special mention has to go to Tim Roth here, because he pulls off one of the most original, deeply motivated, frightening villains I've seen for a long time and manages to sound nothing like himself. If this were an eighteen film it'd be Silence of the Apes! He won't, but should be up for an oscar.And for effectionardo's off the first movie and it's glorious ending, don't panic. I have to say that (despite the improbability of it) the writers have managed to come up with a nice play on the original.I have to say that of all the summers movies so far this is the one I'd want to see again, and while Tim Burton can't resist getting cheezy for a moment or two with us throughout the movie, it won't make you gag as much as most of his others.Go, enjoy, ape it up.

title: Nothing but eye-candy - looks good but leaves you empty...
text: I watched this movie and thought, "ummmm... mediocre".  The plot was completely un-original.  The acting was atrocious.  It sorta looked nice and had a mildly unexpected ending.Then I watched the original Planet of the Apes... AND - I - WAS - OUTRAGED!!!Planet of the apes is an incredibly original story.  It has depth and meaning, good acting and an incredibly clever and original story line.  To use the same name to sell this... this monstrocity deserves a lawsuit!Only get this movie to show off your new DVD player because it is nothing but visual fluff.  And only get it if it's in the bargain bin.  Better yet, if you are that desperate to show off your DVD player, use Monsters Inc, or Star Wars, or Debbie does Dallas instead.

title: Apes: Sold out....
text: I think I should have realized that the 7:45 showing of Planet of the Apes selling out was a veiled premonition not to watch this movie. But my chakras were unaligned and I stuck around anyway for the 8:25 show. The plot goes like this. The year is 2029. American astronauts are testing chimpanzees as pilots on a space station. After losing a prized chimp in an electric windstorm, Leo, played by Mark Wahlberg tries to rescue him. The electric windstorm also acts as a time warp and transports Leo into the future onto a planet where Apes are evolutionary superior to humans.What has it been about Tim Burton's recent movies that have just left a bad taste in my mouth? Sleepy Hollow was bearable but certainly not up to par with Burton's earlier work. Call me nostalgic, but I think back to the days of Batman and Beetlejuice and I see genius. I watch Planet of the Apes and I think sellout...I went to this movie with no real expectations. Admittedly, I was suspicious of all the hype this movie was getting but I was interested to see it, soley because Burton directed it. Where do I begin? I was disappointed with the acting. Mark Wahlberg played his lead role of astronaut turned hero with complete stoicism but no human depth. Estella Warren was there purely for eyecandy; if she is capable of acting, she wasn't given the chance. Even Tim Roth and Helena Bonham Carter, well established thespians, were held back with a dry, clicheed script. Of course the special effects and set were amazing...blah, blah, blah. But Burton doesn't usually forego story for effects. His effects from earlier years have been just as impressive even with a smaller budget. The set is supposed to add to the movie and storyline, not surpass it. Speaking of storyline, where was it? This movie didn't have one, or at least an original one. I know you're thinking it was just a remake...how could the story be original? If you're going to bother remaking a film, you should do it for a reason...to show a different viewpoint or take on it; go somewhere the first one could have but didn't. For example, the 1968 original was very philosophical and dealt with religious issues. It was kitsch for the time, but it also made you think. 2001's Apes seems to have bypassed all philisophical debate and just provided a limited plot, excellent makeup and set, set, set.  Thats basically all that this movie has to offer, which in my mind is not worth $9 and two hours of my time.

title: The original story re-imagined. Amazing!
text: When 'The Haunting' flopped at the box office while the ultra-low budget 'Blair Witch Project' became all the rage, it was a prime example of how the most sophisticated high-tech special effects don't guarantee a good remake of a classic movie (or, for that matter, any other movie). Consequently, I expected much the same when I heard of the 'Planet of the Apes' remake: today's advanced effects, prettier actors perhaps, and essentially expensive rehash. Tim Burton's version of the classic epic is a pleasant surprise. Sure enough, the movie does have dazzling special effects--the most impressive beyond a single doubt Rick Baker's ape makeup. And the actor's are, for the most part, new-millennium pretty (even some of the apes). But the story has also been completely and compellingly re-imagined and re-created. This is a new tale which has little in common with the original movie except that they are both based on Pierre Boulle's book--and that they are both excellent. The attention to (often hilarious) detail in Tim Burton's movie is delightful, and for those who remember the original 'Planet of the Apes' well enough, there are also a few pleasantly twisted nods to the classic to discover. The story moves along at a brisk pace and never fails to involve, making the movie seem shorter than it is, and the plot surprises in intelligent ways during the final part of the action. Another wonderful thing to observe is how well the makeup allows the actors behind it to bring their characters to life. While the masks in the original films were impressive, they allowed for little more than moving mouths and the occasional twitching nose. The masks in the new movie, on the other hand, accommodate a seemingly unlimited range of facial expressions. It takes more imagination to picture that there are human faces behind the makeup than it does to accept the simian characters as genuine. This new 'Planet of the Apes' is indeed not a remake, but an original movie based on the same novel that inspired the first one. A strong story, solid characters, AND amazing special effects, that's the stuff the 'suspense of disbelief' is made of. Let's just hope it won't suffer from the same sequel-itis as the original.

title: I'm not going to be able to look at a $5 bill or a penny the way again!
text: Marl Wahlberg plays a USAF astronaut on a space station. While going into space to find Pericles the Chimpanzee, he is transported via time ward to a dark and mysterious planet where simians are the masters and humans the slaves. Pericles the chimpanzee lands on this globe and is revered as a deity. The simians accept humans as their equals. Wahlberg is again caught in the same time warp , and reversed, only to find out the awful truth about The Planet of The Apes! Not as great as the first original, but definitely worth a go and see.

title: Don't think and you MIGHT enjoy this movie.
text: The entire movie lacked foundation.  I understand that it is fiction, but since we are having to accept talking apes, they could attempt to make something plausible. One easy way would be to change the date.  The movie starts in the distant future of 2029??  In 28 yrs we will have star trek like shuttle that can go in and out of orbit with a single stage and then travel across the solar system.  We will have a magnificent research center somewhere around saturn that has batteries that last thousands of years. I just can't wait to see what we will have before I am 50. The next big gripe is the uninhabited planet that has only apes and humans...and horses.  Where'd those horses come from?  While I appreciate the attempt to explain the source of the apes, it could have been much better.  How'd the apes rebel against the armed humans in the first place? I'm sure an ape can kick my butt, but I can blow it's head off with a gun. There are countless other problems with the movie that I don't feel like bringing up.  The movie was also slow for an action flick, two hours pass and you can count major moments on one hand. The final gripe is the ending which I won't "spoil" for anyone.  Try as hard as you want to defend it, but it makes absolutely no sense.  It was meant as a shocker, but the surprise came from how ridiculous it was.  People laughed in the theater where I was. Don't waste your money on this movie.  Maybe rent it, but I'd recommend waiting for it to be on a movie channel.

title: Burton goes bananas with an action-packed ape-fest...
text: If you go into this looking for Tim Burton's usual quirkiness, you may be disappointed: it takes a backseat to good ol' movie spectacle. This "Planet" is a full-on action/science fiction thriller that barely lets up.  It's funny, fast and loud; the special effects don't overpower the story, and Rick Baker's ape make-up is amazing - after a while you believe you're watching an advanced race of apes, rather than actors buried beneath layers of latex and fake fur.  The whole cast is very good, especially Helena Bonham Carter, whose performance as the ape-woman Ari is witty, sharp and sweet. Two things: Chuck Heston should retire from films after this, since I can't imagine a better exit than the one this movie gives him, and the film's final gag is funny, but doesn't really make sense (especially in light of the story we've just seen).  Other than that, though, big Hollywood summer popcorn flicks don't get much better than this.  Viva la Movies!

title: You should compare
text: You should compare this film with the original - those that crafted this were well aware of what went on in that film. Look at what they kept, look at what they omitted. Clearly, character development and dialogue were thrown out in favour of a frenetic, action-filled pace. While this might please an illiterate teenager, others will probably not be so satisfied. Could it be that this film was crafted by apes? I sense the lack of an opposable thumb in the screen writing process........

title: Tim Burton
text:
This movie is Tim Burton. There is no use comparing it to the original. Forget the original, for now.There is great special effects and a lot of humor around the edges.
You could tell this was a Burton movie.A few points. Wahlburg cannot fly, or at least cannot land well. The plot devices to set up the whole time line twist don't work. Don't even try to figure them out. Just watch the movie and enjoy the (over) acting.Wahlburg's character is an idiot. Roth's character is too overdone. Bonham-Carter was fun to watch.Tim Burton makes a great fantasy movie. Reality takes a back seat. Enjoy.

title: Different, but not an improvement.
text: I did what the author of a previous comment suggested and watched this film with an open mind and tried not to compare it with the original.  Compare it or not there was definitely something lacking in the story.  I won't spoil the origin of the apes for those who haven't seen the film but (and pardon me but I can't resist) even a monkey could figure it out and the ending while it does open the door for a whole new set of possible sequels is really disappointing and lacks the punch of the originals ending.  One high point however has to be the talents of the actors playing the apes, their not just actors in costume but really become the apes they are portraying and for an instant you do feel like they are really talking, civilized apes. Much less can be said about the actors portraying the human slaves, I liked it better in the original when they couldn't talk.  Director Burton was definitely trying to go somewhere different with this one but seemed to not really follow through with his ideas.  Out of a possible four stars, I give it ** 1/2.

title: Come on, people!
text: There are movies which invite deep thinking and reflection; there are movies that do not. This movie is of the latter type. Don't expect deep plot or social meaning--remember, it's just for fun! The original had pretensions of social commentary, while this version is obviously designed to be enjoyed. The effects are great, the script adequate and it is one of the few movies I've seen this summer that haven't left me feeling cheated. 8 out of 10 from this movieholic.

title: PLANET OF THE PLOTLESS, ANNOYING, UNENJOYABLE PIECE OF GARBAGE
text: I am growing so very tired of Hollywood and the junk that they have been putting out. This movie certainly was not worth my time or my money. The only thing good about this movie is Danny Elfman's theme and that's it. The make up effects are down right horrible as well as the acting and what little of a screenplay there is is absolutely disgraceful. The ending, which I will not give away so not to ruin it for the poor souls who are still considering seeing this piece of garbage is absolutely pointless and adds nothing to the movie. In fact the ending makes absolutely no sense and feels as though it was a last minute ending that was added on a week before the movie was released. This movie will also be very offensive to a certain minority group. A lot of what I guess Hollywood executives think are funny little inside jokes are actually extrmely racist and serve no purpose in a film like this. Yes the Planet Of The Apes films have always reflected the racial tensions in this country but they certainly never made a joke of it.I think it is time for Richard Zanuck to retire being he hasn't made a good film since Jaws and Tim Burton should stick to making films like Ed Wood which showcased a lot more of his talent than this piece of garbage.

title: Warmed-up or half-baked?
text:
Like many others, I rather admire Tim Burton's artistic spin-outs, although for every BATMAN there is a MARS ATTACKS, and for every EDWARD SCISSORHANDS a  SLEEPY HOLLOW. He had NO RIGHT however messing with PLANET OF THE APES, a great film that was majorly under-valued critically (NOT at the box-office) even on its release in 1968. "Are things so bad that BEN-HUR has to start mixing it with Gorillas?" proclaimed one dumb-ass reviewer! Wonder what he would have written about this?Well guys for whats its worth, here's my assessment! In a word, INSULTING to the original! (and to anyone in the audience of moderate intelligence.) Obviously  geared towards two distinctly identifiable social groups: those who have never seen the original series and today's (for the most part) attention-deficient audiences, who just want some one-dimensional entertainment to accompany their popcorn (or ecstasy tablet). Burton is selling himself short here - he is worth more than that.
PLANET OF THE APES (2001) is not categorically a turkey, the special effects are excellent, although the incessant use of digitizing becomes wearisome eventually. What IS wrong with it is loopy Wahlberg as an intergalactic Captain....I mean could you take this guy seriously? Would YOU rather fly to Alpha Centauri with Chuck Heston at the controls or under the direction of some guy who flashes his "jewels" while boogeying?  Aimed at a "youthful," marketable audience, sure he's your man, but in the interests of credibility, Wahlberg is a 10-1 longshot! The film suffers from ludicrously unstable continuity with a script to match - it is sheerly a visual extravaganza. Obviously in an attempt to play down the social and paradoxical issues of the original (coz you might have to actually THINK!) Burton has gone for noise and movement.The marvellous ending of the 1968 film (probably only ever equalled in power by THE USUAL SUSPECTS) is replaced by an obviously tacked-on "lets not worry how to explain this - anything to leave us a sequel" finale.  In the upshot, not the embarrassment Gus Van Sant's PSYCHO was, but totally unnecessary and totally unsatisfying!

title: A Good Popcorn Flick
text: First off let me just say that because of the endless negative reviews I have been reading for the last couple of weeks I went to see tim Burton's "Planet Of The Apes" with my expectations lowered. So I was naturally very pleased to have my expectations surpassed by this film. I will say this right off the bat, POTA 2001 is inferior to the original, but who really expected it to be better than that one? Anyway, the film gets off to a great start and continues that way for about the first hour. First we get the basic story setup and the introduction of our hero (a perpetually indifferent Mark Wahlberg) but it doesn't take long for the primates (the real stars of the show) to show up and the action to get going. I can't go any further without mentioning Rick Baker's ape makeup-it's absolutely stunning, as are the actors behind the prosthetics. Tim Roth sneers and growls as Thade, the general with a serious chip on his shoulder. I would actually tense up when this guy would walk onto the screen-I think he reminded me of my dad who, like Thade, was always on edge with his temper. To balance that out is the always lovely and charming Helena Bonham Carter as a "human rights activist" (snicker) ape who takes a fancy to Wahlberg's Leo. She is all at once elegant, charming, sympathetic and, inspite of her being a primate, totally sexy! I know the gorgeous Estella Warren makes her film debut here (notice i didn't say "acting debut"-she only says about 5 lines!), but when the 2 were on screen together I would always follow Helena Bonham Carter. Yes I was attracted to an ape. For that Carter deserves an Academy Award. Period. Also on board among others are Michael Clark Duncan as a rather intimidating gorilla and the always reliable Paul Giamatti as a slave trader. Anyway, I am rambling-let me get down to the meat of the review. Other merits of the film include fantastic set design and cinematograpy as well as Danny Elfman's thrilling score.
